title: Kinematic Analysis of a 3-RPS Parallel Mechanism for Passive Rehabilitation of Sports-Related Ankle Sprains
authors: Dario Gonzalez-Dancourt, Jaime Huaytalla-Pariona, Piero Calderon-Mendez, Deyby Huamanchahua
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Ankle sprains are common among athletes, especially in ball sports, and often require targeted rehabilitation to restore joint mobility. This article presents the design and evaluation of a 3-RPS type parallel mechanism developed for the passive rehabilitation of lateral ankle sprains. The system replicates natural ankle movements using inverse kinematic models based on geometric methods and screw theory. To solve the forward kinematics, three numerical strategies were tested: gradient descent, gradient descent with momentum, and Newton-Raphson, with the latter being the most efficient. Workspace analysis confirmed that the mechanism covers the physiological ranges for dorsiflexion-plantarflexion (30° to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-20^{\circ})$</tex> and eversion-inversion (20° to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-10^{\circ})$</tex>, with vertical displacements ranging from 0.2044 m to 0.3046 m. Both positional and orientational workspaces were analyzed to ensure complete therapeutic coverage. A singularity analysis identified twelve critical configurations, all of which are outside the effective operating range. Structurally, the device is compact and lightweight <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\leq 3.5 ~\text{kg})$</tex>, ensuring portability and ease of use in clinical and sports environments. Its precision, stability, and ability to generate controlled, repeatable ankle movements make it a valuable tool for early-stage rehabilitation, promoting functional recovery in injured athletes.

title: The Design and Debugging of the High-Frequency Low-Level System of PREF Synchrotron
authors: Wang Zhang, Xu Zhe, Chenjian Biao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The Proton Radiation Effects Facility (PREF) is a miniaturized proton accelerator built by the Institute of Modern Physics of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. It includes linear accelerators and small synchrotrons. The synchrotron high-frequency system is composed of a digital low-level system, solid-state power source, and magnetic alloy loading cavity. The entire system operates in sweep mode, with a sweep frequency range of 0.38 MHz to 6.5 MHz and a maximum voltage of 1 kV, thus ensuring that the PREF unit can output a proton beam with a maximum energy of 60 MeV. Considering the system requirements, cost, and existing development experience, the hardware framework based on the CPCI bus architecture is adopted in the low-level of the system. It uses 14-bit high-speed ADCs, 16-bit high-speed DACs, and Virtex-5 series FPGAs as the core high-speed processing units. The system communicates with blade computer controllers via a CPCI high-speed backplane bus to achieve system data delivery and real-time upload of operational data. At the same time, to solve the problem of uneven ADC sampling passband frequency response in extremely wide bands, a nonlinear correction is designed in the closed loop, and the response is calibrated online according to the real-time frequency, ensuring the amplitude control accuracy of the system. Through system testing, the phase control accuracy is better than ±1°, and the amplitude control accuracy is better than ±1<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>, meeting the requirements of the system design and operational index. The device has been installed online, meets the requirements for beam tuning, and is running.

title: Exploring Generative AI: Insights from Educators and Students on Accuracy Reliability and Conciseness
authors: Anil Khurana, V. V. Ravi Kumar, Chandra Prakash Gupta
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a cutting-edge technology also referred as Generative AI. Artificial Intelligence (AI) has rapidly made inroads in diverse areas and AI adoption in academia was inevitable. The responses were natural humanlike, and was quickly adopted. The responses produced were from a large database. AI may be a transformative tool for academic however, its limitations-such as outdated data, potential biases, and inaccuracies is possible. This study adopts a quantitative approach using surveys with educators across disciplines and experience levels, and students as respondents. The instrument comprised of Likert scale to examine AI generated content characteristics - accurate, reliable and conciseness. The study employed SPSS for analysis. The findings suggest that the two groups were not homogenous. While the AI usage has its merits; the limitations cannot be overlooked. AI generated output may require more investigation.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Decision Trees, Random Forests, and XGBoost for Enhanced Crop Recommendation
authors: Rachna Rathore, Avdesh Arha, Nagendar Yamsani, Richa Sharma, Preeti Jangra, Madhuri Sharma
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Agriculture is crucial to meeting food demand, and crop choices must improve productivity and sustainability. Machine Learning (ML) algorithms have been useful in this setting for recommending crops. This research analyses the current state of the art in crop recommender systems and how they might be improved via the use of ML methods. Effectively predicting what crops would thrive in a given environment is now possible using ML algorithms. Each model's strengths and drawbacks are highlighted in the comparative study, shedding light on how well or poorly they perform in crop recommendation tasks. Decision trees, random forests, and XGBoost are just a few examples of the prominent ML models used in crop recommendation systems. These models factor in a wide range of environmental and soil-related characteristics to determine which crops would thrive in a particular setting.

title: Fair Resource Allocation in C-V2X Networks: A Reinforcement Learning Approach for Perception Message Dissemination
authors: Xin Xu, Jingxiang Hao, Yifeng Xiao, Qiang Xue, Enshu Wang, Bingyi Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: Multi-agent collaborative perception enables agents to share complementary information through communication, thus significantly improving sensing performance. In pursuit of effective collaboration, intelligent connected vehicles (ICVs) must exchange massive volumes of perception messages, the transmission of which demands substantial communication resources. However, many researches concentrates on resource allocation for simple messages, overlooking the substantial resource requirements of perception messages, thus failing to guarantee quality of service (QoS) in such scenarios. We treat each ICV as an agent and design a cooperative multi agent fair reinforcement learning (CMAFRL) framework for learning the efficient and fair resource allocation policy for each agent. Specifically, to avoid mutual interference among different vehicles during the transmission process, we leverage the heterogeneous-agent proximal policy optimization algorithm to generate cooperative resource allocation policies for ICVs. As ICVs compete intensely for resources to transmit perception messages, the framework optimizes a fairness utility function and ensures equitable communication opportunities for all ICVs. We establish a V2V communication simulator to evaluate CMAFRL's performance. The results show that CMAFRL significantly outperforms all baselines.

title: Design of a Multi-Frequency Slot Microstrip Antenna with a Loaded Defected Ground Structure
authors: Mao Pengrong, Wang Jing, Gao Canguan, Shi Yang, Wang Yantong, Liu Hang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: To meet the growing demand for wireless communication systems, a design scheme for a multi-frequency slot microstrip antenna based on a defected ground structure is proposed. The microstrip antenna uses a rectangular radiating patch as its initial structure, after which symmetric U-shaped slots and rectangular groove slots are etched on its surface, while an H-shaped defected ground structure is loaded on the ground plane. By adjusting the positions and sizes of the U-shaped slots, rectangular groove slots, and the H-shaped slot, the distribution of radiating current on the antenna surface is altered, achieving multi-frequency resonance of the microstrip antenna. Simulation results indicate that the antenna can resonate simultaneously in four frequency bands: 2.39-2.42 GHz, 3.14-3.17 GHz, 4.56-4.62 GHz, and 5.36-5.44 GHz, with good directivity at the center frequency of each band. The physical antenna was tested using a vector network analyzer, and the return loss was found to be less than -10 dB at 2.33 GHz, 3.13 GHz, 4.67 GHz, and 5.47 GHz. The test results are basically in agreement with the simulation results. The antenna features a simple structure that is easy to fabricate, making it a useful reference for the design of multi-frequency antennas in wireless communication terminals.

title: A Multiterminal Setup for Complex Dynamics Characterization and Unconventional Computing in Self-Organizing Memristive Networks
authors: Davide Pilati, Fabio Michieletti, Alessandro Cultrera, Carlo Ricciardi, Gianluca Milano
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The recent growing interest in neuromorphic architectures based on emergent dynamics of self-organizing memristive networks has posed some challenges regarding the spatiotemporal characterization of these multiterminal systems. This work presents a versatile measurement platform specifically designed for the characterization of memristive nanowire networks and for testing the implementation of unconventional computing paradigms in these systems. By integrating an FPGA controlled, parallel multiterminal array of source-measure units with a custom fixture based on spring-loaded electrodes, the system allows for real-time, reconfigurable voltage and current measurements across 16 terminals without hardware reconnections. The platform supports seamless transition between conventional two-terminal characterization, multiterminal characterization and testing computational properties in the framework of physical reservoir computing. Local conductance measurements, voltage mapping, and real-time dynamic monitoring offer unique insights into the spatiotemporal behavior of the networks. Furthermore, we show that the system enables to correlate electrical properties of the multiterminal network in terms of conductance matrices and voltage maps with computational performances, allowing also adaptive control over the network's operating state. The here reported setup provides a versatile platform for computing at the matter level (i.e., in materia) with multiterminal systems based on self-organizing memristive networks.

title: Bridging CNNs and Transformers for Skin Cancer Detection: A Comparative Analysis
authors: Yash Aryan Kuntal, Aruna Bhat
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Automated detection of skin cancer demands both precision and efficiency, yet conventional visual and histopathological methods remain time- consuming and variable. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) such as ResNet50, DenseNet121 and EfficientNet-B0 have set performance benchmarks on the HAM10000 dermatoscopic dataset, while vision transformers (ViTs) offer an alternative via global self-attention. To our knowledge, no prior study has systematically compared CNNs and transformers under identical training and evaluation conditions on a dermatology dataset. Here, we present a unified evaluation of three CNNs (ResNet50, DenseNet121, EfficientNet-B0) alongside two transformer variants (ViT-B/16, DeiT-S) on HAM10000. We evaluate resilience to class imbalance, computational cost, and diagnostic accuracy. Our findings demonstrate that while ViTs may attain similar accuracy with substantial pre-training, their clinical utility is limited by their large data needs and computational cost. On the other hand, EfficientNet-B0 is a strong contender for practical implementation as it achieves the ideal balance between speed and performance. This work underscores the necessity for transformer adjustments specific to medical datasets and provides guidance for model selection for automated skin cancer screening by elucidating these trade-offs.

title: Evaluating Managed Kubernetes Distributions for Enterprise Adoption: A Comparative Analysis of EKS, GKE, AKS, and OCP
authors: Nigam Bhatt
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The rapid evolution of cloud computing has transformed the way organizations approach infrastructure and application management. A pivotal development in this transformation is the rise of containerization, which has enabled resource-efficient and scalable cloud-native applications. Kubernetes, a leading container orchestration platform, has emerged as the de facto standard for managing containerized workloads, offering enhanced automation, scalability, and flexibility. However, managing Kubernetes at scale presents significant challenges, prompting cloud providers to offer managed Kubernetes solutions tailored to enterprise needs. This study provides a comparative analysis of four prominent managed Kubernetes distributions-Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS), Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE), Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS), and Red Hat OpenShift Container Platform (OCP). By evaluating key features such as scalability, security, cost structure, and enterprise-level functionalities, this research identifies the strengths and weaknesses of each distribution and assesses their suitability for various business use cases. The findings aim to guide organizations in selecting the optimal Kubernetes distribution based on specific operational requirements and industry needs.

title: Research on Distributed Machine Learning Training Based on the FedDyn Algorithm
authors: Ziyi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Federated learning has attracted widespread attention because it can share data without leaking privacy. Traditional federated learning algorithms (such as Federated Averaging Algorithm (FedAvg) often show low adaptability and robustness when facing non-independent and identically distributed (Non-IID) data and dynamically changing data environments. Federated Learning based on Dynamic Regularization (FedDyn) improves the training effect of the global model under unbalanced and dynamically changing data distributions. This study aims to evaluate the performance of the FedDyn algorithm in a non-IID data environment, focusing on its effect under the combination of optimizer adjustment, communication compression, and differential privacy protection mechanisms. The study uses the Cifar10 dataset and designs three experimental scenarios: comparing the performance of FedDyn and FedAvg under different optimizers (SGD and Adam), analyzing the robustness of the algorithm under communication compression conditions, and evaluating the impact of differential privacy mechanisms on privacy protection. The experimental results show that the FedDyn algorithm shows high robustness under various experimental conditions, especially under the combination of optimizer adjustment and communication compression, showing better accuracy and effectively improving communication efficiency. In summary, the FedDyn algorithm provides an effective solution to the federated learning problem under non-IID data and has great application potential.

title: Introducing UNIQuE: The Unconventional Noiseless Intermediate Quantum Emulator
authors: Reece Robertson, Dan Ventura
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: We implement an open-source quantum computing emulator that includes arithmetic operations, the quantum Fourier transform, and quantum phase estimation. The emulator provides significant savings in both temporal and spatial resources compared to simulation, and these computational advantages are verified through comparison to the Intel Quantum Simulator. We also demonstrate how to use the emulator to implement Shor's algorithm and use it to solve a nontrivial factoring problem. This demonstrates that emulation can make quantum computing more accessible than simulation or noisy hardware by allowing researchers to study the behavior of algorithms on large problems in a noiseless environment.

title: Random Search for Investment and Operating Costs Trade-Off in Capacitor Sizing and Placement
authors: Oscar Danilo Montoya, Víctor Manuel Garrido-Arévalo, Luis Fernando Grisales-Noreña
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This paper presents a multi-objective optimization framework for the optimal placement and sizing of fixed-step capacitor banks in radial distribution networks. The proposed model, formulated as a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) problem, simultaneously minimizes energy losses and the total cost of investment and operation. A set of Pareto-optimal solutions is obtained, offering decision-makers a spectrum of technically and economically viable alternatives. The results confirm the effectiveness of the approach in enhancing voltage profiles and reducing operating costs, contributing to a more efficient and sustainable network planning.

title: Forecasting Regional Tourist Influx with Decision Tree Regression and GRNN: A Data-Driven Approach
authors: Nikhil Gupta, Anukrti Mishra, Prakash Garia, Ritika Saxena, Shokhjakhon Akhmedov, Siddharth Joshi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Kumaun, a renowned region in Uttarakhand, attracts a large number of tourists annually due to its natural beauty and rich cultural heritage. The influx of tourists varies significantly with the seasons, with certain months experiencing higher footfall than others. This study aims to predict tourist arrivals in the region using various factors such as month, temperature, number of local events, and hotel prices. A preexisting dataset comprising 100 records was utilized for the analysis. Two predictive models were developed: Decision Tree Regression and Generalized Regression Neural Network (GRNN). The performance of both models was evaluated using standard metrics including Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), and the Coefficient of Determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>). The Decision Tree Regression model demonstrated moderate predictive capability with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of approximately 44.94%, whereas the GRNN model underperformed, yielding a negative R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> value. Based on these results, the Decision Tree model is considered more suitable for this application. The findings of this study may assist government bodies and tourism authorities in better planning and resource management during peak and off-peak tourist seasons.

title: Design and Implementation of an Autonomous Precision Lawn Cutter
authors: T. Kiruthiga, B Gokulraj, S Balasubramaniyan, S. R Darsan Sanjai
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The increasing need for smart and environmentally friendly automation has led to the progress of robotic systems powered by renewable energy that take over outdoor maintenance tasks completely and repeatedly. The article highlight the creation and execution of an APLC (Autonomous Precision Lawn Cutter) that is powered by solar energy. The APLC is a combination of renewable energy collection, embedded control, and multisensor fusion to offer effective and completely autonomous lawn care. The proposed setup is based on an Arduino microcontroller, which is the main control unit in charge of sensor data gathering and relay-based motor actuation. A combination of a $\mathbf{1 2 V}$ solar panel and Li-ion battery is the hybrid energy source that supplies power to the entire system through a charge controller, which guarantees the system’s continuous operation under different sunlight conditions.A VL53L1X Time-of-Flight (ToF) sensor is used by the mower for an accurate measurement of grass height and the blade is turned on only when the height of grass detected is more than the previously set height, thus saving energy. An HC-SR04 ultrasonic distance sensor serves to detect obstacles and avoid collisions by monitoring continuously the way of the mower. The controlling of the motors is done by a relay-based switching network instead of normal H-bridge drivers, which leads to less power loss, better torque efficiency, and easier circuit design. Experimental tests substantiate that the new APLC offers a grass height detection accuracy of $\mathbf{\pm 5 ~ m m}$, Experiments conducted in typical outdoor weather have validated correct sensing and navigation module operation over the conventional manual or wired mowers. The system shows that combining renewable energy, sensor-based intelligence, and efficient relay control can make a sustainable and low-cost solution for modern precision lawn maintenance.

title: Research on Trajectory Tracking Control Method of Multi-Joint Flexible Robotic Arm Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Jiayu Zou
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: In this study, a reinforcement learning algorithm based on proximal policy optimization (PPO) is used for trajectory tracking control of a multi-joint flexible robotic arm. A multi-joint flexible robotic arm with Z-shape geometry is designed, and the kinematic model is established using the improved D-H parameter method, and a planar simulation environment is constructed, including the state space of joint angles, angular velocities, end position errors, target trajectory derivatives, and kinetic energy indexes, as well as a specific action space and a reward function. The PPO algorithm is improved by introducing a clipping operation to limit the magnitude of the policy update, which improves the training Stability. The performance of the algorithm is optimized by a planar feature extractor, a policy network parameterized by a Gaussian distribution, and a value network that introduces the derivative of the target trajectory. Motion control training was carried out in planar space, and the experimental results show that the algorithm performs poorly at the beginning of training, but the reward value rises rapidly as the training proceeds, and eventually reaches a high level of stability. The end-effector of the multi-joint linear mechanical structure can accurately pass the given target point, the control signals of different joints are different, the end-effector stays at the specific position with high frequency. And the expected trajectory control is basically realized, and this study provides an effective method for the trajectory tracking control of the multi-joint flexible robotic arm.

title: Enhancing Awareness in the Design of Dissemination and Teaching Activities: Using Context for Integrating Knowledge Sharing and Technology
authors: Andrea Zingoni, Chiara Tagliaferri, Pasquale Arpaia, Valentina Bello, Loredana Cristaldi, Valentina Elisabetta Ferrara, Nicola Moccaldi, Antonio Moschitta, Marisa Pesola, Fabio A. Schreiber, Letizia Tanca, Leila Es Sebar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: In education and science communication, technological innovation often progresses without adequate consideration of context and intended outcomes. This work proposes a context-driven, interdisciplinary approach for designing knowledge dissemination activities that purposefully employ digital technologies. The Context Dimension Tree (CDT), a conceptual model from data management, has been adopted by Res4Net, a national network of Italian laboratories and research groups, as a support tool for planning communication and dissemination strategies. Two case studies on dyslexia awareness and assessment illustrate how CDT enables scenario mapping, stakeholder identification, and goal clarification. The approach enhances both educational initiatives and broader efforts in public science communication.

title: Hybrid CNN-RNN Model for Identifying and Classifying Literary Themes and Structures in English Novels
authors: S Lora, S Ramya, Sweta Priya, RVS Praveen, C. Tharini, Punit Pathak
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The automated analysis of literary themes and structures in English novels presents a significant task due to the complicated interplay of stylistic patterns and long-range narrative relationships. Current models often inadequately represent both local and global features., resulting in minimized classification accuracy. The proposed study presents a hybrid CNN-RNN model that integrates convolutional layers for n-gram pattern recognition with bidirectional GRU layers for sequence modelling., resulting in enhanced performance in literary analytics. Experiments utilizing unique datasets from Kaggle illustrate the model's effectiveness., attaining 98.6% accuracy., 97.9% precision., 98.2% recall., and a 98.0% macro Fl-score. Comparative evaluations demonstrate significant improvements over baseline models., including independent CNN., Bi-GRU., and BERT fine-tuning. The suggested methodology markedly enhances the current capabilities in literary theme and structure identification., providing a powerful instrument for digital humanities and automated educational systems. This study establishes a basis for subsequent efforts in multimodal and multilingual literary analysis.

title: Blockchain Integration for Ensuring Real-Time Data Integrity in Internet of Things Frameworks
authors: Sudeep Kumar Gupta, R. P. Ram Kumar, Ramy Read Hossain, Isroilov Sardorbek Solijon ugli, Ashu Nayak, Feruza Jumaniyazova
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: Coverage of Internet of Things (IoT) frameworks with blockchain technology is a revolutionary approach that provides absolute integrity to the actual-time data. Proliferation of IoT systems demands strong data security mechanisms that call for special attention for smart cities, as well as healthcare systems and industrial automation. Through this research, the ways in which the blockchain technologies can provide protected decentralized storage avenues for iot data with automatic perpetual protection of their integrity is explored. This paper discusses how blockchain based platform guard IoT systems from their classic susceptibilities to central controlling points and data manipulation likelihoods through safe duly decentralized storage capabilities. Other than data security features, blockchain platforms apply consensus algorithms to come up with timely data verification to thwart data alteration and make data much reliable. This research conducts evaluations of blockchain enabled IoT networks through both simulation and case-study oriented performance capability determination as well as network scalability metric determination to display security and latency privileges as well as an extent of participants' confidence. The research concludes with descriptions of future possibilities for blockchain-IoT integration that will revolutionize data management circumstances where more vigorous means of maintaining the security of data are required.

title: A Three-Layers Defense Scheme for Resilient CRYSTALS-Dilithium in Blockchain Security
authors: Kurnia Mustika Wati, Khoirul Anwar, Danu Dwi Sanjoyo
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Quantum computing's rapid progress threatens traditional cryptography like Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA) in blockchains. This paper examines CRYSTALS-Dilithium, a NIST-approved lattice-based signature scheme using Module Learning With Errors (MLWE) and Module Short Integer Solution (MSIS), for quantum-resistant blockchain security. However, Dilithium's complex key structure risks full compromise from partial leaks. We propose a three-layer defense: (1) Threshold Signature Scheme (TSS) distributes <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$s_{1}$</tex> across 20 nodes with threshold <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$t=15$</tex> using Multi-Party Computation (MPC) signing to avoid single points of failure; (2) Dynamic Key Rotation (DKR) enables rapid revocation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$s_{2}$</tex> upon anomaly detection; (3) Verifiable Timed Signatures (VTS) leverage Timelock Puzzles (TLP) and Non-Interactive Zero-Knowledge Proofs (NIZKP) to impose timed delays, allowing detection of malicious activity. This architecture enhances post-quantum blockchain resilience, scalability, and decentralization while significantly increasing the cost of attacks. In 20-node simulations, baseline architectures fail after 4–5 node compromises, whereas our system endures up to 14, raising attack costs by a factor of 100. The combination of VTS and DKR reduces detection latency by 94.9% (from over 5 minutes to under 30 seconds). The overhead is approximately 2.5 KB per signature plus MPC operations, remaining feasible at 500 TPS for Proof-of-Work (PoW) or 100 TPS for Proof-of-Stake (PoS) systems.

title: Hybrid Trust-Based Malicious Node Detection in Wireless Sensor Networks Using Dempster-Shafer Theory
authors: Yendreddy Jaya Durga, Gayathri M
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Networks of wireless sensors (WSNs) experience growing utilization across vital applications that include environmental observations and smart cities as well as automation systems in factories. The decentralized structure of wireless sensor networks alongside resource limitations creates security holes that enable malicious node attacks to disrupt network functionality and reliability. This study presents a combined detection method which employs Dempster-Shafer Theory (DST) and trust-based metrics to detect malicious network nodes. The framework utilizes trust score collection from neighboring nodes to implement Dempster-Shafer Theory for effective uncertainty management in trust evaluation. The system utilizes the Contiki operating system for implementation and runs simulations through the Cooja simulator. The experimental findings demonstrate that the new detection method maintains high packet delivery rates and decreases end-to-end delay while sustaining energy efficiency across various network structures.

title: Performance Analysis of Cooperative Relays in 5G Wireless High Speed Train Communication
authors: M. Bindhu, P. Pattunnarajam, Sabareeswari, A. N. Duraivel, A. Raguraman, A. Mahadevan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The work investigates methods for improving wireless communication performance in high-speed railway (HSR) environments by integrating moving relay (MR) technology within a 5 G framework. As modern rail systems require stable, high-capacity connections for both passenger services and train-control applications, addressing the communication challenges associated with rapid mobility remains essential. The initial phase of this study evaluates system behavior using classical analytical tools, including MATLAB-based simulations to estimate metrics such as signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), transmission capacity, handoff probability, and network coverage under omnidirectional antenna configurations. These baseline results highlight constraints of traditional models in environments characterized by unpredictable and rapidly changing channel conditions.To overcome these shortcomings, machine learning (ML) techniques are later incorporated to enable adaptive handoff control and real-time signal optimization. Ensemble bagging algorithms are applied to predict channel variations and refine mobility management processes. Comparative evaluation shows that ML-driven techniques provide notable improvements in throughput consistency, handoff reliability, and SNR estimation of HSR System.

title: An Efficient Algorithm for Nonconvex-Concave Minimax Quadratic Problem_supp1-3657161.pdf
authors: HENG QIAO
publish: N/A
abstract: A nonconvex-concave minimax quadratic problem is studied in this paper. An efficient alternating algorithm is proposed without any convexification procedures and constraint relaxations. By introducing a random perturbation in each iteration, the uniqueness of feasible updates is guaranteed based on the property of nonconvex quadratic programming. Furthermore, under mild conditions on the algorithmic parameters, a novel sequential convergence result is obtained that benefits potential use in signal design applications. Extensive numerical simulations are carried out to validate the advantages of the proposed algorithm against the contemporary competing methods.

title: PALM-Gripper: Integrated Gripper With Parallel Adaptable Mechanism for Shelf Picking in Logistics
authors: Seunghwan Um, Yeong Gwang Son, Juyong Hong, Chun Soo Kim, Issac Rhee, Heeyeon Jeong, Hyouk Ryeol Choi
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: Automating logistics tasks in factories has been challenging due to the high variability in processes. Among these tasks, robotic shelf picking is particularly challenging due to the limited capability of current robotic systems for reliable operation in unstructured environments. In particular, cluttered objects standing on shelves make it difficult to obtain object’s information, making it challenging to determine the suitable grasp candidate. This study proposes an integrated finger and retractable suction gripper to address the complexities of shelf picking and compensate for computer vision uncertainty. Specifically, the finger mechanism facilitates stable grasping by providing adaptive parallel support, even when object dimensions are not accurately estimated. The gripper achieves stable grasping even with a relatively simple vision model by employing a grasp-and-pull strategy following suction grasping. The system was tested in a simulated logistics environment, demonstrating its effectiveness in overcoming the lack of vision algorithms. This research contributes to developing a versatile robotic gripper for picking and stowing tasks on a shelf, essential for improving automation in the logistics industry.

title: AI-driven Semi-Supervised Pancreatic Cancer Diagnosis Technique Using Consistency Regularization
authors: Suchi Jain, Renu Dhir, Geeta Sikka
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Pancreatic cancer is a highly malignant disease with a low survival rate. The primary reason for its high mortality is the absence of early-stage symptoms and the lack of effective early diagnostic systems. The late-stage diagnosis further exacerbates its mortality rate. Supervised artificial intelligence (AI) techniques have recently demonstrated promising results in earlystage diagnosis. However, a significant challenge with supervised AI methods is their reliance on large, labeled data sets, which are challenging to obtain in the medical field. In this work, the authors investigate the potential of semi-supervised AI techniques to address this limitation. The performance of supervised deep learning classification models is evaluated quantitatively using smaller training datasets. In addition, the authors explore the integration of contrast loss functions with existing AI models to enhance the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer using limited data. The performance of the models is analyzed using three publicly available datasets: BTCV, NIH, and MSD. Experimental results indicate that incorporating contrastive loss with classification loss can significantly improve the diagnostic accuracy of deep learning models, even with a reduced number of training data points.

title: A Wind Energy Based EV Charging Technique Under Variable Wind Speed Conditions
authors: Venkatesh Reddy Birudala
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: A new wind energy-powered electric vehicle (EV) charging method under variable wind speed has been introduced in this paper. It employs a PMSG, connected to the grid using a diode rectifier and a boost converter, to generate a constant DC output supply from the wind energy. A variable step Perturb and Observe (P&O) Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) algorithm is utilized for the maximum power extraction. A charging strategy is proposed for varying wind speed profiles to maintain the desired charging power through the already mentioned mechanisms while using a single inductor and with the ability to respond according to the changing environment. The simulation results demonstrate the proposed method being a promising solution for Reliable and Sustainable Charging for Electric Vehicle.

title: Enhancing Real-Time Internet of Things Data Processing: A Comparative Study of Fog and Cloud Computing with Intelligent Offloading Strategies
authors: Samreen Fayaz, Sparsh Sharma
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: With the multitude of IoT applications, the limitations of traditional cloud computing have been exposed, particularly in the area of real-time response and latency. Fog computing addresses these issues by delivering computation and storage services closer to the data sources. This study investigates the role of fog computing in complementing IoT applications, presenting a smart offloading mechanism whereby data processing is done locally at the fog nodes before selective transfer to the cloud. The selective offloading depends on several parameters such as current network load, latency sensitivity, computational intensity, and task size, which together form the basis of the criterion for intelligent offloading. By means of architectural investigation, comparative analysis, and a delay-sensitive mathematical model in Python designed for synthetically efficient IoT tasks and corresponding latencies calculation, we demonstrate the potential of fog computing in latency minimization, resource usage optimization, and Quality of Service improvement. The experimental results show an average latency of about 50 ms for the cloud-only solution and 15 ms for the fog-based solution, which is approximately a $70 \%$ reduction of the total latency. Validating its worth in latency-constrained IoT applications. The future could see AI-based adaptive offloading and real-world deployment scenarios.

title: High robustness partial discharge detection technology using fiber F-P interferometer based on differential phase demodulation_supp1-3656982.docx
authors: Wei-Chao Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Fabry-Perot (F-P) sensors exhibit extremely high sensitivity in partial discharge (PD) detection. However, traditional F-P intensity demodulation systems are susceptible to disturbances from vibration and temperature, leading to a decrease in demodulation sensitivity or even failure. A novel demodulation method with high robustness is proposed to detect PD by leveraging differential interference, ensuring reliable PD detection performance of the F-P sensing system in complex environments. The theoretical frequency characteristics and sensitivity of the method are firstly calculated and analyzed. Then, the differential phase demodulation system for F-P sensor is designed and manufactured for insulation PD detection, and the response performance of the system is tested and evaluated in the laboratory. Furthermore, compared with the universal intensity demodulation method, it is certified that the new method has the same phase sensitivity. Meanwhile, F-P interference system with differential phase demodulation demonstrates improved linearity and a wider response bandwidth. Within the temperature range of 30-90°C, the signal amplitude of the F-P intensity demodulation system decreases by 94%, while the F-P differential phase demodulation system only attenuates by 10.7%. At a starting discharge voltage of 12kV, the signal-to-noise ratio of the differential phase demodulation system is only 1.36% lower than that of the intensity demodulation system. Moreover, under harsh environmental changes, the differential phase demodulation system exhibits extremely high stability. The highly robust F-P local electric detection system is conducive to the broader application and promotion of fiber optic F-P sensors.

title: Towards Real-Time Prosthetic Control Using Multi-Domain Time-Frequency EMG Classification and ResNet Transfer Learning
authors: Sarah Hussain Khuwaja, Balvinder Dhillon, Maham Mahnoor Mughal, Siraj Hussain, Mohammad Hasan Shaheed
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: We propose a novel multi-resolution time-frequency fusion framework for real-time classification of surface electromyography (sEMG) signals. The system jointly encodes Continuous Wavelet Transform (CWT) scalograms and Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) spectrograms to capture both transient and sustained muscular activation patterns. These heterogeneous representations are processed via a parallel dual-branch encoder and fused early using a 1x1 convolutional bottleneck, enabling synergistic feature extraction. The fused inputs are then classified using a fine-tuned ResNet-50 convolutional neural network via transfer learning. Evaluated on the SEEDS HD-sEMG dataset with 14 gesture classes, the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance in classification accuracy and robustness, while maintaining sub-20 ms inference latency. These results demonstrate the framework's suitability for deployment in closed-loop neuromuscular interfaces, such as myoelectric prosthetic control and interactive robotic systems.

title: Research on the Application of Computer Application Technology Based on Machine Learning in Intelligent Learning Systems
authors: Xian Dekun
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: A novel intelligent recommendation algorithm is proposed, which combines deep learning and reinforcement learning. Traditional recommendation algorithms usually rely on static models and cannot fully consider the dynamic changes and individual differences of learners' behaviors. Deep learning can effectively extract implicit features such as learners' interests, behaviors, and knowledge mastery. The algorithm in this paper combines the advantages of deep learning and reinforcement learning. First, the deep learning model is used to extract features from learners' historical behavior data to obtain personalized interest and demand features. Then, the reinforcement learning algorithm dynamically adjusts the recommendation strategy and optimizes the recommended content in real time, so that the system can make adaptive adjustments based on learners' feedback and needs to improve the accuracy of recommendations. To test the validity of the proposed algorithm, an intelligent learning platform is designed, and various learning scenarios are simulated. The experiment results indicate that, compared with the traditional recommendation algorithms, learners can improve on average 12% on average, improve on recommendation accuracy by 15%, and reduce learning time by 10%. These data show that the intelligent recommendation algorithm based on the fusion of deep learning and reinforcement learning can significantly improve the learning effect of learners and the personalized recommendation ability of the system, thereby optimizing the learning process and improving learning efficiency.

title: The Impact of Non-Task-Related Neural Activity in EEG-Based Motor Imagery Classification
authors: Simone Bove, Martino Giaquinto, Gennaro Percannella, Alessia Saggese, Mario Vento
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: In the context of Brain-Computer Interfaces, detecting motor imagery events from electroencephalography signals plays a crucial role. Traditionally, this task has been formulated as a classification problem among different imagined movements. However, despite remarkable accuracy in distinguishing among different events, real-world biomedical applications introduce the additional challenge of differentiating motor imagery events from non-task-related background neural activity. To address this challenge, in this work, we conduct a comparative analysis between two deep learning based approaches (end-to-end and hierarchical) for also taking into account background class alongside motor imagery classes (specifically, left and right hand motor imagery). We demonstrate that the end-to-end approach achieves performance comparable to the hierarchical one, with only a negligible drop in accuracy, while offering significant advantages in terms of model complexity and suitability for portable applications.

title: Ensemble of Vision Transformers for Enhanced Classification of Gastrointestinal Diseases
authors: Aruna Kumari Kakumani, Karthik Reddy Devi Reddy, Lokesh Eggadi
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: One of the major challenges in medical image processing is correctly detecting and categorizing artifacts inside gastrointestinal tract images. Due to the advances in medical science and artificial intelligence, many diseases can now be automatically detected and treated. The development of robust algorithms is necessary for image recognition and classification, which is necessary for the development of advanced diagnostic and therapeutic systems. The benchmark dataset for gastrointestinal tract disease, Kvasir V2 is utilized for the current study which consists of 8000 gastrointestinal tract images divided into 8 classes. Our proposed ensemble model makes use of the predictions of three pre-trained vision transformer models namely DeiT, MaxViT and Swin Transformer with accuracies of 91.13%, 93.37%, and 93.63%, respectively. Stacking ensemble technique is used to aggregate the base learners improving classification accuracy to 95.87%. The evaluation findings show that features of individual base learners learnt erroneously can be classified in a better way by using an ensemble of base learners.

title: Omnidirectional Photographic Capture for VR-Based Representation of Indoor Space: A Subjective Study
authors: Giovanni Lo Monaco, Luca Guarnera, Sebastiano Battiato, Salvatore Livatino
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The availability of high-resolution omnidirectional cameras enables the rapid acquisition of real-world environments, which can be leveraged for virtual visits. This has significant potential for applications in education, cultural heritage, and simulation. This paper presents a subjective evaluation of a lightweight technique for representing real indoor spaces in Virtual Reality (VR) using 360-degree imagery. A real room was captured and displayed as an equirectangular texture mapped onto a virtual sphere. Twenty-two participants explored the scene using natural locomotion and completed perceptual and cognitive tasks. Their experience was assessed using standardized questionnaires concerning presence, depth perception, visual realism, and distortion. Results indicate that the method can effectively convey a sense of immersion and spatial presence when viewed through a VR headset, though projection-related distortions remain a limitation. Overall, the approach is shown to be a viable solution for rapid VR deployment where visual immersion is prioritized over interactive complexity.

title: A Heterogeneity-aware Training Framework for Large-scale Geo-distributed Deep Learning
authors: Renchao Xie, Zhe Deng, Qinqin Tang, Li Feng, Ran Zhang, Hongye Zhou, Tao Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 19th International Conference on Big Data Science and Engineering (BigDataSE)
abstract: As datasets and model complexity increase, Geo-distributed deep learning (GeoDL) trains models across multiple sites to avoid single-site capacity limits. Unlike relatively homogeneous intra-datacenter networks, wide-area networks (WANs) exhibit significant heterogeneity and variability, leading to synchronization and communication bottlenecks when resource-limited nodes become stragglers. To tackle this challenge, we propose a heterogeneity-aware GeoDL framework that employs a hierarchical federated tree synchronization mechanism to coordinate the computational and transmission pacing of heterogeneous nodes, thereby enhancing global training efficiency. Additionally, we develop an adaptive scheduling algorithm based on distributed Bayesian optimization (BO) and validate its effectiveness through emulation-based simulations.

title: Operationalizing Semantics from Domain Diagrams
authors: Aakash Mor, Mrunal Gangrade
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: This paper introduces AMIDOL, a framework for machine-assisted extraction of formal computational semantics from domain-specific visual diagrams. Our approach tackles significant challenges in Explainable AI by converting intuitive graphical representations into rigorously defined executable models. Through domain-specific ontological languages and a unified intermediate representation, AMIDOL facilitates automated generation of actionable insights and analytical queries. This empowers domain specialists with precise comprehension of complex system behaviors and enables evidence-based decision-making across various application domains.

title: Farm Sage Multilingual Agricultural Q&A Assistant And Plant Leaf Disease Detection
authors: J Karthick, M Bhargav Reddy, Lc Karthick, A. Eswari
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: This work proposes an AI-powered agricultural decision-support system to overcome the limitations of traditional advisory mechanisms that often fail either in their diagnostic acumen or contextual awareness. In this respect, the proposed approach integrates a hybrid convolutional neural network-Swin Transformer architecture for plant disease detection with a multilingual conversational module powered by Google Gemini. The hybrid visual framework merges convolutional feature extraction with shifted-window selfattention, thus accurately identifying subtle and globally distributed disease patterns within natural farm images. The conversational module interprets farmer queries across regional languages, assuring reliable intent understanding and domainspecific response generation. Real-time meteorological data from the OpenWeatherMap API have been integrated to align diagnoses with localized environmental risks, rendering more actionable recommendations. The empirical investigation shows that the system has outperformed traditional CNN-based architectures on accuracy, precision, recall, and robustness metrics. Collectively, the framework offers a scalable, contextaware, and multilingual solution for enhanced crop health management under precision agriculture.

title: Enhancing Stock Market Fraud Detection using the SECURE Framework: A Comparative Study with Logistic Regression
authors: S. Malathy, R. Anandhi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Internet-based trading of stocks on the stock market in today's globalized era relies heavily on internet infrastructure. As much as the internet has revolutionized opportunity and access to financial markets, it has opened doors to opportunities for increasing cyber vulnerabilities and intricate fraud schemes. Traditional fraud detection systems, even though widely installed, are insufficient in keeping up with the evolving and dynamic character of cyber threats. This research paper presents a detailed comparison of an Logistic Regression-based model of traditional fraud detection with a novel multilayered AI-based system called the SECURE framework. The SECURE framework applies real-time monitoring, risk classification, regulatory enforcement, contextual awareness, fast response, and real-time improvement to identify and respond to stock market-related cyber attacks. The results of comparative analysis show the enhanced performance of the SECURE framework in reducing false positives, minimizing detection latency, and achieving effective fraud identification by applying real-time market behavior patterns.

title: Optimizing Sorting Efficiency Through MaTe: A Digit-Based Algorithm for Large-Scale Datasets
authors: Piyush Kumar, Kishorjit Nongmeikapam
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Sorting is a core operation in computer science with wide-ranging applications in optimization, data retrieval, and system performance. This paper introduces MaTe Sort, an efficient hybrid algorithm tailored for datasets containing both positive and negative integers with variable digit lengths. By grouping data based on digit count and applying Shell Sort within each group, MaTe Sort minimizes unnecessary swaps and comparisons — enhancing overall performance. Unlike conventional algorithms such as Quick Sort or Merge Sort, MaTe Sort offers a balance of computational efficiency and reduced operational complexity(comparisons/swaps) with efficient memory use. The paper includes a thorough mathematical proof of correctness, a time complexity analysis, and benchmark comparisons against leading sorting algorithms.
