title: Privacy-Preserving Out-of-Distribution Alignment for Federated GNNs
authors: Monika Varshney, Tanima Dutta
publish: IEEE MultiMedia
abstract: Out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization is a major challenge in federated graph learning, where client data distributions often differ significantly due to shifts in node features and structural patterns. This non-IID nature leads to poor performance of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) trained solely on federated task losses. While domain-alignment techniques—such as adversarial training, invariant risk minimization, and kernel-based methods like Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD)—offer promising solutions for mitigating distribution shifts, they typically require access to shared embeddings, which compromises user privacy. We propose FedMMD-P, a framework for privacy-preserving alignment in federated out-of-distribution graph learning. Each client computes a compact, noisy RFF-based sketch of its node-embedding distribution, enabling a DP-MMD penalty with only O( nD) local cost and D-dimensional communication per round. Across five benchmarks (Reddit, OGB-Arxiv, Ethereum, Tox21, PubMed), FedMMD-P delivers up to 6 percentage-point accuracy gains over non-private baselines under severe domain shifts while incurring <0.1% communication overhead and only 5–10% runtime overhead. We derive end-to-end (ε, δ)-DP bounds via Moments Accountant and Rényi composition, demonstrating practical privacy guarantees.

title: A Lightweight Machine Learning Model for the Automatic Classification of Near-Field and Far-Field Earthquakes
authors: Suat Gokhan Ozkaya, Mehmet Baygin
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Classification of seismic signals is critical in distinguishing between Near-Field (NF) and Far-Field (FF) seismic events in earthquake engineering and structural analysis. In this paper, we propose an innovative machine learning-based model for automatic classification of seismic signals. The proposed method consists of signal decomposition using Tunable Q-Factor Wavelet Transform (TQWT), feature extraction using Nigerian Pattern and statistical moment methods, feature selection using Iterative Neighborhood Component Analysis (INCA) algorithm, and finally classification using Support Vector Machines (SVM) algorithm. The proposed model provides a lightweight framework with low computational cost and high classification accuracy compared to traditional methods in the literature. The model was tested on 147 open-access seismic signal data and achieved 93.2% classification accuracy with a 10-fold cross-validation strategy. This study aims to make a significant contribution to earthquake engineering analysis and structural design processes by providing an effective method for the automatic classification of seismic signals.

title: Enhancing Lane Detection Systems by Leveraging Segment Anything Integrated with Dual Attention Mechanism
authors: Aisyah Aiza Rosli, Mohd Ibrahim Shapiai, Noor Jannah Zakaria
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: This paper introduces a lane detection system that improves upon traditional Fully Convolutional Networks (FCNs) by integrating dual attention mechanisms and a preprocessing strategy that uses Meta's Segment Anything Model (SAM). The core of the system's innovation lies in its use of Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) channel and spatial attention modules to refine feature representation, and its use of SAM to guide the network towards lane-specific features. The system was trained on the TuSimple dataset and achieved a test accuracy of 96.4 %, outperforming standard FCN approaches. Although the model is highly accurate, its high latency poses a challenge for real-time applications. Future work will include conducting ablation studies to reduce this latency and training the model in other datasets to improve its performance in complex driving environments.

title: Research on Optimizing Teaching Reform Decision Support System Using Big Data Analysis
authors: Guangling Zhang, Xiangrong Zhang, Jingjing Yan, Xiaoli Jiang, Miao Zhang, Lei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes an optimization decision support system based on big data analysis, combining a hybrid model of ensemble learning and deep learning, aiming to generate optimal decisions in a dynamic data-driven way. The system first uses ensemble learning models (such as random forests and gradient boosting trees) to preliminarily process multi-source data, extract features and generate decisions. Subsequently, the decision model is further optimized through deep neural networks to handle complex nonlinear relationships and improve the prediction accuracy of the system. In addition, the system introduces an adaptive optimization mechanism to dynamically adjust the weight of the model according to historical data to ensure efficient decision-making in different scenarios. Experimental results show that the system improves decision accuracy by 7.2% and reduces response time by 15.4% compared with traditional methods in multiple experimental scenarios. In particular, the proposed hybrid model shows significant advantages in large-scale data processing and real-time optimization. This study provides innovative ideas for decision support systems based on big data and demonstrates its potential in multiple practical applications, especially in the face of dynamically changing data environments. It has strong adaptability and robustness.

title: Computer Aided Diagnostic System for Ovarian Cyst Classification and Abnormality Detection Using MobileNetV-2 and VGG-16
authors: MunishSood, EmjeePuthooran, NishantJain
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Developing a computer-aided diagnostic (CAD) system is the aim of this project. It uses deep learning networks to classify and identify anomalies in ovarian cysts. Using a 4D ultrasound scanner called the Voluson-S8, many operators collected 1319 ultrasound images of ovarian cysts from a prestigious obstetrics and gynecological hospital. The Voluson-S8 is a device made specifically for gynecological scans by General Electric (GE). Each image in the dataset was meticulously categorized by a radiology specialist with more than 20 years of gynecological experience. Five image classes were created. The two deep learning networks, mobileNetV-2 and VGG-16, were developed using MATLAB R 2022b’s Deep Learning Toolbox. The research compares these two pre-trained deep learning networks on a number of significant metrics. The validation accuracy of mobileNetV-2 is 90.11%, whereas that of VGG-16 is 74.52%. MobileNetV-2 is 15.59% more accurate than VGG-16. Endometriomas, hemorrhagic cysts, hydrosalpinges, polycystic, and normal ovaries are the five different abnormalities that we were able to classify in the current study. The classification results were compared with their analysis by the gynecologist/radiologist, who has many years of expertise and currently completes the assignment regularly. We have found that the deep learning (DL) based CAD system has a high degree of accuracy in identifying and classifying ovarian cysts when compared to radiologists and gynecologists.

title: Energy Optimization in Wireless Sensor Networks Using MHBA-Based Cluster Head Selection for IoT applications
authors: P. Satyanarayana, Arjun Nelikanti, M Arun, Jampani Ravi, K Sai Krishna, V. Gokula Krishnan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: WSNs have established themselves as critical research subject because they enable numerous practical applications in environmental monitoring and industrial automation and military surveillance and healthcare systems and smart cities operations. A sensor network embraces many nodes as deployed sensors across geographic space for the purpose of data acquisition and forwarding information to a centralized hub station. The sensor nodes found in WSNs face energy constraints which create challenges for maintaining network operations and ensuring reliable communication because of their limited power resources. This paper presents an energy-efficient routing protocol which can strengthen both secure network operations and extend operational lifetime in WSNs. The proposed approach leverages the Modified Honey Badger Approach (MHBA) for optimal clustering and cluster head (CH) selection. The multi-objective optimization method which powers the MHBA framework takes into account three main factors including residual energy together with node distance and security risk to develop energy-efficient data paths with strong protection features. The proposed model enhances network energy efficiency while promoting security which results in longer network lifetime together with superior data delivery performance according to experimental findings and simulation results. Results demonstrate that using MHBA leads to effective cluster building for dynamic and adaptive operations in constrained energy WSN systems.

title: Design and Development of Military Personnel Monitoring System Using LoRa Module with SOS Functionality
authors: Yussi Perdana Saputera, Muhammad Aulia Rahman Dc, Yusnita Rahayu, Arie Setiawan, Puput Dani Prasetyo Adi, Teguh Praludi, Yudi Yuliyus Maulana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: The security of a nation is closely tied to its military strength, with soldiers playing a significant role in maintaining national defense. However, soldiers often face challenges such as in determining their precise coordinates, the inability to discern whether they are situated within a secure area, and the lack of surveillance to assess both environmental security and their physical condition on the battlefield. This study presents the development of a LoRa-based system to monitor the health of military personnel on the battlefield. Operating at 915 MHz, the prototype transmits health data from a LoRa transmitter (TX) to a receiver (RX), enabling the utilization of the data for problem-solving. The resulting personal tracking device supports soldier health surveillance during combat. The prototype incorporates various supporting components, including GPS Neo-7, MAX30102 sensor, $\mathbf{1 2 8} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{6 4}$ OLED display, and emergency (SOS) button. Performance test was conducted to evaluate transmission delay over distances ranging from 100 to 500 meters. Results showed a minimum delay of 0.12 seconds at 100 meters and a maximum delay of 5.23 seconds at 500 meters. Notably, the system successfully transmitted SOS signals at all five test points, including in non-line-of-sight (NLOS) conditions. These results demonstrate the potential of the proposed system to enhance soldier safety through real-time monitoring and reliable emergency communication.

title: Automated Brain Tumor Segmentation Using Deep Neural Networks Architectures of V-Net and W-Net
authors: K Prabhakar, C Selvi, M Birunda, S Sakthi, R Praveena, Sundara Rajulu Navaneethakrishnan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: This paper presents a systematic approach that uses contemporary deep-learning techniques to extract brain malignancies from MRI data. Clear MRI scans are first gathered, then they are refined and prepared for analysis. Segmentation of brain tumors is performed utilizing V-Net and W-Net architectures, which are specialized convolutional neural networks capable of accurately identifying and outlining tumorous regions. The overall capability of these representations is evaluated through metrics such as Dice loss and accurateness, ensuring the effectiveness and reliability of the segmentation results. This workflow aims to assist clinicians by providing precise tumor delineations, thereby supporting diagnosis and treatment planning in neuro-oncology.

title: AE-Transformer-Based Air Pollutant Concentration Prediction Model
authors: Liuman Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the accelerated process of urbanization, air pollution has become increasingly severe, particularly in terms of fine particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10). The accurate monitoring and prediction of these pollutants are crucial for environmental management and public health. However, due to the nonlinear and nonstationary nature of environmental data, traditional prediction methods exhibit certain limitations in air quality forecasting. To address this issue, this paper proposes a hybrid approach that integrates an Autoencoder and a Transformer-based prediction model. First, the Autoencoder is employed to remove noise from environmental data, thereby reducing its complexity and eliminating redundant information. Subsequently, the Transformer model leverages its strong capability of capturing long-range temporal dependencies to further model the denoised time-series data, enhancing the accuracy of air quality prediction. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to LSTM, GRU, MLP, and RNN models, the Transformer achieves the best performance in terms of MAE, RMSE, and MAPE, significantly improving the prediction accuracy and robustness. This study provides new insights into the field of air quality forecasting.

title: Enhanced System for Autonomous Navigation in Adverse Weathers
authors: Sri Darshan M, Thiruthamil M K, T Sugirtha
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel framework to improve navigation of autonomous vehicles by integrating road condition detection, trajectory prediction, and path planning to enhance the performance in a variety of environmental conditions. The proposed model uses Red Green Blue (RGB) and Near-Infrared (NIR) images to detect Adverse Weather Conditions like Fog, Rain, Snow, and Low Light for reliable environmental awareness. The condition-specific trajectory prediction reduces Root-Mean-Square Error (RMSE) as low as 0.52, showing how accurate the system is forecasting the future positions of the surrounding vehicle. The Path Planning system deploys a hybrid method involving both deterministic <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{A}^{*}$</tex> and probabilistic RRT algorithms, offering both optimum and flexible route generation that dynamically changes its configuration due to environmental conditions. By integrating this, high accuracy is achieved, comparing to other existing path planning strategies. The model was trained with IDDAW dataset with extreme conditions like fog, rain, lowlight and snow. The accuracy of our proposed model is 95.1%, which is comparatively higher than the average of other existing models. The visual outputs, together with accuracy-loss plots and by plotting paths will complement the validations for general robust conditions under challenging situations. Furthermore, the proposed integrated framework enhance the actual time decisions in the autonomous cars that would make them avoid risks, while at the same time achieve efficiency in environment with diverse road and weather conditions. Based on this methodology, great progress has been achieved towards achieving reliable autonomous navigation under complex weather conditions. It has been achieved by making seamless road condition detection, trajectory prediction, and path planning to fit within one framework, which makes the autonomous systems more robust and adaptable.

title: Bridging Formal Methods and Software Engineering Through a Tagless-Final Embedded DSL for Program Semantics
authors: Rohit Sanjay Puranik
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This paper introduces a pedagogical and practical approach to bridging formal methods and mainstream software engineering through a tagless-final Embedded Domain-Specific Language (eDSL) for executable program semantics, implemented in Scala 3. We detail the construction of a richly-typed eDSL that supports user-defined data structures, pre/post-conditions, and recursion, facilitating denotational semantics that are directly executable and type-safe. Our architecture includes two distinct Abstract Syntax Trees (ASTs)-a GADT for semantic reflection and an ADT optimized for code generation-enabling both interpretation and artifact synthesis (e.g., Scala source code). We also present a type reconstruction mechanism aligned with Scala's compiler logic, enhancing semantic fidelity. By minimizing reliance on macros and exotic metaprogramming, our design democratizes access to formal specification techniques for everyday developers. The approach demonstrates scalability via a blockchain ledger use case but is generalizable across domains, offering a roadmap for future extensions in theorem proving, testing, and code synthesis.

title: Application of Blockchain Technology for Continuous Monitoring and Defect Detection in Wireless Power Transfer Networks
authors: V. Samuthira Pandi, D Shobana, J Lakshmi Priya, Ala’a Al-Shaikh, Neeraj Sunheriya, M Dinesh
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Power transfer is a promising new technology Wireless charging networks are being deployed for a RES array, which will be used in electric vehicles, industrial automation, and biomedical implants. Yet, due to power losses, electromagnetic interference, as well as the potential of unauthorized access or malicious attacks, guaranteeing the reliability and security of WPT systems is still a big challenge. Conventional monitoring and defect detection mechanisms need to be more efficient, reactive in real-time, and prone to data tampering. Implementation of the blockchain is a promising usable solution to solve these issues due to decentralized, tamper-proofed and transparent data management characteristics of the technology. At the same time, the research presents results on the implementation of one of the blockchain-oriented technologies in terms of constant control of normal operating conditions and detection of defects in wireless power transfer (WPT) networks, thus improving the efficiency of the operation while ensuring the security of the entire system. This study presents a novel data integrity assurance and autonomous fault detection framework for WPT systems by integrating blockchain with real-time sensor networks and artificial intelligence (AI)-based analytics. Automated Responses: Smart contracts allow automatic reactions when anomalies are detected, minimizing downtime and maintenance costs. Moreover, it enables secure and transparent records of power transactions using distributed ledger technology (DLT), preventing unauthorized access to energy and enhancing accountability of the system. Results of simulation and experimental validation show the gain in defect detection accuracy, reduced fault reporting latency, and improved cyber-attack resilience of blockchain-enabled WPT networks. This research proposes a pioneering model that can utilize blockchain-based monitoring solutions to enhance the design of WPT networks, providing an innovative proof of concept that can address the limitations of such systems. In the future, research directions that address challenges such as optimizing consensus mechanisms specifically for low-power IoT devices and investigate hybrid blockchain models could improve scalability and increase transaction speed to facilitate potential real-world applications of WPT in practical cases.

title: Efficient Generation and Simulation of Synthetic Text Corpora for Scalable Information Retrieval Testing
authors: Rohit Sanjay Puranik
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Synthetic text corpora are essential for evaluating information retrieval (IR) systems, especially in scenarios where privacy concerns restrict access to real data. This paper presents a scalable and statistically grounded framework for generating synthetic corpora that replicate key statistical properties of real-world datasets. We explore and compare multiple models for simulating document length distributions-including Gaussian, negative binomial, gamma, piecewise linear, and histogram-based models-and assess their effectiveness in replicating empirical behavior. Furthermore, we introduce a compact, parameterized method for term generation based on piecewise Zipfian distributions and singleton modeling, allowing for vocabulary scalability and term co-occurrence fidelity. Our methodology supports on-the-fly corpus generation with low memory overhead, making it suitable for benchmarking indexing performance and IR scalability testing. This work advances the state-of-the-art in synthetic corpus simulation and promotes reproducible, privacy-conscious IR experimentation.

title: Novel Strategies for Integrating Blockchain and Deep Learning: Foster Ethical, Secure, and Transparent Artificial Intelligence Systems
authors: K. Janaki, A Naga Lakshman Kumar, D. Nirmala, Ibrahim Mohammad Khrais, Alok Jain, G. Karthikeyan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Blockchain technology and deep learning are converging to offer new means of building AI systems that are powerful and efficient as well as ethical, secure, and transparent. The decentralized, immutable and tamper-proof characteristics of blockchain mitigate many of the challenges that exist in deep learning, including data privacy, trust, and accountability. Deep learning, on the other hand, provides us with robust computational techniques for identifying tight relationships within massive datasets, which elevates the predictive power of AI systems. To overcome the challenges in information security, privacy, transparency, and ethical decision-making in AI, this study proposes new techniques of synergy between blockchain and deep learning AI. Some of the critical aspects of this integration are the usage of blockchain to create a verifiable audit trail of the AI model training process, data provenance, and enabling secure energyefficient sharing of data between distributed entities. In this comprehensive study, latest findings on new areas on the Confines of Blockchain & deep learning applied to AI systems are reviewed and discussed along with how the mutual complementing security aspects of each other can be providing the solutions to the risk/metrology challenges faced in AI. In addition, blockchain’s consensus mechanisms, smart contracts, and decentralized frameworks are investigated as tools to improve the transparency and fairness of AI decisionmaking processes. It also explored the combination of blockchain with federated learning, which allows the decentralized and privacy-preserving training of AI models, while maintaining the integrity of the training data. This study shows how the combination of blockchain and deep learning appears successful in constructing more ethical and trustworthy AI systems after a comprehensive review of the literature concerning existing implementations and case studies. By integrating blockchain with deep learning, the research tries to augment security and data integrity, besides addressing bigger ethical issues like accountability for AI decision making and potential data monopolization issues. This study ends with a consideration of the possible challenges to this integration, such as scalability, energy consumption and regulatory implications, and also proposes avenues for future research to improve the integration of blockchain technology with the IoT.

title: Improve the Cybersecurity Frameworks Powered by DL: Reactive Learning to Counter Emerging Threats in Multi-Layer IT Settings
authors: D Shobana
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Cyberattacks have becoming increasingly sophisticated, and static cybersecurity constructs are now not well enough equipped to secure layered IT infrastructure. Modern enterprises exist in complex interconnected systems comprised of application, network, data, and endpoint layers with their own set of vulnerabilities. Because Internet threats are constantly changing to bypass security devices and applications, the software checks itself daily to acquire the ability to identify and block new threats. In response to these challenges, DL- based reactive learning systems provide an innovative path to cybersecurity by being able to detect, adapt, and mitigate threats in real-time. This research introduces reactive learning to deep learning architectures to fight against emerging threats in multi-layer IT environment, offering this enhanced cybersecurity model. Unlike traditional static defenses, the proposed method learns in real-time from novel attack vectors such as unwarranted communication from any blocked addresses, adapting its detection models from real-time threat intelligence and behavioral analysis. The engine uses neural models like convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for packet snapping, RNNs and LSTM networks for sequencebased anomaly detection, and GANs for synthetic threat simulation, to proactively harden defenses against new attack patterns. The system includes a multi-tier defense mechanism, with each IT layer (network, transport, application, and user endpoint) having an associated deep learning-based detection and response mechanism. Consolidated threat intelligence aggregation provides the means for correlating events across layers, so that an attacker implementing coordinated multi-vector attacks that would be beyond the capabilities of any isolated security tool would not otherwise go unnoticed. Moreover, reactive learning is, by nature, the model periodically or incrementally re-trains with streaming data, which enables it to defend against new attacks with little human effort. Experimental validation in simulated enterprise IT environments shows that the proposed DLenabled reactive cybersecurity framework increases the accuracy of detection by up to 18% against conventional intrusion detection systems and reduces response time to incidents by more than 25%. The flexibility of the framework provides robustness against polymorphic malware, APTs, zero-day exploits, and beyond, providing an adaptive and selfimproving defense stance. Through the incorporation of the deep learning with the reactive learning strategies, the study offers a reference for the next generation intelligent cybersecurity systems that are able to protect multi-layer IT infrastructures in constantly changing threat landscape. It doesn’t just harden the organization; it fills in what is arguably the most serious missing line item on any security balance sheet - the ability to learn and adapt faster than the adversary.

title: Compressor-Based Approximate Multiplier Optimized for PADP with Controlled Accuracy Trade-Off
authors: Kotte Guna Karthik, Ganapathi Hegde
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: An error-tolerant application such as image processing encounters power consumption problems and complexity elevation when using multipliers, yet approximation and error correction techniques solve these difficulties. A variety of approximate compressors exist today, but researchers have not investigated their collective implementation extensively. This work introduces an innovative 4-gate 4–2 approximate compressor which integrates a multiplexer (MUX) for compatibility with previously studied compressors. A hybrid multiplier is then constructed using this compressor, a constant approximation strategy, and an error correction mechanism implemented through an AND gate. The proposed design, when synthesized on a 45nm CMOS technology node, demonstrated significant improvements-achieving up to 60.37% reduction in PDAP for 8-bit and 63.39% for 16-bit multipliers compared to exact designs, while maintaining competitive accuracy. These results confirm the design's efficiency for low-power, high-performance VLSI applications.

title: A High-Gain Tri-Band Wideband Leaky-Wave Endfire Antenna Based on Staggered Offset-Fed Dipoles
authors: Weihao Diao, Yue Li, Le Chang, Kunpeng Wei, Zhijun Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: In this communication, a high-gain tri-band wideband leaky-wave endfire antenna is proposed. By alternatively arranging offset-fed dipoles on a parallel strip line, two new modes only existing on the staggered arms are excited. The bands where the elements weakly resonate in the two modes are taken as the working band. On account of the air-substrate TEM transmission line, the propagation constant required by endfire radiation can be guaranteed in wide bands. The excitation of the 3/2 λ mode of the long arm pairs and the 1/2 λ mode of the short arm pairs spread the field to the whole transverse aperture, thus improving the high band (HB) gain. The uniform aperture field facilitates the achievement of high gain with a small length of 3.04 λL. Besides, the working band can be adjusted by tuning the length and width of the long and short arms. The proposed antenna exhibits high gains of up to 11.6, 12.1, and 15.7 dBi, respectively in the low band (LB), the middle band (MB), and the HB. The 3dB gain bandwidths of 8.5%, 54.8%, and 22.1% cover the Wi-Fi 6 bands with broad bandwidth and high gain, indicating an excellent point-to-point communication capability.

title: An Intelligent Optimization Platform Using Edge Computing and IoT Sensors for Home Energy Management
authors: Aparna Sharma, Chanchal Jayant, Ritika, Birendra Kumar Saraswat, Ahimsa Bhardwaj, Tarun Kumar Sharma
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: An intelligent optimization platform using edge computing and the Internet of Things (IoT) sensors for home energy management is designed to address this problem. Cloud computing methods and placing scalable area computing techniques collectively to price records regionally instead of sending all data returned to a centralized server would enable software to keep network payload down. It decreases the necessity for real-time cloud connectivity and, thus, makes decision-making more quick. The system would rely on IoT sensors placed throughout the house that provide readings of power will-use, climate patterns, and consumer behavior. The platform uses advanced algorithms to filter this data, which can improve energy consumption or reduce wastage. It is like upgrading HVAC systems, shutting off energy-sucking appliances, or running high-consumption electricity use during non-peak hours. It also has devices learning to understand the exact electricity consumption patterns unique to each house and provide tailored energy management solutions. With this home energy management solution based on edge computing and IoT sensors, an economical, more efficient, and easily expandable comes to life with the power of integration. Its purpose is not only to help cut strength prices for customers, but it also has a part in the broader sustainability goals of the energy sector.

title: Fractal Antennas for Wearable Devices of Fire Fighters in Body Area Network
authors: T. Sampath, A. Kavitha
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Body Area Network technology is rapidly evolving, presenting a future where wearable devices seamlessly integrate with our lives, fostering a new era of personalized healthcare through wearable devices. These gadgets need antennas that can generate precise results while withstanding human motion and being noise-immune. The antennas ought to be small and flexible. The substrate has a significant impact on the antenna's flexibility. A miniature wearable patch antenna for body area network (BAN) application is presented in this research. The antenna reduces its size by 31% over traditional designs by using a crown fractal design technique. Furthermore, a flexible Rogers RT Duroid 5880 substrate is used, which qualifies the antenna for use in wearable medical equipment. With a gain of 4.54 dB and a bandwidth of 145 MHz, the proposed antenna covers the 2.45 GHz ISM band when operating. Simulations analyze the antenna's performance through return loss (S11), radiation pattern, and directivity [1] [2]. The results make it a strong candidate for wearable BAN applications.

title: ImageReviveCore: A Dynamic Framework for Real-Time Image Enhancement and High-Accuracy Noise Reduction
authors: M. Manonmani, R. Arun Kumar, Thanisha SK, Thejaas S, Ubermensch Kargil K, Sruthi M
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Image enhancement and noise reduction play essential roles in the use of imaging systems in remote sensing, medical fields, and security cameras and for personal photography. Even so, the majority of current denoising algorithms are either hard to apply or do not effectively deal with all types of noise in real life. Therefore, we suggest ImageReviveCore which uses various techniques to combine convolutional and transformer architectures, scale factors and attention to achieve high-performing image restoration quickly. The system is built on a CNN-Swin Transformer backbone, use of spatio-temporal attention and adaptive denoising paths directed by reinforcement agents. Ten benchmark datasets like DIV2K, BSD68, Set5 and Urban100 were carefully evaluated using various image quality metrics. It is shown that ImageReviveCore has better results than DnCNN and RIDNet with their average PSNR reaching 32.56 dB and SSIM at 0.874 and performs in real time (taking less than 165 ms for 1080p images). Perception and numbers from BRISQUE make it clearer that my method is better than other techniques. The model's average user rating is 4.5/5, meaning that people find the visuals very pleasing. With edge-aware enhancement, content-adaptive fixing and scalable use, ImageReviveCore raises the standard for restoring images in real-life cases. It is particularly designed for live use in things like embedded systems, mobile imaging and telemedicine. Progressive work will prioritize making models smaller, combining different types of images and applying federated learning for security in mobile applications.

title: Information-Theoretic Limits of Quantum Learning via Data Compression
authors: Armando Angrisani, Brian Coyle, Elham Kashefi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: Understanding the power of quantum data in machine learning is central to many proposed applications of quantum technologies. While access to quantum data can offer exponential advantages for carefully designed learning tasks and often under strong assumptions on the data distribution, it remains an open question whether such advantages persist in less structured settings and under more realistic, naturally occurring distributions. Motivated by these practical concerns, we introduce a systematic framework based on quantum lossy data compression to bound the power of quantum data in the context of probably approximately correct (PAC) learning. Specifically, we provide lower bounds on the sample complexity of quantum learners for arbitrary functions when data is drawn from Zipf's distribution, a widely used model for the empirical distributions of real-world data. We also establish lower bounds on the size of quantum input data required to learn linear functions, thereby proving the optimality of previous positive results. Beyond learning theory, we show that our framework has applications in secure delegated quantum computation within the measurement-based quantum computation (MBQC) model. In particular, we constrain the amount of private information the server can infer, strengthening the security guarantees of the delegation protocol proposed in (Mantri et al., PRX, 2017) [1].

title: A Proposal for an Self-Rescue System Based on offline LLM for Minor Injuries after an Earthquake
authors: Francesco Carotenuto, Giovanni Acampora, Aldo Zollo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Earthquakes cause several losses every year, both in terms of human lives and infrastructure damage. Therefore, it is increasingly important to think of new tools that reduce the damage caused by an earthquake as much as possible. In this context, the role of Earthquake Early Warning Systems (EEWSs) is becoming increasingly significant. These systems can rapidly detect earthquakes and issue alerts that guide emergency safety actions. They capture ground shaking shortly after an earthquake occurs and raise alarms in target areas with an advance of seconds to several tens of seconds before the strong ground motion impacts on target infrastructures. This paper proposes the design of an system intended to assist a moderately injured operator, after a seismic event within a critical environment, who is unable to communicate with emergency responders. The system provides autonomous self-rescue instructions that aim to mitigate the risk of additional complications from injuries. The system architecture is based on the integration of Large Language Models (LLMs) offline with the continuous monitoring of selected vital parameters, periodically acquired through wearable smartwatch technology.

title: OTFS-Based ISAC using Zadoff–Chu Pilots and Iterative Delay–Doppler Map Refinement
authors: Budiman P.A. Rohman, Ratna Indrawijaya, Dayat Kurniawan, Chaeriah Bin Ali Wael, Suyoto, Agus Subekti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation has recently attracted attention for integrated sensing and communications system (ISAC) due to its resilience against doubly-selective channels. In this paper, we propose an enhanced OTFS-based ISAC framework that combines a Zadoff-Chu piloting with a weighted linear minimum mean square error channel estimator. An iterative refinement loop to delay-Doppler (DD) map is further introduced to improve the channel estimate. Numerical simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms the orthogonal frequency division multiplexing based method, achieving lower bit error rates in single and multiple target under various observed environments. Besides, the proposed framework able to detect the existence of the object through DD map visualization. These results highlight the feasibility of the proposed framework toward ISAC system in real world.

title: Real-Time Image Processing for Fault Detection in Electronic Circuit Boards Using Deep Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: M Zahid Alam, Monika Kapoor
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: In this paper, a novel approach using deep convolutional neural network (CNN) is proposed for real-time fault detection in electronic PCBs. The developed model is capable of detecting and classifying different types of defects including open circuits, short circuits and missing holes in high resolution PCB images. Trained on a richly annotated dataset of various PCB designs, our model is able to capture intricate pattern and defect representations. Data augmentation methods improve the generalization of the model, while Grad-CAM visualizations help to unravel the black box model. Numerical measures accuracy, precision, recall and f1-score demonstrate that the trained model is robust across different design categories. The system's low inferencing time shows that it could be deployed in real-time in an industrial production context, providing an affordable solution for PCB inspection automatization.

title: 'Climashield': Quantum-Enhanced Smart Textiles for Adaptive Thermal Regulation and Biometric Monitoring in Defense Environments
authors: Nehaiman Alqubaisi, Omar Nabeel, Ali Alhammadi, Ali Alhashmi, Abdullah Salem, Ahmed Shuhaiber
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: ClimaShield is an advanced smart textile developed for military and law enforcement personnel operating in extreme environments. The research addresses the problem of ineffective thermal regulation and limited real-time health monitoring in current tactical gear. This study aims to create a self-powered, intelligent wearable that integrates thermoelectric fabrics, biometric sensors, and quantum AI chips for dynamic temperature control and physiological tracking. Using bismuth telluride nanofibers, the system harvests heat to power embedded components. The methodology follows Design Thinking and I-Team models to iteratively prototype and test sensor integration and quantum inference. Results show over 92% of user approval for comfort, accuracy, and operational efficiency. ClimaShield reduces logistical burden, enhances safety, and contributes a scalable, autonomous solution that advances the convergence of smart textiles, AI, and quantum computing in defense applications.

title: Structural Design of an Autonomous Mobile Rebar-Tying Robot
authors: Haijie Yang, Xingping Liu, Hao Duan, Haili Jiang, Shuai Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: Addressing the issues of low efficiency and high labor intensity in manual rebar tying, this paper presents the design of a fully automatic rebar tying robot (970 mm × 660 mm × 520 mm), The robot integrates three core modules: longitudinal movement (self-adaptive wheel system for adapting to spacing and cushioning impacts), transverse movement (lifting-disengaging mechanism + chain transmission for precise positioning), and automatic tying (multi-DOF fine-tuning). It can autonomously traverse the rebar mesh surface and precisely locate tying nodes. The paper elaborates on its structural design, working principle, and control flow. Experimental validation demonstrates that the robot efficiently and stably performs longitudinal movement, transverse movement, and tying tasks, providing an effective solution for construction automation.

title: Data Processing and Verification of Flight Performance Simulation
authors: Jin Lei, Liu Jianchao, Ji Siyu, Rong Hange, Zhao Yunan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: The simulation accuracy of flight simulators directly affects training effectiveness. The current verification technologies and methods for flight performance simulation models of flight simulators rely on subjective evaluations based on pilots' experience. Therefore, this paper proposes a verification method for flight performance simulation models based on flight dynamics theory, designs dynamic simulation software, and adds a setting and display platform for control and flight quality, to conduct simulation experiments for verification. The research results show that the proposed verification method can effectively improve the quality and reliability of flight simulators, meet the objective verification needs of simulator developers for flight performance simulation models, and is of great significance for enhancing the effectiveness of flight simulators.

title:
Performance of ABC
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    -Structured Perovskite Solar Cells: Impact of Composition and Deposition Method
authors: Carlos Castañeda, Camilo Hernández, Sergio Castro, Byron Medina, Oriana López, Dinael Guevara, Erick Reyes, Alexander Sepúlveda
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have demonstrated rapid efficiency improvements over the past decade, emerging as a leading candidate in the development of third-generation photovoltaic technologies. This paper presents a statistical analysis of 41,498 experimental PSCs with confirmed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$ABC_{3}$</tex> crystal structure, exploring the relationship between power conversion efficiency (PCE) and two key factors: perovskite composition and fabrication method. Using a cleaned dataset derived from The Perovskite Database, only materials and processes with more than 200 entries were included to ensure robust comparisons. Results show that hybrid compositions, particularly those involving methylammonium (MA), formamidinium (FA), and cesium (Cs), consistently outperform purely inorganic and tin-based formulations. Likewise, multi-step spin-coating and doctor blading techniques yield the highest average and median efficiencies. A heatmap matrix highlights specific material-process combinations associated with superior PCE values. These findings provide practical insights for optimizing PSC design and manufacturing strategies while supporting sustainable technology development through data-driven decision-making.

title: Skin Disease Classification Using Wavelet Scattering Transform and Color Layout Descriptor
authors: Pramod Sharma, A. K. Verma, Shivani Lavaniya
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Skin illness is one of the major worldwide health issues that causes physical and psychological suffering and, in extreme cases, can progress to life threatening skin cancer. In the field of medical image analysis, accurately diagnosing skin conditions from clinical photographs is a difficult task. In the proposed work, a Machine Learning (ML) based method is presented which can identify the cancerous (Malign) and noncancerous (Benign) skin disease types from the input skin images. The proposed scheme utilizes the strength of Wavelet Scattering Transform (WST) and the Color Layout Descriptor (CLD) of Mpeg-7. The Wavelet Scattering Transform is used to capture texture features while Color Layout Descriptor is a strong color feature extractor. Both WST and CLD together have given competitive outcomes and recognition accuracy of 98.25%. As the proposed scheme uses Machine Learning, it does not require large image dataset like Deep Learning. Also, it is faster and robust. The skin images used for training and testing are taken from ISIC image database.

title: EEG Correlates of Vection: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Gael Van der Lee, Francois Cabestaing, Hakim Si-Mohammed
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Vection, the illusory sensation of self-motion induced by visual stimuli, is fundamental to understanding sensory integration and has significant implications for virtual reality (VR) and motion sickness research. This review synthesizes findings from 16 peer-reviewed studies that employed electroencephalography (EEG) to investigate the neural correlates of vection. We find that EEG research consistently identifies modulations in the alpha frequency band (a), particularly over parieto-occipital regions, as a key neural signature. Early visual event-related potentials (ERPs), notably the N2 component, also serve as reliable correlates, indexing the initial processing and integration of motion cues sensitive to stimulus properties. Neural activity patterns are further influenced by stimulus characteristics (e.g., field-of-view, motion type), task demands, and individual differences, including handedness and susceptibility to visually induced motion sickness (VIMS). Emerging research explores network connectivity and demonstrates the potential for manipulation of vection via non-invasive brain stimulation targeting a oscillations. Despite these advances, considerable methodological heterogeneity in stimuli, EEG analysis, and vection assessment across studies currently limits direct comparison and the establishment of universally accepted biomarkers. Future research with standardized protocols and larger sample sizes is necessary to solidify these findings. Nonetheless, EEG stands as a valuable tool for exploring the temporal dynamics of vection, offering potential pathways to enhance VR design, mitigate adverse effects like motion sickness, and deepen our understanding of human self-motion perception.

title: Performance Analysis of IRS-Assisted Cell-Free Massive MIMO-URLLC Systems
authors: Yiling Chen, Cai Zhang, Meng Wang, Wenqing Li, Sinian Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRSs) have emerged as a transformative solution for enhancing the performance of Internet of Things (IoT) devices, particularly in areas where coverage is limited in cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) networks. This enhancement is especially crucial in ultra-reliable and low-latency communication (URLLC) environments, where stringent requirements on reliability and latency are imposed. In this work, we investigate the rate characteristics of a cell-free massive MIMO system augmented by IRSs, operating under Rician fading conditions within a URLLC framework. We begin by formulating a comprehensive system model that captures both the wireless channel and the downlink transmission scheme. Assuming ideal uplink channel state information (CSI) for the composite links between access points, IRSs, and end users, we derive two analytical expressions representing the achievable rate under maximum ratio transmission (MRT) precoding. These formulations shed light on efficient strategies for power allocation and phase adjustment, thereby facilitating more effective resource optimization. To validate our theoretical findings, we conduct a series of numerical experiments that confirm the precision and practical utility of the proposed rate models.

title: Comparative Study of Reinforcement Learning-Enhanced Control Strategies for Nonlinear Multidimensional Systems
authors: Patryk Ba∤azy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: This paper investigates the application of reinforcement learning (RL) in the control of nonlinear multidimensional systems, specifically focusing on an overhead crane as the test object. Three distinct RL-based control strategies are compared: direct control using RL agent actions, feedback regulator enhancement through RL agent actions, and auxiliary control signals provided by RL agent actions to the feedback regulator. Each control system was initially trained on a mathematical model of the crane and subsequently fine-tuned on the actual physical system. The direct control approach leverages the RL agent's actions as immediate control inputs, aiming for rapid adaptation to dynamic changes. The feedback enhancement strategy integrates RL actions to refine the feedback loop, improving stability and response time. The auxiliary control method uses RL actions to support the primary feedback regulator, enhancing overall system robustness. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of each approach, with detailed performance metrics highlighting their respective advantages and limitations. This study provides valuable insights into the practical implementation of RL-based control systems for complex, real-world applications.

title: Phase Recognition Based Electrical Fire Protection Current Limiting Protector Test Platform
authors: Chao Sun, Xiaobai Li, Xu Jing
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Electrical fire protection current limiting protector is a safety device used to prevent electrical fires. It can effectively overcome the drawbacks of traditional circuit breakers, such as long interruption time of short-circuit current and large arc sparks generated during short-circuit, and achieve microsecond level current limiting. Based on the principle of voltage and current phase recognition, combined with load dynamic adjustment function, an electrical fireproof current limiting protector test platform with phase recognition function has been developed, which solves the problems of poor consistency of product test results and single current limiting protection testing methods. The platform has been applied to product testing and achieved good results. The application of the platform is conducive to further promoting the improvement of protector product quality.

title: Revolutionizing Healthcare Data Anonymity
authors: Shreya G. Tendulkar, Parikshit N. Mahalle
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: In modern healthcare, safeguarding patient privacy amidst rapid digital transformation is paramount. This study rethinks the management of sensitive health data by proposing a framework that decouples personal identity from service delivery. By leveraging distributed ledger technology for immutable record-keeping, employing anonymous digital payment systems to obscure transaction trails, and utilizing decentralized storage networks for secure data access, the framework enables the confidential provision of services such as diagnostic testing, genetic screening, and legal consultations. This innovative approach not only complies with stringent regulatory standards but also enhances trust and fairness between patients and providers, paving the way for a more secure and patient-centric digital health ecosystem.

title: Benchmarking and Evaluating Time Series Databases for Appliance-Level Energy Consumption Data
authors: Simin Shehbaz, Mohammad Mehabadi, Kenneth B. Kent
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Time series databases (TSDBs) are widely used to store high-frequency energy consumption data, but their performance varies depending on workload characteristics. This paper benchmarks leading TSDBs to identify their suitability to handle appliance-level, per-minute energy data. While prior work has evaluated TSDBs, limited research has been done on TSDBs for wide-format, fine-grained residential energy data at the appliance level. We introduce a custom-generated dataset simulating the usage of twenty-six appliances across five household types in a wide-format schema. Building on the TSM-Bench framework, we adapt it to support our appliance-level dataset, domain-specific workloads, and evaluation metrics. We analyze ingestion and query performance across three TSDBs that support this wideformat, while highlighting the trade-offs in latency, resource usage, throughput and storage. Looking ahead, we plan to evaluate schema transformations (wide to narrow), explore additional TSDBs optimized for narrow-format ingestion and compare their performance against wide-format results. These measures aim to provide a comprehensive and format-aware comparison of TSDBs.

title: Dependency Then Compression: Global Dependency Network with Three-Stage Knowledge Transfer for Visible-Infrared Transmission Line Detection
authors: Wujie Zhou, Beibei Tang, Meixin Fang, Yuanyuan Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Although deep learning techniques have largely solved the transmission line detection (TLD) problem, three major challenges remain. First, most methods ignore the effects of visible and infrared images on the predicted maps. Second, they fail to generalize adequately to future unseen data. Third, methods that limit the number of model parameters often reduce the model complexity and degrade the performance. To resolve the aforementioned issues, we designed global dependency networks (GDNet-S* and GDNet-S) utilizing three-stage knowledge distillation (KD) for TLD. First, to extract useful information from visible and infrared images, we developed two generators that extract essential information from the main and auxiliary images, respectively. Second, we designed a Bayesian module to enhance the ability of the model to generalize to new data. Finally, we designed three KD methods for encoding the basic, relational, and output features of the student and teacher networks to improve the performance without changing the GDNet-S parameters. Comprehensive experiments on a TLD dataset demonstrated that both GDNet-T and GDNet-S* achieved outstanding performance. Furthermore, to validate the generalizability of GDNet-S*, we tested it on three public RGB-D datasets. GDNet-S* achieved moderately competitive results on these datasets. The experimental results and network code can be accessed at github.com/BeibeiIsFreshman/GDNet.

title: Clustering Techniques for Survey Response in Education Using Large Language Models
authors: Emelie C. Villaceran, Alaine Tess A. Cabije
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are transforming education through personalized learning and intelligent tutoring. However, their outputs often lack semantic coherence, limiting pedagogical effectiveness. This study applies clustering techniques—K-Means and Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering (AHC)—to organize survey responses from 396 participants at Cebu Technological University, focusing on seven pedagogical constructs: Rethinking Assessment and Examinations (RAE), Generic Skills (GS), Preparing Students for the AI-Driven Work-place (PS), Balanced AI Adoption (BA), Perceived Usefulness (PU), Perceived Ease of Use (PEOU), and Intention to Use LLMs (IU). Descriptive analysis revealed high mean scores for GS (4.02), PS (3.96), and BA (3.88), indicating favorable perceptions. Correlation analysis showed strong relationships, with GS and PS (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r=0.887$</tex>) and BA and PS (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r=0.878$</tex>) being most correlated. K-Means clustering identified three optimal clusters, supported by silhouette scores (0.303) and decreasing withincluster variance. ANOVA confirmed significant differentiation among clusters, with PS <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{6 05.08}, p<0.0001)$</tex> as the most influential variable. Cluster profiles revealed distinct attitudinal patterns, from high engagement to skepticism. These findings validate clustering as a tool for organizing educational survey data, enhancing the interpretability of LLM-related perceptions and informing adaptive, AI-enhanced learning environments.

title: Robust Image Caption Generator Based on Gemini 1.5 Flash with Transformer and ResNet50 Fallbacks
authors: Richa Mishra, Swati Srivastava
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Current studies in image captioning are usually plagued by various shortcomings such as they tend to produce incomplete or irrelevant descriptions, especially in the case of intricate scenes, uncommon objects, or image style changes. The majority of methods lack effective means to encode the multifaceted relationships between visual features and their respective textual descriptions. This work resolves these issues by introducing a new multi-model image captioning network that incorporates a fallback design. Our strategy takes advantage of the Gemini 1.5 Flash API as the main caption generation model, supplemented by a Transformer-based and a ResNet50-based fallback, to guarantee both high accuracy and service availability. In particular, we combine the Gemini 1.5 Flash API and implement a solid error recovery mechanism to cope with API failures and provide uninterrupted service. Experiments show that the solution offered in this work enhances service availability and user satisfaction through realtime and natural language captions. This work also adds to the development of image captioning with improved reliability and user experience for various applications.

title: Statistical Tool-Based Reliability Analysis of the UGC Quality Mandates Questionnaire: A Cronbach's Alpha Approach
authors: Neha Srivastava, Mala Tandon, Mitima Sachdeva, Pallavi Asthana
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Quality in higher education is crucial for the growth of the country, as it builds the skills, knowledge that encourage professional growth of the people. Professional skills are driving the economy, innovations, academics, administration, and industries of the country. To bring uniformity in the educational process across India, UGC (University Grant Commission) issued mandatory guidelines for all Higher Education Institutions in the country. These guidelines are known as Mandates. In 2018, UGC introduced quality mandates to enhance the quality of education in higher education to enhance employability for graduates through meaningful teaching and learning practices. This work aims to determine the level of higher education teachers' awareness in the colleges and universities of Lucknow district in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India. This method utilizes Exploratory Factor Analysis (EFA) and Confirmatory Factor Analysis (CFA) as statistical tools to determine the internal consistency of responses for multiple variables and confirm this through analyzing the responses under the same variable. 92 samples were tested for the 15 test items on various quality mandates. These samples comprise the responses of 55 female and 37 male teachers. Responses show a high level of awareness among the teachers. Validation of the questions' consistency is done through exploratory factor analysis and confirmatory factor analysis. Cronbach's alpha (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex>) is used as a statistical tool to determine the inner consistency. The calculated value of Cronbach's alpha has validated the inner consistency between the questions through EFA and CFA which verifies the authenticity of the responses.

title: Parameter Sensitivity Analysis of Bidirectional Wireless Power Transfer System Based on LCC-S Topology for EVs
authors: Fanbin Meng, Hongsheng Hu, Yugang Su, Zhengjun Su, Zhiping Zuo
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Bidirectional wireless power transfer (BD-WPT) systems, characterized by their safety, reliability, convenience, flexibility, and strong environmental adaptability, are playing an increasingly significant role in EV charging applications. Currently, the majority of bidirectional WPT systems adopt bilaterally symmetric structures, while limited research has been conducted on asymmetric compensation networks. This paper focuses on the parameter sensitivity of a BD-WPT system based on the LCC-S compensation topology for EVs. A system model is established, and the conditions for power transmission are derived. To investigate the sensitivity characteristics of power transfer, a parametric analysis is performed on the DC bus voltage and phase shift angles (internal and external), identifying the most influential parameters and their operational mechanisms. Finally, the theoretical model and parametric sensitivity of power transmission are validated through MATLAB/Simulink simulations.

title: Design of an Advanced Variable Step MPPT-Fed Fuel Stack System
authors: Sayeeda Farzana, Ch Hussaian Basha, Nagaraju Dharava, Muralikrishna Boddu, Santoshi Kanagala, Pawan Kumar Pathak
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: From the present energy production scenario, it has been studied that renewable energy installation is improving all over the world because of its merits friendly environmental nature and better reliability. So, in this work, the fuel cell energy system is referred to as providing electricity to hydrogen vehicles. However, the fuel stack peak energy delivered from the fuel module device is very difficult because it supplies continuously disturbed nonlinear energy, which is not recommended for the consumer automotive system. So, the Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) concept is included in the fuel module energy production system. Here, the traditional Perturb & Observe and Incremental conductance technologies are investigated to select the appropriate MPPT block for the introduced fuel module system. Finally, the fuel stack voltage delivery is a low value. So, the non-isolated converter technology is referred to as boosting the voltage levels of the fuel stack system. This proposal is analyzed by using MATLAB software.

title: YOLOX Speed Improvement through Pruning, Quantization, and TensorRT for Object Tracking in Football Match Analysis
authors: Zacky Faishal Abror, Fadhil Radja Assyidiq, Priyanto Hidayatullah, Yudi Widhiyasana
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Occlusion is still a challenge in object tracking, especially in Football Match Video Analysis. Deep-EIoU (Deep Expansion Intersection over Union) is a multi-object tracking method that enhances object association in occlusion-heavy scenarios by combining IoU-based bounding box matching with deep feature embeddings. In the context of football match analysis, it leverages YOLOX as its object detector, but the detector's high computational demands become a bottleneck for real-time applications. This study proposes an optimization strategy combining architectural pruning, FP16 quantization, and TensorRT acceleration to reduce inference latency. The proposed method reduces YOLOX parameters from 99 million to 39.56 million. It enhances system throughput by 3.5x increasing from 4.22 to 14.84 FPS, without compromising tracking accuracy on NVIDIA T4 GPU hardware. The accuracy is validated by the Higher Order Tracking Accuracy (HOTA) metric. These results demonstrate a practical and efficient approach to improving detector performance in end-to-end multi-object tracking systems for sports analytics

title:
