                    : Improved Collaborative Consortium of Foundation Models for Open-World Few-Shot Learning
authors: Shuai Shao, Rui Xu, Bingfeng Zhang, Baodi Liu, Weifeng Liu, Yicong Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Open-World Few-Shot Learning (OFSL) is a critical research domain focused on accurately identifying target samples under conditions where data is scarce and labels are unreliable. This field is highly relevant to real-world scenarios, holding significant practical implications. Currently, the field has only a few solutions, primarily relying on conventional methods such as metric learning and feature aggregation. However, these methods often struggle in more complex scenarios. Recent breakthroughs in foundation models such as CLIP and DINO have demonstrated their strong representational capabilities, even in resource-limited environments. These advancements have led to a shift from “training model from scratch” towards “exploiting the extensive capabilities and expertise of these pre-trained foundation models for OFSL”. Inspired by this shift, we introduce the Improved Collaborative Consortium of Foundation Models (CO<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup><sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>), an extension of CO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>, first presented in AAAI 2024. CO<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup><sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3 </sub>significantly improves the accuracy of OFSL by integrating the strengths of four foundational models. It includes three decoupled blocks: (1) The Label Correction Block (LC-Block) rectifies unreliable labels, (2) the Data Augmentation Block (DA-Block) enriches the available data, and (3) the Text-guided Fusion Adapter (TeFu-Adapter) merges various features and reduces the impact of noisy labels through semantic constraints. We evaluate CO<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup><sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> across eleven benchmark datasets, comparing it against recent state-of-the-art methods. Our thorough evaluations demonstrate that the proposed CO<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup><sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub> consistently surpasses existing methods by a substantial margin, particularly in high-noise scenarios.

title: QCA-MolGAN: Quantum Circuit Associative Molecular GAN with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Aaron Mark Thomas, Yu-Cheng Chen, Hubert Okadome Valencia, Sharu Theresa Jose, Ronin Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: Navigating the vast chemical space of molecular structures to design novel drug molecules with desired target properties remains a central challenge in drug discovery. Recent advances in generative models offer promising solutions. This work presents a novel quantum circuit Born machine (QCBM)enabled Generative Adversarial Network (GAN), called QCAMolGAN, for generating drug-like molecules. The QCBM serves as a learnable prior distribution, which is associatively trained to define a latent space aligning with high-level features captured by the GANs discriminator. Additionally, we integrate a novel multiagent reinforcement learning network to guide molecular generation with desired targeted properties, optimising key metrics such as quantitative estimate of drug-likeness (QED), octanol-water partition coefficient (LogP) and synthetic accessibility (SA) scores in conjunction with one another. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach enhances the property alignment of generated molecules with the multi-agent reinforcement learning agents effectively balancing chemical properties.

title: Embodiment in Nature: How Avatar Choice Shapes an Underwater Virtual Reality Experience
authors: Antonella Giangualano, Paolo Boffi, Sofia Adelaide Osimo, Mona Yavari, Alessandro Gabbiadini, Pier Luca Lanzi, Alberto Gallace
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Immersive Virtual Reality (IVR) applications are increasingly used to foster environmental awareness and promote pro-environmental behaviors by reducing psychological distance and enhancing nature-connectedness. In this study, we investigated how different avatars, in an underwater educational IVR experience, influence users' Sense of Embodiment (SoE), measured through self-reported and physiological measures (Electrodermal Activity – EDA). Results showed that the Sense of Agency plays a key role in enhancing overall SoE, raising it when users embody an avatar capable of free movement and interaction. Conversely, restricted interactivity resulted in higher EDA, suggesting that this may be due to the frustration caused by the unmet desire to move and explore.

title: A Fire Emergency Light System-on-Chip Design Methodology
authors: Yong Pan, Jing Xu, Ruifen Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: To address the issues of low integration and poor reliability in fire emergency lights designed using discrete components or simple control chips, this paper proposes a design methodology for high-performance, high-reliability, and highly integrated fire emergency lights based on the System-on-Chip (SoC) concept. By combining C language programming with a co-design approach of digital circuits, the design achieves functions such as main circuit monitoring, battery charge/discharge protection, and fault alarm indication. The main working characteristics of the fire emergency light were simulated using software, and the test results showed that the design functions were consistent with the software simulation results, verifying the correctness of the SoC design methodology for fire emergency lights.

title: Degradation Mechanism of Meta-Aramid Pressboard under Multi-Field Coupling Aging
authors: Jiayi Chen, Guan Wang, Kuo Yan, Hongbin Wu, Hongshun Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Converter transformers are critical for the reliable operation of high-voltage direct current systems, yet they operate under harsh conditions involving high electrical stress, elevated temperatures, and mechanical vibrations. Conventional cellulose pressboard exhibits limited resistance to these combined stresses, which motivates the use of meta-aramid pressboard as a promising alternative insulation material. To elucidate the multi-field coupling aging mechanisms of meta-aramid pressboard, this study develops a thermal-electrical-mechanical multi-field coupling aging platform. The degree of polymerization is employed to quantitatively evaluate macroscopic aging progression. Scanning electron microscopy is used to observe surface morphology evolution, including fiber peeling, microcrack generation, and pore formation, while X-ray diffraction characterizes changes in crystal structure, diffraction intensity, crystallinity, and microcrystalline size at different aging stages. Breakdown strength is measured to evaluate the evolution of dielectric withstand capability under different aging conditions. Furthermore, molecular dynamics simulations are carried out to calculate cohesive energy density and the number of hydrogen bonds under different field combinations, providing molecular-scale insight into structural deterioration. The results indicate that thermal aging induces more pronounced microstructural and mechanical degradation of the meta-aramid pressboard than electrical or mechanical loading, while superimposed electrical and mechanical stresses mainly act to further intensify the deterioration caused by thermal aging. Overall, the combined action of thermal, electrical, and mechanical stresses produces a synergistic effect that significantly accelerates the hierarchical degradation of meta-aramid pressboard.

title: A 12-b 3-GS/s Pipelined ADC With Piecewise-Linear Gain Nonlinearity Calibration
authors: Mingyang Gu, Yi Zhong, Lu Jie, Nan Sun
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Solid-State Circuits Society
abstract: This article presents a novel piecewise-linear gain nonlinearity calibration technique with low computational complexity and background coefficient extraction, enabling the use of open-loop amplifiers in pipelined ADCs for high energy efficiency. In addition to the gain nonlinearity calibration, circuit innovations such as a dual-path amplification scheme and a high-speed flash comparator are also introduced. Incorporating these techniques, a prototype 12-b 3-GS/s pipelined ADC is fabricated in a 28-nm CMOS process. Including the on-chip calibration engine, it consumes 50.5 mW and achieves an SNDR of 58.8 dB with a 1.5-GHz input, corresponding to a competitive FoMS of 164 dB.

title: Analyzing Local Texture Patterns for Estimating Tropical Cyclone Intensity Over the North Indian Ocean
authors: Pinto Das, Diganta Das, Chinmoy Kar, Swagata Paul, Shiladitya Munshi
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: This study investigates the effectiveness of five local texture descriptors—Local Binary Pattern (LBP), Completed Local Binary Pattern (CLBP), Local Ternary Pattern (LTP), Median Binary Pattern (MBP), and Multi-Modal Local Binary Pattern (MMLBP)—for classifying tropical cyclone intensity using satellite imagery. Each descriptor was evaluated in combination with five machine learning classifiers: Naive Bayes, Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Decision Tree, and Random Forest. The models were assessed using accuracy, F1 score, and ROC AUC metrics. This study shows that the LTP with Random Forest classifier achieved the highest accuracy of 90.71%. The results demonstrate that texture-based features combined with classical machine learning approaches can provide high accuracy, with the added benefits of simplicity and the ability to work on a small dataset, making them suitable for real-time meteorological applications. Future work will explore the integration of time-series data and additional meteorological parameters such as sea surface temperature and wind speed to further enhance prediction performance.

title: Selection of Statistical, Embedding and Distance-Based Metrics for Evaluating LLMs in Text Generation Tasks
authors: Krity Kansara, Tareeshi Mittal, Rahul Mahadik, Pavan Laxmeshwar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: With the rapid rise of Large Language Models (LLMs), they have become an essential part of our daily lives. Among their many applications, text generation stands out as a particularly impactful domain, sometimes even involving high-stakes decision-making. As more LLMs are developed, a growing number of evaluation methods and metrics have also emerged to assess their performance. Although recent advances have introduced several new evaluation techniques, this document reaffirms the continued relevance of Statistical, Embedding, and Distance-based evaluation metrics. In today's landscape, characterized by numerous tools and overlapping approaches, it is often challenging to determine the most appropriate metric for a given task. This work aims to provide clarity by suggesting suitable metrics for specific text generation tasks. We center our analysis on the task of Question-Answering, using it as a case study to demonstrate how carefully selected evaluation metrics can meaningfully distinguish the performance of three state-of-the-art LLMs. Our findings suggest that employing a small set of well-chosen metrics is effective and sufficient for robust model evaluation.

title: Benchmarking of YOLO Variants for Robust Small Object Detection
authors: Sanchi Kalra, Udayan Ghose
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Small object detection is an indispensable challenge in computer vision due to issues such as low resolution, background clutter, and occlusion. This study conducts a comparative evaluation of four prominent YOLO (You Only Look Once) variants, namely, YOLOv3, YOLOv5 (n, m, x), YOLOv8 (n, m, x), and YOLOv12 (n, m, x) for their effectiveness in detecting small objects on a curated MS COCO subset. Models are evaluated using mAP@0.5, mAP@0.5:0.95, precision, recall, and inference speed. The analysis indicate consistent gains with each generation in both accuracy and localization precision. YOLOv12x outperformed all other variants with mAP@0.5 = 0.846, mAP@0.5:0.95 = 0.7419, Precision = 0.6022, and Recall = 0.2666. However, it marginally surpassed YOLOv3 in fine-grained accuracy while matching its coarse localization. YOLOv12m demonstrated a strong balance between speed and accuracy, making it viable choice for balanced workloads. YOLOv8x also performed competitively with mAP@0.5 of 0.8051 and an improved recall over YOLOv5x. The ultralight variants like YOLOv8n and YOLOv12n maintained a reasonable detection accuracy with less than 90s inference speed. Thus, making them ideal for edge and resource constrained deployments. The study also revealed that the recent models exhibit smaller reductions in mAP@0.5 and mAP@0.5:0.95, reflecting that bounding box regression and spatial accuracy under stricter IoU thresholds has generationally improved. YOLOv3, while achieving good performance in coarse detection was less performant in recall and fine localization, illustrating the impact of modern enhancements such as anchor-free prediction, and attention-based feature aggregation. The results validate that the improvement in performance of small object detection are due to the architectural evolution in YOLO family. High-end models, such as YOLOv12x achieve state-of-the-art accuracy for precision-dependent tasks, while lightweight variants offer competitive real-time detections for embedded and resource-constrained environments, broadening the applicability of YOLO models to diverse computer vision applications.

title: Miniature Arduino-Compatible Rover for Accessible Mechatronics Education
authors: Kristijan Nelkovski, Danijela Efnusheva, Marija Kalendar
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a novel wheeled robotics platform developed for accessible education. While contemporary humanoids, industrial manipulators, and planetary explorers showcase the cutting edge of mechatronics, most educational platforms remain either prohibitively costly or limited in flexibility. Our work addresses this by combining the form factor of an Arduino UNO development board with a wide range of sensors and actuators, all while retaining complete compatibility with its existing shields, modules and software packages. The resulting platform, named Rovrduino, provides a low cost, approachable, and modular pathway to robotics education, enabling beginners with little to no prior experience to assemble and operate a fully functional robot using mostly off the shelf components and easy to use development tools. In addition, this platform offers scalability for more advanced experimentation, bridging the gap between introductory kits and research-oriented platforms.

title: A Model for Land Cover Ecological State Assessment of Southern Ukraine Based on Remote Data for Analyzing the Consequences of the Kakhovka Reservoir Shallowing
authors: B. Yailymov, L. Pidgorodetska, L. Kolos, O. Fedorov, H. Yailymova
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: To develop scenarios for post-war reconstruction of Ukraine, in particular the measures to stabilize the functioning of war-damaged territories, it is necessary to assess the land cover ecological state based on comprehensive system monitoring. Currently, there are no comprehensive quantitative assessments that combine multiparametric analysis of physical, hydrological properties of the surface soil layer and land cover parameters using high spatial resolution satellite data. The purpose of this article is to create a model for assessing land cover ecological state of southern Ukraine based on satellite data with high spatial resolution (10 m) to analyze the consequences of the Kakhovka Reservoir shallowing. To form an integrated ecological state index (ESI), the Principal Component Analysis (PCA) method is used for four main indicators: normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI), land surface temperature (LST), moisture deficit in the surface soil layer (SSMD) and drought severity index (DSI). Sentinel, Landsat and MODIS satellite data, as well as machine learning methods, are used to calculate the values of the indicators. The ESI allows for a quantitative and qualitative assessment of the land cover state. Analysis of long-term ESI data showed a significant deterioration in the ecological state of the studied territory. The average index value decreased by 17.3% over 2019 2024, with the sharpest deterioration observed in 2022-2024 (a decrease of 15.5%). Qualitative analysis revealed that the area of favorable zones decreased by almost half (–49%), while the area of problem zones increased by 59%. If in 2019–2022 the distribution of zones remained relatively stable (the share of problem zones increased only from 33.9% to 34.8%), then in 2022 2024 there were sharp changes (an increase to 53.9%), likely caused by increased drought conditions and the consequences of the destruction of the Kakhovka HPP. The developed model with 10 m resolution enables ecological state assessment, land degradation detection and restoration planning, irrigation optimization in water-scarce conditions, evaluation of crop production potential and food security, monitoring of territories where ground surveys are impossible, and evidence-based support for land management and post-war recovery.

title: Modeling ETL Process of Biomedical Sensors: A Cloud-Based Approach to Data Integration and Manipulation
authors: Luis A. Florez-Prias, Fernando Luis Carrascal Porras, Sonia H. Contreras-Ortiz, Brian Restrepo, Andres Velez
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This paper presents a cloud-based Extract, Transform, Load (ETL) process model designed to facilitate the integration, processing, and analysis of biomedical signals. The study focuses on data collected from electroencephalography (EEG), photoplethysmography (PPG), and galvanic skin response (GSR) sensors. By implementing a systematic approach using the ESP32 microcontroller and Python frameworks, data were extracted, transformed, synchronized, and loaded into a NoSQL database (MongoDB). The proposed ETL model ensures accurate integration of heterogeneous signals, improving the efficiency of data management and analysis in medical research, personalized healthcare, and cognitive studies. Moreover, data visualization tools, such as Power BI, were employed to enable comprehensive monitoring and analysis of physiological states. The results demonstrate that the proposed workflow can harmonize asynchronous data streams with low latency and high synchronization accuracy. This work emphasizes the novelty of integrating multiple biosignals into a unified cloud-based ETL architecture, demonstrating its potential for applications in research, telehealth, and real-world healthcare environments.

title: Design of a Reinforcement Learning-Based Lightweight Adaptive PID Controller for Low-Computational- Resource Platforms
authors: Yuquan Wang, Fanqin Zeng, Xiaoxiao Zhu, Chuntao Leng
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The parameter tuning process of traditional PID controllers is cumbersome and heavily relies on the experience of the tuner. Moreover, fixed PID parameters are incapable of adapting to dynamic environments. To address these issues, we have designed a self-tuning PID controller based on error backpropagation and developed a controller optimization system using Q-learning and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). To reduce computational load during operation and meet the real-time requirements of motor speed control, we introduced the concept of pre-training. By pre-training an optimized control system framework in a high-level simulation environment and then transferring it to a low-computation motor control platform, we enable real-time fine-tuning of parameters during operation. Experimental results demonstrate that the designed controller exhibits rapid response and minimal overshoot, maintains good control performance under load variations, effectively bypasses the complex tuning process, and significantly enhances the precision and stability of the control system.

title: Tri-Band F-Shaped Meander Line MIMO Antenna with DGS for L-Band, Sub-6 GHz, and ISM Applications
authors: Riski Ramadani, Rohim Aminullah Firdaus, Yohanes Galih Adhiyoga, Hanan Zaki Alhusni
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: The rapid development of wireless communication technology has increased the demand for compact, efficient, and high-performance multiband antennas in MIMO systems. This research proposes a tri-band MIMO antenna design with an F-shaped patch configuration, incorporating an integrated meander line structure with parasitic elements and a defected ground structure (DGS) to reduce mutual coupling. The main aim of this design is to support three primary frequency bands- L-band, sub- 6 GHz, and ISM bands- simultaneously without enlarging the overall size. The antenna features two ports and is developed using the Particle Swarm Optimisation algorithm to enhance performance metrics such as reflection coefficient (S11), bandwidth, gain, envelope correlation coefficient, and diversity gain. Simulation results indicate that the antenna achieves a reflection coefficient of -47.02 dB, a VSWR as low as 1.01, a gain of up to 4.58 dBi, a maximum bandwidth of 1.10 GHz, an ECC below 0.01, and a diversity gain approaching 10 dBi. These results demonstrate significant advantages, making it a promising option for next-generation wireless applications like 5G, IoT, and portable devices.

title: Benchmarking of D-Wave's and IBM's Devices on Known Quantum Solutions to NP-Complete Problems
authors: Junjie Zhu, Filippo Orazi, Sara Marzella, Daniele Ottaviani, Stefano Lodi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: Quantum computing has the potential to revolutionize the way we solve problems that are computationally infeasible for classical computers. This paper explores the application of quantum computing to NP-complete problems, and by focusing on the Graph Coloring Problem (GCP) we benchmark the performance of two prominent quantum computing devices: D-Wave's quantum annealer and IBM's gatebased quantum processors. After mapping instances of the GCP native formulation, we evaluate the effectiveness and limitations of quantum annealing and gate-based approaches in tackling such combinatorial problems. For annealers, the problem is cast into Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) forms, while gate-based quantum devices employ variational algorithms like the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA). The research includes a comparative analysis, highlighting the scalability, accuracy, and practical challenges faced by current quantum hardware.

title: AI-Enhanced Vulnerability Assessment in Cloud Environments for Salesforce CRM
authors: Arokia Suresh Kumar Joseph, K. Vivekrabinson, P. Deepalakshmi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: With the increasing complexity, scope, and diversity of modern cyber threats, vulnerability assessment enabled by AI is increasingly essential for cloud-based platforms such as Salesforce CRM. The existing system is dominated by rule-based scanning and human audits, but it lacks flexibility and scalability, resulting in a significant number of false positives, especially in dynamic, multi-tenant setups. The strategy relies on artificial intelligence. To solve these problems, the paper suggests using an AI-based method that combines machine learning models like Isolation Forest for spotting unusual activities, Random Forest for identifying threats, and LSTM for analyzing behavior to find configuration errors, new threats, and suspicious user actions in real time. Contextual risk prioritization and visual reporting give insights into remedial stages for automated remediation. The performance evaluations show that these outperform with the greatest detection accuracy of 95.2%, the highest true positive rate of 91.2%, the fewest false positives of 8.8%, and the shortest detection delay of 7.6 seconds. These enhancements demonstrate that the outlined system is a very efficient, effective, and scalable method for safeguarding Salesforce CRM instances.

title: Face Recognition of Partially Occluded Images Using Machine Learning
authors: Mayank Srivastava, Akarsh Singh, Debashis Chakraborty, Vivek Kumar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Face recognition and validation has been an integral part of the security system globally. Most of the modern security, authentication and surveillance system consider it as a core component. A real challenge initiates when faces are partially covered or occluded by some external arrangements. During the COVID-19 pandemic, as masking became mandatory at every nooks and corners of the world, the proximity of security breaches hyped by many times. With the increasing priority of recognizing the partially occluded faces, this paper aims to leverage advanced machine learning techniques with the efficacy of MobileNet in recognizing both masked and unmasked faces apart from comparing it with other neural network architectures. The proposed method is designed to enhance the robustness of facial recognition systems aiming for considerable performance in various practical applications.

title: An Empirical Analysis of the Legal Framework Governing Work-Life Balance in the IT Area: Focus on Long Working Hours
authors: N Thousif Mohammed, Petikam Sailaja, B. Jeyaprabha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Many experts think that in the near future, artificial intelligence (AI) and specifically machine learning (ML) will improve many aspects of people's daily lives in cities, nations, and even individual neighborhoods. Examples include the hypothesis that machine learning may soon be able to relieve employees of some of their duties, which could lead to better processes or the capacity to identify the most effective ways to complete tasks. The goal of Work-life balance means keeping a good balance between a person's personal life and their job. The IT industry has grown a lot and is now an important part of the country's economy. As time has passed, more people working in IT have started to focus on balancing their personal and professional lives. Employers need to support their workers in achieving this balance life in order to maintain employee motivation. Employers can assess and analyse their employees' WLB using a variety of methods, including ML and questionnaires. This study used effort and work-life balance metrics to categorise employees according to turnover rates. This is accomplished by machine learning, which includes ensemble learning (EL) strategies. The k-NN and Navie Bayes algorithms produced the worst results in this investigation, whereas the BRDT algorithm produced the best. Random Forest, an ensemble learning algorithm, achieved the maximum score of 97% and performed nearly as well as BRDT.

title: Multilayer Credit Card Fraud Detection Using a Hybrid Autoencoder-BiLSTM-XGBoost Framework with XAI
authors: C. Sathiyamoorthy, Parveen Banu S, Pawan Mandal, Hariharan K. S, Chandigarh Ayushi, Gourav Kalra
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Credit card fraud continues to be a significant concern in the banking sector, marked by increasingly complex methods of attack and substantial expenses. Current models frequently struggle to achieve a balance among detection accuracy, temporal analysis, and model transparency. This study presents a hybrid multi-layer system containing Autoencoder for dimensionality reduction, BiLSTM for temporal pattern recognition, and XGBoost for final classification, augmented with SHAP for explainable AI (XAI). The system underwent evaluation using a Kaggle-derived dataset of 284,807 transactions, demonstrating exceptional performance with an accuracy of 99.92%, precision of 98.34%, recall of 97.89%, F1-score of 98.11 %, and ROC-AUC of 99.96%. In comparison to baseline models like Logistic Regression and Random Forest, the proposed system markedly minimised false positives and enhanced interpretability. This research handles the technological problem of real-time fraud detection while providing a scalable and transparent system that meets industry requirements. The results indicate significant potential for practical implementation in digital payment systems, enhancing the ability of secure, transparent, and efficient fraud detection mechanisms.

title: Research on Supply Chain Quality Management and Intelligent Decision-Making Model Based on Dynamic Programming Algorithm
authors: Yijie Tang, Qianhao Sun, Haoyu Chai
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This study explores the potential applications of dynamic programming in sampling inspection for evaluating supplier part quality, and discusses how it can be used to optimize production decisions in enterprise supply chain quality management. A mathematical model based on the De Moivre-Laplace central limit theorem is established to determine the minimum sample size needed under reliability and test power constraints, providing guidance for accepting supplier parts. Additionally, an optimized decision-making model for production processes is developed with an improved dynamic programming algorithm. By dividing production into three stages-parts procurement and inspection, finished product inspection, and defective product handling-the study analyzes interdependencies and identifies optimal strategies. The proposed algorithms enhance quality management and improve operational efficiency.

title: Dynamic Ensemble Learning With Received Signal Strength Transformation for Robust Multi-Floor Wi-Fi Indoor Localization
authors: Farid Yuli Martin Adiyatma, Panarat Cherntanomwong, Dwi Joko Suros
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Received Signal Strength (RSS)-based Wi-Fi localization offers a cost-effective solution for multi-floor indoor location estimation. However, its accuracy is often degraded by signal fading, multipath propagation, and device heterogeneity, posing major challenges to reliable localization. Recent studies have increasingly employed deep neural networks due to their ability to extract meaningful patterns from RSS data; however, these models require substantial computational resources and extensive parameter tuning, which limits their adaptability across diverse dynamic environments. To address these limitations, we propose DELLoc-RT, a localization framework integrating Dynamic Ensemble Learning (DELLoc) with RSS Transformation (RT) for accurate, efficient, and adaptable multi-floor indoor localization. The RT module applies Sigmoid-scaled normalization and confidence weighting to convert RSS values into compact, learnable features. DELLoc employs multiple base learners optimized via the Tree-structured Parzen Estimator with a pruning strategy (TPE-PS) that accelerates convergence by focusing on promising configurations. Additionally, Iterative Ensemble Optimization with Stepwise Selection (IEO-SS) selects complementary learners to enhance overall performance. Experimental results demonstrate that DELLoc-RT achieves floor classification accuracies of 93.32%, 94.38%, and 94.02% on the UJIIndoorLoc, UTSIndoorLoc, and Tampere datasets, respectively, with mean Euclidean errors (MEE) of 10.63 m, 7.87 m, and 8.19 m. These results highlight the model’s strong adaptability across diverse datasets. Evaluation on a self-constructed dataset further confirms that DELLoc-RT delivers high accuracy and efficiency while substantially reducing the need for manual tuning, enabling rapid deployment in practical scenarios.

title: Spiking Neural Networks for Modeling Synaptic Activity in Brain Simulations
authors: Dayashankar Singh, Raja Thimmarayan, E. Punarselvam, S. Sangeetha, S. Murugan, Pravisha A
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) are a robust computer model that accurately replicates the temporal rhythms and synaptic activity of biological neurons, representing notable progress in the domain of neural computation. This paper examines the use of SNNs in simulating synaptic activity in large-scale brain simulations, focusing on their capacity to accurately reproduce the complex mechanisms of neuronal communication and plasticity. Unlike conventional neural networks, SNN s use accurate spike timing and temporal coding to replicate synaptic contacts. This facilitates a more authentic depiction of brain processes such as learning, memory, and signal transmission. This study investigates the key characteristics of spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) to illustrate the ability of SNNs to represent synaptic plasticity and adaptability in neural circuits accurately. It demonstrates with a sequence of simulations that SNN s accurately represent the complex synaptic dynamics and provide a valuable understanding of the fundamental processes involved in cortical processing. The results emphasize the potential of SNN s to enhance our comprehension of brain function and to construct advanced neurocomputational models for future study.

title: Automated Fruit Disease Diagnosis Using Edge-Deployed Vision Transformers (ViT) and Sensor Data Fusion
authors: S. Kumaran, Prabakaran Paranthaman, M. Suresh, B. Arivu Selvam, Beulah Jackson, Premalatha. L
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Early detection of plant diseases in fruits is critical for reducing economic losses and increasing agricultural productivity. Manual inspection procedures are subjective and labor-intensive, whereas CNN-based models frequently require cloud infrastructure and have limited understanding of the external environment. Such techniques suffer from latency, privacy problems, and limited adaptability in remote or changing field circumstances. To address these limitations, it offers a system that combines edge-deployed Vision Transformers (ViT) with real-time sensor data to provide localized, real-time, and accurate diagnosis. The technique likewise uses lightweight equipment and combines temperature/humidity, soil moisture, and leaf wetness data with image features to detect and identify the disease's proposed complicated pattern. The results show the best achievements: 94.2% accuracy, 93.5% precision, and 93.0% recall, significantly surpassing the existing systems. It also achieves almost 92% disease-specific accuracy while being robust, scalable, and real-time, making it ideal for smart farming applications in resource-constrained environments with demanding environmental conditions.

title: VIRFace: A 100-Million-Scale Framework for Visual Identity Resolution via Unsupervised Deep Face Similarity Clustering
authors: Suraj Gadhe, Mrugank Purohit, Ronak Shah, Kapil Mehrotra, Daya Chand Mandad, Swati Mehta
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: In identity databases of hundred-million-scale such as electoral rolls, PAN card systems, and e-KYC platforms duplicate facial records often emerge due to redundant enrollments or fraudulent submissions. These duplicates degrade biometric verification accuracy and compromise the integrity of identity systems. We propose VIRFace, a scalable, fully unsupervised dedu-plication framework for visual identity resolution. It integrates quality-based image filtering using Face Image Quality Assess-ment (FIQA), identity-discriminative embeddings from trained face recognition model (FaceReZero), and a high-throughput Approximate Nearest Neighbor (ANN) search pipeline that combines Inverted File Indexing (IVF), Hierarchical Navigable Small World graphs (HNSW), and Product Quantization (PQ). Duplicate identities are identified via Infomap-based clustering over a locally constructed KNN similarity graph. Evaluated on real-world datasets comprising over 100 million face images, VIRFace achieves F-scores above 98%, demonstrat-ing high clustering accuracy, excellent scalability, and strong practical utility for large-scale biometric deduplication.

title: Optimization of Image Data Storage Using Mobile Cloud Computing and Device-Aware Compression techniques
authors: Sridhar S K, P Naresh, Praveen Kulkarni, Shreekant Salotagi, Gurupriya M, Rakshita B M
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This paper introduces an Android-based mobile application designed for efficient peer-to-peer image sharing, where emphasis is placed on energy efficiency and capability - dependent compression techniques on devices. The application assigns a unique user ID during installation and classifies devices as high-end or low-end based on hardware specifications such as RAM, processor type, and screen resolution. When a user captures or captures an image, the mobile application dynamically compresses it depending on the capability of the sender's device before transmission. The receiver is chosen randomly from registered users, and after the image is delivered, it is further modified to fit the requirements of their devices specifications to optimize display quality and storage efficiency. The app facilitates remote sharing through Firebase Real time Database in addition to local transfers via Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct. Encrypted data transmission and Firebase authentication provide security. This system guarantees an adaptive image viewing experience across heterogeneous mobile devices, improves data transfer efficiency, and uses less network bandwidth.

title: Evaluation of Fast Charging Effects on Battery Packs Using a Battery State Driven Approach
authors: Ali Chrakie, Moustapha El Hassan, Nagham El Ghossein
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The paper proposes a detailed analysis of electric vehicle (EV) battery modelling, state estimation, and charging infrastructure in an integrated MATLAB Simscape framework. As EV penetration is increasing at a rapid rate, sound battery management and coordination of charging are the primary challenges. The analysis combines sophisticated battery modelling, Extended Kalman Filter (EKF)-based estimation, and high-speed DC charging in a single framework. At the pack level, a precise 96s46p pack arrangement with Molicel INR-21700 P45B cells was simulated to embody electro-thermal behavior, resistance characteristics, and degradation patterns. EKF algorithms were implemented for State of Charge (SOC) and State of Health (SOH) estimation with an average error margin less than 1.8% that exhibited high accuracy, nonlinear stability, and steady thermal profiles at 45 °C. At the charging system level, an ultra-fast DC charging/discharging mode both grid-to-vehicle (G2V) and V2G modes. Simulation results confirmed stable performance for different conditions, proving the proposed control strategy. Unlike isolated analyses of existing work, this study integrates modelling, estimation, and charging control. The work aligns with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals on affordable clean energy, sustainable cities, and climate action. The results encourage both industrial practice and research, and this study is a major contribution towards sustainable and intelligent EV systems.

title: Optimizing Beamforming and Transmit Power for Improving mmWave Wireless Network Performance
authors: Parmida Geranmayeh, Eckhard Grass
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Optimization methods are crucial for improving the performance of 5G and 6G networks, primarily by enhancing key aspects such as beamforming and transmission power. These methods enable the efficient use of the available spectrum, leading to increased data rates, lower latency, and improved reliability, all of which are fundamental for supporting the applications envisioned for these networks. By optimizing beamforming, networks can achieve more precise directional signal transmission, reducing interference and increasing capacity. Similarly, power optimization ensures that the transmission power is used judiciously, extending battery life in user devices and reducing overall energy consumption. These improvements are essential for meeting the ever-growing demand for higher data throughput and better quality of service in modern wireless communication systems. This article explores how optimization methods can be applied to finetune transmission power of beamforming antennas with various transmit and receive patterns, ultimately maximizing overall channel capacity. We employed these optimization techniques to identify the highest achievable total channel capacity by identifying the optimal beamforming steering vectors for both transmitters and receivers. Among the seven optimization methods evaluated, Genetic Algorithm, Hill Climbing, and Shotgun Hill Climbing consistently demonstrated superior performance achieving up to 99.7% accuracy which making them the most effective approaches when considering both accuracy and execution time. The goal of this approach is to improve the efficiency and performance of 5G and 6G networks while also minimizing energy consumption.

title: Research on Planting Revenue Optimization Based on Genetic Algorithm and Pigeon-Inspired Optimization Algorithm
authors: Yongyue Yu, Zhenfeng Gong, Jiale Hu, Yingrui Ma, Zhicheng Jin, Yuhan Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This study integrates supply-side structural reform and rural agricultural issues, utilizing Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) to establish an optimization model for crop selection, land type allocation, and sowing time optimization. To address the multi-constraint optimization problem, a genetic algorithm with elite retention is employed for global search, iteratively optimizing the planting strategy through crossover and mutation operators to ensure solution diversity and optimality. Additionally, considering fluctuations in crop sales, yield per acre, planting costs, and market prices, as well as potential planting risks, the study introduces range-based indicators to measure variability and incorporates soft constraints on overproduction to enhance model robustness. Furthermore, to solve the multi-objective optimization problem, a three-objective programming model is constructed, with a Pareto ranking method used to design the fitness function. The pigeon-inspired optimization (PIO) algorithm is then applied for global search to determine the optimal planting strategy for 2024–2030. This approach not only improves computational efficiency but also enhances the adaptability and stability of the optimization strategy.

title: Enhancing Embedded Systems in Autonomous Vehicles and Robotics through the Integration of VLSI Design and Deep Learning
authors: S.D. Jayavathi, Baskar Gopal, Abdul Subhani Shaik, Chitravalavan, K. Thamaraiselvi, S Sankar
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The deep neural network quantization in the embedded intelligent system domain are becoming totally reliant on deep learning-based approach for the real time tasks like object detection, sensor fusion, and path planning, the hardware designing becomes more and more important. The unique and high computational processing demands in the power and space constraint embedded system make the traditional general-purpose processors (CPUs, GPUs) often not sufficient. Incorporating VLSI-based architectures, such as ASICs and FPGAs, into embedded systems allows for increased computational efficiency, decreased latency, and improved power management. This study investigates the combination of VLSI design samples with deep learning models, focusing on the advantages of accelerating hardware technology in mobile autonomous devices. Some key areas include low-power design techniques, memory optimization, and real-time deep learning inference using reconfigurable hardware. Dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS), power gating, and customized dataflow architectures are considered as the potential approaches with the potential to optimize energy consumption and performance. These advancements in energy efficiency and performance will continue to shape the landscape of embedded systems and will directly impact future advancements in autonomous robots and vehicles alike.

title: A Two-Stage Framework with 3D Shape Constraints for Pancreas Segmentation in Abdominal CT
authors: Qingru Liu, Sonit Singh
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Pancreas segmentation in computed tomography (CT) imaging presents significant c hallenges due to the organ’s small size, anatomical variability, and unclear boundaries with surrounding tissues. We propose a novel two-stage framework combining TransUNet architecture with 3D Denoising Autoen-coder (DAE) post-processing for improved pancreas segmentation. The framework employs coarse segmentation for region localisation, fine segmentation using TransUNet for boundary refinement, and 3 DDAE post-processing for shape constraint enforcement. Experimental results on the NIH Pancreas-CT dataset demonstrate significant improvements, achieving a Dice Similarity Coefficient of $84.44 \% \pm 4.48 \%$, representing a 7.58 percentage point improvement over UNet as baseline method. The approach effectively addresses the three primary challenges in pancreas segmentation while maintaining computational efficiency.

title: Sentiment Analysis of Code-Mixed Hinglish Video Comments Using Advanced Deep Learning Models
authors: Nagendar Yamsani, Neelu Shaktawat, Premanand S Chauhan, Richa Sharma, Arjun Mehra, Seema Bushra
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Hinglish has some problems in sentiment analysis in terms of code-switching, informal writing, and transliteration. Such linguistic complexity is usually out of the scope of conventional NLP solutions as they employ rules and heuristics, especially about user-generated content such as comments to videos. This work proposed the usage of deep learning models for the code-mixed video comment sentiment analysis on Hinglish dataset. We, therefore, consider multiple deep learning approaches with a focus on the Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) that is enhanced by the Gated Recurrent Units (GRU) to analyze the mixed-coded texts accurately. With a test accuracy of 91.7 %, our model can capacitate in cases with problems created by code-switching and colloquialism. The results, reveal to what extent BiLSTM with GRU can capture the changes in context and semantics' cohesion in the Hinglish video comments. This research has implications for increasing analysis of consumer engagement and/ or sentiment detection in the faster-growing social media networks. It also gives some ideas on the possible application of deep learning methods for sentiment analysis in a code-mixed environment.

title: State Estimation in the Occurrence of Short Circuits Using Bat-Inspired Meta-Heuristics
authors: Sebastiao E. D. S, Wilingthon G. Zvietcovich, Mylena C. Da Silva, Francisco R.A.C. Baracho
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study proposes the application of the Bat Algorithm (BA), a metaheuristic inspired by the echolocation behavior of bats, to identify fault conditions that generate Short-Duration Voltage Variations (SDVVs) in electrical power distribution systems. Short circuits are the main cause of these voltage disturbances, which can result in sags and/or swells affecting groups of consumers, often leading to significant financial losses due to equipment malfunctions and production process interruptions. Given the unpredictable nature of such events, especially in systems with sensitive loads, accurately determining the fault conditions presents a significant challenge for utility industry. The proposed methodology estimates key fault parameters, including fault type, impedance, location, and duration. The BA was adapted to efficiently handle both continuous and discrete variables simultaneously. The approach was validated through simulations on a standard 33-bus distribution network, demonstrating the effectiveness and potential applicability of the proposed method for optimization problems in electrical power system operation.

title: A Novel Current-fed Soft-Switched DC/DC Converter for Vehicle-to-Vehicle Energy Exchange
authors: Nil Patel, Luiz A. C. Lopes, Xiaodong Li, Akshay Kumar Rathore
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Industrial Electronics
abstract: This paper investigates a novel zero-current-switching enabled single-stage single-phase current-fed SiC-based full bridge DC-DC converter for vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) charge sharing application. Through a novel secondary-modulation technique, the current fed dual active bridge topology achieves natural voltage clamping across the primary-side devices and resolves the long-standing issue of voltage spikes across devices during turn-off, this solution eliminates unnecessary snubbers or clamping circuits. As a result, converter is snubber-free, characterized by reduced hardware complexity, enhanced compactness, and improved cost-effectiveness. By enabling zero current switching on the primary side and zero-current turn-on switching on the secondary side, converter effectively reduces switching losses. A 1.5 kW hardware has been designed, and results are demonstrated.

title: Rank-Revealing Bayesian Block-Term Tensor Completion with Graph Information
authors: Zhongtao Chen, Lei Cheng, Yik-Chung Wu, H. Vincent Poor
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing
abstract: Block-term decomposition (BTD), particularly its rank-(L<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r</sub>,L<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r</sub>, 1) special case, is widely used in signal processing. Traditional methods for computing BTD either unrealistically assume the number of blocks and block ranks are known or require exhaustive tuning of these parameters. While sparsity-promoting regularization has been introduced to estimate these parameters more efficiently, it still requires regularization parameter tuning. Bayesian learning addresses these issues by employing sparsity-promoting priors on the number of blocks and block ranks, but so far is limited to fully observed BTD tensors. To process incomplete BTD tensors, only a few optimization-based methods have been proposed, and they continue to suffer from heavy parameter tuning. To enable tuning-free BTD completion, a prior that simultaneously enforces block-wise sparsity and withinblock column-wise sparsity while incorporating graph structure is introduced within the Bayesian framework. Besides theoretically establishing the legitimacy of the prior distribution, a mean-field design is developed to obtain a closed-form updating variational inference (VI) algorithm without loss of graph information. Extensive experiments on both synthetic datasets and real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method over existing optimization-based algorithms and the Bayesian model without graph information, in terms of rank learning, tensor recovery, and factor recovery.
