title: Unifence: A Geofence-Based Hostel Attendance System with Biometric Authentication and Role-Based Access
authors: Devendra Bhavsar, Pranab Roy, Hafizur Rahaman, Apoorva Dixit, Kartik Sharma, Anwesha Mondal
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: A system namely “Unifence”, - that describes a mobile system for recording hostel attendance – is described in this paper in order to design for detection of proxy attendance for ensuring location-based Realtime verification of students using geofencing and biometric authentication. The system is divided into two major control panel—for students and wardens—both offering distinctive functionalities suited to their respective roles. The main innovations are combining GPS-based geofence tracking, face detection biometrics, and Firebase real-time cloud storage, enclosed into a user-friendly mobile interface. The system carryout strict time windows and location constraints, ensuring only authorized, present users can mark their attendance. This paper also reviews applicable academic work on geofencing and Location-Based Services, (LBS) placing Unifence within the wide perspective of mobile computing in academic institutions.

title: Deep Learning-based Robust sEMG Intention Detection for a 1-DOF elbow Exoskeleton
authors: Arsène Langevin, Toshiyuki Murakami, Zielińska Teresa
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Exoskeletons are nowadays at the core of research for human enhancement, rehabilitation and prevention of musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs). MSDs are one of the major causes of long-term disability and illness among workers, and some of them could be prevented by the use of exoskeletons. However, the control of those devices is not always intuitive, and thus, they are poorly accepted. Some control methods using surface electromyography (sEMG) information are currently under research and give promising results. This paper aims to introduce a robust sEMG-based intention detection relying on an LSTM neural network. The method consists of collecting three channels of sEMG together with the position and acceleration angle and rotational speed of the end effector to teach a long short-term memory neural network to predict the angle of contraction of the elbow. The negative effect of external factors on the prediction, such as the presence of load in the hand or the differences between individuals, are highlighted, and the benefits of calibration methods to solve this problem are presented.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Approaches for Feature Extraction and Cancelable Template Generation in Iris Recognition
authors: Shakti Mehta, Krunal Vaghela
publish: IEEE Communications Standards Magazine
abstract: One significant way to address privacy, security, and revocability concerns in biometric systems is through cancelable biometrics. For efficient iris recognition, this paper presents a deep learning-based model that combines cancelable template generation techniques with hybrid convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures. Two benchmark datasets, MMU Iris and Cornea Iris, are used, with preprocessing involving Gaussian filtering and hold-out validation. Hybrid feature extraction models that integrate MobileNetV3Small, InceptionNetV3, EfficientNetB0, DenseNet121, and XceptionNet are utilized to obtain highly discriminative iris features. Ten transformation methods, i.e., Gaussian Random Projection, Bio-Hashing, Deep Hashing, Homomorphic Noise, and Block Permutation, are evaluated systematically for cancelability. With up to 99.32% accuracy and an EER of 0.027 on the Cornea dataset and 97.78% accuracy and an EER of 0.044 on the MMU dataset, experimental results demonstrate that Block Permutation offers the best trade-off between recognition accuracy and template security. From the hybrid models, MobileNetV3Small + InceptionNetV3 and XceptionNet + MobileNetV3Small are always at the top. Experiments validate that hybrid CNNs combined with lightweight cancelable transformations have the capability to maintain high recognition performance and guarantee non-invertibility, revocability, and diversity, making the method highly applicable to robust secure biometric authentication in real-world scenarios.

title: Self-Healing and Optimization in Mesh Networks Using Glowworm Swarm Optimization
authors: Ashwin Shenoy M, Sudhanshu Maurya, K. Prema, Feruza Jumaniyazova, Nimmy Lazer, Vaibhav C. Gandhi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: This research work proposes the use of the Glowworm Swarm Optimization technique for the integration in to mesh networks to improve their self-healing and optimization function. Mesh networks, as is well understood, consists of nodes that can dynamically communicate with each other; the lack of centralized controller, while being beneficial in many ways, entails that different protocols need self-healing capabilities to ensure that communication is maintained in situations where one or more nodes are offline or the network is otherwise disrupted. Known methods of self-healing for software applications are not very efficient when it comes to the scalability and flexibility, which can become major issues when it is applied to rapidly changing surroundings. To tackle these issues, we mount a GSO-based approach enhancing routing paths, load balancing and fault tolerance in mesh network. In fact, the GSO algorithm that mimic the light emitting capacity of glowworms is ideal in solving large optimization problems in real time. The framework that has been proposed in this paper was thoroughly validated with the help of numerical simulations based on the datasets characterizing the different network settings. These conclusions show that the proposed GSO-based approach provide better results for the recovery time, the network throughput, the energy consumption and the delivery packet ratio than the excluding strategies. Thus, this work advances the improvement to the robustness and reliability of mesh networks while offering future use cases in various fields including military, disaster management, the Internet of Things(IoT).

title: An Effective QUBO Formulation for Knapsack Problems
authors: Sutapa Samanta, Dagen Wang, Todd Hodges, Andras Ferenczi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: Combinatorial optimization problems are central to addressing complex decision-making challenges in finance and represent a promising avenue for demonstrating quantum advantage using near-term quantum hardware. While significant progress has been made in encoding unconstrained optimization problems into Hamiltonian formulations for quantum computing, constrained optimization problems remain an open challenge. The knapsack problem, a class of NP-hard constrained combinatorial optimization problems, exemplifies this issue. Existing Hamiltonian encodings for knapsack problems typically employ either a prohibitive number of slack variables, exceeding the qubit capacity of current quantum devices, or unbalanced penalty methods that demand extensive parameter tuning to achieve the optimal solutions. This paper introduces a novel Hamiltonian formulation that addresses these limitations by requiring only two slack variables and significantly reducing the need for penalty parameter calibration. Experiments conducted on a quantum annealer for small-scale instances demonstrate the proposed method's superior performance compared to existing approaches, achieving higher success rates in locating the optimal solutions while maintaining hardware feasibility. The results highlight the potential of this formulation to advance the practical application of quantum optimization to constrained combinatorial problems in finance and beyond.

title: Celebrating Three Decades of IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design
authors: Kapil Dev, Jerald Yoo, Younghyun Kim, Srividhya Venkataraman
publish: IEEE Design & Test
abstract: Last Year Marked the 30th anniversary of the IEEE/ACM International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design (ISLPED). The conference was held on August 6–8, 2025, on the University of Iceland Campus in Reykjavík, Iceland, as an in-person event. The symposium spanned 2.5 days to accommodate a large number of paper presentations and special events. The program featured three keynote speeches delivered by Dr. Michaela Blott (AMD), Prof. Kenichi Okada (Institute of Science Tokyo, Japan), and Dr. Brucek Khailany (Nvidia), along with two panel discussions, two special sessions, two tutorials, 39 regular paper presentations, 21 poster presentations, and a design contest showcasing four demos. The symposium attracted 131 attendees from 16 countries.

title: Optimizing Acoustic Emission-Based Partial Discharge Identification with Metric-Driven Saliency Map Selection
authors: Arvind Sharma, Harimurugan Devarajan
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Acoustic emission provides an effective, nondestructive method for assessing the well-being of high-voltage equipment, enabling engineers to identify failures at an early stage and thereby improve the safety and reliability of electricity systems. This paper examines how saliency methods can be used to enhance partial-discharge identification in environments with heavy noise. The convolutional neural network was designed and trained to work with experimentally recorded acoustic-emission waveforms, which include three different classes: hot-spot events, partial discharges, and ambient noise. After training, five types of saliency visualization were used to produce complementary saliency maps. The automatic process of choosing the most informative maps was based on the comparison to the weighted-average deletion score. The selection strategy was validated by retraining the network on 50% of the best salient regions, based on the best maps, as inbound masks. Further variants of the models were trained using the best 50% of salient regions in each map in order to compare the results. Examples of experimental findings demonstrate that the model using optimally chosen saliency masking achieves a classification accuracy of 95.01%, equivalent to that of a full spectrogram with no masking. The results indicate that saliency-directed masking in terms of weighted-average deletion score will enable the preservation of a high detection rate and focus computational resources on the most important acoustic features. The method is, therefore, a potential route for improving the process of partial-discharge diagnosis in real high-voltage installations, which will eventually aid in achieving reliability in the grids.

title: TRUSTPIX: A Hardware-Accelerated Deep Learning Framework for Image Integrity Verification
authors: S.N Subikshaa, R Nandhitha, P Ajitha
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Digital image manipulation is among the top sources of misinformation worldwide and a driver of digital distrust, calling for proactive, real-time, scalable verification approaches. This work introduces TRUSTPIX, a system built using Deep Learning techniques to achieve high accuracy in the detection of splicing, copy-move, and AI-generated image tampering. The developed system relies on CNNs using Xception and MobileNet architectures and performs on a lowcost hardware accelerator, enabling low-computational-cost and real-time operation. The proposed system analytically examines the images to identify subtle inconsistencies at a pixel level, as well as compression artifacts. Whenever a forgery is detected, it outputs a visual heat-map that localizes the tampered regions and gives users timely insights about the integrity of an image. It may become a useful enabler in the realms of digital forensics, journalism, and social media moderation through its capabilities as a robust, non-invasive, and accessible tool for integrity verification.

title: A Quantum Enhanced Transformer-Based Gated Capsule Network for Product Review Sentiment Analysis
authors: Christiana Rose Elizabeth Korrapati, Deepak Chowdary Edara
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: By utilizing high-dimensional state superposition for effective text categorization, quantum computing improves sentiment analysis. This work refines feature representations by combining a gated capsule network, amplitude-based quantum circuits, and a contextual BERT encoder. Textual features are encoded by quantum states and then processed using amplitude encoding and entangling layers to enhance embeddings. The capsule network's hierarchical gating mechanism improves classification accuracy by capturing contextual relationships. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Simultaneous Perturbation Stochastic Approximation (SPSA) are used to maximize computing efficiency. The experimental results show that quantumenhanced deep learning can be used to classify sentiment with an accuracy of 93.33%.

title: Fabrication of Multi-Material Stator Core with Advanced Additive Manufacturing
authors: Ali Sarp Uyandiran
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: This research presents an improved stator design for 3D-printed electric motors, developed using fused deposition modeling (FDM) and multi-material bonding strategies. Unlike the generally used default stator design, the proposed structure introduces a shell-core architecture designed to mimic the functional layers observed in commercial stators. The study outlines the change from single-material designs to a triple-component structure: a magnetic iron-filled PLA core, a surrounding shell that replicates the epoxy insulation, and an inner steel-filled PLA ring that provides mechanical rigidity and serves as the shaft interface, improving overall structural integrity under rotation and load. Key design parameters, segmentation strategies, and printing workflows are described in the paper. A simulation-based magnetostatic analysis was conducted to validate the proposed stator design against the standard iron-PLA variant.

title: Wheelchairs Unleashed: System Design For Using Electric Wheelchairs As Mobile Robotic Platforms
authors: Jan Patrick Schulte, Jürgen Graf
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Electric wheelchairs are a crucial part of everyday life for users. But besides that, they are also great mobile robotic platforms due to their driving capabilities. The latter aspect has not been considered much in research since there are significant technical hurdles, mainly the absence of an open control system. Here we present such a system. Our work consists of two parts. One is closely related to the technical details of electric wheelchairs and is based on a lot of reverse-engineering. The other one is more high-level, consisting of a system design that is no longer specific to wheelchairs, but can be applied to other mobile platforms as well. We equipped a wheelchair with cameras and positioning sensors to make it drive autonomously across the campus, showing that we have control over it. The proposed higher-level system design is very flexible to make it usable for a wide range of projects. As our main focus, we show how the system can be tailored to the requirements of wheelchair users. We anticipate that it will be used to create innovative user interfaces for wheelchairs in the future, improving safety, comfort, mobility and independence of users.

title: The Cost of Simplicity: How Reducing EEG Electrodes Affects Source Localization and BCI Accuracy
authors: Eva Guttmann-Flury, Yanyan Wei, Shan Zhao, Jian Zhao, Mohamad Sawan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Electrode density optimization in electroencephalography (EEG)-based Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs) requires balancing practical usability against signal fidelity, particularly for source localization. Reducing electrodes enhances portability but its effects on neural source reconstruction quality and source connectivity - treated as proxies to BCI performance - remain understudied. We address this gap through systematic evaluation of 62-, 32-, and 16-channel configurations using a fixed, fully automated processing pipeline applied to the well-characterized P300 potential. This approach's rationale is to minimize variability and bias inherent to EEG analysis by leveraging the P300's stimulus-locked reproducibility and pipeline standardization. Analyzing 63 sessions (31 subjects) from the Eye-BCI dataset with rigorous artifact correction and channel validation, we demonstrate: (1) Progressive degradation in source reconstruction quality with sparser configurations, including obscured deep neural generators and spatiotemporal distortions; (2) A novel <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sqrt{R_{\mathrm{e}}}$</tex> scaling law linking electrode reduction ratio <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(R_{e})$</tex> to localization accuracy - a previously unquantified relationship to the best of our knowledge; (3) While reduced configurations preserve basic P300 topography and may suffice for communicative BCIs, higher-density channels are essential for reliable deep source reconstruction. Overall, this study establishes a first step towards quantitative benchmarks for electrode selection, with critical implications for clinical BCIs requiring anatomical precision in applications like neurodegenerative disease monitoring, where compromised spatial resolution could mask pathological signatures. Most importantly, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sqrt{R_{e}}$</tex> scaling law may provide the first principled method to determine the minimal electrode density required based on acceptable error margins or expected effect sizes.

title: Interpretable anomaly detection of multi-satellite attitude control systems based on TabGMAN
authors: Yiming Gao, Shi Qiu, Lixian Zhang, Ming Liu, Xibin Cao, Guangren Duan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The health status of multi-satellite attitude control systems exerts a crucial impact on the operational efficiency of constellations. However, the inherent spatio-temporal correlation and heterogeneity of multi-satellite telemetry data increase the anomaly detection difficulty using traditional methods. To address the challenges in multi-satellite attitude control system health management, this paper proposes an interpretable anomaly detection method based on the tabular graph multiattention network (TabGMAN). First, this paper integrates constellation orbital and component information and time-frequency domain features to construct multi-satellite graph data. Subsequently, we propose the TabGMAN, an interpretable spatiotemporal neural network that adopts a spatio-temporal attention mechanism and instance-wise feature selection to identify anomalous satellites and attitude control system components. Finally, in several cases of anomaly detection in constellations, the proposed method achieves effective identification of anomalous satellites and attitude control system components and fault attribution through quantitative interpretability analysis.

title: Guest Editorial: Advanced Topologies, Control Techniques and Modeling Methodologies for Bidirectional DC/DC Converters
authors: Shanshan Gao, Concettina Buccella, Ziwei Ouyang, Yijie Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: In recent years, the accelerating adoption of renewable energy has significantly increased the penetration of diverse DC loads, such as electric vehicles and energy storage systems, imposing unprecedented demands for operational flexibility and adaptability on modern power infrastructures. Bidirectional DC/DC converters, which facilitate controlled power flow in both directions, have emerged as pivotal components in managing power transfer and regulating voltage and current, thereby ensuring stable, reliable, and efficient system performance. With rapid advancements in power electronics, achieving high power density and efficiency has become a critical challenge in the design of next-generation converters. Therefore, significant research efforts have been devoted to developing advanced control strategies, novel topological structures, accurate modeling approaches and so on. This “Special Section on Advanced Topologies, Control Techniques and Modeling Methodologies for Bidirectional DC/DC Converters” provides an insight on some of the newly emerging challenges and potential solutions to overcome those issues.

title: A Neuroradiomic Approach for Age-Group Classification of Healthy Human Brains
authors: Noemi Pisani, Maria Agnese Pirozzi, Federica Franza, Alessandro Pasquale De Rosa, Francesco Amato, Antonio Gallo, Mario Cirillo, Leandro Donisi, Fabrizio Esposito
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Neuroradiomics is an emerging subfield of radiomics that focuses on the extraction of high-dimensional quantitative measures from region of interests within the human neural tissue. This study aimed to extract radiomic features from the grey matter (GM) of structural brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of seventy-five healthy control (HC) subjects, to classify them based on age-related differences. Subjects were classified as “young” and “old” using the median age as a reference, excluding those within a range of ten years around the median. T1-weighted anatomical scans were acquired for all participants, and MRI images were preprocessed before radiomic feature extraction. A total of 107 features, including shape, first order and texture, were collected. Several machine learning (ML) algorithms-Extra Tree Classifier (ETC), Random Forest (RF), XGBoost (XGB), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Linear Regression (LR), and K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN)-were employed to classify HCs in the two groups. Additionally, the SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) analysis was carried out to identify the most informative radiomic features contributing to brain age estimation. Most classifiers achieved performance metrics exceeding 0.80, with LR yielding the best results: an accuracy of 0.86 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\pm 0.09)$</tex>, sensitivity of 0.88 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(+0.12)$</tex> and specificity of 0.84 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\pm 0.10)$</tex>, in terms of mean (±standard deviation). Finally, the SHAP analysis further revealed that texture features were predominant among the 15 most influential variables used in the training of models. In conclusion, the presented neuroradiomics approach shows promise for characterising age-related changes in the healthy brain using structural MRI.

title: Unpacking Machine Learning Models for Time Series Prediction: A Comparative Review
authors: Nimish Gigras, Vansh Arora, Ankur Maurya, Niharika Keshari
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Time series prediction is a complex technique in finance, medicine, and energy, but it is plagued by noise, non-linearity, and long-range dependencies. This paper looks into how well different models form Machine learning domain perform in forecasting insights, from traditional methods like ARIMA along with KNN to more advanced deep learning models such as LSTM, and DA-RNN and many more, compares the strengths and the weak links of mentioned models and their suitability for different forecasting tasks. Linear approaches offer explanatory power but struggle with complex patterns, while hybrid approaches like DA-RNN improve performance by automatically computing feature weights. This study aims to assist both the academics and professionals in selecting the most appropriate forecasting models for practical, real-world use cases.

title: Intelligent Gesture Recognition for Safety Assessment of Mechanical Manufacturing Learners Using Immersive VR and AI Technologies
authors: Mohamed Amine Ben Yahia, Issam Dridi, Med Karim Azizi, Leila Mekacher, Noureddine Ben Yahia
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) is transforming vocational and industrial training by providing realistic, risk-free environments that enable the acquisition of technical competencies, particularly in hazardous fields such as mechanical manufacturing. This paper presents an immersive “Learning-Assessment” application developed in Unity for the Meta Quest 3 headset to teach safe and efficient operation of a metal lathe. The system integrates three main components: (1) an interactive learning module introducing machining principles and tool-workpiece interactions, (2) an adaptive assessment module based on dynamic multiple-choice questions (MCQs) to evaluate theoretical understanding, and (3) a real-time gesture and posture monitoring module using artificial intelligence (AI). The latter relies on OpenPose for skeletal keypoint extraction and a convolutional neural network (CNN) for detecting hazardous or ergonomically incorrect postures. The proposed AI pipeline was optimized for on-device execution and validated on a dedicated dataset of lathe-operation gestures. Initial experiments with 20 novice participants demonstrated an 85% posture-detection accuracy, a 90% recognition rate for critical hazardous postures, and a 35% reduction in gestural errors after three learning sessions. User feedback also indicated strong engagement and perceived safety (mean score: 4.6/5). These results highlight the potential of the proposed system as an effective, interactive, and ergonomically compliant VRbased training solution for mechanical manufacturing.

title: Lumen: Developer Agency Through Transparent Context Control in AI-Assisted Programming
authors: Nakul Goel, Glaucia Melo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: The landscape of software engineering has undergone rapid transformation with the emergence of Artificial Intelligence (AI) coding assistants, which are being increasingly integrated into development workflows to boost productivity and automate routine tasks. Although modern AI coding assistants, such as Claude Code, Cursor, Codex, and many others, can automatically access entire repositories, they operate as black boxes: developers cannot see or control what context drives AI decisions. This automatic operation creates uncertainty about whether critical dependencies, security configurations, or test files are considered. We present Lumen, an open-source tool that takes a fundamentally different approach: preserving developer control through transparent context assembly. Using a double-copy interaction paradigm that leverages natural clipboard behavior, Lumen instantly shows developers the dependency graph and AI-generated summaries of files connected to their copied code. This allows developers to create AI-generated code where the model uses the same context that the developer is focusing on. This design philosophy, which incorporates human-in-the-loop capabilities with full visibility, lays the foundation for future agentic capabilities, ensuring that developers understand and control what the AI sees and does. We demonstrate through Cognitive Walkthrough Analysis how Lumen reduces context assembly overhead while maintaining the transparency necessary for production code. Our open-source implementation provides a foundation for the community to build upon, developing AI tools that enhance rather than replace human judgment.

title: A statistical approach to assess the relationship between interdigitated geometry characteristics and shear stress performance in Electro-Adhesive Devices
authors: Federico Bertolucci, Lara Rebaioli, Lorenzo Molinari Tosatti, Irene Fassi, Rocco Vertechy
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Over the past decade, several studies have proposed optimization strategies targeting components of Electro-Adhesive Devices (EAD) to enhance their performance in terms of normal or shear grasping force. Notably, the comb-shaped interdigitated geometry, widely used in EAD grasping applications, has demonstrated superior shear force performance. While many studies have focused on determining the optimal electrode geometry for specific applications, employing analytical models and finite element method (FEM) simulations of electrostatic interdigitated systems, few studies have systematically explored the optimal combination of electrode gap and width, incorporating an empirical evaluation. However, the EAD performance is often influenced by several physical factors related to the manufacturing process and environmental conditions, which are neglected by analytical and numerical models. This work presents an empirical-statistical method for optimizing EADs through a study based on the Design of Experiments (DoE) technique. EADs comprising two comb-shaped electrodes are fabricated using the Drop on Demand inkjet printing technique to deposit a silver-based ink on thin polyethylene terephthalate (PET) film. By varying the gap and width, and by assessing shear force through shear stress tests, the best combination for grasping a given material is determined, providing a suitable benchmark for selecting the appropriate device geometry for a specific application. Tests on a conductive substrate resulted in less intense electro-adhesive phenomena than tests on a dielectric substrate. In both cases, increasing the electrode gap decreased the shear stress. However, reducing electrode width led to opposite effects: shear stress increased on the dielectric substrate, but decreased on the conductive one.

title: Optimized LED-PD Pairing for Downlink Data Rate Enhancement in a VLC System Based on Transmission Distance and Angle
authors: Faranita Surwi, Ahmad Sirojuddin, Gamantyo Hendrantoro
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Visible light communication (VLC) offers high-speed wireless data transmission using the visible spectrum, providing an efficient alternative to RF systems in indoor environments. This paper proposes an optimized LED-PD pairing framework based on the Hungarian algorithm to maximize the total downlink data rate in multi-user VLC networks. The system model considers geometric positioning, optical channel characteristics, and angle-dependent channel gain. Simulation results show that the proposed method achieves a total sum rate of 57.55 Mbps, yielding a 68% improvement over random pairing (34.18 Mbps). In addition, the computational time remains below 0.01 s, compared to 0.53 s for the brute-force method with ten LED-PD pairs, demonstrating the efficiency and scalability of the proposed approach for real-time VLC systems.

title: AI-Enhanced Collision Detection for Autonomous Drones Using LiDAR and Neural Network
authors: Vaibhavi Painuly, Omprakash Gurrapu, W. Hepzibah Jebaselvi, Umidbek Abdalov, Yashan Noushad, Vaibhav C. Gandhi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: This research introduces the enhanced collision detection system for the autonomous drones on which the LiDAR technology and neural networks are utilized in the increased safety and operational performance. Existing techniques of collision avoidance do not suffice when implemented in dynamic settings, hence the reason for advanced solutions. LiDAR has been employed as a 3D mapping tool while neural networks have been used to detect patterns with the proposed system using both to develop a real time collision detection system. It also improves the capability of detecting obstacles and avoid them through using deep learning models to process LiDAR data. The training and validation datasets include both synthetic and actual data with considerable enhancement over existing techniques shown in the work. The numerical performance shows high values of accuracy, precision, recall, and also low time complexity which establishes the effectiveness of the proposed system. Consequently, the results of the study to conclude that, LiDAR in conjunction with neural networks hold considerable promise for bringing improvements in the autonomy of drones. I will explain, how the idea of the proposed system is aimed not only at correcting the main drawbacks of traditional methods, but also offers more opportunities for delivering more complex operations. This study makes a small input to the existing literature of autonomous navigation and opens the door to progress concerning the collision detection and avoidance systems.

title: Smart Automated Cleaning Robot
authors: K. Devibalan, R. Kishore, X. Jerbin Ashick, J. Sanjay Kumar
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The rapid growth of municipal solid waste has intensified the demand for automated and efficient waste segregation systems. Manual sorting remains labor-intensive, inconsistent, and unsuitable for large-scale deployment. This paper presents an integrated smart automated cleaning robot that combines deep learning-based image processing with sensor-driven material detection. A YOLOv8 object detection model is employed for real-time classification of biodegradable waste using images captured from a camera positioned above the conveyor belt. Metal and plastic waste are identified through inductive and capacitive proximity sensors, respectively, based on their electromagnetic and dielectric properties. An Arduino Uno serves as the central controller, synchronizing sensor inputs and operating servo-actuated diverters to route each waste item to its designated bin. Experimental evaluations demonstrate reliable classification and multi-stage separation of biodegradable, metal, and plastic waste with minimal human intervention. The proposed system offers a scalable, low-cost, and practical solution suitable for smart cities, public infrastructures, and decentralized waste management environments.

title: Research on the Efficiency Improvement of Big Data Integration in Financial Information Mining
authors: Yan Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes an optimized MapReduce algorithm, which aims to significantly improve the efficiency and accuracy of financial information mining. Faced with the complexity of multi-source heterogeneous financial data, this paper designs and implements an efficient integrated framework that integrates data preprocessing, feature extraction and model training. The framework can quickly process large-scale, high-dimensional financial data. By optimizing the task decomposition and parallel execution mechanism of MapReduce distributed computing, it effectively improves the efficiency of data processing and the adaptability of the system. This paper selects multiple public financial data sets for simulation tests. The results show that the optimized algorithm improves the data processing efficiency by 27.5% and the classification accuracy by 8.3% compared with the traditional method, showing a strong performance advantage. In addition, the system performs particularly well when processing high-dimensional data. The experimental data show that its data throughput rate reaches up to 1.2 GB per second. This result shows that the optimized MapReduce algorithm cannot only quickly cope with massive data, but also maintain excellent computing performance under the condition of complex high-dimensional features. The experiment also further verifies the scalability and robustness of the system. Under the condition of significant increase in data scale and computing tasks, the system can still complete the task efficiently and maintain a low error rate.

title: Assessment of Distributed PV Hosting Capacity in the IEEE 13-Bus Distribution Network Via Binary Search Algorithm
authors: Marlon Lainez Martinez, Asheyn Rivera Fajardo, José Napoleón Zelaya, Juan Carlos Huaquisaca, Jonathan Muñoz Tabora
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: In recent years, renewable energies have experienced exponential growth in power systems. However, an excess of renewable energy in a specific area can generate reverse power flows in transmission lines, overvoltages, and overloads. Therefore, analyzing the hosting capacity in distribution systems is essential to ensure the proper integration of renewable energies into the distribution network. Initially, an IEEE 13-Bus Distribution Network was selected and modeled using OpenDSS software, and through the integration of Python with OpenDSS, a binary search algorithm was applied to determine the hosting capacity at each node. The results show that hosting capacity decreases as the distance from the substation increases and is higher when closer to it. Additionally, they reveal that high levels of uncontrolled renewable energy penetration can compromise the reliability of the electrical grid by exceeding critical technical limits, such as the current-carrying capacity of conductors, transformer overloads, and over-voltages. Based on the proposed methodology, it is possible to increase the hosting capacity of distribution networks with a proper integration strategy by monitoring the growth of renewable energy.

title: Implementation of Quadrature Locking and Duty Cycle Correction Schemes for UCIe Interface
authors: A Munidurga Prasad, M. Madhu Babu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The design and implementation of quadrature locking and duty cycle correction (DCC) schemes for the transmitter stage of Universal Chiplet Interconnect Express (UCIe) interfaces. High-speed chiplet communication depends heavily on the accuracy of quadrature clock phases, and even small deviations can disturb the setup and hold margins required for reliable data transfer. To overcome these issues, the proposed design brings phase alignment and duty-cycle adjustment together in a single control loop. This integrated approach helps the system settle more quickly, lowers switching noise, and strengthens overall signal integrity. The receiver in a UCIe link relies on a tight phase relationship, where data transitions occur at 0° and 180°, and clock transitions are positioned at 90° and 270°. Preserving this relationship across process and voltage variations is critical for consistent operation. The circuit is implemented using a $65-\mathrm{nm}$ CMOS technology and powered by a 1 -V supply, achieving data rates of up to 6 Gbps. Simulation results show noticeable improvement in phase accuracy and duty-cycle stability, even under varying operating conditions. These results highlight the suitability of the proposed approach for building efficient, high-performance UCIe interfaces in nextgeneration chiplet-based systems.

title: Comparing Informer and LSTM in Predicting Network Traffic toward Achieving Intelligent Network Management
authors: Toto Bachtiar Palokoto, Tjong Wan Sen, A. A. N. Ananda Kusuma, Rusdianto Roestam, Tahar Agastani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: Research for network traffic prediction (NTP) has emerged in recent years since the development of processing technology and Machine Learning (ML), and makes an NTP-based intelligent network management (INM) a possibility. Informer, a modified version of Transformer, was specifically designed for Long Sequence Time-series Forecasting (LSTF). Introduced in year 2021, Informer is still considered a new algorithm, and its implementation in NTP requires comparison with the commonly used algorithm, such as Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM). One of the challenges in NTP is whether an algorithm can be implemented in different network traffic dataset (NTD). Hence, this research has compared LSTM and Informer using 3 different NTDs namely Abilene, GEANT, and CBT datasets. Informer showed slightly better performance in irregular behavior NTDs, such as Abilene and CBT, and a considerable superior performance in a regular behavior NTD, such as GEANT. In terms of MSE and $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$, Informer achieved almost 8 times and 0.14 units better than LSTM respectively. Furthermore, RMSE and MAE results showed approximately 0.35 GB and 0.25 GB error differences between LSTM and Informer. Despite that, a balance between performance and computational efficiency needs to be established, as LSTM entails a lower computational burden compared to Informer.

title: Identification of Pine Wilt Disease Based on the Improved YOLOv5s Network
authors: Yu Miao, Ruifen Huan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This study introduces an enhanced approach for identifying diseased wood, utilizing a refined version of the YOLOv5s network. By integrating the YOLOv5s framework with a weighted bidirectional feature pyramid and a shuffle attention mechanism, the method achieves superior accuracy in detecting diseased wood. The weighted bidirectional feature pyramid facilitates the efficient exchange and amalgamation of feature data across various scale layers. Meanwhile, the shuffle attention mechanism adeptly merges spatial and channel attention mechanisms, employing group convolution to minimize computational expenses. To substantiate the efficacy and interplay of the components within the upgraded YOLOv5s network, the study conducts ablation experiments, juxtaposing the performance of the enhanced YOLOv5s algorithm against other algorithms using a shared dataset of pine wilt disease. The findings reveal that the proposed algorithm markedly enhances the model's capability to detect diseased wood, with a negligible impact on computational demand.

title: A New Image Encryption Technique based on Triple Playfair Cipher and Randomized Pixel Permutation Operation
authors: Alekha Kumar Mishra, Subodh Marandi, Ritik Lahari, Dhananjaya Behera, Sonali Kumari
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel Triple Playfair image encryption algorithm inspired by the popularity of the 3DES standard, with support for pixel permutation. The proposed algorithm uses three rounds of the standard Playfair algorithm with two different key matrices. The non-key elements of the key matrices are also re-positioned using a monoalphabetic substitution cipher to enhance the protection of image features. It is shown that the encryption process is the reverse of the decryption process and achieves a higher degree of diffusion of color intensity in the cipher image. The performance evaluation shows that the PSNR is marginally lower while still maintaining acceptable visual quality. The UACI values are significantly higher with standard NPCR value shows the ability of the proposed method to secure an image against various statistical attacks.

title: YOLOv8-SF: A Chip Defect Detection Model Based on Improved YOLOv8
authors: Qingya Yuan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Chip quality control is vital to maintaining the reliability and performance of electronic devices. Conventional manual inspection approaches are resource-intensive, time-consuming, and costly, highlighting the need for solutions based on computer vision. This paper presents an improved YOLOv8-based detection model, YOLOv8-SF, tailored for high-precision and lightweight chip defect detection. The proposed model integrates two key enhancements: the Squeeze-and-Excitation attention mechanism and the C2f_Faster module. The SE mechanism enhances chip defect detection by emphasizing important features through adaptive channel weighting. The C2f_Faster module, replacing the traditional Bottleneck structure, reduces computational complexity while maintaining efficient chip defect feature extraction. Experimental results demonstrate that YOLOv8-SF achieves outstanding performance compared to mainstream YOLO models with mAP50 of 88.6% and mAP50-95 of 72%, while maintaining low computational demands with 6.4 GFLOPS, making it highly suitable for industrial environments. Ablation experiments validate the effectiveness of the individual improvements, showing their contributions to both detection accuracy and computational efficiency. Furthermore, comparative experiments confirm that YOLOv8-SF outperforms existing YOLO models in detecting chip defects under complex conditions. This study not only introduces a lightweight and accurate detection framework for chip inspection but also provides valuable insights for developing high-performance object detection models in other industrial applications. Future work aims to improve this model's scalability and investigate its potential in wider industrial scenarios.

title: Fusion of Space-Borne Vision Transformers and GLCM Textures: A Dual-Path GVF-SVMApproach for Advanced Satellite Scene Classification
authors: Yogendra Chhetri, Srinivas Reddy Kosna
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Image classification of remote sensing images is an important task of environmental monitoring, urban planner and land use evaluation, but currently it is a problem because of the complexity and variability of aerial scenes. The classic methods tend to have problems with both intra-class variability and inter-class similarity, which are particularly acute in case of scarce labeled data and different imaging conditions. Based on the identification of these problems the present paper proposes a dual-path approach-GVF-SVM- that complements the handcrafted texture features using Gray Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM) with deep semantic representations learned using a ViT. The latter are concatenated by a fully connected layer and are then separated by a Support Vector Machine in the form of an RBF kernel, which is very non-linear in nature. What is new about it, though, is that it combines both classical and transformer-based paradigms into a single and explainable pipeline. The superiority of the method is proven by the experimental assessment of similarity on the UCMerced_LandUse dataset, which takes into account only eight classes of the most essential land use types and employs a thorough data augmentation strategy. GVF-SVM obtains a macro average accuracy of 93.76% and an overall better improvement rate over CNN s and transfer learning baselines. The findings highlight the efficacy and generalizability of the framework and hence it is a reliable candidate to remotely sense on a large-scale in real-life scenarios.

title: A Federated Reinforcement Learning Framework for Sustainable Energy Optimization in Edge-Driven Smart Grids
authors: M. Rudrakumar, Raja Sathish Kumar, Sradhanjali Pattanaik, M. Swetha, Mallareddy Adudhodla, M Bhavsingh
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Sustained complexity and decentralization of smart grids have made the older centralized energy optimization methods inadequate, mostly due to privacy concerns, the communication load, and scalability issues. The key need of modern edge-based smart energy systems is efficient, privacy secured and intelligent energy management. This investigation provides a Federated Reinforcement Learning (FRL) approach that could enhance energy consumption of distributed edge devices and secure users' privacy. The objective is to enable residential or microgrid systems within the grid to work as a collective to design effective control policies through the exchange of model parameters, without requiring raw data. Integrated to the proposed framework are Deep Q-Networks (DQNs) and Federated Averaging (FedAvg) and the performance under these conditions is assessed using the real-world Smart dataset which emulates interactions with 10 non-lID residential clients. Each agent itself tapers based on local data and synchronizes model parameters to the central server periodically. The system's primary elements are adaptive reward tuning, battery-conscious state representations, and economical communication techniques. Analysis reveals that the proposed FRL framework produces 14.7% energy savings, a 19.3% improvement of battery use, and 32% data transmission cost decrease compared. The framework demonstrates effective convergence and is easily adaptable to various client settings. This research verifies the efficiency of federated reinforcement learning to provide scalable, secure and efficient methods of energy optimization in real-world smart grid environments.

title: Intelligent Question Answering System Based on Large Language Model: Research on Application of Mixed Architecture
authors: Zihao Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The rapid evolution of artificial intelligence (AI) and natural language processing (NLP) has significantly transformed intelligent question-answering (QA) systems. Leveraging large language models (LLMs) with transformer-based architectures, these systems can comprehend and respond to complex natural language queries with remarkable accuracy, finding applications across various domains, including healthcare, education, and customer support. However, challenges such as factual inconsistencies, hallucinated responses, high computational demands, and domain-specific adaptability persist. To address these issues, hybrid architectures integrating LLMs with external knowledge bases and retrieval mechanisms have emerged, enhancing response accuracy, contextual relevance, and system efficiency. This study delves into the progression of QA systems, highlighting key milestones, persistent challenges, and the impact of hybrid architectures in advancing the field.
