title: Harnessing Machine Learning for Ocular Disease Detection: Performance Evaluation of Gradient Boosting Models
authors: Ragini Y P, Ghassan Samara, Swathi B, N E Chandra Prasad
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The risk of vision loss can be reduced by early diagnosis of ocular diseases and hence better patient outcomes. As the ophthalmic imaging data continues to increase, machine learning (ML) techniques are being used as effective method in elaborated disease diagnosis. The paper is dedicated to the implementation of the Gradient Boosting Models (GBMs) to the accurate discrimination and detection of different ocular diseases according to the fundus images features and patient metadata. The dataset which contained clinical characteristics like the age, sex, fundus images of both the eyes and related diagnostic keywords were examined. Data pre-processing and feature engineering have been performed to maximize the quality of data and derive the patterns of interest. Stratified k-fold cross-validation was used to provide robustness as well as avoiding over fitting using the GBM algorithm. The most important parameters by which the performance of the models was tested consisted of accuracy, precision, recall, Fl-score, and the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC-ROC). Findings indicate that GBMs have good diagnostic precision and generalizability rates concerning various ocular disorders. The present study presents the opportunity offered by ensemble learning, GBM in particular, to help ophthalmologists by giving them automated, trusted diagnostic support. The results can support applying ML models with interpretable behaviour to the clinical workflow to ensure the early diagnosis and treatment strategy in ophthalmology.

title: Research on the Dynamic Impact Model of ESG Ratings on Financing Using Reinforcement Learning
authors: Yuqian Dai, Chunlan Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a dynamic impact model of ESG ratings on financing based on reinforcement learning, aiming to optimize corporate financing decisions through deep reinforcement learning methods. This paper adopts the DQN algorithm, uses multiple variables such as ESG ratings, market risks, and corporate financial status as state inputs, and financing decisions (such as financing amount, financing interest rate, etc.) as actions. The optimization goal is to reduce financing costs and risks. The experimental results show that with the improvement of ESG ratings, the financing costs of enterprises show a significant downward trend, and the reinforcement learning model is more flexible than the traditional fixed rule financing model to adapt to changes in the market environment and effectively reduce financing costs. Specific data experiments show that when the ESG rating of an enterprise increases by 10%, its financing cost can be reduced by about 3.2%, and the prediction accuracy of the model is as high as 94%. In addition, in the process of optimizing financing decisions, the model can also flexibly adjust strategies and improve financing efficiency, which is crucial to the enhanced ability of reinforcement learning in dealing with complex decision-making problems. The research in this paper not only provides an innovative financing optimization method for the financial field, but also provides new ideas for the application of ESG ratings in financing, and promotes the process of transformation in the financial field.

title: A Machine Learning Pipeline for Evaluating Pre-Stimulus EEG Features and Their Impact on Post-Stimulus TMS-EEG Responses
authors: Sadaf Moaveninejad, Antonio Luigi Bisogno, Simone Cauzzo, Maurizio Corbetta, Camillo Porcaro
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) combined with electroencephalography (EEG) offers a direct window into cortical excitability and connectivity. Among several TMS-evoked potential (TEP) metrics, the absolute area under the curve (AUC) reflects the total energy of the post-stimulus response. However, the extent to which pre-stimulus neural features influence these responses remains unclear. This study presents a transparent machine learning pipeline to systematically evaluate how pre-stimulus spectral power and complexity measures predict post-stimulus TEPs. Methodological choices-including scaling techniques and feature selection methods (mutual information, LASSO, f-regression)-were rigorously compared and validated. The results demonstrate that gamma band power and Higuchi Fractal Dimension (HFD) consistently yield the highest predictive relevance. The best performance was achieved using the full feature set, suggesting a complementary role of spectral and nonlinear features. These findings emphasize the importance of methodological transparency and robust validation in TMS-EEG analysis. Future work may benefit from incorporating subject-specific modeling and connectivity-based features to enhance both prediction and neuroscientific insight.

title: Research on the Intelligent Recognition Pattern System of User Behavior in Social Networks Based on Data Mining
authors: Song Qiao, Song Zengren
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes an intelligent recognition pattern system of user behavior in social networks based on data mining, which aims to efficiently identify and analyze user behavior patterns and provide support for user research and application development in social networks. The core of the system adopts an optimized matrix decomposition algorithm to process complex social network interaction data through deep mining and feature extraction, and accurately identify user behavior patterns. Compared with traditional algorithms, this method has significant advantages in the ability to process massive data and recognition accuracy. This paper combines multi-feature fusion technology to deeply integrate multi-dimensional data of user behavior. The matrix decomposition algorithm is optimized in a targeted manner in the design, so that it can more efficiently process complex network structures and dynamic interaction data. Simulation tests on real social network data sets show that the system performs well in key indicators such as accuracy, recall rate and F1 value, reaching 93.7%, 91.2% and 92.4% respectively, which is significantly better than traditional methods. In addition, in large-scale data processing scenarios, the system shows good scalability and real-time performance, and can quickly adapt to changes in data scale and complexity.

title: Research on Accuracy Improvement of Global Camera Human-Machine Interaction and Local Camera Calibration of Intelligent Rebar Binding Robot
authors: Wang Qiling
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: In this paper, an intelligent rebar binding system based on machine vision is proposed, aiming to realize automatic identification and precise positioning of rebar intersection points. The system adopts a multilevel vision scheme combining global and local cameras, realizes the global positioning of the mold by eight high-resolution industrial cameras, and completes the local scanning and reconstruction of the rebar intersection points by using depth cameras. For point cloud data processing, a planar filtering and multilinear fitting method based on Random Sampling Consistency (RANSAC) algorithm is proposed, which effectively solves the noise interference and feature extraction problems of rebar point cloud. Meanwhile, the system significantly improves the accuracy of visual measurement through monocular camera calibration and aberration correction techniques. In terms of eye-in-hand calibration, the system adopts the “Eye-in-hand” mode to establish an accurate transformation relationship between the camera coordinate system and the robot end coordinate system, which provides a reliable spatial reference for the lashing path planning. The experimental results show that the system can efficiently and accurately identify the rebar intersection points, which provides a practical solution for automated rebar tying.

title: AI-Powered Satellite Tracking of Urban Trees
authors: G. Saranya, V. Sivasangari, B. Uma Maheswari
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Urban trees are critical for regulating microclimates, improving air quality, and sustaining biodiversity, yet monitoring their health at scale remains challenging. Traditional sensor-based or manual inspection systems are costly, slow, and difficult to scale across large metropolitan areas. This paper presents GreenScan, a novel large-language-model (LLM) powered platform that integrates citizen participation, multimodal machine learning, and retrieval-augmented knowledge bases to monitor urban tree health in real time. Citizens submit text descriptions and images of trees through a web or mobile interface. Images are processed by a vision-language encoder that extracts descriptive features, while a retrieval-augmented LLM consults a curated forestry knowledge base to infer potential diseases, stressors, or environmental impacts. The system provides immediate, evidence-backed recommendations and generates aggregated analytics for urban planners and environmental agencies. Results from simulated datasets and publicly available plant pathology images demonstrate the framework’s scalability, low deployment cost, and high diagnostic relevance compared to traditional sensor-only approaches. GreenScan illustrates how LLMs can bridge knowledge retrieval, visual reasoning, and community engagement to deliver actionable insights for sustainable urban forestry.

title: Exploring Focus Groups as a Technique for Knowledge Acquisition and Conceptualization Phases in Ontology Engineering
authors: Daniele Spoladore, Sara Vannelli, Filippo Visintin, Alberto Trombetta
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Focus Groups (FGs) bring together domain experts to discuss ideas and co-design in a collaborative way. Among the techniques suggested by Ontology Engineering Methodologies for knowledge acquisition, FGs are not suggested. In this work, we propose a preliminary experiment to assess the potentialities of FGs to validate a given conceptualization and elicit implicit and tacit knowledge through collaborative discussion. The ex-periment consisted of 5 FGs - guided by two analysts and a set of Competency Questions (CQs) - with different numbers of participants, who were asked to share their opinions over a conceptual map in the fields of Medical Devices (MDs) and Health Technology Assessment (HTA). All experts had experience in adopting MDs. They were MD manufacturers, clinicians, HTA analysts, or managers responsible for introducing new MDs into healthcare facilities. This work sketches the qualitative results from the FGs' discussions and presents the quantitative results of a questionnaire aimed at investigating participants' perspectives on FGs experience; in particular, knowledge acquisition and flexibility features, satisfaction, perceived role, and collaboration were assessed. Although preliminary, the results indicate that FG has the potential to elicit implicit and tacit knowledge and that using CQs to guide the discussion can result in an enhanced domain analysis phase during Ontology Engineering.

title: The Uncanny Valley: Is it the Body or the Mind?
authors: Clara Gangemi, Francesco Bossi, Caterina Vannucci, Lorenzo Cominelli, Enzo Pasquale Scilingo, Pietro Pietrini
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The Uncanny Valley (UV) phenomenon refers to the negative affective reaction people experience toward robots with highly human-like appearance. Ongoing debates in the literature question whether this effect is driven solely by appearance or by deeper socio-cognitive expectations. To contribute to this debate, the present study assessed disturbance ratings for robots, androids, and humans images, described as either mindful or mindless. The results indicate that mismatched mind descriptions affect uncanniness only when the entity's appearance allows for clear category identification (e.g., a mindless human), whereas for perceptually ambiguous entities (e.g., an android), appearance alone determines the uncanny response.

title: Research on 3D Reconstruction Method of Grid Structure Based on Deep Learning
authors: Zhang Jian, Meng Xiangchong, Zhu Wei, Shang Pengfei, Wang Wei, Tao Xin, Zhang Junjie, Li Ling, Huang Xiaokang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The grid structure has been used in public buildings as it has unique mechanical properties and spatial modeling advantages. Accurate and efficient three-dimensional reconstruction of grid structure is of great significance for architectural design, construction monitoring and structural analysis. The traditional 3D reconstruction method often has the problems of low precision and low efficiency in the face of complex grid structure. Therefore, in this paper, the relevant theories and technologies of deep learning in the field of 3D reconstruction are systematically sorted out, and the network model suitable for the reconstruction of the grid structure is analyzed by convolutional neural network, and the mechanism of extracting the geometric features of the grid structure is discussed. Secondly, according to the characteristics of the grid structure data, a special data set is constructed. It has significantly improved the reconstruction accuracy and efficiency, and can accurately restore the spatial geometry of grid structure, provide high-precision 3D model.

title: Improving Interpretability in Alzheimer's Prediction via Joint Learning of ADAS-Cog Scores
authors: Nur Amirah Abd Hamid, Mohd Shahrizal Rusli, Muhammad Thaqif Iman Mohd Taufek, Mohd Ibrahim Shapiai, Daphne Teck Ching Lai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Accurate prediction of clinical scores is critical for early detection and prognosis of Alzheimer's disease (AD). While existing approaches primarily focus on forecasting the ADASCog global score, they often overlook the predictive value of its sub-scores (13-items), which capture domain-specific cognitive decline. In this study, we propose a multi-task learning (MTL) framework that jointly predicts the global ADAS-Cog score and its sub-scores (13-items) at Month 24 using baseline MRI and longitudinal clinical scores from baseline and Month 6. The main goal is to examine how each sub-scores—particularly those associated with MRI features—contribute to the prediction of the global score, an aspect largely neglected in prior MTL studies. We employ Vision Transformer (ViT) and Swin Transformer architectures to extract imaging features, which are fused with longitudinal clinical inputs to model cognitive progression. Our results show that incorporating sub-score learning improves global score prediction. Subscore-level analysis reveals that a small subset—especially Q1 (Word Recall), Q4 (Delayed Recall), and Q8 (Word Recognition)—consistently dominates the predicted global score. However, some of these influential subscores exhibit high prediction errors, pointing to model instability. Further analysis suggests that this is caused by clinical feature dominance, where the model prioritizes easily predictable clinical scores over more complex MRI-derived features. These findings emphasize the need for improved multimodal fusion and adaptive loss weighting to achieve more balanced learning. Our study demonstrates the value of sub-score-informed modeling and provides insights into building more interpretable and clinically robust AD prediction frameworks. (Github repo provided)

title: A Proposal for a VR Serious Game for Training of Earthquake Early Warning Systems for Wearable Devices in the Context of Critical Environments
authors: Francesco Carotenuto, Giovanni Acampora, Aldo Zollo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The Earthquake Early Warning Systems (EEWS) are a critical tool for seismic risk mitigation, enabling protective measures such as automated shutdowns in critical infrastructure (e.g., nuclear plants, gas pipelines, etc) and individual safety responses. With the rapid advancement of wearable devices, Large Language Models (LLMs), Indoor Positioning Systems (IPS) and augmented reality, a new generation of EEWS is emerging. These new generation EEWS not only alert a user of the arrival of a potentially destructive seismic event, but are also able to actively support the operator working in the critical environment, during all phases of the seismic event by providing him with contextual safeguard information: to his actual state of health, to the place where he is at the time of the seismic event alert, maintaining a good degree of resilience to damage to the communication infrastructure both internal and external to the critical environment. This work aims to propose a Serious game in Virtual Reality (VR) that is essential both for developing this type of EEWS and in particular the development and validity of the workflow related to the management of the alert by the operator and as a training tool for the EEWS for real operators.

title: Evaluating Abex Data Augmentation on Common NLP Tasks
authors: Nishant Kumar, Anurag Bhanu, Priyanshu Raj, Anukul Kapoor, Akshay Deepak, Samant Saurabh
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: ABEX is a recently proposed state-of-the-art generative data augmentation technique that first transforms a document into a brief, abstract representation and then generates new documents by elaborating on that abstraction. ABEX produces a variety of semantically coherent augmentations by abstracting input text using Abstract Meaning Representation (AMR) graphs and subsequently expanding it with a sequence-to-sequence model (BART). This paper evaluates ABEX on three common Natural Language Understanding (NLU) tasks under low-resource conditions text summarization, sentiment analysis, and spam detection across a range of machine learning models. Improvements of up to 9.3% for sentiment analysis, 10.93% for text summarization, and 3% for spam detection were observed after applying ABEX. A qualitative discussion of the enhanced results is also included, featuring examples from all three tasks before and after augmentation.

title: “Xingqi Learning Companion Machine”: A New Model of Intelligent Educational Hardware Integrating Diverse Technologies
authors: Wenxuan Song
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This product is based on multiple recognition modes, with self-designed algorithms and reasonable hardware combinations. It integrates biosensing, machine vision, Python, OCR, object detection, and Raspberry Pi, and adds a user-friendly reminder module to achieve diverse and intelligent point-reading functions. Users can use our product to learn and expand unfamiliar knowledge and study multiple languages. It can assist users in learning foreign languages such as English and also provide convenience for blind people to read. The application scenarios are rich and diverse. It can not only recognize a single word when pointed at but also identify a module on a book drawn by hand, making learning more efficient and convenient. Moreover, this product proposes a new and implementable human-computer interaction method. It will be independently applied to the system and has functions such as gesture sensing, resonance rate, operation settings, human gesture recognition, and trigger channels, featuring accurate detection, efficient management, and a user-friendly design.

title: Enhanced 5 GHz Microstrip Patch Antenna with Octagonal Geometry and Coaxial Feed for Wireless Applications
authors: Murali Narayanan R, Anitha G, G. Ramkumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: An octagon-shaped microstrip antenna employing coaxial probe feeding is proposed in this work. The design utilizes RT Duroid 5880 as the substrate material, which has a dielectric constant of 2.2, and measures <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$63 \text{mm}\times 25\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. The radiating patch features an octagonal shape with a radius of 12.54 mm. A coaxial feed, composed of a copper outer ring and inner rod with dimensions of 3.8 mm and 1 mm respectively, and a Teflon inner ring of 1.3 mm diameter, is used to excite the antenna, with a total feed height of 5 mm. To enhance performance, RF switches modelled using lumped resistance, inductance, and capacitance components are incorporated into two slots on the patch, and an additional small octagonal slot is introduced at the center of the patch. The designed antenna achieves an impressive return loss of −76.99 dB, a VSWR of 1, an impedance of 49.99 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Omega$</tex>, and a peak gain of 7.1 dBi. The proposed antenna demonstrates suitability for 5G applications, including wireless networks, industrial automation systems, radar systems, point-to-point communication links, and medical imaging equipment.

title: An Adaptive Trust Evaluation Method for Distribution Terminal Based on Multi-dimensional Behavior Features
authors: Xinge Li, Yongcai Xiao, Wenming Mei, Chaoqun Kang, Yong Li, Lixiang Shen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the rapid evolution of new power systems, ensuring secure access for heterogeneous distribution terminals has emerged as a key challenge. Traditional trust evaluation methods focused on static rules or subjective experts and struggled to address sophisticated terminal behaviors. To tackle this problem, this paper proposes an adaptive evaluation method for distribution terminals with multidimensional behavior features. Leveraging a random forest regression algorithm, the proposed method integrates terminal attributes to quantify terminal trust dynamically while autonomously learning the impact of behavior features without relying on predefined rules. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method can identify five key behavioral factors with a cumulative contribution of over 90%, which can effectively evaluate the trustworthiness of distribution terminals. MSE, MAE and RSME of the evaluation model are close to 0, providing reliable support for secure access of different terminals in the distribution system.

title: Foreground-Aware Geometry Compression With Hybrid Attention for Large-Scale Point Clouds
authors: Liang Xie, Haoran Li, Baoliang Chen, Ge Li, Sam Kwong, Wei Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Broadcasting
abstract: Regions of Interest (ROI) play a crucial role in point cloud compression, especially in applications such as autonomous driving and robot navigation, where foreground regions often contain key information such as obstacles and object boundaries. However, traditional point cloud compression methods typically fail to optimize for these critical areas, instead applying uniform processing across the whole point clouds. The paper aims to optimize the point cloud compression process by allocating more bitstream resources to the foreground regions, thereby preserving important information in the point clouds. To achieve this, we propose a separation-based Foreground-Background Network (FB-Net) for compressing point cloud. The framework first identifies and separates the foreground and background regions, then designs an attention-based compression network, which includes multi-stage Occupancy Probability Estimation (OPE) module. The OPE module consist of an Attention-based Feature Extraction Layer (AFEL) and an Occupancy Probability Generation (AOPG) module. By controlling the number of OPE modules, we can allocate more bitstream resources to critical regions in the scene point cloud, such as tables and chairs, thus improving the performance of downstream detection tasks. Furthermore, to compensate for perceptual distortions in human vision, we design a large-scale receptive field-based Point Cloud Upsampling Network (PCU-Net), to enhance the objective quality. Through extensive experiments on point cloud datasets such as ScanNet and SUN RGB-D, we demonstrate that allocating more bitstream resources to the foreground regions benefits the accuracy of detection tasks. Compared to G-PCC and many state-of-the-art learning-based point cloud compression methods, our approach shows superior performance in detection tasks than compression-then-detection process methods.

title: Improving Ride Comfort in Automated Vehicles Using V2I Communication at Intersections
authors: Hadhoum Hajjaj, Edward R. Griffor, Wenqi Wendy Guo, Ahmed Lbath
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: As vehicle automation continues to progress to-wards full autonomy, the potential for increasingly sophisticated interactions between vehicles and traffic infrastructure presents new opportunities and challenges for improving the driving experience. One critical area is passenger comfort, particularly during transitions at signalized intersections. Vehicles that rely solely on onboard perception may respond abruptly to traffic signal changes, leading to uncomfortable acceleration or deceleration patterns. By leveraging vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) communication, automated systems could react in anticipation of signal transitions to enhance ride comfort and overall system efficiency. This study explores the potential benefits of V2I communication in enhancing passenger comfort at signalized intersections. Two operating scenarios are compared: one that relies exclusively on the car perception system, and another that incorporates V2I communication, which provides traffic signal timing data to the automated vehicle (AV). A co-simulation testbed integrating CARLA, Robot Operating System 2 (ROS 2), ns-3, and MATLAB/Simulink is developed to model both scenarios and assess passenger comfort based on acceleration and deceleration metrics. The results show that V2I-enabled AVs achieve smoother and more predictable deceleration, reducing abrupt maneuvers and enhancing ride comfort without compromising safety. By quantifying these improvements, this work contributes to a better understanding of how V2I communication can enhance passenger experience while supporting safer and more anticipatory driving behaviors.

title: Physics-Informed Neural Network Method for the Thermal Optimization of Turbulence and Heat Transfer in a Shell-and-Tube Heat Exchanger
authors: José Sánchez-De-La-Hoz, Alexander Troncoso-Palacio, Jaime Fernández Marenco, Paul Sanmartin-Mendoza, Daniel Marcelo-Aldana, George Archbold-Taylor
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Shell-and-tube heat exchangers are critical components in industrial thermal systems where energy efficiency and performance depend on turbulence modeling and heat transfer efficiency. Conventional optimization relies on Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) using Reynolds-Averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) models such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k-\varepsilon$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k-\omega S S T$</tex>, which, although accurate, demand high computational resources and often struggle to generalize turbulent flow behavior. In this work, a PhysicsInformed Neural Network (PINN) framework is proposed for the thermal optimization of turbulence and heat transfer in a FUNKE A100 shell-and-tube heat exchanger. The system was modeled in SolidWorks and simulated with ANSYS Fluent under steady-state turbulent flow conditions, supported by mesh independence analyses to ensure numerical reliability. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k-\varepsilon$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k-\omega S S T$</tex> turbulence models were validated against manufacturer data, with results indicating that <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k-\omega S S T$</tex> provided a more accurate prediction of near-wall gradients (4.7% deviation) compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k\varepsilon(7.9 \%)$</tex>. Heat transfer coefficients reached <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$812 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \cdot \mathrm{K}$</tex> under optimal flow conditions, while shell-side pressure drops were quantified at 21.4 kPa. These CFD datasets were subsequently used to train and evaluate the PINN model, which successfully reproduced thermal-hydraulic behaviors with a mean relative error below 3.5%, while reducing computational cost by approximately 85% compared to traditional CFD. The integration of physics-based deep learning and governing conservation laws demonstrates that PINNs can deliver accurate, fast, and scalable predictions of turbulent heat transfer, enabling real-time optimization and offering a robust alternative to CFD for the design and operation of industrial heat exchangers.

title: Performance Evaluation of Large Language Models using RAG based Metrics in Responsible AI
authors: Sanya Tripathi, Nancy Sinha, Rahul Mahadik, Krity Kansara
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive and multi-dimensional evaluation of state-of-the-art open-source Large Language Models (LLMs) across nine key metrics: Faithfulness, Answer Relevancy, Contextual Relevancy, Contextual Precision, Contextual Recall, Summarization Quality, Bias, Toxicity, and Prompt Alignment. We benchmark prominent LLMs model (like LLaMA3.2-3B, Gemma, Mistral, and BioMistral) using task-aligned and rigorously curated datasets. Our objective is to quantify tradeoff across performance variability and safety dimensions, offering a transparent, interpretable comparison to guide responsible model selection for diverse application domains. The evaluation methodology provides valuable insights into model capabilities, limitations, and trade-offs, supporting principled decision-making in real-world LLM deployments.

title: Deep Learning Techniques For Option Price Prediction: A Comparative Analysis
authors: Shubhangi Porwal, Namita Srivastava, Manoj Jha
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Artificial intelligence has become increasingly popular in the financial sector in the modern era. In contrast to traditional parametric methods, nonparametric approaches for pricing options have been found to offer higher prediction quality and need less computing time. This study performs a thorough comparison of different deep learning approaches: Convolutional neural network, Long-short term memory neural network, Bidirectional long-short term memory neural network, and Multi-layer perceptron in predicting the price of European call options. With the help of Pearson correlation coefficient and the Principal Component Analysis (PCA) technique, we carefully selected a set of fourteen predictors based on technical indicators and fundamental (historical) market data to capture the fluctuations of the financial market. The efficacy of applied models is analyzed using evaluation metrics: Root mean square error (RMSE), R-squared (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex>), and Mean absolute error (MAE). Additionally, we carried out statistical analysis to test the significance of the applied models, ensuring reliability and stability. For executives in risk management, institutional investors, traders and other stakeholders, this study is a valuable resource. In addition, it offers insightful research ideas to future researchers in this area.

title: NLOS: Experimental Evaluation of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Disease Prediction Based on Neural Learning and Optimization Strategy
authors: R B Revathi, T P Ramachandran
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) is normally diagnosed through a series of medical tests process that is often slow and stressful for the patient. Recent studies have recognized speech as a useful biomarker for neurodegenerative disorders. Automatized approaches for the prediction of ALS progression provide a more accurate and time-efficient alternative to the subjective and labor-intensive manual examination. This paper present the Neural Learning and Optimization Strategy (Neural-LOS) model, a novel advanced model for automatic ALS speech detection. Filters can well separate speech characteristics between ALS and non-ALS subjects and distinguish samples in a binary form. The investigation consists of two different classifiers: (i) a sample-based classifier that performs epoch-by-epoch classification of the speech samples, and (ii) a patient-based classifier that uses a majority voting mechanism over the sample-based classifier decisions, for each patient. Results indicate that this model is effective and in prospect, it has the ability to develop a low-cost, user-friendly tool which might be helpful for early screening of ALS.

title: Network Intrusion Detection Using Big Data Analytics - A Study on UNSW-NB15 Dataset
authors: Shiela David, A. Nethra Devi, Mohammed Aasim
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Intrusion detection systems (IDSs) are currently drawing a great amount of interest as a key part of system defense. IDSs collect network traffic information from various points on the network or computer system and then use this information to secure the network. Distinguishing between normal and malicious network activities is challenging and time-consuming due to the large volume of data and complex patterns involved. Traditionally, an analyst must review extensive datasets to identify sequences of intrusion within network connections. Thus, there is a need for efficient methods to detect network intrusions that reflect current network traffic conditions. In this study, a novel method is proposed to identify intrusion characteristics for IDSs using a stacking classifier in machine learning. The method involves generating rules through classification by a stacking classifier that combines multiple models to improve prediction accuracy. These rules can identify intrusion characteristics and are implemented in the stacking classifier to not only detect the presence of intrusions but also to execute preventive actions by denying intrusions. The classification of attack types includes: Fuzzers, Analysis, Backdoors, DoS, Exploits, Generic, Reconnaissance, Shellcode, Worms, and Normal. The evaluation techniques used to assess the performance of the proposed method include Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Squared Error (MSE), and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE). This approach aims to enhance the effectiveness of IDSs by leveraging the strengths of ensemble learning, thus providing a more robust and accurate detection and prevention mechanism for network intrusions.

title: QuITO v.2: Numerical Solutions with Uniform Error Guarantees to Optimal Control Problems under Path Constraints
authors: Siddhartha Ganguly, Rihan Aaron D'Silva, Debasish Chatterjee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: This article introduces a new transcription, change point localization, and mesh refinement scheme for direct optimization-based solutions and for uniform approximation of optimal control trajectories associated with a class of optimal control problems (OCPs) for control affine nonlinear systems under convex cost and path constraints. The base transcription algorithm, for which we establish the mesh refinement scheme, is a direct multiple shooting technique (DMS) — QuITO v.2 (Quasi-Interpolation based Trajectory Optimization). The mesh refinement scheme consists of two steps — localization of certain irregular regions in an optimal control trajectory via wavelets, followed by a targeted mesh refinement approach around such regions of irregularity. Theoretical approximation guarantees on uniform grids are presented for optimal controls with certain regularity properties, along with guarantees of localization of change points by the wavelet transform. Numerical illustrations are provided for control trajectories involving irregularities to show the effectiveness of the localization and refinement strategy. We also announce and make freely available a new software package developed based on QuITO v.2 for completeness of the article.

title: Financial Time Series Forecasting Analysis Based on Gradient Boosting Decision Tree Modeling
authors: Haoran Liu, Yongxi Mu, Huifang Liu, Yue Wu, Ziyi Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The aim of this study is to investigate the application of Gradient Boosted Decision Tree (GBDT) model in time series forecasting in financial markets and its effectiveness. The complexity and dynamics of financial markets make traditional time series models limited in capturing nonlinear relationships, and machine learning algorithms provide new ideas to cope with this situation. GBDT, as an integrated learning algorithm, demonstrates a powerful nonlinear fitting capability and feature selection function through the iterative combination of multiple decision trees. In this study, the GBDT model is first analyzed in detail and compared with traditional statistical models (e.g., ARIMA) and other machine learning models to evaluate its performance in stock price prediction in the U.S. financial market. Then, in order to improve the prediction effect of the model, this paper also carries out an in-depth study on the parameter optimization and sensitivity analysis of the GBDT model. Ultimately, it is shown that GBDT is highly adaptable in dealing with financial market data and can provide more accurate prediction results than traditional models.

title: Transient Voltage Impact Mechanism and Control Technologies of Grid-Connected Distributed Photovoltaics
authors: Tao Zhou, Zhixin Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: Distributed photovoltaics (DPV) has become a key element in energy transition, but its grid integration introduces significant challenges to transient voltage stability of distribution networks. This paper presents a comprehensive review of the transient voltage impact mechanism and control technologies of grid-connected DPV. In terms of the impact mechanism, it analyzes the dynamic interaction between DPV and distribution networks, including changes in power flow direction and voltage distribution caused by single or multiple DPV grid connections, and discusses quantitative assessment methods for transient voltage stability such as time-domain simulation, energy function, and artificial intelligence-based methods. Regarding control technologies, it elaborates on ontology control technologies based on optimized DPV reactive power control strategies, distributed control technologies comparing local, centralized, and cluster control modes, and cooperative control technologies involving coordinated operation of traditional reactive power compensation devices and DPV inverters, with emphasis on the role of artificial intelligence algorithms in multi-time scale coordination and heterogeneous device collaboration. This review provides in-depth insights for mitigating transient voltage impacts of DPV integration and supports stable and efficient operation of distribution networks with high photovoltaic penetration.

title: Intention-Aware Session-Based Recommendation with Sparse Attention Mechanism
authors: Wenming Cao, Hongjun Liu, Lu Cheng, Xujun Yang, Bing Li, Man Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: Session sequences are inherently complex due to user anonymity, making it challenging to infer user intent. Existing session-based recommendation models often overemphasize the last click, which may not truly reflect user preferences. To address this, we propose IASSR-an Intention-Aware Session-based Recommendation model with sparse attention. IASSR employs sparse self-attention to filter irrelevant items and extract target embeddings, followed by an intent-aware filter that captures fine-grained item details to model dynamic user intent. The final fused representation predicts the next click. Experiments on Nowplaying and Tmall show that IASSR outperforms baselines in HR{@}10 and MRR{@}10. Ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of its core components: target embedding learning, intent-aware filtering, and item positional encoding.

title: MAPF-HD: Multi-Agent Path Finding in High-Density Environments_supp1-3642762.mp4
authors: Hiroya Makino
publish: N/A
abstract: Multiagent path finding (MAPF) involves planning efficient paths for multiple agents to move simultaneously while avoiding collisions. In typical warehouse environments, agents are often sparsely distributed along aisles; however, increasing the agent density can improve space efficiency. When the agent density is high, it becomes necessary to optimize the paths not only for goal-assigned agents but also for those obstructing them. This study proposes a novel MAPF framework for high-density environments (MAPF-HD). Several studies have explored MAPF in similar settings using integer linear programming (ILP). However, ILP-based methods require substantial computation time to optimize all agent paths simultaneously. Even in small grid-based environments with fewer than 100 cells, these computations can take tens to hundreds of seconds. Such high computational costs render these methods impractical for large-scale applications such as automated warehouses and valet parking. To address these limitations, we introduce the phased null-agent swapping (PHANS) method. PHANS employs a heuristic approach to incrementally swap positions between agents and empty vertices. This method solves the MAPF-HD problem within a few seconds, even in large environments containing more than 700 cells. The proposed method has the potential to improve efficiency in various real-world applications, such as warehouse logistics, traffic management, and crowd control.

title: Bridging Theory and Practice: A Model-Free Control Educational Experience on the EPC Trainer
authors: Luis Caiza, Diego S. Benitez, Oscar Camacho
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This paper presents the implementation and experimental evaluation of a Model-Free PID controller applied to the EPC Educational Plant. The proposed approach does not require an explicit process model and relies solely on input-output data, simplifying tuning and improving robustness against disturbances and model uncertainties. The performance of the Model-Free PID is compared with that of a conventional PID controller under the same operating conditions. Results highlight the advantages of the Model-Free strategy in terms of ease of implementation, reduced sensitivity to process changes, and suitability for educational and cost-sensitive industrial environments.

title: Design of Burst Mode Enabled SRAM Controller Using FSM
authors: Paramasivam. C, Gunnala Meghana Sri
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Static Random Access Memory (SRAM) is crucial for high-speed digital systems, but because it operates asynchronously, interfacing with synchronous logic can be difficult. This paper brings up the gradual development of two SRAM controllers(controller five and controller six) depending on Finite State Machines (FSMs), which solved particular concerns resulting in a bus write-contention, smaller write-enable (WE) pulse width, and unconfirmed tristate control. The last architecture, Controller 6 brings a new burst-mode operation, full cycle WE compatibility, dedicated precharge stage, tristate safety to provide timing integrity and data asynchronous at high frequency range (50MHz and 100MHz). Simulation of the controller is implemented on xilinx Vivado, and post synthesis analysis done on Cadence Genus. Controller 6 exhibits better slack, lesser setup time and non-contention than earlier designs. It is also well-suited as an embedded system designed on FPGA using fast and reliable communication in SRAM because it is integration of friendly and has strong behavior.

title: LLM-Powered Code Quality Bot: Automating Refactoring in CI/CD
authors: Akram Adem, Glaucia Melo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Code quality issues, such as code smells and minor bugs, consume valuable developer time and can slow down software delivery pipelines. This poster presents SonaRefactor, an AI-assisted CI/CD pipeline that merges SonarCloud static analysis with Gemini LLM to automatically summarize flagged issues and propose safe, minimal code fixes. When a pull request is opened, the bot automatically detects issues, explains them in context, and generates a minimal safe autofix that is committed back as a new pull request. This work demonstrates how large language models can act as hands-on teammates in software development pipelines, offloading repetitive refactoring tasks so developers can focus on more complex and creative aspects of software engineering. Our tool minimizes developer interruption by enforcing conservative, auditable changes that reduce friction in the review process, without compromising safety or autonomy.

title: IoT-Enabled Interactive Solar Energy System Optimization and Fault Detection
authors: Vishnu Dev, Kuwar Mausam
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: This paper is contains an analytical investigation of data driven energy optimization and real-time fault detection in IoT-enabled interactive photovoltaic (PV) grid systems. The conventional PV systems are usually inefficient and response time of faults is too slow and the outcome is low energy production and high costs of operation. Through the adoption of Internet of Things (IoT) including sensor, networks, real-time communications (MQTT, CoAP) and edge-cloud analysis, PV systems can continuously adapt to changes in the environment and faults can be identified with low latency. The performance of the system was assessed on a hybrid experimental configuration that involves the combination of physical hardware and MATLAB/ Simulink simulation platform. Results indicate that there has been an improvement of the daily energy yield by 12.8 percent and a substantial decrease in the time fault response time in IoT enhanced systems by 15 minutes to less than 30 seconds. Support Vector Machines and Random Forests machine learning algorithms were used to detect anomalies and did so with high accuracy. Scalable data analysis and visualization with hierarchical computing (edge, fog, cloud) was also implemented into the system architecture.

title: Integration of Wearable Sensors and Metabolic Chamber Data for Energy Expenditure Assessment: A Preliminary Study
authors: Giulio Pisaneschi, Gianluca Rho, Alberto Greco, Mirko Marracci, Alessio Basolo, Ferruccio Santini, Enzo Pasquale Scilingo, Alberto Landi, Paolo Piaggi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Accurate assessment of energy expenditure is crucial for characterizing human metabolism and health. The gold standard method for measuring energy expenditure is indirect calorimetry in a metabolic chamber, which provides accurate estimates of metabolic rate under controlled conditions. However, the limited availability of metabolic chambers worldwide limits large-scale research and clinical applications. Wearable technologies offer a promising alternative, allowing continuous monitoring of key physiological parameters such as heart rate variability, electrodermal activity, and physical activity, all of which correlate with metabolic rate. This study integrates 24-hour metabolic chamber measurements and multimodal wearable sensor data to quantify day-night (diurnal-nocturnal) differences in energy expenditure and autonomic state. Physiological data were collected using two multimodal wearable devices: a textile-based smart t-shirt (Wearable Wellness System, Smartex) and a wrist-worn smartwatch (Embrace Plus, Empatica). In a preliminary sample of six healthy men, the median metabolic rate was 42% higher during the daytime compared to nighttime, mirroring a 3.1-fold increase in sympathetic electrodermal activity power during the day. During daytime, metabolic rate showed the strongest pooled Spearman correlations with heart rate variability features derived from the smart t-shirt: mean RR interval (average time between heartbeats; <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\rho=-0.37$</tex>), low-frequency <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\rho=-0.31)$</tex>, and high-frequency <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\rho=-0.28)$</tex> components. At night, tonic electrodermal activity (EDA) features from the smartwatch (Embrace Plus) were most informative, with the minimum (minTonic, lowest baseline skin conductance, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\rho=0.36$</tex>) and mean (meanTonic, average baseline skin conductance, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\rho=0.34$</tex>) values showing the highest associations. Synchronizing wearable-derived measures with continuous chamber calorimetry validates their ability to track diurnal metabolic dynamics and provides a foundation for large-scale metabolic monitoring, facilitating broader applications in health and metabolic research.

title: Evaluating Knowledge Management Capabilities in a Peruvian Agricultural Research Station
authors: Silvia Elisa Ayqui-Vilca, Carlos Guillermo Hernández-Cenzano, Nilton César Portugal-Charre, Richard A. Montalván-Simón
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study evaluates the status of knowledge management (KM) within a public agricultural research station in Peru. A structured survey instrument was applied to 40 workers, obtaining 27 responses, assessing six KM dimensions: leadership, technology, organizational culture, knowledge production, storage, and transfer. The methodology combined descriptive statistical analysis, hierarchical and k-means clustering, and principal component analysis (PCA) to identify capability gaps and perception patterns among institutional units. The results reveal an incipient level of KM maturity, characterized by limited documentation practices, weak internal policies, and underutilized technological infrastructure. Based on PCA outputs, a hybrid KM model is proposed, integrating institutional policy, collaborative culture, infrastructure, and knowledge codification strategies. This work contributes empirical evidence to the development of KM systems in public research institutions in Latin America.

title: Financial Fraud Detection Model based on Autoencoder Feature Learning and XGBoost
authors: Bingcheng Zhang, Ke Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Financial fraud not only causes huge financial losses to financial institutions, but also threatens the stability of the entire financial system. In order to effectively detect and prevent financial fraud, this study proposes a novel detection model based on Autoencoder feature learning and XGBoost, aiming to improve the accuracy and efficiency of financial fraud detection. We use Autoencoders for feature learning. An Autoencoder is a neural network structure that is trained to compress input data into a low-dimensional representation by an encoder, and then reconstruct the original input by a decoder. In doing so, the Autoencoder is able to capture the intrinsic patterns in the data and filter out the noise to extract more representative features. These characteristics not only retain the main information of the original data, but also better reflect the characteristics of potential fraud. The features extracted by the Autoencoder are fed into the XGBoost classifier. XGBoost is a gradient boosting decision tree (GBDT)-based machine learning algorithm known for its efficiency, flexibility, and excellent performance. It works by constructing a series of weak classifiers and combining them additively to form a strong classifier, while utilizing regularization terms to prevent overfitting. XGBoost excels at handling high-dimensional sparse data, making it ideal for financial fraud detection tasks. Experimental results show that compared with the traditional XGBoost model, the proposed model based on Autoencoder feature learning has significant improvement in accuracy, recall and F1 score. The model can not only effectively identify known types of fraud, but also have certain generalization capabilities to deal with emerging fraud methods. In addition, explanatory analysis of the model can provide valuable insights for financial institutions to understand which characteristics are most important for fraud detection.

title: Design and Development of the Holographic Risk Perception Platform for Cable Tunnel
authors: Yupeng Hou, Gang Tian, Zhiren Tian, Zhenhua Wang, Jinqiang He, Bo Gong, Xinran Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: As the core infrastructure of urban power transmission, cable tunnels face complex fire risks, and the traditional monitoring system is difficult to meet the modern safety management needs due to its decentralized function and lagging response. This paper proposes a holographic risk sensing platform for cable tunnels based on the four-level linkage of “sensing-transmission-application-decision-making”, which realizes real-time monitoring of environmental parameters and accurate early warning of fire risk through the integration of multi-source sensor networks and artificial intelligence technology. The platform adopts the hierarchical analysis method (AHP) to build a risk assessment model, combining expert scoring and judgment matrix to quantify the weight relationship between fire facilities, video monitoring, environmental and gas parameters and other dimensions to form a hierarchical early warning mechanism; and through the fusion of multi-source heterogeneous data, four-dimensional alarm algorithms, intelligent video analysis and the integration of security and fire safety technology, to build a “monitoring-analysis-response” closed-loop system. Experimental results show that the platform can reduce the false alarm rate to more than 85%, significantly improving the early detection of fire hazards and emergency response efficiency. The study not only provides intelligent solutions for cable tunnel safety management, but also provides theoretical support and practical reference for the digital transformation of risk prevention and control in urban underground space with its flexible architecture and core technology.

title: Integrating Cross-Domain Data Analytics through LLM-Derived Embedding and Transfer Learning Techniques
authors: Sukanth Korkanti
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Nowadays, data are being generated from so many diversified domains, characterized by their own traits and intricacies. Data integration from such diversified sources poses significant challenges in heterogeneity, scalability, and meaningful feature representation. The paper introduces a new paradigm for cross-domain analytics using the power of LLM-derived embeddings combined with transfer learning techniques. This will also enable us to show how LLMs can effectively capture complex patterns and semantic relationships within and across domains. We take real-world datasets across diverse sectors such as healthcare, finance, and social media, and show that it is possible to leverage state-of-the-art LLMs for creating high-dimensional embeddings as a unified representation framework across diverse data sources. These are then followed by transfer learning to fine-tune such embeddings on a specific analytical task, hence improving the generalization of the model and its accuracy across diverse applications. We show via an extensive set of experiments that our integrative approach substantially improves both the predictive performance and interpretability of traditional cross-domain analytics methods. Moreover, since transfer learning is applied here, much fewer labeled data are needed, making the approach quite time-effective and scalable. The findings point to the possibility of extracting the embeddings from LLMs, which further uses transfer learning to bridge the gap between disparate data domains and allows for much more robust and deep analytics. This advancement not only strengthens the capability for data-driven decision-making but also opens up new avenues for interdisciplinary research and innovation. This will enable organizations to unearth deeper insights, to drive more informed strategies in an increasingly data-rich environment, by embedding cross-domain data analytics using sophisticated techniques of embedding and transfer learning.

title: Joint Deployment, Power Control and Beamforming Designs for Movable Antenna-aided UAV Communication: A DRL-based Two-Stage Approach
authors: Tao Zhou, Kui Xu, Guojie Hu, Chunguo Li, Xiaochen Xia, Yufan Chen, Chen Wei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Movable antenna (MA) technology enables flexible beamforming through adaptive adjustment of antenna positions, thereby enhancing communication performance. This paper investigates the MA-aided air-to-ground (A2G) system, where an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) equipped with MAs serves multiple ground users. The primary objective is to jointly optimize UAV deployment, antenna positions, beamforming, and power control to maximize the downlink communication sum rate. A key challenge lies in the difficulty of acquiring complete instantaneous channel state information (I-CSI), as the antennas cannot traverse all possible positions to obtain such full-scale I-CSI, which impedes the efficient optimization of system parameters. To address this challenge, we propose a two-stage transmission scheme: in the first stage, location-aware statistical CSI (S-CSI) is leveraged to optimize UAV deployment, power control, and MA positions for maximizing long-term system performance, while the second stage estimates I-CSI based on the optimized UAV and antenna positions to refine short-term transmit beamforming after long-term variables are determined, thereby substantially reducing CSI acquisition overhead. For long-term policy optimization, we introduce a novel dual-spatial-scale hierarchical deep reinforcement learning (DSSH-DRL) framework, which preserves flexibility in global policy formulation while enhancing training efficiency via effective decoupling of control variables. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm and validate the promising application potential of MA technology in A2G communication networks.

title: DisHelis: Optimizing Deployment of Disaggregated LLMs Inference Serving over Heterogeneous Environments via Hierarchical Max-Flow
authors: Tao Zhang, Huihuang Qin, Dong Jin, Shuangwu Chen, Huasen He, Xiaobin Tan, Shiyin Zhu, Jian Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: Disaggregated LLM inference service (DLIS), which decouples the compute-intensive prefill phase and the memory-intensive decode phase, enables more flexible and efficient resource usage. Existing solutions for deploying DLIS are typically designed for homogeneous environments. However, real-world production environments are becoming increasingly heterogeneous due to GPU shortages and rapid hardware evolution. Deploying DLIS in heterogeneous environments introduces three key challenges: (1) complicated GPU resource allocation caused by significant performance differences between GPUs; (2) communication bottlenecks caused by additional key-value (KV) cache transfers; and (3) dynamic inference loads caused by time-varying arrival rates and diverse task types. Existing methods adopted uniform model partitioning on heterogeneous GPUs and single-instance partitioning, suffering from heavy straggler effect and cross-node communication overheads. Additionally, they rely on reloading model parameters for dynamic tasks, which leads to significant service interruptions. To address these issues, we propose DisHelis, a high-throughput and low-latency DLIS system for heterogeneous environments. We formulate the DLIS deployment over heterogeneous environments as a hierarchical max-flow problem. This formulation jointly incorporates non-uniform model partitioning and hybrid instance partitioning to maximize DLIS throughput. Furthermore, we design a light-weight instance-switching approach to handle dynamic tasks without service interruptions. We solve it via a hierarchical alternating optimization algorithm that iteratively converges to a high-quality deployment plan. Experimental results show that DisHelis improves throughput by up to 1.63× and reduces latency by up to 2.4× over existing approaches.

title: Integrating Artificial Intelligence in Language Education: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Pan Qi, Nurul Farhana Binti Jumaat, Hassan Abuhassna
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: AI integration in language education has significantly improved students' language proficiency and created an engaging learning environment. However, some challenges continue to hinder the development of AI. While existing literature reviews tend to focus narrowly on specific AI technologies and language skills. To address this gap, this study aims to conduct a comprehensive systematic literature review to critically analyze <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A I$</tex> integration in language education, exploring its contributions to language learning. We methodically selected and analyzed 27 papers from 226 documents based on the WOS and Scopus databases. Our findings indicate that the main challenges are limited sample size, technical difficulty, ethical issues, short research duration, etc. To address these challenges, more empirical research with a larger sample size and a long-term duration is needed to validate the effect of AI tools in language education. Accordingly, both students and instructors should undergo systematic training to tackle technical issues. Finally, combining AI technologies with human instructions is recommended as a future direction to ensure the accuracy of feedback and address ethical considerations.

title: Smart Insole for Foot Pressure Monitoring and Therapeutic Support
authors: S. Shanmugapriya, N.Chelli Devi, J. Sandhiya, P. Karthika, E. Rathesh, P. Prathisha
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Driving long distances can be tiring and can cause discomfort in the driver’s legs and feet due to the constant pressing of the accelerator and brake. This can, over the long term, cause foot and leg discomfort. In response to this issue, we developed an innovative insole with integrated massagers. The insole works with the use of pressure sensors that determine the pressure the driver’s foot is exerting on the brake and accelerator. When the pressure is too intense, the vibrating motors on the insole start working. The motors provide relaxing relief to the feet, aiding in the relief of basic discomfort. Undoubtedly, the massagers serve to alleviate discomfort in the feet and legs, in addition to decreasing the driver’s fatigue. The insole is thin and lightweight, so it can easily fit inside normal shoes without causing any difficulty or discomfort. Overall, this smart provides a simple, practical, and highly effective solution to improve comfort and relaxation. Smart insole food pressure and massage relief satisfy the sustainable goals like SDG 3 Good Health and Well-Being.

title: 3D Shape Identity Matching Across Domains using Shared Kernel Transform Learning with Laplacian-Beltrami Operator
authors: Yu Wang, Dan Zhang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Identity matching (ID matching) across domains using skull or facial features is a challenging task, particularly when transitioning from homogeneous-domain (face-face) to heterogeneous-domain (skull-face). To mitigate the computational errors in ID matching caused by the strong dependence on sampling locations for shape feature descriptions and the limitations of linear matching techniques, we propose a shared kernel transform learning (SKTL) method leveraging the Laplacian-Beltrami operator (LBO) for shape feature description, referred to as LBOSKTL. The LBO is unaffected by sampling locations and captures both global and local shape information, spanning low to high-frequency descriptions. By integrating the LBO with a kernel version of shared transform learning algorithm, we derive a transform matrix via nonlinear ways, addressing the complex nonlinear relationships between shapes as they align with real-world scenarios in the LBO kernel feature space. Subsequently, the Gram matrix is employed to solve the problem. In the matching process, shape similarity is assessed by comparing the sparse coefficient/representation induced by the transform matrix. We validate the efficacy of our method through three datasets – multilinear model, FaceWarehouse, and FaceScape – demonstrating its performance in 3D skull-face and face-face ID matching tasks, with evaluation based on quantitative metrics such as matching accuracy and F1 scores.

title: A Hybrid Space Vector Modulation Method for Current Source Rectifier
authors: Naizhe Diao, Xiaoqing Zhang, Ruizhen Zhang, Xiaoqiang Guo, Yupeng Wei, Ning Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: In order to ensure continuous DC link current, the overlap time introduced in the switching process of the current source rectifier (CSR) can lead to undesirable harmonics and reduce grid-side current quality. To address this issue, a hybrid space vector modulation (HSVM) method is proposed. This method designs two current vector sequence modes by reconstructing the sequence of the dwell current vectors. Then, an adaptive threshold decision (ATD) method is introduced, which can dynamically select two sequence modes during the modulation process to solve the current sharing phenomenon. The proposed method no longer need to add overlap time in modulation and fundamentally eliminates the overlap time effect (OTE). Moreover, it can minimize the switching times by using reverse voltage to block the on-state switches. By comparing with the ideal five-segment space vector modulation, theoretical analysis, simulation and experimental results prove the effectiveness of HSVM in improving system performance and minimizing the number of switching operations.

title: Web based Smart Ration Card System and Time Efficiency using MERN Stack
authors: K Monisha, U M Vimal Sachin, T Subalaxmi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: People living in rural and urban slum areas are disproportionately affected by the Public Distribution System’s (PDS) ongoing problems, which include lengthy wait times, a lack of real-time information, manual recordkeeping errors, and operational inefficiencies. These restrictions lead to decreased customer satisfaction, delayed service delivery, and crowded ration shops. A Web-Based Smart Ration Card and Time Efficiency System utilizing the MERN Stack (MongoDB, Express.js, React.js, and Node.js) is suggested as a cutting-edge and scalable digital solution to address these problems. A React-powered interface facilitates safe beneficiary registration utilizing ration card and Aadhaar details, while a Node.js-Express backend effectively manages shop data management, automatic notifications, and authentication. For all user profiles and transaction records, MongoDB offers scalable, transparent, and safe storage. Beneficiaries can more effectively schedule their trips thanks to a real-time queue monitoring system that continuously monitors client traffic and instantly notifies them when the queue length drops below a predetermined threshold. In order to ensure optimal resource utilization, the system also incorporates welfare-oriented features including automatic identification of unclaimed ration goods for redistribution to approved orphanages and temporary home delivery for senior residents and people with health issues The proposed system improves efficiency, reduces crowding, cuts waiting times by $30-40 \%$, and increases transparency the distribution process when compared to conventional manual operations. All things considered, the system provides a clever, citizen-friendly, and time-efficient digital infrastructure for the distribution of public rations.

title: Real-Time Intrusion Detection System for Wi-Fi-Based Wireless Sensor Networks using Deep Learning and Explainable AI
authors: S. Thiruvenkatasamy, V Boobalan, L Gokul, V Keerthi, S Logeshwaran
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: As the amount of wireless sensor networks (WSN) built into Wi-Fi-based IoT systems is growing at a rapid pace, the growing degree of connectivity has increased the threat of cyberattacks, including information leakage, network outage, and communication blockade. Current machine-learningbased IDSs are poor in scalability, transparency, and high false positive, making them inappropriate in current dynamic networks. To combat these problems, this paper suggests a real-time Intrusion Detection System (IDS) based on Deep Learning (DL) and Explainable AI (XAI). It uses CNN-LSTM-DNN ensemble to train on intricate spatial-temporal network traffic features, and SHAP to interpret to determine the most significant features associated with attacks. An interactive dashboard (Streamlit based) is deployed in order to visualize the performance metrics, SHAP information, and traffic categories. Tests on the UNSWNB15 and synthetic IoT-WSN datasets indicate the 99.36 and 1.1 percent detection and false positive errors, respectively, which are higher than the conventional ML and single-scale DL methods. These findings indicate that XAI should be used together with DL to enhance the transparency and practical implementation to provide a next-generation IoT and WSN security solution that can be scaled and efficiently implemented.

title: Hierarchical Robust Spacing and Speed Control Against Chassis Actuation Perturbations and Unknown Disturbances
authors: Yanjun Ren, Fanxun Wang, Tong Shen, Mingzhuo Zhao, Qixiang Zhang, Guodong Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Most spacing and speed control systems adopt a two-level architecture. However, robustness is typically ensured at only one level, leaving the closed loop susceptible to actuation uncertainties and external disturbances. This article proposes a hierarchical robust control scheme to address this gap. At the lower level, actuator dynamics are experimentally identified and characterized via frequency-dependent uncertainty weighting functions. A mixed-μ-synthesis-based controller with a two-degree-of-freedom (2-DOF) structure is designed for robust acceleration tracking, improving the robust performance margin by 7% and 40% over classic μ and H∞ synthesis, respectively. At the upper level, a spacing-error integral and an actuation time delay are incorporated into the car-following model. A time-delay-dependent guaranteed-cost robust optimal control is then developed to reject preceding-vehicle disturbances. Simulations show that the proposed method reduces maximum deceleration and jerk variations by 50.4% and 93.4%, respectively, compared with the nominal optimal controller. It also alleviates the safety–comfort tradeoff caused by high-gain disturbance rejection. Real-vehicle experiments validate the approach’s effectiveness and robustness under practical uncertainties.
