title: A Novel DS-GIN-DANN Approach: Limited-Sample Cross-Domain Recognition of Partial Discharge from Generator Stator Bars to PP Cables
authors: Shiyuan Jia, Yuncong Cao, Xiaosheng Peng, Cong Li, Ji Wu, Xin Yu, Yinge Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: With the increasing deployment of polypropylene (PP) cables in power systems, early identification of partial discharge (PD) defects is critical for ensuring equipment reliability. However, as PP cables remain in the trial stage, defect samples from industrial sites are limited, making traditional recognition methods ineffective under limited-sample conditions. A limited-sample cross-domain recognition method for PD defects in PP cables is proposed in this paper, with the transfer recognition task from generator stator bar PD to PP cable PD being addressed. In the proposed framework, PD signals from generator stator bars and PP cables are collected as source- and target-domain data under typical defect scenarios. Phase-resolved PD (PRPD) patterns are constructed, and a deep synthetic minority oversampling technique (DeepSMOTE, DS) enhancement technique is applied to balance feature distribution among defect types in the target domain. A transfer framework combining graph isomorphism networks (GIN) and domain-adversarial neural networks (DANN) is then employed to improve graph feature representation and cross-domain adaptability. Experimental results show that the DS-GIN-DANN method achieves 90.25% accuracy at 64×64 resolution under limited-sample conditions, outperforming CNN-based transfer methods by 8.75%, effectively mitigating the problem of limited samples. Therefore, a new technical pathway for limited-sample recognition of PD defects in cable equipment is provided, with significant practical application value.

title: Integrated Optical Wireless Communication and Sensing for Multiple Mobile Users
authors: Yuechao Li, Liang Wu, Zaichen Zhang
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Integrated optical wireless communication and sensing (IOCAS) has been investigated in many recent works for single mobile user (MU) or static scenario. For the mobile scenario, the conventional center-aligned beam method sacrifices half of the communication time. This letter presents an unmanned-aerial-vehicles-assisted IOCAS scheme, which adopts a new beam alignment method to increase communication time for multiple MUs. We derive the sum ergodic achievable rate (SEAR), and formulate the optimization problem to maximize the SEAR by jointly optimizing the power allocation and beam waists of the communication and sensing, while considering the impact of distinct velocities and sensing errors across multiple MUs. Simulation results demonstrate that the SEAR of the proposed scheme is higher than that of conventional schemes, and approaches ideal free-space optical communication.

title: Investigating Role of With a Hybrid Device Discovery Strategy in Enhancement of Security and Efficiency in D2D Communication
authors: Rachna, Rakesh Kumar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Contemporary wireless networks rely on data transmission between devices, referred to as Device to device communication. Their primary concerns are enhancing network capacity, reducing latency, and optimizing spectrum use. The paper introduces an innovative hybrid approach in the field of Device to Device communication systems by combining Particle Swarm Optimisation with Multiverse Optimisation. This notion aims to find useful techniques devoid of danger. The hybrid method leverages the optimization capabilities of Particle Swarm Optimisation to get improved device matching accuracy. It concurrently circumvents local optima using Multiverse Optimisation exploration, hence enhancing device identification throughout the network. The hybrid paradigm seeks to address prevalent security issues like as eavesdropping, MITM attacks, and impersonation. This architecture facilitates continuous communication between devices, hence augmenting their capabilities. The proposed method is rational for future communication networks because to its advantages in resource allocation, expedited discovery time, and minimal energy usage. The hybrid model surpasses standard methods in terms of security resilience, processing efficiency, and discovery success rate. This outcome was achieved via simulations and performance evaluations. Device to Device applications need this architecture as it provides an optimal equilibrium between security and communication velocity.

title: Fine-Tuning DeepSeek for Efficient and Accurate Natural Language Querying on CSV Data
authors: Abhinav B K, Aron Thomas, Adhil Salim, Elzabeth Bobus, Elizabeth Jullu, Neenu R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: General-purpose large language models (LLMs) often struggle to interpret structured data such as CSV files, limiting their effectiveness in real-world data analysis tasks. This work presents an approach to fine-tuning the DeepSeek R1 Distill LLaMA 8B model for domain-specific structured data querying. Our contributions include a LoRA-based 4-bit quantized fine-tuning pipeline on the Stanford/WikiTableQuestions dataset, integration with TalkDB (a voice-enabled CSV analytics platform), and comprehensive evaluation using Weights & Biases (W &B) tracking. Experimental results demonstrate a 21% improvement in inference speed, stable gradient updates, and a final training loss reduction to 0.95. This work provides new insights into adapting LLMs for structured reasoning and presents TalkDB as a deployable solution for natural language data querying.

title: Graph Theory-Based Topology Derivation for Multifunctional DC Choppers of a DFIG
authors: Chenguang Yan, Zhangheng Liu, Weixiang Wang, Ying Liu, Hongxi Yang, Baohui Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery
abstract: As critical protection devices for achieving low voltage ride-through (LVRT) in a doubly-fed induction generator (DFIG), DC choppers are widely used because of their low costs and high reliability. The conventional DC choppers are limited to DC-link voltage regulation and cannot provide rotor current control. This inherent limitation has spurred growing research interest in multifunctional DC choppers (MDCCs). However, the absence of a systematic approach for deriving the topologies of MDCCs has significantly constrained their practical applications, resulting in only a limited number of proposed configurations. To address this challenge, in this study, a systematic topology derivation methodology for MDCCs is proposed. The hierarchical three-stage topology derivation method sequentially generates unweighted, weighted, and directed-weighted graphs. Moreover, the specific characteristics of an MDCC are modeled via formally established topology filtering criteria, which ensures the completeness of the generation process. The proposed code implemented method significantly improves the efficiency of MDCC design while maintaining high configuration accuracy. A hardware-in-the-loop experimental validation conducted on a real-time digital simulator (RTDS) confirms that the optimized topology (with only two insulated-gate bipolar transistors (IGBTs), two diodes and one resistor) achieves satisfactory performance during LVRT transients.

title: Renal Cyst Segmentation Using U-Net with ResNet-50 Backbone and Explainable AI Integration
authors: J. Mary Hanna Priyadharshini, Rithika K, Hemalatha. M, Janani D, Aglin Beni G, Vasmathi Natchi S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Segmentation of renal cysts is critical for the early diagnosis and detection of kidney diseases. The current paper introduces a state-of-the-art model that carries out segmentation with a U-Net model over a pretrained ResNet-50 backbone, which is combined with Explainable AI (XAI) methods. Preprocessing operations like grayscale conversion, Gaussian blurring, and Otsu's binarization are included as part of the utilized methodology. In addition, an XAI method, such as Grad-CAM, is utilized for explaining and interpreting the model's predictions. The introduced approach allows for the effective detection and segmentation of cysts without the need for manually annotated binary masks, thus emerging as an effective detection and segmentation of cysts without an effective medical imaging tool that promotes confidence in AI-based diagnosis. This amalgamation of Explainable AI(XAI) technique with the deep learning algorithm provides increased segmentation accuracy and a transparent view for the clinicians on how the model is into a decision making process. Further, the future work is planned on expanding this framework on other renal abnormalities and incorporation of multi-modal imaging for improved diagnostic precision.

title: A Hybrid Rule-Driven and Unsupervised Learning Framework for High-Accuracy Malayalam Stemming
authors: Sheeja Sudheer, J. Ramya, S Swetha
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Stemming is a very important part of Natural Language Processing (NLP) operations like information retrieval, text classification, and machine translation because it minimizes the lexical variants to a shared root. The agglutinative and complex morphological Malayalam language has large patterns of suffixation that complicate the use of traditional stemmers. The paper presents a better hybrid stemming architecture that combines a suffix-stripping engine that is linguistically based with an unsupervised K-Means clustering module. The morphological component is first carried out through the rule-based component in which handcrafted suffix heuristics are used based on the Malayalam inflectional and derivational patterns. The clustered refinement phase then clusters stem candidates according to similarity of vectors, and allows word perfecting over-stemming and understemming mistakes to be automatically corrected. Benchmark Malayalam corpus experimental evaluation shows much higher accuracy, precision, and recall than current rule-based and statistical stemmers. These findings confirm the efficacy of the integration of linguistics with machine learning tools in order to achieve strong morphological normalization in low resource Indian languages. The suggested structure offers a scalable platform on behalf of sophisticated Malayalam NLP-based systems such as semantic retrieval and text analytics at scale.

title: Comparative Study of Deep Learning Models for Pneumonia Detection with Gaussian Blur and Multi-Source Data Evaluation
authors: Kasandika Andariefli, Vincentius Dewanto, Jervino Leonard Handaya, Karli Eka Setiawan
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Pneumonia remains a leading cause of mortality across all age groups, particularly in low-resource settings where early and accurate diagnosis is critical. Chest X-ray imaging is the most accessible diagnostic tool but is often affected by motion blur or equipment limitations. This study evaluates the performance of eleven deep learning models for binary pneumonia classification under two training conditions: with and without Gaussian blur. The models span CNN-based architectures, hybrid convolution-attention networks, and transformer models. To increase training volume and assess generalization, data from two public datasets were merged. Each model was evaluated on a consistent unblurred test set using macro-averaged accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. EfficientNet, ConvNeXt, CoAtNet, and MobileNet achieved the best class-wise F1 performance under blurred training, each with class gap scores below 0.04. In contrast, the CNN with LSTM and ANN exhibited severe class imbalance, with the former failing to detect pneumonia cases. Models trained on unblurred data consistently outperformed blurred-trained models on the clean test set, while blurred-trained models demonstrated greater resilience to image quality degradation. These findings highlight the importance of both model architecture and training strategy in designing robust classification systems, offering valuable insights for the development of reliable diagnostic tools suitable for deployment in diverse clinical environments.

title: Kinematic Analysis and Calibration Experiment of a 2UPU-SP+RR Hybrid Robot
authors: Xiaoyu He, Xuejian Ma, Yu Wang, Yundou Xu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Hybrid robots integrate the advantages of both serial and parallel mechanism, demonstrating significant potential for complex surface machining of aluminum alloys. This study focuses on the kinematic analysis and error calibration of the 2UPU-SP+RR hybrid robot. The inverse kinematic analytical solution is first derived to establish the coordinate mapping between the end-effector and joint inputs. A novel forward kinematic analytical solution with joint angles as the inputs is subsequently proposed, based on which a real-time pose detection system for the hybrid robot’s end-effector is developed. Furthermore, an elasto-static stiffness model of the 2UPU-SP parallel mechanism is established using the weighted generalized inverse method to map the relationship between external loads and terminal deformations. Error modeling is implemented through two distinct approaches: zero-point calibration and comprehensive error calibration. Laser tracker-based measurements provide geometric error parameters for both methods, which are then compensated in the robot’s kinematic algorithm. Experimental findings confirm that the two calibration approaches significantly improve the positioning precision of the end-effector. After zero-point calibration and comprehensive error calibration, the end-effector positioning accuracy of the robot is improved by 38.40% and 56.71% respectively, confirming the effectiveness of the proposed calibration methods.

title: Surrogate-Driven Structural Optimization of a Vacuum-Compatible Robotic End-Effector Using ANSYS and a Python Digital Twin Framework
authors: Ponnapudi Durga Prasad
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Designing robotic end-effectors often begins with a simple question: how will the structure behave when its material, geometry, and loading conditions change? In practice, answering this question demands numerous finite-element simulations, each consuming significant computation time. To address this challenge, this work develops a surrogate-driven digital twin capable of predicting key structural responses maximum Total deformation and Equivalent stress without repeatedly running full ANSYS simulations. A parametric dataset is first created using three materials, three load levels, and fingertip and finger geometric parameters (length, breadth, and thickness). This dataset trains a Python-based surrogate model that rapidly estimates the structural performance of the end-effector across its design space. The model is validated through randomly selected cases re-simulated in ANSYS, showing strong agreement within engineering accuracy limits. Finally, an optimization stage identifies feasible material, geometry and load combinations that minimize deformation while meeting yield constraints. The overall framework demonstrates a fast and reliable pathway for structural decision-making, with strong applicability to vacuumcompatible grippers used in semiconductor automation and other precision robotic environments.

title: Identity Reflections: Hyperspectral Skin Analysis via Reflectance Distance Learning with Context-Aware Contrastive Transformers
authors: Emanuela Marasco, Bhargavi Janga, Gautham Gali, Raghavendra Ramachandra
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biometrics, Behavior, and Identity Science
abstract: Hyperspectral Imaging (HSI) enables real-time analysis with rich spectral detail, offering a promising path to spoof-resistant AI-based identity verification. Leveraging this spectral information, we present a novel biometric approach that extracts and analyzes skin reflectance patterns from hyperspectral fingertip images. In prior work, hyperspectral analysis has primarily been applied to facial biometrics; however, the associated lighting requirements are often impractical or inconvenient for users in real-world scenarios. From a computational perspective, while deep learning has significantly advanced recognition using conventional imaging, effectively applying these frameworks to the rich and complex signals captured by HSI remains a critical open challenge. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) often have difficulty preserving the sequential structure of spectral information. Vision transformers effectively capture global context through self-attention but often face challenges in modeling fine-grained local features due to the lack of convolutional inductive biases. To address existing limitations, this work introduces a novel integration of Context-Enriched Contrastive Loss (CECL) into two architectures: SpectralFormer, a ViT-based model that employs decoupled spatial–spectral processing to handle spectral signatures extracted from carefully selected spatial regions; and the Swin Transformer, which leverages a unified 3D joint representation. For the first time, SpectralFormer is employed for identity verification, leveraging group-wise spectral embeddings, inspired by ViT’s patch-based processing, across adjacent bands, along with intermediate skip connections to enhance the analysis of complex spectral data. The proposed approach was evaluated on three biometric databases, including the Mason FHSD-2022 hyperspectral fingertip dataset collected at George Mason University with 100 subjects. The code will be publicly available on GitHub.

title: Volumetric ultrasound imaging with a sparse matrix array and integrated fiber-optic sensing for robust needle tracking in interventional procedures
authors: Weidong Liang, Javad Rostami, Christian Baker, Simeon West, Athanasios Diamantopoulos, Sunish Mathews, Adrien E. Desjardins, Sebastien Ourselin, Laura Peralta, Wenfeng Xia
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Objective: Accurate visualization of interventional devices, such as medical needles, in relation to the procedural target is critical for the safe and effective guidance of interventional procedures. Ultrasound (US) imaging is widely used for guiding percutaneous needle interventions, but the 2D nature of most clinical US probes limits accurate 3D localization, particularly of the needle tip. In this work, we introduce a novel system that combines both volumetric US imaging and 3D needle tracking. Method: The proposed novel system integrates a fiber-optic hydrophone (FOH) into the needle and employs a 2D sparse spiral US array with 256 active elements. Real-time volumetric US imaging was achieved by plane-wave imaging with the sparse array, while 3D needle tip tracking was enabled through communications between the US probe and the FOH. Results: The system achieved spatial resolutions (mean ± standard deviation) of 2.06 ± 0.29mm (lateral), 2.26 ± 0.23mm (elevational), and 0.69 ± 0.12mm (axial) at depths ranging from 10 to 40mm. The tracking accuracy was better than 0.30 ± 0.21mm. The clinical potential of the system was demonstrated using a nerve block training phantom. Conclusions: This study presents a proof-of-concept for an integrated solution that enables simultaneous volumetric anatomical imaging and precise 3D needle tip tracking. Significance: The proposed system holds strong potential to enhance the efficacy and safety of image-guided interventional procedures by providing real-time 3D anatomical visualization and accurate needle tracking.

title: A Novel and Systematic Approach for the Performance Analysis of Medical Image Compression Algorithms
authors: Abida Begum S, Saranya Nair M
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Today’s modern health care system significantly relies on medical imaging for diagnostics, therapy protocol, planning and treatment. The rapid analysis, dissemination and storage of the substantial data generated by advanced imaging modalities such as CT and MRI presents great challenges. Consequently effective image compression methods are essential for minimizing the storage space and increasing the transmission speed without compromising the quality needed for an accurate diagnosis. In this work, we have explored and evaluated different methods for compressing medical images, starting with classical lossless algorithms and extending to modern deep learning frameworks. In addition to hybrid frameworks that combine Huffman coding with DWT, new deep learning architectures such as AutoEncoders (AE), Convolutional AutoEncoders (CAE), Variational AutoEncoders (VAE), and CNN-driven Predictive Encoders are analyzed and the evaluation is carried out using their performance metrics such as their Compression Ratio (CR), Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Mean Square Error (MSE), Bits Per Pixel (BPP), Compression Time (CT), and Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) are measured and compared. This study evaluates the performance metrics of various image compression methods and summarizes the methods and strategies incorporated in the traditional and deep learning approaches.

title: Diagnosis of Malaria from Red Blood Cell Images Using Deep Learning Techniques
authors: L.V ArunShalin, Karra Pradeep Reddy, Vangala Lokesh Reddy
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: One of the significant contributors to human diseases is malaria and the early diagnosis is a key factor for the success of the treatment. Manual microscopic examination of blood smears is a reliable method but it is also very laborintensive and needs a lot of expert knowledge. In this paper, an automatic deep learning-based framework is put forward for the detection of malaria-infected red blood cells employing three different architectures: custom CNN, AlexNet, and DenseNet. For the sake of fairness and reliability, a uniform preprocessing pipeline and a cross-validated evaluation process are adopted for the comparison. Moreover, an enhanced dataset is created by having the ambiguous and low-quality samples removed, which makes it possible to analyze the performance under both original and refined conditions. The experimental results indicate that among the architectures, DenseNet obtains the highest accuracy (97.79 on the refined dataset). The framework proposed illustrates a very strong possibility for the use in real-time malaria screening and gives reproducible insights for the future studies in AI-based healthcare diagnosis research.

title: Wideband MLFACA-CBFM for Electromagnetic Scattering Problems
authors: Fan Gao, Xinlei Chen, Zhiwen Dong, Changqing Gu, Zhuo Li, Wu Yang, Weibing Lu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: We present an efficient wideband multilevel fast adaptive cross approximation-characteristic basis function method (Wideband MLFACA-CBFM) for wideband electromagnetic scattering problems. In this method, the multilevel fast adaptive cross approximation (MLFACA) of the impedance matrices and the generation of the CBFs are performed only once at the highest frequency within the given band. The resulting decomposition and compression information is reused across the entire band, eliminating the need to repeatedly perform the time-consuming MLFACA decomposition and CBF generation at each analyzed frequency. Moreover, impedance interpolation is employed to efficiently construct the approximate decomposed impedance matrices at analyzed frequencies. As a result, the proposed method effectively reduces the time required to compute the wideband radar cross section (RCS).

title: A Game-Theoretic Framework for Adaptive Calibration of Blind Quantum Computing with Metaheuristics and Quantum GAN Feedback
authors: Hubert Kołcz
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: Quantum networks require continuous parameter calibration to maintain optimal performance as hardware drifts and environmental conditions change. This paper presents a game-theoretic framework for adaptive calibration of universal blind quantum computing networks, treating calibration as a strategic three-player game between classical optical sources, quantum servers, and machine learning agents. The approach integrates stabilized Kerr frequency combs with quantum generative adversarial networks (qGANs) to achieve Nash equilibrium solutions that balance security and performance. Comprehensive experimental validation across multiple quantum hardware platforms demonstrates the framework's effectiveness, with detailed performance metrics presented in Section II. The framework addresses critical scalability challenges while providing formal cryptographic security guarantees through min-entropy analysis of quantum random number generators.

title: Understanding the Issue Types in Open Source Blockchain-Based Software Projects with the Transformer-Based BERTopic
authors: Md Nahidul Islam Opu, Shahidul Islam, Sara Rouhani, Shaiful Chowdhury
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Blockchain-based software systems are increasingly deployed across diverse domains, yet a systematic understanding of their development challenges remains limited. This paper presents a large-scale empirical study of 497,742 issues mined from 1,209 open-source blockchain projects hosted on GitHub. Employing BERTopic, a transformer-based topic modeling technique, we identify 49 distinct issue topics and organize them hierarchically into 11 major subcategories. Our analysis reveals that both general software development issues and blockchainspecific concerns are nearly equally represented, with Wallet Management and UI Enhancement emerging as the most prominent topics. We further examine the temporal evolution of issue categories and resolution times, finding that Wallet issues not only dominate in frequency but also exhibit the longest resolution time. Conversely, Mechanisms issues are resolved significantly faster. Issue frequency surged after 2016 with the rise of Ethereum and decentralized applications, but started declining after 2022. These findings enhance our understanding of blockchain software maintenance, informing the development of specialized tools and practices to improve robustness and maintainability.

title: A Bi/Tri-Layer Propagation Model for UG2AG Communication in Wireless Underground Sensor Networks
authors: Ge Gao, Linjing Zhang, Wenhao Luo, Wuzhou Zhai, Zirong Zhang, Nicole Metje, Tong Hao
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Wireless Underground Sensor Networks (WUSNs) have emerged as a key enabling technology for applications such as precision agriculture, underground infrastructure monitoring, and environmental sensing. However, electromagnetic (EM) wave propagation in the underground-to-aboveground (UG2AG) link is strongly influenced by multilayered, lossy, and heterogeneous media, which poses significant challenges for accurate signal modeling. In this paper, a novel bi/tri-layer UG2AG channel model is proposed that explicitly incorporates EM spherical wavefront deformation and antenna reflection losses. The model is analytically derived for an arbitrary number of layers and validated through comprehensive laboratory experiments using a LoRa-based WUSNs system. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model significantly reduces the prediction error of 81% and 89%, compared to the traditional ray tracing-based models under the bi-layer and tri-layer condition, respectively. The model also provides a detailed decomposition of signal attenuation, revealing the relative contributions of diffusion, absorption, and reflection losses in bi/tri-layer conditions. These findings offer new insights into UG2AG communication mechanisms and provide a new perspective for advancing future research on underground wireless channels and the design and optimization of WUSNs.

title: Evolutionary-Based Circuit Optimization for Distributed Quantum Computing
authors: Leo Sünkel, Jonas Stein, Gerhard Stenzel, Michael Kölle, Thomas Gabor, Claudia Linnhoff-Popien
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: In this work, we evaluate an evolutionary algorithm (EA) to optimize a given circuit in such a way that it reduces the required communication when executed in the Distributed Quantum Computing (DQC) paradigm. We evaluate our approach for a state preparation task using Grover circuits and show that it is able to reduce the required global gates by more than 89 % while still achieving high fidelity as well as the ability to extract the correct solution to the given problem. We also apply the approach to reduce circuit depth and number of CX gates. Additionally, we run experiments in which a circuit is optimized for a given network topology after each qubit has been assigned to specific nodes in the network. In these experiments, the algorithm is able to reduce the communication cost (i.e., number of hops between QPUs) by up to 19 %.

title: Swin-SemantIC: A Transformer-Driven Enhancement Scheme for Semantic Interference Cancellation
authors: Yizheng Huang, Wensheng Lin, Lixin Li, Zhu Han
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: This paper proposes an enhanced semantic interference cancellation (SemantIC) technique, Swin-SemantIC, which improves the efficiency of cross-domain noise mitigation and anti-interference performance by optimizing the semantic auto-encoder in the original SemantIC system. Grounded in the Wyner-Ziv theorem, the original SemantIC system constructs a Turbo loop by cascading a channel decoder and a CNN-based semantic auto-encoder, enabling alternating denoising in the signal and semantic domains to enhance received signal quality. However, the inherent limitation of CNNs in local feature extraction constrains their capability to capture global semantic content of information, thereby degrading the quality of side information. To address this, Swin-SemantIC employs a Swin Transformer-based semantic auto-encoder to strengthen global dependency capture, enabling more efficient and reliable side information transmission within the Turbo loop. Simulation results demonstrate that Swin-SemantIC achieves further performance gains, with particularly significant advantages under low signal-to-noise ratio conditions, meanwhile incurring no additional channel resource consumption.

title: Enhancement of Machine Learning-Based Automated Soft Tissue Tumor Diagnosis
authors: S.M.E. Vadivel, R Bhuvaneshwari, E Gobubalaaji
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: This study points to using a machine learning approach - specifically ResNet50, built on CNNs - to spot and sort soft tissue tumors more accurately, especially skinrelated cancers. STTs present diagnostic challenges due to their heterogeneity, which can lead to misdiagnosis, highlighting the need for automated and precise diagnostic methods. The method incorporates advanced data preprocessing and feature extraction techniques to improve classification performance and reduce errors. Multi parametric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data is used to evaluate the model, emphasizing precise tumor delineation, which is crucial for radiation therapy planning. The primary objective is to achieve high accuracy in distinguishing Melanoma from normal skin tissue, thereby enhancing diagnostic precision, treatment planning, and patient outcomes.

title: Performance Analysis of Deep Learning Models for 3D Point Cloud Classification: A Comparative Study on the TogogBali3d Dataset
authors: Ida Bagus Ary Indra Iswara, Anny Yuniarti, Shintami Chusnul Hidayati, Fajar Baskoro, Lynn Htet Aung
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: The classification of 3D objects from point cloud data is a fundamental task in computer vision, with significant advancements driven by deep learning models, such as PointNet and dynamic graph CNN (DGCNN). Although these models have shown high performance on standard benchmark datasets, such as ModelNet10and ScanObjectNN, their efficacy on culturally specific specialized datasets remains largely unexplored. This paper presents an experimental study to evaluate and compare the classification performance of PointNet and DGCNN using a novel dataset, TogogBali3d, which comprises eight classes of traditional Balinese statues (Togog). We benchmarked the performance of these models on the TogogBali3d dataset and compared the results with their established performance on ModelNet10 and ScanObjectNN. This study aims to assess the generalization capabilities of state-of-the-art 3D classification models and highlight the challenges associated with classifying objects with intricate and unique geometric features. The DGCNN model achieved an Overall Accuracy (OA) of 61.25%, narrowly outperforming PointNet's 60.83% OA. The performance drop compared to generic benchmarks confirms the challenge posed by the fine-grained geometry of the dataset. A detailed analysis shows that while PointNet's global features are highly effective for specific macro-level classes (such as Punakawan and Pengapit), DGCNN's local feature aggregation provides marginally better overall consistency, particularly in achieving superior recall for classes defined by localized detail (such as Penabuh and Dewi).

title: Design and Implementation of Motion Posture Test and Evaluation Software for Firefighting Exoskeleton Assisted Robots
authors: Wei Zheng, Shichao Kuai
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: In fire rescue operations, carrying heavy loads and traversing rough terrains to reach the rescue site is not only a significant test of the physical fitness of firefighters but also crucial to the efficiency and outcome of rescue missions. This paper aims to design a software for testing and evaluating the movement posture of fire rescue exoskeleton robots. The design process starts from the analysis of software functional requirements and performance requirements, and proceeds with software functional design, architecture design, interface design, and data transmission process design. The goal is to explore a scientific, efficient, and reliable software design method for fire rescue exoskeleton robots' movement posture testing and evaluation, thereby promoting the comprehensive development of the performance of fire rescue exoskeleton robot equipment.

title: Harnessing AI and IoT for Smart Water Infrastructure: A Scalable Framework for Industry 4.0 Adoption in Malaysia
authors: Siti Daleela Mohd Wahid, Wan Mohd Hirwani Wan Hussain, Mohamad Rohieszan Ramdan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: In response to Malaysia's uneven progress in Digital Water Transformation (DWT), this conceptual paper proposes a scalable, AI-IoT-integrated framework aimed at modernizing the nation's water infrastructure. While states like Selangor have made strides in deploying smart meters, AI-based analytics, and real-time IoT monitoring, many regions still grapple with high Non-Revenue Water (NRW), outdated systems, and fragmented governance. Anchored in Systems Theory, Institutional Theory, and Change Management Theory, this study synthesizes global case studies, national policy mandates (AIR2040), and Selangor's empirical success to develop a six-pillar framework encompassing technological infrastructure, institutional alignment, workforce development, financial innovation, data governance, and cultural transformation. It offers explicit technical models, including neural networks, edge computing, and SCADA-integrated IoT, to support predictive maintenance and demand forecasting. By addressing both controllable and structural barriers to adoption, the framework provides actionable pathways for policymakers and industry leaders to accelerate DWT in alignment with SDG 6 and SDG 13. This paper contributes to bridging Malaysia's digital divide in the water sector by outlining a roadmap for building a smart, sustainable, and resilient water future.

title: Democratizing AI Linguistic Technologies for Understanding Diverse Social Voices
authors: Isayeva Dildora, Otaxon Khayitboyev Shokirovich, Gulora Yuldasheva, Abhinav Singhal, Rano Alimardanova, Lazizbek Abdirahmonov
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Current AI linguistic technologies predominantly reflect the perspectives and linguistic patterns of dominant social groups, creating barriers for equitable representation of diverse communities and marginalized voices in digital spaces. This study aims to develop and evaluate a framework for democratizing AI linguistic technologies to better understand and represent diverse social voices across different demographic, cultural, and linguistic backgrounds. We employed a mixed-methods approach combining large-scale corpus analysis of underrepresented dialects and sociolects, community-participatory design sessions with marginalized groups, and the development of inclusive natural language processing models using transfer learning and domain adaptation techniques. Our methodology included collecting linguistic data from 15 diverse communities, implementing bias detection algorithms, and creating culturally-aware language models through collaborative annotation processes involving community members. The results demonstrate that our democratized AI framework achieved 23% higher accuracy in understanding diverse linguistic patterns compared to conventional models, with significant improvements in sentiment analysis (18% increase in F1-score) and intent recognition (31% reduction in misclassification) for underrepresented groups. The democratized approach also showed enhanced cultural sensitivity scores and reduced algorithmic bias across all tested demographic categories. This research contributes to the growing field of inclusive AI by providing a replicable framework for developing linguistic technologies that authentically represent diverse social voices, with implications for improving digital equity, enhancing cross-cultural communication, and ensuring fair representation in AI-driven social platforms and decisionmaking systems.

title: Performance Analysis of Cooperative Content Sharing in LTE-MEC Networks for Video Streaming Applications
authors: K Sachin Hebbar, Vijayalakshmi M
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Cooperative content sharing is becoming increasingly significant in modern cellular networks to meet the growing demand for high-speed, low-latency applications like video streaming and online gaming. While isolated base station operations and static resource allocation are problems for typical LTE networks, Multi-Access Edge Computing (MEC) provides a framework for localized and dynamic decision-making. This study reduces dependency on central servers by implementing a cooperative content-sharing approach in which User Equipments (UEs) work together to efficiently distribute cached content. Using the NS-3 simulator, the system is evaluated under both cooperative and non-cooperative setups for a network of 28 UEs. The results demonstrate that the cooperative approach achieves a consistent throughput of 0.07 Mbps across all UEs and significantly reduces delays compared to the non-cooperative setup, where only the first 4 UEs achieve marginal throughput, and others experience stalling. These findings highlight the potential of cooperative content sharing to enhance resource utilization and Quality of Service (quality of service) in high-traffic LTE-MEC environments.

title: Machine Learning-Based Modeling of Reservoir Inflows from Precipitation Data
authors: Andrés Pico, Mauro A. Gonzalez-Sierra, Juan C. Martinez-Santos
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Accurate inflow forecasting is vital for hydroelectric power generation and water resource management. This study utilizes machine learning models to predict inflows into Urrá I, a Colombian reservoir, leveraging historical weather data, including precipitation, temperature, wind speed, and humidity. Algorithms, including decision trees, gradient boosting, and Knearest neighbors, are evaluated using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> and mean squared error. Results show that ML models can reliably predict inflows, which supports more efficient and sustainable hydroelectric operation.

title: Enhancing DBSCAN via KD-Tree and Ball-Tree Structures in a Performance-Driven Way
authors: Bhupender Singh Rawat, Anushree Singh, Himanshu Sharma, Renu Bahuguna, Pooja Verma
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: The widely used clustering method known as Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) combines densely packed data points and recognises sparse areas as outliers. DBSCAN's adaptability stems from its ability to identify clusters of varying shapes without needing a pre-defined number of clusters. This makes it applicable across diverse fields. However, challenges like high-dimensional data processing, parameter sensitivity, and scalability with massive datasets can limit its effectiveness. This research focuses on enhancing the efficiency of DBSCAN by optimizing nearest neighbor search techniques, specifically Ball-tree, KD-tree, and Approximate Nearest Neighbors (ANN). These optimizations aim to reduce computational complexity, improve clustering performance, and increase DBSCAN's applicability to large-scale, highdimensional datasets. We also analyze the impact of these improvements in domains such as geospatial analysis, anomaly detection, and bioinformatics. Ultimately, this study provides insights into overcoming DBSCAN's limitations and maximizing its practical utility.

title: Research on Path Prediction and Classification Based on Optimization Algorithms and Machine Learning
authors: Yihang Xie, Chen Dai, Tianyi He
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Driven by information technology, path prediction, and its underlying pattern classification have garnered significant attention due to their importance in optimizing resources and enhancing efficiency. However, traditional methods struggle to address the complex dynamic characteristics of high-dimensional nonlinear data and fail to meet the demands for accuracy and flexibility. In response, this study integrates optimization algorithms with machine learning, employing a random forest model optimized by hyperparameters based on the ant colony algorithm for path data classification, and a LightGBM model optimized by hyperparameters based on the Harris Eagle algorithm for regression. The classification accuracy reached 0.9738, while the regression goodness of fit was 0.852 and 0.807, respectively. This paper utilizes a dynamic time-warping algorithm for path comparison, demonstrating that machine learning based on optimization algorithms employed in this study can effectively identify patterns in path data and predict future paths, offering valuable insights for related fields of path prediction.

title: Supply Chain Risk Prediction and Evaluation Model Based on BP Neural Network
authors: Yang Han
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper mainly applies BP neural network in the supply chain risk management to build a risk prediction and evaluation model, selects supply chain enterprises to obtain sample data, imports it into the model, and conducts simulation training to predict and evaluate the risk level of supply chain management. Matlab is used to train and verify the model, the accuracy and efficiency are significantly improved. The research of this paper not only provides powerful technical support for enterprises to timely insight into supply chain risks and formulate targeted prevention and control strategies, but also opens up a new path for the intelligent development of supply chain risk management.

title: Observation of Higher Upset Rates in Multi-Bit Flip-Flops Utilized in Low Power Designs
authors: Junkyu Kim, Robert Bloom, Yong Hyeon Yi, Chulseung Lim, Iloh Jang, Jungho Jin, Yuchul Hwang, Kichul Chun, Chris H. Kim
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: Multi-bit flip-flops (MBFFs) are widely adopted in low-power digital designs due to their ability to reduce area and clock switching power by sharing clock buffers across multiple individual flip-flops. However, this clock resource sharing introduces new bit-upsets vulnerabilities in the form of single-event transients (SETs) within the shared clock buffer, distinct from standard storage-node single-event upset (SEU). This work presents neutron-induced soft error characterization results for MBFFs implemented with both standard and radiation-hardened dual interlocked storage cell (DICE) latches in a 0.9V, 28nm CMOS technology. Neutron irradiation experiment was conducted at the ChipIR facility in the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, UK. A total of 84 test chips containing over 800,000 flip-flops were tested under multiple voltage conditions and data patterns. Upset mechanisms were classified into storage-node upsets, local clock buffer SETs, and global scan clock SETs. The results confirm that MBFFs, despite the use of DICE for hardened storage, exhibit significantly increased susceptibility to SETs in shared clock buffers. This study highlights an important trade-off between power efficiency and radiation resilience in multi-bit flip-flop designs, calling attention to the need for targeted mitigation strategies to ensure robust system operation in radiation prone environments.

title: Strategies for Workforce Motivation in Airline Operations: A Human-Centered Perpective
authors: Alberto Alonzo Christopher, Sofía Aizpú, Katleen Jurado
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: In the aviation industry, human capital is a critical asset that directly impacts operational efficiency, service quality, and safety. This study investigates the key factors influencing employee motivation within Copa Airlines, focusing on operations at Tocumen International Airport, Panama. Through a mixedmethods approach combining surveys, semi-structured interviews, and internal documentation review, the research identifies major demotivators such as work overload, limited autonomy, personalized feedback, and insufficient recognition mechanisms. Leveraging insights from organizational behavior and human resource management theories, the study proposes data-driven and technology-supported strategies to foster a positive work environment. These include digital platforms for continuous performance monitoring (e.g., SAP SuccessFactors), well-being apps (e.g., Virgin Pulse), and recognition systems (e.g., Kazoo). The results underscore the relevance of integrating analytics and employee-centered digital tools to optimize motivation, reduce turnover, and sustain high service standards. The implications are valuable for engineering managers and organizations seeking to align talent development with operational excellence in high-pressure environments.

title: Air Purification Robotics Using Cloud and Deep Q Networks for Autonomous Systems
authors: Priyanka Kaushik, Pawan Kumar, S. Mathumohan, Bura Vijay Kumar, Divya Negi, Vinod Sharma
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Rising urban air pollution poses serious health dangers. Through robots, cloud computing, and deep reinforcement learning, this research proposes a new air purification method. The suggested autonomous system analyzes real-time air quality parameters and optimizes air purification tactics using cloud-based data processing. Advanced sensors and purification processes allow robotic agents to intelligently adapt to shifting pollution patterns in dynamic settings. Robots use Deep Q Networks (DQN) to learn and change their purifying tactics based on past data and environmental input. Cloud computing and deep learning improve air purification efficiency and enable real-time pollution response decision-making. The autonomous system is scalable and adaptable to varied urban environments since it requires little human involvement. The cloud-based design lets autonomous agents communicate and coordinate to improve air quality. Experimental findings show that the suggested strategy improves air purification over previous approaches. This system advances environmental robotics and lays the groundwork for intelligent, autonomous systems that handle urban air quality and pollution issues.

title: Climate Trends and Projections in the Ecuadorian Amazon
authors: Ana Salguero, Wilson Chango, Mónica Brito, Aurora Ariza
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive multivariable analysis of climatic, soil, and water quality data from the agricultural cantons of Loreto and Joya de los Sachas in Ecuador's Amazon region, covering the period 1998-2025. Using historical records and ARIMA modeling, key climatic variables-including temperature, atmospheric pressure, precipitation, relative humidity, solar radiation, and wind speed-were analyzed to identify trends and forecast near-future behavior. Results reveal a progressive increase in temperature and atmospheric pressure, particularly in Joya de los Sachas, accompanied by a decline in precipitation and relative humidity, indicating a trend toward warmer and drier conditions. Seasonal variability in climatic parameters is predicted to decrease, suggesting more stable but less resilient environmental conditions. Soil analyses confirm higher fertility in Joya de los Sachas, while Loreto exhibits a clayrich texture with nutrient limitations. Water quality assessments detected seasonal spikes in metals and microbial contamination, with irrigation sources in Joya de los Sachas exceeding permissible copper levels. The study highlights significant spatial and temporal climatic differences between the cantons, driven by factors such as altitude and microclimate, and underscores implications for sustainable agricultural planning, water resource management, and climate adaptation strategies. These findings offer critical insights for local stakeholders aiming to enhance resilience amid ongoing environmental changes in the Ecuadorian Amazon.

title: Research on the Design of an Intelligent Adaptive Learning System Based on Deep Learning
authors: Zhou Shen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: In the digital age, with the deep integration of IT and education, research on an intelligent adaptive learning system for preschool English based on deep knowledge tracing has drawn great attention. This paper centers on building its basic components to address low-efficiency and non-personalization in traditional preschool English teaching. Deep knowledge tracing, relying on RNNs and LSTMs, we need to precisely record and analyze preschoolers' multi-dimensional English-learning data (vocabulary, grammar, oral skills). Using these data, the system customizes learning paths, like auto-adjusting content push and offering targeted help. Experiments show a 40% rise in word-memorization accuracy, a 35% increase in grammar-understanding correctness, and a knowledge-absorption rate jump from 30% (traditional) to over 60%. The system has modules of intelligent assessment, learning content push, learning task design, and innovative learning mode. The assessment module uses RNNs or LSTMs for analysis; the content-push module selects from a graded resource library; the task-design module adjusts tasks based on personalization and gradation; the innovative-mode module uses VR/AR for immersive learning. This research fills the gap in creating an intelligent preschool-English education scenario by integrating AI, offers an innovative solution for its intelligent transformation, and is expected to draw expert cooperation to boost preschool English education.

title: Experimental Evaluation of the Impact of Body Obstruction on UWB Distance Estimation Accuracy: Comparative Analysis of Multiple Locations on the Human Body
authors: Danny Daniel Díaz López, Victor Quintero
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Ultra-Wideband (UWB) technology offers high accuracy in distance estimation, a crucial characteristic for localization and tracking systems. However, when people carry UWB devices, the accuracy of distance measurements can be compromised by signal absorption and blocking due to the human body, as well as by environmental propagation conditions. This work presents a comprehensive experimental evaluation of distance estimation accuracy, specifically analyzing the influence of device location on seven parts of the human body: head, hips, hands, wrists, chest, knees, and ankles, under different channel conditions: Line of Sight (LOS) and Non-Line of Sight (NLOS). The study employs DWM1001 UWB modules and the Two-Way Ranging (TWR) technique to obtain distance measurements in two representative scenarios: an outdoor environment (open space) and an indoor corridor. Key findings reveal that the chest location achieves the highest accuracy, with a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.0364 m under outdoor LOS conditions. In contrast, the knee location exhibits the worst performance, with errors up to 2.23 m under outdoor NLOS conditions. The study identifies a counterintuitive phenomenon where specific device locations, such as the hand and wrist, present superior performance under NLOS conditions compared to LOS in confined environments. The degradation factor ranges between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.5 \times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16.3 \times$</tex> when transitioning from LOS to NLOS conditions, with an overall MAE of 0.3944 m for all configurations. The results provide a detailed characterization of how device location on the body and channel conditions affect UWB distance estimation accuracy, offering guidelines for the design and deployment of applications that require precise distance measurements with wearable devices.

title: Employee Attrition for Strategic HR Decision-Making: An Analysis Through Multiple Machine Learning Models
authors: Neetu Chaudhary, Neha Sharma, Merry Saxena, Alok Kumar Agrawal, Deelip Kumar Sarangi, Pradeepta Kumar Sarangi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Employee attrition is referred to the gradual loss of members within a work place. Over time, various factors can lead to staff departures, which may be either voluntary or involuntary. For companies, employee attrition poses a significant risk and is a critical concern, as it affects not only operational efficiency but also the overall effectiveness of the organization. The employees are the most important asset of any organization, making it essential to identify potential employees who might leave. This is important due to the costs associated with training, the loyalty developed over time, and the sensitive nature of certain roles like social welfare. Organizations can leverage technology to assist in decision-making across various areas. For instance, machine learning techniques are increasingly relevant today, as they support personnel management, organizational challenges, and corporate strategy. This research aims to identify the key factors influencing staff employment and attrition. Four machine learning models (LDA, MLP, AdaBoost and Gradient Boosting) have been implemented in this work. The experimental results show that the AdaBoost and Gradient Boosting models perform better than the other two models with same accuracy of 90%.

title: Leveraging Large Language Models for Efficient Vulnerability Detection in IoT Firmware
authors: Jie Liu, Shan Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The integration of Internet of Things (IoT) technologies across various domains has significantly enhanced operational efficiency. However, it has also introduced serious cybersecurity threats. For instance, buffer overflow vulnerabilities can lead to device crashes, often arising from inadequate validation of data format and length in back-end processing of front-end transmitted data, which may subsequently be misused by unsafe functions. Static taint analysis is an effective approach for detecting such vulnerabilities, but existing methods often suffer from high computational overhead and excessive false positives due to the identification of too many irrelevant sources. To address these challenges, this paper proposes LLMIOT, a large language model-assisted vulnerability detection method that improves efficiency and reduces false positives through keyword filtering in embedded firmware. We leverage shared front-end and back-end keywords to identify relevant function call paths in the program's function call graph (CG). Large language models (LLMs) are then used to filter out irrelevant keywords before performing taint analysis to detect vulnerabilities. We evaluated LLMIOT on two datasets and compared it against state-of-the-art methods, SaTC and HermeScan. Experimental results show that LLMIOT efficiently eliminates more irrelevant keywords, reducing their count by 66% compared to SaTC and 83% compared to HermeScan. Furthermore, LLMIOT improves processing speed, achieving an average speed up of 1.9x over SaTC and 1.83x over HermeScan.

title: Impact of Brain Parcellation on MRI-derived Neurovascular Coupling Estimates Across Large-Scale Functional Networks
authors: Federica Franza, Mario Cirillo, Marcello Silvestro, Francesca Trojsi, Antonio Russo, Fabrizio Esposito, Maria Agnese Pirozzi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Brain parcellation enables the extraction of region-specific measurements from multimodal MRI data and represents a crucial step in neuroimaging analyses. Different atlases, derived using segmentation or clustering approaches, may play a crucial role in shaping analytical outcomes. Neurovascu-lar coupling (NVC)-the local spatial relationship between blood perfusion and neuronal activity-can be estimated by correlating functional connectivity with cerebral blood flow measures within predefined brain parcels. Although NVC alterations have been investigated in several neurological conditions, the impact of parcellation schemes on the resulting NVC estimates-both regionally and within large-scale functional net-works-has yet to be systematically assessed. The present study addresses this gap by comparing NVC estimates across Yeo's seven canonical large-scale brain networks using two widely adopted network-labelled parcellation schemes: the Schaefer atlas, originally derived from functional MRI data only, and the Brainnetome atlas, constructed from multimodal structural and functional connectivity data. Despite the overall good consistency in NVC estimates across all networks (Interclass Correlation Coefficient ≥ 0.702), significant differences (p < 0.05) were observed between the Schaefer and Brainnetome atlases in all networks, especially in dorsal and ventral attention networks. These findings highlight that parcellation choice can substantially impact NVC estimation, even when using atlases with high overall consistency, underscoring the need to carefully consider atlas properties when investigating more subtle neurovascular alterations across brain networks.

title: Deep PatchMatch and Pairwise Ranking Learning for Robust Copy-Move Forgery Detection
authors: Deepak Sharma, Pooja Pathak
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: The copy-move forgery is one of the most widespread image manipulations that is often used to tamper with images in a general sense, this kind of forgery involves duplicating a part of an image and placing it in a new area of the image. Such manipulation is difficult to detect because the copied area does not change the color tones, texture and illumination with the original area. Detecting high precision is a challenge of the traditional methods when post processing changes such as rotation, scaling, and compression are involved. In our current paper, We present a novel deep learning architecture using Pairwise Ranking Learning and Deep PatchMatch to identify and locate copy-move forgeries in the most resilient and accurate way. In order to create a model that has the ability to detect subtle differences between authentic and manipulated areas, we apply deep features to adaptive patch comparison and even include a ranking loss. Experiments on standard datasets demonstrate that our approach is superior to the current state of the art approaches with regard to detection and post processing artifacts resistance.

title: Real-Time Aerial Threat Detection and Crowd Dispersion Management: An Integrated Approach for Public Safety in UAV-Impacted Scenarios
authors: Naimish Gupta, Meera Sharma, Ashu Saxena, Mohd Wazih Ahmad, Schephalika, Shivangi Ghildiyal
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative system design for real-time aerial threat detection and crowd management, integrating advanced deep learning frameworks and geospatial analysis to enhance public safety and emergency response. The system employs sensors, radars, and cameras to monitor airspace and identify aerial threats, such as combat aircraft and drones, using state-of-the-art object detection algorithms like you only look once (YOLO) and faster region-based convolutional neural network (R-CNN). By calculating the speed and trajectory of incoming threats, it predicts the probable impact zone and leverages geospatial analysis to identify safe and danger zones. This information is disseminated to users via notifications, guiding evacuation efforts with real-time, map-based alerts. A threat classifier, developed using machine learning algorithms like support vector machines (SVMs), assesses the severity of threats based on parameters such as size, speed, and predicted impact point. The system further integrates with cloud-based geographic information system (GIS) platforms, such as Google Maps application programming interface (API), to optimize evacuation routes based on crowd density and threat projections. It achieves high accuracy through training on a mix of real-world and simulated data, including flight and crowd scenarios. By combining aerial threat detection with crowd management, the system delivers actionable intelligence that enhances operational efficiency and sets a new standard for security technology in highstakes environments.

title: Optimizing Financial Trading Strategies for Gold: Bayesian XGBoost and Genetic Algorithms in Tandem
authors: Yupeng Fan, Lushi Pu, Yufan Zhou, Biyuan Han, Hongjue Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a method to optimize financial trading strategies by combining data augmentation, Bayesian-optimized XGBoost models, and genetic algorithms to enhance performance in volatile markets. We first preprocess and augment financial data to ensure accuracy and consistency, and simulate market volatility to enhance model robustness. Subsequently, Bayesian Optimization is employed to tune the hyperparameters of the XGBoost model, minimizing prediction errors. Finally, a Genetic Algorithm identifies profitable trading opportunities within market constraints. Experimental results demonstrate that this framework effectively optimizes trading strategies across various market conditions, showcasing strong adaptability and generalizability.

title: Accelerating Heterogeneous Tensor Parallelism via Flexible Workload Control
authors: Zhigang Wang, Xu Zhang, Ning Wang, Chuanfei Xu, Yu Gu, Hui Lu, Dawei Zhao, Zhihong Tian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Big Data
abstract: Transformer-based foundation models are becoming deeper and larger. For fast training, their billions of parameters (tensors) are split onto parallel tasks running on many modern yet expensive accelerators. To amortize the huge hardware investments, it is cost-effective to share the aggregated resources among multi-tenants. However, resource contention yields the heavy straggling problem. Existing works feature contributions for the traditional data parallelism. They cannot work well for the new tensor parallelism, due to the dependency among split tensors. This paper is the first attempt on accelerating heterogeneous tensor parallelism. We summarize specific challenges, including the very frequent synchronizations and the heavy tensor computation workloads. Our solution is to resize dimensions of parameters on demand, to quickly and dynamically balance workloads. The accuracy loss is reduced through priority resizing. We also migrate workloads between tasks, without any loss of accuracy. The most efficient communication primitives are selected and then scheduled in a non-redundant manner, to reduce the runtime latency. Our final hybrid solution is built on top of resizing and migration. By studying the tradeoff between accuracy and efficiency, it can smartly hit the “sweet spot”. Extensive experiments validate the effectiveness of our proposals.

title: Enhancing the Management of Fisheries and Quotas Using Customized Blockchain
authors: Premanand Ghadekar, Atharv Joshi, Palash Joshi, Arushi Kadam, Payal Powar, Vedant Sutar
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: This paper presents a groundbreaking blockchain-integrated system for enhancing the sustainability, transparency, and financial fairness of the fishing industry. The solution offers end-to-end traceability using a Random Forest model for real-time price forecasting (97.03% accuracy) and a VGG-based model for species classification (97.88% accuracy). Compliance is automated, and banned practices such as mislabelling and fishing are removed. Fair pricing and sustainable fishing practices are guaranteed through the use of AI-based data in a tailored blockchain. The approach offers a scalable model that can be applied to other resource-based industries.

title: Explainable AI for Band Selection in Hyperspectral Imaging: A Comparative Analysis
authors: Aparna Halbe, Vaishnavee Rathod, Dhruv Mehta, Amey Agarwal, Vidhi Gajra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Hyperspectral imaging (HSI) captures detailed spectral data, but its high dimensionality requires band selection to reduce complexity while preserving critical information. Explainable AI (XAI) techniques, such as SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) and Partial Dependence Plots (PDPs), illuminate why specific bands are chosen, fostering trust in automated processes. This paper compares three band selection methods-Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Dual-Constrained Low-Rank Representation (DCLRR), and Cuckoo Search with Correlation-Based Initialization (CSCI)-through an XAI lens. Using the Salinas-A dataset, the study highlights how each method balances performance and interpretability. Comprehensive SHAP, PDP, and band similarity analyses reveal band contributions, interactions, and relationships, with near-infrared bands consistently identified as critical. These XAI insights enhance transparency and guide practical HSI applications.

title: Design of a Miniaturized Four-Band Microstrip Antenna Based on Slot Technology
authors: Mao Pengrong, Wang Jing, Gao Canguan, Shi Mingyun, Wang Yantong, Liu Hang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: To meet the diverse frequency requirements of antennas for wireless communication terminals, a design for an antenna capable of operating across four distinct frequency bands is presented. Constructed from polytetrafluoroethylene, the antenna incorporates symmetric dual circular ring gaps with slotted configurations on a rectangular microstrip patch, along with a rectangular slot gap on the ground plane. This design enables the antenna to achieve multi-frequency functionality. To optimize performance within the constraints of the antenna's overall size, the dimensions of the rectangular slots on the ground plane and the dual circular ring gaps on the patch surface are finely tuned. The optimization of the antenna's design is achieved using electromagnetic field simulation software, which helps determine its optimal structure. Simulation results confirm that the antenna resonates effectively at frequencies of 2.45 GHz, 3.9 GHz, 4.45 GHz, and 5.1 GHz, exhibiting return losses of -23.74 dB, -21.82 dB, -19.76 dB, and -15.57 dB, respectively. The measured performance aligns closely with the simulation predictions. Distinguished by its lightweight, low profile, and ease of fabrication and tuning, this antenna represents a significant advancement in the design of multi-frequency antennas for wireless communication devices.

title: Personalized Biofeedback for Affective Dynamics: A Virtual Reality Framework Based on Markov Modeling
authors: Pietro Cipresso, Gloria Simoncini, Francesca Borghesi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Affective dynamics, the unfolding of emotional states over time, are central to understanding emotion but remain difficult to capture experimentally. This paper presents a novel framework integrating immersive virtual reality (VR), heart rate variability (HRV) biofeedback, and discrete-time Markov modeling to capture and enhance emotional flexibility, offering a trajectory-focused approach to both measuring and training affective dynamics. Participants experience twelve validated VR transitions based on Russell's circumplex, while HRV is recorded and analyzed offline to create individual affective dynamic profiles. Using these, a personalized VR biofeedback protocol is delivered via the Excite-O-Meter platform. This trajectory-focused approach offers a promising tool for advancing affective science and developing adaptive emotional training systems.

title: Cybersecurity Threat Analysis utilizing Deep Learning: Apply Natural Language Processing Techniques to Extract Compromise Indicators from Unstructured Logs
authors: Koushik Lingam, Ramanan Sathiaseelan, Perumalsamy Devaraj, Abhilash Narayanan, Prameela Lavadya, A. Prasina
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Abstract-The methods that hackers use to break into systems are becoming increasingly sophisticated. Cyber security systems of today are required to deal with a large amount of unstructured data, which includes system logs, network traffic, and threat intelligence reports, in order to find possible indicators of compromise (IoCs). Because of the many, complicated, and confusing cyber incidents that have happened in the last few years, traditional rule-based systems and manual log analysis techniques are no longer enough. This study aims to illustrate the application of an advanced deep learning architecture and Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques to autonomously identify, interpret, and correlate indicators of compromise within unstructured cybersecurity data. The method uses transformer-based designs like BERT and GPT to figure out what words imply based on the context in which they are used. Because of this, the system can find behaviors that weren’t expected, threat patterns that were hidden, and attack signatures that had never been seen before. The recommended solution uses preprocessing pipelines to do both log normalization and entity recognition. Then, it uses semantic embedding to turn unstructured log entries into vectors that the learning model can understand. It is possible for the model to detect critical signals such as IP anomalies, unlawful access attempts, and hazardous payloads without the requirement to be configured with specific criteria. The labeled threat datasets not only contribute to the further improvement of the deep learning module, but it also makes use of attention techniques in order to select the most significant tokens associated with threats. The results of experimental assessments show that the accuracy and recall of IoC extraction are significantly higher than those of typical machine learning benchmarks. Additionally, it is able to manage a wide variety of log formats and an everevolving threat vocabulary. The goal of this project is to construct an autonomous threat analysis system that is able to learn from data streams that are constantly changing. This project links natural language processing (NLP) and cybersecurity. Furthermore, it improves the effectiveness of proactive security methods and makes it simpler for analysts to identify items in real time. According to the findings of our research, powerful natural language processing (NLP)driven cybersecurity analytics have the potential to transform threat intelligence by transforming unstructured data into a dependable and efficient method of identifying and resolving new cyber threats.

title: AI-Driven Predictive Modeling: Transforming Diagnosis and Management in Women’s Health
authors: Sunita Waila Tiwari, Kavita Bisht, Mamta Joshi, Garima Chand, Shivali Sagar, Vandana Pandey
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become a revolution in predictive modeling, which has made remarkable progress in ensuring that women will enjoy better healthcare with early diagnosis, precise treatment, and personalized services. The review indicates AI applications, advantages, and limitations in managing and predicting women-specific health-related issues like Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), breast and cervical cancers, urinary tract infections, pregnancy complications, and mental health disorders. The models developed with the help of AI process big data, such as clinical, genetic, and imaging data, to find minor patterns that increase the accuracy rates of the diagnosis and allow designing treatment plans based on the patient. In fertility, AI enables prediction of pregnancy, monitoring of pregnancy, and identifying complications during the early stages of pregnancy like preeclampsia and gestational diabetes. Machine learning and deep learning algorithms have shown high levels of accuracy in the interpretation of mammograms, Pap smears, and ultrasound images to detect cancer. Additionally, wearable and chatbots using AI are also utilized in providing constant health monitoring and mental health care. As promising as it is, there are still concerns of data inclusivity, algorithmic bias, privacy and ethical concerns. The future outlooks are that clear, unbiased, and open sourced AI tools will be required to secure fair access to healthcare services by women worldwide. On the whole, AI is a new paradigm of more active, accurate, and proactive and patient-oriented approaches to female health.

title: The impact of Automation and AI: Exploring how automation and AI will reshape team dynamics and the skill set needed for the future high-performing team
authors: Vinod Patel, Ajit Kumar Singh, Anurag Jain, Maharshi Thaker, PraseejaRajeev Menon, Aparna Patrikar
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: This paper discusses how automation and artificial intelligence (AI) are transforming the way teams work and the skill base that is necessary to build high-performing teams. The study is based on empirical data collected from 280 professionals across IT, manufacturing, finance and healthcare sectors, we modeled seven reflective variables using SEM (SmartPLS)4.0: Automation Integration (AUT), AI Utilization Quality (AIU), Collaboration and Communication Quality (COL), Psychological Safety (PSY), Future-Ready Skills (FRS), Team Adaptability and Learning Agility (TAD), and Team Performance (TPF). The measurement model showed a high level of reliability and convergent validity (all AVE $\gt 0.70$). There is a mediated architecture as supported by structural results: AUT, AIU, and COL have significant incremental benefits, and the direct impact of COL on TPF is the largest, with FRS and TAD having smaller yet significant incremental benefits. PSY enhances coordination through the positive effect on COL. The model only describes a middle portion of the variance in performance (TPF R $2=$ about 0.29), which means that outcomes are being driven by human-machine complementarity and not only by automation. In practice, organizations are advised to combine automation with routines, which improve the quality of AI use, invest in psychologically safe collaboration, and develop hybrid skills and learning agility to transfer their technological potential into the quality of continued team performance. The findings also highlight the importance of ethical AI use and workforce reskilling to ensure that automation enhances human potential rather than replacing it.

title: Enhancing PPP/INS Navigation by Tightly Integrating Visual Map Matching based on Heterogeneous Road Markings
authors: Yuxuan Zhou, Meng Sun, Xingxing Li, Xuanbin Wang, Shengyu Li, Chunxi Xia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: High-precision and robust positioning is crucial for ensuring safety and reliability of autonomous driving. The combination of precise point positioning (PPP) technology and inertial navigation system (INS) offers a globally available solution for continuous outdoor positioning. However, due to satellite signal degradation and error accumulation of low-cost INS, the positioning performance is challenged in complex urban environments. To address this issue, leveraging visual perception of specific prior map elements is an effective and applicable complementary approach. In this work, we tightly integrate visual map matching into PPP/INS navigation through a centralized extended Kalman filter (EKF).
