For map matching, heterogeneous road markings that structure urban roads are considered for constraint construction, whose observations are compactly modelled in 3D space and can be flexibly associated with the prior map. The complementary characteristics of map matching and PPP are fully exploited through tightly coupled integration, offering fast convergence, robustness against outliers, and sustained accuracy. The positioning performance and influencing factors of the proposed system are evaluated in both simulation and realistic urban road experiments. The results indicate that with the incorporation of map matching measurements, the proposed method exhibits superior performance in terms of accuracy and convergence, maintaining sub-decimeter to decimeter level positioning accuracy even under harsh GNSS observation conditions.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Underwater Bioacoustic Recognition with Multi-Feature Spectrogram Analysis and Augmentation
authors: R. Dharshan Kanna, R. Aruna
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The effective identification of marine animal vocalizations is critical for advancing ecological conservation and underwater biodiversity monitoring. This study presents an innovative deep learning framework architecture that integrates a fine-tuned ResNet18-based CNN for spatial feature extraction and a temporal BiLSTM network for temporal acoustic information capture. with high accuracy and robustness. The framework is designed to leverage the complementary capability of convolutional layers (CNN s) to effectively extract spatial and spectral patterns from spectrogram inputs, while Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) component is tasked with the temporal dynamics present within audio data. To cope with the challenges arising from the highly variable and noise-rich underwater environment, we incorporate a spectrogram-based data augmentation approach using natural ambient sounds, which effectively enhances the model's generalization to diverse acoustic conditions. Our system is trained on a comprehensive dataset comprising multiple marine species, with both original and augmented samples, to ensure scalability and adaptability across varied underwater soundscapes. Extensive experimental evaluations on real-world marine bioacoustic datasets demonstrate that the proposed hybrid model consistently outperforms baseline CNN-only and Bi-LSTM-only architectures with respect to accuracy, recall, and F1-score metrics. Moreover, the model exhibits strong resilience to environmental noise, validating its applicability for practical, real-time underwater acoustic monitoring tasks. This research contributes a robust, scalable, and introduces a unified deep learning framework that advances the current state-of-the-art in automated marine animal sound classification, enabling more efficient monitoring and conservation efforts in acoustically diverse and increasingly noisy marine habitats.

title: Research on Evaluation Model of University Innovation Projects Based on Computer Vision
authors: Hongyi Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes an evaluation model of university innovation projects based on computer vision. The model combines image processing and video analysis technology and uses deep learning algorithms to automatically evaluate project display materials. Specifically, the system uses CNN to extract features from project display images (such as posters, photos, etc.), and evaluates the display effect and creativity of the project by analyzing visual features such as creativity and design aesthetics. For the display video of the project, the system uses LSTM algorithm for time series analysis to evaluate the clarity, interactivity and completeness of the project expression. The multimodal fusion of image and video data makes the evaluation more comprehensive and accurate. The accuracy of image evaluation is 94.8%, the accuracy of video evaluation is 92.3%, and the accuracy of comprehensive evaluation reaches 95.5%. Compared with traditional manual evaluation methods, this system can significantly improve the objectivity and efficiency of evaluation, reduce human bias, and save review time. This study provides an efficient, intelligent and objective evaluation tool for university innovation projects, which has wide application potential, especially in various scientific and technological innovation competitions and project presentations, and can provide more accurate evaluation basis.

title: Fusing Electromyography and Electroencephalography Signals with Machine Learning
authors: Ravi Suppiah, Noori Kim, Anurag Sharma, Khalid Abidi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Two physiological signals, electromyography (EMG) and electroencephalography (EEG), are critical in the rehabilitation process. Research into the use of Muscular Activity to aid in developing rehabilitative robotic systems has been ongoing for several years. The objective of this paper is to validate the effect of fusing EEG and EMG signals via machine-learning analysis. The data is processed using Python scripts for filtering and feature extraction. Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) is used to capture the main features. The processed datasets, along with the features, were organized for labelling for classification. Random forest, support vector machine (SVM), and linear discriminant analysis (LDA), are well-established classifiers which were used as the Machine Learning (ML) models. The initial results have shown that using the fused signals for classification yields better results from the ML model. Further analysis is to be done to better understand the relationships of these signals to design a better ML model suited for such applications.

title: Evaluation of ChatGPT and Gemini Large Language Models for Generating Pharmacokinetic Models with SimBiology
authors: Libera Lucia Del Giudice, Agnese Piersanti, Alessandro Morelli, Christian Göbl, Laura Burattini, Andrea Tura, Micaela Morettini
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) chatbots like ChatGPT or Gemini rely on Large Language Models (LLMs), which are deep-learning algorithms capable of recognizing, generating, summarizing, translating, and predicting content using large data sets. They are yielding a strong boost to technological innovation in all fields, including drug discovery and development, in which in-silico models are often used to describe the behavior of biological systems and study their pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic (PK/PD) properties. This study aimed to evaluate how Generative AI tools, such as ChatGPT and Gemini, among the widely accessible LLMs, can support the PK/PD modeling process. It evaluated the potential of these LLMs in generating instructions within SimBiology, a MATLAB tool dedicated to modeling, simulation and analysis of biological systems. Four case studies were considered, the first two aimed at teaching SimBiology fundamentals and at providing basic model examples, and the second two directly related to the creation of a PK/PD model. Each output was evaluated based on the instructions provided, the differences between the two LLMs' answers, the errors made, and the ability of the tool to correct them. The results showed that ChatGPT offered greater accuracy and flexibility in code generation than Gemini, since it is able to better correct its errors, although both presented structural and syntactic errors, limiting the fully automated modeling tasks. In conclusion, ChatGPT and Gemini are promising tools for building in-silico models, especially in the early stages of model development, but at present, they require human supervision and expertise to correct errors and improve reliability.

title: Surface and Deep Signal Correlation in a Pediatric Dystonia Case with DBS
authors: Elisa Barbi, Andrea Di Rita, Luca Mesin, Chiara Rossi, Alice Noris, Renzo Guerrini, Edoardo Fino, Sara Ciabattini, Flavio Giordano, Simone Peraio, Federico Melani, Matteo Lenge
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) is a therapeutic strategy for the treatment of dystonia, also in pediatric settings. It acts selectively on deep areas such as the internal Globus Pallidus (GPi). In this study, we report a multimodal analysis carried out on a young patient suffering from generalized dystonia who underwent bilateral DBS implantation at the level of the GPi. The objective was to identify the neurophysiological correlates of dystonia. Through the synchronized recording of deep cerebral (Local Field Potentials, LFP), electroencephalographic, (EEG), and electromyographic (EMG) signals, dystonic events were identified and analyzed in different stimulation configurations (including ring mode and directional settings using contacts either proximal to or distal from GPi) and at various levels of stimulation intensity. Spectral analysis was performed on the signals to identify frequency bands associated with dystonic events and to investigate the effects of stimulation. The findings suggest that a personalized approach to DBS may improve the therapeutic management of pediatric dystonia.

title: Am I Working with “Someone”: Psychological Ownership as a Lens for Designing Agentic GenAI
authors: Yuxin Xu, Mengqiu Cheng, Anastasia Kuzminykh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Agentic AI systems are gradually integrated into people's daily lives, often designed with an emphasis on anthropomorphic characteristics to promote acceptance, adoption, trust, and participation. Yet, in collaborative human-AI interaction contexts, such as working with generative AI (GenAI) to co-create pieces, human-like features can undermine user autonomy and therefore reduce perceived psychological ownership. Psychological ownership offers a productive lens for examining humanAI interaction, particularly in human-AI collaboration, in which AI might be viewed as a tool, a partner, or even something in between. Drawing from previous research on the topic, we argue that design for agentic GenAI should prioritize user autonomy by limiting anthropomorphic features to promote productive and safe use of GenAI.

title: Application of Deep Learning Approach to Cybersecurity Attack Classification: Creating Comprehensive Multimodal Neural Networks for Detecting Cross-Layer Threats
authors: Prashanth Kura, Teja Pusarla, Rajashekhar Chitimalla
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The growing number of cyber-attacks that penetrate many levels of network infrastructure make the traditional detection method insufficient for sufficient cyber security. To address this challenge, in this paper, we propose a multimodal neural networkbased deep learning methodology for cyber-security attack classification. When communing different sources of observational information, such as network flows, system logs, application behaviors and protocol metadata, the above model is capable to detect and characterize with high degree of accuracy a multitude of cyber threats that target Hot-Cool components from Layer 2 to Layer 7. The deep learning method employs convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and long shortterm memory (LSTM) to capture spatial and temporal features, which in turn assist in recognizing sophisticated and stealthy attack patterns that may not be detected by traditional rule-based techniques. This research develops a multimodal architecture that operates with multiple modalities of heterogeneous data in parallel, which enables the model to distill diverse feature representations from each modality before integrating them into a unified classification output. The fusion of multiple views enables the model to better understand the cross-layer anomalies, for example the coordinated DDoS attack signatures, privilege escalation, lateral movement, polymorphic malware behavior, etc. We train and verify the model on benchmark-derived datasets as well as artificially generated real-world threat scenarios. Experiment results show that our method outperforms the state of the art with respect to latecy, accuracy, precision, recall over the conventional machine-learning methods and single-modal deep learning methods, especially for the case of detecting zero-day exploits and advanced persistent threats. This work aims at demonstrating how multimodal deep learning architectures can be leveraged to achieve an adaptive and scalable defense in the context of intelligent cybersecurity. The proposed system provides the ability of real-time classification with low false positives, as well as canarness new threat vectors through the continuous learning strategy. Its modular structure makes it easy to plug in with existing security information and event management (SIEM) tools and network monitoring systems. The study demonstrates a viable platform for implementing next-gen cybersecurity technologies which leverage deep learning for proactive cross-layer threat detection and classification in complex digital environments.

title: Hybrid Harris Hawks Optimization Using Minimum Cross Entropy for Multilevel Image Thresholding
authors: Tirumalasetti Supraja, Kankanala Srinivas, Balaram Murthy Chintakindi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: For the purposes of object recognition, classification, and feature extraction, image segmentation is essential. Multilevel thresholding offers improved performance over bi-level methods but depends on efficient threshold selection. This paper proposes a hybrid Harris Hawks Optimization (hybrid HHO) algorithm, enhanced with Simulated Annealing (SA) and chaotic maps, to optimize multilevel thresholds. The objective function used to assess segmentation quality is minimum cross entropy. Benchmark images from the BSDS500 Berkeley Segmentation Dataset are used to validate the technique. Results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves superior segmentation accuracy and robustness, outperforming conventional methods in both qualitative and quantitative assessments.

title: Incorporating Negative Node Information in Graph Transformer for MDD Diagnosis
authors: Hao Song, Hao Qin, Weikai Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) is a severe and disabling psychiatric illness, and growing evidence suggests that abnormal brain network connectivity is a key neurobiological marker of the disorder. As a result, numerous studies have explored graph-based Transformer models for MDD diagnosis due to their ability to capture complex topological dependencies in brain networks. However, existing methods are limited by their reliance on large annotated datasets and their tendency to focus only on positive connections, often ignoring negative node relationships that may carry important pathological signals. To address these limitations, we propose a novel model called Negative Node-enhanced Transformer (NNTrans). Specifically, we introduce a self-supervised contrastive learning strategy with a sliding window mechanism to learn robust representations from unlabeled fMRI data, alleviating the need for extensive manual annotation. Furthermore, by preserving the sign information in the adjacency matrix, our model explicitly incorporates negative node relationships during spatial attention computation, thereby enhancing its ability to distinguish abnormal connectivity patterns associated with MDD. NNTrans also employs Grad-CAM to identify brain regions significantly associated with MDD. Cross-site experiments on the REST-MDD dataset demonstrate that NNTrans significantly outperforms traditional machine learning methods.

title: Carotid Artery Segmentation and Radiomic Feature Analysis in Ultrasound using Attention and Transformer-based UNet3+ Variants: A Study of Cardiovascular Health in Hong Kong Women
authors: Ekta Tiwari, Dipti Shrimankar, Yuvraj Sharma, Luca Saba, Jasjit S. Suri
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of the common carotid artery (CCA) in ultrasound is essential for quantifying carotid intima-media thickness (cIMT) and plaque burden-key markers of cardiovascular disease (CVD). We therefore focused on the UNet3+ backbone and built two advanced variants: Attention-UNet3+, which inserts spatial attention gates into every skip connection, and Transformer-UNet3+, which replaces the bottleneck with a multi-head self-attention module. All three models-baseline UNet3+, AttentionUNet3+, and Transformer-UNet3+-were trained with fivefold cross-validation on carotid ultrasound scans from postmenopausal women in Hong Kong and evaluated with boundary errors (lumen-intima, media-adventitia), overlap indices (Jaccard, Dice), correlations with cIMT and plaque area, overall accuracy, and AUC. Baseline UNet3+ achieved a cIMT error of 0.0580 mm. Adding attention gates lowered this to $0.0385 \mathrm{~mm}(33.6 \%)$, while introducing a transformer block reduced it further to 0.0264 mm ($54.5 \%$ versus baseline). Similar stepwise gains were observed across all other metrics, confirming that multi-scale feature fusion paired first with spatial attention and finally with global self-attention delivers the most precise CCA segmentation and, by extension, the most reliable CVD risk assessment.

title: Distinguishing Startle from Surprise Events Based on Physiological Signals
authors: Mansi Sharma, Alexandre Duchevet, Florian Daiber, Jean-Paul Imbert, Maurice Rekrut
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Unexpected events can impair attention and delay decision-making, posing serious safety risks in high-risk environments such as aviation. In particular, reactions like startle and surprise can impact pilot performance in different ways, yet are often hard to distinguish in practice. Existing research has largely studied these reactions separately, with limited focus on their combined effects or how to differentiate them using physiological data. In this work, we address this gap by distinguishing between startle and surprise events based on physiological signals using machine learning and multi-modal fusion strategies. Our results demonstrate that these events can be reliably predicted, achieving a highest mean accuracy of 85.7% with SVM and Late Fusion. To further validate the robustness of our model, we extended the evaluation to include a baseline condition, successfully differentiating between Startle, Surprise, and Baseline states with a highest mean accuracy of 74.9% with XGBoost and Late Fusion.

title: A Proposed Methodology for Smart Animal Shelter for Stray Animals using ATMega 328-P
authors: V Gomathi, S Lokesh, B Mukilan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: In this paper we have proposed a methodology to safeguard the livelihood of stray animals by analysing various methodologies been proposed by several authors through the Internet Of Things (IOT) technology. So we believe a smart stray animal shelter could bring up a change in those animals lives. Here we had used AT Mega 328-P as the Microcontroller which processes the inputs through several sensors such as gas sensor, heart-pulse sensor, Temperature and humidity sensor, PIR sensor and Geophone sensor. After further processing the output gets shared in a telegram bot through a WIFI module present in the ESP-8266 module. This methodology proves to be cost and power efficient in the real time working of the system.

title: Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Algorithms for Crop Recommendation Systems
authors: Arvind Singh Negi, Anchal Rawat, Vartika Agarwal, Rahul Kumar
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Crop recommendation is an important part of precision agriculture. Its goal is to help farmers choose the best crops based on data-driven insights. This study assesses the efficacy of ten machine learning models: Logistic Regression (LR), KNearest Neighbors (KNN), Decision Tree (DT), Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Gradient Boosting (GB), Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM), CatBoost, and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP). The results, which are based on test accuracy, show that ensemble-based methods worked best. The best result was for CatBoost, which had a test accuracy of 0.9977. RF and XGBoost were close behind. LightGBM, MLP, and GB also did well, with accuracies over 0.988. On the other hand, simpler models like LR, KNN, DT, and SVM had accuracies that were a little lower, but they were still competitive. The analysis shows that ensemble methods, especially CatBoost and RF, are the best for creating a reliable crop recommendation system because they are more accurate and stable than traditional models.

title: TriSense Capsule: A Portable Wireless Module for Urine-Based Disease Detection
authors: S Jegadeesan, Arun Sekar Rajasekaran, S Suguna, V Visnupriya, S Yogadharani, E Yuvasri
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Affordable and reliable diagnostic facilities are one of the largest challenges of rural areas and areas that have limited resources. This paper will explain the Trisense Capsule, which is a portable urine diagnostic device that incorporates the use of electrochemical sensing in the offline mode. The capsule is powered by a low power ESP32 microcontroller, LMP91000 potentiostat and LIR2450 coin cell battery. It identifies glucose, albumin, and zinc biomarkers with the help of screen-printed electrodes to identify glucose, anti-albumin antibodies, and zinc oxide, respectively. The model was designed and simulated with the LTspice to test the behavior of the amplification, stability as well as sensitivity of the detector to signals under controlled conditions. Theoretical sensor response analyses, signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), and limit of detection (LOD) prove the viability of the system. My future activities will be in designing a prototype and confirming these performance indicators in the laboratory on synthetic urine samples. The Trisense Capsule provides good prospects of decentralized and sustainable healthcare diagnostics.

title: A Human-AI Collaborative Framework for Product Family DNA Definition and Styling
authors: Xiaoman Lin, Xiu Cao, Tianning Chen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: In today's competitive marketplace, establishing a consistent and recognizable brand identity through product family design has become essential. Traditional design approaches, however, often rely on subjective intuition, consume substantial resources, and lack scalability. This paper introduces a datadriven framework for product family design that integrates deep learning, Kansei engineering, and generative artificial intelligence (AIGC) to enable a structured human-AI collaborative process. The framework identifies explicit DNA features (e.g., body-shape segmentation, decorative lines, ventilation grilles) through ResNet50-based visual analysis and quantifies implicit DNA attributes (e.g., “minimalist,” “stable,” “technological”) through stakeholder interviews and sensory-evaluative questionnaires. These dimensions are systematically translated into precise prompts for generative AI tools such as Midjourney and Stable Diffusion. Through iterative refinement and expert-user screening, the process converges on high-quality styling schemes, which are synthesized and extended across the entire product family. A case study on the Mingjian test instrument family demonstrates the framework's effectiveness. In a blind classification experiment with 12 participants, the redesigned family achieved a 100% correct classification rate, compared with only 39.2% for the original products. These results confirm the framework's ability to establish coherent and extensible brand identity while addressing the subjectivity and scalability limitations of traditional design workflows. This research contributes a quantifiable and reproducible paradigm for human-AI collaboration in industrial design, operationalizing the concept of cognitive synergy. Beyond practical use for design teams, the framework also highlights implications for design education, underscoring the need for future designers to integrate data analysis, prompt engineering, and AI collaboration into their skillset.

title: Optimization of Wireless Sensor Network Energy Harvesting Using PSO and FPO Tuned Model Predictive Control
authors: S. Thiyagarajan, K. Udayakumar, D. Elamvazhudhi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The reduction in energy consumption will be supplemented by the collection of high-frequency energy from solar power plants using practically implemented technologies, taking into account a number of mandatory restrictions. We proposed a control method when developing a control system for energy harvesting. Redundancy schemes, unlike today’s simple networks, require respecting operator-imposed limits on the amount of data received while extending the lifetime of the network. In some of these networks, the supervisory and control controller receives less unnecessary or reciprocal feedback from the nodes. Therefore, control methods should be designed to achieve efficient energy harvesting based on the utility’s needs through data-driven evaluation. Among several control methods, model predictive control is one important control techniques. There are several effective ways to use it. This article compares MPC techniques with particle swam optimization next Flower Pollination Optimization for auto tuning. The main task of MPC is to coordinate the control coefficients of multiple WSN targets, and PSO or FPO applications for automatic tuning can be used as part of the solution. The MPC tuning problem is an optimization problem. Optimization techniques such as PSO and FPO can be used. PSO and FPO are well- known metasearch approaches. Instead of relying on ascension and chasing higher percentages, seek out the best overall solution. The calculation results of WSN energy harvesting show the influence of the proposed parameters based on PSO and FPO.

title: Monitoring Tunas and Sharks Using YOLO Models in the Galápagos Islands
authors: Diego Morales, Noel Pérez-Pérez, Diego S. Benítez, Marco Herrera, Oscar Camacho, Alex Hearn
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Sharks and tunas play a pivotal role in marine ecosystems, yet their populations are declining due to overfishing and habitat loss. Accurate, non-invasive monitoring methods are urgently needed to guide effective conservation strategies. In this study, we propose a YOLO-based automated detection system designed to accurately identify sharks (specifically silky and tiger sharks) and tunas in underwater videos recorded in the Galápagos Islands. Our training dataset was constructed from two one-minute video clips-one focusing on silky sharks and the other on tiger sharks and tunas-yielding 229 annotated images. We used 90 % of these images for training and 10 % for testing, applying a 5-fold cross-validation procedure. Each model was trained for 30 epochs, and multiple YOLO architectures such as YOLOv8 and YOLOv9 were evaluated based on mean Average Precision (mAP@50) and inference speed. Among the tested configurations, YOLOv9 Medium achieved the highest mAP@50 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(95.83 \%)$</tex>, while YOLOv8 Medium provided a strong balance between accuracy and computational efficiency, attaining a mAP@50 of 94.20 %. By adjusting the frame processing rate, the system can be optimized for real-time or near real-time monitoring. To avoid data contamination, training and evaluation were conducted on distinct video clips. Results indicate that YOLO-based detection frameworks can facilitate efficient, reliable monitoring of sharks and tunas, providing a powerful tool for informed conservation efforts and sustainable management of marine protected areas.

title: Super Twisting Sliding Mode Controllers Based Direct Torque Control of BLDC Motor
authors: Purushotham Endla, Karanam Deepak, P. Srikavitha, V. Surendar, Vipashi Kansal, S. Senthil Kumar, B. Rajagopal Reddy, Suresh Kakinatla
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Among various electric motor drives, BLDC motor drives are gaining attention for numerous applications because of their unique features and characteristics. To operate the BLDC motor, the most commonly employed method is direct torque control (DTC). Traditional DTC models struggle to function efficiently when there are alterations in the source and swift fluctuations in load torque. Traditional PI controllers are unable to deliver precise output immediately during abrupt changes in the drive. Consequently, this paper proposes modified DTC utilizing super twisting sliding mode (STSM) controllers to operate the BLDC motor across different operating conditions. By integrating the regulation of the dc-link current (which serves as the input to the inverter) into the proposed control model, valuable speed and torque responses can be attained even amidst fluctuations in the power supply system. The proposed methodology is evaluated against several existing methodologies. Additionally, the design of the STSM controller has been integrated, and the PSO methodology has been developed to update the parameters of the STSM controllers. The suggested methodology is executed through the use of OPAL-RT units to demonstrate various outcomes of the hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) process.

title: Enhancement of Cloud-Based Big Data Analytics with Blockchain Technology: Revolutionizing Industries with Smart, Efficient Data Processing
authors: Naga Venkata Rama Krishna Guduri, Praveen Talari, Prabhu V, Zakaria Azzam, H Pal Thethi, M. Dinesh
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: In recent times., the accelerated growth of data has established big data analytics as an integral part of decision making in various industries., including healthcare., finance., manufacturing., retail etc. With the rise of big data., cloud computing., the relatively recent trend of using remote servers to hold and process data., has become a powerful tool for managing large datasets., providing storage and computational capabilities that are scalable., economical., and also elastic. But., when data is getting complex and distributed., security., privacy and data integrity have emerged as major concerns. The inherent features of blockchain technology like decentralization., immutability., and transparency can serve as a revolutionary alternative to tackle these challenges., while improving the efficiency and trustworthiness of big data analytics based on cloud. Data integrity., tampering prevention., and transparency-based auditing mechanisms help to secure data on cloud systems., and blockchain can improve these aspects. Additionally., the distributed nature of blockchain makes it possible to securely share data across different organizations without sacrificing privacy., which is especially important in industries like healthcare and finance. In addition., incorporating blockchain technology enables efficient tracking of data provenance., guaranteeing the verifiability of data origins and transformations., thereby enhancing trust and transparency. Blockchain has applied the security enhancement of cloud-based big data analytics platforms., which can also improve processing efficiency. Similarly., various consensus mechanisms used by blockchain i.e.., Proof of Work., Proof of Stake etc.., aid in cutting down the amount of time and resources required to validate and authenticate data in real-time., thus making a faster yet more secure processing time possible. Moreover., self-executing contracts (smart contracts) define terms that are directly built into the blockchain., and can automate data workflows and decisions., thus improving efficiencies. By ushering in new efficiencies that could sharply trim operational budgets and accelerate data- based decision-making across an array of sectors., these abilities hold immense potential.

title: Research on the Resistance Analysis Algorithm for Butterfly Stroke Athlete Posture Optimization Based on Machine Vision
authors: Wu Di, Chen Guang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a resistance analysis algorithm for butterfly stroke athlete posture optimization based on machine vision. It combines deep learning and fluid dynamics models to capture the athlete's movements in real time and optimize their postures to achieve precise control of water flow resistance. The algorithm obtains the athlete's motion data in real time through machine vision technology, extracts the athlete's key posture features using DNN, and calculates the resistance under different postures in combination with the fluid dynamics model. Then, RL is used to optimize the athlete's motion path, reduce water flow resistance, and improve sports efficiency. The experimental results show that the posture optimization algorithm based on deep learning performs significantly in controlling water flow resistance. The optimized athlete's swimming speed is increased by 12% and the resistance is reduced by 18%. Compared with the traditional resistance analysis method, this method not only improves the accuracy, but also can adjust the athlete's motion path in real time, and has stronger adaptability and real-time feedback capabilities. This study provides a new intelligent optimization method for the training of butterfly stroke athletes, which has broad application prospects, especially in improving the training effect and competition performance of athletes.

title: AI-Based Internship Recommendation System
authors: Bs Geethanjali, P Madhavi Reddy, Shivang Karol, R Vaishakh Pavan Ganesh, R Jennie Bharathi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: AI-based recommendation systems can significantly improve internship search by reducing information overload and aligning opportunities with students’ skills [1]. This survey reviews the main techniques used in intelligent recommendation engines, including content-based filtering [4], collaborative filtering [3], hybrid approaches, semantic embedding-based models [2], and feedback-driven learning [9]. The paper also examines key system components such as preprocessing, feature extraction, and recommendation logic, which are consistent with foundational research in recommender systems [3]. Additionally, the paper proposes a lightweight AI framework tailored for the PM Internship Scheme portal to generate highly relevant internship suggestions.

title: Experimental Validation of Decision Tree-Based Adaptive Modulation and Coding Prediction for Multiple Users in Dynamic Wireless Environment
authors: G. Varna Kumar Reddy, M. Meena
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The increasing complexity of modern wireless communication environments necessitates efficient and accurate modulation and code rate classification to optimize system performance. This paper investigates the use of a Decision Tree (DT) algorithm for adaptive modulation and coding scheme (MCS) prediction in multi-user scenarios. Leveraging real-time datasets collected from a Software Defined Radio (SDR) platform using USRP N210 and GNU Radio, the proposed approach classifies modulation type and code rate based on key channel parameters, including user distance from the base station, channel noise, and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). The DT algorithm's performance is evaluated using both Gini Index and Entropy criteria, with results analyzed in terms of predicted values, confusion matrices, and classification accuracy. Experimental findings demonstrate that the Gini Index yields superior accuracy compared to Entropy, achieving up to 100<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup> classification performance for certain parameters. Furthermore, higher user counts (50 users) enhance prediction accuracy due to richer training data. These results confirm the potential of decision tree-based classification for real-time adaptive MCS selection in dynamic wireless environments.

title: Multimodal Relation Extraction Method Based on Expert Framework and Hierarchical Visual Features
authors: Yuxiang Peng, Yahui Zhao, Jinkang Zheng, Huimin Gu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Multimodal relation extraction aims to accurately identify semantic relationships between entities in data by leveraging information from various modalities to enhance textual relation recognition. Current research often underutilizes multilevel features of visual information. This paper proposes a method incorporating multilevel visual and textual interactions while considering the weights of features at different levels. First, the pretrained BERT model encodes textual information, and the Vision Transformer encodes global and local object-level image features, extracting multilevel visual information using its hierarchical structure. Second, an attention mechanism guides the integration of textual and multilevel visual features, generating rich multimodal representations. Finally, expert routing assigns weights to features at each level, and a fusion process combines these features. The multimodal representations are projected through a linear layer to calculate the predicted relation probabilities. Experimental results demonstrate that integrating multilevel visual information with textual interactions significantly improves relation extraction performance.

title: Photovoltaic System in a Public Education Context: A Technical Solution for the Community
authors: Johan Pino, Ingrid Oliveros, Maria Calle, Beatriz Castro Pacheco, Jose Soto, Margarita Narducci, Darlys Román Villarreal, Lacides Ripoll, Diana Rueda
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This article presents the design and technical evaluation of an on-grid photovoltaic generation system for a public educational institution located in the town of Sabanalarga, Atlántico, Colombia. The project was developed under an energy sustainability approach, integrating actual consumption analysis, solar simulations with specialized software, national regulatory criteria, and on-site structural validations. The system uses 168 photovoltaic modules and two 50 kW three-phase inverters, covers 91.45% of the average monthly consumption, with an estimated return on investment in less than three years. A financial, regulatory, and technical analysis is included to validate the comprehensive viability of the system, as well as a characterization of the educational and community impact generated by access to real-time data and the social appropriation of the project. As a contribution to knowledge, this work proposes a replicable and scalable model for school environments in similar contexts, aligned with the national energy transition policy and compliance with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in the education sector.

title: Key Considerations for Auto-Scaling: Lessons from Benchmark Microservices
authors: Majid Dashtbani, Ladan Tahvildari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Microservices have become the dominant architectural paradigm for building scalable and modular cloud-native systems. However, achieving effective auto-scaling remains challenging, as it depends not only on advanced scaling techniques but also on sound design, implementation, and deployment practices. Yet, these foundational aspects are often overlooked in existing benchmarks, making it difficult to evaluate autoscaling methods under realistic conditions. In this paper, we identify practical auto-scaling considerations by applying several state-of-the-art autoscaling methods to widely used microservice benchmarks. To structure these findings, we classify the issues based on when they arise during the software lifecycle: Architecture, Implementation, and Deployment. The Architecture phase covers high-level decisions such as service decomposition and inter-service dependencies. The Implementation phase includes aspects like initialization overhead, metrics instrumentation, and error propagation. The Deployment phase focuses on runtime configurations such as resource limits and health checks. We validate these considerations using the Sock-Shop benchmark and evaluate diverse autoscaling strategies-including threshold-based, control-theoretic, learning-based, black-box optimization, and dependency-aware approaches. Our findings show that overlooking key lifecycle concerns can degrade autoscaler performance, while addressing them improves stability and efficiency. These results underscore the importance of lifecycle-aware engineering for unlocking the full potential of auto-scaling in microservice-based systems.

title: Utilizing Machine Learning for the Identification and Categorization of Cardiovascular Disorders with ECG Signals and Sensor Data
authors: Priyanka Kaushik, Raj Thilak K, V K Senthil Ragavan, Sripelli Jagadish, Karthikayen A, Rachna Rathore
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) continue to be a pressing concern in today's medical landscape. Among various diagnostic tools, the electrocardiogram (ECG) remains a prime method for detecting cardiac abnormalities. Traditional interpretation, while effective, demands expert knowledge and is time-intensive. This research introduces a machine learningbased approach to enhance the accuracy and efficiency of CVD detection using ECG signals and sensor data. We explored various modern methodologies, including the application of Frequency Domain Measures coupled with deep-learning image classifiers. Furthermore, we leveraged the raw ECG signals, processing them through a one-dimensional convolutional model, and utilized the XGBoost model for time- series feature-based predictions. Preliminary results indicate the effectiveness of Frequency Domain Measures in predicting atrial fibrillation, though with some limitations for other arrhythmias. TheXGBoost model demonstrated proficiency with long-term data, albeit with extended inference times due to computational demands during pre-processing. This study underscores the potential of machine learning in revolutionizing ECG-based CVD detection, emphasizing the need for continual refinement and research in this domain.

title: A Multi-Stage Decision Model of Dynamic Programming Based on Greedy Ideas
authors: Hantong Zhang, Sen Xu, Ruiheng Song, Jiale Li, Yinming Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Accurate assessment of component defect rates is crucial in industrial engineering to ensure product quality and enhance production efficiency. This study addresses multi-stage decision-making in manufacturing, encompassing parts procurement, inspection, assembly, and handling of nonconforming products. A dynamic planning-based decision model is proposed to optimize decisions at each stage, achieving a global optimum. The model aims to minimize the number of inspections while accurately determining if defect rates exceed predefined thresholds, thereby improving operational efficiency and product quality. Initially, sampling inspection and the Sequential Probability Ratio Test (SPRT) method are employed to estimate defect rates. Subsequently, a dynamic programming model, guided by a greedy algorithm, optimizes the production process, ensuring optimal decisions at each stage and an overall optimal sequence. Although real-world constraints may prevent full implementation of the theoretical optimal results, the framework significantly enhances process performance and decision-making in manufacturing environments.

title: Smart Street Light with Dynamic Brightness Control and Fault Detection
authors: Navakrishnan M. R., Kavyasree A. Nair, Drisya M. K., Reshma Roy, Alan Tomy
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: In recent years, the increasing demand for sustainable and energy-efficient solutions has led to the development of smart technologies in various sectors. A smart solar street light system equipped with dynamic brightness control and fault detection mechanisms can enhance the efficiency and reliability of outdoor lighting infrastructure. The system utilises solar energy as a renewable power source, reducing dependence on conventional electricity grids and minimizing the environmental impact. The system employs PIR sensors to detect the motion of vehicles or pedestrians, automatically adjusting the brightness of the street lights in response. This dynamic brightness control not only ensures optimal visibility but also maximizes energy savings by dimming the lights during periods of low activity. To enhance the system's reliability, a comprehensive fault detection mechanism has been integrated. The fault detection system monitors the functioning of lights through LDR modules. In the event of a malfunction or abnormality, the system is designed to promptly identify the issue and trigger appropriate alerts. The street light control system is configured to integrate with the Blynk platform. This integration allows the system to communicate with the Blynk servers and utilize its features, including sending notifications to connected devices via the Blynk app. This feature facilitates proactive maintenance, minimizing downtime and ensuring uninterrupted illumination of the street. A web interface is implemented, serving as a centralized platform for remote monitoring, control, and management of the street light system, while providing real-time insights. The integration of smart technologies not only makes the system an energy-efficient and environmentally friendly solution but also contributes to the creation of intelligent urban lighting systems. As cities continue to evolve towards smart and sustainable environments, the implementation of such innovative systems becomes imperative for a greener and more efficient future.

title: Multi-Version Analysis of YOLO: A Deep Dive into YOLOv5, YOLOv7, and YOLOv9 for Face & Person Detection
authors: Syed Mohd Fazalul Haque, V Niranjani, Gotte Ranjith Kumar, Deepti Singh, Riya Kapoor, Sneh Kapoor
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: This study provides a comparative performance analysis of YOLOv5, YOLOv7, and YOLOv9 for real-time face and person detection, using key metrics like detection accuracy (mAP0.5), inference speed (FPS), and computational efficiency (GFLOPs). These models cater to critical applications such as autonomous vehicles, surveillance, and edge computing. YOLOv5 excels in lightweight deployments, achieving 91.2% mAP at 72 FPS. YOLOv7 improves accuracy to 93.6% at 58 FPS through enhanced feature aggregation. YOLOv9, the most advanced, achieves 95.1% mAP with multi-scale feature fusion and dynamic convolution, albeit at 41 FPS. The study highlights performance trade-offs and offers guidance for choosing models based on deployment needs and precision-critical requirements.

title: When Digital Twin Meets Low-Altitude Economy Networks
authors: Zongming Cai, Li Qin, Yixiong Feng, Kebing Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE 28th International Conference on Computational Science and Engineering (CSE)
abstract: Integrating Digital Twin (DT) technology with low-altitude economy networks enables intelligent urban services. However, limited Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) resources and dynamic task demands introduce significant challenges for real-time scheduling and coordination. To tackle these issues, we propose a novel framework—Digital Twin-enabled Low-Altitude Economy (DT-LAE) which creates synchronized virtual replicas of physical UAV systems. This enables real-time monitoring, intelligent decision-making, and adaptive cross-layer collaboration. In addition, we explore the communication mechanisms, core capabilities, application scenarios, and several open research challenges within this framework. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework in dynamic traffic environments, we propose Lyapunov-based Aerial Traffic Optimization Scheduling (LATOS), an online scheduling framework for resource allocation that balances UAV energy consumption, communication delay, and computational load. Within the LATOS framework, we decompose the scheduling problem into two subproblems centered on transmission time and energy consumption. These subproblems are solved in an iterative manner to jointly optimize system timeliness and energy efficiency. Extensive simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves scheduling robustness and energy efficiency.

title: Wireless Sensor Network Fault Detection Using A Random Forest Classifier Implemented on FPGA
authors: N. Haritha, B.R. Tapas Bapu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Fault detection in Wireless Sensor Networks areindispensable in maintaining reliable conveyance and network performance. Techniques often rely on manual diagnosis or singlemodel approaches, which suffer from lower accuracy and delayed responses, especially in large-scale or real-time sensor environments. These limitations can lead to undetected node failures, data loss, and increased maintenance costs. To overcome these challenges, this work presents a composite Machine Learning-based Fault Detection System that integrates the predictive capabilities of Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and XGBoost (XGB) models. The hybrid ensemble effectively analyzes sensor and network parameters such as battery level, temperature, humidity, signal strength, and packet loss rate to detect abnormal node behavior with high accuracy. Once a fault is detected, classification result is transmitted to an FPGA module (XC9572XL), which controls visual alerts using ON/OFF indicator LED to signify node health status. Additionally, Keywords—WSN, FPGA, fault diagnosis, random forest classifier

title: Advanced Learning Models for Satellite-Based Cyclone Intensity Estimation through Hyperparameter Optimization
authors: Mohit Kumar, Rohit Kumar Mishra, Khushi Kumari, Rishu Raj, Ram Chandra Barik, Adyasha Rath
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Accurate prediction of past cyclone intensity is important in disaster mitigation and preparation. In this paper, machine learning algorithms for cyclone intensity prediction are investigated based on radarset2 satellite imagery and truth-validated Atlantic hurricane database (HURDAT2), which is maintained by the National Hurricane Center (NHC). This paper entails comparison of Decision Tree, Random Forest, Naive Bayes (Gaussian), and ensemble models. Models were validated using all features from RADARSET2 images and the five most important features derived from feature analysis. Accuracy, precision, and recall were used as performance metrics, and classification reports and precision-recall curves were analyzed. Results indicate that the Random Forest model had the best performance among all models with the highest accuracy (0.968), precision (0.967), and recall (0.968) when trained on the full feature set. Even though the performance dropped when the top five features only were used, the model remained predictive, proving that a smaller subset of features could perform.

title: Liquid Deposition Modelling - Shrinkage behaviour of 3D-Printed Parts made from Spent Coffee Grounds
authors: Züleyha Saraç, Konstantin Nuss, Uwe Gleiter, Sebastian M. Schillo
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Liquid Deposition Modelling (LDM) enables the additive manufacturing of paste-like materials and is increasingly relevant for processing bio-based and compostable feedstocks. In this study, spent coffee grounds (SCG) were utilized as the primary filler to develop a sustainable, extrudable paste. The formulation comprised finely ground, dried SCG combined with carboxymethylcellulose and xanthan gum as binders. The paste was processed via LDM to fabricate geometrically identical test specimens. To evaluate the influence of drying conditions on dimensional stability, different drying regimes were systematically applied. The results show that both drying kinetics and initial water content significantly affect shrinkage and warping behavior. Particular emphasis was placed on analyzing anisotropic shrinkage and the development of warpage during drying. This study contributes to the material and process optimization of bio-based pastes in additive manufacturing and demonstrates the potential of spent coffee grounds as a sustainable filler material.
