title: Interactive Data Visualization for Statistical Analysis Based on Web Technologies
authors: Chaojie Wang, Shuangshuang Yang, Yingying Li, Qiuxue Ouyang, Hanzhi Cui
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper aims to explore the application of Web technology in statistical data analysis visualization and interaction, and builds a simple and easy-to-use Web platform. Through a questionnaire survey, the evaluation of statistics students on SPSS, R language, Python and Excel, four data visualization tools, was collected, and experiments were conducted based on them. The experimental results show that the web-based visual data analysis platform is superior to previous visualization tools in terms of ease of use and interactivity. Users can understand the distribution of data more intuitively and learn the concepts and methods of statistical analysis by interacting with graphics. The platform supports data uploading, data modification, data analysis, graphics drawing and interaction, providing users with a convenient data exploration and analysis tool, demonstrating the great potential of Web technology in the field of statistical data analysis, helping to promote the innovative development of data visualization tools, and providing more efficient and intuitive solutions for education and practice.

title: Development of a preliminary prototype robotic gripper inspired by the tentacles of cuttlefish
authors: Daniel Attard, Michael A. Saliba, Pierluigi Mollicone, Arif Rochman, Dixia Fan
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Soft robotic grippers offer unique advantages when it comes to tasks involving the delicate manipulation of irregular objects with a high degree of shape variability. These advantages stem from the use of inherently compliant soft materials, making them the safer option in many applications. Taking inspiration from biological systems, controlled deformation is “programmed” into a soft gripper through its geometry and materials, as opposed to joints and linkages as in conventional pinch-type grippers. This work outlines the development of such a system, a cable-actuated soft robotic gripper whose prehension is inspired by the tentacles of a cuttlefish. A segmented geometry and tendon-like actuation define the design to replicate the effortless, distributed bending observed in nature. The system development involved material selection, structural design, actuation and transmission design, manufacturing constraints, and the control system design. Through the integration of these elements, this work demonstrates a structured approach to building a soft bioinspired robotic gripper.

title: A Novel Deep Learning Model to Predict Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) Disease Based on Intensive Neural Classifiers
authors: R B Revathi, T P Ramachandran
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The structure and function of brain neurons is severely damaged in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), resulting in the pathology of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Disorder (ALSD). The affected individuals are prone to different physical morbidities and psychological morbidities if it is not diagnosed and managed at the earliest. For this purpose, Electroencephalogram (EEG) signals that can record the brain's internal activity at a relatively lower spatial resolution, are mostly used. Nevertheless it is difficult to manually analyze the EEG signals for ALSD detection as they are in the microvolts in amplitude and due to the complex nature of the brain. To address this challenge, an automated Intensive Neural Classifier Model based on Deep Learning (DL-INC) for ALSD has been developed to assist medical experts in the screening of ALSD. Since EEG signals are nonlinear and oscillatory, the proposed DL-INC method examines this signal through distinct frequency sub-bands. The approach is based on an Enhanced Flexible Analytical Wavelet Transform (E-FA-WT) that breaks up EEG signals into the approximate and detailed wavelet coefficients. The statistical features comprising of mean, standard deviation, skewness, kurtosis and Shannon entropy are calculated from the calculated motion coefficients and these are utilized for model DL-INC training as input. The procedure apply a 12-fold cross-validation strategy for model training and evaluation. Performance is analyzed based on standard measures such as accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, F -measure, and precision extracted from the confusion matrix. The DL-INC with polynomial kernel among the models experimented recorded the highest accuracy of 99.06% using 12-fold cross-validation method.

title: Beyond Functional Correctness: Exploring Hallucinations in LLM-Generated Code
authors: Fang Liu, Yang Liu, Lin Shi, Zhen Yang, Li Zhang, Xiaoli Lian, Zhongqi Li, Yuchi Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering
abstract: The rise of Large Language Models (LLMs) has significantly advanced various applications on software engineering tasks, particularly in code generation. Despite the promising performance, LLMs are prone to generate hallucinations, which means LLMs might produce outputs that deviate from users’ intent, exhibit internal inconsistencies, or misaligned with the real world knowledge, making the deployment of LLMs potentially risky in a wide range of applications. Existing work mainly focuses on investigating the hallucination in the domain of Natural Language Generation (NLG), leaving a gap in comprehensively understanding the types, causes, and impacts of hallucinations in the context of code generation. To bridge the gap, we conducted a thematic analysis of the LLM-generated code to summarize and categorize the hallucinations, as well as their causes and impacts. Our study established a comprehensive taxonomy of code hallucinations, encompassing 3 primary categories and 12 specific categories. Furthermore, we systematically analyzed the distribution of hallucinations, exploring variations among different LLMs and benchmarks. Moreover, we perform an indepth analysis on the causes and impacts of various hallucinations, aiming to provide valuable insights into hallucination mitigation. Finally, to enhance the correctness and reliability of LLM-generated code in a lightweight manner, we explore a training-free hallucination mitigation approach by prompt enhancing techniques. We believe our findings will shed light on future research about hallucination evaluation and mitigation, ultimately paving the way for building more effective and reliable code LLMs in the future. The replication package is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Lorien1128/code hallucination</uri>.

title: Determinants of Deployment Smart Road Asset Management for Real-Time Pavement Defects Detection
authors: Raftah Abdul Razak, Noor Irza Mohd Zaki, Mohd Khairi Abu Husain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Effective Road maintenance is critical for maintaining infrastructure quality, ensuring road safety and extending its service lifespan. However, traditional pavement defect detection methods at Pasir Gudang Highway are a reactive approach, time-consuming, labor-intensive, and lack real-time monitoring capabilities. The adoption of smart road asset management (SRAM) can address these challenges; however, its deployment remains limited. This study examines the key determinants that influence the deployment of SRAM for real-time pavement defect detection on the Pasir Gudang Highway, with the aim of transitioning from conventional to proactive maintenance. A quantitative approach was employed, utilising a structured questionnaire survey distributed among authorities, road maintenance professionals, engineers, and contractors involved in the Pasir Gudang Highway project. Data were analysed using both descriptive and inferential statistics to identify significant factors influencing adoption. Results indicate that perceived usefulness, including high productivity, accuracy, and reliability of output, as well as ease of operation, are the most influential determinants of SRAM deployment. The operational challenges and drawbacks of the current system have a significant and direct impact influencing the determinants. The findings provide actionable insights for policymakers and road authorities to facilitate SRAM adoption by addressing critical barriers and leveraging enabling factors. This study contributes to the literature on smart infrastructure and road management by highlighting the prerequisites for successful technology integration in road maintenance.

title: A Focused Approach to Generator Superiority in Digit Generation
authors: Pranita Mohapatro, Biswaranjan Routray, Subhasmita Pani, Akankhya Satapathi, Lipsa Priyadarsini Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: This work focuses on designing a modified Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) to improve the generator's performance while keeping the discriminator's influence minimal. The network is trained using the MNIST dataset, which consists of handwritten digits in grayscale. A DCGAN-inspired (Deep Convolutional GAN) architecture is adopted, featuring convolutional layers in both the generator and discriminator. To ensure stable training and encourage the generator to produce more realistic images, several enhancements are applied. These include adding noise to real images, applying label smoothing, and introducing dropout layers within the discriminator to prevent it from overfitting. Additionally, the discriminator is trained with a slower learning rate compared to the generator, helping to maintain a balance between the two networks. During training, both generator and discriminator losses and accuracies are tracked and visualized. The results show that the generator becomes more effective over time, producing images that the discriminator struggles to classify correctly. As training progresses, the generator loss decreases and its accuracy increases, while the discriminator's accuracy tends toward chance level. These outcomes highlight how targeted adjustments to training and architecture can improve GAN performance by allowing the generator to learn better and replicate the characteristics of real data.

title: Characterization of an Underwater Point-to-Point Communication System Developed with the JSN-SR04T Ultrasonic Transducer with a Frequency of 40 kHz
authors: Diana Giselle Armero Molina, Javier Andrés Rosas Villamarín, Mario Fernando Henao Rosero
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Communications have been an object of study for years, but not only terrestrial, now thanks to the advancement of technology and the need to study or maintain aquatic ecosystems, even for defense mechanisms in areas of war, are exploring alternatives underwater communication. This paper presents the development of a low-cost point-to-point underwater digital communication system based on acoustic signal transmission. The system uses a standard ultrasonic transducer operating at 40 kilohertz and amplitude shift keying for digital data modulation. A microcontroller manages the communication process and applies Reed Solomon block coding to reduce the effects of noise and signal distortion in the water medium. A custom communication protocol is implemented to manage data framing, synchronization, and retransmission. Experimental tests were conducted in a controlled freshwater environment at data rates of 100,600, and 1000 bits per second, and distances of 0.30, 1.00, and 3.12 meters. Results demonstrate that the system is capable of achieving reliable data transmission up to 3.12 meters at 100 bits per second with a bit error rate under four percent. The use of Reed Solomon coding achieved a consistent improvement in communication quality, reducing error rates by over forty percent in most cases. These findings validate the feasibility of low-cost underwater communication for short-range applications such as sensor networks and environmental monitoring.

title: Simulation-Based Evaluation of Vehicle-to-Grid Integration for Microgrid Frequency Control and Power Balancing
authors: Ana Cecilia Moreno-Alamo, Carlos Guillermo Hernández-Cenzano, Fernando Octavio Jiménez-Ugarte, Eduardo Raúl del Rosario-Quinteros
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This paper investigates the integration of a Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) system into a hybrid microgrid with conventional and renewable sources, evaluating its effectiveness in frequency regulation and power balancing. The architecture comprises a diesel generator, a photovoltaic (PV) plant, a wind system, and 140 electric vehicles (EVs) under five user profiles. The system is dimensioned to supply about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4, 0 0 0}$</tex> residential units under moderate seasonal demand. A 24-hour dynamic simulation analyzes interactions among generation, load, and bidirectional energy exchange via V2G. The diesel generator provides frequency support during load disturbances, while renewable sources exhibit intermittency from environmental variability. The V2G fleet contributes by modulating charging/discharging cycles, supporting peak-load mitigation and frequency stabilization. Results across baseline and contingency scenarios (PV or wind disconnection) show that coordinated EV integration cuts diesel use by 13.7 % (165.3 MWh to 142.7 MWh), raises renewable utilization from 62.4 % to 78.1 %, and narrows frequency deviations from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 0.25 \mathbf{~ H z}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 0.15 \mathbf{~ H z}$</tex>. These outcomes highlight V2G's role in enhancing resilience and renewable absorption in microgrids. While simulationbased, the study provides quantitative evidence and a modeling framework useful for grid operators, designers, and policymakers aiming to strengthen flexibility and sustainability in distributed energy systems.

title: Visible Light Indoor Positioning with a Single LED and Distributed Single-Element OIRS: An Iterative Approach with Adaptive Beam Steering
authors: Daniele Pugliese, Giovanni Iacovelli, Alessio Fascista, Domenico Striccoli, Oleksandr Romanov, Luigi Alfredo Grieco, Gennaro Boggia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: The integration of Optical Intelligent Reflective Surfaces (OIRSs) into Visible Light Communication (VLC) systems is gaining momentum as a valid alternative to RF technologies, harnessing the existing lighting infrastructures and the vast unlicensed optical spectrum to enable higher spectral efficiency, improved resilience to Line-of-Sight (LoS) blockages, and enhanced positioning capabilities. This paper investigates the problem of localizing a low-cost Photo Detector (PD) in a VLC-based indoor environment consisting of only a single Light Emitting Diode (LED) as an active anchor, and multiple spatially distributed single-element OIRSs. We formulate the problem within an indirect, computationally efficient localization framework: first, the optimal Maximum Likelihood (ML) estimators of the LoS and Non-Line-of-Sight (NLoS) distances are derived, using a suitable OIRS activation strategy to prevent interferences. To overcome the grid-based optimization required by the ML NLoS estimator, we devise a novel algorithm based on an unstructured noise variance transformation, which admits a closed-form solution. The set of estimated LoS/NLoS distances are then used within a low-complexity localization algorithm combining an Iterative Weighted Least Squares (IWLS) procedure, whose weights are set according to the inverse of the Cram´er-Rao Lower Bound (CRLB), with an adaptive beam steering strategy that allows the OIRSs network to dynamically steer the reflected NLoS signals toward the PD, without any prior knowledge of its position. Accordingly, we derive the CRLB for both LoS/NLoS distance and PD position estimation. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in terms of localization accuracy, robustness against OIRSs misalignment conditions, and low number of iterations required to attain the theoretical bounds.

title: Design of the Control System for a Pipeline Cleaning Robot
authors: Lili Wan, Lingxi Deng, Huiying Tang, Yuan Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the increasing number of industrial pipelines and the complexity of pipeline systems, traditional manual cleaning methods can no longer meet the current demands for pipeline cleaning. This paper designs a control system for a pipeline cleaning robot, which includes five main modules: the controller module, power supply module, motion module, cleaning module, and sensor module. The main controller module uses the STM32 microcontroller, which is responsible for processing system instructions and coordinating the normal operation of the modules. The power supply module ensures stable power delivery, the motion module enables the robot's movement and obstacle avoidance, the sensor module detects the distance to the pipeline wall and provides feedback, and the cleaning module performs the cleaning tasks. The pipeline cleaning robot can adjust its movement, ensuring more thorough cleaning. The rationality of the design is verified through simulation. The control system designed in this paper provides a reference for the development of pipeline cleaning technology towards automation and intelligence.

title: Educational Impact of Competitive Robotics in Emerging Contexts: A Case Study from Peru
authors: Diego Godinez, Jairo Gonzalez, Franco Rivadeneira, Dante Arroyo, Diego Arce
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Education is essential for the development of emerging countries, fostering economic growth, social stability, and technological advancement. Competitive robotics provides a practical framework for students to apply and acquire technical knowledge through real-world challenges. This paper presents a case study on the development of Rockbot, a low-cost teleoperated MiniSumo robot, as a Project-Based Learning initiative at Pontificia Universidad Católica del Perú. Rockbot served as a reference for students to design and implement their own competition robots. Survey data revealed that 87.2% of participants reported academic and technical improvement, particularly in areas such as mechanical design, electronics, and programming.

title: Enhancing Cloud Security in Critical Infrastructure with Deep Learning
authors: Ankush Joshi, Deepika Joshi, Chesta Kandpal, Anuj Kumar, Naman Chauhan, Vikash Kumar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Cloud computing has revolutionized critical infrastructure sectors by improving operational efficiency and data management. However, its adoption introduces significant security challenges, necessitating advanced solutions such as deep learning. This paper explores the application of deep learning in securing cloud-based critical infrastructure, highlights prevalent threats, and showcases case studies demonstrating its efficacy. It also discusses future directions and challenges in deploying AI-driven cloud security systems.

title: Issue Prioritization in Agile Development Through the Lens of Constraint Solving
authors: Tianna-Lee Salmon, Dawn MacIsaac, Francis Palma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Issue prioritization in agile software development remains a challenging task that is often addressed through classification rather than explicit ordering. This paper explores the use of an efficient constraint solver, CP-SAT, from Google to automatically generate explicit issue orderings in agile development sprints. Using historical data from real-world agile projects managed in Jira, we evaluate how well different constraint configurations approximate a gold-standard resolution order. Additionally, we simulate user elicitation to resolve ambiguities in cases where the solver produces multiple orderings, including scenarios where user input may deviate from the gold standard due to user errors. By varying both the quantity and accuracy of user elicitation, we evaluate its impact on the quality of the generated prioritization of the issues. This analysis aims to identify the constraint configurations that best replicate the orderings of real-world issue resolutions. Our findings suggest the system accurately captures improvements in the solution space with increased elicitation and remains robust to user errors. All three constraints: priority class, issue type, and creation date potentially impact prioritization.

title: Design of Wideband Planar Inverted Cone Millimeterwave Antenna based on Frequency Selective Surface for Gain Enhancement
authors: Harikrishna Paik, S. Priyadharsini, Jyothi Prasad M, R. Chinnaiyan, Sardor Sabirov, N Sivasankari
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: This paper proposes a wideband millimeter wave (mmW) antenna based on a frequency selective surface (FSS) for gain improvement for 5 G cellular communication. The presented antenna is a planar inverted cone antenna (PICA) which resonates at 28 GHz in the FR2 band and has a footprint of $11 \times 12 \times 1.6 \mathrm{~mm}^{3}$. The antenna gain is improved by integrating an FSS superstrate implemented with $6 \times 6$ unit elements antenna that used as a reflecting surface. Proposed antenna has a impedance bandwidth -10 dB at 12.6 GHz $(25.2-37.8 \mathrm{GHz})$ and a peak gain of 7.73 dB at 28 GHz. Due to FSS, the proposed antenna gain is improved by about 4.02 dB. The far-field patterns in H and E planes are at 90° to the antenna boresight axis. A prototype is fabricated to verify the simulation results. Due to compactness, wideband, and high gain, the proposed antenna may be a great choice for 5 G communication.

title: An Explainable Data Depth-Based Method in Anti-Money Laundering (AML) Domain
authors: Hanieh Ghabelialla, David Bremner, Rasoul Shahsavarifar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach for anomaly detection in Anti-Money Laundering (AML) using data depth-based methods, specifically <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta$</tex>-Skeleton Depth and Projection Depth. These unsupervised techniques leverage geometric principles and statistical analysis, with hyperparameters fine-tuned through Pareto optimization to enhance detection performance. Depth functions deliver good results while offering advantages such as interpretability and independence from normalization. Experimental results validate their effectiveness, with Logistic Regression and Autoencoders serving as baselines. Autoencoders achieved the best performance among unsupervised models but face challenges in explainability. Logistic Regression, while yielding strong results, requires labeled data, limiting its applicability in unsupervised scenarios. Correlation analysis further highlights the strong relationship between depth values and the target variable, showcasing their potential as features for AML detection. This study underscores the value of depth-based methods as robust, interpretable tools for anomaly detection in financial data.

title: Optimizing Content Marketing Strategies with Reinforcement Learning: An A/B Testing Approach
authors: Montader M. Hasan, Yaragudipati Sri Lalitha, Om Prakash Bhariya, Zebo Madrahimova, Pooja Sharma, Rashidkhon Uulu Atabek
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: This study examines how RL may be incorporated with A/B testing when it comes to content marketing, as traditional approaches are often deeply ineffective in contending with the volatility of present-day consumer habits. The presented RL-based framework stems from the ability of reinforcement learning algorithms to continue learning and adapt the content elements, like headlines and images on the basis of individual user interactions. Based on the experiments provided on the sample content marketing environment, the study shows that RL-based approach yields higher KPIs such as click-through rate, conversion rate and time-spent than the conventional A/B testing technique. The experimental results show the significant increase of all the measured parameters proving that the proposed methodology can be used for enhancing the content strategies. This research gives a new perspective into content adaptation for marketing on the Internet by automatically adapting content to individual users and so improving their response rates. Based on the study's results it is possible to propose that incorporating reinforcement learning into A/B testing can be viewed as a potential area of improvement of content marketing approaches within the constantly developing digital environment.

title: ASTANet: A Multi-Modal Adaptive Spatio-Temporal Attention Framework for Predicting Neuroendocrine Transformation in Prostate Cancer
authors: S. Aghalya
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Prostate adenocarcinoma can progress to aggressive neuroendocrine phenotypes that are refractory to standard therapies, but the epigenetic mechanisms underlying this transition are not well characterized. Towards resolving this issue, we propose an Adaptive Spatio-Temporal Attention Network (ASTANet) that fuses multi-modal data to simulate the interactions among epigenetic regulation, lineage plasticity, and tumor progression. Transcriptomic, chromatin data and temporal proliferation data are jointly represented by Attention-Augmented Convolutions (AAConv) and Squeeze-and-Excitation Networks (SENet) to boost spatial and channelwise feature learning. A Graph Attention Network (GATv2) extracts the relationships between the members of a six-gene epigenetic signature (KMT5C, MEN1, TYMS, IRF5, DNMT3B, CDC25B/DPP4), and Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCN) represent progression trajectories. Combination of spatial, relational and temporal embeddings enables accurate predictions of neuroendocrine transformation with accuracy = $99.56 \%$, precision $=99.48 \%$, F1-score $=99.50 \%$. The AIpowered system provides an innovative solution to early detection, clinical stratification and therapeutic guidance to manage high-risk prostate cancer.

title: Walking Assistance Stick For Visually Impaired Person Using GPS Tracking Based On IoT
authors: Gabriel Juan Pranata, Muhammad Evan Permana, Chaironi Latif, Isa Hafidz
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: For people with non-functional visual impairments, the commonly used assistive device is a cane. However, a regular cane is considered less effective when used in crowded activities and in conditions where the terrain may be challenging for the visually impaired. Therefore, walking aids for visually impaired individuals are equipped with an IoT system to help them become aware of obstacles around them. The walking aid is equipped with two ultrasonic sensors to detect obstacles and an analog water level sensor to detect puddles. It also uses Mamdani fuzzy logic for intelligent decision-making responses based on multiple possible inputs along the way. The device also features real-time GPS tracking and can be monitored via a Telegram bot. Arduino Nano is used as the microcontroller, and the HY-SRF05 Ultrasonic Sensor is used to measure the distance from the visually impaired person to the obstacles in front of them, supported by sound notifications from a buzzer. A water level sensor is used to detect puddles with a vibration notification from a vibrating motor. GPS tracking is installed to determine the location of visually impaired individuals if they get lost. In the Internet of Things (IoT) system. The GPS sends coordinate data to the ESP32. Based on the test results, ultrasonic sensors performed well, the water level sensor also achieved satisfactory results, and the fuzzy logic system in this device can generate decisions with a reasonable level of accuracy. It is hoped that the proposed device can help facilitate activities for people with visual impairments.

title: An Orangutan Optimization Based ProtoPNet Framework for Reading Error Detection in Dyslexia Students
authors: Neeraja James, Jarin T, Aparna Mohan, Jyotsna E
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This learning platform is basically designed to help children with dyslexia. Dyslexia is a common learning disorder that can make reading and writing a bit challenging. Traditional teaching methods are really difficult to meet the needs of users, especially for their personalized needs. The traditional approaches faces the challenges like significant posing that impairs of writing, reading and comprehensive capabilities. To overcome the challenges, this work presented as optimized deep learning model for detecting reading error in dyslexic students via their reading patterns as well as text based responses. The input data collected and pre-processed with text normalization, tokenization and sequence padding. Next to pre-processing, the bidirectional encoder representation from transformer (BERT) is utilized to extract features and the reading errors determined via ProtoPN et followed by an Orangutan Optimization (OO) algorithm applied to tune the ProtoPNet parameters and offering better detection performances. Over the traditional methods, the significant enhancements demonstrated with experimental results in response time and accuracy for error detection.

title: StyleSearch: Enhanced Retrieval Techniques for Fashion Images
authors: Chidella Teja, Sahithi Burri, Ramya Chukkapalli, Subhashini Jetti, Venkatesh Movva, Suvarna Buradagunta
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This advance research work is on an advanced jewelry search system that specializes in identifying bangles using deep neural networks. Leveraging the custom dataset, BangleFIR, which contains a diverse collection of bangle images, we aim to achieve accurate and efficient retrieval of visually similar bangle designs. We evaluate several popular deep learning models, in-cluding VGG16, VGG19, ResNet50, DenseNet201,NASNetMobile and MobilNet, to identify the most effective approach for this task. Each model is fine-tuned on the BangleFIR dataset to capture unique visual features that distinguish different bangle styles, colors, and patterns. Our results reveal that the MobilNet architecture, known for its lightweight and high-performance design, outperforms the other models in both accuracy and processing efficiency. Makes it an uniqe choice for real-time applications in fashion image retrieval for e-commerce platforms. The proposed system, utilizing MobilNet, enables fast and accurate image-based searches, improving user experience in fashion-related searches and recommendations.

title: RaDRoad-AI: An Autoencoder Approach to Intelligent Road Anomaly Detection
authors: C. Nikitha Singh, Lincy Meera Mathews, Rudresh Shirwaikar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This project addresses the problem of road anomaly detection, a pertinent challenge for autonomous driving. Autonomous cars are well equipped with sensors to read the environment patterns. Anomalies such as cracks, potholes, sidewalks, or surface wear are a challenge in non-autonomous and autonomous driving. To offset this, our model, RaDRoad-AI uses the RadRoad dataset that comprises diverse images of road condition. The data is pre-processed, including resizing and normalization to be ready for model training. Autoencoders, an unsupervised learning model has been employed for the same. The model is based on the reconstruction strategy. The reconstruction error pattern is used to identify the presence of anomalies on the road. Challenges such as high-dimensionality, noisy images, and feature learning are dealt efficiently with autoencoder pipeline. This research focuses on the building of intelligent, autonomous road condition monitoring systems to enable timely maintenance of infrastructure and enhanced transportation safety.

title: Power Consumption Minimization in FSM with Optimal State Encoding Using Whale Optimization Algorithm
authors: Nataraj Urs H.D., Manju K S, Kuberachari S.H
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: The power consumption performance of a Finite State Machine (FSM) is significantly influenced by state encoding. Optimal state encoding can greatly reduce dynamic power consumption by minimizing switching activities. This work employs the Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA) to determine the optimal state encoding and reduce power consumption. A cost model aimed at minimizing power consumption has been developed based on Minimum Weighted Hamming Distance. The proposed approach utilizes state probabilities and a total transition model to form a weighted graph for the FSM. Additionally, other meta-heuristic approaches, such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) in both static and adaptive versions, were also examined, and their performances were evaluated. Ultimately, the WOA achieved the lowest power consumption and demonstrated excellent consistency.

title: Semantic Hazard Mapping for Environmental Understanding in Mobile Robot
authors: Muhammad Salam Pararta Saragi, Deden Pradeka, Anugrah Adiwilaga, Muhammad Taufik Dwi Putra, Wirmanto Suteddy, Jezzy Putra Munggaran, Fauzi Abdul Rohim, Dyah Kusuma Dewi, Roni Permana Saputra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: This paper presents a semantic hazard mapping system for mobile robots, designed to enhance environmental understanding by integrating object segmentation with SLAMbased mapping. The system employs a $\mathbf{3 6 0}$-degree array camera consisting of six RGB cameras, combined with a 2D ray sensor, to detect and localize hazardous objects in unstructured indoor environments. Using a custom-trained YOLO model and transfer learning, it segments objects and assigns hazard levels, which are then transformed into spherical coordinates. These semantic labels are embedded directly into the occupancy grid produced by the GMapping SLAM algorithm. Experimental results in a Gazebo simulation show consistent mapping with hazard-level annotations, achieving an average RMSE of 0.093 and a mapping cycle time of 893 ms. The method offers reliable performance for near real-time semantic SLAM. However, manual field-of-view calibration is currently required.

title: A Study on the Application of AIGC in Children's Food Packaging Design Supported by the AIRAI Cloud Platform
authors: Li Yixuan, Maslin Masrom
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: As artificial intelligence-generated content (AIGC) technologies advance rapidly, their role in visual design has expanded from simple image synthesis to enabling creative workflows and seamlessly integrating into design systems. However, existing research has largely focused on AIGC's core image-generation capabilities, with scant systematic examination of workflow efficiency, targeted adaptability, and practical deployment in specific design contexts. This study leverages AIRAI Cloud — a cloud-deployed AIGC visual platform underpinned by Stable Diffusion—to propose and empirically validate an AI-assisted workflow framework specifically designed for children's food packaging. The platform empowers users, regardless of local hardware limitations, to navigate every critical creative phase, from initial concept ideation to visual prototype realization, while ensuring robust scalability and configurable adaptability. Empirical results indicate that AIRAI Cloud substantially improves designers' ideation efficiency, shortens iteration cycles, and enhances the effectiveness of visual communication with stakeholders. Compared to conventional design workflows or off-the-shelf AIGC solutions, the AIRAI platform demonstrates superior process alignment and integration value in targeted consumer product design tasks. This study addresses a critical gap in research on AIGC deployment pathways and system-level validation within professional design settings, offering empirical evidence and a platform-based framework to support AI-assisted methodologies in consumer visual design workflows.

title: Color Transfer-Based Image Enhancement for OCR Optimization on Degraded Book Pages
authors: Annisa Nur Chasidiyah, Nurcahya Pradana Taufik Prakisya, Yudianto Sujana
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: The digitization of historical documents faces significant challenges when dealing with degraded book pages that suffer from physical degradation including yellowing, faded text, stains, and uneven lighting conditions. These factors severely impair Optical Character Recognition (OCR) performance, creating barriers to effective text extraction and preservation of cultural heritage. This study presents a novel Color Transfer-based image enhancement approach specifically designed to optimize OCR performance on degraded book pages. The research employed a quantitative experimental design using a dataset of 50 pages from books published before 1990, representing typical aging symptoms found in historical documents. The enhancement pipeline implemented a six-stage process including illumination correction, noise reduction, color transfer using Reinhard's method, edge-preserving denoising, unsharp masking, and contrast stretching. Evaluation was conducted using Full-Reference Image Quality Assessment metrics (PSNR, SSIM, RMSE) and OCR performance metrics (WER, CER). Results demonstrated significant improvements in both image quality and OCR accuracy: PSNR values increased from 28.08 dB to 30.91 dB, SSIM improved from 0.49 to 0.63, RMSE decreased from 10.06 to 7.37, while OCR performance showed dramatic enhancement with Word Error Rate (WER) reducing from 70.81% to 20.02% and Character Error Rate (CER) improving from 44.90% to 5.25%. The study reveals that color transfer techniques can effectively address the unique challenges of historical document processing, though performance varies depending on initial image characteristics. This research contributes a practical solution for improving the accessibility and preservation of historical texts through enhanced digitization processes.

title: Decomposed Nowcasting of Tropical Cyclone Satellite Cloud Imagery via Deterministic-Probabilistic Ensemble Learning
authors: Sirong Huang, Hui Yu, Qin Zhao, Xiao Wang, Peihan Wu, Xinyu Wang, Peiyan Chen, Jie Lian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate nowcasting of Tropical Cyclone Satellite Cloud Imagery (TCSCI) is critical for disaster prevention and mitigation, but it remains challenging due to coupled uncertainties and multiscale dynamics in TCSCI evolution. While data-driven deep learning-based deterministic models mitigate biases inherent in traditional physics-driven approaches, their deterministic nature inherently limits uncertainty quantification. To address this, we propose TCSat-Diff, an ensemble framework that integrates spectral deterministic prediction with a frequency-adaptive probabilistic diffusion model. Specifically, we introduce a physics-inspired Reynolds decomposition strategy that separates TCSCI evolution into a large-scale trend flow and a small-scale fluctuating flow. The trend flow is predicted using the Adaptive Fourier Neural Operator (AFNO) with MSE loss for smooth large-scale forecasts, while the fluctuating flow is captured by a Conditional Latent Diffusion Model (CLDM) for highly uncertain small-scale fluctuations. To further improve frequency-aware uncertainty modeling, we develop a Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR)-guided Noise Frequency Modulation module and a Time-Frequency Response module into the CLDM, enabling adaptive spectral focus during denoising. Experiments on 1,099 tropical cyclones (TCs) from the Northwest Pacific demonstrate that TCSat-Diff outperforms previous deterministic and probabilistic baselines. Ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of the decomposition strategy and frequency-aware modules. Notably, cross-regional generalization evaluation on 480 TCs from the Southern Hemisphere reveals excellent generalization capability across different hemispheres. These results highlight the potential of TCSat-Diff for global TCSCI nowcasting, supporting early warning and risk reduction for TC hazards.

title: Long-Range Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) Data Transmission Technology Based on Fiber Optic Lasers
authors: Abhishek Shrivastava, Vinesh Kumar, Jay Prakash Maurya
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: For Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) to transmit vital flight control signals, telemetry, and sensor data, efficient data transmission systems are needed. The standard for many years has been radio frequency (RF) communication, but it has drawbacks like limited bandwidth, interference susceptibility, and possible security flaws. Using fiber laser technology, this paper presents a novel data transmission system that connects UAVs to ground control stations (GCS). Rapid data transfer, immunity to electromagnetic interference (EMI), and enhanced security make this method a viable answer to the communication problems facing modern UAVs. A laser connects the UAV to the ground control station, allowing for quicker data transfer.

title: A Quantum Dot-Doped Artificial Synaptic Transistor for Bionic Vision
authors: Weidong Xie, Zhiwei Zhu, Weiqi Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Traditional machine vision is limited by the Von Neumann computing system, and there are issues such as power consumption and efficiency, in the face of the explosion of data and real-time processing requirements brought about by vision tasks such as autonomous driving and target tracking and prediction in the age of artificial intelligence. The biological visual system, consisting of the human retina and brain, has the ability to perceive and process the changing information from the outside in real time. Here, based on synapses as the basic units of neural network processing in the human brain, we propose a quantum dot-doped artificial synaptic transistor that integrates perception and processing for bionic vision. CdSe/ZnS quantum dots are doped into the P-type organic light-absorbing material IDTBT as the active and light-absorbing layers of the transistor, and the device exhibits good transistor performance with a 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</sup> current switching ratio. The dispersed quantum dots provide a quantum well-like effect, which successfully simulates the modulation of synaptic weights under different light pulses, such as excitatory postsynaptic current (EPSC), paired-pulse facilitation (PPF) and long-term plasticity (LTP) and other synaptic properties, and enables perceptual processing of visual information as well as colour recognition.

title: An AI-Enhanced Predictive Control for Flicker-Free Operation in Hybrid Energy Systems with Low Computational Resources
authors: D. O. Cardozo, C. Quintero, M. Pardo
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This paper presents an enhancement to a hybrid energy system by incorporating an AI-driven predictive control mechanism designed to improve power supply stability and continuity. The proposed approach addresses a common limitation in conventional control strategies, which often respond reactively to short-term drops in solar irradiance by prematurely switching from renewable sources to the electrical grid. These transitions can lead to power flicker degrading the user quality of experience. Thus, a traditional operation state controller is extended with an AI-powered predicting operational mode governed by a real-time prediction model that forecasts shortterm solar power generation using a lightweight LSTM-BiCNNMLP neural network. This prediction, combined with an estimation of battery bank autonomy, enables the system to distinguish between transient and sustained irradiance reductions and to defer switching decisions accordingly. The control logic is implemented and validated in MATLAB/Simulink, demonstrating a significant decrease in redundant source switching and improved load stability under fluctuating environmental conditions. Results confirm that the proposed predictive strategy not only enhances system reliability but also operates efficiently on low-resource platforms, making it particularly suitable for rural microgrids and cost-constrained autonomous energy systems. This work represents a meaningful step toward the development of more resilient, adaptive, and intelligent renewable energy solutions.

title: A Bridge-T Resonator With Lumped-Distributed Dual Equivalence for Cross-Band Filter Design in IPD Technology
authors: Yuhao Yang, Shiyu Xie, Yongle Wu, Pengshuai Liu, Weimin Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article analyzes the low-frequency (LF) and high-frequency (HF) response characteristics of bridge-T coil (BTC) structures and proposes a cross-band filter design theory based on the BTCs, enabling a single circuit to exhibit distributed behavior at low frequencies and lumped behavior at high frequencies and obtaining a large frequency ratio (FR). Drawing on classical filter synthesis, a method to determine parameters for the HF equivalent circuit is established, while parameters of the LF equivalent circuit are derived according to positions of transmission zeros (TZs) and poles. As a result, analytical design formulas that simultaneously satisfy both LF and HF responses are obtained. This work breaks the conventional limitation that BTCs are only used in LF designs. To validate the proposed theory, a compact on-chip cross-band filter based on BTCs is implemented using four BTC units in GaAs integrated passive device (IPD) technology, achieving an FR of 7.31 within a chip area of only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.90\times 1.51$</tex-math> </inline-formula> mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The fabricated filter exhibits two distinct passbands covering 3.39–6.17 and 30.85–39.62 GHz, showing excellent agreement with the theoretical analysis. Targeting fifth-generation (5G) applications, the proposed design effectively covers both the sub-6 GHz and millimeter-wave (mm-wave) bands, which makes the circuit reusable.

title: On the Effect of Local Readout Error Mitigation on Genetic Algorithm-Based QAOA
authors: Giovanni Acampora, Angela Chiatto, Roberto Schiattarella, Autilia Vitiello
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) is a leading variational quantum algorithm for solving combinatorial optimization problems on near-term quantum devices. However, its performance is strongly affected by quantum noise, particularly readout errors. While full readout quantum error mitigation (QEM) is resource-intensive for large qubit systems, we adopt a scalable local approach using the tensor product of single-qubit calibration matrices. In this work, we analyze the local QEM effect on QAOA trained via genetic algorithms (GA-QAOA), solving Max-Cut instances on up to 15 qubits using a mock IBM quantum backend. We compare three scenarios: non-mitigation baseline, post-training mitigation, and step-wise mitigation. Results show that step-wise application improves both optimization performance and solution quality, confirming the benefit of integrating local QEM into the training process for practical use on noisy near-term devices.

title: Explainable Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare: Techniques, Applications and Challenges
authors: Narayanan Booshanan, Lawanya Shri M
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) will transform the healthcare sector through technical revamping of patients monitoring, medication development, and diagnosis. The development of AI is however stunted by the fact that the models lack transparency in its decision making commonly referred to as the black box. An example of such an antagonism has seen the development of the Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI), which are designed to fill in the gap between interpretability and the distinguished outcomes of XAI especially to the medical practitioners. The paper justifies why there is a necessity to apply XAI to healthcare with references to the application of XAI to advance trust, accountability and adherence to ethical and legal principles. We discussed some of the largest-sized XAI methods, Viz., Grad-CAM, SHAP, LIME, and Decision Trees, how they are functioning in oncology, radiology, pathology and emergency care. We also discuss how such things are implemented as the criteria of evaluation, accuracy/interpretability trade-offs, and privacy data. As per case articles and cross-reading, we provide collaborative solutions where we bring together the designers of AI and clinicians to make sure that there is ethical and clinically viable integration of XAI.

title: Drug and Dosage Recommendation Based on Explainable Generative AI Using Patient-Specific Modeling
authors: Evren Daglarli
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Despite advances, personalized medicine involving patient-specific drug selection and dosing remains challenging. In this paper, we propose an interpretable, generative AI framework for drug recommendation and dosing. While clinical decisions often follow general guidelines, our approach uses patient-specific data to generate evidence-supported candidate drug-and-dose recommendations informed by up-to-date, provenance-linked sources. The Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) framework combines data from electronic health records (EHRs) and employs machine learning and explainable AI methods. The digital twin approach supports this by simulating counterfactual treatment effects in a virtual patient model. Hence, the approach provides not only patient-tailored recommendations but also a clear, evidence-supported justification for the suggested drug and dose. We demonstrate feasibility via illustrations and simulations and outline record-based evaluations across multiple cohorts, reporting lower dose-prediction error, better calibration, and better discrimination of adverse drug reactions (AUC-ROC) and lower simulated ADR-risk indicators (RRI = 0.78; 95% CI 0.72-0.85) relative to guideline-based baselines, together with clinician-trust assessments. Retrospective results were consistent across heterogeneous cohorts, suggesting robustness to population and data shifts. The dataset comprises 75% real anonymized EHR records and 25% validated synthetic samples used only for training, with all test metrics computed on real-only data. We evaluate our approach on a de-identified, multi-cohort EHR-pharmacogenomics dataset of 20,030 patients spanning Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus, Oncology, and Renal Impairment cohorts (hereafter, the ADR-20K multi-cohort dataset), constructed from anonymized EHRs, PharmGKB resources, and GAN-augmented synthetic samples with patient-level splits and temporal blocking to prevent leakage.

title: ProSt: Provably Secure Homomorphic Steganography
authors: Shahzad Ahmad, Stefan Rass
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper introduces Provably Secure Homomorphic Steganography (ProSt), a novel technique that combines the principles of steganography and homomorphic computation. ProSt enables secure computations on data hidden within cover images using steganographic techniques. Unlike traditional steganography, which hides the existence of a message, ProSt assumes the cloud provider knows it is processing hidden data. However, it conceals the specific location and meaning of the secret bits, maintaining their imperceptibility and security. The system utilises the Fredkin gate, a universal reversible logic gate, to perform homomorphic operations on secret bits embedded in image pixels using Least Significant Bit (LSB) steganography. The paper provides an implementation of the scheme, including setup, secret embedding, homomorphic computation (which involves evaluating a single gate that is arbitrarily repeatable), and extraction processes. The security analysis shows that ProSt admits only a cryptographically negligible advantage for an honest-but-curious adversary. This advantage decays with the number of decoy bits and is preserved over any number of gate evaluations. This approach opens new possibilities for secure computation outsourcing in public cloud environments, enabling privacy-preserving data analytics, secure multi-party computation, and confidential image processing on untrusted cloud infrastructure. The paper concludes by discussing potential enhancements and future research directions to further improve the system’s security, efficiency, and applicability.

title: Image Processing Approach for Skin Disease Classification Using MATLAB
authors: S. Palpandi, Ganjikunta Eswara Govindu, Shaik Yoonus Basha
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Skin disorders are to be found among the most prevalent health issues globally and early diagnosis will make a great deal of difference in severity these disorders will be. Traditionally, skin inspection is the indispensable part in the dermatological diagnosis, which is, however, time-consuming, subjective, and error-prone. A skin diseases classification system for image processing automation in MATLAB is introduced in this paper. The system includes preprocessing techniques, segmentation, feature extraction, and classification algorithms for effectively, diseased regions identification. The features in the form of texture, color, and shape of the segmented images are used and classified by machine learning algorithms. The experimental results will illustrate that Support Vector Machine and K-Nearest Neighbor are dependable classifiers that yield high accuracy in differentiating common skin diseases. The method proposed can be employed as a computer-aided diagnostic tool to help dermatologists and, in this way, ensure the healthcare service provision even in the most remote locations.

title: Enhancing Explainability of Time Series Anomaly Detection for NVH Testing
authors: Lan Jia, Bram Cornelis, Claudio Colangeli, Konstantinos Gryllias
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Large-scale NVH (Noise, Vibration, and Harshness) testing involves high-channel-count, multi-physical sensors operating in harsh environments, making measurement anomalies a common challenge. Caused by sensor malfunctions, environmental interference, or human errors, these anomalies currently require manual inspection, which is time-consuming and prone to error. This paper explores the use of feature-based machine learning for automated anomaly detection, focusing on the interpretability of model decisions through SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations). Traditional automated anomaly detection methods struggle with generalization and often produce false positives and missed detections, motivating the need for more adaptive approaches. We apply Isolation Forest to detect anomalies in both synthetic and real NVH signals. SHAP values are used to analyze and explain model outputs, offering insights into whether detected anomalies are true positives or false alarms, and helping to characterize different anomaly types. The results show that SHAP-based interpretability significantly enhances the reliability and transparency of machine learning-based anomaly detection, making it more practical for industrial NVH testing applications.

title: MEDICHECK: A Platform for Remote Vital Signs Sensing
authors: Henry Capdevilla, Yeison Ortiz, Diana Rueda-Delgado, Cristian Olivares, Norelli Schettini
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Accessing healthcare remains challenging for individuals with limited mobility or those in underserved, remote areas. These barriers often limits timely access to care and impedes the delivery of high-quality medical services. In response to this issue, the present work introduces a telemedicine platform designed to extract two key physiological parameters: oxygen saturation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SpO}_{2}$</tex>) and heart rate (HR). These variables are monitored in real-time during teleconsultations using computer vision algorithms that analyze facial video data captured through standard consumer-grade cameras. The solution requires no additional or specialized hardware, ensuring high scalability and accessibility, particularly for low-resource settings. Beyond reducing the need for physical travel, the platform also contributes to the decongestion of healthcare facilities. By enabling remote monitoring of vital signs directly from the patient's home, the system supports preventive care, enhances accessibility, and promotes patient well-being.

title: Sports Injuries Classification Using Machine Learning Models on Biomechanical Data
authors: Emilia Aguirre, Noel Pérez-Pérez, Diego S. Benítez, Ricardo Flores-Moyano, Felipe Grijalva, Daniel Riofrío
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Early detection and prevention of running-related injuries are fundamental to protecting the health of athletes and optimizing performance outcomes. Despite this importance, early diagnosis remains a significant challenge due to the subtle and often nonspecific nature of initial symptoms, as well as the dependence on subjective clinical judgment. To address these limitations, this work proposes a machine learning-based classification framework aimed at enhancing the identification of injury patterns among runners, thus improving diagnostic accuracy. The proposed method explores five classification models, such as random forest, three different feed-forward back propagation neural networks, support vector machine, K-Nearest Neighbors, and Gaussian naive Bayes on a comprehensive dataset encompassing biomechanical, anthropometric, demographic, and training history variables. The feed-forward back-propagation neural network with 1544 and 772 neurons in the first and second hidden layers was the best model, achieving the highest F1-score of 0.980 and 0.983 in the training and test phases, respectively. Consistent performance in unseen data demonstrated the robust learning capacity of the model and strong generalization in classifying running-related injuries. These results underscore the promise of machine learning approaches in supporting objective and scalable decision-making within sports injury prevention and management.

title: Machine and Deep Learning Applications in IoT: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Jose Mario Baldovino Diaz, Daladier Jabba Molinares
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: The Internet of Things has become increasingly popular over the last decade to provide new solutions for both modern industry and society. At the same time, the growth of the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) has provided various benefits by connecting infrastructure around the world via sensors. On the other hand, we have seen a huge technological advancement in Machine Learning, which has opened the door to many possible research studies to address current and future challenges in IoT. Therefore, this paper aims to systematically review and analyze the research landscape on Machine Learning and Deep Learning approaches applied to IoT. In addition, existing datasets designed for the same will be reviewed.

title: Learning Classification Representations Using Multi-Target Hash and Multi-Hot Encoding
authors: Prasad N R
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: The statistics of 2D transforms can be used to classify images. This is the hypothesis and an algorithm to test this is offered. This involves the usage of both gray-scale images and resized versions. Multi-hot encoding and multi-class HashMap are offered. Also, image classification involves several pixels while the output is a single class label. So, HashMap may work better when we need to compute the classes of similar patches. The classification accuracy of MNIST data is about 80 percent; Fashion-MNIST, 67 percent. The code for this is available at https://github.com/PrasadNR/explainable-classification

title: Optimizing Urban Air Quality Prediction for Smart Cities with Bayesian Random Forest
authors: Yiwen Zhang, Sen Niu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: As China's smart city development accelerates, environmental monitoring becomes a key component for supporting data-driven urban planning. This study presents an advanced air quality prediction system that integrates low-cost distributed sensors and communication modules for real-time data collection. The system uses a Bayesian-optimized Random Forest algorithm for hyperparameter tuning, enabling accurate and reliable Air Quality Index (AQI) predictions. Experimental results show that the Bayesian-optimized model outperforms traditional Random Forest methods, offering precise air quality forecasting through intelligent feature extraction and hyperparameter optimization. This approach provides valuable tools for environmental monitoring in smart cities and supports their sustainable growth.

title: Hardware Design of CDC Solenoid Valve Controller
authors: Tao Xiong
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This design is centered around the main control chip, electromagnetic valve control module, PSI5 signal acquisition module, and CAN communication module, aiming to achieve precise control of vehicle suspension damping. The main control chip utilizes a high-performance microcontroller (MCU) to handle data processing, control algorithm execution, and system diagnostics. The electromagnetic valve control module employs the L9305 chip to drive and regulate current, ensuring rapid damping response. The PSI5 signal acquisition module captures real-time sensor data, providing essential inputs for control. Using the SMI230 six-axis inertial measurement unit to obtain vehicle body attitude information. The CAN communication module facilitates data exchange and status monitoring with other vehicle systems. Through a modular architecture, this design integrates control precision, real-time performance, and communication efficiency, making it suitable for modern vehicle suspension systems.

title: A Big Sports Data Analytics Solution for Redefining Basketball Player Roles
authors: Kaiden R. Bereznycky, Carson K. Leung, Itay Nudel, Om A. Sevak, Eyal Zingerman
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: For more than a century, basketball has undergone significant evolution, with changes in rules and regulations transforming both the game itself and the skill sets of its players. The traditional five-position framework may no longer fully capture the diverse skill sets associated with each role. To address this limitation, we present a big sports data analytics solution designed to analyze basketball player data, infer their offensive and defensive roles, and classify players according to their most representative roles. Evaluation on real-world data demonstrates the effectiveness of our solution and enables redefinition of basketball player roles.

title: Quantum Software: From Engineering to Interaction
authors: Mina Alipour
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: Recent progress in quantum computing has under-scored the need for specialized software to effectively address the unique challenges posed by quantum systems. While early research emphasized hardware and algorithmic breakthroughs, recent progress underscores the necessity of Quantum Soft-ware Engineering (QSE), an emerging discipline that combines software lifecycle processes, tooling, hybrid orchestration, and human-centered design. This paper integrates insights from QSE and quantum software architecture (QSA) to propose a hybrid execution architecture explicitly shaped by Quantum HCI principles, emphasizing developer experience, trust, and the quality of interaction with quantum systems. While quantum software represents a new genre of software-intensive systems, existing processes and notations can be adapted to derive architecting activities and develop modeling languages for quantum software. Additionally, tool chains can incorporate reusable knowledge and roles to automate and customize the architectural process. By analyzing current research and iden-tifying existing gaps, this paper aims to guide the systematic development of robust and scalable quantum software systems. Central to this vision is meaningful human interaction, ensuring that developers can interpret, act on, and trust system outputs from design to post-execution analysis.

title: Pushing Feelings: Emotion and Sentiment in Software Commit Messages
authors: Krishno Dey, Jagannath Singh, Hung Cao, Francis Palma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Software repositories are the primary source of information for software artifacts and contain a large amount of unstructured data, including commits, issue reports, and code comments. Mining information for different tasks, such as sentiment and emotion analysis, has been studied on several artifacts. While significant progress has been made in sentiment analysis on various artifacts, the study of emotion analysis remains under-researched due to a lack of resources, such as relevant and labeled datasets. This study presents a manually annotated dataset comprising 12,005 commit messages from the open-source Apache Tomcat project, exploring emotion and sentiment analysis through the application of natural language processing and machine learning techniques. We studied traditional models (SVM and random forest), deep learning models (bidirectional-LSTM), and pre-trained language models (LMs), as well as their ensemble, to evaluate and compare their performance on the curated dataset. Our findings suggest that software engineering domain-specific pretrained LMs consistently outperform traditional and deep learning models. The ensemble of pretrained LMs performs better on sentiment analysis. Additionally, identifying sentiment from commit messages outperforms emotion analysis tasks. We have made model implementations and the curated dataset available.

title: Building Heat Load Prediction Based on Recurrent Neural Network
authors: Zhenkui Xi, Junhong Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: As an important part of building energy consumption, the prediction of building heat load is of great significance for intelligent building management and energy system optimization. Aiming at the low accuracy of traditional heat load forecasting methods, this study proposed a building heat load forecasting model based on improved recurrent neural network, which introduced the time feature embedding mechanism, multi-scale convolutional feature extraction module and LSTM/GRU hybrid structure enhanced by attention mechanism to achieve high accuracy prediction of building heat load. The experimental data of this study show that compared with the traditional method, the prediction accuracy of this model is improved by 17.8% on average under various building types and climate conditions, the RMSE is reduced to 9.32kW, and the R2 of the predicted result and the actual heat load reaches 0.958.

title: Emotional Matters: Psychometric Design of Response Formats for Assessing Emotional Awareness in Volumetric Contexts
authors: Gloria Simoncini, Francesca Borghesi, Eleonora Diletta Sarcinella, Alice Chirico, Pietro Cipresso
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: This study introduces a novel framework for assessing Emotional Awareness through volumetric video stimuli, with a specific focus on evaluating the response design of the proposed items. Volumetric video offers a dynamic and immersive medium, allowing emotionally rich, socially situated scenarios to elicit real-time affective responses. The aim was not only to develop items targeting different facets of Emotional Awareness - such as interoceptive perception, emotional clarity, causal reasoning, and meta-reflection - but to examine how these items function when embedded in life-like scenes and paired with specific response formats. Each item was anchored to a volumetric clip, inviting participants to reflect on their own emotions or infer those of others in context. By analyzing expert feedback on item formulation, scale structure, and interpretability, the study foregrounds response design as a central component in measuring Emotional Awareness. This work moves beyond traditional self-report, offering insights into how immersive media and carefully crafted response modalities can enhance the ecological and conceptual validity of emotional assessment tools.

title: Application of Improved Natural Language Processing Technology in English Composition Assessment
authors: Hui Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel model for evaluating English essays that integrates advanced NLP techniques, aiming to enhance the precision and efficiency of automated scoring systems. The model primarily consists of three essential components: BERT, Bi-LSTM, and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). To begin with, BERT serves as a feature extractor, leveraging its robust pre-training capabilities to capture the contextual semantic information present in the essay. The bidirectional encoding approach of BERT effectively captures the text's deep semantic meaning, providing a comprehensive feature representation for the subsequent evaluation process. Subsequently, the features obtained from BERT are input into the Bidirectional Long Short- Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) network to capture the sequential information and long-range dependencies within the essay, thereby enhancing the model's capability to evaluate grammar and structure accurately. Finally, the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm is utilized to optimize the parameters of the scoring model, thereby enhancing its performance by minimizing scoring errors. Experimental results indicate that the model performs exceptionally well in practical scoring tasks, making it highly suitable for automated grading systems, particularly in the context of educational assessments and essay evaluations on online learning platforms.

title: Simulation of Servo Control System for FPV UAV Trajectory Tracking Based on H-PID Algorithm
authors: Yi-yang Chen, Guang Yue, Qin-rong Wang, Hui Wang, Jin-hao Tian, Si-qi Pang, Yi-fen Ding, Yu-tian Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: The low altitude flight characteristics of FPV drones play a huge role in aerial photography, power inspection, emergency rescue and other scenarios, and the performance of trajectory tracking control directly affects the efficiency and safety of task execution. In complex aerial environments, FPVs have nonlinear and strong coupling characteristics, and are also affected by airflow disturbances. Traditional PID control is prone to response lag and low tracking accuracy. In view of the above, this article proposes a research on FPV unmanned aerial vehicle trajectory tracking servo control system based on H-PID algorithm. Firstly, a dynamic model is established, a PID structure is established, weight functions are taken to build a generalized Plant, and H ∞ optimization is solved to obtain a set of robust PID control parameters. Finally, through simulation, a tracking curve is obtained. The results show that the algorithm proposed in this paper has strong anti-interference ability, high control accuracy, and small error, which verifies the effectiveness of the algorithm and provides a theoretical basis for future intelligent research on unmanned
