publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)

title: Task Allocation and Strategy Optimization in Multi-Agent Attack-Defense Games of Heterogeneous UAVs
authors: Chen Fangzhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper investigate the multi-agent attack-defense game problem, where the attackers aim to reach a target area while the defenders strive to intercept them. The outcome of the game can be determined by constructing for each defender and attacker their respective areas of dominance. In the case of one defender versus one attacker game, a adjust strategies method is proposed for the attacker to dynamically adjust strategies to identify the optimal attack point. For scenarios involving two heterogeneous defenders and one attacker, the study examines whether both defenders can function as effective defenders and proposes a cooperative defense strategy. In multi-attacker versus multi-defender scenarios, a task allocation mathematical model is constructed, and the problem is transformed into multiple one versus one and two versus one games by solving a simplified 0–1 integer programming problem, aiming to maximize the number of intercepted attackers. Finally, simulations are conducted to validate the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed methods.

title: A Sensor-Integrated Shoe for Ankle Health Monitoring: A Novel Approach to Diagnosis and Rehabilitation
authors: S. Shanmugapriya, Shaik Mahammad Rafi, Teja Guddanti, Pawane Ramulu Adigantla, N. Chelli Devi, S. Kalimuthukumar
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The article introduces a sensor-based smart shoe with automated therapeutic intervention as new solution to active ankle health management in this work. The methodology of the system involves the use of embedded pressure, temperature and motion sensors to keep a continuous check of ankle conditions to detect any stress or inflammatory conditions. According to intelligent logic, a microcontroller triggers therapeutic mechanisms via a cooling module to be received in reaction to sensor-detected thresholds. The prototype was proven to be functional as automatic interventions activated within a critical response time of 25 milliseconds and satisfied the requirement of proactive care. Although the technical efficacy had been proven, preliminary user feedback identified that ease of use and adherence were an important area of development in the future. The current closed-loop system has a potential to form the basis of a new generation of intelligent healthcare devices that combine monitoring and automated action together, to serve the patients better.

title: Fractional Hybrid 2DOF-PID Control with Complex Basis for Dominant Deadtime Systems
authors: Antonio Di Teodoro, Ronny Chalco, Juan J. Gude, Renato Montaluisa, Sebastian Vega, Oscar Camacho
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study introduces a Fractional Hybrid Two-Degree-of-Freedom PID controller that employs a complex basis formulation to enhance control performance in systems with significant delays. The proposed model integrates fractional calculus with hybrid control elements, improving transient dynamics and efficiency in both tracking and disturbance rejection. Results with complex basis functions show that the novel 2DOF controller enhances tracking and disturbance rejection while maintaining low control effort.

title: Integrating Deep Learning and Augmented Reality for Personalized Dental Implantology: The Development and Application of the GIST-3DR System for Enhanced Precision and Visualization in Dental Implant Procedures
authors: Sarika Jadhav, Madhura Jagtap, Aakifa Shahul, G. Pavithra, V. Shashidhar, T.C. Manjunath
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: The GIST-3DR research work aims to revolutionize dental implant procedures by integrating cutting-edge technologies such as 3D Augmented Reality (AR) and advanced segmentation models. The primary objective is to automate and personalize implant generation, addressing critical issues like improper dimensions, nerve canal damage, and lack of regional visualization. By utilizing CT scan data, GIST-3DR generates detailed 3D models of oral anatomy, enabling clinicians to visualize, plan, and execute implant surgeries with precision. The methodology involves a three-stage pipeline: Vision Stage, which processes DICOM images using deep learning models like Mask R-CNN and YOLOv8; API Stage, which manages model outputs and interfaces; and User Interaction Stage, which offers AR-based visualization for real-time testing. The project achieves high accuracy with metrics such as mAP-50 values exceeding 0.95. Results demonstrate significant improvements in implant precision and reduced manual effort. Applications include enhanced pre-surgical planning, remote collaboration through AR, and integration with CAM systems for streamlined manufacturing. Future developments aim to incorporate real-time testing, fully automated pipelines, and non-anonymous patient data integration, expanding its scope in dentistry and medical technology.

title: Development of a Solar Tracking System for Measuring and Transmitting Radiation Data on Biodegradable Plastic Samples
authors: Oscar Oviedo-Tapia, Juan Mendoza-Haydar, Laura De-Avila-Barragan, Jose Luis Villa
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a low-cost, real-time solar radiation monitoring system intended for testing samples of biodegradable plastics. The proposed system includes a calibrated solar radiation sensor, a robust data storage module, and an efficient data transfer mechanism. The sensor is designed to capture and record the intensity and variability of solar radiation in real time, while the storage module ensures the secure and accessible storage of the collected data. Data transfer is performed through an optimized interface that allows remote access and visualization of results.

title: Validity of an Automatic Approach for Acceleration Signal Segmentation during Weight Lifting
authors: Giuseppe Prisco, Maria Agnese Pirozzi, Fabrizio Esposito, Antonella Santone, Mario Cesarelli, Paolo Gargiulo, Francesco Amato, Leandro Donisi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The increasing adoption of wearable sensors in biomechanics has enhanced the acquisition and analysis of physiological signals, enabling continuous real-time monitoring in naturalistic settings. In this context, automatic segmentation methods have emerged as efficient alternatives to manual segmentation, helping to overcome limitations such as time consumption and subjective variability. This study assessed the validity of an automatic segmentation approach for acceleration signals recorded during load-lifting tasks, comparing it with manual segmentation. Four healthy female participants (aged 20 to 30) each performed 20 load-lifting tasks, conducted under safe conditions in accordance with the guidelines of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. An inertial sensor positioned on the lumbar region recorded acceleration data along the vertical axis. The automatic segmentation approach consisted of a subject-specific threshold algorithm, which used a 4th-order Butterworth filter and Savitzky-Golay smoothing to detect lifting events. For comparison, three time-domain features - rectified signal area, root mean square, and peak-to-peak amplitude - were extracted from both manual and automatic segmentations. Statistical analyses revealed strong agreement between manual and automatic segmentations for rectified signal area (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{p}=0.535$</tex>; bias <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.731$</tex>, CI: -2.689 to 1.226) and peak-to-peak amplitude <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{p}=\mathbf{0.371}$</tex>; <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\textbf{bias} =\textbf{0.003}$</tex>, CI: -0.002 to 0.008), with no observable trends or systematic errors. However, root mean square values exhibited a systematic constant error (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p} < \mathbf{0.001}$</tex>; bias CI: 0.003 to 0.007), with the automatic method consistently overestimating compared to manual segmentation. These findings underscore the potential of the proposed automatic segmentation method as a fast, accurate, and effective tool for signal analysis, although further refinements are needed to improve its generalizability.

title: Research and Application of Key Technologies for Centralized Energy Storage Power Station in Kaiyang County, Guizhou Province
authors: Xiang Zirui, Li Xinyi, Chen Siyu, Wang Yiqun, Song Xiaojing, Sun Hang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the rapid development of new energy, the demand for energy storage technology in the power system is growing. This paper introduces the 200MW/400MWh centralized energy storage power station project in Kaiyang County, Guizhou, which adopts modular energy storage technology, effectively improving the regulatory capacity of the power system and meeting the development of electricity demand. Through a detailed introduction and analysis of the project, this paper discusses the position and role of the energy storage power station in the power system, as well as its key technological innovation points and demonstrative promotion situation.

title: A Data-Driven Resting-State fMRI Study of Chronic Low Back Pain: Unraveling the Relationships Between Gender, Brain Connectivity, and the Noradrenergic System
authors: Federica Tomaiuolo, Francesco Cerritelli, Carlo Sestieri, Teresa Paolucci, Stefano L Sensi, Stefano Delli Pizzi, Antonio Ferretti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Chronic pain is a complex condition that affects millions of people worldwide, significantly impacting quality of life. Women tend to report more intense and persistent pain than men, but the neurophysiological mechanisms underlying this difference remain unclear. This study applied a data-driven method to assess gender-specific alterations in brain functional connectivity of patients with chronic low back pain, aiming to minimize operator-related biases. In addition, spatial correlation of connectivity changes and neurotransmitter maps derived from PET studies were investigated. Findings revealed that women exhibited enhanced connectivity in certain regions of the pain matrix, which correlated with pain clinical measures. Notably, these regions showed a significant spatial overlap with norepinephrine transporter expression areas.

title: Integration of Distributed Consensus Protocols for Scalable Sharded Blockchain Systems
authors: Shivangi, Bharati Sinha
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Sharding has gained prominence as an effective technique for improving the scalability of blockchain systems. While extensively explored in the context of public blockchains, its application alongside classical distributed consensus protocols in permissioned blockchain environments has received limited attention. This paper presents a shard-level integration of the Raft and Paxos consensus algorithms within a private blockchain architecture to support parallel transaction execution and improved fault tolerance. By allowing each shard to operate its own independent consensus process, the system mitigates bottlenecks associated with centralized consensus mechanisms. Experimental results under simulated conditions demonstrate that Raft achieves a peak throughput of 142,943 transactions per second (TPS), surpassing Paxos at 118,339 TPS, yielding a 20.8% improvement. Both protocols maintain low latency and minimal failover time, demonstrating their practicality for scalable shard-based deployments. The results provide valuable insights into the design of high-performance permissioned blockchains leveraging established consensus protocols.

title: AI-Driven Platform for Communication Coaching: Customized for Skill Enhancement and Professional Development
authors: Padira Anusha Chary, Patcha Kirthi, N Lohitha, Nekkanti Rama Subhash, Priyadarshini Chatterjee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Traditional communication training methods are often time-consuming, generic, and lack the personalised feedback necessary for effective skill development. Existing AI tools may offer real-time analysis, but they frequently provide limited, generalised insights, lack a non-judgmental approach, and often overlook security factors critical for sustained communication growth. This paper introduces an AI-powered communication coaching web application that delivers real-time, personalised feedback on key aspects such as pacing, tone, clarity, and filler words, with latency under one second. Leveraging technologies like NLP.js, the Web Speech API, and custom logic, the platform ensures fast and accurate speech analysis. Designed with a clean, responsive interface using React.js and TailwindCSS, it supports seamless use across mobile, tablet, and desktop devices. The system also provides tailored analytics reports and integrates smoothly into enterprise workflows, supporting goals such as interview readiness, public speaking, and ongoing professional development. Results demonstrate that this AI-driven approach surpasses traditional methods by offering scalable, accessible, and individualised communication training, driving measurable improvements across diverse user groups.

title: CEI: A Unified Interface for Cross-Embodiment Visuomotor Policy Learning in 3D Space
authors: Tong Wu, Shoujie Li, Junhao Gong, Changqing Guo, Xingting Li, Shilong Mu, Wenbo Ding
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Robotic foundation models trained on large-scale manipulation datasets have shown promise in learning generalist policies, but they often overfit to specific viewpoints, robot arms, and especially parallel-jaw grippers due to dataset biases. To address this limitation, we propose Cross-Embodiment Interface (CEI), a framework for cross-embodiment learning that enables the transfer of demonstrations across different robot arm and end-effector morphologies. CEI introduces the concept of functional similarity, which is quantified using Directional Chamfer Distance. Then it aligns robot trajectories through gradient-based optimization, followed by synthesizing observations and actions for unseen robot arms and end-effectors. In experiments, CEI transfers data and policies from a Franka Panda robot to 16 different embodiments across 3 tasks in simulation, and supports bidirectional transfer between a UR5+AG95 gripper robot and a UR5+Xhand robot across 6 real-world tasks, achieving an average transfer ratio of 82.4%. Finally, we demonstrate that CEI can also be extended with spatial generalization and multimodal motion generation capabilities using our proposed techniques. Project website: https://cross-embodiment-interface.github.io/.

title: Secure Genomic Data Collaboration: A Complete Framework against Contemporary Privacy Attacks
authors: Varun Sudheer, Sheeja Sudheer
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: This work focuses on the need for structured frameworks in sharing genomic data through ethical debates, attack methods and emerging solutions. Genomic datasets are sensitive and therefore issue of privacy is a concern because they are extensively applied in the current day medicine, research and consumer services. These databases can be attacked in a de- anonymization attack even without the identifiers attached since they can re-identify the person. Long-range familial searches reveal identities, which brings the question of consent as well as family implications and equity in genomic research. genomic beacons are query systems that can be attacked by allele inference attacks to alter the genotype of an individual. Observable characteristics can be traced to genomic records that can undermine its anonymization and re-identify researched people. The privacy issues involve surveying the systemic risks of sharing the genomic datasets and searching the research opportunities in case of safe cooperation. The problems associated with a synthetic dataset include keeping the accuracy but still provide perfect means of balancing between utility and privacy. All these issues can be addressed with the help of the multi key homomorphic encryption, which allows privacy preserving genomic calculations with the help of a state-of-the-art approach.

title: An Automated Detection Of Intracranial Aneurysms Using An Enhanced Deep Learning Architecture
authors: S. Sarumathi, A Muthukumar, S Sanjay, D. Tamizharasan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The study aimed to design a deep learning-based framework for the automatic detection and volumetric segmentation of intracranial aneurysms from three-dimensional medical imaging data. In this paper, an adapted 3D-U-Net architecture is applied to a multi-modal RSNA Intracranial Aneurysm Detection Challenge dataset comprising CTA, MRA, and MRI scans. The framework focuses on high accuracy in detecting aneurysms and minimizing false positives by using optimized preprocessing and adaptive learning techniques, along with refined post-processing. This system is able to provide sensitive and precise segmentation that clearly visualizes regions of aneurysms. The results demonstrate its potential to assist radiologists in early diagnosis and patient follow-up by offering reliable localization and consistent volume estimations of intracranial aneurysms. These results simplify complex neurovascular examinations and reduce the variability of manual interpretation. The framework further ensures stable performance for heterogeneous imaging conditions.

title: Prediction of Indoor Environmental Quality Parameters Using Attention-Based LSTM Models
authors: Jayabharathi M, Ruchi Juyal, Vaibhav Pratap Singh, Haribabu Pasupuleti, S D Sudarsan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Indian cities are experiencing high levels of air pollution and unfavourable weather conditions, making indoor living conditions challenging. To ensure a comfortable environment within buildings, it is necessary to have a precautionary mechanism to maintain residents' comfort and health. Indoor Environmental Quality (IEQ) mainly depends on indoor air pollution factors, such as the concentration of gases like CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, particulate pollutants (PM2.5, PM10), etc., as well as user comfort indicators like temperature, humidity, and lighting conditions inside the building. If the air quality factors and comfort indicators can be forecasted, it would allow for the prediction of future indoor conditions, enabling proactive measures. To contribute in this area, this paper proposes self-attention-based Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Hybrid Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)-LSTM models for predicting future values of CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, PM2.5, PM10, temperature, and humidity. In addition to forecasting, this paper also revisits the literature on the calculation of an IEQ index and discusses future plans towards managing sick building syndrome.

title: Low-Rank Adaptation of BERT for Indonesian Cognitive Distortion Detection
authors: Kuncahyo Setyo Nugroho, Ajie Kusuma Wardhana, Mahmud Isnan, Bens Pardamean
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Cognitive distortions are key indicators in identifying psychological disorders; however, their recognition in Indonesian text remains underexplored. This study evaluates the effectiveness of a Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) approach using Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) to fine-tune three Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) models: Multilingual-BERT, IndoNLU-IndoBERT, and IndoLEM-IndoBERT for cognitive distortion classification. The dataset consists of 4,992 Indonesian sentences annotated by psychology experts. To assess model robustness, experiments were conducted across various data proportions: 10%, 25%, 50%, and 100%. The results show that LoRA improves and stabilizes model performance, particularly under low-resource conditions. IndoLEM-IndoBERT achieved the best performance with an accuracy of 0.9657 and an F1-score of 0.9676 using 100% of the data. This study also evaluates inference efficiency through a trade-off analysis between F1-score and throughput, demonstrating that LoRA can maintain efficiency without compromising performance.

title: Generalization Error Analysis for Attack-Free and Byzantine-Resilient Decentralized Learning with Data Heterogeneity
authors: Haoxiang Ye, Tao Sun, Qing Ling
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing
abstract: Decentralized learning, which facilitates joint model training across geographically scattered agents, has gained significant attention in the field of signal and information processing in recent years. While the optimization errors of decentralized learning algorithms have been extensively studied, their generalization errors remain relatively under-explored. As the generalization error reflects the scalability of a trained model on unseen data and are crucial in determining the performance of a trained model in real-world applications, understanding the generalization error of decentralized learning is of paramount importance. In this paper, we present fine-grained generalization error analysis for both attack-free and Byzantine-resilient decentralized learning with heterogeneous data as well as under mild assumptions, in contrast to prior studies that consider homogeneous data and/or rely on a stringent bounded stochastic gradient assumption. Our results shed light on the impact of data heterogeneity, model initialization and stochastic gradient noise – factors that have not been closely investigated before – on the generalization error of decentralized learning. We also reveal that Byzantine attacks performed by malicious agents largely affect the generalization error, and their negative impact is inherently linked to the data heterogeneity while remaining independent on the sample size. Numerical experiments on both strongly convex and non-convex tasks are conducted to validate our theoretical findings.

title: Integrated Climate-Malaria Prediction Modeling for Disease Surveillance
authors: Natasya Afira, Yoga Cahya Putra, Fauzan Faldy Anggita, Lya Hulliyyatus Suadaa, Hammam Riza, Kaushik Sarkar, Hellen Dewi Prameswari, Ganesha Tri Chandrasa, Robi Muharsyah, Alberth Christian Nahas, Mamenun, Ardhasena Sopaheluwakan
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Malaria continues to pose a major public health burden in Indonesia, with transmission patterns varying widely across regions. Western provinces have made significant strides toward elimination, while persistent transmission remains in eastern zones, particularly Papua. Climatic variability is a key driver of malaria dynamics, yet its integration into routine surveillance and prediction systems remains limited. To address this gap, this study introduces framework that integrates malaria surveillance data (2019–2025) with climate observations (BMKG, Copernicus ERA5) and demographic data (BPS) to enhance early warning systems and prediction accuracy. Three models were developed to capture distinct malaria transmission dynamics: deep learning architecture (LSTM-GRU-Attention) for endemic zones in Central Papua, hurdle model for elimination zones in Lampung, and univariate time-series model for Mimika Regency as a high-burden hotspot. Results indicate that zone-specific approaches substantially improve predictive performance, with the elimination zone model achieving higher accuracy (SMAPE 19.05<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>) compared to the endemic zone model (SMAPE 172.21%). These findings highlight the importance of tailoring modeling strategies to transmission intensity and demonstrate how integrating climatic and epidemiological data can strengthen surveillance and accelerate progress toward malaria elimination in Indonesia.

title: Modeling, Analysis, and Simulation of Transient Problems in High-Speed Bipolar Dynamic Wireless Power Transfer System
authors: Chang Liu, Xin Gao, Shumei Cui, Chunbo Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: In the high-speed bipolar dynamic wireless power transfer (DWPT) system, the fast movement of the receiver (Rx) leads to the high-frequency mutual inductance fluctuation (MIF). This causes the violent Rx current oscillation, thereby resulting in elevated stresses and equipment damage. However, due to the complexity of modeling and experiment of the high-speed DWPT process, existing studies tend to focus on the low-speed quasi-static process. In order to analyze this transient problem, this article first proposes a Rx equivalent large-signal modeling method considering MIF for LCC-S compensation topology. In order to reduce the volume and cost of existing experiment platforms, a high-speed rotating experimental platform employing the MIF frequency equivalence principle is established. Furthermore, the mechanism of the Rx current oscillation is explained, the effects of different speeds and circuit parameters on the Rx current oscillation are analyzed by the model and platform, and the guidance on parameter design for high-speed DWPT systems is given. Finally, the above principles are verified by the experiment with an output power of 1.8 kW and a maximum speed of 120 km/h.

title: On Ambiguity in 6-DoF Electromagnetic Pose Estimation Systems
authors: Xinlei Zhang, Shuda Dong, Yifeng Zeng, Dekang Liu, Heng Wang
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: Magnetic pose estimation is an accurate, noncontacting pose tracking method that is insusceptible to occlusion, making it widely used for tracking intracorporeal medical robots and devices in minimally invasive interventions. However, the ambiguity problem in magnetic pose estimation has been long overlooked that could result in inaccuracy and even divergence of pose tracking. This article is devoted to fundamentally investigating the ambiguity issue in 6-DoF electromagnetic pose estimation systems. Magnetic ambiguity is formally defined, and its existence and impacts on pose estimation are analyzed for single-magnet and dual-magnet tracking systems, then generalized to multiple-magnet systems. It is found that there are different types of ambiguity, each with distinct influence on pose estimation. Efficient algorithms are proposed to systematically identify all ambiguous poses in a workspace. The ambiguity in typical configurations of dual-magnet systems is identified and discussed. It is found that ambiguity can be completely eliminated by using at least THREE magnetic sources. An unambiguous tri-magnet system is proposed by combining the collocated and parallel dual-magnet systems and validated by tracking a continuum robot. This article lays the foundation for optimizing configurations of magnetic sources and designing compact, energy-efficient, but unambiguous magnetic tracking systems with minimum number of magnetic sources.

title: Migration Dynamics of Cellulose Particles in Oil-Paper Insulation Under DC Voltage: Experiments and Simulations
authors: Chen Chen, Lijun Yang, Ruijin Liao, Xueqin Yang, Zhengyu Chen, Xiang Wang, Xinxi Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: The aggregation of impurity particles is one of the main factors contributing to the degradation of transformer oil insulation performance. Investigating the migration dynamics of impurity particles in transformer oil is highly important for guiding daily maintenance and ensuring the safe operation of transformers. This study focuses on the motion and aggregation behavior of cellulose particles in transformer oil under DC voltage, establishes a simulation model for the migration dynamics of cellulose particles in oil-paper insulation, and the aggregation properties of cellulose particles under different insulation structures are computed. An experimental observation platform is constructed to monitor the aggregation behavior of cellulose particles in oil under various contamination levels, which verifies the effectiveness of the proposed migration dynamics model. The results show that, under the action of dielectrophoretic force, cellulose particles aggregate in high electric field intensity regions to form high-concentration aggregates, and such aggregation occurs even when insulation barriers are introduced between electrodes. The aggregation behavior leads to a significant distortion of the electric field in the oil gap, with the local field strength increasing by more than 30% compared with that of the unaggregated state. These findings enhance the understanding of cellulose particle aggregation under DC voltage and offer new theoretical support for interpreting sudden discharge failures in transformers.

title: Enhancing Remote Direct Memory Access Network with Loss-Tolerant Flow Control for Distributed AI Clusters
authors: Yibo Wang, Wei Wang, Qiaojun Hu, Yiyang Li, Yanran Xiao, Yongli Zhao, Xiaoyu Wang, Jie Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Current AI training clusters widely utilize RoCEv2 to enhance the communication efficiency of interconnect networks across machines. RoCEv2 relies on priority flow control (PFC) to ensure a lossless network. However, PFC brings specific side effects, such as head-of-line blocking, congestion spreading, and deadlock. Numerous studies have been proposed to eliminate the side effects. Unlike traditional high-performance computing applications, distributed machine learning (DML) is bounded-loss tolerant. In light of this observation, this paper proposes a loss-tolerant flow control (LTFC). LTFC does not rely on PFC to ensure a lossless environment, but to control the packet loss ratio within the tolerance threshold. Compared to the traditional trigger condition, LTFC reduces the likelihood that the PFC will be triggered. Additionally, we replace RoCEv2's default Go-back-N mechanism with a non-retransmission mechanism to eliminate retransmission delay. Further, we adapt LTFC to high network load scenarios through loss-aware buffer management. We demonstrate the bounded-loss tolerance feature of DML on our testbed and evaluate the performance of LTFC in simulations. Simulation results show that LTFC reduces the average flow completion time (FCT) slowdown by up to 27.2% and tail FCT slowdown by up to 23.8%.

title: Bi-Directional Motion Enhanced Semantic Communication for Wireless Video Transmission
authors: Zhenguo Zhang, Qianqian Yang, Shibo He, Zhiguo Shi
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: With the increasing proliferation of Ultra-High-Definition (UHD) videos, the demand for efficient video transmission schemes to alleviate network congestion is growing. In this paper, we propose a bi-directional motion enhanced semantic communication (SemCom) system for efficient and robust video transmission. In particular, we introduce a bi-directional motion estimation module to capture inter-frame differences caused by camera movements, where the obtained forward and backward motion vectors are combined with the residual information to generate motion-compensated frames. We also introduce a predicted feature module to discard semantically redundant features, prioritizing crucial semantic-related content. Leveraging information from previously reconstructed frames, the frame prediction module refines predicted frames with the assistance of the motion compensation module. To enhance the system’s robustness to channel noise, we propose a noise attention module that assigns varying importance weights to the extracted features under different channel conditions. Experimental results show that our proposed method outperforms existing deep learning (DL)-based approaches in terms of transmission efficiency, achieving about 33.3% reduction in the number of transmitted symbols while improving the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) and multi-scale structural similarity index measure (MS-SSIM) performance by an average of 0.56 dB and 0.0024 over an additive white Gaussian noise channel for different schemes. When employing the same compression ratio, our method achieves an average gain of 0.637 dB in PSNR and 0.0038 in MS-SSIM over the slow Rayleigh fading channel.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Based Proactive Diagnosis of PCOS and PCOD through Clinical and Hormonal Measures
authors: Mercy Paul Selvan, S. Sahana, Y Sai Lekhana, S D Kalaivani, E. Priyadarshini, Kalyaniswari Parida
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome and Polycystic Ovary Disorder are common female hormonal disorder which cause irregular period, infertility, obesity, and other metabolic problems. Hence, the management of these disorders and early prediction is of great importance. The current project implies the use of data- driven methodology to identify and forecast PCOS/PCOD using machine learning algorithms, including Logistic Regression and Random Forest. The data set includes the varied scope of clinical and lifestyle characteristics, such as Age, BMI, Pulse rate, Cycle length, FSH, LH, AMH, PRL, and TSH levels and ultrasound measurements. In this project, various preprocessing practices are performed, and the main attention is paid to data normalization, categorical attributes encoding, and missing values. In the given project, models are trained and evaluated in terms of such performance measures as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1- score. Random Forest was found to be better than another model as it produced the highest accuracy. Thus, one can possibly indicate that this model is the most dependable and could be used to deal with nonlinear interactions between features. In addition, the model does not only categorize whether a particular individual is a PCOS or PCOD patient but also identifies the most potent attributes, which result in the occurrence of the disorder. As such, it is an effective decision support system that can be used to assist clinicians in making appropriate decisions.

title: Cognitive Load in Web Interface Design: A Study Based on Visual Complexity and Task Difficulty
authors: Qian Liao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: This study examines the interplay between visual complexity and task difficulty on cognitive load in web interface design, a pivotal element in human-computer interaction that affects user efficiency, satisfaction, and performance. Grounded in cognitive load theory, we posit that elevated visual complexity and task difficulty will heighten cognitive load, potentially leading to reduced usability. Employing simulated data from 225 participants across three levels of visual complexity (low, medium, high) and task difficulty (simple, medium, complex), we assessed metrics including reaction time, cognitive load scores, error rates, and NASA-TLX subscales. Two-way ANOVA results indicate significant main effects for complexity and difficulty on reaction time <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\mathrm{F}(2,216)=68.86, \mathrm{p} 0.001; \mathrm{F}(2,216)=36.39, \mathrm{p}_{\mathrm{i}} 0.001\right)$</tex> and cognitive load <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(F(2,216)=115.03, p_{i} 0.001; F(2,216)=67.96, p_{i} 0.001\right)$</tex>, without significant interaction. A moderate correlation exists between reaction time and cognitive load (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r=0.55, p_{i} 0.001$</tex>). To further explore relationships, path analysis via OLS regressions was conducted, revealing direct effects of complexity and difficulty on reaction time without mediation through cognitive load. Visual aids such as heatmaps and distributions highlight trends, with peak loads in high-complexity, complex-task conditions. Implications include design strategies to reduce extraneous load via simplified interfaces, advancing HCI practices for enhanced user experiences in digital environments. This work offers empirical insights for optimizing web interfaces amid growing information demands.

title: Fast Spectral Thermal Simulation for Wire Laser Additive Manufacturing
authors: Mohamed Rochdi Hentati, Sana Koubaa, Moncef Hammadi, Zoubeir Bouaziz
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Low-latency prediction of thermal fields is essential for in-process monitoring, path planning, and defect prevention in Wire Laser Additive Manufacturing (WLAM). In this work, a fast physics-based spectral methodology for temperature monitoring and prediction in WLAM is presented. The transient heat equation with temperature-dependent properties is solved by a pseudo-spectral Fourier scheme in space and a firstorder Exponential Time Differencing (FFT-ETD1) update in time, which analytically integrates the linear diffusion in the spectral domain while the nonlinear residual (moving heat input and surface exchanges) is treated explicitly. The heat input is represented by a double-ellipsoidal (Goldak) volumetric source with energy normalization to conserve absorbed power. Boundary losses are applied with a thin-layer sink combining convectionradiation at the free surfaces and convection at the base. For process monitoring, a thermocouple (TC) and the global maximum temperature are streamed at each time step and are used in a lightweight calibration loop (Differential Evolution followed by L-BFGS-B) to align the model with in-situ data. On a representative single pass, TC and peak-temperature histories are reproduced with about $6 \%$ normalized error, indicating suitability for parameter studies and supervisory monitoring in wire-laser deposition.

title: Saturated Feedback Control for Synchronization Tracking Control Between Steering Wheel and Road Wheels in Steer-By-Wire Systems
authors: Huyen T. Dinh
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In this study, a saturated controller was built for steer-by-wire applications, that includes time-varying dynamic uncertainties and bounded external disturbances. By designing as a smooth saturation function, the proposed controller is developed as a robust, continuous, and magnitude-limited control torque to guarantee the road-wheel asymptotically tracking to the driver input reference angle. The Lyapunov stability analysis methodology corresponding to the robust integral of the sign of the error (RISE) control method is exploited to theoretically prove the asymptotically tracking result, despite unknown uncertainties, tire self-aligning torque, and exogenous disturbances. The control input bounds are preceding determinedly known and can be adjusted by selecting the feedback gains. Several MATLAB simulations for SBW system are accomplished to illustrate the superior tracking capability demonstrated by the proposed control method under different steering scenarios, several road surface conditions and at different vehicle velocities in comparison with two other controllers.

title: Anew Paradigm of AI Development Driven by Low-Code
authors: Wenxuan Song
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: In the big data era, to solve algorithm engineers' problems of complex data analysis and low development efficiency, “low-code” platforms emerged. The Intelligent Simplification and Innovation AI Platform in this paper is a low-code-based AI algorithm platform. It builds applications via graphical interfaces. Technologically, it uses low-code to free developers, applies machine and deep learning, offers one-stop services, helps build custom models, and promotes data science-IT O&M collaboration. Functionally, it integrates multiple functions, eases communication, supports the whole development process, and meets diverse needs. It's also easy-to-use, fast-developing, zero-co de-friendly, and has pre-built modules. It suits various AI learning scenarios, supports automated modeling and drag-and-drop task flows, benefits both pros and beginners, has great enterprise application advantages, and follows the low-code development trend.

title: CFE-Based Tunable α-Order Multifunction Filter Realized Using DDTA
authors: Hemlata Gururani, Dharmendra Kumar Upadhyay
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: A Differential Difference Transconductance Amplifier (DDTA) based fractional-order tunable multifunction filter circuit using continued fraction expansion (CFE) is employed in the proposed design. The filter structure utilizes two Differential Difference Transconductance Amplifiers (DDTAs) and a single grounded fractional capacitor, leading to a versatile filter design with four inputs and a single output that supports low, high, and all-pass filter responses at fractional orders in inverting as well as in non-inverting modes in a single topology. The proposed configuration allows for electronic tunability, with the filter characteristics being adjustable by modifying the biasing current (I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">b</inf>) and the fractional order (α). The CFE approximation is used to get the rational function for the fractional-order Laplacian operator, which is realized by Foster-I and Foster-II topologies using MATLAB. Furthermore, the circuit's performance is validated using LT SPICE software using a 180-nm CMOS technology.

title: Secure and Reversible Data Hiding in Digital Images Using DES Encryption
authors: R. Tamilrasu, S. Dhanush, M. Elakkiya, J. Harin, Josfer Dsouza
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: With the rapid advancements in multimedia technologies, the need for security of digital data is becoming more and more essential. Choose the best encryption technique for each data type, and basic encryption techniques will probably not hold in a data violation. The composition is given another meaning that can be easily undone. title: A Sparse Bayesian Learning-Based Approach With Indian Buffet Process Prior for Joint Wideband DOA and Frequency Band Estimation
authors: Tao Tang, Chengzhu Yang, Shefeng Yan, Lijun Xu, Desheng Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Sparse Bayesian learning (SBL)-based methods for wideband direction of arrival (DOA) estimation have shown impressive performance in terms of high-resolution. It generally assumes that all signals share the same frequency band, resulting in performance degradation when signals occupy different frequency bands. To deal with this problem, we propose a wideband DOA estimation method utilizing the Indian Buffet Process (IBP) prior, namely IBP-SBL, to explore the frequency band correlation structure of target signals and hence their DOAs. Specifically, IBP-SBL regards the spatial spectrum as the combination of multiple latent features to be estimated, and infers the occupied frequency band of each signal by exploring the activation of the latent features at each frequency point. Subsequently, the DOA refinement procedure based on maximum likelihood (ML) is applied to reduce the quantization error caused by grid mismatch problem. Compared to the previous methods, the proposed algorithm can associate each sub-band with the relevant signals even in scenarios with severe overlap of signal frequency bands, thereby realizing more accurate DOA estimation by using the estimated frequency band related to each signal. Numerical simulation results of 500 Monte Carlo experiments show that our method achieves lower DOA estimation error and convergence time. In real-world data experiments, our method also exhibits superior DOA estimation accuracy and clearer target trajectory.

title: Orbit Aware-Based Satellite Selection Method for Reducing Handover Frequency in LEO Satellite Networks
authors: Keita Kashiwagi, Kazuya Tsukamoto
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite networks, represented by Starlink, have rapidly advanced as communication solutions for unconnected regions and during disaster scenarios. However, related studies have reported that communication via Starlink experiences significant performance degradation due to link quality fluctuations caused by frequent handovers. Moreover, since Starlink employs a proprietary communication system, existing research has mainly focused on end-to-end performance evaluation, while its internal route selection mechanisms remain undisclosed. To address this, we simulate both current and future Starlink environments using the ns-3 LEO module and evaluate the impact of satellite selection methods on communication performance in LEO satellite networks. This study proposes a satellite selection method that predicts the satellite trajectory based on the variation in RTT, enabling the selection of satellites capable of providing longer communication durations. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified using two key performance metrics: communication duration per satellite and route establishment success rate, which have been challenges in previous studies. As a result, the proposed method demonstrated up to 98.4% of the theoretical maximum performance, achieving both stable route establishment and extended communication duration.

title: A novel wireless-wired hybrid ergodic sequential logic central pattern generator: efficient FPGA implementation and multi-channel FES application
authors: Rikuto Nozu, Hiroyuki Torikai
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In this study, a novel wireless-wired hybrid central pattern generator (CPG) is presented based on the concept of ergodic sequential logic. Detailed analyses reveal that the CPG is able to generate stimulation signals suitable for supporting typical human motion. The CPG is implemented using field programmable gate arrays connected via on-off keying radio transmitters and receivers. Experimental results demonstrate that the presented CPG can effectively assist human motion. Moreover, the presented CPG is demonstrated to use fewer circuit components and to have lower power consumption compared to a commonly-used conventional digital-processor-based CPG. The potential impact of this study is also discussed.

title: LLM-Driven Automated Penetration Testing: Architectures, Benchmarks, and Safety Considerations
authors: Akshitha Segireddy
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: In recent years, there has been a growing trend toward using large language models (LLMs) to automate penetration testing tasks, including reconnaissance, vulnerability discovery, exploit identification, and reporting. Previous works, including PentestGPT, Curriculum PT, RapidPen, White Rabbit Neo- PentestGPT, and HackSynth, have shown that LLM guided workflows can be superior to naive prompting and traditional scripting-based approaches on both capture the flag (CTF) challenges and realistic lab environments, and have attracted significant community interest and public benchmarking. Nevertheless, the complete automation of penetration testing remains an unsolved problem: current tools continue to fail to address issues related to managing context, orchestrating tools, handling environmental variations, and enforcing safety constraints. In this paper, we introduce a unified LLM-driven automated Penetration Testing Framework that divides the workflow of penetration testing into formally defined tasks, states, and actions, utilizing LLM-based agents to develop, execute, and modify multi-step attack chains across multiple layers of networks, web, cloud, and application environments. We detail how to integrate external tools (scanners, exploit frameworks, and knowledge bases) into the framework, design a memory and reasoning layer to prevent the loss of context, and define safety and governance controls to limit the misuse of the system. We conduct experiments using synthetic labs, standardized CTFstyle benchmarks, and real-world-inspired scenarios, and compare our results against those obtained from human testers, scripted pipelines, and previous LLM-based systems. Our results indicate significant improvements in task completion, coverage, and time-to-compromise, while also identifying failure modes and informing future research directions. The purpose of this paper is to provide a reference architecture and experimental guide for next-generation, LLM-driven penetration testing.

title: Fluid Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface with Element-Level Pattern Reconfigurability: Beamforming and Pattern Co-Design
authors: Han Xiao, Xiaoyan Hu, Kai-Kit Wong, Xusheng Zhu, Hanjiang Hong, Chan-Byoung Chae
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: This paper proposes a novel pattern-reconfigurable fluid reconfigurable intelligent surface (FRIS) framework, where each fluid element can dynamically adjust its radiation pattern based on instantaneous channel conditions. To evaluate its potential, we first conduct a comparative analysis of the received signal power in point-to-point communication systems assisted by three types of surfaces: (1) the proposed pattern-reconfigurable FRIS, (2) a position-reconfigurable FRIS, and (3) a conventional RIS. Theoretical results demonstrate that the pattern-reconfigurable FRIS provides a significant advantage in modulating transmission signals compared to the other two configurations. To further study its capabilities, we extend the framework to a multiuser communication scenario. In this context, the spherical harmonics orthogonal decomposition (SHOD) method is employed to accurately model the radiation patterns of individual fluid elements, making the pattern design process more tractable. An optimization problem is then formulated with the objective of maximizing the weighted sum rate among users by jointly designing the active beamforming vectors and the spherical harmonics coefficients, subject to both transmit power and pattern energy constraints. To tackle the resulting non-convex optimization problem, we propose an iterative algorithm that alternates between a minimum mean-square error (MMSE) approach for active beamforming and a Riemannian conjugate gradient (RCG) method for updating the spherical harmonics coefficients. Simulation results show that the proposed pattern-reconfigurable FRIS significantly outperforms traditional RIS architectures based on the 3GPP 38.901 and isotropic radiation models, achieving average performance gains of 161.5% and 176.2%, respectively. Additionally, it reduces the required number of antennas and RIS elements by over 300%, offering substantial improvements in hardware efficiency.

title: A Near-Field Extension of the 3GPP Geometry-Based Stochastic Channel Model for Sub-THz Communications
authors: Shrayan Das, Peize Zhang, Pekka Kyösti
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: Many conventional radio channel models, such as 3GPP TR 38.901, assume far-field conditions and rely on the plane wave approximation. However, as antenna arrays grow in size and link distances decrease, near-field propagation effects become significant, particularly at sub-THz frequencies. This letter proposes an initial extension to the 3GPP channel model to incorporate near-field characteristics at these frequencies. The approach models both line-of-sight and non-line-of-sight paths using exact geometric distances. An image-theory-based method is introduced to model specular reflections. The extended model maintains consistency with the existing 3GPP framework while enhancing modeling accuracy in the near-field.

title: Tongue-Yoga: Precision Visual Feedback Rehabilitation Improves Tongue Agility
authors: Andrea Scarpellini, Lorenzo Di Silverio, Anna Carroll, Leora R. Cherney, Edna M. Babbitt, James L. Patton, Hananeh Esmailbeigi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: The tongue is a uniquely agile muscular structure essential for vital tasks of speech, breathing, chewing, and swallowing, functions commonly disrupted following neurological injury. Yet, current rehabilitation approaches lack objective measures and techniques to characterize impairment and restore the tongue’s ability. Here, we introduce a clinic-friendly method that isolates and quantifies tongue agility, defined as the ability to execute rapid and precise movements, using a wireless intraoral sensing device that provides real-time visual feedback of movement. Six participants diagnosed with dysarthria completed seven one-hour intervention sessions. Tongue movement probability distributions were generated to identify individualized deviations from neurotypical patterns. An individualized visual feedback intervention was designed to redirect movement away from over-expressed regions toward under-expressed deficient areas. Across the intervention, sensing area coverage increased significantly by 10.29 %, while over-expressed areas decreased significantly by 3.99 %, and movement velocity improved significantly by 3.85 %. This pilot study provides promising preliminary evidence that precision visual feedback rehabilitation can reshape tongue movement patterns and enhance tongue agility in individuals with oral motor disorders.

title: Bridging Urban Data and Sustainability: LightGBM for Predicting Environmental and Infrastructure Risks
authors: Maya Dawood, Makram Hatoum, Bilal Komati, Ali Attar, Ahmad Mikati, Mohammed El-Hajj
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Urban analytics addresses multifaceted challenges of urbanization through data-driven solutions. This study bridges the gap in applying advanced machine learning models like LightGBM to urban challenges in resource-constrained settings. Using real-world datasets on air quality, traffic congestion, and energy demand, we trained a LightGBM model achieving high accuracy (RMSE: 3.25, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>: 0.88, F1: 0.92), outperforming benchmarks. Key findings reveal the model's ability to predict PM2.5 levels, identify pollution hotspots, and forecast peak energy demands, enabling proactive resource allocation. Feature importance analysis highlighted population density and PM2.5 levels as dominant predictors of traffic congestion. Results underscore machine learning's potential to enhance urban sustainability by reducing energy waste, alleviating traffic bottlenecks, and improving disaster preparedness. Ethical challenges-data privacy, algorithmic bias, and computational constraints-are discussed alongside policy implications.

title: Learning an Autonomous Dynamic System to Encode Complex Periodic Human Motion Skills_supp1-3656796.mp4
authors: Andong Liu
publish: N/A
abstract: Autonomous dynamic systems (ADS)-based encoding of human motion skills has been widely demonstrated to exhibit high transfer efficiency in goal-directed tasks; however, significant gaps remain in the study of skill transfer for periodic motions, particularly complex periodic motions. In this letter, we propose a novel method for directly learning complex periodic movements using Lyapunov functions (LF), which is fundamentally different from all existing methods that learn periodic movements through limit cycle mapping. First, we introduce a polar coordinate transformation to decouple trajectory and angle modulation, enabling the radially increasing Lyapunov energy function to acquire non-radial expansion capabilities. Then, based on this, we learn a data-driven Lyapunov energy function by solving a dual objective optimization problem that combines geometric alignment and orbit parallelism constraints, aligning one of its horizontal surfaces with a periodic human demonstration trajectory. Finally, ADS is learned by sequentially solving LF-related constrained optimization problems. By designing appropriate constraint functions, we can ensure that the trajectories generated by ADS converge to an LF-level surface whose shape resembles that of periodic human demonstration trajectories. Both simulations and real robot experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Quantum LSTM Guided Sampling for Efficient Configuration Interaction in Solving the SchröDinger Equation
authors: Jorge I. Hernandez-Martinez, Sandra Leticia Juárez-Osorio, Andres Mendez-Vazquez, Gerardo Rodriguez-Hernandez, Eduardo Rodriguez-Tello
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: We present a novel quantum generative framework based on Quantum Long Short-Term Memory (QLSTM) networks to optimize the sampling of Slater determinants in Full Configuration Interaction (FCI), a key method in quantum chemistry for solving the Schrödinger equation. Our model employs variational quantum circuits to learn an approximate distribution over the configuration space, guiding the generation of new, physically meaningful determinants. This distribution reflects the correlations among significant electronic configurations, allowing for a guided exploration of the determinant space and accelerating convergence toward reference energies. By framing determinant selection as a generative modeling task, our approach contributes to the emerging field of quantum generative AI applied to many-body systems. Implemented using Pennylane and accelerated with JAX, the QLSTM model converges faster than both classical LSTM and random baselines. Notably, it exhibits stable and consistent convergence across different hyperparameter settings, suggesting that the model captures an underlying physical structure rather than overfitting to specific training conditions. Our results demonstrate the scalability and physical consistency of hybrid quantum-classical generative models for quantum chemistry tasks.
