title: Coordinated and Optimised Operation of Integrated Energy Systems for Photovoltaic Storage and Charging
authors: Xiaoxue Huang, Zuocang Zhang, Shujun Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Aiming at the problem of energy fluctuation caused by fast access to the grid by microgrids, this paper investigates how to integrate wind power with adjustable electric vehicles and flexible load resources to optimize the peak-to-valley difference of the load profile and optimal scheduling of microgrids. Firstly, this paper establishes a “source-grid-load-storage” microgrid topology for electric vehicles that takes into account the demand-side wind power; secondly, a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) model is constructed to solve the problem; Then, an example is developed based on the predicted wind power; Thirdly, based on the predicted wind power data and load forecast data, and under the condition of satisfying the model constraints, and with the objective of the lowest generation cost, the example is solved by matlab simulation and cplex solver to obtain the 24-hour power output of each unit in a certain park. And the comparison of the storage power and load curves before and after the participation of trams in the grid scheduling proves the correctness of the model and the methodology.

title: IoT and AI-Driven Adaptive Traffic Signal Control Using Deep Reinforcement Learning and Graph Neural Networks
authors: R Sumathy, A Rinu Rija
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The urban transportation system suffers from severe congestion due to rapid growth in vehicle density, limited road infrastructure, and inefficient traffic signal control. Fixed-time and actuated controllers fail to adapt with the dynamics of varying traffic conditions, which eventually results in lengthy delays, higher consumption of fuel, and increased emissions. This work proposes an IoT and AI-driven adaptive traffic signal control framework by incorporating DRL and GNN methodologies for real-time optimization. The continuous V2I communication facilitated by IoT-enabled RSUs and OBUs provides real-time live data related to queue length, vehicle density, and waiting time. The DRL agent incorporates several algorithms, namely, $\mathrm{DQN}, \mathrm{PPO}$, and A3C, to calculate the optimal phase duration. Further, GNNs model the spatial dependencies among intersections for enabling coordinated network-level control. The concept of edge computing has also been exploited to reduce latency and increase scalability. Experimental validation has been done in the SUMO environment, where performance metrics like average delay, queue length, and emission level have been analyzed. The proposed IoT-AI-GNN hybrid ensures improved traffic flow, reduced waiting time, and enhanced environmental sustainability, thus proving its viability for smart city applications.

title: Multi-Band Antenna with Defective Ground Structure for IoT Communication and Energy Harvesting
authors: S. Sharon Sweeti, J. Jayasudha, N. Ramya, K. Sathana
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The design and analysis of a small multiband patch antenna in microstrip that uses a Defective Ground Structure (DGS) to facilitate IoT communication and RF energy harvesting is presented in this paper. It is an antenna that is based on FR-4 substrate and is optimized to resonate at more than one frequency $(2.4 \mathrm{GHz}, 5.2 \mathrm{GHz})$ to be compatible with common wireless standards (ISM, WLAN) and at the same time to reuse the $\mathbf{R F}$ energy in the environment. The squareshaped DGS etched on the ground plane increases the impedance bandwidth and forms other resonant modes that allow efficient multi-band operation without expanding the antenna size by a significant percentage. CSST Studio Suite 2024 simulation studies have verified that the antenna has a return loss no more than -10 dB and a VSWR of less than 2 at all target bands, and optimizes to an antenna gain of approximately 8.1 dBi at 2.4 GHz and 4.4 dBi at 5.2 GHz. The radiation patterns are constant and directional throughout the bands and the radiation and overall efficiencies of the antenna are more than 80%. The suggested design, therefore, provides a high-performance and energy-saving design as a next- generation IoT node by eliminating reliance on the battery and utilizing ambient RF energy. The paper presents the design procedure of the antenna, the comparison of the antenna performance with the current multiband DGS- based antennas, and the applicability of the antenna to sustainable IoT and wireless sensor application. 8.2

title: Efficient Revocable Conditional Anonymous Authentication with Verifiable Self-Generated Pseudonyms for VANETs
authors: Shuqin Luo, Xuelin Cao, Xinghua Li, Zhe Ren, Yunwei Wang, Yinbin Miao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Pseudonym self-generation (PSG) is essential for Conditional Anonymous Authentication (CAA) in Vehicular Adhoc Networks (VANETs), enabling vehicles to autonomously create communication identities without centralized control. However, existing self-generation schemes face two problems: efficiently revoking malicious vehicles remains difficult, and hardware-independent solutions additionally struggle to verify the legitimacy of pseudonyms. To overcome these issues, we propose an efficient Revocable CAA scheme with Verifiable Self-generated Pseudonyms for VANETs (RCAAVSP). First, a Traceable Chameleon Hash (TCH) function is designed to implicit membership through TCH collision, enforcing verifiable and unlinkable pseudonym generation. And then a multi-parameter authentication mechanism leveraging dynamic accumulators, which achieves O(1)-complexity revocation via domain membership polynomial updates without system-wide reconfiguration. Formal security analysis demonstrates the semantic security of our proposed scheme under the random oracle model, with proven resilience against common attacks. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that RCAAVSP achieves a 76% relative improvement in pseudonym generation efficiency, while maintaining the overhead of anonymous authentication and malicious vehicle revocation at ms-level, providing a lightweight solution for secure VANET communication.

title: gpuPairHMM: High-Speed Pair-HMM Forward Algorithm for DNA Variant Calling on GPUs
authors: Bertil Schmidt, Felix Kallenborn, Alexander Wichmann, Alejandro Chacon, Christian Hundt
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: The continually increasing volume of DNA sequence data has resulted in a growing demand for fast implementations of core algorithms. Computation of pairwise alignments between candidate haplotypes and sequencing reads using Pair-HMMs is a key component in DNA variant calling tools such as the GATK HaplotypeCaller but can be highly time consuming due to its quadratic time complexity and the large number of pairs to be aligned. Unfortunately, previous approaches to accelerate this task using the massively parallel processing capabilities of modern GPUs are limited by inefficient memory access schemes. This established the need for significantly faster solutions. We address this need by presenting gpuPairHMM – a novel GPU-based parallelization scheme for the dynamic-programming based Pair-HMM forward algorithm based on wavefronts and warp-shuffles. It gains efficiency by minimizing both memory accesses and instructions. We show that our approach achieves close-to-peak performance on several generations of modern CUDA-enabled GPUs (Volta, Ampere, Ada, Hopper, Blackwell). It also outperforms prior implementations on GPUs, CPUs, and FPGAs by a factor of at least 11.7, 14.2, and 19.8, respectively. gpuPairHMM is publicly available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/asbschmidt/gpuPairHMM</uri>.

title: Enhancing Medical Chatbots with RAG-Based Retrieval on Fine-Tuned DeepSeek Models
authors: MD. Harshida, O. Bhaskaru, Khushi Kumari, N. Ahalya
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The increasing burden on healthcare systems due to rising patient demands, overworked medical staff, and resource limitations has highlighted the need for efficient AI-driven solutions. Health care chatbots have emerged as a promising tool to bridge the gap between patients and healthcare providers by offering instant access to medical information. These chatbots, powered by Natural Language Processing and Large Language Models, can assist in symptom assessment, condition prediction, and guiding patients toward appropriate care, thereby alleviating the workload on medical professionals. This study presents a hybrid AI model that integrates DeepSeek R1 fine-tuning with a Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) system powered by MiniLLM. Unlike conventional transformer-based models, our approach leverages fine-tuned DeepSeek R1 for contextual medical understanding while utilizing MiniLLM as a lightweight retrieval engine trained on medical literature. This hybrid frame-work ensures real-time access to updated medical knowledge, improves response accuracy, and reduces hallucinations. The integration of RAG enhances the chatbot's ability to reference authoritative medical sources, making interactions more reliable and informative. With the increasing global demand for accessible and accurate healthcare information, this hybrid chatbot model offers an effective, scalable, and patient-friendly AI-driven solution, capable of providing timely and well-informed medical guidance in both resource-rich and resource-limited settings. By leveraging these technologies, we successfully enhanced the accuracy (95.22%) and efficiency of medical query processing. The chatbot retrieves relevant information through optimized embeddings and generates context-aware, well-structured, and user-friendly responses, achieving a BLEU score of (97.07%).

title: PrivCervBoost: Privacy-Enhanced Federated Gradient Boosting for Cervical Cancer Risk Prediction
authors: N Meenakshisundaram, Sajiv G
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Early detection of cervical cancer is a critical global health objective, especially in resource-limited and privacy-sensitive clinical settings. Traditional machine learning approaches rely on centralized data collection, raising significant privacy concerns and regulatory challenges. To address these issues, we introduce PrivCervBoost, a federated gradient boosting framework that enables cervical cancer risk prediction without transferring sensitive patient data. Built on Federated XGBoost and secured through privacy-preserving aggregation protocols, PrivCervBoost ensures both high predictive accuracy and data confidentiality. The model is evaluated using the Cervical Cancer Behavior Risk dataset within a simulated cross-institutional federated environment, reflecting realistic healthcare deployment. Experimental results show that PrivCervBoost performs on par with centralized models, while minimizing data exposure risk. Furthermore, SHAP-based explainability is integrated to provide transparent insights into the decision-making process, thereby enhancing its clinical interpretability. Overall, PrivCervBoost demonstrates strong potential as a secure, collaborative solution for scalable cervical cancer screening.

title: Design and Development of Efficient and Secure Boolean Keyword Searchable Encryption for Cloud Data Repositories
authors: Sowmya S, Shrihari M R, Ajay N, Murthy S V N, Manjunath T N
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The rapid adoption of cloud services for data storage and processing has heightened the need for robust security measures, particularly for sensitive information stored in cloud data warehouses. In this context, ensuring data confidentiality while enabling efficient data access poses a significant challenge. Boolean Keyword Searchable Encryption (BKSE) emerges as a promising approach to address this issue, offering a balance between strong data protection and operational utility. This project delves into the critical aspects of secure and efficient BKSE tailored for cloud data warehouses. Our study introduces a novel BKSE scheme designed to ensure three key objectives: data privacy, search result integrity, and high query performance. By employing advanced cryptographic methodologies and optimized algorithms for keyword search, our approach achieves secure and verifiable query operations without compromising efficiency.

title: Streamlining Epidemiological Model Generation Using Large Language Models
authors: Aaditya Karamchandani, Fatemeh Seyeddabbaghi, Marios Fokaefs
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Epidemiological modeling is a critical step in understanding and studying diseases. While conventional modeling techniques, like compartmental or agentic models, exist, supporting tools are not necessarily standardized. Consequently, learning a new tool may incur significant effort. In this work, we explore the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) as a means to quickly transition from requirements, in the form of graphical model representations and initial parameters to a software-aided modeling platform with simulation and verification capabilities. Our methodology employs a metamodel-based language specification for prompt engineering, combined with multimodal inputs comprising textual descriptions and epidemiological diagrams. We evaluate LLM performance across three epidemiological models of varying complexity: a simple SIR compartmental model, a COVID-19 pandemic model, and an HIV transmission model. Initial results demonstrate the potential of LLMs to significantly reduce manual modeling effort while maintaining accuracy in structural representation and parameter extraction. The study provides insights into optimal input configurations and identifies key challenges in automated epidemiological model generation.

title: An Enhanced Approach for Crop Prediction Using CNN-Based Soil Feature Extraction
authors: Rachna Krishnaji Somkunwar, Roshani Parate, Sarika Sawarkar, Varda Gotmare, Abhijit Dnyaneshwar Jadhav, Yash Sudhir Patil
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Agriculture has been a major means of survival in our India since ancient times. In today's era almost many farmers performed various traditional strategies and practices to safeguard crops from various threats such as pests, diseases and adverse environmental conditions. Now a day some farmers are integrating additional <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{A I}$</tex> models with conventional agricultural techniques to improve decision-making processes and maximize the effective use of available resources. The primary challenge with the existing system is the presence of unreliable data in the datasets which directly impact the accuracy of the model. Small, landed farmers cannot adopt the new agricultural methods due to lack of education and knowledge. To help these farmers, we developed an efficient crop prediction model to develop smart harvesting through CNN algorithm. By analyzing soil type and temperature, we can predict crop suitability and growth potential. It also helps to optimize agricultural trails.

title: CA-YOLO: Underwater Bio-detection Algorithm Based on Improved Yolov8
authors: Tongxu Wang, Sizhe Yang, Yanqiu Liu, Mingrun Zou, Ziheng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Underwater target detection technology plays a critical role in marine monitoring of underwater vehicles, aquaculture, and rescue operations. However., due to the complexities of the underwater environment and the scarcity of training samples, the accuracy of existing underwater target recognition algorithms remains a significant challenge. To address this issue, we propose an improved underwater target detection model, CA-YOLO, based on YOLOv8 and the Coordinate Attention (CA) mechanism, aimed at enhancing detection accuracy in complex underwater scenarios. By incorporating the Coordinate Attention mechanism, CA-YOLO improves the model's multi-scale feature extraction capabilities, enabling it to effectively recognize target objects of varying sizes across different underwater environments. Extensive comparison experiments validate the model's performance on the 2020 Underwater Target Detection Algorithm Competition optical channel dataset, with Recall reaching 71.3% and mAP improving to 77.3%, surpassing YOLOv8 by 0.6% and 3%, respectively. The experimental results demonstrate that CA-YOLO can more effectively focus on target objects by enhancing attention to key features, significantly reducing false detections and missed detections. This model offers robust technical assistance for real-world applications in underwater biological monitoring and the protection of marine ecosystems.

title: A Preliminary Systematic Review on LLM-Based System Assurance: Is Generative AI All You Need?
authors: Alvine Boaye Belle, Gerhard Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Assurance cases allow verifying that the nonfunctional requirements (e.g., safety, security, reliability) of mission-critical systems are correctly implemented. This helps avoid system malfunction, which could have catastrophic consequences (e.g., deaths, environmental damage, financial losses). However, assurance cases are usually very large documents spanning several hundred pages. Their creation and maintenance may therefore be time-consuming and tedious. Relying on (semi)automated techniques such as those supported by generative AI through LLMs could alleviate the task of assurance case developers by facilitating the execution of all activities related to the assurance case lifecycle. In this paper, we report a critical analysis of the peer-reviewed literature on LLM-based system assurance to inform future research on this topic.

title: Bayesian Network Structure Learning Based on Adaptive Clustering Genetic Algorithm
authors: Haoran Liu, Yunhe Zhao, Kai Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Finding the globally optimal structure of Bayesian networks is an NP-hard problem. To address this, a Bayesian network structure learning algorithm based on an improved genetic algorithm with adaptive clustering is proposed. The maximum weight spanning tree algorithm is used to establish the initial structure and orientation, followed by a simplified Hill-Climbing strategy to generate the initial population. An adaptive population clustering strategy divides the population into subpopulations based on fitness differences to enhance diversity. A marriage operation promotes co-evolution and prevents local optima. A regional crossover-mutation strategy is applied in subregions, and adaptive parameters adjust the crossover-mutation probability to improve evolutionary efficiency. The algorithm was simulated and compared with other algorithms on the ASIA, CAR, and ALARM networks. Results show improvements in BIC score and accuracy over other algorithms.

title: Real-Time Human Activity Recognition Using Decision Trees and Wearable Sensor Data
authors: Shanmugam Muthu, P. Deepalakshmi
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Both human behavior recognition (HAR) and smart environment applications contribute to health and fitness monitoring. The disadvantages of typical systems that utilize video methods in elevators include privacy concerns, heavy computational workloads, and their limitation to real-time processing on resource-constrained devices. An analysis suggests shifting the challenges to real-time decision tree-based systems, which rely on input from wearable sensors. With accelerometers and gyroscopes, the system can collect motion data, perform fast pre-processing, extract features, and classify activities using lightweight decision trees. Such solutions not only have a lower computational footprint than other approaches, but these also have excellent interpretability; these are ideal for embedded platforms. Test results show that the proposed system outperforms existing systems on the market, with an average classification accuracy of 95.5%, an estimated time (ms) of 12 ms, and memory consumption of 15 MB, the best available. The study demonstrates privacy-preserving, accurate, and efficient behavior recognition that is suitable for real-time use on wearable devices.

title: Research on Chinese Traditional Geometric Pattern Design Based on Generative Artificial Intelligence
authors: Mengzhen Xiong, Jian Rao, Yangting Wu, Haoran Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: Geometric pattern design has evolved over thousands of years, exhibiting rich and diverse structural characteristics and organizational forms that reflect humanity's enduring pursuit of pattern aesthetics. However, with the proliferation of new technologies like generative AI, traditional design workflows face radical transformation. Current research on geometric patterns largely remains focused on interpreting existing designs. While some designers and scholars have applied geometric patterns to modern creations through pattern redesign, their creative approaches remain relatively monotonous. Works suffer from severe homogenization, and the creative methodology still relies on traditional design models, lacking innovation. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel creative approach: generative AI-based geometric pattern design. This methodology empowers designers to explore new pathways in pattern creation.

title: ShuffleNet-AMC for Fetal Brain Growth and Pediatric cancer Prediction
authors: D Gowthami, C Gowri Shankar, V. RaamPrasad, B. Krishna, N.T. Prasath
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Early fetal brain development and childhood cancer cases are important to detect such abnormalities and initiate the much-needed treatments and enhance long-term results. The traditional deep learning models, though they are effective, have been known to consume high amounts of computational resources and memory, which restricts its applicability in resource-constrained healthcare settings. To address the problem of fast and accurate image analysis of medical images, this paper suggests ShuffleNet-AMC a lightweight deep learning architecture that is a hybrid of the efficiency of ShuffleNet and Automated Model Compression (AMC) to analysis medical images. ShuffleNet can extract the discriminative features of fetal MRI images to measure brain development and pediatric MRI/CT images to identify cancer, whereas AMC is able to automatically detect redundant parameters and compress the model to achieve a smaller size and lower latency without loss of accuracy. Experimental analysis of fetal brain imaging and childhood cancer applications shows that ShuffleNet-AMC can produce up to 70% of model compression, which reduced the cost of computations by a large margin and still produced sampletestable predictions. Its small size supports its application on low power medical equipment, mobile platforms, and edgecomputing devices allowing it to be deployed to scalable, realtime early diagnosis applications. Efficiency and accuracy are the two aspects through which ShuffleNet-AMC offers a feasible remedy in improving maternal-fetal health monitoring and pediatric oncology diagnostics.

title: Search Engine Augmented Chinese Named Entity Recognition for Big Data Content Security
authors: Qinghua Mao, Jiatong Li, Kui Meng, Yuanyuan Sun, Pengjiao Wang, Jianhua Li, Xi Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: Named Entity Recognition (NER) is a critical component for real-time public opinion monitoring and threat perception in big data systems. Compared with English, Chinese suffers from more grammatical ambiguities, such as fuzzy word boundaries and polysemous words, which can make contextual information insufficient to support Chinese NER. To address this issue, recent works have suggested that retrieving background knowledge as assistance is a potential solution, yet how to obtain and leverage related background knowledge for the NER task remains a challenge. In this paper, we propose a neural-based approach that utilizes auxiliary knowledge from search engines for Chinese NER in big data systems. Specifically, we retrieve external related texts via the search engine with a query generated from the input sentence. Then, a multi-channel semantic fusion model is adopted to aggregate the original sentences with the retrieved external related texts. Experiments have demonstrated the superiority of our model across four NER datasets, including formal and social media language contexts, which further proves the effectiveness of our approach. By improving the accuracy and robustness of Chinese NER, this work provides a practical solution for safeguarding big data content security.

title: Collaborative Optimization of Structural Parameters in CNNs and Its Application in Industrial Equipment Health Monitoring
authors: Shupei Du, Ye Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The rapid evolution of Industry 4.0 and smart manufacturing has underscored the critical role of fault detection in managing industrial equipment and facilitating autonomous factory operations. Industrial equipment data typically exhibits high volume, diversity, and real-time characteristics, rendering traditional monitoring methods that primarily rely on expert knowledge and rule-based heuristics insufficient for addressing the complex and dynamic conditions encountered. To overcome these limitations, this study transforms raw signal data from industrial bearings into images using wavelet transformation. Additionally, noise is introduced to simulate varying signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs), allowing for the evaluation of noise resistance in classic deep networks such as GoogLeNet, ResNet, and AlexNet. This process aims to identify the most suitable network architecture for the given dataset. Subsequently, image-based training is performed to accurately classify images into fault and normal categories. To further enhance model performance, parameter optimization is conducted using grid search, progressive grid search, and population-based optimization algorithms, resulting in a set of optimal parameters tailored to the specific equipment under analysis. Finally, decision fusion of multiple trained models is implemented to improve classification accuracy for test samples. Experimental results demonstrate that this approach effectively extracts image features through convolution and pooling operations, enabling automatic recognition and intelligent diagnostics in industrial processes. This provides new insights into equipment monitoring and lifecycle management.

title: Research on the Fusion Algorithm of Intelligent Ship Autonomous Navigation System and Big Data Analysis
authors: Zhijie Zhang, Yonggang Zong
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This study proposes a fusion algorithm for intelligent ship autonomous navigation system based on big data analysis. The system improves the real-time and efficiency of data processing by combining distributed computing with edge computing. In the system architecture, the intelligent system works collaboratively in a complex marine environment to perform environmental perception, path planning and autonomous decision-making. The focus of the study is on the design and optimization of the algorithm, especially by introducing a distributed computing framework to achieve real-time processing and analysis of multi-source heterogeneous data. The simulation model is verified under different navigation scenarios based on massive data sets. The simulation results show that the algorithm significantly improves the autonomous navigation capability of ships, especially in complex waters, where the decision-making efficiency and safety are significantly improved. Accurate data analysis shows that the system has improved the accuracy of path planning by 15% and reduced energy consumption optimization by 12%, laying a solid technical foundation for the development of future intelligent ships.

title: Exploring the Link Between Climate Variables and the NSE Nifty 100 ESG Index: A Time Series and Causal Analysis
authors: Manali Agrawal, Rohit Agrawal, Prateek Kumar Bansal
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Over the past ten years, there has been a notable surge in socially conscious investment due to the increased significance of the environmental and social effects of investment choices. The main objective of this paper is to analyze the intricate relationship between climate risk and the performance of ESG-compliant businesses. To evaluate the performance of ESG-compliant businesses the NIFTY ESG 100 Index is used. In addition, monthly rainfall data, mean temperature, and maximum and minimum temperatures are utilized as climate risk indicators to demonstrate their impact on ESG performance in India using a multifaceted methodology. The Granger causality test is conducted to assess the direction of the influence of the change in climate risk on market performance. Time series models are developed using ARIMA in order to forecast trend lines and explain dynamic interaction across time. The results indicate ESG index is being positively influenced by rising mean and minimum temperatures, which may indicate market optimism for more comfortable climatic developments. The negative effects of maximum temperatures and rainfall may be a sign of operational or economic difficulties brought on by extreme weather.

title: Research on Optimization of Motion Control Algorithm of Cable-Driven Robot Based on Deep Learning
authors: Kunlin Meng, Zixiang Peng, Kai Chen, Zhengrong Gui, Yongxin Ji
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a motion control optimization algorithm of cable-driven robot based on deep learning, which combines DNN and RL. The algorithm extracts features of the motion characteristics of the cable-driven robot through deep neural network, analyzes and learns historical motion data, and combines the reward mechanism of reinforcement learning to optimize the control strategy and motion trajectory in real time in complex and dynamic environments. The experimental results indicate that the proposed algorithm has higher precision, faster response and higher energy efficiency than the conventional one. Specifically, the optimized control scheme improves the robot control accuracy by 15%, the response speed by 20%, and the energy efficiency by 10%. The results show that the algorithm combining deep learning and reinforcement learning can effectively improve the robot's motion control ability in complex environments, which not only improves the accuracy and stability of the robot's motion, but also enhances its adaptability in changing environments.

title: Assessing Geo-Foundational Models for Flood Inundation Mapping: Benchmarking models for Sentinel-1, Sentinel-2, and Planetscope
authors: Saurabh Kaushik, Lalit Maurya, Elizabeth Tellman, ZhiJie Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Geo-Foundational Models (GFMs) enable fast and reliable extraction of spatiotemporal information from satellite imagery, improving flood inundation mapping by leveraging location and time embeddings. Despite their potential, it remains unclear whether GFMs outperform traditional models like U-Net. A systematic comparison across sensors and data availability scenarios is still lacking, which is essential to guide end-users in model selection. To address this, we evaluate three GFMs—Prithvi 2.0, Clay V1.5, DOFA—and UViT (a Prithvi variant), against TransNorm, U-Net, DeepLabv3+, and Attention U-Net using PlanetScope, Sentinel-1, and Sentinel-2. We observe competitive performance among all GFMs, with 2–5% variation between the best and worst models across sensors. Clay outperforms others on PlanetScope (0.79 mIoU) and Sentinel-2 (0.72), while Prithvi leads on Sentinel-1 (0.57). In leave-one-region-out cross-validation across five regions, Clay shows slightly better performance across all sensors, with mIoU scores of 0.72, 0.66, and 0.51 for PanetScope, Sentinel-2, and Sentinel-1 respectively, compared to Prithvi (0.70, 0.64, 0.49) and DOFA (0.67, 0.64, 0.49).Across all 19 sites, cross-validation reveals a 4% improvement by Clay over U-Net. Visual inspection highlights Clay's superior ability to retain fine details. Few-shot experiments show Clay achieves 0.64 mIoU on PlanetScope with just five training images, outperforming Prithvi (0.24) and DOFA (0.35). In terms of computational time, Clay is a better choice due to its smaller model size (26M parameters), making it approximately 3× faster than Prithvi (650M) and 2× faster than DOFA (410M). Our results suggest GFMs offer small to moderate improvements in flood mapping accuracy at lower computational cost and labeling effort.

title: Cognitive Fuzzy Logic Algorithms for Advanced Spectrum Management in 5G Networks
authors: P. Harikrishna, Kusuma Tummala, P. Jayaprabha, Sabirov Sardor, Niranjanamurthy M, S.B. Prakalya
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: The increasing need for efficient spectrum management arises from the speed of sending 5G networks into service to support different applications while keeping peak network performance levels. Spectrum management tactics which work traditionally do not have the capability to calibrate efficiently to the complex 5G environment hence encountering the efficiency problems of distributing spectrum resource. This research assesses cognitive fuzzy logic algorithms as revolutionary methods for 5G networks high spectrum management structures. The cognitive fuzzy logic combines fuzzy logic reasoning with cognitive computing technology to provide smart real time decision system at dynamic operational situations. The proposed framework leverages user demand along with traffic pattern with interference level and QoS to make optimal spectrum allocation decision. The fusion of fuzzy systems structure and cognitive models results in an algorithm that offers superior spectral performance and reduced latency times with guaranteed fair distribution of resources. Simulation tests along with performance analyses ensure successful verification that the proposed method provides outstanding results as compared to conventional spectrum management practices. The research shows that cognitive fuzzy logic is a transformational solution to spectrum challenges in 5G networks and support the intelligent sustainable wireless communication.

title: Derived Topic Propagation Model Based on Topic Relevance and User Sentiment
authors: Shihong Wei, Yang Yang, Yifan Guo, Rong Wang, Sirui Duan, Yunpeng Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Affective Computing
abstract: The spread of hot original topics gives rise to a variety of derivative topics, and studying the spread of these derivative topics on social networks has become a key task in social network analysis. This paper explores the differences in correlation between original and derived topics, as well as the challenges in capturing users' dynamic emotions, while proposing a derivative topic propagation model that integrates topic relevance and user sentiment. First, to tackle the identification and classification of derived topics, this paper introduces the KC-SIFRank model. By extracting topic keywords and performing keyword clustering, this model enables the identification of derivative topics and the evaluation of their relevance to the original topic. Secondly, to tackle the challenge of capturing users' dynamic emotions and their changes, this paper proposes DeepLex, a novel text-to-emotion method. This method can learn the dynamic changes in users' emotions and calculate specific user sentiment scores. Finally, to solve the problem of multi-level feature interaction in user-topic interactions, this paper develops the TRS-GCN derivative topic prediction model. Experimental results confirm that this model, which integrates topic relevance and sentiment analysis results, can not only predict user behaviors more accurately and infer the propagation patterns of derivative topics effectively, but also significantly enhance its interpretability and predictive performance.

title: Sparse-Constrained NMF Dereverberation Algorithm
authors: Gao Tiande, Li Ruizhe
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: In shallow water settings, reverberation stands out as a key form of background interference in active sonar systems. This issue has long been a prominent subject of study in the marine acoustics domain. This paper proposes a reverberation suppression algorithm based on sparse-constrained non-negative matrix factorization (NMF). The algorithm constructs frequency basis matrices and time basis matrices for target echoes and reverberation, respectively. It establishes sparsity constraints to fully utilize the sparse characteristics of target echoes and combines optimization estimation with constraints such as temporal continuity and time length. This effectively improves the robustness of target signal extraction. When compared to PCI algorithms and AR pre-whitening algorithms, this method demonstrates significant improvements in SRR while also better preserving the temporal and spectral properties of the target signals.

title: Tuning PVA Molecular Weight for Structure–Property Optimization in Piezoresistive Hydrogel–Based Flexible Sensors
authors: Thasia Gian Pavita, Fitri Khoerunnisa, Rilo Berdin Taqriban, Rohana Adnan, Athanasia Amanda Septevani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: Hydrogel-based sensors have gained increasing attention in the development of wearable and flexible electronics due to their softness, biocompatibility, and ability to detect mechanical deformation. This study investigates the role of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) molecular weight in determining the performance of a composite hydrogel sensor. The effect of varying molecular weights of PVA at $61,70,145$, and 200 kDa on the mechanical strength, swelling behavior, surface hydrophilicity, and electrical conductivity properties of hydrogel sensor were investigated. The results showed that molecular weight significantly influences the structure and functionality of the hydrogel. Hydrogels with 145 kDa PVA demonstrated the most favorable balance across key performance metrics including high swelling ratio, low water contact angle (high hydrophilicity), good tensile strength, and reliable piezoresistive behavior. Although the 200 kDa PVA hydrogel exhibited the highest electrical conductivity (0.010 S/m), its excessive rigidity and limited flexibility reduced its suitability for dynamic sensing. In contrast, the 61 and 70 kDa variants showed moderate conductivity but lacked mechanical robustness. Notably, the 145 kDa hydrogel, despite its lower conductivity ($0.007 \mathrm{~S} / \mathrm{m}$), offered the optimal balance between mechanical resilience and stable piezoresistive as the most promising formulation for flexible sensing applications.

title: Performance Evaluation of Hybrid 3D-to-2D Versus Standard 2D U-Net Models in Denoising Low-Dose CT Scan
authors: Safa Alfattama, Ankita Vaish
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) reduces radiation exposure but suffers from increased image noise, requiring effective denoising for diagnostic reliability. This paper presents a systematic comparison of two deep learning architectures for LDCT denoising: a conventional 2D UNet and a hybrid 3D-to-2D UNet. Both models were trained and tested under identical conditions on the Mayo Clinic LDCT Challenge dataset and evaluated using peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR), structural similarity index measure (SSIM), normalized root mean square error (NRMSE), and edge preservation index (EPI), alongside qualitative analysis. Results show that the 3D-to-2D UNet achieves superior fidelity and structural preservation by exploiting inter-slice context, though at a higher computational cost, while the 2D UNet offers faster, resource-efficient performance. Despite many denoising techniques in the literature, direct comparisons between 2D and hybrid 3D-to-2D models remain limited; this work addresses that gap and underscores the tradeoff between accuracy and efficiency in LDCT denoising.

title: Design of a Sub-6 GHz Wideband Power Amplifier with Low-Pass Filter Synthesis Network
authors: Jairo Alonso Mesa Lara, Jorge Julián Moreno Rubio, Edison Ferney Angarita Malaver
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This article presents a design strategy for broadband power amplifiers (PAs) operating at sub-6 GHz frequencies, based on the use of an impedance matching network by modelling a low-pass filter with transmission lines. The strategy focuses on take advantage of parasitic elements from the GaN HEMT CGH40006P transistor in order to be part of the filter and establish conditions for adapting to the optimal resistance of the FET device across a wide range of frequencies. The design considers a single-stage architecture; simulation results in Advanced Design System - Keysight (ADS) software, obtained at a centre frequency of 3.5 GHz, show an PAE between 50% and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 4. 2 \%}$</tex> in the 0.1 GHz to 5 GHz band, with an output power between 38.7 dBm and 40.6 dBm, with a gain greater than 13.3 dB for the entire band.

title: Multimodal Indoor Scene Modelling and Feature Extraction Techniques for Adaptive Reconstruction
authors: Minghao Sun, Hong Zhang, Yijian Bai, Yizhe Geng, Xinwei Xu, Yuhui Zhang, Zihang Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: Indoor scene reconstruction faces multiple challenges, particularly in achieving precise modelling within complex environments. This paper proposes an adaptive multimodal indoor scene reconstruction method. By integrating RGB-D camera and LiDAR data, it designs adaptive feature extraction techniques to enhance feature robustness. Combined with a dynamic parameter adjustment strategy based on scene complexity analysis, it achieves efficient and accurate reconstruction. Furthermore, it constructs a structured scene representation based on semantic information. Experiments demonstrate the method's superior performance under varying illumination and complex geometric conditions, offering a novel technical pathway for indoor scene understanding and virtual reality applications.

title: Task Offloading in Edge Computing: Energy Optimization Through SAC Based Reinforcement Learning
authors: Shanmukhi Lakshmi Sidwini, Suchismita Rout, Harish Kumar Patnaik, Bibhuti Bhusan Dash, Utpal Chandra De, Sudhansu Shekhar Patra
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Task offloading is the process of transferring computationally intensive tasks from a local device to a remote resource, such as a server or cloud, to improve performance and efficiency. This paper focuses on minimizing energy consumption and delay in task offloading in cloud-edge systems. A Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) based reinforcement learning approach is proposed to dynamically decide where to offload computational tasks (local, edge, or cloud). A custom simulation environment was built using OpenAI Gym and Stable Baselines3. Comparative evaluations were conducted against DDPG and DQN. SAC demonstrated superior performance in balancing reward, energy efficiency, and delay, making it a promising solution for intelligent task offloading in edge computing.

title: Multi-Objective Reinforcement Learning Based Dependent Task Scheduling with Service Caching in Mobile Edge Computing
authors: Fuhong Song, Mingsen Deng, Huanlai Xing, Yanping Liu, Zhiwen Xiao, Lexi Xu, Xianfu Lei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: This paper investigates the dependent task scheduling with service caching (DTSSC) in mobile edge computing (MEC) systems, where each task requires a specific service program for execution. The DTSSC problem is characterized by bi-objective optimization, minimizing the application delay and energy consumption of the mobile equipment, simultaneously. The conflict between the two objectives in the problem makes it quite challenging to address. Recently, some single-objective reinforcement learning (SORL) algorithms have been introduced to solve the DTSSC problem. Nevertheless, these SORLs adopt the weighted sum method to define the user utility, thus ignoring the conflict between objectives. Furthermore, in dynamic MEC scenarios, the weights (i.e., preference) assigned to each objective may vary over time, posing significant challenges for conventional SORLs. Although several multi-objective reinforcement learning (MORL) algorithms have been adopted to handle dynamic preferences, they only adapt to small-scale dynamic preferences and cannot generalize across all possible preferences. To solve these challenges, we first build a multi-objective Markov decision process model that has a vectorial reward mechanism. Each component of the reward and one of the two objectives is correlated. Then, we propose a new trajectory-based experience replay scheme to improve sample efficiency and reduce replay buffer bias, resulting in a modified MORL algorithm. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm is more adaptive to dynamic preferences and strikes a better balance between objectives compared with several algorithms.

title: A Survey on Next Generation Physical Layer Security for URLLC and HRLLC: Finite Block Length Design and CSI Imperfections
authors: S Madhan, S Kavvinguru, K Kumaravel, M Madhukiran, S Nagavinubalan, V Samuthira Pandi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: In the fast-evolving communication systems, we are currently in the 5 G phase and continuously progressing toward the 6th generation spectrum. Ultra-Reliable Low Latency Communication (URLLC) and Hyper-Reliable Low Latency Communication (HRLLC) are the cutting-edge services offered by 5G and 6G wireless systems, enabling more missioncritical applications by employing highly reliable and low latency signal transmission. Apart from applications emphasize reliability and low latency, this study focuses on a lightweight security mechanism known as Physical Layer Security (PLS), which is an essential requirement to enable secure data transmission in mission-critical applications. URLLC/HRLLC uses finite block length (FBL) signals to achieve stringent reliability and latency requirements, thereby eliminating the need for traditional key-based cryptographic techniques. Then the Channel State Information (CSI) value and signal block length, are correspondingly introduced. Therefore, this survey presents a comprehensive and detailed study on the PLS of URLLC/HRLLC in 5G and beyond communications. This paper mainly concentrates on the current enhancements in PLS for mission-critical applications and provides an in-depth review of finite block length-oriented and CSI-driven strategies employed in URLLC/HRLLC. This review emphasizes state-of-the-art robust and adaptive CSI-based security frameworks that address channel estimation errors. The Novel Idea of this study is to introduce a unified design oriented PLS frame work that integrates FBL communication theory and Practical CSI limitations in wireless networks Finally, the survey discusses several key challenges and identifies open research directions in joint FBL-CSI optimization, secure training signal design, and energy-efficient secrecy protocols for future 6 G wireless networks.

title: Cross-Domain Fault Diagnosis Method of Rotating Machinery Based on Classifier Prediction Consistency and Domain Generalization
authors: Yixuan Du, Ningfu Xu, Kun Zhang, Yunjian Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: To improve the accuracy and robustness of fault diagnosis with limited identically distributed labeled data and unknown diagnostic targets, this paper proposes a fault diagnosis method that integrates Classifier Prediction Consistency with Domain Generalization (CPC-DG). First, unlike traditional DG-based fault diagnosis, which primarily focuses on aligning global feature distributions and neglects inter-class boundary ambiguity, our method employs a dual-classifier adversarial training strategy, which refines the decision boundary by maximizing prediction divergence between classifiers on boundary samples and guides the shared feature extractor to learn more discriminative features, specifically keeping robust under shifted target domain. Second, to mitigate the noise associated with traditional pseudo-labeling techniques, which typically rely on the confidence outputs of a single classifier, we develop a pseudo-label generation and validation technique based on dual-classifier consensus. This approach assigns pseudo-labels only to unlabeled samples exhibiting high prediction consistency between classifiers by iterative updates to filter out unreliable labels that could impair model performance. Third, the boundary refinement and high-quality pseudo-labeling mechanisms are integrated with a global alignment strategy based on Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD) to minimize distribution discrepancies across multiple source domains. Lastly, extensive experiments on the CWRU and PU bearing benchmark datasets verify that the proposed method achieves superior diagnostic accuracy in scenarios characterized by label scarcity and an unknown target domain.

title: Motorized Arm Support (MARS) &#x2013; An Underactuated Robot for Adaptive Arm De-weighting in Neurorehabilitation_supp1-3657054.docx
authors: Sivakumar Balasubramanian
publish: N/A
abstract: Research has shown that providing external arm weight support increases the arm’s range of motion, and training with graduated weight support can help break abnormal movement patterns. Arm rehabilitation robots can be used for training with adaptive arm weight support, but they tend to be complex and bulky for use in small clinics or homes. Passive arm weight support devices, on the other hand, can be used in small clinics or homes but require manual adjustments of springs/rubber bands for de-weighting the arm and do not measure arm movements to provide feedback. To this end, we propose a simple robot with a single actuator and four degrees of freedom: MARS (Motorized Arm Support), which can provide adaptive arm de-weighting and measure arm movements to provide gamified feedback for in-clinic and at-home use. This article presents the mechanical design of MARS, the algorithms for estimating human arm joint kinematics from the robot’s data, and the characterization of the Challenge Point Controller that adapts the weight support based on the success rate of task completion. A three degrees-of-freedom mechatronic model of the human arm was used in the characterization of MARS. The results indicate that (1) the human arm joint kinematics can be estimated with high accuracy (median error <2.5°) without any external sensors, and (2) MARS can maintain a desired success rate (mean error <13.3%) during training by adapting the weight support. We believe the simple approach proposed here can lead to a compact, cost-effective tool with significant benefits for both in-clinic and home-based hand rehabilitation.

title: A Deep Learning Framework for Unmanned Aerial Vehicle-Based Sugarcane Crop Analysis: Weed Detection and Yield Prediction
authors: D Geethaanjali, N. Thilagavathi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Crop yield prediction plays a vital role in precision agriculture. Traditional methods perform based on sampling test and empirical formulas. Traditional methods do not consider spatial complexity and seasonal variability data. Moreover, major problem in crop yield prediction is weeds in between crops. In this paper, a multi- framework approach is proposed and termed as Sugarcane Weed Detection (SWD) framework. SWD framework performs weed-crop classification based on sugarcane leaf area index (LAI) estimation, and predicts yield. The SWD framework consists of customers convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with pre-trained architectures such as ResNet18, VGG16, and MobileNetV2 to classify sugarcane weeds such as grassy weeds, broad leaved weeds and sedges from UAV-based multispectral and RGB images. LAI based weed detection in sugarcane fields combines the radiometric correction, vegetation index computation (NDVI, GNDVI), sequential land cover masking, and empirical LAI modelling. SWD framework segments the soil background and improves the accuracy in heterogeneous regions in sugarcane field. Proposed SWD measures yield prediction through using environmental parameter such as rainfall, temperature, soil nutrient concentration, and pesticide application. Proposed SWD framework provide 95.2% accuracy for classification weeds and calculates yield.

title: An Immersive Hazelnut Tree Pruning Simulator for Agricultural Operator Training
authors: Davide Fabiocchi, Carol Sergenti, Silvia La Placa, Marco Carnevale, Hermes Giberti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The agricultural sector faces significant challenges in workforce training due to labor shortages, high costs, and seasonal constraints. To address these issues, this study presents the design and evaluation of an immersive hazelnut pruning simulator developed within the DEMETRA research project. The simulator leverages Virtual Reality (VR) and mechatronics to provide an interactive and realistic training environment for agricultural operators. Using high-fidelity 3D reconstructions created through photogrammetry and laser scanning, the system offers an engaging and lifelike experience. Key features include a step-by-step virtual instructor, realistic pruning tool interactions, full-body motion reconstruction for enhanced immersion, and markerless Human Pose Estimation (HPE) for ergonomic studies. The system also incorporates branch-cutting mechanics and an omnidirectional treadmill for unrestricted movement. Preliminary evaluations highlight the potential of this technology to improve skill acquisition and training efficiency in agriculture, offering a scalable solution for operator education.

title: Research on Video-Enhanced Target Recognition Technology of Radar Security Monitoring System in Oil Field
authors: Meng Ye
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the improvement of oilfield safety monitoring demand, traditional technology faces the problems of low image quality and poor target recognition accuracy. This paper studies the video enhancement and target recognition technology in the oil field radar security monitoring system, focuses on the analysis of video enhancement methods under low light and bad weather conditions, and discusses the improvement of target recognition performance by radar and video data fusion. The application of low light enhancement, defogging and denoising technology and high dynamic range technology are studied. Combined with traditional methods and deep learning algorithms, a target recognition technology based on radar and video data fusion is proposed. Fusion technology can improve the accuracy of target detection, especially in complex environments, which has important application value. With the improvement of recognition accuracy and processing efficiency, oilfield security monitoring system will be widely used in the future.

title: Automated Bridge Crack Detection and Quantification Via an Improved YOLOv7 Model and UAV Imagery
authors: Di Wu, Rui Yang, Zhi Ye, Huichao Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: Bridge cracks are a critical defect that compromises the safety of transportation infrastructure. Traditional manual inspection methods face challenges in efficiency, subjective judgments, and the significant risks of working at heights. To overcome these limitations, this study proposes an automated method for bridge crack identification and quantitative analysis utilizing an improved YOLOv7 model and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). The approach integrates high-resolution UAV-based imaging with deep learning, incorporating key optimizations in three areas: (1) the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) to enhance feature extraction of fine cracks; (2) the adoption of a focal loss function and an adaptive data augmentation strategy to improve generalization in complex environments; and (3) the design of a lightweight network architecture to enable real-time processing on embedded UAV platforms. Experimental results on a dataset of 500 bridge crack images demonstrate that the improved model achieves a mean Average Precision (mAP@0.5) of 98.7%. The average measurement errors for crack length and width are 1.5 mm and 0.3 mm, respectively. The proposed method shows high precision and efficient for bridge structural health monitoring with considerable practical value for engineering applications.

title: A Multi-Class Text Sentiment Analysis Using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs)
authors: Sonica Upadhyay, Yogesh Kumar Gupta
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Sentiment Analysis is used to analyze customers' text sentiments, which helps to identify whether a customer's opinion or reviews for specific products are positive, negative, or neutral. Due to the exponential growth rate of textual data on social media platforms, it becomes more essential to analyze review sentiments of the text data automatically. This digitalized review system helps to understand consumers' overall feeling or mood towards a specific brand or company. It determines whether they are viewed positively or negatively on social media platforms. Sentiment analysis has been widely used in classifying product reviews and movie review ratings. In this research paper, we propose a sentiment text classifier that extracts valuable information from Flipkart products' textual dataset, classifies products' text reviews using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs), and categorizes customer reviews as positive, negative, and neutral. Some deep learning and machine learning based classifiers are already performing well for textual classification, but these existing methods do not allow for rich hypotheses. The Flipkart product dataset was used for the experimental research work, and the accuracy of the ANN model was scored at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0, 8 1 \%}$</tex> on test data.

title: Machine Learning for Accurate Crop Disease Identification and Diagnosis
authors: Priyanka Kaushik, Narendra B Mustare, S. Anupkant, Premkumar R, Anandakumar Haldorai, Karthikayen A
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Crop diseases pose a significant threat to global food security by negatively impacting agricultural productivity and quality. Traditional methods of disease detection and diagnosis often rely on visual inspection by experts, leading to delays in identification and treatment. Machine learning (ML) techniques offer a promising solution to automate the diagnosis and detection of agricultural diseases. This paper provides a comprehensive overview of recent advancements in ML-based strategies to address this critical agricultural challenge. The research explores the potential of Artificial Intelligence Markup Language (AIML) for developing models that detect and diagnose crop diseases. AIML is used to construct complex patterns and templates that capture distinctive features differentiating various genders and age groups, akin to rule-based programming. These AIML components serve as the foundation for classifiers designed to infer crop diseases from diverse input sources, including images and videos. Additionally, the study evaluates the adaptability of AIML models across different contexts, domains, and languages. The resulting insights offer a thorough understanding of AIML's capabilities as a versatile tool for crop disease detection, potentially overcoming linguistic barriers and complex domain-specific nuances. The project highlights the potential of data science to advance intelligent systems for various real-world applications by proposing a robust and ethical approach to visual analysis. Emphasizing transparency and interpretability is prioritized to build trust and facilitate the model's integration into practical applications.

title: Energy Storage Integration with Wind Power for Primary Frequency Regulation and Voltage Control
authors: Josimar Tello-Maita, Diego Edison Vargas Guerrero, Agustin Marulanda Guerra
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: The growing integration of non-conventional energy sources into power systems requires understanding their performance in providing ancillary services, such as primary frequency regulation and voltage control, mandated by certain grid codes. This paper examines the voltage and frequency behavior of power systems integrating wind power plants and battery energy storage systems (BESS) with the grid under disturbance events. Through case studies, the response of each technology is analyzed to assess their performance over time and identify potential benefits based on their integration. Results demonstrate that BESS enhance power system performance due to their rapid response during frequency and voltage events. When combined with wind power plants, they provide a flexible and reliable solution for ancillary service provision, ensuring grid stability and operational reliability.

title: Optimizing QoS of Task Offloading in Edge Computing through DRL-Driven Approaches
authors: Puneet Kansal, Manoj Kumar, Om Prakash Verma
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Edge computing stands out as a pivotal technology in enhancing the performance and efficiency of various applications, including online gaming, autonomous vehicles, smart cities, and more. This model expands the reach of cloud paradigm to the periphery of the network, closer to data sources, thus reducing delay, conserving bandwidth, and enhancing privacy. However, it introduces significant challenges in resource management and task offloading due to the diverse and dispersed nature of edge devices. To tackle these challenges, this paper advocates the use of Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) techniques to handle heterogeneous task in dynamic environment. DRL's adaptive and predictive capabilities make it an ideal solution for dynamically managing tasks in an edge environment, optimizing Quality of Service (QoS) aspects such as delay, energy usage, and resource allocation. We present a comprehensive framework, explore various DRL algorithms, and simulate the environment to evaluate the proposed methods' effectiveness. This study aims to contribute significantly to the field of edge computing by enhancing the QoS, thereby supporting the robust development of real-time, distributed applications.

title: Dynamic Tokenizer for Robust Face Recognition
authors: Himanshu Kumar, Shubham Gautam
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Vision Transformers (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V$</tex>iTs) have shown significant performance gains across various computer vision tasks, including face recognition. However, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V$</tex>iT has a higher computational cost with the increase in linear tokens. By combining stochasticity and dynamic token selection, we present a unique face recognition application of the vanilla Vision Transformer in this study. Stochasticity improves robustness and generalisation by adding unpredictability in ViT. At the same time, dynamic token selection allows the model to process the inter-patch informative tokens, concentrating on essential face regions like the mouth, nose, and eyes. Our method achieves notable accuracy gains on the TALFW dataset, a benchmark for face recognition in adversarial scenarios. We have evaluated our method on face recognition benchmarks to demonstrate the model's robustness in different scenarios such as pose, occultation, and age invariance. These findings highlight how dynamic tokens and stochasticity can be combined to improve transformer-based face recognition models.

title: Visibility into Agentic AI for Required System Theory and Increasing Harms in Algorithmic System
authors: Naveen Kunchakuri, Veera L. Patchigolla, Abhilash Shashikumar Kedlaya, Tejas Upreti
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Agentic AI systems that can pursue complex goals with minimal direct supervision-should show to be generally advantageous if we can successfully integrate them into our culture. Numerous sources and manifestations of algorithmic harm have been identified by research in the areas of fairness, accountability, transparency, and ethics. These include policing, recommendations, health care, and finance. It will take considerable work to mitigate the enormously harmful impact of such systems, especially those having an especially disproportional adverse impact on disadvantaged communities. AI systems relying on machine learning are emerging with incredibly swift speeds that change our day-to-day experience, but disadvantages as well exist. In both private and public sector contexts, scholars from diverse disciplines have increasingly raised concerns regarding algorithmic systems' privacy, transparency, bias, discrimination, exploitation, and exclusion. Focusing on the need to ensure fairness in automated consumer profiling, this research examines bias discovery and mitigation in agentic AI-driven target marketing. Initial investigation found strong biases in AI models, driven by factors such as geographic location and prior purchases, which closely map onto stored features like race and socioeconomic status. The findings of the current study substantiate existing work and demonstrate that bias in agentic AI is a persistent and multifaceted problem that requires a multi-pronged solution. The article highlights the importance of continuous audits, transparency, and crossdisciplinary collaboration in countering bias. The implications are vast for marketers, AI practitioners, and policymakers, as they point to the necessity of ethical AI use in supporting legal obligations and consumer confidence. The approach reduces bias in AI-based marketing frameworks, contributes to the wider debate on AI ethics, and promotes fairness.

title: Novel Configuration of Multilevel Inverter with Reduced Switch Count for PV Applications
authors: Purushotham Endla, Narayana Rao Kolagani, M. Udayakumar, Sirisha Narkedamilli, Sumit Pundir, G. Durgadevi, G A E Satish Kumar, Burada Sankara Rao
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Providing electrical power to utility points is crucial for development in all areas. In light of the constraints and limited as well as restrictions on utilization of fossil fuels, there is an interest shifted towards the advancement of power generation through renewable energy sources. Nonetheless, the provision of high-quality power remains a challenging aspect within the power system. Fortunately, with the advent of power electronics components, the conversion and transmission of electric power have become significantly easier when appropriate controllers are selected based on our specific requirements. The idea of multilevel converter is widely recognized in various power electronics applications. The utilization of multilevel converters in power production from renewable energy sources is increasingly gaining popularity with the advent of new technologies. Nevertheless, the primary disadvantage of multilevel inverters is the rising quantity of switches as the level increases. Furthermore, the control methods become more complex as the levels in multilevel inverters increase. Therefore, it is necessary to minimize the number of switches in order to configure multilevel inverters for improved performance. This paper proposes a new configuration combined with an innovative control methodology for a photovoltaic (PV) power production system. The proposed controller allows for the regulation of voltage at the load, making this configuration suitable for various applications that require adjustable voltage. Comprehensive results based on MATLAB/Simulink are provided to substantiate the proposed system.

title: Parameters Identification of 4H-SiC MESFET Including Surface Trapping, Substrate Trapping, and Thermal Effect by Using Modified Grey Wolf Optimization
authors: S. Jyothirmaye, Mohamed Shaik Honnurvali, Abhishek Agarwal, G. Divya, Vipashi Kansal, Monisha Jothi. R, Rajendar Sandiri, Suresh Kakinatla
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: 4H-SiC MESFETs are employed across a wide range of applications, including residential, industrial, and other sectors. There are several techniques available for analyzing the models of 4H-SiC MESFETs. However, studying the direct current characteristics of MESFETs poses a significant challenge. This paper highlights three critical factors that influence these characteristics: surface trapping, thermal effects, and substrate trapping. By exploring these factors, we aim to deepen the understanding of the DC behavior of MESFETs. The current-voltage (I- V) characteristics model we propose is based on the Caughey-Thomas configuration. This model effectively addresses electron trapping in the substrate through various deep-level trapping mechanisms, takes into account the field-dependent mobility of electrons, and provides a comprehensive analysis of the two-dimensional charge distribution beneath the MESFET gate. Our proposed approach is holistic, considering all significant thermal effects and material imperfections, including traps. The task of solving the intricate mathematical equations that define the 4H-SiC MESFET and deriving its I-V characteristics across different regions is notably challenging due to the inherent complexity of these equations. To address this challenge, the Modified Grey Wolf Optimization (MGWO) Algorithm is employed, which effectively resolves the multiple complex equations associated with the 4H-SiC MESFET, thereby ensuring the accuracy of the I- V characteristics. As a result, the performance of the proposed analytical model closely aligns with that of an actual 4H-SiC MESFET. Furthermore, various behavioral traits are extracted and assessed using the MATLAB programming package, allowing for a comprehensive evaluation of the model's performance.
