title: Supervised Semantic Similarity-Based Conflict Detection Algorithm: S3CDA
authors: Garima Malik, Mucahit Cevik, Ayşe Başar, Devang Parikh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Identifying conflicting requirements is a key challenge in software requirement engineering, often overlooked in automated solutions. Most existing approaches rely on handcrafted rules or struggle to generalize across different domains. In this paper, we introduce S3CDA, a two-phase algorithm designed to automatically detect conflicts in software requirements. Our method first identifies potentially conflicting requirement pairs using semantic similarity, and then validates them by analyzing overlapping domain-specific entities. We evaluate S3CDA on five diverse real-world datasets and compare it against popular large language models like GPT-4o, Llama-3, Sonnet-3.5 and Gemini-1.5. While LLMs show promise, especially on general datasets, S3CDA consistently performs better in domain-specific settings with higher performance. Our findings suggest that combining Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques with domainaware insights offers a practical and effective alternative for conflict detection in requirements.

title: Performance Improvement of Wind Speed and Direction Forecasting Using Modified XLNet Method Based on Cyclical Data and Regressor
authors: Alfiah Zalfa Tsabitah, Suryo Adhi Wibowo, Sudarmono Sasmono
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: The prediction of wind speed and direction using artificial intelligence has advanced significantly over the past few years. However, existing approaches still face several limitations and challenges. In this study, we propose an enhancement to the XLNet Method to improve the accuracy of wind speed and direction forecasting through a regression-based approach. The main innovations include the cyclical feature encoding using sine and cosine transformations, as well as the addition of a custom regression head that enables the method to recognize and map complex patterns in meteorological time-series data. Experimental results using wind data from Banyuwangi indicate that the modified XLNet Method achieved a MAE of 0.0320, RMSE of 0.0439, and MAPE of 0.1665. These results highlight a substantial improvement in forecasting accuracy, with the method outperforming benchmark methods such as SVR, CNN, ANN, and LSTM, especially in reducing mean and squared errors. This research confirms that XLNet can effectively handle non-textual numerical forecasting tasks, supporting the broader application of AI in renewable energy and other sectors.

title: A Methodical Approach to Creating Medical Imaging Datasets for Deep Learning-Powered Lung Disease Identification
authors: M Arivukarasi, J Nithisha
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Recent developments in deep learning models have significantly accelerated the creation of automated decisionmaking systems, especially those designed to identify lung issues using medical imaging techniques. Large, varied, and highly labeled chest X-ray (CXR) and computed tomography (CT) databases would be necessary for the positive identification of respiratory diseases including COVID-19, pneumonia, and tuberculosis. This study provides an overview of the process of gathering data and creating datasets for deep learning-based lung disease detection systems. We perform efficient preprocessing and labeling operations, conduct a systematic analysis of various institutional and publically available data, and handle important concerns such class imbalance, inter-site variance, and ethical considerations. Our performance evaluation reveals that our developed data framework, which filters data, has high classification parameters with 0.985 AUC and 96.4 percent accuracy when it classifies into various classes of lung diseases. These results provide an excellent foundation for efficient classification systems and the clinical application of deep learning models to diagnostic systems.

title: Genetic Algorithm Based Control of BLDC Motor with Buck Boost Converter
authors: G. Subramaniam, K Moharajamoorthy, R Saran, B Saravanakarthick, P G Sowmiya
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Brushless DC (BLDC) motors are widely used in electric vehicles (EVs) due to their high efficiency, compact size, and low maintenance. Due to high efficiency, compact designs, and consistency in operation, brushless DC (BLDC) motors have been the choice of propelling electric vehicles. Nevertheless, it is difficult to have accurate control over speed and torque at different load conditions and road conditions. The paper provides an optimization method (Genetic Algorithm (GA) based) of tuning parameters of a PID controller in a BLDC motor drive. This GA approach proposed automatically changes the controller gains to ensure that the speed error is minimized and the system dynamic performance is enhanced. It has been demonstrated through simulation studies in MATLAB / Simulink that the GA-tuned PID controller has lower response time and overshoot as well as lower steady-state error than a conventional PID control. These findings qualify the control strategy based on GA, as it improves the efficiency and stability of BLDC motor drives, and hence is suitable in the nextgeneration electric vehicles.

title: Research on Radio Interference Prediction for 750 kV High-Altitude Transmission Lines Based on CNN-LSTM
authors: Yulong Chen, Xiaorui Wu, Huang Rui, Zhenhuan Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: To overcome the prediction challenges of radio interference (RI) phenomena in 750 kV ultra-high voltage transmission systems under high-altitude conditions, this study pioneers a data-physics fusion framework harnessing longitudinal monitoring data from the Gangcha High-Altitude Observation Station (3,320 m AMSL) in Qinghai Province, China. Through synergistic integration of multidimensional heterogeneous data fusion and a hybrid convolutional-recurrent neural architecture, we develop a novel CNN-LSTM prediction paradigm with dual validation mechanisms. The proposed methodology advances RI forecasting accuracy through three key innovations: 1) A multi-timescale data purification protocol combining kNN-imputed meteorological compensation and 3σ-optimized corona discharge characterization; 2) A cross-domain feature extraction mechanism employing dilated causal convolutions for spectrum-time dependency modeling; 3) A dual-attention LSTM module with adaptive gate structures for non-stationary interference pattern decoding. Experimental results demonstrate prediction errors reduced to 2.8 dB (RMSE) and 2.1 dB (MAE) with 94.7% explainable variance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{R}^{\mathrm{2}})$</tex>, significantly outperforming conventional prediction models. This research establishes the first quantitative correlation model between plateau microclimate variations and RI intensity fluctuations, providing both methodological advancement in power electromagnetic analytics and operational guidance for EHV grid optimization in extreme environments.

title: A Privacy-Aware Framework for Distributed AI in Regulated Environments
authors: Sowjanya Pandruju
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: With the extensive growth in terms of data and AI adoption across various fields such as finance, healthcare and insurance, data security and privacy have become significant barriers to innovation. This paper provides a privacy-aware framework for distributed AI as a possible solution which is integrated with cloud-native architectures. By leveraging decentralized model training without sharing raw data, this solution offers a compliant and secure framework for deploying machine learning at scale. A scalable and cost-effective system architecture is proposed that aligns with data protection regulations while maintaining high performance and model accuracy. This approach empowers organizations to leverage AI responsibly, unlocking the potential of sensitive data without compromising privacy.

title: Research and Practice on Cultivating Top Innovative Talent Under the Guidance of Chief Engineer-Oriented Educational Culture
authors: Haocheng Cao, Fan Zong, Yiting Du, Xiaoxiao Xie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: This article utilizes CiteSpace visualization software to conduct a research analysis on the literature concerning the cultivation of top innovative talent under the guidance of chief engineer-oriented educational culture in recent years. The findings show that “innovation” has consistently been a central topic of discussion and research in the area of cultivating top innovative talent under the guidance of chief engineer-oriented educational culture. Key research frontiers in this field include “curriculum development” “creativity” “experimental teaching” and “gifted education”. This article further explores new approaches to cultivating top innovative talent through several aspects involving value shaping and guidance, the establishment of training mechanisms and curriculum systems, practice processes and skill development, as well as support measures and evaluation systems.

title: Automated Scrutiny of Question Papers Using Natural Language Processing and Large Language Models
authors: Soham Mali, Aditya Koli, Afifa Shaikh, Pradeep Awubaigol, Savita Bagewadi, Rajashri Khanai
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: India's education system uses Bloom's taxonomy as one of the primary techniques for making the Indian curriculum outcome-based, following the needs of the governing councils like AICTE and NAAC. It offers a way of actively drafting the learning objectives together with regards to the levels of cognition, starting with core knowledge up to analysis, evaluation, synthesis, and application level. Such alignment assures the level of questioning to focus more on understanding concepts and their application and less on mere memorization. This system allows questions to be charted along Bloom's levels and respective Course Outcomes (COs), thereby allowing educators to construct more valid, and balanced assessments applicable to the national standards. This, in turn, will improve and reinforce teaching quality and learning quality in both engineering and other higher education institutes in India.

title: Analyzing Deep Learning for Intrusion Detection Systems: Effectively Categorizing Threats in Cybersecurity Networks
authors: M. Sukanya, Mohyedin Hamza, V. Samuthira Pandi, Gaurav Sethi, R. Balasubramaniyan, Ragini Y P
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This study investigates how deep learning technology could be used to improve the intrusion detection system (IDS) in a cyber-security network and the accurate classification of various real-time and evolving cyber threats. As a consequence, the traditional IDS techniques usually suffer from high false positive rates and are not flexible enough to cater for new attacks, which introduce the requirement of more advanced techniques. Utilizing the advances in deep neural networks (e.g. convolutional neural networks and recurrent neural networks), this work is expected to provide more reliable, faster, and more specific detection and identification of threats. Extensive experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that the deep learning models can achieve efficient performance in learning complex attack patterns and classifying various threats, comparing with traditional machine learning methods. The study also conducts experiments on feature extraction and selection that improve the performance and computation costs of the model. High-order features are learned for subtle anomalies and complex temporal dependencies within network traffic data by integrating sophisticated methods including autoencoders and attention mechanisms. The work also handles class imbalance issues and signature changes as the novel approach considers data augmentation and transfer learning technique. The results show that the deep learning model can effectively be adjusted to various evolving cyber security scenes and offer acceptable high detection rate and low false positive alarm. In summary, this paper presents extensive research into the potential to reinvigorate IDS through deep learning, allowing for more accurate and scalable threat classification, with the goal of improving the security of contemporary network infrastructures.

title:
RG
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    : Reasoning With Scene Graphs and Traffic Rule Graphs for Interpretable Autonomous Driving Decisions
authors: Xiaoyan Xiao, Yuchen Zhou, Linkai Liu, Chao Gou
publish: IEEE Intelligent Transportation Systems Magazine
abstract: Interpretable driving decisions are a critical prerequisite for the large-scale deployment of autonomous vehicles. To address the user expectation that autonomous driving decisions be perceptually grounded and legally compliant, we propose RG<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, a pioneering framework that achieves reasoning with scene graphs and traffic rule graphs to generate interpretable and regulation-compliant driving decisions. RG<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> performs fine-grained visual scene parsing via structured scene graphs, retrieves contextually relevant rules from a curated traffic rule knowledge base, and constructs explicit chain-of-thought reasoning sequences that systematically associate scene elements with corresponding rules and driving decision recommendations. We introduce the Scene-Rule-Decision Chain Dataset, consisting of 15,571 traffic scenarios annotated with dynamic and static traffic elements, rules, and interpretable driving decisions. Experimental results across six widely used open source large language models demonstrate that RG<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> achieves strong robustness and generalizability across models. RG<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> provides a scalable, interpretable framework for context-aware and rule-compliant driving decisions.

title: Design and Development of an Intelligent AntiTremor Glove for Parkinson’s Patients Using Adaptive Control Mechanisms
authors: K Manikandan, S Prabakar, K Nithya Manoj, K Haripriya, S S Harsha Vardhini, P B Madhomitha
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder it usually results in involuntary hand tremors that complicates daily activities such as dressing, eating, and writing [5]. This project introduces design and development of the wearable glove system that detects and suppresses hand tremors to enhance patient independence [2]. The glove uses an MPU6050 gyroscope and accelerometer to track hand movement and detect involuntary tremors. A microcontroller executes the movement information and distinguishes tremors from voluntary activity. On detecting a tremor, a DC motor introduces a counter force in the opposite direction to decrease the shaking without interfering with normal movement [19]. The system includes a feedback loop to continuously monitor and make real-time adjustments in order to respond to changes in tremor magnitude and direction [11]. It is Lightweight, ergonomic, and affordable also provides a useful solution for tremor management.

title: Real-Time SLAM-Guided Closed-Loop Photodynamic Therapy with Pixel-Accurate Light-Dose Control_supp1-3656777.mp4
authors: Sungwook Yang
publish: N/A
abstract: Precise light-dose delivery is essential for photodynamic therapy (PDT), yet current handheld systems remain operator-dependent and lose accuracy under motion. We present a SLAM-guided, closed-loop control framework that enables co-temporal and co-spatial photodynamic diagnosis (PDD) and PDT with a single handheld endomicroscopic probe, while enforcing pixel-level dose control. The probe integrates a fiber bundle that shares a common optical path for both PDD and PDT and is paired with a digital micromirror device (DMD) for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>m-scale pattern projection. An extended Kalman filter fuses optical-tracking measurements with texture-limited endomicroscopic images at 30 Hz, providing robust six-degree-of-freedom pose estimates that expand the probe's effective field of view and drive real-time pattern updates. A dose-map SLAM algorithm accumulates light dose over the reconstructed lesion surface during handheld scanning, while pixel-level dose control is enforced by referencing previously accumulated light at each location. Quantitative evaluation shows a spatial registration error between diagnostic and therapeutic systems within <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$5.2~\mathrm{\mu m}$</tex-math></inline-formula>. Experiments on fluorescence phantoms achieved sub-millimeter localization accuracy (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{0.3}~\text{mm}$</tex-math></inline-formula> RMSE), significantly outperforming vision-only and tracker-only baselines. Finally, tests on targets with quadrant-specific dose limits confirmed SLAM-based dose control, achieving dose uniformity within <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\pm 0.186~\mathrm{mJ/cm^{2}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> across millimeter-scale regions.

title: Multi-Modal Crime Scene Evidence Classification Using Transformer Networks
authors: Mohammed Fallah, Inti Laxmi Bindu, Deepak Kumar Gupta, Saidov Saydulla Abdikadirovich, Ghorpade Bipin Shivaji, Umidjon Musaev
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: This research proposed the use of a transformer for classifying the multiple form of crime scene evidence including images, audio recording, and textual description. The model got an accuracy of 91 percent on the test set of the evaluation. 5%, a recall of 94.5%, and a recall of 87.8%, and an F1-score of 91.90%, and outperforms other machine learning architectures such as CNNs and RNNs. The results prove that transformers can learn complex features and combine several modalities making them a powerful tool to improve the accuracy of crime investigation process. The study also shows the effect of class imbalance problem and as well an advantage of data augmentation to enhance the performance of the model. Based on the results obtained above, we are inclined to propose that transformer networks can greatly contribute to the development of forensic analysis by offering more precise and detailed crime scene categorization.

title: Scalable Synchronous Stochastic Gradient Descent for SVM Using Spark and Kubernetes
authors: Venkata Madhu Prateek Reddy Kambala
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: A novel approach to synchronous stochastic gradient descent (SGD) for support vector machines (SVM) is presented, leveraging Apache Spark for distributed computation and Kubernetes for container orchestration. This implementation resolves key limitations in existing Python-based frameworks, including suboptimal learning rates, collision-induced delays, and premature stopping. By introducing weighted gradient aggregation and a robust stopping criterion, the system achieves faster convergence and higher accuracy across distributed environments. The deployment process employs Docker for containerization and Kubernetes for efficient job scheduling and log management. Benchmarking on the Reuters Corpus Volume I dataset demonstrates improved scalability and consistency, highlighting the advantages of this Spark-Kubernetes integration for large-scale machine learning tasks.

title: Artificial dielectric waveguide for efficient traveling-wave MRI at 7T
authors: Zicheng Wen, Georgiy Solomakha, Stanislav Glybovski, Xiaotong Zhang, Yang Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: -Uniform nuclei-spin excitation via the circularly polarized transverse magnetic field (B<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sub><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup>) is essential for high-quality clinical magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). At ultra-high field (UHF, ≥ 7T), it becomes increasingly challenging due to the higher operational frequency ( ≥ 297 MHz) required for excitation, where conventional volume resonators fail to produce a homogeneous transmit field over the electrically large human body because of standing-wave effects. Traveling-wave (TW) excitation based on metallic circular waveguides offers a promising alternative, yet its clinical application has been hindered by low transmission efficiency and inhomogeneous field distribution caused by suboptimal waveguide modes, radiation losses, as well as phase-velocity mismatches. While high-permittivity dielectric waveguides have been proposed to enhance TW performance, their practical implementation is limited by the availability of suitable natural materials. Water-based dielectric waveguides offer improved field confinement and transmission efficiency, but they introduce MRI signal artifacts and are susceptible to long-term degradation, thereby limiting their reliability and clinical applicability. In this study, we present an artificial dielectric waveguide engineered to replicate the electromagnetic properties of a water-based dielectric waveguide while mitigating high weight and undesired MRI signal of the latter. The proposed design achieves efficient hybrid-mode conversion—over 95% of the magnetic-field energy in transverse components under unloaded conditions and about 80% under realistic loading—thereby improving power confinement and achieving 75% improvement in B<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sub><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> field efficiency compared with the classic TW method, as well as a 14% improvement in field homogeneity over a conventional single-channel system for human brain MRI at 7T.

title: Physics-Informed Neural Networks for Fast Thermal Simulation in Laser Wire Additive Manufacturing
authors: Larbi Yousfi, Amir Guizani, Moncef Hammadi, Slim Bouaziz, Mohamed Haddar
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Robotized manufacturing processes such as Wire Arc Additive Manufacturing (WAAM) and Laser Wire Additive Manufacturing (LWAM) are inherently multi-physics and governed by partial differential equations (PDEs). Classical numerical solvers (FEM, FDM, FVM) provide accuracy but are often too slow for mechatronic use cases like real-time monitoring, model-predictive control, or high-fidelity digital twins. This paper demonstrates how Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) can approximate transient thermal fields in LWAM by minimizing PDE and boundary residuals directly, eliminating the need for meshing or time stepping at inference. We provide a reproducible PINN implementation, an ONNX-exportable inference wrapper for deployment, and a companion ONNX validator that confirms faithful model export by comparing ONNX predictions against the trained PyTorch model outputs (MAE $\lt0.001^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$).

title: Age-Aware Incentive Mechanism for Differentially Private Federated Learning Using Stackelberg Game
authors: Maoqiang Wu, Zhentao Chen, Wanjing Chen, Min Hao, Hui Song, Yuanjia Su, Mingxiong Zhao, Shengli Xie
publish: 2025 IEEE 28th International Conference on Computational Science and Engineering (CSE)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL), as a distributed machine learning paradigm, enables clients to upload model updates rather than local data to enhance privacy. However, directly sharing model updates still risks privacy breaches. While Differential Privacy (DP) is commonly employed to mitigate privacy issues by injecting noise to perturb model updates, existing mechanisms often overlook the critical impact of time variation in privacy protection, namely Age of Information (AoI). Meanwhile, without reasonable incentives, clients are unwilling to join the FL under privacy risk. In this paper, we propose a novel age-aware incentive mechanism for differentially private FL. The FL uses the AoI-dependent DP, where the privacy budget dynamically decreases over time to reflect the diminishing privacy leakage of model updates. We formulate the incentive-design problem as a Stackelberg game, where the server acts as the leader and chooses the incentive, while clients act as followers and adjust their time-varying privacy budgets. Theoretical analysis confirms that the game can reach a unique equilibrium. Simulation results demonstrate that with the proposed mechanism, the server achieves the highest utility while enforcing age-aware privacy guarantees for the clients.

title: Secure Medical Record Encryption Using The CatBoost Algorithm
authors: Chettiyar Vani Vivekanand, M Mitesh Kumar, T Mithilesh
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The trend towards the digitalization of medical. records should have an intelligent and secure method of storing confidential. This paper presents a time-controlled encryption system that provides privacy and confidentiality of patient records only within a specified time. The suggested system relies on the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES-256) to encrypt patient data on attribute level to provide end-to-end data confidentiality when transmitting and storing data. In order to increase security control, limited time decryption key mechanism is used, in which the decryption keys are dynamically generated, timed, and automatically revoked after the allocated validity time. This will ensure that it is not accessed on a long-term basis or by unauthorized persons even after the expiry of the session by authorized users. The framework incorporates a secure key management facility that stores encryption keys, duration of validity and identity of users in an immutable datastore that is capable of providing traceable and auditable access control. Through experimental analysis, it is shown that applicability of the suggested encryption and timedkey validation system is well-resistant to replay and brute-force attacks and that it has low-computational overhead. The design creates a base on which machine learning-based authorization can be added in the future. In particular, the CatBoost algorithm will be introduced to the next stage and will allow providing adaptive, context-dependent access control according to user behavior and the sensitivity of the data. In general, this framework offers a solid and scalable methodology towards the attainment of fine-grained, time-sensitive, and smart security in electronic health record management systems.

title: Early Detection of Student Depression Using Deep Learning Algorithms
authors: R. Usha, N. Bala Krishna, Midigesi Mounika, Pemmana Sowmya, Sedji Vineetha, Palukuri Venkata Sai Surya Teja
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: This endeavor is designed to build a more advanced system. that applies deep learning techniques to detect early-stage depression in students. Growing concern exists for depression in educational settings and early identification facilitates timely intervention and support. The system looks at much data from students' responses to standardized questionnaires, behavioral factors like mood, sleep, social interaction, and school performance. For this purpose, the system applies Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) are deep learning algorithms. To automatically recognize complex and subtle patterns in the data that can inform about depression. Traditional methods fail to notice these patterns which makes this approach more efficient in detecting students at risk. The dataset is trained on a wide and complete dataset that integrates fully various emotional and behavioral factors to offer a sturdy and exact model. We measure these systems using important factors like how often they are right, how many relevant cases they get right, how few they miss, and their combination of both precision and recall to make sure they work well. We want to help schools get a tool that can find signs of depression in students early and reliably, to act more quickly and provide timely support. The system is trying to detect mental health issues in students and shed off the effect that depression negatively has on student's academic performance and personal development. An important contribution to the ever-growing need for mental health monitoring in educational settings for facilitating anything that boosts the happiness and achievements of students.

title: Fast Charging of Lithium Iron Phosphate Battery Using 3-Phase Interleaved Buck Converter and MCC-CV Method with Fuzzy Logic Control
authors: Epyk Sunarno, Eka Prasetyono, Suhariningsih, Mochamad Ari Bagus Nugroho, Rachma Prilian Eviningsih, Muhammad Taufik Maulana
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Lithium Iron Phosphate (LiFePO<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup>) batteries are widely used in electric vehicles and portable devices due to their thermal stability, long lifespan, and safety. However, fast charging remains a technical challenge. This study proposes an efficient and battery-friendly charging system using the Multistage Constant Current-Constant Voltage (MCC-CV) method. To enhance performance, a three-phase interleaved buck converter is employed, which reduces current ripple more effectively than conventional buck converters. The system is controlled using fuzzy logic to adaptively adjust the charging current according to the battery's condition. Test results show that the battery can be fully charged in 50 minutes with low current ripple of 5.92%. This system effectively accelerates charging without compromising reliability and battery lifespan.

title: The Mean of Multi-Object Trajectories
authors: Tran Thien Dat Nguyen, Ba Tuong Vo, Ba-Ngu Vo, Hoa Van Nguyen, Changbeom Shim
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing
abstract: This paper introduces the concept of a mean for trajectories and multi-object trajectories (defined as sets or multisets of trajectories) along with algorithms for computing them. Specifically, we use the Fréchet mean, and metrics based on the optimal sub-pattern assignment (OSPA) construct, to extend the notion of average from vectors to trajectories and multiobject trajectories. Further, we develop efficient algorithms to compute these means using greedy search and Gibbs sampling. Using distributed multi–object tracking as an application, we demonstrate that the Fréchet mean approach to multi–object trajectory consensus significantly outperforms state-of-the-art distributed multi-object tracking methods.

title: Building Information Modeling and Analysis Based on Big Data and Deep Learning
authors: Ruoyu Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the rapid development of information technology, big data and deep learning technologies have been widely used in all walks of life. In the field of construction, building information modeling integrates all relevant information of construction projects and is increasingly becoming an industry standard. However, traditional BIM technology still has limitations when facing the needs of massive data processing and intelligent analysis and decision-making. In response to this challenge, this paper first deeply explores the application background of big data and deep learning technology in BIM, and analyzes the shortcomings of current research. Subsequently, this paper studies the BIM modeling and analysis method based on big data and deep learning. This method uses big data and deep learning algorithms to optimize the building information modeling and analysis process. Through experimental verification, the BIM modeling accuracy is above 0.94, and it has shown significant advantages in intelligent analysis and decision-making, opening up a new path for the performance improvement and intelligent application of BIM technology.

title: From Crisis to Control: Innovations in Disaster Management Ecosystem
authors: R. Banu Prakash, Caprisha Vijay, Vidhyaatharan NRK, Vishali R
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Significant weaknesses of the current disaster management systems were seen in the Wayanad landslide that happened in 2024 in Kerala, mainly the long response times for the recovery plan and the absence of fast risk assessments were observed as the drawbacks of the existing system, Approximately 60% of the emergency calls during the incident were ignored and they were answered very late. As well as the failure to prioritize the riskiest sites, more than 70% of the cases were not treated promptly. So the present technologies are not effective in prioritizing the emergency calls from the victims and are not able to provide real-time feeds of high-risk areas, which makes rescue delayed and inefficient. The Disaster Management Ecosystem (DME) fills important gaps in the existing system. This system combines a low-cost emergency communication device, a highly capable surveillance drone, and a Machine Learning (ML) model. The drones made it possible to identify high-risk areas using a live aerial feed of the disaster site, which gives a detailed geographical impact and a survey of the site. The emergency communication device has been made for communication and location tracking, leading to a quicker and more effective rescue effort. The ML model prioritizes emergency calls by severity, facilitating targeted rescue operations in affected areas. This integrated method aims to dramatically increase survival rates in future calamities by maximizing situational awareness and response times.

title: Smart Irrigation System for Precision Farming
authors: R Balamurugan, P Girishanth, T Dharshan, B Dhivakar, S Dharshan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Efficient utilization of water is a critical component of precision agriculture that seeks to maximize crop production while using minimum resources, including water resources. Conventional forms of irrigation typically rely on some quantifiable measure of manual control or a timed irrigation schedule to determine when to water, typically resulting in overwatering, loss of water, or inconsistent soil moisture status. Our Smart Irrigation System uses soil moisture sensors, temperature and humidity sensors, a microcontroller unit connected to wireless cellular network, and some logic, to generate a continuous cycle of acquiring environmental data from the field and making the appropriate irrigation decision in real-time. Our Smart Irrigation System is able to automatically turn on/off water flow through solenoid valves using information from the sensor data, while providing separate irrigation for different zones of the crop. Data is visualized using a cloud-based dashboard interface that allows a farmer to monitor and even control irrigation anytime and anywhere. Our experimental results indicate water savings and an overall improved crop yield consistency compared to conventional irrigation methods. Finally, it is a practical solution that is cost-effective and easily scalable while also being energy efficient, therefore providing a salient means of addressing agricultural irrigation in modern and precision farming contexts.

title: Revolutionizing Cloud Computing: Decentralized Scheduling with Federated Learning for Enhanced Resource Utilization
authors: Damayanthi A, Amit Lathigara, Rajanikanth Aluvalu, M. Giridhar Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: In cloud computing, where workloads are constantly changing and resources are limited, efficient task scheduling is a major challenge that requires significant solutions to maximise performance and minimise expense. When dealing with sensitive or dispersed datasets, traditional centralised schedulers frequently encounter problems with data privacy and scalability. This research offers a new approach to cloud computing scheduling by using Federated Learning (FL) to facilitate decentralised, pre-decentralised collaboration among cloud nodes, which should help with these issues. This architecture allows numerous users or cloud servers to secure sensitive workloads or resource data while training a shared scheduling model. To solve significant problems, including significantation efficiency, model convergence, and non-IID (non-independent and identically distributed) data, the suggested system uses cutting-edge FL approaches. Before this, ECSA–the Enhanced Crowd Search Algorithm–was responsible for allocating cloud computing resources to minimise makespan and task utilisation. The solution guarantees efficient allocation of tasks, faster execution times, and better use of resources by incorporating resource-aware scheduling rules into the FL paradigm. Test results in virtualised cloud environments show that the framework may improve scheduling efficiency while protecting user data. This study demonstrates how federated learning can transform cloud computing by implementing intelligent scheduling solutions that are secure, scalable, and federated. Future studies will optimise communication protocols, expand the framework to accommodate heterogeneous cloud settings, and enhance decision-making capabilities through reinforcement learning approaches. This research highlights FL's significance as a game-changing technique for improving cloud computing infrastructure.

title: DeSecShare: A Secure Decentralized File Sharing System Using Encrypted Data Chunking and Distributed Node Storage
authors: N. Giridharan, S Sakthidevi, V Sree Gousalya, J K Shalini
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: DeSecShare is a proof-of-concept decentralized file-sharing system developed to overcome the privacy and security challenges of traditional centralized cloud storage. It protects data by encrypting files using AES, splitting them into smaller encrypted chunks, and distributing those chunks across independent storage nodes, ensuring confidentiality, integrity, and resilience. Only the uploader possesses the unique encryption key required to reconstruct and decrypt the file, preventing unauthorized access and eliminating single points of failure. Designed as a lightweight, education-focused framework, DeSecShare avoids the complexity of blockchain components seen in platforms like IPFS or Storj, while still demonstrating the essential principles of decentralized storage. Its modular chunk-handling process, transparent encryption workflow, and flexible node-level storage control make it accessible for students and researchers. This minimal- infrastructure design provides a practical environment for understanding decentralized concepts without requiring full peer-to-peer networking or token-based mechanisms, with potential future enhancements such as blockchain-based metadata management for transparent and immutable access control.

title: The Role of Generative AI in Shaping Student Behavior in Digital Information Search and E-Learning Process
authors: Jonathan Angelo, Marlion Malvin Chu, Joni Suhartono, Cadelina Cassandra, Erwin Halim
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Rapid improvement of generative artificial intelligence (AI) tools such as ChatGPT, Gemini, and others has significantly altered digital learning behaviors among students. While these tools offer personalized assistance and improved learning efficiency, their widespread adoption raises concerns about over-reliance and reduced cognitive engagement. This study explores the influence of academic and psychological factors, namely self-efficacy in academic self-efficacy, academic stress, critical thinking, performances expectations, positive experiences in using AI, and trust in AI on students' dependence of generative AI in the digital information search and e-learning context. This research is using Purposive Sampling Method by using structured questionnaire that distributed to 451 respondents in Indonesia from February to June 2025, with 445 eligible participants from the JABODETABEK (Indonesia) region who have used generative AI tools for academic purposes, the data was also analyzed with SmartPLS 4. The outcome indicates that ASE significantly correlates to academic stress and critical thinking, as well as performance expectations. On the other hand, stress on academics has a significant association on generative AI, while critical thinking does not significantly correlate with AI dependency. AI trust in generative AI and positive experiences are also highly related with the dependencies. Interestingly, performance expectation and academic self-efficacy do not significantly related to AI dependency, suggesting that emotional and behavioral factors may be more influential than rational expectations.

title: Spatio-temporal Transfer Learning for Urban Data Modeling
authors: Lin Wu, Shijie Li, Haoqin Li, Jiesheng Huang, Xin Lei, Huaiguang Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 28th International Conference on Computational Science and Engineering (CSE)
abstract: With the acceleration of digitalization, Spatiotemporal big data is becoming increasingly important in urban management. Current research primarily employs deep learning methods to model massive Spatio-temporal data, aiming to capture the operational patterns and intrinsic correlations of urban systems. However, data-driven Spatio-temporal analysis methods often suffer from high data dependency, limiting their generalization capability and prediction accuracy in data-scarce regions. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a transfer learning-based Spatio-temporal modeling approach, which effectively overcomes data scarcity by transferring knowledge from data-rich source domains to data-poor target domains. Extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets in transportation and power domains demonstrate that our model significantly outperforms all baseline methods in key metrics.

title: Interface Optimization Design for Elderly Hypertension Healthcare APP Based on Multimodal Technology
authors: Tianshuang Zhang, Peixin Song
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: The accelerating aging population in China has created an urgent demand for digital health management among elderly hypertensive individuals. However, existing healthcare APPs are not adequately adapted to the physiological (declining vision, hearing, and hand flexibility) and cognitive (reduced memory and learning ability) characteristics of the elderly. Problems such as cumbersome operations, unclear icons, and lack of functional and emotional support make it difficult to meet longterm management needs <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[2]</sup>. To address these issues, this study aims to enhance APP usability and user satisfaction by integrating multimodal interaction theory and elderly UI design principles, establishing a “requirements-design-validation” closed loop. Optimization strategies are proposed across five dimensions: Visually, improving information recognition through high-contrast color schemes, appropriate fonts, skeuomorphic icons, and modular layouts. Interactively, building a synergistic “voice + touch + haptic” framework, simplifying gestures, and incorporating feedback and error-tolerance mechanisms. Functionally, leveraging AI for blood pressure data interpretation, personalized medication reminders, and one-tap emergency assistance. Feedback-wise, covering the entire operation process, matching modalities to scenarios, and using plain language. Emotionally, care is conveyed through personalized encouragement, appropriate knowledge push and family affection linkage modules. This study optimizes the problems identified in elderly hypertension APP design, provides practical references for agefriendly medical product design, and supports the implementation of the “Healthy Aging” strategy <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[3]</sup>.

title: pH Sensing Performance of ZnO:CS on ScreenPrinted Electrodes (SPEs): A Green Technology Approach for Environmental Monitoring or Water Quality Applications
authors: Joselyn Nathania Cathrine Sembiring, I Dewa Putu Hermida, Indra Pardede, Diki Purnawati, Shobih Shobih
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: Sustainable fabrication routes are essential for developing the next generation of chemical sensors, particularly for environmental monitoring applications. This study presents the pH-sensing performance of ZnO-Chitosan (ZnO:CS) composites fabricated via a water-based screen-printing method as a green technology approach. Zinc Oxide (ZnO), a non-toxic and chemically stable semiconductor, was combined with chitosan (CS), a biodegradable natural polymer, to enhance film uniformity, adhesion, and ionic conductivity. Structural and morphological characterizations were conducted using X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). XRD results confirmed the hexagonal wurtzite structure of ZnO and the formation of an amorphous ZnO:CS composite, while SEM revealed a uniform film morphology with a thickness of approximately $60 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ and strong adhesion to the substrate. Three ZnO:CS ratios $(1: 2,1: 4$, and $1: 8)$ were tested in buffer solutions of pH 4, 7, and 10. All sensors exhibited excellent linearity, with sensitivities ranging from $-1.1 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{pH}$ to $-1.95 \mathrm{mV} / \mathrm{pH}$. The ZnO:CS 1:2 composition demonstrated the fastest response time $(22.2 \mathrm{~s})$ and consistent potential stability. These results highlight the potential of the ZnO:CS composite as a low-cost, eco-friendly, and reliable material system for potentiometric pH sensors, supporting the advancement of green technology for sustainable, real-time water quality monitoring.

title: Women's Safety App Based on Artificial Intelligence: Sound Anomaly Detection
authors: K. V Priyadharshini, M. Nitharshana, S. Prasika, S. Prithiba, M. Sowmiya
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The safety of women has become a very big issue in the present time due to the increasing cases of violence and harassment. Available safety gear, like helplines and manual distress calls, is typically constrained by slowness in responding and their dependence on external help. The proposed Safety Alert System to Women in this paper combines a mobile application that activates a sound anomaly detection and a live location sharing feature as its basic functionalities. The system is made in such a way that the mobile application automatically identifies the presence of strange or harmful sounds, such as screams or distress calls. After this, the system instantly triggers an alert and notifies registered guardians of the current position of the user in real-time. Both automated outlier-detection and continuous location monitoring ensure faster responses are ensured as well as enhancing surveillance, giving the women a more secure and reliable application to use to protect themselves.

title: Ensemble-Based Gold Price Prediction Using Super Learner
authors: K Sudarshan, S Sharan Karthik, K. Sudha
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Proper prediction of gold prices is essential as a risk management tool, portfolio optimization, and strategic financial planning- Gold is one of the most prominent assets in global financial markets because of its status as a safe-haven, inflation-hedge, and long-term value holding asset. To solve the intrinsic instability of large fluxes and a complex dynamic of the gold prices, the given paper proposes a complex pattern of a gold price prediction with the help of a Super Learner ensemble model which is the system based on several algorithms and able to take advantage of the strengths of each separately and reduce the drawbacks of each. The model integrates five different learners- Linear Regression (LR), Random Forest (RF), Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM), Support Vector Regression (SVR), and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) each having its own strength in terms of predictivity of the model owing to the types of assumptions that they make as well as their predictive algorithms. indexes, stock market indexes, and exchange rates. Each entity base learner would be trained on this augmented database, where the non-linear patterns and linear relations were capture, and the metalearner of the ensemble would cumulative these estimations in a stacking design with cross-validation to decrease overfitting and raise the degree to which it would represent the general population. The performance of the Super Learner uses extensive evaluation metrics, such as Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and Rsquared ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$), thereby validating the greater effectiveness of ensemble learning to address complex forecasting requirements within a financial setting.

title: Enabling Multi-Application Multi-Objective Autoscaling With Quick Analytic Hierarchy Process
authors: Ioannis Dimolitsas, Dimitrios Dechouniotis, Symeon Papavassiliou
publish: IEEE Networking Letters
abstract: Dynamic autoscaling in Edge Clusters must reconcile conflicting resource demands from multiple co-hosted applications within short decision intervals, as conventional single-application controllers fail to consider such inter-application competition. The computational cost of classic optimization and decision-making methods increases rapidly with the number of alternative resource deployments, limiting their real-time applicability for short control loops typical in 5G/6G environments with rapid demand fluctuations. This letter introduces quick Analytic Hierarchy Process (qAHP), a modification of AHP formulation that preserves the ranking consistency of AHP while reducing the priority vector computation to linear time with respect to the number of alternatives. We formally prove this complexity reduction, achieving identical decision outcomes to classic AHP, and we validate it through proof-of-concept experiments showing that qAHP enables real-time autoscaling, mitigates over-and under-provisioning, and achieving up to two orders of magnitude lower execution time compared to classic AHP.

title: Development of an Informative Dashboard for Electric Vehicles Based on The Kano Model and Integration of Human Machine Interface (HMI) for Battery Management Systems (BMS)
authors: Siti Yuki Lestari, Silvi Istiqomah, Huki Chandra
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: With increasing public awareness of sustainability and energy efficiency, battery-based electric vehicles have become an innovative and environmentally friendly transportation alternative. One of the important components in these vehicles is the Battery Management System (BMS), which requires a user interface to convey technical information in real-time and easily understood. This study aims to identify and classify informative dashboard features that influence user satisfaction using the Kano Model approach, as well as develop a battery condition monitoring feature to support driving efficiency and safety. A total of 17 dashboard features were analyzed and classified into several Kano categories. The analysis results show that no features are included in the Must-be category. Approximately 29% of features such as the speedometer and SOC gauge are categorized as One-Dimensional, which impacts user satisfaction. 47% are categorized as Attractive, such as mileage estimation and interactive maps, while 18% are categorized as Indifferent, which are features that do not have a significant influence on satisfaction. In addition, a prototype of the BMS balancing feature integrated with the Human Machine Interface (HMI) was developed. This feature allows users to monitor the condition of battery cells in real-time for more effective management. The results of this research are expected to form the basis for developing an electric vehicle dashboard that is informative, adaptive to user needs, and supports sustainable transportation.

title: Social Media Content Generation: An AI-Based System for Automated Viral Short-Form Video Creation
authors: Gautham B, K Somasundaram
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The prevalence of short-form video content on platforms such as YouTube Shorts and Instagram Reels has prompted the need for automated tools for extracting and optimizing viral moments from long-form video. This work outlines a fully realized LLM-based system that automatically identifies, processes, and augments viral video clips. The system combines yt_dlp for high-definition video extraction, Assembly Aifor speech-to-text transcription with accurate word-level timestamping, and LLM based workflow to identify high-engagement points. MoviePy and OpenCV are also used for resizing, formatting, and overlaying synchronized, word-level highlighted subtitles to maximize viewer engagement. By removing the need for manual editing, this system allows content creators and digital marketers to effectively repurpose long-form videos into high-impact, platform-optimized clips. This paper delves into the architecture of the system, challenges of implementation, and its future uses in the changing context of AI-based content generation and social media advertising.

title: A Fully Autonomous Mechanical Weed-Cutting Robotic System for Orchards
authors: Mohamed Abdelhafez, Ulrich Panten, Thorsten Hermes, Peter Hecker
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Weed growth around trees in orchards negatively affects tree health by competing for essential soil nutrients and providing shelter for rodents that damage tree roots. Traditional orchard weed control systems rely on tractor-mounted mechanical tools or chemical herbicides, both of which present operational and environmental drawbacks. In this paper, we present the design and control of an autonomous weed-cutting robotic system tailored for structured orchards. The proposed system integrates an autonomous mobile robot and a weedcutting mechanism attached to the robot with a photoelectric sensor and real-time velocity feedback from the robot’s autonomous navigation stack. When a tree is detected in the robot’s path, the mechanism executes a controlled circular retreat trajectory around the tree to remove weeds precisely in the problematic area. Unlike conventional mechanical systems, which rely on physical contact sensors and hydraulic actuators, our approach is fully electric, contact-free, and dynamically adapts its motion based on the robot’s instantaneous velocity. The system has been validated in an apple orchard environment, demonstrating its ability to autonomously remove weeds around trees during intrarow navigation without human intervention. This work represents a step toward sustainable and precise mechanical weed control in smart farming applications.

title: Brain Tumor Detection and Classification From MRI Using U-Net and Hardware Acceleration
authors: B Shrikrishna Udupa, Bhoomishree Gowda, Sadhana Shashidharan, Pavan A C
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Medical image analysis plays a vital role in the early diagnosis and treatment of brain tumors. Detecting brain tumors from MRI scans is a time-consuming process that relies on expert medical interpretation. To address this issue, we have introduced an automated pipeline that uses deep learning and machine learning techniques to detect and classify brain tumors. A U-Net model for segmentation was trained on MRI data to generate tumor masks. Morphological and statistical features of these masks were extracted and given as input for classification. The LightGBM classifier was used to classify the tumors into 4 categories - Glioma, Meningioma, Pituitary, and No tumor. Although image preprocessing using ADF+CLAHE was performed for visualization purposes, it was not included in the automated-pipeline. Additionally, for hardware acceleration, the convolution block of the U-Net model was implemented using the Vitis HLS toolchain and the IP block design was viewed in the Vivado suite. Our system shows promising accuracy and offers a balance between software flexibility and hardware efficiency.

title: Contextual Decision-Making Framework for Green Hydrogen Projects: Insights from Colombia Via FAHP
authors: Erika Alejandra Suarez Agudelo, José Sánchez-De-La-Hoz, Cesar Viloria-Núñez, Christian Manuel Moreno Rocha, Andrés Rodríguez Toscano, Rafael Ramírez Restrepo
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study presents a structured methodology based on the Fuzzy Analytic Hierarchy Process (FAHP) to identify and rank the most relevant criteria for the planning and execution of green hydrogen projects in Colombia. Drawing from a comprehensive literature review and the input of 129 experts from academic, industrial, governmental, and research sectors, five primary criteria-economic, environmental, technical, social, and risk - and 40 sub-criteria were assessed using surveys and fuzzy pairwise comparison matrices. The results show that the economic criterion is the most influential, with a normalized weight of 42.84 %, followed by environmental (28.06 %) and social (10.91 %) criteria. At the sub-criteria level, the most critical factors were operation and maintenance costs, return on investment, and the use of renewable energy sources to power electrolyzers. These findings reflect the prevailing priorities of stakeholders within Colombia's energy sector. The novelty of this study lies in its contextualized application of FAHP, which integrates expert judgment and fuzzy logic in emerging regions characterized by high uncertainty. Key contributions include the development of a replicable hierarchical model, empirical validation of decisive factors, and a decision-support tool to guide strategic planning. The model is recommended for informing public policies and investment strategies aimed at advancing green hydrogen deployment. Its adaptability further supports application in other Latin American countries with similar regulatory and infrastructural contexts.

title: EMIST- ML:Advance Malware Detection and Classification Using Embedded Malware Instruction and Machine Learning
authors: Tanu Jain, Sanjeev Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Targeted and sophisticated attacks can be collected using honeypots. Among them, the binary samples can also be collected on honeypots. However, the detection and classification of binary samples, as well as their attribution to cyber threat actors, are well-known research problems. Widely used signature-based approaches are unable to detect unknown malware attacks, which could be clean or suspicious files. Hence, those files need to be analyzed and labeled to prevent future cyberattacks. This paper proposes a new architecture for malware detection and classification that utilizes malware instruction sets and incremental machine learning. The proposed model is fully automated and integrated with a collection framework for identifying novel malware attacks via clustering and populating the unknown samples into these clusters. A prototype is selected to represent the entire cluster, and categorization of new binary samples is performed by labelling the prototype only. Detection of newly classified malware binary samples is performed by labeling the prototype of the entire cluster. It can be modeled as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$f$</tex> = n * p, where n is the given malware sample and p is the prototype of the cluster to which it is assigned. The proposed EMIST-ML model is validated using two datasets: i) Malheur, and ii) Real-world malware samples. The EMIST-ML model achieves 99.1 % accuracy using the Malheur dataset and 83 % accuracy using real-world malware datasets, demonstrating remarkable performance. The proposed EMIST-ML can detect unknown binaries that are not detected by anti-virus scanners, producing promising results in a live malware defense system.

title: Research on the application of visual inspection algorithm in SMT solder joint defect detection
authors: Zhensheng Chen, Wenling Lei, Yuhan Jiang, Qinghe Li, Hongjun Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper presents a real-time SMT solder joint defect detection system based on a lightweight YOLOv8 model, integrating digital economy and loT technologies. Using the RemiPi embedded board, the system captures and processes solder joint images on an SMT production line and detects defects like bridging, cold soldering, and missing solder. To improve small object detection, a Cross-Scale Feature Fusion (CFM) module and data augmentation techniques like Mosaic and Mixup are applied. YOLOv8's high speed and accuracy make it suitable for industrial defect detection. The system achieves 97.6% mAP@0.5 in PCB defect detection, a 2.1% improvement over the original model. It enhances detection efficiency and accuracy, integrates seamlessly with existing production lines, and applies green computing principles to reduce resource usage. The system lowers detection costs and boosts production efficiency, supporting the shift toward smarter, higher-quality manufacturing.

title: Application of Hybrid Genetic Algorithm-Based Fuzzy MPPT Controller for Fuel Cell Vehicles
authors: Fini Fathima, CH Hussaian Basha, J.N. Bhanutej, Muralikrishna Boddu, Santoshi Kanagala
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: At present, renewable energy sources are the most popular and are used in all of the hydrogen vehicles. The merits of nonconventional energy systems are low cost of implementation, very low ecological pollution, high sustainability unlike fossil fuels, very low harmful gas emissions, cheap cost, plus creating more jobs. Also, these systems are independent of the main grid. However, the main issue of these sources is less continuity in energy production. Here, the Solid Oxide Fuel Module (SOFM) is recommended to start energy production for hydrogen vehicles. The merits of this fuel module involvement are better energy production rate and convergence efficiency. Also, this fuel module operates a wide range of fuels, with less pollutant emissions, high scalability, plus more security in energy supply. However, the fuel module obtained output characteristics are nonlinear. So, the achieving of maximum voltage from the SOFS is quite difficult. Here, the most predominant Genetic Optimization fuzzy is referred to for catching the peak voltage point of the solid oxide electrolyte device. The features of this technology are low oscillations of voltage, high peak voltage identification speed, moderate design complexity, less convergence time, plus suitable standalone, and micro grid application. The proposed topology performance is studied by following the MATLAB environment.

title: WordTree: Hierarchical Word Cloud via Treemap Layout
authors: Yuanzhe Jin
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: Visualizing hierarchical text data requires balancing structural representation with semantic emphasis, which remains a challenging task. Traditional word clouds fail to convey hierarchical relationships, while treemaps, though efficient in spatial partitioning, are limited in expressing semantic features such as word importance. To address this issue, we propose WordTree, a novel visual design that combines word clouds with treemap layouts to represent hierarchical text data. By embedding word frequency visualization within the spatial structure of a treemap, WordTree effectively communicates both multi-level hierarchical structures and the relative importance of words within the dataset. Compared with traditional word clouds or treemaps, WordTree offers improved space efficiency, supports hierarchical exploration, and enables direct visual comparison across categories or subgroups. We demonstrate the effectiveness of WordTree through several case studies involving textual datasets such as news corpora and topic hierarchies. User feedback suggests that WordTree enhances understanding of data structure while maintaining a strong visual appeal.

title: Coconut: Multi-Level Collaborative Deployment for Real-Time Deep Learning Tasks in Heterogeneous Edge GPU Cluster
authors: Changyao Lin, Zhenming Chen, Jie Liu
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: With the rapid development of artificial intelligence, intelligent manufacturing factories usually deploy various deep learning models on some heterogeneous edge devices to process data or tasks generated by sensors. Scheduling these tasks in such a resource-constrained and heterogeneous edge cluster to satisfy their real-time requirements is challenging. Existing task deployment frameworks for edge clusters optimize at the model-level, lacking fine-grained resource awareness and concurrency control, where the urgent tasks are frequently blocked and miss their deadlines. Therefore, we propose a multi-level collaborative deployment framework Coconut for real-time deep learning tasks in the typical heterogeneous edge GPU cluster. Coconut collaboratively optimizes model deployment and fine-grained concurrency control. To address the high complexity of multi-level collaborative optimization, we employ an efficient learning-based search algorithm. Based on the operator-level information, we also pre-train an accurate latency predictor for each device, enabling centralized optimization to further accelerate the search. We implemented and validated Coconut on a real-world case of intelligent steel structure manufacturing. Compared with the advanced task deployment framework, Coconut improves the deadline satisfaction rate by more than 27% and the cluster GPU utilization by more than 18%. Coconut is an offline optimization framework with almost no additional runtime overhead.

title: Optimised Coding Technique for Low Power Network on Chip Applications
authors: Surya V.N. S. V. Chakka, Ravirala Sooraj, Peneji Vishnu Sai Revanth, M. Vinodhini
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Current computing systems require ever-increasing reliability, particularly as memory technology needs to cater for data-intensive and mission-critical applications. As the sizes of transistors are reducing and the densities of memory are increasing, the probability of memory cells being affected by transient faults, soft errors, and bit flips has dramatically increased. Even an error that is left uncorrected can cause catastrophic failures in the systems used in aerospace, automotive, medical devices, and cloud infrastructure. Error-Correcting Codes (ECCs) have become a key mechanism for protecting data integrity as well as system stability in hostile operating environments. In this work, we precisely focus on self-transition-induced errors, which are a growing class of faults related to internal instability in highly scaled memory cells. To overcome these challenges, we propose a Row-Wise Hamming scheme that significantly reduces redundancy through efficient row-level encoding and decoding. The design attains 100 % correction efficiency of burst errors up to the maximum of 5 bits, alleviating the localized and self-transition faults. Synthesis results show an impressive 82.35 % area reduction and 98.99% power saving, making our solution an efficient and scalable alternative to traditional ECC architectures of future memories. The whole design was carried out in Verilog HDL and used in the ModelSim environment. In addition, synthesis was performed using the Cadence Genus tool.
