title: From Requirements to Models: A Case Study of Large Language Models on Epidemiological Modeling
authors: Aaditya Karamchandani, Fatemeh Seyeddabbaghi, Marios Fokaefs
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Epidemiological modeling is a critical step in understanding and studying diseases. Although conventional modeling techniques exist, such as compartmental or agentic models, supporting tools are not necessarily standardized. Consequently, learning a new tool may take a significant amount of effort. In this work, we explore the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) as a means to quickly transition from requirements, in the form of graphical model representations and initial parameters, to a software-aided modeling platform with simulation and verification capabilities. Our methodology employs a metamodelbased language specification for prompt engineering, combined with multimodal inputs comprising textual descriptions and epidemiological diagrams. We evaluated LLM performance in three epidemiological models of varying complexity: a simple SIR compartmental model, a COVID-19 pandemic model, and an HIV transmission model. Initial results demonstrate the potential of LLMs to significantly reduce manual modeling effort while maintaining accuracy in structural representation and parameter extraction. The study provides insights into optimal input configurations and identifies key challenges in automated epidemiological model generation.

title: Evaluating Virtual Memory Algorithms in the UR-OS Simulator
authors: Gabriela Aldana, Valeria Arce, Santiago Jorigua, Samuel Flores, Pedro Wightman
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: The UR-OS operating system simulator is an academic tool designed to support the teaching and learning of concepts in the area of Operating Systems. This simulator incorporates a complex structure that emulates active elements of a computer system (processor, main memory, swap memory, interrupts) and of an operating system (process management, memory addressing, etc.). In its current version, UR-OS allows modeling virtual memory management algorithms, like First-in-First-out (FIFO), Least Recently Used (LRU), among others. The main characteristic of this simulator is that it is a very simple tool to work with and modify, and it is freely available for academic activities and research. In this work, two new virtual memory algorithms are introduced: Second-chance Least-Frequently-Used (SCLFU) and Least Recently/Frequently Used (LRFU). These techniques were tested over three distinct scenarios: sequential, random, and patterned memory accesses. Results show that mainly in random scenarios, both LFU and LRFU reduce the page faults in the testing scenario, compared to the rest of the algorithms.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Machine Learning Techniques for Predicting Clinical Mastitis in Dairy Cows Using IoT Sensor Data
authors: Zurisaddai Severiche-Maury, Sebastian Mercado-Martinez, César Viloria-Núñez, David Rivas-Lalaleo, Isaac Chagui
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study presents the development of a predictive model for the clinical diagnosis of bovine mastitis using real-world data collected from IoT sensors placed on the udder lobes. The CRISP-DM methodology was applied to structure the entire process. After careful data preparation and class balancing with SMOTENC, eight classification algorithms were trained and evaluated. Ensemble models, particularly Bagging and Random Forest, achieved outstanding performance, with overall accuracy close to 99 % and an almost perfect balance between precision and recall. In the deployment stage, an interactive system was implemented in Streamlit, allowing users to obtain mastitis diagnoses based on clinical symptoms. These results demonstrate how machine learning, combined with IoT, enables effective early disease detection in livestock production systems.

title: Optimized Machine Learning Models for Wind Power Prediction
authors: Mayta Cadena, Alex Cadena, Mario Jojoa-Acosta, Martha Bastidas-Salamanca, Alfonso Bahillo
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Within wind energy production, weather variables are a complex factor to address. Their random and unpredictable behavior makes their estimation for energy generation calculations fraught with difficulties and challenges. Machine learning (ML) techniques have emerged as a valuable tool in prediction systems; their potential to generate Artificial Intelligence (AI) based models provides fundamental support, and their implementation in power generation predictions taking weather variables into account is the subject of this research. To this end, three ML techniques were implemented: a neural network based on multilayer perceptron regression (MLP), support vector regression (SVR) and random forest regression (RF), implementing improvement techniques focused on modifying hyperparameters. To optimize the prediction results, the algorithm ensemble technique was used, specifically a stacking ensemble, in which the outputs of previously trained algorithms are combined to generate a more optimized prediction. The data used to implement the prediction algorithms were a combination of two information repositories: a SCADA system for active power data and weather data from the GIOVANNI satellite (NASA), from which meteorological variables were extracted from the same geographic location and measurement period. The best results for power prediction were obtained with the stack regressor and ensemble average models.

title: Immersive Virtual Reality Training for Smart Traffic Light Maintenance: A Serious Game Approach
authors: Marina Ricci, Nicola Mosca, Maria Di Summa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: This study presents a serious game concept in immersive Virtual Reality (iVR) for training maintenance personnel responsible for intelligent traffic light systems in smart cities. Following a Human-Centred Design (HCD) approach, the system aims to provide a highly realistic virtual environment reconstructed from 3D point cloud data. The training aims to enhance predictive maintenance competencies by integrating real-time monitoring data and simulating complex maintenance scenarios. Maintenance personnel will undergo theoretical and practical assessments to ensure effective knowledge transfer. The serious game model aims to increase maintenance efficiency and to offer potential scalability across other domains of urban infrastructure management.

title: Federated Learning With Energy Harvesting Devices: An MDP Framework
authors: Kai Zhang, Xuanyu Cao, Khaled B. Letaief
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Federated learning (FL) necessitates that edge devices conduct local training and communicate with a parameter server, resulting in significant energy consumption. A key challenge in practical FL systems is the rapid depletion of battery-limited edge devices, which limits their operational lifespan and impacts learning performance. To tackle this issue, we implement energy harvesting techniques in FL systems to capture ambient energy, thereby providing continuous power to edge devices. We first establish the convergence bound for the wireless FL system with energy harvesting devices, illustrating that the convergence is affected by partial device participation and packet drops, both of which depend on the energy supply. To accelerate the convergence, we formulate a joint device scheduling and power control problem and model it as a Markov decision process (MDP). By solving this MDP, we derive the optimal transmission policy and demonstrate that it possesses a monotone structure with respect to the battery and channel states. To overcome the curse of dimensionality caused by the exponential complexity of computing the optimal policy, we propose a low-complexity algorithm, which is asymptotically optimal as the number of devices increases. Furthermore, for unknown channels and harvested energy statistics, we develop a structure-enhanced deep reinforcement learning algorithm that leverages the monotone structure of the optimal policy to improve the training performance. Finally, extensive numerical experiments on real-world datasets are presented to validate the theoretical results and corroborate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms.

title: Design and Experimental Validation of mmWave Surface Wave Enabled Fluid Antennas for Future Wireless Communications
authors: Yuanjun Shen, Boyi Tang, Shuai Gao, Kin-Fai Tong, Hang Wong, Kai-Kit Wong, Yangyang Zhang
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: While multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) technologies continue to advance, scalability challenges persist. The fluid antenna system (FAS) offers position flexibility, significantly reducing its dependency on channel-state-information (CSI) spatial adaptation with only a single RF chain. However, most existing FAS studies remain theoretical and lack experimental validation. This paper presents two fully implemented fluid-antenna prototypes featuring dynamically position-flexible radiators. Enabled by surface-wave launchers, 3D-printed fluidic channels, and a fluid-control system, a single-channel and a double-channel fluid antenna are simulated, fabricated, and measured. The measured <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$S_{11}$</tex-math></inline-formula> confirms operation within the 24-30 GHz 5G mmWave band, and the radiation patterns exhibit spatial variations as the radiator position changes. Crucially, the novelty of this work does not lie in improving traditional antenna parameters such as gain or isolation; rather, it introduces a new communication mechanism in which position-flexible radiation reshapes the wireless channel to escape deep fading-something fixed antennas fundamentally cannot achieve. The results demonstrate that compact fluid-antenna designs provide a practical solution for future mmWave systems requiring reconfigurability and spatial adaptability.

title: Stage-Wise Analytical Modeling of the Stray Magnetic Field in Surface-Mounted Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors Under Mixed Eccentricity
authors: Hongwei Cui, Conggan Ma, Yanyan Wang, Xiangyi Li, Cheng Zhu, Guoqian Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion
abstract: Conventional subdomain methods face challenges in calculating the stray magnetic field of surface-mounted permanent magnet synchronous motors (SPMSMs) under eccentric conditions due to their inability to handle complex boundaries, leading to low computational efficiency. To address these issues, this paper proposes a cell-based Schwarz-Christoffel (SC) mapping method and a stage-wise calculation strategy to improve computational efficiency while maintaining accuracy. First, an analytical model (AM) integrating equivalent surface current, conformal transformation method is established. Based on magnetic field superposition, the load air-gap magnetic field is derived. Second, a stage-wise subdomain-based computational strategy is employed to decouple the magnetic field calculations for the air-gap region and the outer air region. The stray magnetic field is analytically modeled using SC mapping and separation of variables. Finally, the proposed method is validated through experiments on an 8-pole 18-slot interior-rotor SPMSM with mixed eccentricity. Results show that the TM achieves a computational error of only 3.49% and that the computational speed is 136 times faster than that of the finite element method (FEM).

title: Waiting Time Higher-Order Moments and the Distributional Little’s Law in the Discrete-Time M/G/1 Queueing System
authors: Sandra Lirio Castellanos-López, Felipe A. Cruz-Perez, Genaro Hernandez-Valdez
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper develops a unified and distributionally complete characterization of the discrete-time M/G/1 queue. Both the discrete-time Pollaczek-Khinchine formula for Bernoulli arrivals and the discrete Residual Lifetime Theorem are comprehensively addressed through a new proposed probability distribution, referred to as Infinite Mixture of Discrete Uniforms (IMDU), which provides an intuitive and mathematically consistent representation of the residual service time. For the waiting time distribution analysis, it is first shown that the idle period is identically distributed to the geometric interarrival time. Building on this identity, the Laplace Transform of the waiting-time distribution for Bernoulli arrivals with general service times is derived. Then, exact functional relationships between the moments of the waiting time and those of the discrete residual service time are obtained. Furthermore, using the distributional Little’s law, non-closed structural relation between the moments of the queue length and those of the waiting time is derived. The non-closedness is due to the staircase-like behavior of the expected number of arrivals in an ordinary renewal process. To make this relation tractable, the stepped-like function is approximated by a straight line whose slope and x-interception are determined minimizing the mean-square difference. Simulation and approximate analytical numerical results of the second (third) factorial moment of the queue length for deterministic, discrete uniform, and shifted Poisson service time show differences smaller than 0.242% (2.17%); in contrast to the substantially larger errors, up to 15.67% (42.4%), incurred by the Poisson arrival process approximation (x-interception at origin).

title: Lightweight Rice Leaf Disease Detection Method Based on Improved YOLOv8 Network
authors: Song Zhang, Xiaoyong Bo, Shuhao Zhang, Meng Yuan, Yi Zhang, Weidong Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The occurrence of rice leaf diseases will seriously threaten rice yield and quality. Timely and accurate disease detection is crucial for formulating effective prevention and control measures. Existing rice leaf disease detection methods have problems such as low variety detection accuracy, complex modeling process, and poor real-time performance on mobile devices. Based on these considerations, this paper proposes a lightweight rice leaf disease detection method based on an improved YOLOv8 network. First, the YOLOv8 network is optimized, and a lightweight convolution module and a channel attention mechanism are added to reduce model parameters and computational complexity. Secondly, spatiotemporal data enhancement technology and transfer learning strategies are used to enhance the model's adaptability to complex backgrounds and disease types. Then, in order to improve the detection experience, multi-scale feature fusion and adaptive anchor frame mechanisms are used. The improved model has an average detection accuracy (mAP) of 98% on a self-built rice leaf disease dataset, and can achieve real-time detection at 54 FPS. This method is an effective method for rapid and accurate detection of rice leaf diseases, and has important practical application value.

title: Deep Learning-Based Detection of Diabetic Retinopathy: A Comparative Study of CNNs and Vision Transformers
authors: Rahul Sharma, Nitin Singh Parihar, Karan Rautels, Nishant Singh Kaundal, Manoj Diwakar, Neeraj Kumar Pandey
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: This Diabetic Retinopathy is a condition which happens when there is a sudden increase in the blood sugar level of vessels which may lead to vision related problems. In this study we have tested the performance of CNN, ViT and their hybrid models. The dataset used is publicly available on Kaggle and the dataset contained around 35,000 retinal images which were divided into 5 classes namely No DR, Mild DR, Moderate DR, Severe DR and Proliferative DR. In CNN we tested 4 different architectures in which we achieved the best accuracy of 75.4% with Resnet50 architecture and with ViT model we achieved an accuracy of 83.9% and from the hybrid model we achieved an accuracy of 88.4% from the Resnet50 + ViT. The results shown by the models were promising but there were some gaps in the study. The dataset used was skewed towards NO DR class. For future work more balanced datasets with some data augmentation techniques could be used. Additionally, the study used only 50 epochs which can be increased in future work to use the model to their full potential.

title: D2D-SignalAI: An Optimized Device-to-Device Fading Signal Detection Framework Using AI-Based Techniques
authors: Ayushee Das, Bibudhendu Pati, Tanmay Mukherjee, Sujit Bebortta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Device-to-Device (D2D) communications have gained attention as a possible beneficial technique for situations involving next-generation wireless networks. Transferring data directly between two devices without the use of a server or central hub is known as D2D communication. In D2D communications, wireless fading significantly affects the quality and dependability of the communication link, leading to a number of problems, including lower signal quality, higher latency, lower throughput, and reduced coverage. In this context, it is important to propose a robust deep learning (DL) framework that can widely capture varying fading scenarios in D2D networks. In this work, a one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1D-CNN) is employed to assess the signal quality of the considered dataset (RadioML2016.10a) over D2D fading networks, acronymized as D2D-SignalAI. In addition, the proposed approach is compared with some well-known conventional algorithms on different performance metrics, such as accuracy and loss, to validate the efficacy of the proposed approach.

title: TransSE: A Transfer Learning-Based Predictive Model for Distinguishing Super Enhancers and Typical Enhancers
authors: Yin Shen, Xuan Xu, Shuaibin Wang, Tong Chen, Zihao Zhang, Qiaoyu Sun, Xuan Sun, Zhen Liang, Junxiang Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Super-enhancers (SEs), comprising clusters of transcriptional regulatory elements, play essential roles in gene expression regulation and cell fate determination. Current computational methods for identifying SEs from genomic sequences face challenges in prediction accuracy and cross-species generalizability. This study introduces TransSE, a deep learning framework combining convolutional and recurrent neural networks with cross-species transfer learning for SE prediction. TransSE employs a two-phase strategy: pre-training on combined human and mouse data to learn conserved regulatory features, followed by species-specific fine-tuning to capture organism-specific patterns. Evaluation on human and mouse datasets demonstrates that TransSE achieves superior accuracy compared to existing methods including SENet, DeepSE, and transformer-based models (DNABERT, Enformer), with AUC values of 0.828 (human) and 0.832 (mouse). Ablation studies confirm that convolutional blocks are essential for feature extraction, while transfer learning and recurrent layers provide meaningful performance improvements. Feature analysis reveals that TransSE distinguishes SEs from typical enhancers based on learned sequence representations, achieving 10.4-fold improvement in clustering metrics. The model demonstrates effective cross-species prediction capability, maintaining AUC <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\gt $</tex-math></inline-formula> 0.79 when trained on one species and evaluated on another. Conservation pattern analysis shows that TransSE integrates both evolutionarily conserved and species-specific regulatory features, enabling robust performance across organisms with limited training data. A user-friendly web interface (<uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">http://transse.shenlabahmu.com</uri>) provides automated SE prediction, motif analysis, and variant impact assessment. Case studies using experimentally validated SEs demonstrate the tool's utility for investigating regulatory elements and prioritizing functional variants in disease-associated genomic regions. TransSE advances the investigation of gene regulatory mechanisms and facilitates identification of disease-associated variation in enhancer regions.

title: Hill Climbing MPPT Algorithm with Buck Booster Converter in Solar Power System
authors: Shweta Goyal, Anisha Anil Jadhav, Preetham N. Raj, Meenu Prajapati, Samriddhi Gururani
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Improved maximum power point tracking (MPPT) performance can greatly boost the energy consumption of solar systems. For example, neural network controller, P & O, IC, fuzzy logic controller, hill climbing (HC), FOCV, FSCC, and so on. This method is provided by MPPT algorithms. In the present investigation, P&O and the HC approach for MPPT are modelled and simulated using the Buck Boost converter. Numerous strategies have been put out to maximise the electricity that photovoltaic modules can generate under a variety of meteorological circumstances. A MPPT technique for the solar system based on perturbation and observation was proposed in this work. MATLAB/SIMULINK is utilized to model and analyse the solar panel. A system of photovoltaic is linked to a DC-DC BBC. The MPP is the operational point at which a solar panel can generate its maximum power. The MPP of the PV panel stays constant despite variations in solar irradiation and cell temperature. Then, to maximise a PV system's power output, methods of MPPT are employed. As a result, P&O-based MPPT is created, and simulation results show that the P&O-based controller produces more consistent power.

title: GLOF Monitoring System in High Mountain: Evaluation of Latency Data Transmission and Precipitation Influence Trough IoT Satellite Network
authors: Robert A. Alvarado-Lugo, Jean P. Lujan-Leon, Jhean Aguilar-Bueno, Guido Silva, Juan de la Torre, Luis Torres Obando
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Glacier Lake Outburst Floods (GLOFs) pose significant risks in high-mountain regions, particularly for rural populations. However, the performance of real-time GLOF monitoring systems under varying meteorological conditions remains poorly understood. This study presents the development and evaluation of an IoT-satellite-based monitoring system designed for GLOF detection, with a specific focus on analyzing the impact of rainfall on data transmission latency. The system integrates rainfall and water level sensors, a CR1000X datalogger, and an ST6100 satellite transceiver, enabling automated data collection and transmission to the IsatData Pro web service. Preliminary results show that rainfall did not significantly affect latency (Spearman's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\rho=0.007$</tex>). In addition, the average latency was 22.9 seconds, with 95% of transmissions completed within 33 seconds, establishing a potential performance benchmark for similar systems. These findings support the refinement of real-time GLOF early warning systems.

title: AI in Enhancing Student Academic Performance: A Bibliometric Analysis
authors: Jehad M Shehab, Nurazmallail Marni, Diaya Ud Deen Deab Mahmoud Al Zitawi, Mehmet Akif Kılıç
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Over the past decade, artificial intelligence (AI) has gained remarkable traction in education, offering new ways to support student learning and academic performance. This study takes a closer look at how research in this area has evolved, using a bibliometric approach to map the trends, tools, and key contributors shaping the field. Drawing on 103 peer-reviewed articles published between 2015 and 2024 and sourced from the Scopus database, the study found a 650 % increase in AI-in-education publications between 2015 and 2021, underscoring a sharp rise in global research activity. Despite this growth, there remains a lack of consolidated insight into who is leading this work, what technologies are being explored, and where the field is headed. To fill that gap, this study applies the PRISMA framework to ensure a systematic selection process and uses tools like VOSviewer and Biblioshiny to analyze author networks, research themes, and citation patterns. The results show that countries like China and the United States are leading the way in AI and education research. Common themes include adaptive learning systems, machine learning, intelligent tutoring, and realtime feedback tools. Chatbots and virtual classrooms are among the emerging technologies gaining attention. However, the findings also point to ongoing challenges, such as ethical concerns, teacher preparedness, and digital inequality. By offering a big-picture view of the research landscape, this study helps educators, researchers, and decision-makers understand where <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A I$</tex> is having the most impact and where more work is needed. Future research should move beyond publication patterns to explore how these technologies are actually shaping learning experiences and outcomes in real classrooms.

title: ViGlauNet for Ophthalmic Intelligence: An Attention-Modulated Deep Framework for Glaucoma Detection
authors: A Alaimahal, S Vasuki, K B Aparjitha, R Harishma, P Balasri Ranjani
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Glaucoma leads as the major cause of irreversible vision loss, causing damages within the optic nerve that gradually leads to retinal ganglion cell attrition and results in structural changes of the optic disc in humans. The common type is Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma, related to an increase in the intraocular pressure where nerve damage can occur. There’s a significant genetic aspect to POAG. This study presents a deep learning system designed to classify diseased images from normal images using retinal fundus images. The images are first modified to $128 \times 128$ pixels. Then they are normalized to fit the model’s requirements. The dataset is categorised into training and testing sets. To improve the detection, a Convolutional Block Attention Module is added to the modified VGG16 architecture. Using a modified classification head with L2 regularized dense layers and dropout added to prevent overfitting, the last eight convolutional layers are unfrozen to allow for additional model training. An Adam optimizer, complete with a learning rate scheduler and early stopping, is employed to fine-tune the model. To evaluate performance, accuracy was measured, the confusion matrix and classification report were analyzed, the training curves were visualized, and stratified 5-fold cross-validation was employed. This approach with deep transfer learning models demonstrates attention mechanism’s capacity to assist in glaucoma diagnosis by utilizing the optic nerve head features, characteristics of the retinal nerve fiber layer, distinctions based on intraocular pressure (IOP), and automated classification.

title: Random Forest-Based Classification of Railway Wheel Defects: A Comparative Data Perspective
authors: Nurfitri Muhamad Nasir, Siti Armiza Mohd Aris, Tay Yung Yaw
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of machine learning performance in classifying defective and non-defective railway wheels using two datasets: (1) the original dataset and (2) an augmented dataset created by adding synthetically generated data to the original dataset. The study focuses on two distinct categories which are defective (all fail) conditions and non-defective (all pass) conditions, based on three key features namely flange thickness, flange height, and flange inclination (Qr). A Random Forest (RF) classifier was employed, and both datasets were evaluated under the same experimental pipeline using standard classification metrics including accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score. To enable a direct comparison, synthetic data was generated using Kernel Density Estimation (KDE), which produced additional samples for both classes while preserving the original statistical distribution. Results show that the classifier achieved 100% performance in both classes, indicating that the original dataset was already highly informative. However, KDE-based synthetic data augmentation is a preferred approach as it effectively addresses data scarcity and imbalance, thereby enhancing the reliability and future readiness of predictive models in railway maintenance systems.

title: The Role of Supervised Machine Learning in Industrial Cybersecurity: Detecting Protocol Anomalies and Counteracting Control Signal Tampering in SCADA Networks
authors: Suresh Kottur, Kannan Velusamy, Niveditha
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The major core infrastructure that is utilized in the complex industrial settings of today is known as SCADA systems, which is an acronym that stands for supervisory control and data acquisition. They keep a close eye on critical processes in a wide range of industries, such as manufacturing, water treatment, and energy transportation, to name just a few of the many sectors that they monitor. Some of the industries that they keep an eye on include. At this point in time, these systems are significantly more vulnerable to intrusions as a consequence of the fact that they are becoming increasingly connected to the networks of organizations and the internet. It is because of the fact that they are becoming increasingly connected to the internet that this trend is occurring. Protocol discrepancies and control signal tampering have been brought to everyone’s attention as two of the most severe hazards that might potentially occur. This information has been brought to everyone’s immediate attention. They are capable of altering the direction in which operations are carried out, causing physical processes to become chaotic, and causing considerable harm. Using labeled datasets that are obtained from SCADA communications, the research presents a comprehensive architecture that is used for the purpose of training supervised models that are able to discern between normal and aberrant communication patterns. This is presented for the goal of training supervised models. During the training process, the supervised models are taught to differentiate between normal and abnormal patterns of communication. This enables the creation of models that are capable of educating themselves using their own knowledge, which is a significant advancement. In order to identify errors at the protocol level as well as unauthorized changes in control signals, the framework makes use of techniques such as Random Forest, Support Vector Machines (SVM), and Gradient Boosting. These techniques are applied in order to discover defects. By utilizing these many ways, this objective can be successfully accomplished. In order to accomplish this specific goal, such methods are applied. These models are trained using real-world datasets, which include traffic from Modbus, DNP3, and IEC 60870-5-104. The training process itself takes place on these datasets. Performing this step is done in order to guarantee that the models are appropriate for the domain in which they are being utilized. A significant amount of attention is paid to the significance of feature engineering in this work.

title: Development of a Nomogram-Based Machine Learning Model for Predicting Urinary Calculi Risk Factors
authors: Renyu Zhou, Xiaoya Zhang, Yuannong Ye
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Urinary calculi is a common urological disease. This study aimed to build a prediction model for the risk factors of urinary calculi based on the nomogram in machine learning, providing a basis for the prevention and treatment of this disorder. The clinical data of 205 non-urinary calculi volunteers and 105 urinary calculi patients were finally included. The differences in basic clinical data between the control group (non-suffering) and the observation group (affected) were analyzed. Univariate and multivariate Logistic regression analyses were used to determine the risk and predictive factors of urinary uric acid calculi, and a prediction model for the risk factors of uric acid calculi was thus formulated. The calibration curve and ROC curve were used to evaluate the calibration and performance of the prediction model. The results showed that age, red blood cells, white blood cells, urate crystals, protein, ketone bodies, and platelets are the risk factors for urinary calculi. The area under the ROC curve of the prediction model is 1, indicating an ideal model. The calibration curve suggested that the predicted values of the independent predictive factors for urinary calculi are approximately consistent with the actual values. In conclusion, the prediction model constructed by age, red blood cells, white blood cells, urate crystals, protein, ketone bodies, and platelets has a high predictive value, which is beneficial for improving the early diagnosis ability of urinary calculi and achieving individualized prevention. Future studies can further explore the application of this model in clinical practice.

title: Multi-Objective Optimization and PID Control of Great Lakes Water Level Based on Time Series Prediction
authors: Xueqian Yuan, Jiayi Chai, Kai Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The Great Lakes, the largest freshwater lakes in the world, are crucial to the development of various industries, including transportation, fishing, manufacturing, and tourism. Fluctuations in water levels can significantly impact the economic interests of these industries. This paper presents a seasonal index prediction model designed to forecast future water levels with high accuracy, providing valuable information for decision-making. To assess the potential effects of water level variations on different stakeholders, a fuzzy comprehensive evaluation method is employed, capturing the complexity of the issue. We need to establish different functional relationships for different populations to increase accuracy and reliability, and then introduce a multi-objective optimization model to determine optimal water levels to reduce negative effects while maximizing stakeholder satisfaction. The Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) control algorithm is applied to regulate the outflow of the dam, ensuring that the water levels of the Great Lakes are maintained at the optimal level. To evaluate the robustness of the proposed model, a sensitivity analysis is conducted to assess how sensitive the algorithm is to changes in environmental factors, such as rainfall and temperature. By introducing efficient and simple algorithms, this model not only supports early prediction of water levels but also aids in balancing the competing interests of different stakeholders, promote sustainable economic growth targetedly, and finally maximize the overall economic benefits.

title: Restoration and Enhancement of Historical Images Using GAN-Based Super-Resolution and Facial Prior Techniques
authors: N Lohitha, Patcha Kirthi, Padira Anusha Chary, Nekkanti Rama Subhash, Priyadarshini Chatterjee
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Fields like digital preservation, surveillance, and recovery of old or damaged photographs all require the restoration of facial images. In this regard, the paper outlines an end-to-end fully automated automated enhancement framework featuring the integration of two advanced deep learning models—GFPGAN and Real-ESRGAN—for facial reconstruction and image upscaling. Real-ESRGAN for global image enhancement and texture detailing while GFPGAN for the reconstruction of severely degraded facial parts using facial priors. The framework intends user efficiency, Automated model weight downloads, model weight downloads for GPU acceleration, batch processing capabilities from a specified directory, and fully automated face enhancement are all features of the framework. In terms user performance feedback, the system has a built-in evaluation comparison module for the user, which places the original and processed images side by side for visual assessment of image quality. Built in Python using PyTorch for model inferences, OpenCV for image processing, and Matplotlib for output visualization, the system streamlines each processing step. The system has been designed for real-world applications, and experimental analysis on the framework with diverse facial images has demonstrated improvements in perceptual clarity and restoration of facial details.Facial image restoration is important in areas such as digital preservation and surveillance, as well as recovering old or damaged photographs. This paper presents an end-to-end fully automated enhancement framework combining two state-of-theart deep learning models—GFPGAN and Real-ESRGAN—for face reconstruction and image upscaling. Real-ESRGAN focuses on the enhancement of the details and textures on the whole image, while GFPGAN reconstructs facial elements, even when they are largely degraded, using facial priors. Designed with users in mind, the framework allows automated downloads of model weights, provides GPU-accelerated inference, and permits users to batch process from a particular folder in the system. The system performs both full image enhancement as well as adjustable face enhancement with minimal user effort required. To streamline the performance evaluation, a built-in comparison module displays the original and processed images side by side. The system is developed in Python where PyTorch is employed for model inference, OpenCV for image processing and Matplotlib for visualization of processed images. Experimental studies on various facial images confirm the combined approach enhances perceptual clarity, detail restoration of the face and is suitable to enhancement.Restoring facial images can be useful for digital preservation and damaged photograph recovery and for surveillance. This paper proposes an end-to-end automated enhancement framework using two advanced deep learning models—GFPGAN and Real-ESRGAN—for face reconstruction and image upscaling. Real-ESRGAN focuses on image scale and detail enhancement, while GFPGAN reconstructs facial features from highly degraded images using facial priors. The framework aims for user ease with automated model weights downloads, GPU processing, and batch processing from a given directory. It provides full enhancement of the entire image and face refinement with minimal effort on the user's part. To assess performance, a built-in comparison module allows users to view original and processed images side by side to make a qualitative assessment of the image quality. Built using Python, the system leverages PyTorch for model inference, OpenCV for image processing, and Matplotlib for image visualization to showcase results. Through different facial images, the experimental analysis confirms the combined approach offers a practical solution for enhancements restoring facial details and a significant improvement in their perceptual clarity.

title: ResAquaEnhance-Net: A Deep Residual Style Transfer Framework for Underwater Image Color Restoration
authors: Rajat Amat, Mourina Ghosh, Amitava Nag, Robin Pathak
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Because of color distortion, low contrast, and light scattering effects, underwater image enhancement is a difficult undertaking. In order to restore natural color and enhance the visual quality of underwater photos, this research introduces ResAquaEnhance-Net, a revolutionary deep residual style transfer system. The network gradually corrects color imbalance and improves structural details by using residual learning and a stepwise enhancement technique. The suggested methodology outperforms current methods in terms of PSNR, SSIM, UIQM, and UCIQE, according to experimental assessments on common underwater datasets. Even in badly deteriorated photographs, the model’s capacity to restore true colors and fine textures is confirmed by the visual results. An efficient and scalable method for reliable underwater image restoration is offered by ResAquaEnhance-Net.

title: Kantian-Utilitarian XAI: Meta-Explained
authors: Zahra Atf, Peter R. Lewis
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: We present a gamified explainable AI (XAI) system for ethically aware consumer decision-making in the coffee domain. Each session comprises six rounds with three options per round. Two symbolic engines provide real-time reasons: a Kantian module flags rule violations (e.g., child labor, deforestation risk without shade certification, opaque supply chains, unsafe decaf), and a utilitarian module scores options via multi-criteria aggregation over normalized attributes (price, carbon, water, transparency, farmer income share, taste/freshness, packaging, convenience). A meta-explainer with a regret bound <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\approx 0.2)$</tex> highlights Kantian-utilitarian (mis)alignment and switches to a deontically clean near-parity option when welfare loss is small. We release a structured configuration (attribute schema, certification map, weights, rule set), a policy trace for auditability, and an interactive UI. Artifact & Code (v0.1.0): https://github.com/ShabnamAtf/gamified-XAIsystem/releases/tag/v0.1.0

title: Diagnostic Performance of Key Anatomical Structural Magnetic Resonance Imaging Slices in Alzheimer's Disease: A Deep Learning Perspective
authors: Gihan Rangana, Tharindu Samaranayake, Nisal Jayathilaka, Uditha Wijewardhana, Mithara Induwara, Umaya Balagalla
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Early detection of Alzheimer's disease (AD) is vital for timely intervention, yet full volume MRI analysis is often computationally intensive and anatomically variable. This study presents the first comparative evaluation of four anatomically standardized MRI slice types axial lateral ventricle (ALV), coronal lateral ventricle (CLV), midbrain (MID), and anterior commissure-posterior commissure (AC-PC) aligned slices within a unified deep learning framework for multi stage AD classification. A lightweight CNN was trained separately for each slice type (ALV, CLV, MID, AC-PC) using 2D MRI data from 1,720 ADNI images spanning four diagnostic groups (CN, EMCI, LMCI, AD). The ALV slices achieved the highest balanced accuracy of 94.36%, while the AC-PC and MID slices also demonstrated strong performance with balanced accuracies of 94.10%. The CLV slices performed competitively as well, attaining an accuracy of 92.05%. These results highlight the value of anatomically informed slice selection for capturing early AD pathology. Furthermore, the findings validate that all four slice types ALV, AC-PC, MID, and CLV provide realistic and diagnostically meaningful representations for early stage Alzheimer's disease detection. This work demonstrates that slice-based Convolutional Neural Networks(CNNs) offer a scalable, interpretable alternative to volumetric models and provides practical guidance for integrating efficient, high performing neuroimaging strategies into real world AD screening workflows.

title: Woodpecker: A Locally Deployed Large Language Model for Protecting Sensitive Information via RAG and Semantic Recognition
authors: Yiwei Liu, Duo Li, Hu Wang, Pengpeng Zhou, Yuying Xie, Peng Yin
publish: 2025 IEEE 19th International Conference on Big Data Science and Engineering (BigDataSE)
abstract: In recent years, large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable performance in natural language processing tasks. Owing to their strong capabilities in language understanding and generation, they have been widely applied and increasingly deployed locally in domains such as education, healthcare, law, and classified information processing. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) models enable the integration of local knowledge bases with general knowledge bases, thereby producing richer, more accurate, and contextually relevant outputs. However, in scenarios involving classified or sensitive data, local knowledge bases often contain highly confidential information, raising the critical challenge of ensuring usability while preventing leakage. To address this issue, we propose the Woodpecker Model, a large language model designed for sensitive information protection. Built on the RAG framework, the model combines BERT and rule-based regular expression matching to achieve sensitive information recognition, balancing effective content generation with robust security mechanisms. For evaluation, we constructed a test set consisting of 400 general texts and 200 sensitive texts. Experimental results show that the hybrid approach of BERT and regular expression matching achieves higher recall and F1 scores than either method used independently. Moreover, in expert-based evaluations on 50 queries related to a local knowledge base, the Woodpecker Model achieved an average score of 3.7, significantly outperforming baseline methods in generating useful information. These results confirm the effectiveness and practical value of the proposed model in sensitive information scenarios.

title: Design and Development of BiMorph: A Multi-Terrain Dual-Mode Robot
authors: Piyush Kumar, Henin Dikson Paul, Ashwani Kumar Dubey, Gaurav Kumar Bharti, Angela Amphawan
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: This paper presents the design and development of a transformable BiMorph, a robotic system capable of both aerial and terrestrial operation. The system incorporates custom designed linear actuators with dual moving arms, each integrating drone motors for aerial lift and a single motor per side driving two wheels simultaneously, resulting in a 4-wheel drive configuration for ground mobility. Internal wire management was incorporated through the motor arms and body lift actuator to maintain an organized assembly, and airflow optimized openings were included to reduce thrust loss and improve efficiency. The prototype demonstrates the feasibility of combining aerial and ground locomotion into a single transformable platform, providing a foundation for further development in hybrid robotics applications.

title: Optimization of Energy Efficiency in MANET Using Adaptive Bio-Inspired Energy Optimization Algorithm (ABEOA) for IoT Applications
authors: P. Satyanarayana, P. Sushma, Mugada Sri Lakshmi Vani, Pitcheri Praveen Kumar, N. V. Phani Sai Kumar, V. Gokula Krishnan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Mobile Adhoc Networks (MANETs) are important in facilitating dynamic, infrastructure-free communication of Internet of Things (IoT) applications. Energy limitation of mobile nodes is however a major problem on ensuring reliable and extended network operations. In this paper we introduce a new energy efficient optimization algorithm called Adaptive Bio-inspired Energy Optimization Algorithm (ABEOA), which is specifically bent towards MANET environment. The suggested ABEOA combines adaptive clustering, optimal routing and load balanced data delivery to minimise the amount of energy consumed and keeping network connectivity and performance at optimal levels. The results of simulation carried out with different mobility and node density show that ABEOA reduces the amount of energy consumed, packet delivery ration, accuracy, and end to end delay compared to traditional algorithms such as PSO and ACO. The suggested approach is a very effective approach in achieving energy efficiency and increases the lifespan of the systems used in the operation of IoT-enabled MANETs and an efficient and viable solution to real-time and scalable IoT deployments.

title: Distributed Hybrid Beamforming Design for Cooperative Cell-Free Integrated Sensing and Communication Networks
authors: Bowen Wang, Hongyu Li, Fan Liu, Ziyang Cheng, Shanpu Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: This paper proposes a cooperative cell-free integrated sensing and communication network (CoCF-ISACNet) adopting hybrid beamforming (HBF) architecture, which improves both radar sensing and communication performance. The main contributions of this work are three-fold. First, we introduce a CoCF-ISACNet with energy-efficient HBF architecture. To show the benefits of proposed CoCF-ISACNet, we propose to jointly design the HBF to maximize the network communication capacity while satisfying the constraint of beampattern similarity for radar sensing, which results in a highly dimensional and non-convex problem. Second, to facilitate the joint design, we propose a novel distributed optimization framework called Proximal grAdieNt Decentralized Alternating direction method of multipliers (PANDA). Third, we further adopt the proposed PANDA framework to solve the joint HBF design problem for the CoCF-ISACNet. By using the proposed PANDA framework, all access points (APs) optimize the HBF in parallel, where each AP only requires local channel state information and limited message exchange among the APs. Such framework reduces significantly the computational complexity and thus has pronounced benefits in practical scenarios. Simulation results verify the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm compared with the conventional centralized algorithm and show the remarkable performance improvement of radar sensing and communication by deploying CoCF-ISACNet.

title: A Deep Learning-Enabled Framework for Driver Drowsiness Assessment and Forecasting With HRV Matching Based on Dual Optical Fiber Sensor System
authors: Qing Wang, Ke Li, Xiang Wang, Jing Qin, Changyuan Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Fatigue driving is a major cause of road traffic accidents and casualties. Automatically assessing driver drowsiness via vital signs monitoring offers an objective way to boost driving safety. Optical fiber sensors, which are small, lightweight, and resistant to electronic interference, are widely used in medical vital signs monitoring and intelligent transportation systems (ITS). This study proposes a novel dual optical fiber sensor system based on fiber interferometer, featuring high sensitivity, light weight, compact structure, and anti-electromagnetic interference, which accurately acquires raw ballistocardiography (BCG) signals of drivers in various environments. A robust deep learning framework, VSMformer, is proposed for signal processing: its STL module extracts spatial-temporal features from HRV data for graph modeling; a dimension-segmented embedding method and two-stage attention module (ETA) capture cross-time and cross-dimensional correlations; a hierarchical encoder-decoder module (EDSM) generates outputs. VSMformer analyzes BCG signals, predicts long-term drowsiness, and matches it with real-time HRV. Experiments show the mean square error (MSE), mean absolute error (MAE) and R-square (R<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{\mathbf {2}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) of experiments reach 2.311, 1.145 and 0.9845, respectively, outperforming state-of-the-art approaches. The sensor system provides reliable data, and both contributions enable high-precision drowsiness assessment, with great potential in portable vital signs devices and long-term driver drowsiness monitoring.

title: Experimental Investigation of Bacterial Cellulose Based Composites as Deformation Sensors
authors: Giovanna Di Pasquale, Salvatore Graziani, Sara Sadat Hosseini, Luca Patanè, Antonino Pollicino, Francesca Sapuppo, Carlo Trigona, Maria Gabriella Xibilia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: In this study, the open-circuit (OC) voltage and short-circuit (SC) current generated by composites based on bacterial cellulose (BC), when used as deformation sensors, are investigated. The BC sensors consist of a three-layer structure: a BC membrane impregnated with ionic liquids, and conductive polymer electrodes on the opposite faces. This configuration generates OC voltage or SC current when mechanically deformed. The frequency response of composites impregnated with two different ionic liquids is analysed. Using a swept sinusoidal input signal, both the generated OC voltage and SC current are investigated. More specifically, among investigated composites, the highest sensitivity for the generated OC voltage was 0.66 mV/mm. Regarding the SC investigation, the highest sensitivity was 0.099 μ A/mm.

title: Distributed State Estimation Method Based on Heterogeneous Filter Collaboration
authors: Zeqian Wang, Chichen Zhang, Jun Wang, Guangyong Liu, Guoqing Qi, Lijun Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: In target state estimation using sensor networks, conventional methods often face difficulties. These include nonlinear target dynamics, high communication overhead, and weak robustness against disturbances. This paper introduces a distributed estimation framework with heterogeneous filters. It combines the strengths of different filters to suit various operating conditions. The framework builds a multi-layered cluster of nodes. These nodes include standard Kalman filters (KF), extended Kalman filters (EKF), and particle filters (PF). Within each homogeneous filter group, the system applies a covariance-based fusion strategy. Between heterogeneous groups, it uses an adaptive fusion method driven by residuals. To reduce communication load, the framework avoids transmitting raw data. It also introduces a node activation mechanism based on trajectory nonlinearity. This mechanism decides which filter groups should run at each time. Simulation results show clear improvements. The method enhances accuracy and robustness. It also lowers computation and communication costs. These results show promise for real-world use and large-scale deployment.

title: Research on Longitudinal and Lateral Coupling Control of Autonomous Vehicles Under Low Adhesion Conditions
authors: Deyang Zhu, Xingwen Li, Feng Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: To optimize the motion behavior of autonomous electric vehicles when operating under low adhesion conditions, a vehicle cascade longitudinal and lateral coupling control method is proposed. Firstly, a vehicle dynamics model is developed, and the longitudinal and lateral front-end controllers are designed to ensure that the target driving path of the planning layer can be followed. Then, to compute the yaw rate and correct the yaw moment, a post-stability controller has been implemented. Carsim and Simulink software were utilized for a joint simulation to assess the vehicle's tracking accuracy and stability under low adhesion coefficients. The simulation outcomes indicate that, in comparison to uncoupling control, the peak deviations in the centroid side slip angle, yaw rate and trajectory tracking accuracy are reduced by about 45.3<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>, 38.7<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>, and 5.5%, respectively. The designed longitudinal and lateral coupling controller effectively improves the precision and stability of autonomous vehicle tracking in low adhesion environments.

title: Research on Optimization Algorithm of Phase-Sensitive Optical Time Domain Reflectometer Φ-OTDR) Technology in Communication Cable Security Monitoring
authors: Mingsi Zhu, Peigong Xie, Yuhe Zhan, Mi Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Phi$</tex> -OTDR signal optimization algorithm based on CNN, which improves the anomaly detection and positioning accuracy of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Phi$</tex>-OTDR system in optical cable monitoring through deep learning technology. Specifically, the algorithm first processes the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Phi$</tex>-OTDR signal through a multi-scale feature extraction module to remove noise and extract key information, thereby enhancing the ability to respond to small changes in the optical fiber. By designing a CNN, the signal features are further fused and classified to achieve accurate anomaly detection and positioning. The experimental results show that the proposed algorithm has good performance under various noise conditions, and the detection precision is 98.4%, which is 7.2% higher than the conventional algorithm. The location error of the optical cable is decreased to 5.3m, which is about 40% higher than that of the conventional Fourier transform. Furthermore, it is proved by experiments that this algorithm is robust and can work stably in dynamic environment.

title: A Fully Automated Agent for End-to-End Code Translation and Validation
authors: Eray Erer, Aysun Bozanta, Turgay Aytac, Ayse Basar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Migration of software across programming languages is a critical yet labor-intensive task, often requiring deep code understanding and manual intervention. In this study, we develop a fully automated agent for end-to-end code translation and validation. First, we generate code comments from Java source code using various large language models (LLMs) to enhance code comprehension and facilitate cross-language translation. Second, leveraging these AI-generated comments, we automatically generate equivalent C# code, demonstrating the potential of AI in software migration and interoperability. Third, we complete both Java and generated C# code and prepare them to execute. Fourth, we apply automated unit testing to assess functional correctness and ensure the reliability of AI-generated code. Our results show that a fully automated LLM agent may be effective in bridging programming languages with human-in-the-loop. This approach opens new possibilities for scalable, AIdriven software modernization and cross-platform development. We recommend that such an LLM agent should be used in tandem with human experts during the generation of a reliable and correct code.

title: A LCCL-N Compensated CPT System with Receiver Adaptive Characteristic for UAVs
authors: Junxiang Zhang, Zhigang Li, Wenjie Zhao, Guiming Zhang, Tingfa Yang, Zhao Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) frequently charge and fly away, which can make the receiver moving in/out in the wireless power transfer (WPT) system. To overcome the voltage and current surge caused by the moving in/out of the receiver, the LCCL-N compensated system with receiver adaptive characteristic is presented and analyzed in this paper. The structure without compensation on the secondary side is very suitable for UAVs, which can further reduce the weight of the secondary side. Based on the mathematical model, the CPT system can achieve the load-independent constant voltage with receiver, and also can achieve a very low input current without receiver. To verify the system performance, a simulation model is built in Matlab/Simulink. The simulation results show that a constant voltage output can be achieved, when the load resistance is between 20 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40 \Omega$</tex>. When the receiver move out, there is no voltage and current surge in the inverter and compensation inductors. In addition, when the secondary side move out, the proposed CPT system can keep in a low-power state.

title: Intelligent Audio-Visual Noise Reduction for Rail Transit: A Multimodal Collaborative Optimization Approach
authors: Tianyu Lu, Cong Jin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: This paper addresses the issue that excessive noise in rail transit affects passengers' comfort and audio-visual experience. Given the current situation where the active noise reduction function of headphones needs improvement, the innovation focuses on the two-way perception of headphones. That is, let the headphones respond to both environmental and content needs simultaneously, breaking through the single-point noise reduction thinking. It is envisioned that in the future, an intelligent audio-visual noise reduction system integrating big data, AI, and intelligent agent technology will be optimized to achieve specialized noise elimination for different film and television programs. This innovative concept is expected to partially solve the noise problem in rail transit, enhance users' riding experience, and bring about business model innovation and certain economic benefits.

title: An FPGA-Based Spectroscopic Gas Sensing System Enhanced by On-Chip Lightweight Neural Networks
authors: Zihuai Liu, Qinxue Nie, Zhen Wang, Wei Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Wavelength modulation spectroscopy (WMS) is widely used in various industrial applications to precisely detect gas concentrations, temperature, pressure, and other parameters because of its high sensitivity and signal fidelity. However, WMS has inherent limitations in specific scenarios such as residual modulation amplitude in harmonic signals, and is vulnerable to environmental changes. These restrict further improvements to the detection accuracy and stability. To address this issue, we develop a general detection framework for spectral signal analysis by implementing neural networks. The proposed architecture is extremely lightweight and suitable for easy deployment on embedded devices, such as field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs). To demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of this approach, we built a wavelength-modulation photoacoustic spectroscopy (PAS) system and deployed the neural network on an FPGA for real-time inference. We conducted experiments by measuring SF<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sub> gas samples with different concentrations. The accuracy and stability of the concentration predictions from the proposed neural network were validated against those derived from harmonic signals via the conventional WMS technique. The results demonstrate that our approach surpasses the detection limit of WMS by enhancing the technical performance by 57.2%.

title: AI-Driven DevOps in Modern Software Engineering—A Review of Machine LearningBased Intelligent Automation for Deployment and Maintenance
authors: Sai Raghavendra Varanasi
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The accelerated evolution of software engineering at the background has necessitated the inclusion of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in DevOps, which consequently introduces to the existence of AI-based DevOps, or, AIOps. Artificial Intelligence (AI) disrupts DevOps by adding automation, making deployments more effective, and optimizing software maintenance. This paper investigates how intelligent automation technological process driven by machine learning (ML) is revolutionizing software deployment and maintenance through speed, reliability and adaptability. It looks at how AI can help address historical issues of DevOps, including disjointed toolchains, lack of automation and delayed feedback cycles. An examination is conducted on major AI techniques and their functions in areas such as incident management, selfhealing systems, deep learning, reinforcement learning, supervised learning, and anomaly detection in predictive analytics. This study summaries the state-of-the-art applications, limits, and gaps in the present literature, which has also been thoroughly examined. Researchers and practitioners interested in improving software lifecycle management via intelligent automation may learn a lot from these findings, which highlight the need for a robust and extensible framework to fully use AI in existing DevOps pipelines.

title: Multi-Scale Quantized Joint Source-Channel Coding for Energy-Efficient Federated Semantic Communication in Heterogeneous Edge Networks
authors: Ke Wang, Lixin Li, Wensheng Lin, Lin Li, Kexin Zhang, Zhu Han
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: This paper proposes Energy-Efficient Semantic Communication (EESC) for the Federated Learning (FL)-enabled Semantic Communication system, addressing the high energy consumption and data privacy issues in traditional communication systems. This system uses Multi-Scale Joint Source-Channel Coding (MSJSCC) for efficient extraction and transmission of image semantic information. Each device trains a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with low-bit weights to reduce energy consumption and only upload the quantized values of changes in training results to the edge server, further reducing the energy expenditure during communication. Experimental results on the CIFAR-10 dataset show that EESC outperforms typical Joint Source-Channel Coding (JSCC) methods, improving PSNR by over 4 dB and reducing energy consumption by 31.46% compared to full-precision methods. Additionally, EESC demonstrates improved robustness under varying Signal-to-Noise Ratios (SNRs).

title: Research on the Construction of Energy Consumption Prediction Model of Chiller Based on Data-Driven
authors: Meikun Gui, Yi Chu, Yu Wu, Linhui Mao, Tao Sun, Lizhi Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: A model for predicting the energy consumption of chiller based on data-driven approach is put forward, which can enhance the efficiency of the chiller and optimize energy conservation. Initially, the research collected a large quantity of historical data during the chiller's operation, such as environmental temperature, cooling load, and cooling water flow. Relying on the random forest algorithm, this paper analyzes and constructs models for these data, and utilizes its powerful nonlinear fitting capacity to predict the energy consumption of the chiller. To confirm the validity of the model, a simulation system was devised to simulate the energy consumption of the chiller under different operating conditions. Through the precise data analysis of the simulation results, the model can effectively predict the energy consumption, and the prediction error is less than 5%. Furthermore, the random forest algorithm is more precise and stable compared with the traditional one. It is demonstrated that the data-driven random forest model can be utilized to optimize the energy efficiency of chillers.

title: Wireless System of FSR Sensors Encapsulated in Medical Silicone for the Diagnosis of Pressure Points in Diabetic Patients with Transtibial Amputation
authors: Italo Huaman, Jhan Martinez, Alvaro Tito, Franklin Cabezas
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Diabetes mellitus is a frequent cause of transtibial amputation, requiring precise fitting of the prosthesis to avoid ulcers and complications. The lack of diagnostic tools to identify critical pressures increases clinical risk and costs. In countries such as Peru, the price of a silicone prosthetic liner can exceed US$300, making it difficult to acquire. Faced with this reality, a wireless sensorized system capable of detecting pressure points effectively and affordably is proposed. The system acts as direct interface between the residual limb and the prosthesis, simulating real conditions of use. It uses FSR 402 sensors encapsulated in vacuum-cured medical silicone, connected to an ESP32 microcontroller that transmits data via WiFi to an interface developed in MATLAB. The platform allows visualizing pressures on a 3D model of the liner, identifying risk zones and recording data in CSV files. The results validate the technical feasibility of the prototype. The use of an operational amplifier increased the signal similarity to an ideal step by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$58 \%$</tex>, improving stability. The silicon coated sensors showed a reduction in pressure values compared to the sensors without encapsulation. Even so, both cases presented a good fit to the logarithmic model, with low RMSE errors (24.20 with silicone and 25.25 without silicone) preserving a stable behavior. In addition, the average latency was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$101.8 \pm 6.0 \text{ms}$</tex>, below the human perceptible threshold, allowing a real-time response. This system represents a practical, economical and adaptable solution for the clinical follow-up of patients with transtibial amputation due to diabetes.

title: Smart E-Commerce Recommendation System Using Data Engineering and Machine Leaning
authors: Muskan Sureka, Saurabh Bilgaiyan, Aadi Poddar, Mahendra Kumar Gourisaria, Sonal Jain, Sonika Padhi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Product recommendation in E-Commerce websites with the customers' purchase patterns over the years through online shopping is of the highest demand in the industries. These recommendations are based on their previous purchases over the years with their specific price point, location and the season of the purchase. This helps to increase customer satisfaction further, leading to maximizing the profits of the E-Commerce businesses. This paper draws attention to the product recommendation and prediction system based on the dataset including detailed customers purchase patterns over the years. Different ML classification techniques like Support Vector Machine, Random Forest Classifier, K-Nearest Neighbor, Logistic Regression, Gradient Boosting, XG Boost and Decision Tree were tested and trained on the dataset and comprehensively evaluated with F1-score, accuracy, precision and recall. It is found that Random Forest Classifier outperforms other models giving the best results in F1-score with a value of 0.99 and an Accuracy of 99.98%.

title: MFU-Powered RISC-V: Efficient Matrix Processing in a Pipelined Core
authors: Anusree C S, Paramasivam C
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Modern applications, include machine learning and computer vision, more and more count on efficient matrix processors have a hard time keeping up with the requirements for latest technologies. For this reason, we made a 5-stage pipelined RISC-V processor, by employing a MFU and a Matrix Register. An MRF file designed to support fast operations with matrices. 32 registers are included in the MRF, all holding four 5-bit signed as a result, two sharing nodes can be represented in a simple 2×2 matrix. It supports adding elements of matrices, as well as doing numerical multiplications, inversion, transposition and error handling for times when a matrix can't be inverted or the transaction is invalid. Also involves detecting hazards. By using forwarding, aim to prevent stalls within the pipeline and maintain reliable performance. A detailed testbench confirms that the design works properly Among the basic tasks, problems with overflow conditions and issues caused by data hazards. Implemented the processor built with Verilog. Static timing analysis is the process to Arranging both these factors, arranging closure and choosing the proper clock frequency. The design benefits from effective matrix processing, as shown by the results. efficient and reliant processes for jobs that heavily use matrices. Enhancements to the model could improve how inverse calculations are performed. and makes memory operations faster which improves performance in practical situations

title: A Measurement Approach for the Assessment of Indoor Multidomain Comfort: The MULTICLIMACT Experience
authors: Gloria Cosoli, Nibras Abo-Alzahab, Dianel Ago, Simone Murazzo, Rania Christoforou, Mina Moayyedi, Marcel Schweiker, Marco Arnesano, Ilaria Ciuffreda, Gian Marco Revel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The evaluation of indoor multidomain comfort is pivotal from a dual point of view: i) knowing the actual occupants' status enables taking actions for improving it; ii) personal feedback (both objective - inferred through sensors - and subjective - collected through surveys) can be exploited for a better management of the building. This work presents the results obtained from analyzing data collected in an experimental test campaign conducted on 15 healthy voluntary participants. Participants were not assigned a predefined task sequence but were observed during their normal office routine; this included activities such as typing on a keyboard, working at a computer, writing by hand, and using a mobile phone, to capture physiological and environmental signals in realistic working conditions. Data recording was performed in a room of 42 m2 while wearing a smartband (Emotibit) collecting diverse physiological signals (e.g., photoplethysmogram and electrodermal activity); furthermore, a multiparametric environmental sensor was positioned in the room. A survey on comfort (thermal, acoustic, and air quality) and related individual perception and affect (positive and negative) was administered to the participants at regular intervals. A BIM-based platform was used to perform the tests, administer the surveys, and collect all the signals from all the sensors (even when multiple subjects were present in the room). All the collected data were post-processed; after specific cleaning operations, relevant features were extracted from both physiological and environmental signals and used to train Machine Learning modEIS to predict the subject's multidomain comfort sensation; also, synthetic indices combining multiple spheres of comfort were defined to depict the global subject's comfort status. The proposed measurement approach can be applied to regularly monitor indoor multidomain comfort, enabling timely interventions in case needed, also providing early warnings and suggesting actions for improvement.

title: Beam Index Map Prediction in Unseen Environments From Geospatial Data
authors: Fabian Jaensch, Giuseppe Caire, Begüm Demir
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: In 5G, beam training consists of the efficient association of users to beams for a given beamforming codebook used at the base station and the given propagation environment in the cell. We propose a convolutional neural network approach that leverages the position of the base station and geospatial data to predict beam distributions for all user locations simultaneously. Our method generalizes to unseen environments without site-specific training or specialized sensors. The results show that it significantly reduces the number of candidate beams considered, thereby improving the efficiency of beam training.

title: Integrated Smart Sensing System for Continuous Health Monitoring Using IoT with Wireless Fidelity Enabled
authors: Dukhishyam Sabat, Prabina Pattanayak, Abinash Gaya, Prabhat Kumar Patnaik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Continuous health monitoring is of key importance in early disease identification, geriatric care, and disease management of chronic conditions. This article describes a low-cost, scalable, wireless fidelity (Wi-Fi)-based Integrated Smart Sensing System (ISSS) simulation model for non-invasive, real-time health monitoring via the Internet of Things (IoT). In other words, this system monitors critical physiological parameters like body temperature, heart rate, and blood oxygen saturation via a network of smart sensors coupled with a microcontroller and wireless module. Furthermore, utilizing Wi-Fi connectivity, the gathered data is transmitted securely to a cloud platform for real-time analysis and visualization. Continuous remote monitoring is supported with the proposed architecture, which makes it well-suited for in-home and clinical settings. A prototype was applied with commercially available hardware and tested under various scenarios. Experimental results verify consistent performance regarding data accuracy, latency, and energy efficiency. To the best of our knowledge, this is among the first simulation model for low-cost, open-architecture platforms to integrate IoT sensing with Wi-Fi for wireless, 24/7 physiological monitoring. This article also aims to develop an integrated sensing system for real-time health monitoring, leveraging IoT technologies and wearable sensors to continuously collect and analyze physiological data. In other words, the system is designed to improve preventive healthcare and remote patient monitoring, especially for elderly individuals or patients with chronic illnesses.
