title: Divide-Et-Impera Heuristic-Based Randomized Search for the Qubit Routing Problem
authors: Marco Baioletti, Fabrizio Fagiolo, Angelo Oddi, Riccardo Rasconi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: This paper introduces the DIRSH algorithm for the Qubit Routing Problem (QRP), using a heuristic-guided randomized divide-and-conquer strategy. The method splits the circuit into chunks and optimizes each one with a stochastic selection of gates and swaps. It balances global search, via restarts and adaptive tuning of bandit parameters with depth-sensitive local pruning. Tested on RevLib benchmarks mapped to the 20-qubit IBMQ Tokyo topology, DIRSH outperformed three LightSABRE variants across different time budgets, achieving shorter depths and fewer swaps. These results confirm that combining chunkbased decomposition with bandit-driven heuristics is effective for routing quantum circuits on NISQ devices.

title: Research on Situation Awareness Technology of Flywheel Energy Storage Subsystem Based on Matlab
authors: Luo Hairong, Ren Yong, Shen Ning, Li Feng, Jiao Long, Wu Meirong
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the development of smart grids and energy internet, the demand for energy storage in power systems is gradually increasing. Flywheel energy storage is irreplaceable in high-frequency, high-power, and fast-response scenarios, making it particularly suitable as an “energy storage buffer” for power grids, industries, and high-reliability facilities. It complements long-duration energy storage technologies such as batteries, promoting the efficient and stable operation of clean energy systems. Among these, the situation awareness technology of flywheel energy storage is the core to ensuring the safe and efficient operation of the system, as well as a key technology for maintaining safety, stability, and efficiency. This paper uses Matlab/Simulink to construct a simulation model of a flywheel energy storage unit and conducts simulation analysis on the power signal tracking capability during the charging and discharging processes. The results show that the flywheel energy storage unit model established in this paper can respond quickly to changes in power signals while ensuring that the output power consistently follows the given power, aligning with the operational characteristics of actual flywheel energy storage systems. This verifies the feasibility of the proposed method.

title: Simulation of a Medicine-Serving Robot Designed in Fusion 360 Using ROS and Gazebo
authors: Devanarayanan, Rajeshkannan Megalingam, Senthil Murugan
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The world's population is rapidly increasing and will continue to grow in the coming years. A considerable percentage of this population suffers from various diseases, with airborne diseases spreading particularly quickly. Providing proper medication to patients without direct interaction presents a significant challenge. This paper proposes an assistant delivery robotic prototype that is simulated and navigated autonomously in a ROS (Robot Operating System) environment. The robot analyzes its surroundings using LiDAR technology. The aim is to enhance autonomous healthcare delivery systems by improving navigation and object detection. The robot utilizes LiDAR sensors to capture a map of its environment, facilitating real-time detection of obstacles and its avoidance. The architecture of the system, hardware, its assembly and software components and the methodologies employed for environmental analysis are detailed. This prototype introduces a method to access the robot's environment. Future modifications can further improve navigation within the environment.

title: A-MARL: Agile Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Soft Real-Time Task Scheduling in Edge Computing
authors: Amin Avan, Akramul Azim, Qusay H. Mahmoud
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Modern soft real-time applications (SRTAs) impose heavy computational demands on embedded devices. While offloading workloads to Edge Computing (EC) resources is attractive, task scheduling remains challenging due to strict timing constraints, a vast search space, multiple conflicting objectives, and highly dynamic environments. Conventional heuristic and meta-heuristic algorithms struggle to adapt to these conditions. Although reinforcement learning (RL) suits dynamic environments, single-agent RL converges slowly on mediumand large-scale problems due to enormous action spaces and excessive exploration. We present Agile Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (A-MARL), which enhances Multi-Agent PPO by replacing conventional exploration with entropy-guided rule-based exploration. When policy entropy is high, A-MARL employs Shortest Processing Time (SPT) to guide exploration toward promising action space regions. This adaptive mechanism accelerates convergence and delivers schedules better suited for SRTAs in EC environments. Experiments on representative scenarios show A-MARL consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines across all evaluated metrics, demonstrating its effectiveness for SRTA task scheduling in EC.

title: Software for Simulating Path-Loss Models in 5G Scenarios
authors: Lina Cuta, Juan Muñoz, Herman Fernandez, Lorenzo Rubio, Vicent Rodrigo Peñarrocha, Juan Reig
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: The implementation of fifth-generation (5G) networks has posed new challenges regarding infrastructure deployment and the coexistence of different technologies. To understand how electromagnetic waves propagate in the frequency bands assigned by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) for 5G networks, it is necessary to study the path-loss (PL) models proposed by some researchers and standardization organizations. The transmitted signal is greatly affected by propagation scenario conditions. Therefore, it is necessary to develop versatile simulation tools that can predict and compare PL behavior in different scenarios. This paper presents the performance of PL versus the transmitter (Tx) and receiver (Rx) separation distance at 28 GHz, for urban microcell (UMi) environments under non-line-of-sight (NLOS) conditions. The paper discusses PL models proposed by the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP), the Millimeter-wave European Total Integration Solution (METIS) and the Millimeter-Wave Based Mobile Radio Access Network for 5G Integrated Communications Project (mmMAGIC). We also describe the behavior of PL versus distance and frequency, taking the UMi NLOS case given by 3GPP in the FR1 frequency range as a reference. These results were obtained through the development of a software tool that simulates PL models for 5G networks in urban, suburban, and indoor environments. The tool offers an intuitive and functional interface with which users can configure parameters such as frequency, distance, antenna height, and type of environment.

title: Leveraging IoT and Big Data Analytics for Sustainable Urban Mobility: Enhancing Marketing Strategies for Electric Vehicles
authors: Aishwarya D Shetty, Mohammed Waseequ Sheraz, Nissrein Babiker Mohammed Babiker, Abakar Ibraheem Abdalla Aadam, Nitin Zaware, Kunal Gaurav
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: As a more affordable and environmentally friendly option to traditional automobiles, electric vehicles, or EVs, are growing in popularity. But the transportation industry also faces additional difficulties as a result of electric vehicle (EV) adoption, particularly with regard to the provision of sufficient and dependable charging infrastructure. Through their own networks or alliances with other stakeholders, EV charging operators are the organisations that offer charging services to EV owners. Since they make electricity available and accessible to EVs, e-charging operators are essential to the EV ecosystem. Smart charging that supports renewable energy targets, overcomes infrastructure constraints, and advances sustainable mobility by enhancing user experience, reducing costs, and increasing confidence in electric vehicles becomes a feasible option through the use of IoT, AI, and big data analytics. This study aims to create a better Generative Adversarial Network model to create a synthetic electric vehicle data set. That will then be fed into ensemble machine learning algorithms that will predict the energy needed to charge electric vehicles. For synthetically created data for a few urban cities in Odisha, India, the upgraded Temporal Charge Generative adversarial network model yields Skewness and Kurtosis values of − 0.045 and − 0.170, respectively. These values are extremely similar to the city's fourwheeler electric vehicle charging data.

title: Evaluating Tidal Volume Variations Across Dimensions: Displacement, Diameter, Perimeter, and Area during Exercise - A Case Study
authors: Antonella LoMauro, Andrea Aliverti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: We have created surrogates of the estimation of tidal volume derived from wearable technologies and compared them with the volume, set as the gold standard. Because wearable technologies for respiratory health monitoring indirectly estimate the tidal volume according to different dimensions, we have considered surrogates in terms of displacement, diameter, perimeter, and area. We have shown that with increasing amplitude, the tidal volume estimated by vertical motion and antero-posterior diameter progressively overestimates the relative changes of volume variations, while the tidal volume estimated by perimeter and cross-sectional area progressively underestimates the relative changes of volume variations. These results need to be confirmed by a larger population to provide insights into the potential of wearable technology for respiratory health monitoring.

title: Design of a Trust Calibration Adaptive System for Human-Machine Interaction Interfaces Based on Deep Learning Algorithms
authors: Chang Ge, Xinyu Wang, Kanghui Ma
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: The growing prevalence of intelligent systems has heightened the importance of Human-Machine Interaction (HMI), yet the relationship between HMI design and user trust remains poorly understood. Current trust assessment methods, often reliant on subjective or post-hoc measures, struggle to capture trust dynamics in high-risk scenarios. To address the challenges of subjectivity and quantitative modeling, this paper introduces a deep learning-based method for predicting and calibrating user trust in HMIs. Our approach establishes a trust calibration model that identifies key metrics via the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and evaluates risk scenarios using a developed SRD function. A Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) generates datasets of design features, which are processed by a Bayesian updating-based calibration algorithm that implements both trust-enhancement and suppression strategies. A prototype for complex intelligent machinery demonstrates the proposed method. This study offers a novel solution for real-time trust measurement and provides theoretical and practical insights for data-driven HMI design.

title: A Design of Multi-System Integrated Communication Architecture for Unmanned Surface Vessels
authors: Shaodong Feng, Xuexiao Wang, Zhenghong Song, Yunhu Zhou
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: Remote communication capability is one of the important basic capabilities for unmanned surface vessel (USV) navigation and operation. This article conducts research on the remote communication requirements of USV. First, analyze the performance characteristics of five mainstream communication technologies, namely cellular mobile communication <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{4 G} / \mathbf{5 G})$</tex>, satellite communication, Beidou short message and AD hoc network, and clarify the differences among these technologies in terms of bandwidth, delay, coverage and cost. To fulfill the need of USV for transmitting of perception information and controlling orders, a multi-system integrated remote communication architecture is designed in this paper, following the principles of bandwidth matching tasks, reliability, redundancy, size and weight adaptation, and economy. This architecture includes Regular Communication Unit and Emergency Communication Unit. Meanwhile, an algorithm based on multi-index weighted evaluation, Logic of link switching, detail of Emergency Communication Unit are designed in this paper. Then, a prototype was designed and actual navigation tests of the USV on the sea were conducted. The test results have proved that the multi-system architecture designed in this paper can provide USV with more stable and better-performing communication services. Also, this paper lays the foundation for further integration of new communication technologies in the future.

title: Discrete Model Predictive Control for LCC-S WPT System Considering Input Constraints
authors: Hao Yan, Xiufang Liu, Yue Zuo, Dongxing Chen, Zixuan Huang, Panpan Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: For wireless power transfer (WPT) systems, the study of the control of load voltage and current is important in the case of variable output power requirements. In this paper, a Discrete Model-Based Predictive Control (DMPC) method with input magnitude and rate of variation constraints is proposed, which prevents the phase-shifting control signal from changing too quickly, causing the rectifier bridge to enter discontinuous conduction mode (DCM) in LCC-S WPT system, effectively mitigate the output current dead-zone phenomenon in resonant networks and achieves superior reference tracking performance for the load voltage. Furthermore, in order to better deal with the nonlinearity of the control variables, the Hammerstein model is used to characterize the system dynamics. Simulation outcomes demonstrate the efficacy and benefits of the proposed approach.

title: Deep Neural Networks for Brain Tumor Segmentation and Stage Identification
authors: U Mahalakshmi, D Meenakshi Sundaram, T Jaya, Srigitha S. Nath
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Brain tumors present a major clinical challenge because of their diverse structures and rapid growth. This makes it crucial to interpret MRIs accurately and consistently for effective diagnosis and treatment planning. Traditional manual analysis can be quite labour-intensive and often varies between different observers, which is why there’s a pressing need for automated and reliable computational tools. In this study, we introduce a comprehensive deep learning framework that combines an enhanced U-Net for tumor segmentation with a specialized CNN classifier to predict WHO grades using multi-modal MRI data. The segmentation module uses attention mechanisms, batch normalization, and residual connections to better define tumor subregions, including the Whole Tumor (WT), Tumor Core (TC), and Enhancing Tumor (ET). The identified regions are then classified into Grades II, III, and IV using a lightweight CNN designed for clinical efficiency. We applied extensive data augmentation techniques like intensity normalization, rotation, and elastic deformation to enhance generalisation, especially with limited training samples. Experiments conducted on the BraTS 2021 dataset show that our hybrid model achieves a Dice Similarity Coefficient of 0.925 for WT segmentation and a 93 percent accuracy in tumor grading. These findings underscore the framework’s potential to offer a robust, fully automated, and clinically viable solution for brain tumor analysis.

title: A Survey on Noise Mitigation Techniques in Powerline Communication
authors: S Kavvinguru, S Madhan, K Kumaravel, M Madhukiran, S Nagavinubalan, V Samuthira Pandi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Powerline Communication (PLC), where both data and power are allowed to be transmitted via the same channel, has applications in smart grids, home automation, and IoT devices. But due to the increase in data rates, it is affected by noises such as Impulsive Noise (IN), Cyclostationary Noise (CN), and Narrowband Interference Noise (NIN). These noises are responsible for the increase in Bit Error Rate (BER) of a system and, as a result, reduce the strength of the signal. This paper provides a review of PLC and how it evolved over the years. It includes the characteristics of noise in PLC, describes the different noise sources that occur in the system, and the reasons for the occurrence of each noise type. It is followed by the noise mitigation techniques that are applied to certain noise levels based on the nature of the noise. Additionally, it includes a summary of the mitigation techniques, which provides information about the selection of specific methods with respect to the type of noise that occurs in the system. A comparison section is also included that compares the mitigation techniques based on their characteristics. The novelty of this survey is the development of a noise-based selection of mitigation techniques that reduce the particular type of noise effectively instead of reducing all types of noise partially. As a result, the reader can learn about the evolution of PLC systems and advancements in noise-mitigation techniques, which help PLC devices work efficiently in changing noisy environments.

title: Evaluation of Models for Forecasting the Amount of Suspended Particles $P M_{10}$: Case Study of the VAAL 06 Station in Albania, La Guajira - Colombia
authors: Diego Restrepo-Leal, Maryam Carrillo-Reales, John Taborda, Miguel E. Iglesias Martínez
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study evaluates two models to estimate the temporary variability of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0}$</tex> micrometers breathable particulate material <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(P M_{10})$</tex> at the VAAL 06 station, located in Albania, La Guajira, an area with strong mining influence. Descriptive statistics techniques and temporary series models SARIMA and Holt-Winters were applied. Both models showed the ability to capture the seasonality and tendency of the data, nevertheless, SARIMA stood out for its mathematical simplicity, a smaller number of coefficients needed and greater ease of interpretation. The results reflect that the univariate approach is useful and sufficient for initial forecasts, but the limitation of not considering other environmental variables is recognized.

title: AI Applications in Architectural Design: A Bibliometric Analysis
authors: Abdalrahim Shehab, Khairul Anwar Mohamed Khaidzir, Heba A M Shehab
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is starting to play a major role in how we approach architectural and housing design. From improving efficiency to enabling smarter, data-driven decision-making, AI is changing the way buildings are imagined, planned, and constructed. This study takes a closer look at how AI is being used in this space by reviewing existing research through a bibliometric lens. Using the Scopus database, 637 articles were initially gathered based on keywords related to AI, architecture, and housing. After filtering by date range (2005-2024), language, and subject relevance, 106 articles were selected for detailed analysis. The PRISMA framework helped guide a transparent and structured selection process. To better understand the landscape, tools like VOSviewer and Biblioshiny were used to analyze keywords, citations, authorship patterns, and institutional contributions. Results showed a major spike in research activity around 2018, followed by a gradual decline. Common themes included architectural design, BIM (Building Information Modelling), machine learning, and generative design. China emerged as a major contributor, with universities like the Macau University of Science and Technology and Tsinghua University leading the way. The most influential articles often focused on combining BIM with AI, exploring deep learning models for design automation, and developing generative design solutions. Keyword and co-citation analysis revealed two main clusters one tied to traditional design methods and the other to AI-driven innovation indicating a growing connection between architecture and emerging technologies.

title: Adaptive Intelligent Indoor Layout System Based on Multi-Constraint Rule Engine and Genetic Algorithm
authors: Yi Fu, Jie Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: With the acceleration of global urbanization and the continuous improvement of residents' living standards, modern people have put forward unprecedentedly high requirements for the quality of their living environment and the expression of their individuality. Indoor space is no longer merely a place to fulfill basic living functions; it has become a core carrier that carries an individual's lifestyle, aesthetic preferences, and emotional needs. At the same time, the demands of user groups are becoming increasingly diverse and refined. However, the core challenge in meeting such highly personalized needs lies in the fact that indoor layout is essentially a complex multi-objective optimization problem. An ideal layout plan must coordinate numerous interrelated and even conflicting dimensions within a limited space: it not only needs to ensure basic safety and functionality, but also take into account environmental comfort and psychological feelings. To address this challenge, this paper designs and implements an adaptive intelligent indoor layout system based on a multi-constraint rule engine and an improved genetic algorithm. The core idea of this system lies in encoding the professional knowledge and design norms of human designers into a structured and computable multi-dimensional rule base, and through an efficient multi-objective optimization algorithm, automatically generating layout schemes for users that not only meet hard constraints but also conform to personalized soft requirements.

title: Recognizing Textual Entailments in Balinese Cultural Documents Using Biplet Individual Comparisons and BiLSTM
authors: Putu Wirayudi Aditama, Daniel Siahaan, Darlis Herumurti
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Recognizing Textual Entailment (RTE) is a Natural Language Processing (NLP) task that determines the logical relationship between two fragments of texts, such as premise and hypothesis into three categories, entailment, contradiction, and neutral. This study aims to determining entailment relations between Balinese cultural texts, which have complex language structure and rich context from the traditional literature and rituals. A deep learning model using BiLSTM with Biplet Individual Comparison is applied to capture the lexical and syntactic dependencies between words. Biplet representation is represented based on head-dependency relation and optimized with attention mechanisms. This model utilizes 1,208 pairs of sentences, consisting of 966 pairs of training data and 242 pairs of Balinese cultural sentences translated into Indonesian. Experimental results show that the proposed model outperformed existing solution. The training and validation accuracies are in 90.37% and 86.36% at epoch 10,98.45% and 80.99% at epoch 30, and 99.28% and 84.71% on epoch 50.

title: Spatio-Temporal Attention-Based ResNet for Change Detection by Analyzing Multi-Temporal Satellite Images
authors: V Praveen Kumar Bejagam, S. Maruthupermal, S M Roy Choudri
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Multi-temporal change detection has become an important in remote sensing technology, helping to monitor the environment and manage natural resources more effectively. It plays a key role in areas like city planning, farming, and responding to natural disasters. Existing methods, such as change vector analysis, pixel-based differencing, thresholding techniques on vegetation indices like Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI), and post-classification using support vector machines, have been used for years. However, these approaches often struggle to capture the full picture because they analyzes each pixel separately and ignore the surrounding pixel patterns. As a result, it may lead to less accuracy when detecting or classifying changes in satellite images. Therefore, this study aims to implement an efficient and advanced deep learning network-based change detection model using multi-temporal satellite images for determining the climatic impacts on the environment. The satellite images are collected from standard databases. Then, the collected satellite images are considered for the change detection with the development of an advanced deep learning network named Spatio-Temporal Attention based ResNet (STA-RNet) based encoder and decoder architecture. By analyzing satellite images taken at different times, it identifies and quantifies changes in the surface, helping us understand how climate change is affecting various aspects of the environment. The experimental analysis is carried out to analyze the proposed model's efficiency by comparing it with conventional techniques.

title: FileWizz: A Generative AI Based Multi-Format File Convsersion and Management GUI Tool for Enhanced User Productivity
authors: S Venkatraman, D Pushgara Rani, TJ Jeyaprabha, Sumneet Kaur Bamrah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: FileWizz is a multi-functional desktop application designed to simplify essential file operations such as format conversion, PDF manipulation, image processing, and compression with a specific focus on serving the academic community. This tool was developed entirely through prompt engineering using ChatGPT 4o mini, a generative AI model based on advanced natural language processing. The core motivation of this work is to explore the practical viability of using large language models (LLMs) to construct real-world utility software, without manual programming from scratch. While FileWizz does not implement machine learning internally, the software serves as a case study in AI-assisted software synthesis, highlighting the evolving role of generative models in rapid prototyping and zero-cost educational tooling. The outcomes indicate the feasibility of using generative AI agents not just for content generation, but also for scaffolded application development through iterative natural language interactions.

title: The Evolution of Game AI: From Basic Algorithms to Modular Systems
authors: Venkat Reddy Annapureddy
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: The gaming industry has seen a significant shift in the role of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in enhancing player experiences, transitioning from simple graphics-driven games to immersive, challenging environments. With the global gaming market valued at $ 148 billion in 2019, developers are increasingly relying on advanced AI to improve gameplay, challenge players, and create believable virtual worlds. Unlike academic AI, which focuses on task excellence, game AI prioritizes fun, engagement, and the creation of new genres. This paper explores the evolution of game AI, from basic production rule systems and decision trees to the widespread use of Finite State Machines (FSMs). We discuss the advantages and limitations of each approach, highlighting how the complexity and scalability of game AI have led to the adaptation of modular systems, which offer greater flexibility and maintainability. Furthermore, we examine how these AI techniques contribute to the gameplay experience and the challenges faced by developers in meeting the increasing demands of players and game engines.

title: Smart Traffic Management: Optimization and Analysis Using YOLOv8
authors: Keshav G. Tambre, Aryan P. Ghadekar, Arjun S. Gaware, Yash K. Gawande, Kirti A. Genge, Aditya D. Ghadge, Omkar H. Ghantalwad
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: Effectively managing traffic flow is of paramount importance, particularly for emergency vehicles such as ambulances that require expedited passage through roadways. In numerous urban environments, this system fails to operate efficiently. The process of altering traffic signals requires a significant amount of time, which can result in delays for ambulances. A prior research study employed the YOLOv3 model for traffic management based on vehicle density; however, its accuracy was found to be suboptimal. In contrast, the project utilizes the YOLOv8 model, which provides enhanced accuracy and expedience in ambulance detection. The development of the project was carried out using the Python programming language. The findings indicate that YOLOv8 surpasses YOLOv3 in terms of accuracy and prioritizing emergency vehicles, thereby facilitating faster arrival times for ambulances. The infrastructure of smart cities is being advanced by this program. Traffic lights are set up to change automatically when an ambulance is successfully detected, giving the vehicle an unobstructed path while minimizing delays.

title: Enhanced RF Performances of Fractal-Based 8 × 8 SRR Microstrip Antennas for S-Band Applications
authors: G Anitha, C Yashaswi
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This study investigates and compares the performance of a conventional 8 by 8 split ring resonator microstrip patch antenna and a novel 8 by 8 split ring resonator-based fractal array antenna, both designed to operate within the S band frequency range of 2 to 3 gigahertz with a 50-ohm characteristic impedance. A total of 80 antenna samples were analyzed, 40 in each group, using return loss and standing wave ratio as the primary performance metrics. Statistical evaluation was conducted using a predefined alpha level of 0.05, beta level of 0.2, and a test power of 80 percent. The simulation results showed that the fractal-based antenna significantly outperformed the conventional design. The novel antenna achieved a return loss of minus 30.2889 decibels and a standing wave ratio of 1.0631, compared to minus 19.1511 decibels and 1.2479 for the standard configuration. The performance differences were statistically significant with p values less than 0.005. These findings indicate that the 8 by 8 fractal array antenna provides better impedance matching and lower signal reflection, making it more suitable for S band wireless communication applications.

title: ForenXplorer:A Smart Digital Forensic Triage Tool for Fast and Automated Incident Response
authors: R Jagathbala, Gp Bharath Kumar, D Geethanjali, N Nanthini
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Cyberattacks grow in scale and sophistication, conventional forensic tools often fall short, lacking the speed, automation, and intelligence required for efficient incident response. Current solutions are fragmented, heavily manual, and incapable of real-time anomaly detection. To bridge these limitations, this project proposes ForenXplorer, an integrated digital forensic triage platform that unifies disk imaging, file-level investigation, and network behavior analysis within a single automated framework. A central capability of the system is its Support Vector Machine (SVM) model, trained on the CSE-CIC-IDS 2018 dataset, which identifies abnormal patterns in network traffic extracted from pcap files. Alongside this, the tool provides forensic disk imaging with SHA-256 hash verification, advanced file analysis with metadata extraction, signature validation, and malicious behavior detection. Developed using React.js for the frontend and Flask for the backend, ForenXplorer offers investigators a responsive and scalable environment for incident handling. By consolidating multiple functions into one intelligent platform, it minimizes reliance on disparate tools, accelerates investigation workflows, and enhances detection precision. Additionally, the system automatically compiles findings into a downloadable PDF report, outlining attack indicators, forensic insights, and recommended remediation steps. ForenXPlorer thus modernizes digital forensic practices by combining automation with machine Learning driven intelligence, offering a robust framework for faster and more reliable cybersecurity investigations.

title: Zero-Sum Games for Optimal Decision Making With Dynamic Performance Preferences
authors: Peijiang Liu, Xindi Yang, Hao Zhang, Zhuping Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: This article investigates a two-person zero-sum game for sequential decision making processes with dynamically evolving performance preferences. First, we incorporate this problem within a game theoretic framework, and establish the existence and uniqueness conditions for the temporal equilibrium strategy. Moreover, we present a compact formulation for one player's best response to the other's strategy. Furthermore, the specific convergence rate is achieved through the design of utility parameters. Finally, we validate our approach on the optimal liquidation and competitive supply chain models.

title: Internal Model Principle and the Cerebellum: A Treasure Trove of Inspiration for Control Theorists
authors: Mireille E. Broucke
publish: IEEE Control Systems
abstract: The cerebellum is a major brain region responsible for regulating and coordinating all movements of precision. This article gathers available evidence that the oculomotor system, a motor system believed to be the blueprint for all other motor systems, is supported by an internal model that subserves the internal model principle. An adaptive internal model design from the literature is then applied to recover the behaviors of this system. The cerebellum is also known to be responsible for training reflexes—adaptive feed forward inputs used for disturbance rejection. A two-time scale control architecture is presented to explain how the brain trains reflexes. The design highlights a broader principle of energy management in the brain: multiple controllers trade off their steady-state work to achieve optimal steady-state regulation. The article focuses on optimal steady-state regulation in which adaptive feed forward inputs and adaptive state feedback can offload the steady-state cost of operation of adaptive internal models.

title: OmniMamba: Omnidirectional Scanning Meets State Space Models for Efficient Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Qiyun Zheng, Taosheng Xu, Chenglong Zhang, Peng Li, Wenwen Min, Changmiao Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Signal Processing
abstract: Accurate classification of hyperspectral images (HSI) is crucial for earth observation and agricultural production analysis, yet remains challenging due to high dimensionality, spectral variability, and limited training samples. Traditional approaches often struggle to effectively balance computational complexity with the ability to capture spatial-spectral relationships of observation targets. To address this challenge, we propose OmniMamba, a novel omnidirectional state space model that adopts a collaborative alternation strategy integrating single-scale and multi-scale feature processing with omnidirectional scanning mechanisms. Four complementary scanning patterns (row, column, zigzag, and snake) are employed in the omnidirectional scanning mechanism to transfer 2D spatial data into 1D spatially structured feature sequence, which preserves directional sensitivity while achieving global dependency modeling with only linear complexity. This avoids the quadratic complexity bottleneck inherent in self-attention mechanisms. Our collaborative alternation strategy coordinates fine-grained spectral signatures with hierarchical spatial contexts through cascaded processing stages, addressing the spectral-spatial feature fusion challenge in HSI classification. Extensive experiments conducted on four benchmark datasets validate the superiority of OmniMamba, achieving a mean overall accuracy of 99.28%, significantly outperforming existing methods. Remarkably, our model accomplishes the performance with only 246 K parameters and 0.04 GFLOPs, demonstrating dramatically low computational complexity than the state-of-the art conventional CNN and transformer-based architectures.

title: Open RAN-Based Mixed-Timescale and Robust Task Offloading in Vehicular Edge Computing
authors: Mohsen Tajallifar, Nizar Zorba, Nader Mokari, Hamid Saeedi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Vehicular edge computing (VEC) emerges as a critical enabler of low-latency and computation-intensive vehicular applications by offloading tasks from vehicles to edge servers. However, the dynamic nature of vehicular networks introduces significant uncertainty in task characteristics and network conditions, posing challenges for efficient resource allocation. This paper proposes a robust task offloading scheme for VEC within the open radio access network (O-RAN) architecture. Leveraging mixed-timescale optimization, the proposed approach integrates large-timescale computational resource allocation (CRA), moderate-timescale task partitioning, and small-timescale radio resource allocation (RRA) using O-RAN's hierarchical control framework. The robust optimization model minimizes the network-wide resources while meeting the deadline of individual task execution latencies under demand uncertainty. We employ the cutting-set method to address the demand uncertainty in the large-timescale CRA. We obtain a closed-form solution to the optimal task partitioning problem. We adopt both the Lyapunov optimization and a heuristic approach for the small-timescale RRA, wherein we adopt the concave-convex procedure to resolve the non-convexity of the data rate expression. The efficiency of the proposed method is shown through extensive simulations. The results show that the small-timescale RRA succeeds to counteract the demand uncertainty at the large-timescale CRA, that is, no outage occurs when demands are in the assumed uncertainty set, whereas the non-robust scheme exhibits as high as <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$50 \%$</tex-math></inline-formula> outage probability. Moreover, our heuristic scheme is less conservative and consumes less resources than the Lyapunov optimization, and it consumes about <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$40 \%$</tex-math></inline-formula> less bandwidth than the conventional non-slotted robust solution.

title: New DGA Interpretation Method Using Specific Gas Limits vs Type of Faults in Power Transformers
authors: Michel Duval, Luc Paulhiac
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: When using existing standards and methods of interpretation of Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA) in transformers (e.g., IEEE, IEC, Doernenburg and other two-gas ratios), more than half of transformers get classified above status 1, requiring closer monitoring, too many for the limited resources of maintenance personnel. Furthermore, CIGRE TB 771 has shown that these standard methods do not consider the type of fault, which greatly affects the percentile values used as gas limits. The new DGA interpretation method proposed in this paper uses gas limits L1 and L2 specific for each type of fault and thus significantly reduces the percentage of analyses requiring closer surveillance. It also provides more precise information on the severity and location of faults occurring in the transformers, using advanced versions of the Duval Pentagons (2b, Unified) and Triangles (1b, 5b and 4) to identify sub-types of arcing faults in paper and in oil, and of carbonization of paper in specific places in the transformer. This allows users to assess the risk to transformers more precisely and take more appropriate action, such as removing or keeping the transformer in service. Free software is available to apply this new method automatically on any DGA database.

title: Oracles-Blockchain for Quotation Selection and Secure Healthcare Equipment Supply chain
authors: Shakshi Sharma, Shivani Pandey, Yash Sharma, Romita Khurana, Vinay Rishiwal, Latika Pinjarkar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: In the sector of healthcare equipment supply chain, the consumer initially requests quotations from multiple vendors through tenders and gives an order to the selected quotation. In this process, there is involvement of a third party which leads to favoring a few vendors, getting tenders in an unbiased or illegal manner which may result in high cost to the consumer. To overcome these challenges, in this paper, Oracles integrating with a blockchain framework have been proposed in which Oracles will select quotations from the database with a moderate price. The selected quotation details will be sent to the blockchain to track the supply chain through Smart Contract. The blockchain will track the supply chain of healthcare equipment and machinery from manufacturer to diagnostic centers, healthcare clinics, and hospitals. The proposed framework provides unbiased quotation selection and moderated price with a secure environment for the healthcare equipment supply chain. The manufacturer, supplier, distributor, and retailer are first authorized to participate in the supply chain network and later participants can trace the status of the order. To search the status of equipment, a webbased application integrated with the blockchain network has been deployed. The proposed framework has been evaluated on parameters: throughput, latency, and gas consumption.

title: Autonomous Navigation and Mapping of a TurtleBot in a Dynamic Environment with Random Obstacles
authors: Darika NS, Jonnala Thanishka, Killana Pavan Kumar, Aruna varshini N, Akhil VM
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: An autonomous navigation system for a TurtleBot3 robot operating in a simulated environment with randomly placed obstacles. The system integrates Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) with path planning using the Robot Operating System (ROS) and Gazebo. The robot explores a 3m x 3m area, avoids obstacles, and reaches randomly assigned goals. The traveled path is visualized as a dotted line in RViz, while obstacles are dynamically generated between one and ten per run. Performance evaluation indicates an average time of approximately 23 seconds to reach a goal under obstacle conditions. The proposed system demonstrates robust navigation and mapping capabilities, with potential applications in search-and-rescue missions and automated exploration.

title: Envirotech: Revolutionizing Waste Management with IoT-Driven Automated Segregation and Alerts
authors: D.M.Kalai Selvi, Roshini RS, Salini R, Shalini R, V. Sharmila, P. Ezhumalai
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: It is now vital to automate the separation of biodegradable and non-biodegradable trash due to the increasing in urge for waste management. The suggested system analyzes waste and divides it into groups that are either biodegradable or non-biodegradable using image processing based on Python. The technology employs voice commands to route waste to the appropriate dustbin after it has been classified. In addition to trash segregation, the system incorporates temperature and gas sensors to measure temperature variations and monitor environmental conditions in the waste bins. This helps to reduce dangers by ensuring that harmful gases, such as methane, are identified in time.The bin's design also includes a notification system that alerts users when it is time for disposal or when the bins are nearing the capacity. By integrating these features, the smart waste management system used to promotes recycling and also enhances public health and safety in urban environment. The bin's fill level is checked by an ultrasonic sensor, and all sensor data is sent to an IoT platform for real-time tracking that tracks the data and prompt waste pickup. By increasing resource recovery from garbage, this automated system lowers human error, increases waste management efficiency, and supports environmentally friendly practices.

title: Text to Image Generation Using Machine Learning
authors: O. Bhaskaru, Chukkapalli Ganesh Prasad, Kshama Kumari, Penugonda Surya Teja
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The synthesis of visual information from textual descriptions has been transformed by recent developments in gen-erative artificial intelligence, which have revolutionary potential in both the creative and computational spheres. In order to bridge the semantic gap between language and visual representation, this study investigates the construction of an automated text-to-image creation system using Stable Diffusion XL (SDXL), a state-of-the-art diffusion-based deep learning model. The suggested approach uses a pre-trained SDXL model to generate high-fidelity (1024xl024) graphics with scalable efficiency by methodically processing textual suggestions from a structured CSV input. The system enables heterogeneous execution across CUDA and CPU contexts and incorporates sophisticated memory management strategies, such as attention slicing, to maximize computational performance. Future modifications, including fine-tuning for domain-specific applications, are made easier by a modular ar-chitecture's assurance of extensibility. To guarantee traceability, reproducibility, and robustness across the pipeline-from model inference to output storage-rigorous logging techniques are in-tegrated. Empirical validation highlights the system's usefulness in creative design, synthetic media generation, and human-AI collaborative art by proving its capacity to generate a variety of semantically coherent visuals. In addition to offering a useful tool for generative tasks, this work encourages more investigation into the interpretability, controllability, and ethical aspects of large-scale diffusion models by making the implementation open-source.

title: Advancing AI for India: A Survey on Hierarchical Reasoning and Modular Enhancements in Large Language Models
authors: Manish Kumar Gupta, Lakshmi Panat
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have changed how computers read and write text. They are trained on vast amounts of data and can provide clear answers and perform multiple tasks. Rather than just expanding these models, researchers have recently begun including tools, retrieval techniques, and step-by-step reasoning. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), tool-using agents like Toolformer and ReAct, and planning techniques like Chain-of-Thought (CoT) and Tree-of-Thought (ToT) are a few examples. Models are made lighter and faster with the use of Mixture of Experts (MoE) and effective fine-tuning techniques such as QLoRA and AWQ. Multiple levels of reasoning that function at varying speeds are added by Hierarchical Reasoning Models (HRMs). This paper gives a clear explanation and comparison of these ideas. Additionally, it examines actual application cases in various Indian fields, including local languages, healthcare, law, education, agriculture, and governance. The study covers the benefits and drawbacks of multiple strategies. The key ideas are: (1) LLMs remain essential as the fundamental language engine; (2) tools and retrieval help in error reduction; and (3) hierarchical plans improve model thinking but increase system complexity. We conclude with suggestions for adapting AI to Indian languages and future research concerns.

title: A Novel Algorithm based on Ankle-Mounted IMU Configuration for Computing Spatiotemporal Parameters
authors: Giuseppe Prisco, Alfonso Maria Ponsiglione, Fabrizio Esposito, Sergio Lerma Lara, Paolo Gargiulo, Antonella Santone, Mario Cesarelli, Francesco Amato, Leandro Donisi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Gait analysis plays a crucial role in understanding human locomotion, with applications in biomechanics, rehabilitation, and clinical diagnostics. Optical motion capture systems represent the gold standard in the field of gait analysis providing accurate information about human movement although they have the limit to be expensive, time-consuming and limited to the laboratory. Recently, wearable sensors, based mainly on inertial measurement units (IMUs), have emerged as a promising alternative to optoelectronic systems, enabling real-world gait monitoring and in a simpler, faster and cheaper way. However, variations in sensor placement and in the type of inertial signal used to detect gait events can impact on the accuracy of gait parameter estimation. This study presents a novel algorithm for computing spatiotemporal gait parameters using angular velocity signals around the mediolateral axis acquired from two IMUs paced on the ankles. The algorithm was validated comparing its measures with the ones computed using a commercial wearable inertial system based on foot-mounted IMUs. Thirty healthy participants performed a 7-meter walkway protocol wearing IMUs on the lower limbs according to the specification of both methods. Gait events, including toe-off, mid-swing, and heel-strike, were identified, and five spatiotemporal parameters (cadence, gait cycle time, stance phase, swing phase, and double support phase) were calculated. The validation study was carried out using two-tailed paired test and Bland-Altman analysis. The results showed the presence of constant systematic errors in estimating the following parameters: cadence, stance phase, swing phase, and double support phase; while gait cycle time showed a good agreement between the two methods. However, a constant systematic error can be simply corrected by zeroing of the bias through a subtraction operation. In conclusion, the proposed algorithm can be considered a valid tool for gait assessment even if further refinements are needed to remove the constant systematic errors that occur in the spatiotemporal parameters estimation. Future development, considering all the components of both acceleration and angular velocity signals acquired from the two IMUs placed on the ankles, might improve the reliability of the proposed algorithm to compute spatiotemporal parameters.

title: Research on High-Frequency Data Processing and Economic Model Construction in Digital Currency Trading System
authors: Qiang Hao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a method combining machine learning and time series analysis to solve the problem of high-frequency data processing and economic model construction in digital currency trading system. Firstly, an efficient time series analysis algorithm is used to accurately predict and analyze real-time data to capture instantaneous changes in the market. Secondly, a multi-level economic model is constructed, which integrates factors such as market behavior, supply and demand dynamics, and price fluctuations. Then, the prediction ability of the model is optimized through machine learning algorithms, and trading strategies are adjusted in real time. Experimental results show that the proposed algorithm is superior to traditional models in both prediction accuracy and response speed, and can adjust trading strategies in real time, improve the accuracy of market trend prediction and the execution efficiency of trading decisions. In the simulation test, the model using this method achieved a prediction accuracy of more than 85%, which is 15% higher than the traditional method. At the same time, the optimization of trading strategies has increased the back test yield by 20%.

title: CFOA Based Oscillators: Four Novel Circuits Using Generalised Approach
authors: Saniya Rahman, Tajinder Singh Arora, Sudhanshu Maheshwari
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This paper presents four new sinusoidal quadrature oscillator circuits using current feedback operational amplifier (CFOA) as an active building block. Each of the circuit utilise five/six passive resistances and two capacitors only. The circuit is realised using three/four active element blocks and each circuit is capable of generating the quadrature outputs from its low impedance ports. All the utilised capacitors are either grounded or virtually grounded in nature. Paper includes the pen-paper analysis and software testing has been done through PSPICE simulations. The idea has also been validated through experimentation.

title: The Rise of Miniapps: A New Frontier with Security Challenges in Mobile Apps
authors: Yuqing Yang, Chao Wang, Zhiqiang Lin
publish: IEEE Security & Privacy
abstract: We examine mobile super apps that host third-party miniapps reusing platform services. Tracing their evolution to store-vetted runtimes, we develop taxonomies and threat models, identify security flaws and abuses, and propose guidance and research directions to strengthen super app ecosystems without harming usability.

title: Intelligent Surveillance Across Multi-Domain Environments Using Deep Learning Architectures
authors: Navitha R M, Jagadeesha R
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Today's surveillance systems need to do more than just record; they need to understand, react, and protect in real time in places like homes, schools, city streets, and corporate campuses. This paper talks about a unified deep learning framework that combines a number of smart functions, such as spotting objects and fire hazards, recognizing human actions, spotting drones and intruders, and flagging strange behaviour like falls or suspicious activity. We use models like YOLO, EfficientDet, MobileNetV2, ResNet-101, CNN-LSTM, ConvLSTM2D, LRCN, and I3D to learn about and study behaviour over time and space. The system can respond quickly and effectively, even in crowded or complicated scenes, thanks to attention mechanisms, skeletal tracking through Mediapipe, and edge computing. Testing in the real world shows that the system can recognize human activity with more than 98% accuracy and very few false alarms. In general, this method shows that there is a reliable and scalable way to meet the security needs of smart environments with intelligence and speed.

title: Deep Learning-Based Autism Spectrum Behaviour Recognition in Children Using Video and Audio Signal Processing
authors: Navonita Mallick, Shaswata Sahu, Hiranmaya Nanda, Parthasarathi Pattnayak, Tulip Das
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Approximately 1 in 100 children worldwide suffer from Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) (WHO, 2022). Although access to advanced diagnostic services is still restricted, particularly in settings with limited resources, early diagnosis improves developmental outcomes. By examining children's behavioral patterns from audio and video inputs, current research investigates artificial intelligence, in particular deep learning, for early ASD screening. A review of the literature combines models for feature extraction that combine gaze tracking, speech signal analysis, and facial emotion analysis. Multimodal analysis is made possible by open-source datasets, such as TESS/DE-ENIGMA (voice) and Aff-Wild2 (facial expressions). Important behavioral indicators like gaze aversion, flat affect, and delayed speech are recognized by CNNs and LSTMs. The results demonstrate that combining audio and video modalities improves detection, sometimes reaching over 85% accuracy. According to the study's findings, AI-powered technologies can offer scalable, reasonably priced ASD screening options.

title: Quantum Semi-Random Forests for Qubit-Efficient Recommender Systems
authors: Azadeh Alavi, Fatemeh Kouchmeshki, Abdolrahman Alavi, Yongli Ren, Jiayang Niu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: Modern recommenders describe each item with hundreds of sparse semantic tags, yet most quantum pipelines still map one qubit per tag, demanding well beyond one hundred qubits, far out of reach for current noisy-intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices and prone to deep, error-amplifying circuits. We close this gap with a three-stage hybrid machine learning algorithm that compresses tag profiles, optimizes feature selection under a fixed qubit budget via QAOA, and scores recommendations with a Quantum semi-Random Forest (QsRF) built on just five qubits, while performing similarly to the state-of-the-art methods. Leveraging SVD sketching and k -means, we learn a 1000 -atom dictionary (>97% variance), then solve a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \times 20$</tex> QUBO via depth-3 QAOA to select 5 atoms. A 100-tree QsRF trained on these codes achieves superior nDCG@10 with competitive AUC and Log-Loss on ICM-150/50.

title: Dual-Stage Reinforcement Learning-Based Beam Tracking for Integrated Sensing and Communications in V2I Scenarios
authors: Xinxin He, Zhiyong Yang, Dianang Li, Jie Zeng, Tao Jiang, Shanzhi Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: In integrated sensing and communications (ISAC)-enabled vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) scenarios, vehicles are modeled as extended targets, which causes an angle mismatch between the directions of the echo signal and the communication signal, necessitating accurate beam tracking. However, the rapidly changing propagation environment in V2I scenarios, along with the use of directional beams, makes beam tracking highly challenging. To overcome the above challenges, this paper presents a dual-stage reinforcement learning (DSRL)-based beam-tracking method for ISAC-enabled V2I scenarios. Specifically, in the first stage, the vehicle of interest is modeled as an extended target, and the codebook is designed by comprehensively considering the vehicle length, the antenna spacing, the beam angle, etc. Then, considering the mobility of the vehicle, a dynamic quality value (Q)-learning-based method is proposed for coarse beam selection, which aims to guarantee that the target vehicle is covered. In the second stage, considering the angle offset between the directions of the vehicle center and the aligned beam from the first stage, the deep Q-network (DQN) algorithm is designed to solve the fine beam-tracking problem. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed beam-tracking method outperforms existing methods in terms of the achievable rate and tracking time.

title: Enhancing Cybersecurity in Financial Systems Using a Stacked Ensemble Approach with Gradient Boosting and SVM
authors: Shammi L, Kanchana R, Chiranth M V, Sadhvi
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Cybersecurity breaches in financial systems are becoming frequent and complicated, but conventional detection techniques are failing to adapt to changing attack patterns and imbalanced datasets. The proposed study handles the significant issue of real-time fraud and threat detection in digital finance using a stacked ensemble learning approach. The proposed system integrates Gradient Boosting methodologies specifically XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost with a Support Vector Machine (SVM) to identify nonlinear and high-dimensional patterns in financial transactions. A Logistic Regression meta-learner is utilised to combine predictions from foundational models, improving generalisation and reducing overfitting. Preprocessing methods including SMOTE, entropy-based features, and SHAP explainability modules are utilised to enhance interpretability and model resilience. Comprehensive experimentation on benchmark Kaggle datasets demonstrates the proposed model's exceptional performance, attaining an accuracy of 99.31 %, precision of 98.94%, recall of 99.21 %, Fl-score of 99.07%, and AUC-ROC of 0.9987. The stacked ensemble presents significantly better data compared to baseline models such as Random Forest, SVM, and individual boosting algorithms, proving it very appropriate for scalable implementation in payment systems and fraud analytics. The proposed study presents an innovative, comprehensible, and extremely efficient approach to intelligent financial threat identification.

title: ShadowNet: A Deceptive Active Directory Honeypot for Detecting Targeted Intrusions using Splunk
authors: Prasanth K, Raseen Naveeth Hameed Sulthan, Nivetha Sivaraj, S. Praveen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Modern enterprise networks depend heavily on Active Directory (AD), making it a prime target for reconnaissance, credential theft, and lateral movement attacks. Traditional perimeter defenses offer limited visibility into these identity-centric intrusions. This work presents ShadowNet, a high-interaction deception framework that deploys a realistic AD environment designed to attract and profile adversarial behavior. The system integrates Sysmon-based telemetry with Splunk Enterprise for real-time log correlation, enabling precise detection of Kerberoasting, brute-force attempts, and other privilege-escalation techniques. Decoy accounts, service principal names, and bait resources create a controlled environment that captures attacker interactions with high fidelity. Experimental evaluation using simulated intrusions demonstrates sub- 3 -second detection latency, zero false positives, and complete visibility into attacker intent and sequence of actions. By combining deception, behavioral monitoring, and SIEM-driven analytics, ShadowNet provides a scalable and proactive defense mechanism that significantly improves early threat detection in AD ecosystems.

title: Advanced Non-Local Pipeline for Domain-Adapted Intelligent Power Device Defects Analysis for a Robust Traction Inverter in Next Generation Electric Cars
authors: Carmelo Pino, Francesco Rundo, Giulia Castagnolo, Massimo Orazio Spata, Angelo A. Messina, Michele Calabretta, Sebastiano Battiato
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Silicon Carbide (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S$</tex> iC) power devices are highly sought in modern power electronics for their superior performance; however, yield is severely impacted by crystal-growth defects often termed killer defects. Fast and accurate post-growth inspection of SiC wafers is therefore critical to identify such defects and improve manufacturing outcomes. We propose an improved YOLO-based one-stage detector that integrates a Non-Local Block + Gradient Reversal Layer (GRL) module into the YOLO backbone between the Spatial Pyramid Pooling (SPP) and BottleneckCSP layers. The Non-Local blocks enable the CNN to leverage global context in the microscopic images, improving its ability to recognize subtle defect patterns across the wafer. Meanwhile, the GRL-based domain adaptation allows the model to learn domain-invariant features, addressing distribution shifts between different datasets or imaging conditions. The proposed architecture, comprising these components, is evaluated on a dataset of SiC wafer optical micrographs containing various defect types to demonstrate its effectiveness (e.g., dislocations and stacking faults). The proposed method achieves mAP@0.5=95% and mAP@0.5:0.95=94.5%. These improvements demonstrate the efficacy of combining attention and adversarial domain adaptation in the YOLO architecture. The enhanced model detects <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S$</tex> iC defects with higher accuracy and robustness to varying imaging conditions, marking a significant step forward in automated wafer defect inspection.

title: Research on Visual Image Recognition Methods for Wushu Sanda Whip Leg Actions Based on Feature Extraction
authors: Liu Yinan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: As an essential component of traditional Chinese martial arts, Wushu Sanda actions have significant research value and extensive application prospects. This paper addresses the problem of visual image recognition for the whip leg actions in Sanda and proposes a recognition method based on feature extraction. First, by analyzing the mechanical properties and visual features of whip leg actions, a preprocessing and feature extraction scheme suitable for such actions is designed. Then, by integrating Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) with temporal sequence networks, an action recognition model combining spatial and temporal features is constructed. Finally, the whip leg action dataset is built to complete model training and performance evaluation. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms traditional methods in terms of recognition accuracy and robustness, validating its effectiveness and practicality. This study not only provides a new technological approach for Wushu action recognition but also serves as a reference for intelligent recognition research of other complex actions.

title: Development of the User Experience Questionnaire for Virtual Reality Applications in Healthcare (UXVR-H)
authors: Francesca Bruni, Elisa Pedroli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Virtual reality applications in healthcare settings require robust evaluation methods to ensure optimal user experience, particularly when targeting specialized populations such as older adults. Despite the proliferation of virtual reality-based interventions, current assessment instruments often present several limitations, as they typically focus on isolated aspects or were originally designed for conventional interfaces. This paper presents the development of the User Experience questionnaire for Virtual Reality application in Healthcare (UXVR-H), a novel questionnaire specifically designed to evaluate user experience when users interact with virtual reality applications in clinical settings. The multi-phase development process combined literature analysis, user-centered design approach, and expert consultation. We first conducted a comprehensive review of existing assessment tools, identifying eight crucial dimensions of virtual experiences in healthcare: usability and functionality, aesthetics of design, engagement, emotional state, motivation and intention of use, side effects, realism of environments, and presence. An initial pool of 271 items was systematically refined through two key phases: (i) a reformulation technique involving older adults to ensure item clarity and comprehension, and (ii) content validation by eight independent user experience and methodology experts. This rigorous process resulted in a final 24-item instrument with a 5-point Likert scale. This work represents the first critical step toward a fully validated assessment tool to establish reliability and construct validity. The UXVR-H addresses a significant gap in the field by providing a specialized assessment instrument that can enhance the design and implementation of virtual reality-based interventions in healthcare settings once fully validated.

title: Estimation of Affective Responses to Colombian Politicians using Physiological Signals. A Pilot Study
authors: Edder O. Quiñones-Burgos, Yina Cabarcas-Mena, Caleb D. Romero-Mercado, Raul Vargas, Yamil Ballestas, Wendy Gómez, Katherine Figueroa, María Piñerez, Eyleen Restrepo, Kiara Campo-Landines, Sonia H. Contreras-Ortiz
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Affective state estimation seeks to identify emotional responses using physical or physiological cues. In the political context, emotional responses are particularly impactful, as political figures and events can evoke strong feelings that shape public opinion, voting behavior, and civic engagement. The analysis of physiological signals can be a reliable method to estimate affective reactions to political information. This pilot study proposes a method for estimating affective arousal. Physiological signals were acquired from 20 subjects while they viewed images of Colombian politicians. Two signals were recorded: PPG and GSR using a wearable sensor. These signals were analyzed in the frequency and time domains, and various classification models were evaluated. The best model was found to be SVM, with an accuracy higher than 70 % for arousal estimation. The results of this pilot study demonstrate that the proposed method can be effective in estimating affective responses that could be used to predict voting behaviour or political opinions.

title: Performance Evaluation of Kalman Filter-Based Imputation for Water Quality Sensor Data
authors: Fito Wigunanto Herminawan, Eka Setianingsih, Riski Fitriani, Melyana, Khaula Nurul Hakim, Wahyu Cesar, Osen Fili Nami, Tsani Hendro Nugroho, Dito Eka Cahya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: Water quality monitoring systems provide critical data on environmental parameters such as temperature, pH, and dissolved oxygen (DO), which are essential for assessing and managing aquatic ecosystems. However, these systems are often affected by missing values caused by environmental stress, sensor drift, or transmission errors, potentially compromising data reliability and leading to biased analysis or suboptimal decision-making. To address this challenge, this study evaluates the performance of the Kalman Filter (KF) and Kalman Smoother (KS) for imputing missing water quality sensor data. Synthetic datasets were constructed with artificially injected gaps following the Missing Completely at Random (MCAR) mechanism at $\mathbf{1 0 \%}$ and 20% missing rates. The reconstructed data were assessed using Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) and Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). Results show that while both methods effectively handle missing values, KS consistently achieves higher accuracy, producing smoother and more reliable reconstructions. These findings highlight KS as a promising approach for improving the reliability of water quality monitoring data.

title: Exploring Center of Pressure Dynamics Across Age and Gender During Complex Postural Challenges
authors: Lorena Guerrini, Vittorio Santoriello, Federica Pescaglia, Alfonso Maria Ponsiglione, Vincenzo Minutolo, Hannes Petersen, Halldór Jónsson, Paolo Gargiulo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The Center of Pressure (CoP) is a widely used metric to assess postural control (PC). In this study, CoP data from 304 healthy individuals were collected during a balance task performed using the BioVRSea system. Spectral, non-linear, and temporal features were extracted to identify differences in PC strategies based on gender and age group (Over40 vs. Under40). For comparisons across phases, the Friedman test was performed, followed by the Wilcoxon rank sum test as a post hoc analysis. To assess differences within each experimental phase, the Mann-Whitney U test or the t-test were used, depending on data normality. No significant gender differences were found within the phases (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p$</tex>>0.05). Age-related differences in postural control were significant during the PRE and POST phases (p<0.001), with greater sway and reduced stability in the Over40 group. Some instability measures in the Over40 group persisted after the perturbation, showing sustained balance challenges. These findings demonstrate the utility of the BioVRSea system and both spectral and conventional CoP analyzes to detect age-related PC changes and support their use in balance assessment for aging populations.

title: Implementation of a DDS-Based Publishing Interface for Real-Time Inertial Sensor Data in Navigation Systems
authors: Mervin Sosa, Jairo Serrano, Juan Carlos Martinez Santos, Edwin Puertas
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a DDS-based publishing interface for transmitting inertial sensor data in real-time navigation systems. The work focuses on the integration of an embedded sensor that outputs serialformatted navigation data, adapting it into a structured DDS Topic using Interface Definition Language (IDL) and C++ within the Cyclone DDS middleware. The implementation is carried out in a controlled laboratory environment to validate a lightweight, modular, and standards-compliant architecture aligned with OMG specifications. A DDS monitoring tool is used to confirm the integrity and continuity of published messages. This approach eliminates the need for protocol bridges or intermediate converters, thereby reducing latency and enhancing maintainability. The results support the development of interoperable data for autonomous, robotic, and mission-critical systems that require reliable navigation inputs.

title: Cargo: a Framework for Confidence-Aware Routing of Large Language Models
authors: Amine Barrak, Yosr Fourati, Michael Olchawa, Emna Ksontini, Khalil Zoghlami
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: As large language models (LLMs) proliferate in scale, specialization, and latency profiles, the challenge of routing user prompts to the most appropriate model has become increasingly critical for balancing performance and cost. We introduce CARGO (Category-Aware Routing with Gap-based Optimisation), a lightweight, confidence-aware framework for dynamic LLM selection. CARGO employs a single embedding-based regressor trained on LLM-judged pairwise comparisons to predict model performance, with an optional binary classifier invoked when predictions are uncertain. This two-stage design enables precise, cost-aware routing without the need for human-annotated supervision. To capture domain-specific behavior, CARGO also supports category-specific regressors trained across five task groups: mathematics, coding, reasoning, summarization, and creative writing. Evaluated on four competitive LLMs (GPT-4o, Claude 3.5 Sonnet, DeepSeek V3, and Perplexity Sonar), CARGO achieves a top-1 routing accuracy of 76.4 % and win rates ranging from 72 % to 89 % against individual experts. These results demonstrate that confidence-guided, lightweight routing can achieve expert-level performance with minimal overhead, offering a practical solution for real-world, multi-model LLM deployments.

title: Design of a Medical Diagnosis Teaching System Based on Virtual Reality Combined with Machine Learning
authors: Norfarizah Mohd Bakhir, Li Panpan
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a diagnosis teaching system based on virtual reality and machine learning (VR-ML-Diagnosis). The system simulates real medical diagnosis scenarios through virtual reality technology, and combines machine learning algorithms to provide personalized learning experience and dynamically adjust teaching content. The algorithm uses convolutional neural networks (CNN) to simulate student diagnosis, and uses machine learning to evaluate the student's learning progress and diagnostic ability in real time, and feedback to adjust the teaching difficulty. In addition, the system uses RL algorithms to dynamically recommend learning content based on the student's performance to ensure that students can receive the most suitable training at different stages. The system is verified using real medical imaging data sets and virtual patient data. Experimental results show that compared with traditional medical teaching methods, the VR-ML-Diagnosis system can effectively improve the student's diagnostic accuracy, reduce the misdiagnosis rate, and significantly improve learning efficiency in a short period of time. In electronic medical records and imaging diagnosis, the student's accuracy rate increased by more than 15%, and the learning time was reduced by an average of 20%. This system demonstrates the great potential of combining virtual reality and machine learning in medical education, and can provide students with a more immersive, interactive and personalized learning experience, which can be expanded to more complex medical scenarios in the future.
