title: Prediction of Water Quality using Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence Techniques
authors: Prajwal Sanjay Pisal, Niharika Varshney, Anup Shekhar Chamoli, Ashutosh Singh
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Predicting water quality using machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) techniques has emerged as a key tactic for preserving public health and managing water resources sustainably. Conventional techniques for QW assessment are usually labour-intensive, time-consuming, and reactive. On the other hand, by utilising vast datasets from sensors, satellite imaging, and lab results, ML and AI approaches allow for automated, real-time, and predictive study of water quality. These models anticipate important water characteristics like turbidity, pollutant levels dissolved oxygen, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p H}$</tex> using supervised, unsupervised, and hybrid learning techniques. In the forecast of quality of water, methods such as deep learning models have demonstrated encouraging accuracy. AI-powered models are also able to pinpoint the causes of pollution and suggest prompt fixes. This study provides an assertive, flexible, and affordable approach to water resource management by highlighting the importance, methods, and uses of ML and AI in forecast of QW.

title: Automatic English Text Grading System Based on Natural Language Processing
authors: Shali Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The purpose of this study was to develop an automatic English text grading system based on natural language processing (NLP) technology to evaluate the quality of students' writing. The system adopts an integrated algorithm framework, combined with deep learning and traditional scoring methods, and realizes the comprehensive evaluation of grammar, semantics, fluency and other dimensions through the analysis of a large number of annotated text data. The main algorithms include the use of long short-term memory network (LSTM) for text feature extraction and semantic understanding, and the analysis of grammatical structure through convolutional neural network (CNN). In addition, the system combines a word vector model (Word2Vec) and a pretrained language model (BERT) to capture the contextual information of the text to ensure the accuracy and consistency of scoring. Experimental results show that the system is significantly better than the traditional rule-based scoring method in terms of evaluation accuracy, and can effectively reduce the subjectivity and error of scoring.

title: A Survey of Methods Used in Story Generation
authors: Gaargi Viswanath, Mahima Adusumilli, Divya Beldar, Ishu Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Human communication relies heavily on storytelling. Any form of communication involves recounting an event, explaining a concept, asking questions or stating facts. All of these constitute different aspects of storytelling. It is therefore important to human computer interaction to develop and improve automatic storytelling. Storytelling involves several challenges like long term coherence, prompt story coherence, controllability, and planning. This survey intends to focus on some of the challenges and the solutions which have been proposed so far.

title: The Five Levels of Attribution for AI Music
authors: Christopher B. Kuhn, Diego Ponce de Leon Vera, Christoph Burgmair, Tamay Aykut
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is a critical component of a growing number of industries. Most recently, generative AI has been used to create human-like audio, such as deepfake speech or AI music. This application of AI has led to significant ethical concerns since human creators whose work is used for training are rarely credited. It is currently an open debate how such models can be used ethically and who is responsible for ensuring human creators receive appropriate attribution. We observe that a similar challenge has been encountered before - over a decade ago, when AI in autonomous driving led to similar questions about responsibility and ethical use of AI. In this paper, we draw parallels to the five levels of autonomy in driving to propose five levels of attribution in generative AI. We establish which properties ethical and responsible attribution should exhibit at each level. Then, we apply the proposed level structure to a range of existing techniques for ethical and responsible use of generative AI. We show that existing techniques for attribution in AI music reach up to level 4. However, no approach achieves the highest level of responsible attribution, demonstrating the need to further develop such methods.

title: DWR-YOLO: A Lightweight Vehicle Detection Algorithm Based on Improved YOLOv8
authors: Sizhe Yang, Tongxu Wang, Yanqiu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of smart cities and autonomous driving technologies, vehicle detection has become a critical task, directly influencing road safety and reliability. However, current high-accuracy vehicle detection algorithms face challenges in deployment on edge devices due to their computational complexity. To address this issue, we propose DWR-YOLO, an enhanced vehicle detection model based on YOLOv8 and the Dilation-wise Residual (DWR) Attention Module. This algorithm aims to simultaneously improve detection accuracy and accelerate model inference speed, achieving a lightweight design suitable for edge device deployment. The DWR-YOLO introduces the DWR attention module to enhance model performance while reducing computational overhead. Extensive experiments demonstrate that DWR-YOLO performs exceptionally well on the UA-DETRAC-G2 dataset, achieving a recall of 62.4% and a mean average precision (mAP) of 66.5%, marking improvements of 2.4% and 2.6%, respectively, over YOLOv8. Furthermore, when deployed on the NVIDIA Jetson TX2, the model achieves a projected frame rate of 18 FPS, realizing lightweight deployment while outperforming other state-of-the-art object detection models. The experimental results validate that DWR-YOLO meets the real-time and low-power requirements of edge devices without compromising critical detection performance.

title: Research on Optimization Model of Track and Field Athlete Motion Capture Based on Machine Vision
authors: Chen Guang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a new method for the joint optimization of DCGAN and CNN. In order to overcome the disadvantages of traditional techniques, this model aims to improve the precision, detail recovery and environment adaptability of athletes. DCGAN is used to produce high quality athlete motion images, especially in the case of lack of motion data or complicated environment. Then, CNN is used to extract the key movement characteristics of athletes and analyze them. By combining DCGAN with CNN, the paper cannot only improve the quality and precision of the image, but also capture the detailed motion of the athletes, and provide more precise motion capture. The experiment results show that the proposed algorithm can increase the precision of the algorithm by 22<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup> and 15%, and the performance is more stable in complicated sports environment. In addition, the real-time performance of the model has been effectively improved, and efficient motion capture can be achieved in dynamic environments. Through experimental verification, the application of this model in track and field athlete motion capture has shown great potential, and can provide more accurate and reliable technical support for sports training and event evaluation.

title: Detecting Contaminants in Polyvinyl Chloride Resin with YOLOv12: Towards Smarter Quality Assurance
authors: Daniel Andres Cabarcas-Estrada, Andres G. Marrugo
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study provides a computer vision and deep learning-based approach for the detection of contaminants in polyvinyl chloride resins in order to optimize quality assurance processes in petrochemical industries. A YOLOv12 deep learning model is applied, leveraging its enhancements in feature extraction, computational efficiency and detection robustness over previous versions. A pre-trained YOLOv12s model was trained and validated with a set of 2500 images over 100 epochs. The performance metric results achieved an accuracy of 73% and a recall value of 77%, indicating that the model effectively identifies and detects the contaminating particles, offering an optimized, well-adjusted, and reliable solution for quality control of polyvinyl chloride resin. These findings highlight the potential of computer vision and deep learning in industrial applications, as well as paving the way for implementations in other industries that involve granular and powdered materials.

title: GrIIM: Graph-Based IED Impact Assessment Using MCDM
authors: Kishore Sreedharan, Kwasi Boakye-Boateng, Hossein Shokouhinejad, Mahdi Abrishami, Shabnam Saderi Oskouei
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: In the evolving landscape of smart grids, Intelligent Electronic Devices (IEDs) are critical for automating and controlling substation operations, significantly enhancing grid stability and reliability. However, increased digital interconnectivity exposes these devices to sophisticated cyber threats. Compromise of IEDs can result in unauthorized control of critical equipment, causing operational disruptions and cascading blackouts. Despite the severity of this risk, current frameworks rarely focus explicitly on IED-level impact assessment within substations. This study proposes a novel, bottom-up impact assessment framework that integrates Graph Theory with Multi-Criteria Decision-Making (MCDM) methodologies, specifically employing an entropy-weighted Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) model to identify and prioritize IEDs based on their criticality if compromised. Initially, substation component dependencies are represented as a network graph, and the model then ranks IEDs by their potential to disrupt grid operations. Through simulation-based analysis on real-world substation architectures, the approach effectively identifies high-risk IEDs, providing actionable insights to guide proactive cybersecurity and resilience planning This framework is substation agnostic and does not require tailormade adjustments as compared to other assessment frameworks and tools.

title: HiResCAM: A High-Resolution Class Activation Mapping Framework for Satellite Change Detection with XAI-Driven Interpretability
authors: Penukulapati Durga Maruthi Vara Prasad, Allen Saji, Faizan Niyazuddin, Syed Yusuf Hussain, N aymaan Khan, Swati Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Change detection in satellite imagery is critical for monitoring urban dynamics and environmental changes. This work focuses on mechanistic interpretability of change detection models by integrating explainable AI (XAI) techniques to enhance model transparency and trustworthiness. We utilize the LEVIR-CD dataset., consisting of high-resolution bi-temporal satellite image pairs., which was trained on U -net Siamese neural network architecture for urban change detection. To interpret the model's predictions., we apply the post hoc XAI method HiResCAM at the feature extraction layers of the network., enabling visualization of salient image regions influencing the change decisions. Our approach aims to answer key questions such as whether pre-change or post-change images have greater influence and to what extent the model attends to regions. This mechanistic insight facilitates a more reliable and interpretable change detection system. By introducing XAI to the domain of satellite image change detection., we provide a framework that can guide future research in improving state-of-the-art architectures and datasets., ultimately advancing the predictability and robustness of change detection algorithms.

title: Towards Improving the Reliability of LLMs in Requirements Engineering with Structured Confidence and Tag Governance
authors: Dvip Patel, Sanaa Alwidian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Automating requirements engineering with large language models (LLMs) remains risky: existing tools frequently hallucinate tags and lack traceability, making their outputs sometimes unreliable for downstream agile planning. To address this, we propose a scalable, domain-flexible pipeline that first parses stakeholder schema introduced here, and then applies a versioned tag governance stage for enrichment and validation. We benchmarked on 30 real world Fintech and Saas requirements, our evaluation shows that Opus4 and Meta-70b outperform GPT4.1 by 0.31 F1 points in our strictest tag governance stage, while our pipeline substantially improves tag precision significantly across all models (e.g., for GPT 4.1: from 0.657 to 0.897). By open-sourcing our scripts, data and evaluation harness, we aim to make robust, auditable requirement parsing reproducible across domains. Future work will extend our approach to larger, more diverse dataset and enable interactive, human-in-the-loop agile task refinement.

title: Towards Scenario-Driven Reference Architecture for Integrating Microservices and LLM-Based Multi-Agent Systems
authors: Peyman Yazdanian, Yan Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Microservice Systems (MS) and Large Language Model-based Multi-Agent Systems (LLM-MAS) are two major paradigms shaping modern software design. While MS emphasizes modularity and scalability, LLM-MAS introduces adaptive reasoning and autonomy. However, deriving systematic insights into their similarities, differences, and integration potential remains challenging due to their complex heterogeneous technology stacks. This poster proposes a scenario-driven methodology as the core analytical approach. By grounding the comparison of MS and LLM-MAS in concrete, domain-specific scenarios within the retail supply chain management, we expose architectural contrasts and connections across both paradigms. Using this case study, we demonstrate how scenario-driven analysis captures functional workflows, architectural constraints, and quality attributes, enabling the derivation of a layered reference architecture. This provides a structured base for hybrid integration and the development of scenario-based evaluation benchmarks, including failure injection aligned with the SOTA taxonomy.

title: DeepGCN-DynamicStack: A Novel Hybrid Model for Feature Extraction and Dynamic Meta-Learning Using Graph Convolutional Networks and Stacking Ensemble
authors: M. Priyadharshini, V. Murugesh, Subrata Chowdhury, Sudhanshu Maurya, Gyana Ranjana Panigrahi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Acute stroke represents one of the foremost causes of death and disability, and hence, making correct and early predictions is an invaluable feature. Although Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Networks (LSTM), Deep Neural Networks (DNN), etc, had been used for the healthcare data, they fail to capture the inter-feature dependencies in structured datasets. To overcome this limitation, we propose the DeepGCN-DynamicStack, a new heterogeneous model incorporating a deep feature extraction provided by fully connected neural networks, GCNs for capturing feature dependence, and a dynamic stacking meta-classifier. The deep feature extraction component learns high-level interactions, which are non-linear in nature, whereas GCN captures the structure of the relationships existing between these features. In fact, the meta-classifier makes a dynamic adjustment to the weights of models depending on their performance. We used DeepGCN-DynamicStack to interpret and predict the brain stroke dataset, which has a class imbalance, and resolved it through SMOTE-ENN. The model was compared with other modern architectures of CNN, LSTM, and DNN. Other competitor models that were considered as baselines are CNN, which had the following metrics: accuracy 88.0%, precision 87.7%, recall 87.2%; and DNN, which had the following metrics: accuracy 89.0%, precision 87.8%, recall 87.5%. Integration of GCN and dynamic meta-learning leads to interpretability and addresses the flexibility issue in the decision process for DeepGCN-DynamicStack when used in stroke prediction. This approach has the potential of being applied in other areas of health care, especially where the relationship of features is crucial. Subsequent studies will consider a generalization of the model to the big and various data sets.

title: The Development of a Closed-Loop, Patient-Centered, Extended Reality System to Enhance Balance in People with Multiple Sclerosis: A Research Protocol
authors: Gabriele Perachiotti, Nicola Moccaldi, Giovanni D'Errico, Isolde Martina Busch, Elisa Magosso, Sofia Straudi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Background: Falls are common and harmful in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS), especially during daily movements. Stepping impairments contribute significantly to fall risk but stepping-focused interventions are limited and rarely target those with higher disability. Mixed reality (MR) offers a promising, adaptive, and safe solution for stepping training even without supervision. This project aims to develop and test a closed-loop, AR-based system to assess and improve dynamic balance in PwMS. Methods: This observational study on PwMS consists of three milestones: (1) development and validation of a near-fall detection algorithm using head-worn sensors during multidirectional stepping; (2) design of an MR enviroment for personalized, adaptive, stepping training; and (3) testing the usability, reliability, and neural responses of the MR system in PwMS and healthy controls. Results: This project will advance precision rehabilitation in PwMsby developing the first closed-loop MR system for unsupervised, personalized multidirectional stepping training and assessment. Discussion: Volitional stepping training should be a core component on effective fall prevention interventions in PwMS and its effectiveness can be further enhanced through an head mounted display MR system.

title: A Three-Dimensional Polarization-Insensitive Grating Coupler Tailored for 3D Nanoprinting
authors: Oliver Kuster, Yannick Augenstein, Carsten Rockstuhl, Thomas Jebb Sturges
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: Efficiently coupling light from optical fibers into photonic integrated circuits is a key step toward practical photonic devices. While a notable coupling can be achieved by out-of-plane couplers such as grating couplers, their basic planar geometry typically tends to be sensitive to the polarization of light. This is partly due to the fact that the design spaces of such grating structures—typically fabricated with techniques such as electron-beam lithography—are only two-dimensional with a simple extrusion into the vertical dimension. This makes it challenging to optimize for both polarizations simultaneously, as performance typically degrades when trying to achieve high efficiency in both. As a result, conventional approaches either suffer from increased losses or require additional filtering components to account for different polarizations. In this work, we present a fully three-dimensional, polarization-insensitive grating coupler which has a highly efficient simulated coupling efficiency of over <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf {80\%}$</tex-math></inline-formula> in both polarizations. This performance matches that of state-of-the-art couplers that are performant for one polarization only. This comes at the cost of a moderately larger size due to the lower refractive index materials typically available in 3D nanoprinting. Our design method uses density-based topology optimization with a multi-objective approach that combines electromagnetic simulations with a fictitious heat-conduction model acting as a soft constraint to promote structural integrity. This ensures that the designed structures are feasible for fabrication. Our work opens new possibilities for robust 3D photonic devices, enabling advanced integration, fabrication, and applications across next-generation photonics and electronics.

title: Advanced Neural Network Controller for Catching the MPP of Solar PV Systems: A Simulation Analysis
authors: Sunkara Sunil. Kumar, K. Balakrishna
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: In the present worldwide situation, the use of non-conventional sources is increasing due to the new advancement techniques employed in natural resources like solar, wind, and tidal to extract maximum power to meet the power supply demand. In this paper, three-diode models are preferred other than one-diode circuit model and two-diode circuit model due to their optimal accuracy in extracting solar output power. The three-diode model is integrated with traditional MPPT techniques like the Perturbation method, Incremental gradient technique, and Neural Network (NNW) to trace the highest power point of solar output power. By comparing the output characteristics of the three MPPT techniques. The ANN MPPT technique has more benefits compared to P&O in terms of speed of convergence and tracking the peak efficiency point in dynamic temperature conditions.

title: AI-Based Modular Warning Machine for Risk Identification in Proximity Healthcare
authors: Chiara Razzetta, Shahryar Noei, Federico Barbarossa, Edoardo Spairani, Monica Roascio, Elisa Barbi, Giulia Ciacci, Sara Sommariva, Sabrina Guastavino, Michele Piana, Matteo Lenge, Gabriele Arnulfo, Giovanni Magenes, Elvira Maranesi, Giulio Amabili, Anna Maria Massone, Federico Benvenuto, Giuseppe Jurman, Diego Sona, Cristina Campi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: DHEAL-COM - Digital Health Solutions in Community Medicine” is a research and technology project funded by the Italian Department of Health for the development of digital solutions of interest in proximity healthcare. The activity within the DHEAL-COM framework allows scientists to gather a notable amount of multi-modal data whose interpretation can be performed by means of machine learning algorithms. The present study illustrates a general automated pipeline made of numerous unsupervised and supervised methods that can ingest such data, provide predictive results, and facilitate model interpretations via feature identification.

title: Development of a Novel Free Chlorine Sensor based on Graphene Oxide and PEDOT:PSS
authors: Iqbal Syamsu, I Dewa Putu Hermida, Shobih, Diki Purnawati, Erry Dwi Kurniawan, Nanang Sudrajat, Gandi Sugandi, Yusuf Nur Wijayanto, Goib Wiranto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: Fast, reliable detection of free chlorine is critical for public health and environmental safety, especially in water treatment and industrial applications. In this work, we report a novel low-cost chemiresistive free-chlorine sensor that is constructed using graphene oxide (GO)-poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)-polystyrene sulfonate (PEDOT:PSS) composites. The sensor was manufactured on an alumina substrate by a thick-film screen printing technique for the electrode patterns and with a drop-casting process for transferring the active sensing layer. Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared by the modified Hummers method from graphite flakes, and then its structure/chemical nature was characterized using FTIR and XRD. The GO-PEDOT:PSS composite was subsequently used to coat the active area of the sensor. Performance was tested against sodium hypochlorite (NaClO) solutions of $1,5,10,20$, and $30 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{L}$ free chlorine concentrations: the sensor showed a fast and reproducible response with a well-defined relation between electrical characterization and analyte concentration. This work highlights the combined benefit deriving from GO and PEDOT:PSS on sensor improvement and demonstrates thickfilm screen printing as an economically attractive and scalable manufacturing method for the large-scale production of chemical sensors.

title: Enhancing Project Risk Management Through Bayesian Networks and Transformer-Based Time Series Forecasting Framework
authors: Balamurugan Packiam, Sunil Kadyan, Narinder Kumar Bhasin, Anilambica Kata, D. Jyothi Preshiya, S Muthuperumal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Project risk Management is becoming more difficult due to increased complex interdependencies and ever-changing uncertainties. Legacy risk models are inadequate in creating an understanding of the temporal nature of variation and the interdependence of causality. This paper provides a hybrid framework that merges Bayesian Networks with probabilistic risk modeling, alongside Transformer-based time series forecasting to identify risk trajectories under unknown conditions and expertise. Bayesian Networks allow for the integration of expert knowledge and past analogue data while let Transforms forecast temporal risk development, providing opportunities for adaptive and proactive risk mitigation interventions. The framework supports the utility of project manager decision-makers by providing explanation of interdependencies and innovative risk trajectories across project life cycles. The performance experiments demonstrated a high-level prediction accuracy (98.1%) and robustness for risk score forecasting accuracy, providing strong support for the practical application of the framework. The potential system and framework addresses making plausible interpretation actionable to the same extent as predictive strength in allowing project managers to mitigate project risk.

title: Data-Driven Core Loss Modeling of Magnetics
authors: Han Wang, Jiaqing Kuang, Jun Shao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of power electronics, the application of magnetic components is expanding, making core loss a critical factor in the efficiency of power converters. This study constructs a high-precision core loss prediction model using a data-driven approach, which is highly significant for practical applications. Initially, the paper establishes a classification model for magnetic flux density waveforms, detects outliers with the smooth Z-score method, and extracts waveform shape features. It evaluates the correlation of 13 features through Pearson correlation analysis and selects 7 key features using principal component analysis. A random forest is then employed to build a classification model that successfully identifies 20 sine waves, 44 triangular waves, and 16 trapezoidal waves. Subsequently, features such as temperature, frequency, excitation waveform, and core material are extracted, and their contribution is ranked by a random forest. Finally, 11 features are selected for predicting core loss. The paper also enhances a CNN network and proposes a hybrid network integrating MLP and CNN. By comparing the MSE and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> scores of various models and their prediction effects on the test set, it is found that the prediction accuracy of the improved model is significantly enhanced.

title: Key Technologies of Sensor Aircraft and Their Applications
authors: Shengqi Chen, Zhenhua Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: The traditional AEW aircraft “platform and payload” approach not only affects the platform's aerodynamic performance, flight time and payload capability, but also constrains sensor performance. This paper elaborates on the concept of sensor-aircraft based on “sensors as structures” and analyzes in depth integrated payload-platform implementation methods. Four key issues are proposed: the contradiction between large-sized sensors and the aerodynamic performance of the UAV platform; the contradiction between the deformation of the radar antenna and the lightweight requirement of the aircraft; the contradiction between the antenna performance and the complex aerodynamic shape of the platform; and the contradiction the occlusion of the fuselage components and the omnidirectional detection of the radar. By breaking through the integrated aerodynamic configuration and optimization technology, conformal design and compensation technology, and integrated structure design technology, the mutual constraints between the payload and the platform in the implementation of sensor aircraft can be solved, and comprehensive optimization of flight time, range, and mission system capabilities can be achieved.

title: Appropriateness of Empathy in AI: A Signal-Cost Perspective
authors: Tao Wang, Juan Chi-Ching, Harold Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: The appropriateness of empathy in AI has emerged as a critical concern, as excessive empathy risks seeming manipulative while insufficient empathy appear dismissive. While prior research has explored how to quantify empathy in AI, few examine empathy's contextual appropriateness. This paper introduces an economic perspective by applying signaling theory to human-AI conversation. We propose Signal Cost Proxies mapped to affective, cognitive, and associative empathy. This multidimensional framework enables systematic evaluation of empathy not just by presence, but by its appropriateness relative to user demand.

title: Optimization of Electric Bus Fleet Deployment Using Football Optimization Algorithm: A Case Study in Cuenca, Ecuador
authors: Néstor Diego Rivera Campoverde, Daniel Israel Ortega Rodas, Andrea Karina Bermeo Naula
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study evaluates the feasibility of electrifying the urban public transport system in Cuenca, Ecuador, through an approach that combines real data acquisition, dynamic-energy modeling, and optimization. Position (latitude, longitude, altitude) and speed data were collected across 35 urban routes to calculate longitudinal forces, energy consumption, and the state of charge of a reference electric bus. Based on this analysis, the avoided <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> emissions resulting from replacing diesel buses were estimated. To optimize the allocation of electric units, the Football Optimization Algorithm was implemented, formulated as a maximization problem of avoided <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> under capital investment and fleet-size constraints. Results show that the electrification of 150 buses, with an investment of USD 60 million, can reduce approximately 467 kg of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> per day, prioritizing high-consumption routes such as lines 16, 21, and 27. The FOA demonstrated fast and stable convergence in fewer than 100 iterations, strategically distributing units to maximize environmental impact and cost-effectiveness. The proposed methodology provides a replicable framework for other Latin American cities with similar geographic and operational conditions, supporting decision-making for sustainable urban mobility.

title: Social Network Analysis of an AI-Powered Recycling Startup: Insights from CIRSYS in the Peruvian Innovation Ecosystem
authors: Rodrigo Vega-Centeno, Richard A. Montalván-Simón, José G. Castro-Aguilar, Jorge L. Saavedra-Pérez, Carlos G. Hernández-Cenzano
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study examines the social network structure of CIRSYS S.A.C., a Peruvian startup that develops artificial intelligence-based technologies for recycling, with the objective of understanding its position within the national innovation ecosystem. Using egocentric social network analysis applied to publicly available LinkedIn data, the research quantifies key structural metrics-including degree centrality, betweenness, network density, and clustering-and identifies subnetwork configurations across academic and business domains. The results indicate a highly cohesive educational network characterized by small-world properties and the presence of central student actors, but limited connectivity to executives, institutions, and commercial stakeholders. The analysis reveals underutilized brokerage potential, particularly among faculty actors, and a lack of crosssector integration that may constrain innovation diffusion and partnership formation. The study contributes to the literature on innovation networks in emerging economies by highlighting the relevance of actor-level positioning in early-stage ventures and offering practical guidance for strengthening strategic communication and stakeholder engagement. Recommendations are provided to improve institutional linkages and expand outreach to underrepresented segments of the ecosystem. Future research directions include longitudinal network analysis, comparative studies across Latin American startups, and integration of network data with innovation performance indicators.

title: Research on Efficient Navigation Mechanism of Inspection Robot by Fusing RRT-APF and DWA Algorithm
authors: Zhen Sun, Jinreng Zhao, Zhuoling Wu, Lin Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper focuses on the inspection robot path planning problem, given the shortcomings of traditional manual inspection and the needs of automated inspection, the research aims to improve the inspection performance of robots in complex environments. For the global path planning of robots, this paper uses the RRT*-APF algorithm, which utilizes the asymptotic optimality of RRT and the efficient computational advantages of APF to effectively overcome the traditional APF local optimality dilemma. In local path planning, the DWA algorithm is used to determine the dynamic velocity window according to the robot kinematics parameters, and the trajectory prediction and cost function evaluation are used to select the optimal. In the simulation experiment, RRT-APF algorithm in 3000×3000 map, including 10 obstacles scene, the average planning time of 13.8s, shorter than the RRT * of 23.2s and the path is more optimal; DWA algorithm in the 10×l0 local map, multi-random obstacle distribution, so that the robot has successfully avoided obstacles to arrive at the target 20 times, which is a strong validation of the validity of the algorithm, and lays the foundation of intelligent inspection robot. This is a strong verification of the effectiveness of the algorithm, and lays the foundation for intelligent inspection of robots.

title: Digital Twin and Cyber-Physical System Architecture for Musical Instruments and Their Accessories
authors: Juan Sebastián Durán Rodríguez, Luis Alberto Cruz Salazar, Andrés Fernando Jiménez Areiza, Juan Pablo Carrillo Restrepo, Yuber Alejandro Martínez Espitia, Tatiana Manrique, Ernesto Monroy Cruz, Juan Sebastian Sanchez-Gomez
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This paper presents a modular Cyber-Physical System (CPS) architecture designed for real-time control and monitoring of musical devices, supported by a Digital Twin (DT) developed using Node-Red. The proposed system enables both local and remote manipulation of parameters in musical equipment through a combination of physical sensors, digital actuators, and virtual interfaces. Communication between physical and digital layers is managed using lightweight IoT protocols, specifically MQTT, which enables synchronized operation and user feedback. To validate the architecture, two guitar effects pedals, a distortion and a chorus pedal, were digitally twinned and controlled through the CPS. A third case study simulates an effects chain to demonstrate the system's scalability and applicability in more complex, real-world performance environments. The integration of UML diagrams, activity diagrams, component models, and state machines supports the architectural design and facilitates the formalization of interactions between system components, enhancing its replicability and adaptability. The architecture leverages opensource tools and low-cost hardware, aligning with key requirements for adaptability, remote access, transparency, and cost-effectiveness in musical applications. Results demonstrate that the CPS-DT integration enables intuitive real-time control, improves the versatility of analog devices, and opens new possibilities for automation and customization in music technology.

title: Development of a High-Speed Methodology for Manufacturing Biodegradable Superhydrophobic Surfaces Assembled by Modules for Water Harvesting in High Relative Humidity Areas
authors: Andrés Rodríguez Toscano, José Sánchez-De-La-Hoz, Paul Sanmartin-Mendoza, George Archbold-Taylor, Alexander Troncoso-Palacio, Luis Herreño Marenco
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: The development of sustainable nanomaterials has gained considerable attention for hydrophobic surface applications due to their self-cleaning properties and reduced environmental impact. This research introduces a novel highspeed methodology for the fabrication of biodegradable superhydrophobic surfaces, designed as modular units for water harvesting in regions with high relative humidity. The proposed approach integrates conceptual design principles with functional decomposition and material selection via morphological analysis. Two configurations were evaluated: polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) combined with modified silica nanoparticles and PDMS with modified halloysite nanotubes. Experimental procedures included nanoparticle functionalization, surface fabrication, and wettability testing, while aerodynamic and fluid simulations using SolidWorks Flow demonstrated the efficiency of moisture capture at optimal inclination angles (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leq 44.9^{\circ}$</tex>). Results indicated enhanced water droplet capture at 100% relative humidity, with higher nanoparticle concentrations improving surface wettability. These findings affirm the potential of the proposed modular surfaces in providing a viable, eco-friendly solution for water collection in underserved environments.

title: A Multidisease Diagnostic Framework utilizing CNN
authors: Jasman Singh, Kanika Pahwa, Anju Arya, Sanjay Malik, Nisha Panchal
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Early diagnosis of Heart and Lungs diseases is a critical challenge in medical diagnostics field. Heart disease and lungs diseases are one of the major causes of loss of life worldwide which increased the need for accurate, reliable and timely diagnostics to improve patient’s health. This paper proposes a Deep Learning-based Convolution Neural Network (CNN) model for the identification of both cardiovascular and respiratory diseases from X-ray and MRI images, utilizing the AlexNet architecture. The proposed model identifies bacterial tuberculosis, pneumonia, and viral pneumonia for respiratory diseases using X-ray images, and classifying between normal and abnormal cardiovascular conditions using MRI scans. Leveraging AlexNet architecture in deep learning model with an accuracy of 97.8% after running for 350 epochs, the proposed model can effectively handle different imaging modalities and disease types, which provides an accurate prediction while minimizing the need for multiple specialized systems. Furthermore, the proposed work also integrates Explainable AI (XAI) to provide transparent predictions and detailed probability score as well as confidence score for each disease category which enhance users understanding and trust towards the result generated by the model. Incorporating Explainable AI (XAI) improves the model’s interpretability and broadens its real time application in the medical field.

title: Comprehensive Analysis Of Near-Ultrasonic Acoustic Channel For Short Range High Data Rate Aerial Acoustic Communication
authors: Mohammad Safa Jawad, Haneen M. Zaki, Malak Kadhim, Samir Salem Al-Bawri, Zahraa S. Jawad, Samaher Abdulkadhem Abdullah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: Aerial acoustic communication (AAC) enables data transmission and reception using the speakers and microphones available in commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) devices. It can be considered an alternative to radio communication, especially in short-range indoor environments. Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) is one of the most well-known modulation techniques used in many, if not all, modern wireless communication systems. Since the acoustic channel shares similar characteristics with the radio channel, it is a strong candidate for implementing high data rate AAC systems. However, for robust and effective OFDM-based implementation, the effect of the acoustic channel on the signal should be analyzed comprehensively. This work focuses mainly on analyzing and quantifying the acoustic channel effects that can degrade the performance of the OFDM system in a typical indoor environment. Specifically, it analyzes the spreading delays of multipath fading and frequency offset (Doppler shift). The work reports a maximum delay spread ($\tau_{\max }$) of 32.7 ms and a maximum average frequency shift of less than 30 Hz. Unlike previous works that do not provide detailed channel analysis, this work provides the necessary insights that can help in designing more robust systems and selecting appropriate design parameters for future work.

title: Enhanced THz Absorption via Controllable, Polarization-Independent Metamaterials
authors: A. Elakkiya, M Thiruppathiraja, B N Aryalekshmi, D Lakshmi Devi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: A compact and modest triple-band metamaterial absorber (MMA) has been projected at terahertz (THz) frequencies with polarization-insensitive characteristics. Unlike conventional absorbers that have polarization-sensitive or polarization- insensitive behavior of MMA, the proposed device exhibits extra, polarization- controllable behaviour. This is achieved by the single top patch which is formed by grouping of two triangles. When the impact beam field of electricity (e-field) is chosen across the equal direction, three peak forms of absorption are mostly acquired; when the field of charge is chosen along the straight direction, three more spots are subsequently identified. This triple-band terahertz absorber is made up of a metallic basis on the bottom plate and a star-shaped patch on the top. The top model and the bottom ground plate were separated by a 0.125 mm -thick dielectric polyimide substrate. Electric current, magnetism, and area current distributions are used to analyse the physical mechanism of the polarization-controlled MMA. The polarisation type and digestion process in the present investigation were compared with those described in other studies. For large incidence degrees and polarisation angles up to 90 facets, the intended structure performs well. The selection, detection, maintenance, and functionality of polarization-sensitive gadgets should all be broadly applicable.

title: Periodic Common Mode Noise Coupling and Propagation in Gate Driver Isolated Power Supply: Mechanism, Modeling, and Impacts
authors: Han Peng, Qiaozhi Yue, Yue Cui, Huiqiang Ma, Qiaoling Tong, Yong Kang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Periodic common-mode interference (CMI) in gate drivers is a critical factor leading to unrobust switching of high voltage, high-power semiconductor devices. Due to their large isolation capacitance, gate driver isolated power supplies (IsoP) are especially vulnerable to CMI. Periodic CM noise in the IsoP propagated through the control circuit of IsoP and amplified by the power stage will add significant noise on the output of IsoP and cannot be filtered out. It will cause severe gate driver voltage fluctuations which affects normal switching process by increasing switching loss and voltage stress on power transistors. However, this phenomena was never discussed by prior arts. To address this important issue, this paper aims to reveal the mechanism of periodic CM noise coupling and propagation in IsoPs. The coupling mechanism of periodic CM noise through two different sampling approaches is discussed. The characteristics of the propagation of CM noise are firstly analyzed. Linear stages, such as op-amp and filters, are analyzed using super-positions of transfer functions. Nonlinear PWM modulation stage is investigated via double Fourier transform to elucidate the complex harmonics sideband generated by periodic CMI. The relationship between CMI frequency fCM and IsoP operating frequency f<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sw</sub> is examined. The periodic CM noise discussed in this article comes from pulsating switching of power transistor and the analysis presented in this article are not limited to sinusoidal signals. Results show that as fcm approaches f<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sw</sub> and its harmonics, low-frequency (LF) sidebands are intensified and become harder to filter, significantly enlarging LF fluctuations in the output voltage. When fcm aligns with f<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sw</sub> or its harmonics, most serious fluctuations will happen with the peak-to-peak variations exceeding 10% of the average value of the output voltage. The basic law revealed in this article is validated through experiments on flyback IsoP with periodic CMI at different frequencies and amplitudes.

title: Multi-channel Electromagnetic Interference Elimination for Shielding-free MRI Using Null Operations
authors: Jiaqi Wang, Huifang Wang, Linfang Xiao, Mengye Lyu, Yujiao Zhao, Yilong Liu, Ed X. Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Objective: Emerging technologies for electromagnetic interference (EMI) elimination have enabled radio frequency (RF) shielding-free magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), significantly reduced costs and increased accessibility. Existing methods often rely on multiple external sensors for EMI elimination, which can degrade with fewer sensors. Our goal is to develop a method that robustly eliminates EMI with fewer or no sensors. Methods: We propose a method for multi-channel electromagnetic interference elimination in shielding-free MRI using null operations (MEENO). This approach fully exploits the inter-channel correlation across all RF receiving and EMI sensing channels. The method was comprehensively evaluated through simulation studies and human brain imaging. Results: The MEENO approach effectively eliminates EMI artifacts, outperforming existing methods, particularly with a limited number of sensors. It shows superior performance in terms of signal-to-noise ratio and residual EMI levels. Conclusion: We introduce a method for EMI elimination in multi-channel MRI using null operations, which fully leverages inter-channel correlation and surpasses existing approaches, especially with limited sensors. Significance: This work offers a solution for EMI elimination with fewer or no external sensors, providing a more cost-effective and robust approach for shielding-free MRI.
