title: GraphSAGE for Real-Time Target Tracking in UAV Surveillance
authors: S. Gomathi, R. Sathish, S. Oviya, G. Sharmila, Akshya. J, M Sundarrajan, Mani Deepak Choudhry
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The increase in the need to have intelligent aerial surveillance has required the creation of real-time, correct, and scalable target tracking systems for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs). The older methods of doing so generally include Kalman filters, LSTM-based trackers, and convolutional graph networks; however, they tend to face problems with scalability, generalizability to new environments, and fast real-time operation under dynamic missions. To address these gaps, we propose a GraphSAGE-based inductive learning framework customized for real-time UAV surveillance and multi-target tracking. The system can be understood as a dynamic graph with UAVs, targets, and communication areas corresponding to nodes and their relationships to each other as edges. Then, the node embeddings are updated continuously using GraphSAGE neighborhood aggregation. The framework facilitates building online graphs and making decisions so that the drone does not need retraining to adjust to new arrangements. On experimental analysis, our model displays 94.4% tracking accuracy with minimum average error (12.5 m) and a complete 100 percent interruption recovery rate, which surpasses baseline advanced baselines, such as GAT and DGCNN, by a significant margin. Besides high accuracy, the system is high-performance, with inference occurring in real-time and at low energy consumption, making it ideal for embedded applications on edge UAV systems. The given GraphSAGE solution is not only state-of-the-art in air/aural surveillance but also creates a scalable and robust architecture that can learn and adapt in real-time, multi-agent, and mission-critical processes. The study presents a new and practical perspective on AI systems utilizing UAVs, serving as a starting point for implementing intelligent graph-based control in next-generation aerial surveillance operations.

title: Creating Reliable Electric Vehicle Battery Management Systems Digital Twin Technology: Improving Safety, Energy Efficiency, and the Battery Lifecycle
authors: C.Praveen Kumar, T Bhargava Ramu, V. Manohari, Khaled Tawfiq Al-Assaf, Sorabh Lakhanpal, R. Balasubramaniyan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The performance, reliability, and longevity of battery systems used in electric vehicles (EVs) have emerged as key factors impacting user satisfaction and industry uptake as their adoption rates rise globally. Conventional Battery Management Systems (BMS) traditionally depend on an extensive array of physical sensors and predetermined models, which struggle to account for the intricate, non-linear, and time-sensitive nature of lithium-ion battery behavior under diverse operating conditions. In this research we propose a new framework that embeds Digital Twin (DT) technology in the BMS of an EV for the genesis of a real-time, high-fidelity, virtual representation of the real electrochemical/thermal battery system. Using advanced data analytics, machine learning algorithms, and sensor fusion, the digital twin is continually synchronized with the physical battery so that accurate prediction of the battery health is possible, allowing early fault detection, and therefore more efficient usage of the energy. This study explains the design architecture of a digital twin-based BMS, formulated interaction between the physical layer, the virtual model and communication protocols for realtime feedback loops. Furthermore, both experimental results and HIL (hardware-in-the-loop) validations show that the proposed digital twin technique can help mitigate the risk of thermal runaway, extend battery lifecycle by intelligent chargedischarge scheduling, and optimize overall energy efficiency by dynamic adjustment considering both driving behaviors and environmental factors. Additionally, the DT framework supports predictive maintenance and improved decisionmaking at the system-level by delivering insight into degradation patterns, state-of-charge (SoC), and state-of-health (SoH) with higher accuracy than legacy systems. This research provides a solution to the challenges of real time synchronization, computational complexity, and data security while deploying digital twins for EV applications. This proposed system can be integrated into commercial EV platforms as it is scalable and reliable by adopting a layered architecture backed by cloud-edge computing and secure communication protocols. The implications of these findings reinforce the revolutionary potential of digital twin technology in advancing BMS from a reactive controller to proactive intelligent systems. This development is a major breakthrough towards battery systems in the rapidly-evolving world of electric mobility that offer enhanced safety, efficiency, and life.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Framework Combining ResNet-50 and Transformers for Enhanced Eye Disease Classification
authors: Sreedhar Kollem, Samineni Peddakrishna, Satrughan Kumar, Chandrasekhar Sirigiri, T. Venkatakrishnamoorthy
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The paper proposes using ResNet-50 and Vision Transformer (ViT) together to improve classification of diseases affecting the eye. This important architecture, resnet50, is used for excellent classification of images, though it fails to recognize long-term relations and interactions within medical images. While Vision Transformer is good at understanding the entire image, it struggles to extract local details which is better handled by convolutional neural networks. Combining the advantages of ResNet50 and ViT in the hybrid model allows it to identify important details from different parts and the whole image at the same time. According to testing, this training method makes the model operate better, withstand difficulties and perform in more situations than just ResNet-50 or other single models. Spatial and contextual feature extraction helps significantly in automated medical image analysis, meaning that using both techniques is beneficial for discoveries in medical sciences.

title: RoadNet: Efficient Relay Deployment in Traffic Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Zusheng Zhang, Yijun Mao, Jian Weng, Ming Li, Jiasi Weng, Yingjie Kuang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Traffic Wireless Sensor Networks (TWSNs) are a key enabling technology in intelligent transportation systems, supporting Infrastructure-to-Vehicle (I2V) sensing for applications such as roadside parking assistance, traffic flow optimization, and dynamic vehicle routing. In TWSNs, relay nodes are usually installed on existing infrastructure (e.g., street light poles). The problem we focus on is how to select the minimum set of relay node deployment locations to ensure full coverage of sensor nodes. Traditional WSN relay node deployment methods ignore the road network topology and spatial continuity of sensor node distribution, leading to excessive computational overhead and redundant relay placement. This work introduces RoadNet, a time-efficient relay node deployment algorithm that constructs road network graphs, reorders nodes using depth-first traversal to produce an approximately banded coverage matrix, and employs a sliding-window technique to select relay nodes based on the matrix's banded structure. We prove that RoadNet yields the optimal solution under ideal conditions with uniformly distributed sensor and relay nodes, and we establish upper and lower bounds for its performance under general conditions. Additionally, a software system for deployment of relay nodes in TWSNs has been developed. The experimental results indicate that the RoadNet algorithm reduces average deployment costs by 35.62%, 16.48%, and 1.66% compared to greedy, branch-and-bound, and genetic algorithms, respectively. Furthermore, RoadNet achieves over 99% improvement in time efficiency relative to branch-and-bound and genetic algorithms.

title: Path Planning for Mobile Robot on Narrow Road by Imitation Learning
authors: Kosuke Omura, Naoki Motoi
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: This paper proposes a local path planning with turnabouts for mobile robots on narrow roads using behavior cloning. Behavior cloning is one of the imitation learning methods. The neural network is used to learn the action of the expert for the state. The parameters of the neural network are updated to minimize the loss function between the expert data and the output of the training model. This research focuses on a four-wheeled mobile robot with non-holonomic constraints. This mobile robot has a turning radius limit. This study defines a narrow road as a path that a mobile robot with non-holonomic constraints cannot pass without turnabouts. Therefore, local path planning methods including turnabouts for narrow roads have been studied. As conventional methods, local path planning using reinforcement learning methods has generated a path planning according to the environmental information. However, these conventional methods based on reinforcement learning require a long learning time. To shorten the learning time, this study proposes the local path planning method with imitation learning. Simulation results show that the learning time was significantly reduced by using the proposed method. In addition, the proposed method achieved driving performance equivalent to that of the conventional method when driving on narrow roads. From these simulation results, the effectiveness of the proposed method was confirmed.

title: Design and Implementation of a Mixed Reality Architecture for Human-Guided Reconfiguration of Cyber-Physical Production Systems
authors: Francesco Giuseppe Ciampi, Thierno M. L. Diallo, Faida Mhenni, Stanislao Patalano, Jean-Yves Choley
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Nowadays, production systems increasingly need to be reconfigured to cope with unforeseen disruptions in workflows or supply chains, dynamic market requirements and mass personalisation. Industry 4.0 technologies, through Cyber-Physical Production Systems (CPPS), offer opportunities to address these challenges by enabling real-time monitoring and adaptive control to manage dynamic environments and requirements. With the advent of Industry 5.0, which emphasizes human-centric production, Human-Cyber-Physical Systems (HCPS) integrate operators into decision-making loops, enhancing flexibility, resilience, and responsiveness. A key requirement for these systems is reconfigurability, which involves identifying reconfiguration needs, planning actions, and executing them. Although the initial two steps are occasionally automated to some extent, the execution phase is predominantly manual, leading to inefficiencies, higher workloads, and increased risk of errors. Enabling technologies of Industry 5.0, such as Extended Reality, offer new opportunities to overcome these challenges. This work, therefore, introduces a Mixed Reality-based framework that guides and assists operators in performing industrial tasks. The framework is developed following established guidelines from the literature and relevant industrial standards, and it adopts a modular and expandable architecture that facilitates the integration of new functionalities and use cases. The approach is implemented and validated through a case study on the execution of the reconfiguration process in a real-world production line within a research platform. A preliminary evaluation using the NASA-TLX indicates that the MR application reduces workload, mainly through improved performance and lower frustration.

title: Report on the 2025 Embedded Systems Week (ESWEEK)
authors: Tei-Wei Kuo, Andy D. Pimentel, Yuan-Hao Chang, Jen-Wei Hsieh
publish: IEEE Design & Test
abstract: Embedded Systems Week (ESWEEK) is the premier event covering all aspects of embedded systems and software, which brings together three leading conferences (CASES, CODES+ISSS, and EMSOFT), one symposium, three hot-topic workshops, five special sessions, a panel, five tutorials, five education classes, two competitions with demos, and a PhD forum and recruiting event. As such, ESWEEK presents attendees with a wide range of choices, unveiling state-of-the-art embedded systems design and hardware/software architectures.

title: A Survey of Progress in LLM Alignment from the Perspective of Reward Design
authors: Miaomiao Ji, Yanqiu Wu, Zhibin Wu, Shoujin Wang, Jian Yang, Mark Dras, Usman Naseem
publish: IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Reward design underpins the alignment of large language models with human intent, yet the landscape of reward formulations, construction pipelines, optimization roles, and evaluation practices remains fragmented. This review unifies recent progress by addressing four guiding questions. How are rewards specified mathematically across scalar, token-level, and multidimensional regimes, and which shaping objectives support each? How are rewards built in practice through rule-based, data-driven, and hybrid workflows that combine heterogeneous supervision sources? How do rewards interact with optimization paradigms spanning reinforcement learning from human feedback, direct preference optimization, and incontext alignment? How are rewards assessed via benchmarks that probe robustness, generalization, safety diagnostics, and downstream impact? Organizing the field around these questions yields a taxonomy that links structural choices to practical trade-offs, highlights emerging trends such as hybrid supervision and reinforcement-learning-free alignment, and clarifies how the progression of large language model alignment can be viewed as a continuous refinement of reward design strategies, outlining research priorities for reliable, value-sensitive reward systems.

title: Advanced Model-Contrastive Federated Learning Via Knowledge Distillation
authors: Yunfei Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: In recent years, Federated Learning (FL) has gained a lot of attention as a distributed machine learning technique that safeguards data privacy. By merging the concept of contrastive learning, the MOON algorithm enhances the model's capacity for generalization in the non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data scenario. However, the Model-Contrastive Federated Learning (MOON) algorithm still has shortcomings in model performance and computing resource limitations. Knowledge distillation has become a mainstream model compression and optimization method in recent years. Consequently, this paper suggests MOON-KD, an enhanced MOON algorithm based on knowledge distillation, which enhances the algorithm's robustness and performance by integrating the global model's soft labels into the loss function to direct local model optimization. According to the results of the experiment, the MOON-KD algorithm outperforms both the MOON and the FedAvg algorithms. The experiment also further analyzes the impact of hyperparameters such as distillation loss coefficient and contrastive loss coefficient on model performance. The research in this paper provides a way of thinking for model optimization under the federated learning framework and points out the shortcomings and directions for improvement.

title: IPPO: Enhanced PPO Algorithm for Multi-Drone Control
authors: Xinyue Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have gained significant attention in recent years due to their wide-ranging applications in areas such as surveillance, delivery, and disaster response. However, achieving precise and stable attitude control for UAVs remains a critical challenge, particularly in dynamic and unpredictable environments. Traditional control methods often struggle to adapt to complex flight conditions and external disturbances. Reinforcement learning (RL) has emerged as a promising approach for addressing these challenges, with Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) being one of the most widely used algorithms due to its balance between performance and stability. Despite its advantages, standard PPO faces limitations in handling the high-dimensional and nonlinear dynamics of UAV systems. To overcome these limitations, this study proposes an Improved PPO (IPPO) algorithm, specifically designed for UAV attitude control. The IPPO incorporates adaptive learning rate adjustment, enhanced exploration strategies, and a refined reward function tailored to UAV dynamics. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed IPPO algorithm achieves superior performance in terms of convergence speed, control precision, and robustness to disturbances compared to the standard PPO. This work not only advances the application of RL in UAV control but also provides a foundation for developing more autonomous and adaptive aerial systems in complex operational scenarios.

title: Evaluation of Mental Workload and Stress While Driving with and without Steering Aids in a Virtual City Scenario
authors: Sara Arlati, Simone Costantini, Camilla Zanco, Marta Mondellini, Vera Colombo, Marco Sacco, Giovanna Rizzo, Fabio Storm, Alfonso Mastropietro
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: For people with disability, driving is an essential ability to maintain autonomy. However, assessing whether people with disability can drive safely on-road is not trivial, as it requires specifically adapted vehicles. Thus, it is often impossible to assess how much prolonged driving affects cognitive abilities and induces stress in presence of assistive aids and other road occupants. This work aimed at preliminarily assessing the sensitivity of physiological and subjective metrics in discriminating different driving conditions (i.e., steering wheel vs. driving aid), in terms of mental workload and stress, while driving on a simulator. Thirteen healthy young adults drove in a simulated environment for 10 minutes in each condition. We collected electroencephalography (EEG), heart rate variability (HRV), and electrodermal activity (EDA) data and extracted mental workload and stress-related outcomes. We administered NASA-TLX and SAM questionnaires after each condition. Both the virtual driving tasks induced measurable physiological responses. Mental work-load, cardiovascular response, and some EDA metrics increased with respect to the rest phase. The subjective measures showed a tendency toward an increase when using the driving aid, but differences were not significant. The current setup was thus able to capture the increased load and arousal during virtual driving. The lack of differences between the conditions may be due to the ease of use of the aid, which did not imply many changes to standard driving actions. In the future, it would be valuable to expand the study including additional assistive aids and enrolling individuals with disabilities.

title: AI in the Islamic Education to Enhance Personalized Learning: Applications and Future Aspirations
authors: Jehad M Shehab, Nurazmallail Marni, Siti Suhaila Ihwani, Fahrul Irfan bin Ishak, Mehmet Akif Kılıç
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is reshaping education, offering opportunities to make learning more personal, responsive, and effective. In Islamic education, AI could transform traditional teaching by tailoring learning experiences to individual students. This paper systematically reviews existing studies on AI applications in personalized learning, highlighting the theories, tools, and future directions driving this field. The findings show that AI can move education beyond standardized models, creating adaptive pathways that boost motivation and deepen learning. Yet practical integration in Islamic contexts remains limited. To address this, we propose a conceptual case study for Quran memorization classes. This framework combines spaced repetition algorithms and speech recognition to support tajweed accuracy, alongside teacher dashboards that track each student's progress and needs. Such an approach could enhance retention, improve pronunciation, and allow teachers to focus on spiritual mentoring. However, challenges remain, including speech recognition accuracy across dialects, cultural sensitivities, and ethical safeguards to preserve teacher authority and human connection. This study bridges theory and practice, offering educators and policymakers a practical pathway for using AI meaningfully in Islamic education. It suggests that while AI holds transformative potential, its success depends on context-specific design, ethical grounding, and close collaboration between technologists and educators to truly enrich learning in ways that honour human and spiritual development.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Approach for Rice Disease Detection
authors: Rachna Rathore, Phani Kumar Solleti, Kamepalli Sujatha, Raj Thilak K, Poreddy Jayaraju, Karthikayen A
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Rice is one of the most consumed staple foods around the world; thus, it is considered an important food for the greater percentage of the population in the world for its nutritional density. However, it is very often afflicted with different types of diseases which badly affect the quality of yield of rice. The early detection of diseases in rice is crucial for maintaining sustainability in its production and ensuring global food security. It proposes a hybrid deep learning model for rice leaf diseases detection by including the InceptionV3 model along with a self-designed CNN model. The InceptionV3 model acts as a feature extractor and will help in capturing features from the input image with minute details; whereas, the custom CNN contributes to enhancing the discerning capability for different diseases. Our approach uses a carefully compiled dataset of rice leaves infected by three major diseases: Leaf Blight, Brown Spot, and Leaf Smut. With the help of this dataset and our hybrid model, we would like to present a reliable tool for early and accurate disease detection in rice plants that can contribute toward better agricultural practices and improved food security around the world.

title: Machine Learning and Game Theory Applications in Cybersecurity: Predicting Mitigation Strategies from Attack Techniques
authors: Arya Patil, Swastik Ankulge, Ayaan Khan, Anshul Agarwal
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid framework that combines supervised machine learning with game-theoretic analysis to recommend robust mitigations for observed adversarial techniques. We leverage a curated dataset derived from the MITRE ATT&CK knowledge base, augmenting technique descriptions with domain-specific features and textual embeddings. A Random Forest classifier is trained to predict the set of candidate mitigations for each observed technique; its feature importance scores are used to produce interpretable explanations for the top recommendations. To account for strategic interactions between attackers and defenders, we model the mitigation selection problem as a two-player game and compute Nash equilibria over a payoff matrix that captures cost, effectiveness, and attacker incentives. The resulting hybrid approach produces mitigation recommendations that are both data-driven and strategically stable. We evaluate the framework using cross-validation and ablation studies, reporting per-class precision, recall, and F1-scores, and compare the ML-only baseline with the hybrid ML+game-theory method. Results show that the hybrid method improves robustness in scenarios with incomplete information and reduces the rate of high-cost false positives. We discuss limitations related to dataset coverage and computational scalability, and we outline practical integration steps for Security Operations Centers (SOCs). Finally, we propose directions for future work including online learning from streaming threat telemetry and deployment of approximation methods for large-scale game computations.

title: NeuroTwin Intelligence: Bridging Digital Twins and Self-Evolving AI Agents
authors: Gokul Narain Natarajan, Sathish Krishna Anumula, Ramesh Chandra Aditya Komperla, Ranganath Nagesh Taware, Prasad Nagella
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The future of adaptive, intelligent systems is an emerging paradigm created by the intersection of Digital Twin technology and further development of Artificial Intelligence (AI). NeuroTwin Intelligence as presented in this paper is a new framework that combines neuro-symbolic reasoning with self-evolving AI agents regarding ecosystems characterized by digital twins. NeuroTwin Intelligence provides aspects not possible by the passive approach of conventional digital twins as the cognitive capabilities of autonomous learning, predictive adaptation and optimization of decisions can be made possible through continual interaction with the physical and virtual states. Combining reinforcement learning, neuromorphic architectures and generative feedback loops, these AI-enabled twin will move past pre-set rules to predict state of the systems, correct anomalies, and co-design solutions in real-time. Following, we introduce the architecture blueprint, working process, and implementation plans of NeuroTwin systems in several domains, including smart manufacturing, healthcare, and critical infrastructure. Experimentation shows that NeuroTwin Intelligence has stronger resilience, explain ability and contextual awareness, and NeuroTwin Intelligence should be considered as a key capability to enable next-generation cyber-physical systems and autonomous digital ecosystems.

title: Advanced AI-Driven Predictive Framework for Dynamic Crowd Flow Management and Congestion Mitigation in High-Density Environments
authors: Gripsy Paul Mannickathan, Manish T. I, Ansif M. Shamsu
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Managing crowds effectively is key to keeping people safe, especially in environments with large gatherings, such as shopping malls, airports, event venues, and transportation hubs. Overcrowding can lead to discomfort, inefficiencies, and potential safety hazards. This project introduces an AI-driven predictive system that monitors and controls crowd flow using real-time data from multiple cameras, deep learning-based density estimation, and graph-based modeling. The system employs CSRNet, a state-of-the-art crowd-counting algorithm, to analyze pedestrian movement and estimate density levels with high accuracy. It predicts potential congestion areas and suggests proactive interventions, such as rerouting pedestrian flow and issuing early warnings, to prevent dangerous overcrowding. One of the key advantages of this system is its adaptability to both indoor and outdoor environments, allowing for dynamic crowd control in confined spaces with limited movement pathways. A Python-based crowd flow simulator was also developed to test and refine congestion control strategies. The results demonstrate that AI-based crowd flow prediction significantly enhances safety and space utilization by providing real-time insights and automated decision-making support. This approach offers a practical solution for urban planners, facility managers, and security personnel, ensuring efficient and secure crowd management in high-density environments.

title: The Impact of Cross-Border Data Flows on Digital Trade: A Comparative Analysis of the Benefits and Challenges for International Trade and Economic Development
authors: Reshma Soman N, Dinesh Kumar S, H. Sakthi Vadivelan, Kowshik T, Praveen Anandhan, Subhadra Muthuramanathan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Digital trade regulations that focus on cross-border data flow have given nations benefits in contemporary international competitiveness and collaboration. Nevertheless, due to the complexity of international legislation and the lack of adequate privacy legislation, developing nations like India face specific challenges in managing these flows. Digital trade tactics have undergone significant changes in tandem with the growth of communication technology and its impact on trade trends. Machine learning (ML) methods must be used to automate a variety of procedures and advance digital trade to adjust to these shifts. This study presents an ML-based system for identifying challenges in cross-border international digital trade that supports India's economic development. The system tackles the intricate problems in digital trade taxes by combining multilevel detection methods with sophisticated feature development approaches. This study has identified and created new corporate structures and behavioral paradigms through the analysis of cross-border company data. Claims to have substantial regulatory status and to have a 95.7% validation accuracy with a 4.4% FP. The large market variation of the border trade may be monitored in real time because of its 0.2-second transaction effectiveness. According to research findings, the system consistently performs well in detecting intricate financial fraud trends and is stable across a range of operating settings and anomalous kinds. As novel deception trends appear, the platform's adaptable learning algorithms guarantee its continuous efficacy. By offering revenue agencies flexible systems for tracking cross-border international digital trade, the study advances both conceptual knowledge and real-world uses in tax management for digital trade. Comprehensive validation of the system's efficiency confirms its usefulness in actual tax management situations.

title: Early Lung Cancer Prediction by Artificial Intelligence - Inspired Algorithm
authors: Antima, Vennila B, V K Senthil Ragavan, Komuravelly Sudheer Kumar, Saurabh Pratap Singh Rathore, Shailendra Singh Sikarwar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Lung cancer continues to be a major contributor to cancer-related mortality across the globe. Advances in medical imaging and image processing techniques have opened new avenues for improving the prediction and diagnosis of lung cancer. In this research, we propose a novel approach to predict the presence of lung cancer through the application of advanced image processing methods on lung radiographic images. To build an accurate prediction model, proposed machine learning algorithm was employed to examine the extracted features. The results of our study demonstrated promising outcomes, with the prediction model achieving a high accuracy, sensitivity, & specificity in distinguishing between lung cancer & benign cases. The proposed image processing techniques effectively highlighted subtle structural anomalies & patterns characteristic of lung cancer, aiding in early detection & timely intervention. Moreover, the techniques explored in this study could be adapted & extended to predict other types of cancer & contribute to the broader field of medical image analysis. Our proposed algorithm outperforms better accuracy than previous classifiers.

title: Caesarean Section Prediction Using Machine Learning with LIME Explainability
authors: Sukdeb Mondal, Saptarshi Ghosh, Joydip Ghosh, Sarbajit Manna, Tapas Si
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Caesarean section (C-Section) is a surgical treatment that can effectively prevent mother and neonatal mortality when performed for medically necessary reasons. Around the past few decades, the number of caesarean sections performed has been continuously rising. A Clinical Decision Support System (CDSS) is required to advise the doctor in decision-making. In Artificial Intelligence-Driven CDSS (AI-CDSS), AI technologies are revolutionizing CDSS, and are used efficiently in healthcare decision-making. Therefore, in order to determine whether or not a caesarean section is required, we looked into Machine Learning (ML) models in this article. The following methods are used to predict C-Sections: Logistic Regression (LR), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM), AdaBoost, Bootstrap AGGregatING (Bagging). The models are evaluated using well-known classification performance metrics such as accuracy, sensitivity (recall), specificity, false-positive rate, precision, F_{1}-score, and Geometric Mean (GM) to assess their performance. Finally, an Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) model, Local Interpretable Model Agnostic Explanations (LIME), is utilized to interpret the model's predictions and analyze the impact of various clinical features on C-Section classification.

title: Detection and Mitigation of Sensor-Data Tampering Attacks for Leader–Follower CACC Systems with Multiple Inter-Vehicle Distance Sensors
authors: Tenta Yamasaki, Haruki Ichikawa, Michiaki Yamamoto, Yuma Katsuki, Anan Sawabe, Yusuke Shinohara, Ryogo Kubo
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Cooperative adaptive cruise control (CACC) systems are vulnerable to cyberattacks, particularly false data injection (FDI) attacks targeting inter-vehicle distance (IVD) sensors. Previous studies have primarily focused on attacks against communication channels while overlooking the critical threat posed by sensor-data tampering. This paper proposes a method for detecting and mitigating sensor-data tempering attacks that leverages redundant IVD sensing by utilizing both front and rear IVD measurements in conjunction with a model-based tamper detection observer (TDO). By estimating the expected IVD error using a vehicle dynamics model and comparing it with the actual sensor readings, the proposed method selects a more reliable sensor input to maintain safe control. Simulations using a ten-vehicle platoon demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively detect and mitigate FDI attacks on sensors, thereby ensuring platoon stability and safety.

title: Cascaded Residual Dilated Network for Precise Land Cover Classification From Very High Spatial Resolution Satellite Imagery
authors: Vaka Kiran Kumar, V. V. Satyanarayana Tallapragada
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Accurate land cover classification from satellite images is a fundamental task in geographic information systems, with applications in agricultural management, forestry, and land use planning. However, this task is challenged by high intraclass variability, low interclass distinctions, and diverse land cover formations. To address these issues, we propose a Cascaded Residually Dilated Network for land cover mapping from very high spatial resolution satellite imagery. The network utilizes a hybrid architecture composed of residual and dilated modules to effectively capture multiscale contextual information while mitigating the effects of small-object details and boundary confusion. Additionally, a spatial attention block is integrated into the architecture to guide the network's focus toward more discriminative regions of the scene, and an intermediary supervision strategy is implemented to ease training and accelerate convergence. Experiments on the ISPRS Potsdam and ISPRS Vaihingen datasets show that the proposed Cascaded Residual Dilated Network consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving 90.73% and 90.51% overall accuracy, respectively. The results demonstrate the robustness and potential of the Cascaded Residually Dilated Network for large-scale land cover mapping.

title: From Data to Bottlenecks: Enhancing Workshop Performance Via Discrete-Event Simulation and Operator Modelling
authors: Neau Jérôme, Benhamou Latifa, Pellerin Robert, Giard Vincent, Lamouri Samir
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: This article investigates the use of dynamic discrete-event simulation (DES) to assess and improve the performance of industrial maintenance workshops, with a focus on the fine modelling of operators. Using three distinct industrial cases, the study analyses the impact of operator skills, availability, and allocation rules on the identification of bottlenecks. Case A (maintenance of railway bogies) illustrates an iterative sizing approach in the design phase, while Case B (maintenance of aero-engines) highlights the importance of modelling individual skills to plan training in the medium term. Case C (watch case maintenance) demonstrates the value of detailed modelling based on real data for reallocating flows in the short term. The DES models incorporate specifications such as hourly schedules, skill levels (technical and product), and task variability (deterministic or stochastic). Results show that performance indicators, such as operator occupancy rates, skills, or dual skills, can be used to identify bottlenecks and emphasise the importance of detailed operator modelling for effective human resource management in complex industrial contexts.

title: Research on the Path of Intelligent Production Scheduling System Based on Dynamic Programming Algorithm to Improve Enterprise Operation Efficiency
authors: Yuxin Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Here, we propose a production scheduling system based on dynamic programming to enhance manufacturing productivity. The problem-solving system employs real-time processing and adaptive scheduling to enhance resource optimization. Mathematical modeling and experimental verification enabled us to develop an extensive framework that can solve multiple constraints of scheduling without compromising computational efficiency. Experiments with a sample of 200 time production orders over three months showed marked improvement in performance: production cycle time was cut by 25%, equipment usage improved from 65% to 85%, and labor cost was reduced by 25%. The system became 95% reliable across different operating conditions, including random order changes and machine breakdown. Performance comparisons with conventional scheduling techniques indicated greater flexibility and convergence in dynamic manufacturing environments. These results indicate that dynamic programming offers a promising solution to complex manufacturing scheduling issues with sustainable gains.

title: Distributed Quantized Control of Nonlinear Multi-Agent Systems Under Cooperative-Competitive Networks
authors: Chen Chen, Jinghao Li, Rui Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper investigates the distributed quantized control problems of nonlinear multi-agent systems under cooperative-competitive networks, where all signals in the feedback channels and the communication channels are quantized. Since the quantized signals in the feedback channels and the communication channels are discontinuous, the stabilizing functions are also discontinuous. This leads to the unavailability of the backstepping technique that requires the stabilizing function to be differentiable. To this end, a universal smoothness approach is proposed to establish the smooth approximations of the quantized signals in both the feedback channels and the communication channels. Based on these smooth approximations, a distributed quantized control protocol is designed to achieve the cluster tracking when the communications among the agents involve both cooperative and competitive relationships. It is shown that the neighborhood errors are constrained within the prescribed performance bounds. Finally, two simulation examples and a real-world implementation are given to illustrate the validity of the proposed protocol.

title: Visual Localization Using Deep Learning and Graph Neural Networks: Approaches and Evaluation
authors: Dinesh Kumar Koilada
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Determining a camera’s position and orientation from images remains a central difficulty in computer vision. Classical pipelines established on handcrafted descriptors, such as SIFT, perform well under controlled conditions but degrade with lighting or standpoint changes. This paper assesses five localization techniques on a real-world museum dataset - classical SIFT correspondence, A CNN-based classifier, HF-Net’s hierarchical pipeline, an autoencoder for image-similarity embeddings, and SuperGlue, which employs graph neural networks for feature correspondence. Among these, SuperGlue achieves a mean absolute error of 6.37 on the Getty Center benchmark, an improvement of about 88% over the CNN baseline showing that graph based models with attention process effectively identify dependable correspondences in repeated and monotonous and intricate scenes.

title: Detecting and Fixing API Misuses of Data Science Libraries Using Large Language Models
authors: Akalanka Galappaththi, Francisco Ribeiro, Sarah Nadi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Data science libraries, such as scikit-learn and pandas, specialize in processing and manipulating data. The data-centric nature of these libraries makes the detection of API misuse in them more challenging. This paper introduces DSCHECKER, an LLM-based approach designed for detecting and fixing API misuses of data science libraries. We identify two key pieces of information, API directives and data information, that may be beneficial for API misuse detection and fixing. Using three LLMs and misuses from five data science libraries, we experiment with various prompts. We find that incorporating API directives and data-specific details enhances DSCHECKER's ability to detect and fix API misuses, with the best-performing model achieving a detection <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F_{1}$</tex>-score of 61.18% and fixing 51.28% of the misuses. Building on these results, we implement DSCHECKER <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{\text {agent }}$</tex> which includes an adaptive function calling mechanism to access information on demand, simulating a realworld setting where information about the misuse is unknown in advance. We find that DSCHECKER <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{\text {agent }}$</tex> achieves 48.65% detection <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F_{1}$</tex>-score and fixes 39.47% of the misuses, demonstrating the promise of LLM-based API misuse detection and fixing in real-world scenarios.

title: Latent Dirichlet Allocation with Positive/Negative Anomaly Splitting for Bilateral Cortical Analysis in Genetic Epilepsies
authors: Gianni Moretti, Francesco Correnti, Elisa Barbi, Simona Balestrini, Renzo Guerrini, Matteo Lenge
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Focusing on rare genetic epilepsies caused by pathogenic mutations such as in SCN1A, STXBP1, and PCDH19, this work aimed to establish an unsupervised topic modeling framework capable of (i) capturing morphometric brain patterns at the level of individual patients and subgroups, (ii) preserving the directionality (increase or decrease) of anatomical deviations, and (iii) mapping these latent neuroanatomical factors onto clinically relevant variables. Using vertex-wise z-scored cortical area and thickness maps from MRI, we encoded features by separately modeling positive and negative deviations, and applied Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) independently to each hemisphere. Model stability was ensured by consensus clustering and false discovery rate filtering. We compared this directional encoding to the unsigned approach in both unsupervised clustering and supervised clinical prediction tasks. The sign-preserving approach yielded latent factors that separated diagnostic groups and cognitive phenotypes and enabled moderate predictive performance. SHAP analysis indicated that topic-derived features remained interpretable with respect to clinical variables. In contrast, the unsigned encoding resulted in slightly lower regression errors for some outcomes, but with reduced anatomical and biological specificity in the derived topics. Overall, the hemisphere-specific, sign-aware LDA provided a compact and interpretable summary of cortical pathology in genetic epilepsies and supported associations with clinical phenotypes.

title: Intelligent Vehicle Lighting and Safety System
authors: Aswin A, Akash A P, Arjun Suresh, Vishakh K H, Jishnu Sankar V C
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Nighttime driving poses significant challenges to road safety, particularly due to glare from oncoming headlights and the potential to overlook critical traffic signals. This paper presents the design and development of a smart vehicle lighting and safety system aimed at addressing these issues through automation and intelligent control. The proposed system utilizes real-time image processing to detect the headlights of oncoming vehicles and dynamically dims the corresponding high-beam LED light to prevent glare. Additionally, it incorporates a traffic signal detection module based on a YOLOv8 deep learning model, enabling recognition of traffic signs to assist driver awareness and decision-making. The system architecture integrates a camera, processor, microcontroller, and LED driver, with control logic implemented through embedded programming and sensor-based feedback. Experimental results demonstrate reliable detection and response under moderate conditions, highlighting the system's potential for enhancing driver comfort and road safety. This work contributes to the broader effort of implementing affordable, intelligent vehicle systems in both conventional and future smart transportation ecosystems.

title: A Game-Theoretic Agent-Based Model for Tumor Growth and Treatment: Integrating Evolutionary and Stackelberg Dynamics
authors: Atharva Trivedi, Anshul Agarwal
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Cancer progression is driven by complex interactions among heterogeneous cell populations and their microenvironment, presenting significant challenges for therapeutic design. Agent-based models (ABMs) incorporating evolutionary game theory (EGT) and Stackelberg games provide a mechanistic framework to capture these dynamics and enable virtual experimentation on tumor growth and treatment resistance. In this regard, we have developed a modular Python/Mesa implementation that frames cancer treatment as a Stackelberg game where the physician (leader) anticipates tumor cell (follower) responses. Our model reproduces untreated tumor expansion consistent with benchmarks and integrates two treatment strategies: cyclic application and Stackelberg optimization. Results demonstrate how treatment pressures alter evolutionary fitness landscapes, frequently leading to resistance that renders initially effective treatments obsolete. The Stackelberg optimization approach achieved up to approximately 28% reduction in cumulative treatment intensity while maintaining better tumor control compared to cyclic treatment. This Stackelberg framework offers new insights into therapy optimization by explicitly modeling the sequential nature of clinical decision-making and tumor adaptation.

title: Enhancing Decision-Making in Human-Machine Teams
authors: Akashdeep Nijjar, Ittipat Promnorakid, Riccardo Poli, Caterina Cinel, Thomas Reed, Christopher Baker, Stephen Hinton, Stephen Fairclough
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: One of the key advantages of groups is their ability to pool resources and share information effectively, enabling coordinated efforts that result in emergent behaviors and enhanced performance. Here we present preliminary data from two experiments that are part of a larger study aimed at developing and testing a prototype system of a “superorganism” designed to augment decision-making within human-AI teams. One key aspect of the system, is the collaboration between humans and AI agents (AIs). In each team, humans and AIs make decisions as peers, and the optimality of each team decision depends, among other things, on mutual trust and personality, of both the human and AIs. We manipulated team composition and AIs' personality and investigated how these, and human trust in AI, affect individual and team performance. Our preliminary results suggest complex dynamics. There was a clear advantage for groups, compared to individual decision-making, as expected. However, even though humans trusted the “humanized” AI more than the non-humanized AI, performance did not necessarily benefit from it.

title: Ride Request Demand Forecasting Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Telugu Uma Mahesh, Ashwini Tuppad
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Today, ride booking for daily commute has become a ubiquitous and common service in metropolitan cities due to the recent technological advancements. Ride request demand forecasting focuses on projecting future ride demand by analysing historical data to improve driver allocation and reducing driver waiting time. An accurate forecasting system to estimate ride request demand for Rapido application is proposed. Machine learning models are employed to identify similar patterns in upcoming ride requests by means of hybrid PCA+K-Means+DBSCAN clustering. Dataset is obtained from Kaggle and includes features like previous ride patterns, weather, and traffic conditions. An ensemble boosting model is used to forecast future demands. The proposed system produced promising results with Root Mean Square Error of 3.08 and variance of 0.96. It further can be useful in decision making like dynamic driver allocation, improved vehicle fleet management, and affordable pricing, that are most pressing challenges in ride booking industry nowadays.

title: Lightweight Hybrid MobileNetv1–Vision Transformer Model for Human Activity Recognition
authors: Manjot Rani, Munish Kumar
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: In computer vision, Human Activity Recognition (HAR) remains a difficult task, especially in indoor environments with low lighting, and nighttime environments. Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and other traditional models perform well in spatial feature extraction but struggle to capture long-range relationships, which are crucial in complex situations. This study focuses on developing a deep learning framework that balances accuracy and computational efficiency for real-world use with the rising demand for efficient and practical models. MobileNetv1 and a hybrid model combining MobileNetv1 with Vision Transformer (ViT) are explored in this study. MobileNetv1 is a lightweight model that provides efficient and fast processing suitable for resource-constrained devices and real-time applications. On the other hand, Vision Transformers uses self-attention to model long-range relationships but it requires large and challenging datasets and high computational power, limiting their practicality in small-scale settings such as ARID v1.5. This hybrid model offers effective local feature extraction as well as global contextual understanding by combining the benefits of CNNs and Transformers. The model reduces overfitting on small datasets, provides high accuracy while maintaining computational efficiency, and allows for real-time deployment in real-world HAR environments by combining the strength of both architectures. Robust generalization is confirmed by experiments conducted for 10 epochs using Stratified 3- fold cross-validation on imbalanced datasets. MobileNetv1 achieves $99.65 \%$ accuracy, while the hybrid model achieves $99.74 \%$ on ARID v1.5, demonstrating enhanced accuracy, robustness to lowlight conditions, and better generalization in challenging indoor environments.

title: Unsupervised Anomaly Detection in NSL-KDD Using β-VAE: A Latent Space and Reconstruction Error Approach
authors: Dylan Baptiste, Ramla Saddem, Alexandre Philippot, Francois Foyer
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: As Operational Technology increasingly integrates with Information Technology, the need for Intrusion Detection Systems becomes more important. This paper explores an unsupervised approach to anomaly detection in network traffic using $\beta$-Variational Autoencoders on the NSL-KDD dataset. We investigate two methods: leveraging the latent space structure by measuring distances from test samples to the training data projections, and using the reconstruction error as a conventional anomaly detection metric. By comparing these approaches, we provide insights into their respective advantages and limitations in an unsupervised setting. Experimental results highlight the effectiveness of latent space exploitation for classification tasks.

title: Multi-Scale Deep Learning Architecture for Early identification of Pancreatic disease from Radiological Images
authors: J A S Santhosh, A S Surjeet Dharsan, T Jenitha, G Brindha
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: It is important to diagnose pancreatic diseases at an early stage, including pancreatic cancer and pancreatitis, to improve patient outcomes, but this is only difficult because of the indistinct radiology and the complexity of the anatomy. In this paper, the authors propose a hybrid deep learning pipeline that is used to automatically detect and localize pancreatic abnormalities with medical imaging technologies (e.g., MRI). The paradigm combines both a deep residual CNN ResNet-50, used to classify images at the image level, and a state-of-the-art real-time object model YOLOv12, used to localize pathological regions in the pancreas, spatially. The classification branch utilizes transfer learning using a ResNet50 backbone that has been fine-tuned using a curated dataset of labeled samples of normal pancreas, pancreatitis and pancreatic cancer. The YOLOv12 that is used in the detection pipeline is optimized to provide both precision and inference speed in detecting localized lesions by giving them bounding boxes and a confidence score of their class. Generalization is enhanced by the use of data augmentation methods (contrast enhancement and affine transformations). The standard measures are used to evaluate the performance with mean Average Precision (mAP). The initial findings show that the classification accuracy and the strength of detection performance are high, which proves the possibility of the proposed system to assist early and non-invasive disease of the pancreas diagnosis. The suggested multi-model system can be integrated into the computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) system to offer real-time decision-support in radiological processes to clinicians.

title: Evaluating the Role of Composition and Recording Style in AI Music
authors: Tamay Aykut, Diego Ponce De Leon Vera, Christoph Burgmair, Christopher B. Kuhn
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Generative artificial intelligence (AI) has shown remarkable capabilities in producing human-like audio, yet often fails to credit human creators whose work is used to train these models. This raises serious copyright and ethical concerns. Music tracks inherently possess two core properties: the theoretical composition, and the distinctive recording style that brings the composition to life. In this paper, we show that existing latent-space-based techniques for measuring influence of original tracks on AI music fail to distinguish between these two concepts, obscuring proper attribution of either composition or recording rights. We propose a framework for obtaining robust metrics for detecting composition and recording similarities between original tracks and AI music. We show that the latent space predominantly captures recording style, while neglecting compositional elements. Finally, our analysis shows that state-of-the-art AI models exhibit strong composition and recording biases, drifting away from the inherent structure of the original tracks.

title: Adiabatic Training of VQAS for Entanglement Detection
authors: Ernesto Acosta, Carlos Cano, Daniel Manzano, Guillermo Botella
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: This paper introduces a hybrid quantum framework for training Variational Quantum Algorithms (VQAs) aimed at addressing the fundamental problem of entanglement detection using adiabatic quantum computing. This problem is of foundational significance in quantum information science and has been approached through both classical and quantum methodologies. We propose an adiabatic-inspired optimization strategy for training VQAs, which combines a discretization of the parameter space with a hierarchical segmentation scheme. The optimization problem is formulated as a Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) model to leverage the capabilities of quantum annealing. Preliminary results are compared against classical neural networks and conventional VQA training techniques. The findings aim to stimulate further investigation and discussion within the scientific community regarding the efficacy and applicability of the proposed approach.

title: A Weight-Allocation and Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning Approach for the BTM PV Power Forecasting
authors: Jicheng Wu, Shengwei Li, Fanghong Guo, Lei Wang, Dan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy
abstract: Distributed ultra-short-term photovoltaic (PV) power forecasting plays a vital role in analyzing behind-the-meter (BTM) solar generation and enhancing grid stability. As federated learning (FL) is increasingly applied to distributed BTM PV forecasting on a large scale, its deployment is confronted with two major challenges, namely performance degradation arising from device heterogeneity and privacy risks associated with global communication. To address these challenges, a novel collaborative method, termed AWA-DDP-FL, is proposed, which integrates adaptive weight assignment (AWA) with reinforcement learning-driven dynamic differential privacy (DDP). Specifically, AWA mitigates the impact of device heterogeneity by strategically excluding underperforming clients and dynamically adjusting local model aggregation weights during training. Meanwhile, DDP enables each distributed PV client to autonomously adjust its privacy budget in real time according to data sensitivity, balancing privacy protection and model performance through dynamic noise injection. Experimental results on real-world PV datasets show that the proposed method obtains normalized root mean square error of 5.110% and normalized mean absolute error of 2.630%, indicating that the proposed algorithm achieves higher accuracy even under noise perturbations.

title: Post-Processing Geometry Enhancement for G-PCC Compressed LiDAR via Cylindrical Densification
authors: Wang Liu, Zhuangzi Li, Ge Li, Siwei Ma, Sam Kwong, Wei Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: The geometry-based point cloud compression algorithm achieves efficient compression and transmission for LiDAR point clouds with high sparsity. However, the low-bitrate mode results in severe geometry compression artifacts, which involve both point reduction and coordinate offset. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first attempt to directly enhance the geometry quality for compressed LiDAR point cloud (CLGE) in a post-processing manner. Our proposed method consists of two branches: cylindrical densification and adaptive refinement. The former adopts a multi-scale sparse convolution framework to effectively extract spatial features in the cylindrical coordinate system and generate dense candidate points quickly. Large asymmetric sparse convolution kernels are also designed to capture the shapes of different regions and objects. The latter branch refines the candidate points through several MLP layers, which takes the neighborhood features between the candidate points and the input points into account. Finally, the designed ring-based farthest point resampling serves as an effective alternative for achieving the target number while maintaining the geometry distribution. Extensive experiments conducted on several datasets verify the effectiveness of our approach under different compression artifact levels. Furthermore, our method is easily extended to upsampling and is robust to noise. In addition to the geometry signal quality improvement, the point cloud enhanced by our proposed method alleviates the performance degradation in object detection task due to compression distortion.

title: Telepalpation System for Stiffness Recognition of Tissue Digital Twins through Neuromorphic Vibrotactile Feedback in Virtual Reality
authors: Alessandro Profili, Flaminia Piretta, Marton Csaba Mezei, Muhammad Adnan Khalil, Fabrizia Auletta, Mariangela Filosa, Calogero Maria Oddo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: This study proposes a novel approach for telepal- pation of digital twins of biological tissue phantoms within a Virtual Reality environment, integrating neuromorphic vibrotactile feedback. When exploring the virtual sample, which presents varied material properties, a vibrotactile actuator placed on the user's fingertip delivers naturalistic stiffness feedback in real-time. The information is processed through a neuromorphic approach, which implements the spiking behavior of the mechanoreceptors of the human skin, to trigger vibrations of the haptic interface. A psychophysical experiment confirmed that the proposed strategy and system enable the identification of different stiffness levels with an overall accuracy of 94% and a threshold of stiffness difference of 0.13 N/mm. These results provide preliminary evidence for the possibility to detect tumor inclusions in biological tissue through digital twins. This pioneering approach paves the way for advanced telemedicine applications thereby fostering advancements in remote palpation of biological tissues for medical training and both remote and enhanced diagnosis.

title: AI in Operational Strategy: GPT & Perplexity Models in BofA's 2025 Branch Closure Case Study
authors: Yara Mohammed, Manar Alsaid, Gahangir Hossain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: The dynamic landscape of banking operations increasingly benefits from artificial intelligence, enhancing decision-making capabilities. In this study, we implemented two models: one under GPT framework and another using Perplexity, to leverage their powerful computational abilities to analyze and interpret financial data and operational trends. We employed sophisticated attention mechanisms and multi-head attention within these Large Language Models (LLMs) to investigate the strategic reasons behind the anticipated 2025 closures of Bank of America branches [12]. Using unstructured data, this study adopts a mixed-method framework that combines mathematical theories with advanced prompt engineering to compare the effectiveness of ChatGPT and Perplexity AI. By applying this approach, the study aims to highlight how each model performs in analyzing complex, real-world information and uncovering meaningful insights related to branch closures. The comparative analysis confirms that Perplexity AI outperformed ChatGPT by providing more precise and contextual relevant insights that are crucial for strategic decision-making in the banking sector. These results highlight the advanced capabilities of LLMs equipped with attention technologies in processing complex, multivariable datasets effectively. The implications of our research extend beyond just operational strategies within banks. They offer substantial insights that could revolutionize customer service management and investment strategies, contributing to a more nuanced understanding of evolving market dynamics. The study underscores the transformative potential of advanced LLMs in banking, recommending their broader adoption to effectively navigate and adapt to the rapid digital transformations in the industry.

title: Study On Fabrication Of Porous Silicon Formation And Analyze Its Effective Parameters
authors: S Praveen Kumar, J Sakthi Swarrup, D Lingaraja, G DineshRam, S Ramya
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: In this paper, the formation of porous silicon (Psi) using different process and its effective parameters on both n-type and p-type silicon wafer has been reviewed. The anodization based etching process for both Conventional method and double tank method was compared. The etching parameters like electrolytic solution, current densities, etchant time and morphological parameters like porosity, pore size, thickness of the pore, inter-pore distance can be analyzed for different properties of both n-type silicon and p-type silicon. Psi based biomedical application are highly focused.

title: PLSTM-Based Deep Learning Model for Land Subsidence Prediction Using GNSS Data: A Case Study in Padang City
authors: Rizka Rahmadina, Suryo Adhi Wibowo, Meiditomo Sutyarjoko
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: Land subsidence poses a significant risk to urban environments, especially in rapidly developing coastal regions. This research presents a deep learning approach using a novel Parallel Long Short-Term Memory (PLSTM) architecture for predicting land subsidence based on GNSS RINEX data from Padang City (2021–2024). Unlike traditional LSTM models, the proposed PLSTM processes multivariate spatial data streams in parallel, improving the learning of spatiotemporal dependencies. It achieves superior performance (MAE 0.019, RMSE 0.041, MSE 0.001), outperforming GRU, TCN, and Transformer. This work demonstrates the effectiveness of PLSTM for geospatial time series forecasting and contributes to the broader field of deep learning for spatial modeling and environmental monitoring.

title: Secure IoT Architecture Using Graph Neural Networks and Dynamic Trust Models to Combat Sybil Attacks
authors: S. Sweetlin Devamanohari, K. Prathapchandran
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: The rapid growth of IoT devices has increased network vulnerabilities, with Sybil attacks posing a major threat through identity forgery. To counter this, we propose GTSAD (Graph Neural Network-Trust Sybil Attack Detection), a robust framework combining Graph Neural Networks with dynamic trust management. GTSAD models the IoT network as a communication graph, characterizing nodes by features like packet delivery ratio, consistency, and honesty. A composite trust score—based on direct, indirect, and historical data—is computed for each node. These trust-augmented features are processed by a Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) to classify nodes as legitimate, suspicious, or Sybil. Sybil nodes face trust penalties, while suspicious nodes are monitored. GTSAD is adaptable in real time and shows higher detection accuracy and trust evaluation performance than traditional methods, making it a scalable and secure solution for future IoT networks.

title: Hardware Design and Algorithm Implementation of Brushless Motor Driver Based on CYT4BB7
authors: Keyu Yu, Xiai Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: As modern industrial automation improves by leaps and bounds, new energy vehicles, smart homes and other fields, brushless motors have been widely used due to their significant advantages such as high efficiency, high reliability, long lifespan and low maintenance costs. This article aims to design a brushless motor drive board based on Infineon's CYT4BB7 chip, integrating both six-step commutation and the Field Oriented Control (FOC) algorithm to drive Brushless Direct Current Motor (BLDC). The board's capability to process PWM signals and onboard potentiometers allows flexible motor speed control. With Hall sensors or magnetic encoders using the SPI protocol, it ensures precise rotor position feedback for accurate motor control. The integration of FOC optimizes torque and efficiency, making it ideal for applications like electric vehicles where energy use and motor lifespan are critical.

title: Exploring brain correlates of muscular activity and postural sway
authors: Marianna Chianese, Simone Papallo, Giuseppe Prisco, Rosa De Micco, Alessandro Tessitore, Paolo Gargiulo, Fabrizio Esposito, Leandro Donisi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Postural control indicates the ability to maintain stably our body in space and in time. This mechanism could be modelled as a dynamic feedback control system, where the central nervous system played a crucial role in ensuring the postural balance in standing position over time. Therefore, this work would insightfully explore this multimodal mechanism by combining information resulted from the simultaneous acquisition of postural, muscle and brain activity signals. Ten healthy volunteers were asked to stand with feet shoulder-width apart on a stable surface while keeping their eyes open for 30 s and postural sway parameters, lower limb muscle surface-electromyography (sEMG), and electroencephalography (EEG) signals were simultaneously recorded. Six global acceleration-domain postural sway parameters and two time-domain sEMG parameters for each leg muscle were extracted, while the EEG signals were processed to compute the functional brain connectivity matrices and to extract four global network graph theory (NGT) metrics, i.e., clustering coefficient, global efficiency, mean participation and assortativity. Spearman correlations were calculated and statistically significant negative correlation between postural sway parameters and, respectively, assortativity <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{p}=_{-}0.794)$</tex> and global efficiency <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{p}= -0.673$</tex>) and between the muscle contraction of the soleus and the mean participation (respectively, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{p}=-0.685, \mathrm{p}=-0.697$</tex> ) emerged. These results suggested the importance of having efficient organization and a rapid adaptive mechanism of the brain to ensure a good level of stability, as well as a highly interconnected network to determine a higher level of stability with lower muscular contractions. Further analysis on larger datasets, also considering the contribution of the different EEG bands separately and the extraction of local NGT metrics, could bring out newer and compelling links between brain organization and functioning and the adopted postural strategy.

title: Design of Fingerprint Combination Lock System in Ammunition Dump
authors: Chunming Zhang, Xiaofeng Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the development of technology, we can add some modern technologies, such as fingerprint identification technology, to the single unlocking function of Ammunition dump door locks. Fingerprint recognition equipment has been installed at checkpoints in some areas to supervise and record the movements of soldiers and cadres on and off sentries. Bullet management has always been a major part of the army management. We should update the locking mechanism of the Ammunition dump. Fingerprint identification technology is a better choice. The purpose of this design is to develop a fingerprint Combination lock system based on 51 single-chip microcomputer, and apply it to the Ammunition dump management of the armed police force, reduce the hidden dangers of ammunition management, and improve the convenience of ammunition use in grass-roots units.

title: Optimized control of servo angle balancer through computational algorithms
authors: Abhishek Chaudhary
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: This paper investigates the precise tracing of the servo angle reference trajectory for a two-degree-of-freedom ball balancer, which mimics an unmanned land vehicle having two degrees of movement. Two distinct optimization algorithms, namely the Teaching Learning Based Optimization (TLBO) algorithm and the Giza Pyramid Construction (GPC) algorithm, are employed to accurately perform the optimization process while maintaining balance for a ball over a rectangular plate connected to the ball balancer from Quanser. The adjustments to the reference trajectories of the servo angle for the rectangular plate are managed through the optimization of a Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) controller. The control of the simulated servo angle signal is accomplished by optimizing the constrained parameters of the PID controllers. This proposed approach is implemented using the MATLAB simulation platform, and the results are compared with both traditional and contemporary control schemes discussed in the literature.

title: Research on Automatic Recognition and Modulation Classification of Wireless Communication Signals Based on CNN-LSTM
authors: Yawen Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: In the background of the wide application of wireless communication technology, the electromagnetic environment is becoming more and more complex, and the traditional signal recognition and modulation classification methods based on artificial design characteristics are difficult to meet the needs. In this study, a deep learning model that integrates the local perception characteristics of convolutional neural network (CNN) and the temporal dynamic analysis capability of long short-term memory network (LSTM) is used to study various modulated signals such as BPSK, PSK8 and QAM16 under multi-SNR. By standardizing the signal amplitude with Z-score, the accuracy and robustness of signal recognition and modulation classification are improved by using the feature extraction capability of CNN and the advantages of LSTM in processing sequence data. The experimental results show that the accuracy of this model is 0.8139 on the 10-SNR test set, which is superior to other advanced algorithms. With the increase of signal-to-noise ratio, the classification accuracy is improved, and the model is robust to noise. Although some similar modulation types (such as QAM series) are misclassified, the overall classification is good. This research provides an efficient and reliable signal processing scheme for wireless communication system, which is of great significance for promoting the development of wireless communication technology.

title: Design of Student Attendance System Based on Face Recognition and IoT Communication
authors: Yuliza, Rachmat Muwardi, Sakinah Puspa Anggraeni, Mirna Yunita, Felix Tan, Ainul Yaqin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: In response to the increasing demand for efficient, accurate, and contactless attendance systems in educational environments, this study proposes a real-time student attendance system based on face recognition using the YOLOv3 algorithm. The system is deployed on a microprocessor platform and uses MQTT as the primary IoT communication protocol to enable low-latency, reliable, and lightweight two-way communication with a local server. Operating within a closed local host network, the system ensures data security and stability without reliance on external internet connectivity. The system’s performance was evaluated using the WIDER FACE, WIDER PERSON, and a custom dataset collected from Indonesian elementary school students. The results demonstrate that YOLOv3 achieved a detection accuracy of 88.5% (Easy), 86.2% (Medium), and 75.4% (Hard) with a stable processing speed of 25-30 FPS, offering an ideal balance between speed and accuracy for real-time school applications. Comparative evaluations show that MQTT outperformed HTTP and WebSocket protocols, achieving the lowest latency ($\mathbf{7 5 ~ m s}$), highest throughput ($\mathbf{8. 5 ~ m s g} / \mathbf{s}$), smallest payload size (1.5 KB), and highest success rate (99.6%). These findings confirm that YOLOv3 combined with MQTT provides a reliable, efficient, and scalable solution for schoolbased face recognition attendance systems.
