title: A Channel-Correlation-driven Hierarchical Attention Framework for Sepsis Time-Series Analysis
authors: Xian Peng, Yuanqi Zhao, Jianbo Li, Kangxing Wang, Zixuan Wang, Yinjie Lei
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Sepsis drives high mortality in intensive care units, yet existing models struggle to capture the multiscale temporal dynamics and evolving inter-variable correlations in physiological time series. To address this, we propose a Channel Correlation-driven Hierarchical Attention Framework for sepsis prognosis. It uses a Hierarchical Self-Attention Mechanism (HSAM) to model multiscale temporal patterns, and a Wavelet-based Channel Correlation Module (WCCM) that applies the Discrete Wavelet Transform to compute variable correlations and generate learnable masks at each scale. These masks guide HSAM to focus on clinically meaningful interactions and their temporal signatures. On the MIMIC-IV dataset, our model significantly outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on mortality prediction and physiological forecasting.

title: Design and Simulation of Microstrip Patch Antenna Array for Continuous Wave Radar Applications
authors: Navdeep Singh, Sankarsan Padhy, Anil Kumar Chaubey
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and analysis of Microstrip Patch Antenna Array using CST Microwave Studio in X-Band. RT/Duroid-5880 has been used as a substrate with the relative permittivity of 2.2. Different configurations of Microstrip Patch Antenna Array (Single Element, 1x2 Array, 1x4 Array and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4\mathrm{x}4$</tex> Array) have been designed at 10.5GHz resonant frequency. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4\mathrm{x}4$</tex> Microstrip Patch Antenna Array is portable planar antenna and light in weight, which can be used for Continuous Wave Radar applications. The simulation findings demonstrate that the array approach significantly enhances the antenna's performance. Directivity and Gain of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4\mathrm{x}4$</tex> Microstrip Patch Antenna Array is almost more than twice as compared to Single Element Microstrip Patch Antenna. The proposed Antenna Array has the overall size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(86^{*}95^{*}1.67\text{mm}3)$</tex> with the Return Loss -27.54dB, Bandwidth 199MHz, VSWR 1.08, Gain 18.6dBi and Beamwidth <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16.9^\circ$</tex>. The simulated antenna performance parameters show substantial improvement than the existing literature. These characteristics show an optimized electromagnetic design ensuring effective utilization of the radiating elements for better antenna performance.

title: Wearable Gaze-Brain-Computer Interface Instrumentation for Visual Target Detection During Hands-Occupied Dual-Tasking
authors: Xiaoying Xu, Huayu Zhang, Hong Zeng, Aiguo Song, Wenbin Zhang, Dapeng Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The head-mounted augmented reality (AR) device with gesture and verbal interfaces has been shown to facilitate co-located human-robot applications in dynamic environments. However, in hostile scenarios (e.g., search-and-rescue in after-disaster environment, reconnaissance in urban anti-terrorism, etc), the first-responder’s hands are often occupied with tasks and tools, leading to the demand for extra hands-free non-verbal instrumentation to detect and tag vital environment information (e.g., task-relevant targets) to robots. Recent studies on hands-free non-verbal instrumentation have elucidated several practical challenges, such as un-naturalistic efforts and constrained paradigms. Here, we proposed a wearable gaze-brain-computer interface (BCI) instrumentation that can directly detect and tag task-relevant targets based on the fixation-related potential (FRP) component of EEG signals, without flickering visual stimuli or limiting the position/duration of the observation. The proposed instrumentation was validated in a dual-task paradigm that simulated a real-world application, where the human has to concurrently perform knot tying with both hands and target detection/tagging with the proposed instrumentation. The results show that the wearable gaze-BCI instrumentation exhibited only marginal performance degradation in dual-tasking, with a decrease of 0.61 % (95 % CI: 0.10-1.11) in target classification accuracy (ACC), 1.00 bits/min (95 % CI: 0.13-1.88) in information transfer rate (ITR), and an increase of merely 0.39 % (95 % CI: -0.83-1.61) in false positive rate (FPR), compared to the single-tasking target detection. It suggests that the proposed instrumentation retains applicable in dual-tasking with high cognitive load demand. Moreover, the minor accuracy decrease of knot-tying task implies that target detection with the proposed instrumentation has little impact on accuracy of at-hand task. These findings reveal the potential of gaze-BCI as an extra hands-free non-verbal instrumentation for hands-occupied, while sustaining the performance of at-hand tasks.

title: Intelligent Detection and Prevention of Wi-Fi Data Theft using Machine Learning and Cybersecurity Analytics
authors: J. Mythili, R. Gopalakrishnan, M Mano Selvi, N Sundaresh
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Wi-Fi networks are the foundation of contemporary communication, but they are still more susceptible to behavior- based intrusions that get past traditional signature driven defenses, jamming, spoofing, and data-theft attempts. A potent tool for simulating intricate wireless behavior and identifying irregularities that indicate malicious activity is machine learning (ML). This study suggests a framework for intelligent Wi-Fi intrusion-detection and prevention that integrates automated mitigation, packet-level analytics, and supervised and unsupervised learning. The system exhibits increased accuracy, fewer false alarms, and quicker detection response when using AWID, NSL-KDD, and custom Wi-Fi traffic. The framework is appropriate for real-time wireless protection since integrated analytics improve administrator visibility.

title: Mitigating Slow UI Responsiveness in Modern Mobile Systems: A Large-Scale Study and Optimized Android Process Management
authors: Khushali Sandhi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: Modern mobile systems, while increasingly interactive, face a critical challenge of slow UI responsiveness (SUR), negatively impacting user experience. The lack of comprehensive studies on SUR has limited the understanding of its root causes due to challenges in measuring these events across massive mobile devices. In this paper, it present the first large-scale, long-term measurement study on SUR using data from 47 million Android devices. The findings reveal key contributors to SUR from four perspectives: device hardware, operating system, application design, and app market dynamics. Notably, the largest root cause stems from “hogging” apps-applications that disproportionately consume system resources by exploiting Android's optimistic process management design. To address this issue, it proposes a remodeled Android process management framework that incorporates time-sensitive transitions and the actual behavior of processes. This optimization achieves a 60 % reduction in SUR occurrences while also saving 10.7 % of battery consumption, demonstrating significant real-world impact. The work provides valuable insights into enhancing mobile system performance and improving user satisfaction.

title: Novel and Efficient prediction of Brain disorders using deep learning
authors: Ramavath Bikku, S V Dharani Kumar, Latofatoy Nurislomova, R. Chinnaiyan, E. Suneetha, B. Venkataramanaiah
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Present research growing with deep learning technologies. Deep learning models implementing on human health to detect health disorders. CNN used is a deep learning model used in proposed research to prediction brain disorders such as brain tumor. When processing a large number of MRI images, the conventional tumor analysis method depends on the doctor visually examining the person, which may lead to miss classifications. To lower the rate of human error, Proposed system introduces classification system that automatically n categorizes picture into no tumor and positive tumor. Brain tumors are among the diseases that claim the lives of most people worldwide. The chance of survival can be raised if the brain tumor is detected early on. MRI is a technique used to study the brain and detect diseases. CNN is used in proposed research to predict brain tumor with highest accuracy 97% over over existing research methods.Proposed research also used machine learning techniques such as Support vector machine(SVM) to predict brain tumor and achieved 94% accuracy.

title: AI-Driven Neuroplasticity Enhancement in Post-Stroke Recovery through Deep Q-Networks
authors: R. Meenambigai, B Asraf Yasmin, B. Parvathi, R Puviarasi, Monisha R, Anushiya S
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This research investigates AI-facilitated neuroplasticity improvement in post-stroke rehabilitation, using Deep Q-Networks (DQN) to refine recovery tactics. Neuroplasticity, the brain's capacity to reconfigure itself by establishing new neural connections, is essential for post-stroke recovery. It proposes a system incorporating DQN s to evaluate patient data and modify rehabilitation regimens in real time, optimizing engagement and efficacy. The model utilizes reinforcement learning to evaluate the effects of different therapy approaches on motor function recovery, enabling personalized treatment strategies. Findings indicate that the DQN-based strategy significantly enhances motor skill learning relative to conventional rehabilitation techniques. The results demonstrate that AI may significantly enhance neuroplasticity, improving stroke patients' recovery outcomes. It highlights the possibility of integrating modern machine learning methodologies with neurorehabilitation to enhance recovery methods and elevate the quality of life for stroke-affected persons. Future work will enhance the model and broaden its application across other patient demographics.

title: AI-Based SYN Flood Detection in Smart Networks Using Multi-Head Hybrid Sparse Attention
authors: Akshat Gaurav, Varsha Arya, Ritika Bansal, Kwok Tai Chui, Brij B. Gupta
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: SYN flood attacks remain a persistent threat to smart communication systems. These type of attacks exhaust server resources by exploiting TCP handshake mechanisms. Traditional detection methods often suffer from high complexity and limited adaptability. In this context, this paper proposes an AI-driven detection framework for the detection of SYN flood attack. The proposed model is based on a Multi-Head Hybrid Sparse Attention model. Optimal features are selected using evolutionary programming. The proposed model surpasses the baseline and existing methods with an accuracy of 99.99%.

title: Structural Diagnosability of an Electrolyser
authors: Belkacem Ould Bouamama, Douli Abdelhak Samir, Mahdi Boukerdja, Badoud Abd Essalam, Sumit Sood
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Application of model or data-based surveillance to the Green Hydrogen production systems is a challenging task. Their non-stationary and risky behavior are represented by complex nonlinear models because of interaction of several physical domains. The aim purpose of the paper is to show how the specific causal and structural properties of the bond graph as mechatronic modelling tool, can be exploited in the design step for structural detectability and isolability analysis of the degradations which may affect the electrolysis stack with any need of complex numerical calculation.

title: A Novel Deterministic Approach for Automatic Classification of Congestive Heart Failure
authors: Benedetta Rega, Alessandro Filisetti, Pietro Bia, Egidio De Benedetto, Antonio Manna
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: T-wave and R-peak irregularities are indicative of electrophysiological abnormalities in the cardiac cycle. These irregularities are key markers in an electrocardiogram (ECG) as they suggest the presence of congestive heart failure (CHF). Specifically, these anomalies reflect altered ventricular repolarization and abnormalities in the depolarization process, which are characteristic of the impaired cardiac function seen in CHF patients. In this work, a deterministic algorithm was developed with the aim of providing a timely and rapid indication of the presence of the pathology, thus allowing early intervention. The algorithm is based on the analysis of features extracted from T-waves and R-peaks in the ECG. The algorithm was tested on two datasets: the Fantasia Database and the BIDMC Congestive Heart Failure Database. After a band-pass filtering (0.5-15 Hz), modified Pan-Tompkins were used to detect R-peaks even in leads where they were negative. Subsequently, T-waves were identified. R-peaks and T-waves amplitudes were used for discriminating healthy and pathological subjects. These features were compared in terms of percentage error (PE), confusion matrix was computed and derivative index, such as True Positive Rate (TPR), Positive Predictive Value (PPV) and Accuracy (ACC), were extracted from it. The T-wave amplitude emerged as the most effective feature achieving a classification accuracy of 100 %. The promising results achieved by the developed algorithm indicate a substantial advancement in early detection of the disease during its initial stage. In practical applications, this would allow timely intervention by a physician, thereby enhancing patient care and management.

title: Dynamic $\mathrm{T}_{2}^{\ast}$ Mapping of Resting State Functional Connectivity: A Multi-Echo fMRI Approach
authors: G. Ponetti, G. Bosello, F. Dono, G. Evangelista, P. Chiacchiaretta, S. Sensi, M. Caulo, M. G. Perrucci, A. Ferretti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Multi-echo (ME) fMRI has several advantages with respect to standard single-echo (SE) acquisition. In particular, ME fMRI is used to optimize the BOLD contrast using a weighted combination of the signals obtained from acquisition at different echo times (TEs), with improved SNR, recovery of fMRI signal from regions affected by signal dropout and a better separation of BOLD and non-BOLD components. A much less explored approach offered by ME fMRI is the possibility to derive time series of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{T}_{2}^{\ast}$</tex> by modeling the data acquired at different TEs with the exponential decay function <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S=S_{0}\exp(-TE/T_{2}^{\ast}). >\mathrm{T}_2^{\ast}$</tex> time series are expected to be more specific to BOLD activation effects, whereas the acquired signal intensity S can be also affected by scanner drift, motion and inflow effects. In this study we investigated the sensitivity of fMRI based on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{T}_{2}^{\ast}$</tex> time series for the evaluation of functional connectivity in the default mode network during resting state, and showed that it retains a statistical significance comparable to that of standard SE acquisition.

title: Research on the Movement Control of Non-Traditional Six Propeller ROV Based on BP-PID Algorithm
authors: Shiyue Cui, Xinshuo Li, Zhihao Dong, Yong Cao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: In order to solve the problem that traditional PID control is difficult to adapt to the highly nonlinear and strongly coupled characteristics of ROV, this research, focusing on the motion control mechanism of ROV, constructs a non-traditional six-propeller-driven ROV physical platform and designs a PID control algorithm based on BP neural network. Through dynamic modeling and physical tests, the control effects of BP-PID and traditional PID are compared, and the improvement of system response characteristics and performance is evaluated. The experimental results indicate that the BP-PID control algorithm has significant advantages in enhancing the stability and response speed of the ROV system. After optimization, Pitch stabilizes after approximately 40 iterations, with the steady-state error controlled at about 4° and the maximum deviation also at about 4°; Roll stabilizes after 55 iterations, with the steady-state error at about 2° and the maximum deviation at 17°; Yaw stabilizes after 50 iterations, with the steady-state error at about 10° and the maximum deviation at 13°. These data suggest that the optimized system shows a shorter adjustment time before reaching the steady state and a significantly reduced steady-state error. In terms of dynamic performance, the overshoot of the system optimized by BP-PID is significantly reduced, and the recovery time is shortened, demonstrating superior anti-interference ability and robustness.

title: Analysis and Simulation of the Commutation Failure Mechanism in Multi-DC Feed Systems
authors: Huifeng Guo, Xuxuan Chen, Bo Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the increasing load center of the power grid, induction motor loads, due to their highly nonlinear and dynamic characteristics, have become a maj or challenge faced by power systems, bringing risks of voltage instability and even system collapse. Particularly in the context of China's rapid development of the AC-DC hybrid grid, the issue of commutation failure triggered by induction motor loads has posed a severe test to the safe and stable operation of the power system. However, the mechanism of commutation failure has not been fully studied or clearly defined. Therefore, this paper delves into the analysis of the characteristics of induction motor loads and explores their relationship with power system stability. Finally, based on the HYPERSIM platform, a regional AC-DC system model is constructed, and simulation analyses under different load conditions are conducted to reveal the impact of this phenomenon on system stability.

title: AI-Driven Behavioral Inference From Open Energy Data: Implications for Public Data Governance
authors: Yanis Fadili, Valérie Fernandez, Thomas Houy, Guillaume Guérard
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Open data initiatives in smart cities are designed to promote transparency and improve public services. However, recent advances in machine learning allow behavioral inferences to be drawn from anonymized datasets. This paper applies Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) to residential electricity consumption data from a public-government repository to detect patterns of presence and absence. The analysis does not rely on personal identifiers, but instead focuses on temporal similarity across consumption curves. Our contributions include (1) one of the first exploratory applications of DTW to French open energy data for behavioral inference, (2) a comparative evaluation of four DTW implementations, and (3) a governance framework supported by operational recommendations and illustrated by an adaptive cycle.

title: Deep Learning-Based Statistical Anomaly Detection for Credit Card Fraud Using Visual and Tabular Data Fusion
authors: Mitu Sehgal, Sorabh Gupta, Rashmi Makkar, Neera Batra, Shally Nagpal
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Effective identification and prevention of credit card fraud is crucial as it poses a significant financial threat to both individuals and society. This study employs statistical techniques to detect fraudulent transactions. This study has a multistage pipeline frame, which is used to improve the fraud detection accuracy. This pipeline includes ETL (Extract, Transform, and Load) operations, SQL-based data cleaning, and Power BI, aiming for an end-to-end data presentation dashboard. In addition, deep learning models, together with statistical methods, are utilized to identify complex patterns in individual transaction behavior. These models facilitate anomaly identification by integrating multimodal data from both tabular and visual formats. The results show that statistical techniques have the potential to identify unusual patterns in immense financial databases, allowing for more efficient strategies to combat fraud. We intend to direct our future efforts towards merging deep learning models with security frameworks.

title: Teaching Evaluation Algorithm for Higher Vocational Education Design Majors Based on Neural Network from AI Perspective
authors: Hong Zhang, Yu Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the rapid development of artificial intelligence technology, its application in the field of educational evaluation has become an important research direction of educational intelligence. Aiming at the teaching evaluation of design majors in higher vocational education, this study proposed a hybrid neural network teaching evaluation model based on attention mechanism. The multi-source heterogeneous teaching evaluation data was processed by combining multi-layer perceptron, long and short term memory network and self-attention mechanism, and the weight allocation of indicators was optimized by combining analytic hierarchy process and data-driven method. Experimental data in this study show that compared with traditional evaluation methods and existing neural network models, the accuracy, consistency and stability of this model are significantly improved, with an average accuracy of 92.75%, which is 7.83 percentage points higher than that of traditional BP neural network.

title: Comparison of Chunking Techniques Across Diverse Document Types in NLP Retrieval Tasks
authors: Shruti Jaiswal, Priyank Bisht, Krity Kansara, MSH Shankar Datta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: In retrieval-augmented natural language processing systems, how information is segmented—or chunked-plays a critical role in determining the accuracy, efficiency, and robustness of downstream retrieval performance. Despite the increasing reliance on retrieval-based architectures such as open-domain question answering and RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation), there remains limited empirical work comparing different chunking strategies in a systematic, task-specific manner. In this paper, we present a comprehensive comparative study of widely used chunking methods—fixed-size chunking, sentence-based chunking, recursive chunking and semantic similarity-based chunking—evaluated within the context of retrieval performance across diverse document types. We analyze each strategy across multiple metrics including Precision, Recall, MRR(Mean Reciprocal Rank), and chunking efficiency, emphasizing how performance varies significantly with the structural and semantic characteristics of different document types. Our findings high-light key trade-offs between retrieval accuracy and chunking granularity, revealing that while finer-grained semantic chunking often improves precision, it may also introduce computational overhead, especially in certain document types. These insights provide practical guidelines for developers and researchers building retrieval-centric NLP pipelines and lay the groundwork for future work on adaptive and task-aware chunking mechanisms.

title: Automatic Culicoides Biting Midges Classification Using Transfer Learning and Shallow Learning Techniques
authors: Carlos A. Lincango, Noel Pérez-Pérez, Maria Baldeon-Calisto, Sonia Zapata, Juan D. Mosquera, Diego S. Benítez
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Accurate identification of Culicoides species is essential for effective entomological monitoring, but remains challenging due to subtle morphological variation between species. This work proposes the development of a Culicoides species classification method based on a pre-trained ResNet-18 backbone for feature extraction and a set of four shallow learning classifiers to maximize predictive performance. The proposed method was trained and validated on a publicly available database, which was increased in the training partition by using five data augmentation operations. The highest mean F1-score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.964 \pm 0.01$</tex> was obtained by the SVM classifier using a twotimes stratified five-fold cross-validation strategy. Also, it reached a successful classification result of F1-score = 0.966 on the test set, suggesting good generalization and ensuring the proposed method's output. The comparison against two previously developed state-of-the-art methods highlighted the proposed method's superior performance with an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve score of 0.99. The proposed method leveraged the transfer learning strategy to minimize the need for extensive image data in the model's training process and increased the deployment opportunities by implementing a lightweight and scalable classification scheme, which can be considered as a potential tool for classifying Culicoides species in the field.

title: Integrated E-Procurement Trend With Generative AI for Green Purchasing Policy
authors: Wan Abdul Fattah Wan Abdullah, Rozana Zakaria, Siti Maherah Hussin, M. Faizal Zukarnaini, Loganathan Ratana Singaram, Jawa Gara
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Procurement is a process that involves acquiring, managing, and organising products and services. All governments and public sectors engage in public expenditures through procurement procedures, including direct purchases and quotations, closed tenders, open tenders, and direct talks, depending on the circumstances. Green Purchasing Policy (GPP) is a plan of action and/or a policy commitment that will assist an organisation in implementing green purchasing in procurement. E-Procurement is the use of electronic devices and facilities, and online applications for the administration, coordination, and enhancement of an acquisition procedure. Relatively, public procurement has the ability to contribute to the consumption and production of diverse products and services in a sustainable manner. Thus, this study highlights the trend of research for the potential development of an integrated e-procurement decision-making tool for GPP to determine the effectiveness of incorporating green procurement practices into the organisational operations of procurement assessment. A bibliometric analysis is used for the methodology in determining the target selective literature. This study summarised eight common factors recognised as influencing the trend.

title: AI-driven Integration of EEG and Motor Assessment to Explore Motor-Cognitive Interaction in Multiple Sclerosis
authors: Nicola Valè, Ilaria Siviero, Gloria Menegaz, Ander Ramos-Murguialday, Silvia Savazzi, Sofia Straudi, Alberto Gajofatto, Riccardo Orlandi, Mauro Crestani, Marialuisa Gandolfi, Silvia Francesca Storti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Fall risk assessment in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) is typically based on a series of clinical scales and questionnaires. In the past decade, instrumental analysis using wearable sensors has gained attention, although technical limitations, such as recording electroencephalography (EEG) while walking, still limit their applicability. We propose a novel framework for assessing cognitive-motor interaction in PwMS within a cross-sectional study, integrating wearable 8-channel EEG with an inertial measurement unit (IMU) sensor placed on participants' forearm. The study involved 13 PwMS (6 females; mean age: 59.3 ± 11.5 years; Kurtzke Expanded Disability Status Scale (median [25<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup>-75<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> percentiles]: 5.5 [4.25-6.00]), who performed i) the timed up and go (TUG) in isolation (single-task motor, STm); ii)the TUG while performing a cognitive task of serial subtraction of 7s (motor-cognitive dual-task [DT] condition); iii) the serial subtraction for 90 while sitting. Motion data were used for automatic TUG segmentation via a hybrid convolutional neural network and long-short-term-memory model, which also allows the alignment and extraction of EEG epochs corresponding to each trial. EEG workload was quantified using the task load index (TLI), that quantifies cognitive workload defined as the ratio of the power spectral density (PSD) in theta (4–8 Hz) and alpha (8–12 Hz) bands. The model allowed accurate TUG segmentation, with a root-mean-squared-error (RMSE) of 0.42 s and 0.36 s for STm and DT, respectively. On the other hand, EEG-based assessment found a significant effect of condition in TLI, suggesting an increased trend in mental workload during the DT condition, with greater values in DT compared to STc for all the outcomes. The planned inclusion of additional participants is expected to help draw more robust conclusions regarding cortical dynamics in PwMS during DT performance.

title: TinyML-Based Hazardous Gas Detection for Intelligent Personal Protective Equipment
authors: Celina Kudrin-Gusten, Michael Kuhl, Valentin Barth, Hang Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The increasing integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into safety-critical systems has given rise to innovative approaches for real-time monitoring of a variety of dangerous conditions in personal protective equipment (PPE) [1]. In various sectors, such as the fire service and the chemical industry, there are a large number of gases that pose a potential risk to workers. [2] The use of a gas detection system, integrated in the PPE, can be effective in containing this risk. The focus of this study is the presentation of a Tiny Machine Learning (TinyML)-based approach that combines modern MEMS-MOS sensors with a lightweight neural network on an ESP32-C6 to enable the precise detection of hazardous substances under varying environmental conditions. It has been demonstrated through experimental comparisons that the TinyML-based system offers significant improvements in terms of reduced response time and enhanced detection accuracy. Indeed, experimental findings have shown that these gains have been achieved from an average of 70-85% using conventional signal thresholding methods to up to 100% using TinyML-based classification. This was achieved in detecting high-concentration ethanol (99.9%) and distilled water, while maintaining strong performance across other gas types and conditions. Specifically, the TinyML-based system has been shown to reduce alerting time by almost half and achieve a higher classification accuracy, which represents a substantial added value in emergency situations. The adaptive modelling also enables robust performance despite fluctuating environmental parameters, underlining the potential of Tiny ML as a key technology for improving safety in high-risk areas and paving the way for the next generation of intelligent PPE solutions.

title: Enhancement of 5G Ultra-Reliable Low-Latency Communication: Application of Edge Computing and AI-Based Approaches
authors: Sargunavathi S, Vijayalakshmi V, Shobana D, D. Vishnu Priya, Mohyedin Hamza, Ankur Bahl
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The fast deployment of 5G networks has enabled new opportunities for real-time applications for critical areas such as autonomous driving, remote surgery, industrial automation, and mission-critical Internet of Things (IoT). Ultra-Reliable Low-Latency Communication (URLLC) is one of the most challenging features of 5G, with the requirement of transmission reliability higher than 99.999% and latency less than 1 ms. This paper investigates a candidate design framework to enhance URLLC by employing edge computing with artificial intelligence (AI) based optimization strategies. The primary goal is to reduce the and packet loss without degrading services reliability under dynamic and congested network. In its focus on edge as the subject of study, this paper presupposes from distributed computing architectures structures in which the distance between the source of data and the computation is reduced both physically and logically. This offloading leads to decreased duration of transmissions and provides the possibility of a more context-aware control located closer to the UE. For these purposes we exploit AI methodologies like reinforcement learning and deep neural networks, to make resource allocation, spectrum management and even predictive traffic scheduling, adapt in real-time. These techniques lead to proactive booth adaptive and guaranteeing the URLLC performance in time evolutions of network demands with no bottlenecks of centralized coordination. Comparison and simulation results show that the proposed model achieves significant performance gains compared to the conventional centralized methods. The system reduces the latency by as much as 42% and increases the reliability by more than 30% in highly varied environment. The integration of AI in edge-based URLLC orchestration also becomes beneficial for predicting future failure scenarios and avoiding unnecessary resource reallocation for the service continuity. This work is part of the ongoing efforts to evolve intelligent 5GSs that will support real-time and safety critical communications on a massive scale. Finally, the theoretical URLLC standards are connected with practical deployment through edge intelligence (EI) and machine learning (ML) in this work. The results confirm that the combined services of edge computing and AI not only satisfy the highly demanding URLLC requirements, but they also exceed it. Such integrated treatment sets a foundation of future adaptive 6G networks and extends the practical possibility of delay-sensitive applications in real-life scenarios.

title: Botox Optimization Based MPPT of Four Strings PV System Under Partial Shading with a Switched-Capacitor Based High Step-Up Non-Isolated DC-DC Converter
authors: M Rama Prasada Reddy, Ch. Srinivasa Rao, Abhishek Agarwal, B. M. Manjunatha, Ankita Nainwal, S. Senthil Kumar, Nagarjuna Malladhi, Kandi Bhanu Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Many types of maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithms along with MPPT devices are used to extract maximum power from Photovoltaic (PV) systems worldwide for various applications. Due to numerous reasons, there will be a more possibility to effect many number of PV modules in the system by partial shading conditions (PSCs). In generally Perturb and Observe (P&O) technique is regularly used to identify the maximum power point location (MPPL). Unfortunately generalized P&O technique cannot reach global MPPL under PSCs due to existence of multiple peaks. Under these circumstances, optimization methods must be incorporated to identify the global MPPL among many power point peaks. There are several optimization methods existing for the MPPT operation of PV system under PSCs. However, due to many concerns those methods are having their own limits. A novel methodology such as Botox Optimization Algorithm (BOA) is implemented in this paper for the MPPT application. A four strings connected PV system is considered in this paper. Regarding convert of MPPT device, a high step-up non-isolated de to de converter is utilized due to its features over conventional boost converter. The proposed method presented in this paper is compared with Modified Invasive Weed Optimization (MIWO), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) and Grey Wolf Optimization (MGWO) methods. OPAL-RT modules are used to establish a Hardware - in the - Loop (HIL) for presenting realistic responses under various operating conditions.

title: PEFT-Driven LLMs for Pharmaceutical Business Intelligence: A Scalable Framework Using LoRA with Retrieval- Augmented Decision Support
authors: Piyush H. Kadethankar, Ramchandra R. Manthalkar, Krashana D. Nirde, Samruddhi Gajanan Khode, Rutuja Prem Rathod
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This paper introduces a scalable and cost-efficient AI framework for pharmaceutical business intelligence, pow-ered by fine-tuned LLaMA-2 models using Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) and Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA). By updating only 0.39% of model parameters, the system reduces GPU memory usage, training time, and storage needs while maintaining performance. Deployed via a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipeline linked to curated pharma datasets, the model supports domain-specific, context-aware decision-making. Applications include predicting patient responses in clinical trials, automating market intelligence from regulatory and financial documents, and optimizing supply chain operations through logistics forecasting. The framework incorporates data anonymization and differential privacy to ensure compliance and security. Experimental results show high accuracy in di-verse pharma tasks. To our knowledge, this is the first LoRA-augmented RAG system tailored for the pharmaceutical industry. Its modular design enables adoption by both large and mid-sized firms, offering a practical, low-infrastructure path to AI-driven insights and operational efficiency.

title: Analysis and Handling of Partial Discharge Abnormalities in a 500kV Transformer
authors: Limin Qu, Chao Wang, Jian Zhang, Yuenan Guo, Jianquan Liang, Lianbo Wei, Yubo Shen, Xiangyu Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Partial discharge test of transformers is an essential part of equipment factory testing and an important means of assessing the overall insulation performance of transformers. Taking the disassembly analysis and handling method of partial discharge test abnormalities during the factory test of a 500kV transformer as an example, this article elaborates on the background and method of induction withstand voltage test with partial discharge measurement, and describes in detail the handling of partial discharge abnormalities. In the process of identifying the cause of the abnormality, the starting position of the fault was accurately determined through disassembly inspection, simulation calculation, physical and chemical analysis of the insulation cardboard, and X-ray inspection of the formed parts. The discharge traces left on the body were identified, and the discharge path was determined to accurately determine the cause of the fault. At the same time, a repair plan for the subsequent transformer was provided, and two partial discharge tests were conducted to verify that the transformer's handling measures were reasonable and effective, ensuring zero defect operation of the equipment.

title: Light Face Net: A Lightweight CLAHE-Arc Face Framework for Low-Light Face Recognition
authors: S Sakitha, C Sushil Shree, P Jayabharathi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Face recognition in low light has a lower contrast and more noise. The current models of enhancements like Low- FaceNet [1] and Retinex [2] enhance accuracy but can be computationally intensive and cannot be used in real-time to the resource-limited devices. LightFaceNet is a light architecture that incorporates CLAHE to recover the illumination and ArcFace embedded features to discriminate identities. It matches with $94.3 \%$ and $90.1 \%$ accuracy with a low and very-low-light with a latency of less than 50 ms deployable to CCTV, IoT, and mobile using cosine similarity.

title: LIME vs SHAP: Explainable AI for Image Classification with Object Highlighting and Background Blur
authors: M Vijay Anand, S Prem Kumar, A Mohammed Muzammil, A Immanuvel Stanley
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: It is a fact that the performance of deep convolutional networks in different image classification benchmarks is almost consistently at the highest level but retain the mystery of a black-box for both users and professionals working in the same field. Explanatory methods like LIME and SHAP, for instance, produce visual attributions (masks or heatmaps), indicating the areas of an image that have influenced the prediction the most; however, the saliency maps that come along with the diffusion are often not very intuitive for non-expert users and are even sometimes not visually appealing. The current study provides an extensive comparison of the two methods LIME and SHAP on CIFAR-10 dataset with a human-centered critique and, at the same time, presents a visual enhancement pipeline that converts attribution maps into object-centered explanations that are precise. Our pipeline finds the crucial area(s) in an attribution map, it draws an unobtrusive highlight and contour around the focal object and then it applies a controlled Gaussian blur to the remaining background areas in order to create a more perceptually focused effect. We evaluate the approaches from the perspectives of both technical aspects (fidelity, spread, computational cost) and human-centered criteria (clarity, perceived trust), and this evaluation will be conducted by means of a combination of quantitative experiments and a user study. The results show that LIME gives rise to attributions that are more sparse and localized and in many cases very closely matching to the object regions, while on the other hand, SHAP produces attributions that are smoother and more evenly distributed. Our enhancement pipeline notably increases the human interpretability of the two methods, as evidenced by the increase in the clarity and trust scores in the user evaluations, the discovery of a fidelity vs. interpretability trade-off at the same time, and so on.

title: Machine Learning Techniques for Wi-Fi CSI-based Recognition and Sensing: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Siva Sai, Devansh Sharma, Mritunjay Shall Peelam, Vinay Chamola, Mohsen Guizani, Dusit Niyato
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Wi-Fi Channel State Information (CSI) has become a widely studied modality for device-free sensing as it captures fine-grained wireless channel variations that can be mapped to human motion and presence while avoiding the explicit visual disclosure typical of vision-based systems. CSI-based pipelines have been explored for human activity and gesture recognition, fall detection, gait analysis, pose-related inference, and indoor localization. Despite strong results in controlled settings, practical deployment remains difficult due to measurement noise, sensitivity to environmental dynamics, multi-user interference, and system-level constraints in data acquisition and real-time processing. This article surveys machine learning methods forWi-Fi CSI sensing and analyzes more than 65 representative models, connecting algorithmic design choices with implementable end-to-end system design. We introduce a hierarchical taxonomy that organizes the literature into classical machine learning approaches, deep learning architectures, and hybrid strategies. Beyond modeling, we describe the full sensing pipeline- from hardware and network interface card (NIC) selection to software tools, antenna configuration, and signal conditioning- highlighting the design trade-offs that affect robustness and reproducibility. We further compare methods across major application domains and summarize open challenges in generalization to dynamic environments, multi-user separation, and resource-efficient inference. Finally, we outline research directions toward robust generalization, scalable deployment, and privacy-aware learning to support broader real-world adoption.

title: Research on UAV Circular Formation Triangulation Localization Model Based on Greedy Algorithm
authors: Tong Liu, Ziyue Dong, Jianxun Xing, Huijie Gou
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the wide application of UAV formations in the engineering field, circular UAV formations in electromagnetic silence scenarios have gradually become a research focus due to their fast convergence speed, low collision rate, and wide detection coverage. This study realizes autonomous positioning and deviation correction of UAV clusters by constructing a triangulation model of the points to be measured and known points to process the position signals emitted by UAVs in real time. And at the same time, according to the initial polar position of the UAV circular formation during a flight training exercise, the optimal scheme for adjusting the UAVs to the standard position is given based on the triangulation model and greedy algorithm and the accuracy and feasibility of the scheme are proved through the error analysis. The accuracy and feasibility of the program is proved by error analysis. This study provides a real-time localization and position adjustment scheme for UAV circular formation, which autonomously adjusts the UAV cluster that deviates from the orbit within 12 meters to an on-orbit circular formation with an error of less than 0.5 meters after 7 iterations, which is of great significance for the application of UAV clusters in actual flight.

title: Reimagining Interaction through Empathy and Ethics: AI with a Human-Centered Approach
authors: Nazim Hussain Joo, Bhoomi Vij
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: This future AI will be our way of “technologically engaging the world” and as sso technologies must have a similar value, affect and ethos as people. More specifically, regarding research situated within Human-Centered AI (HCAI), 73 articles between 2009 and 2025 counting total of 181 papers were studied for this dissertation, at an average annual rate of growth of 24.57%. When also accounting for the big inputs of Carnegie Mellon and Delft University, the same results show a very high level of clustering of publications around conferences such as CHI and IUI. Both Müller and Holzinger also make valuable contributions to more recent relevant literature on humane-centric design and ethical artificial intelligence. It finds that “user empowerment, emotional responsiveness, and openness start to become a concern for AI systems”. This particular study focused on performance, but the authors warn that “trust, empathy and moral issues can no longer be taken for granted if we are to create truly wise and human- centered technology”. Finally it challenges that empathy and ethics might become necessary drivers for the future of AI-human interaction, and questions the need for research on the new drives that will ideally move AI develop.

title: safeWatch: A SOC Toolkit for Digital Resilience and Learning
authors: Asheesh Tiwari, Ketan Ray, Karan Singh
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: In the increasingly interconnected digital landscape, cybersecurity threats have become more pervasive, sophisticated, and difficult to detect. As enterprises continue to invest heavily in complex Security Operations Center (SOC) infrastructures, there remains a pressing need for accessible, modular, and educationally oriented cybersecurity toolkits for smaller organizations, independent researchers, and academic learners. Traditional SOC platforms often demand significant technical expertise, financial investment, and dedicated infrastructure, placing them out of reach for a large segment of potential users. This research introduces safe Watch, a lightweight, open-source SOC simulation toolkit that addresses these limitations by providing essential threat investigation capabilities in a simplified, modular format. safe Watch is implemented as a dual-interface platform, consisting of a Chrome browser extension and a standalone Tkinter-based desktop application, both interacting with a Python Flask backend. The toolkit allows users to perform critical cybersecurity tasks such as DNS resolution, WHOIS lookups, URL sanitization, and reputation checks via the VirusTotal API, with emphasis on local execution and offline capability where possible. Designed with educational and operational flexibility in mind, safeWatch aims to empower users with hands-on cybersecurity experience without the complexity of traditional enterprise systems. Through real-time observables analysis, modular scripting, and an intuitive user interface, the toolkit serves as an ideal bridge between theoretical cybersecurity knowledge and practical application. Furthermore, safe Watch's modular architecture supports future expansion, allowing new threat intelligence modules and scanning capabilities to be integrated easily. This paper details the technical architecture, implementation methodologies, and practical case studies evaluating safe Watch's usability and effectiveness. The findings demonstrate that safe Watch can serve not only as a learning platform for students but also as a lightweight investigative tool for smaller operational teams, thereby contributing to broader efforts to democratize cybersecurity resilience in an era of increasing cyber risk.

title: Selective Disclosure in Transit : SSI and Key Derivation-Based Privacy Protection for Logistics
authors: Junliang Liu, Zhiyao Liang, Qiuyun Lyu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: With the rapid growth of e-commerce, protecting users' personal information throughout the logistics and delivery process has become a pressing concern. Traditional logistics systems typically handle recipients' delivery details in plaintext, which exposes sensitive information to unnecessary intermediaries or entities—heightening the risk of data leakage and misuse. This paper introduces a novel privacy-preserving logistics framework based on Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) and key derivation mechanisms, enabling users to protect their real-world identities by leveraging digital identities. Through selective disclosure, users can reveal only the minimum necessary information to each party involved in the delivery chain. We propose a dynamic key derivation method to enforce and audit disclosure control throughout the process. The security of the design is formally verified, and performance simulations demonstrate that the system achieves acceptable operational efficiency.

title: A Neurodynamic Approach to Multi-Objective Fuzzy Optimization Problem
authors: Xin Li, Jin Hu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: This paper introduces a neurodynamic framework for addressing multi-objective fuzzy optimization problems (MO-FOPs). Due to the inherent conflicts among objectives and the uncertainty in fuzzy parameters, conventional optimization algorithms often struggle to achieve satisfactory solutions. To overcome these limitations, we develop a one-layer neural network specifically designed for this class of problems. The proposed method first transforms the fuzzy optimization model into an interval-valued one, which is then reformulated as a single-objective optimization problem by integrating the midpoint-radius transformation with a weighted-sum strategy. Based on the Karush-Kuhn- Tucker (KKT) conditions, a neurodynamic model is constructed, and its global convergence and Lyapunov stability are rigorously established. Numerical simulations are conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed approach.

title: Influence of Age and Gender on Cortical Activity During Postural Control
authors: Lorena Guerrini, Federica Pescaglia, Carmine Gelormini, Vittorio Santoriello, Vincenzo Minutolo, Giorgio Di Lorenzo, Hannes Petersen, Halldór Jónsson, Paolo Gargiulo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Aging is a significant factor influencing postural control (PC), leading to a progressive decline in postural stability, with older adults exhibiting greater instability compared to younger individuals. This study investigates cortical activity in 289 healthy individuals, 72% under 40 years old and 28% over 40, during a complex postural task using high-density electroencephalography (EEG) recordings. Relative Power Spectral Density (PSD) was calculated for each electrode, and age-related differences were assessed. The statistical analysis, highlighting electrodes significant at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p < 0.05$</tex> and after False Discovery Rate (FDR) correction, revealed increased Beta and Low Gamma power in the Over40 group, while Theta and Alpha power were higher in the Under40 group across nearly all stimulation phases. Behavioral indices further supported these findings, indicating reduced physical and neurocognitive status in older adults and greater responsiveness to multisensory stimulation in younger participants. These variations across frequency bands and behavioral dimensions reflect distinct PC responses and underline age-related neural and musculoskeletal changes affecting balance. This approach supports the identification of potential biomarkers and can be extended to neurological populations. These findings underscore the importance of age when designing interventions to assess and improve balance, and they may contribute to the early detection of age-related postural deficits.

title: AsymFaceDeformNet: Asymmetric 3D Face Reconstruction for Facial Paralysis
authors: Xiaoxue Fan, Haodong Jin, Yiming Wang, Hui Yu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: Facial paralysis is a disorder characterized by of impaired facial muscle movement due to damage to the facial never or inflammatory responses. The primary pathological manifestation is the partial or complete loss of voluntary muscle control on one side of the face. Accurate diagnosis and treatment require precise 3D reconstruction of the affected facial region. However, reconstructing 3D faces for patients with facial paralysis presents a significant challenge due to the complex geometry and subtle expression details of a paralyzed face. As a result, this problem has rarely been studied so far. To tackle this challenge, we propose a supervised learning-based 3D facial reconstruction method, called AsymFaceDeformNet (AFDN) in this study to generate a high-precision 3D shape for the 2D facial palsy image. AFDN employs a three-layer fully connected neural network as its core structure and can learn complex facial deformations and transformation relationships to model latent shape variations. It is designed to accurately restore the 3D facial structure of patients with facial paralysis. Extensive quantitative and qualitative experiments validate the effectiveness and rationality of the proposed method.

title: SSH-BA: Safeguarding Smart Homes with Intelligent IoT Behavior Analysis Using Classification Techniques
authors: Saurabh Pratap Singh Rathore, Babitha Lincy R, Nagendar Yamsani, Pawan Kumar, Pooja Bhardwaj, Javalkar Dinesh Kumar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Smart home technologies automate regular operations like temperatures and lighting reacting to voice commands, making life easier. Smartphones allow homeowners to remotely operate these devices and monitor and manage their homes in real time. Smart home devices use IoT to make life smarter, more effective, and more customized. Smart home IoT devices may be hacked to access security cameras and personal data. Attackers might manipulate smart locks or thermostats, threatening people and their property. These IoT devices are networked, making strong cybersecurity necessary to guard against emerging threats. Early cybersecurity identification enables quick reaction and remediation, limiting damage and averting attack escalation. Early detection of security breaches allows proactive actions to stop unwanted access, limit the effect, and protect critical data. It dramatically minimizes the window of vulnerability, improving cybersecurity resilience and safeguarding systems from protracted exploitation or criminal activity. This research improves smart home security by training Aposemat IoT-23 dataset. XG Boost, Simple Neural Network, Gaussian NB and Logistic Regression are evaluated to identify and prevent harmful data injection and illegal access. The results show they protect smart home networks with over 99% accuracy. Smart home IoT device protection is excellent with machine learning techniques like XG Boost and Simple Neural Network. These algorithms identify and block unwanted access and harmful data injection.

title: AI-Enabled Smart Irrigation and Crop Health Monitoring System
authors: Josephine Selle Jeyanathan, G. Keerthiga, K. Yaswanth, V. Giri Sai, K. Nandha Kishor Reddy
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Using artificial intelligence and the Internet of Things, the AI-Enabled Smart Irrigation and Crop Health Monitoring System is a creative way to revolutionize conventional agriculture. Its goal is to use real-time data and insights to automate and optimize crop health and irrigation management. Sensors, controllers, communication modules, cloud platforms, and user interfaces are some of the parts that make up the system. The camera will take a picture of the plant leaf, and the system will analyze its condition, provide AI insights, and, via a mobile application, advise the user on the necessary safety measures. The sensors gather information on variables like crop health, humidity, and soil moisture. The controllers use wired or wireless modules to process the data and connect to the cloud platform. In parallel, early indicators of crop diseases and nutrient deficiencies are detected through image-based analysis employing deep learning techniques. The system minimizes resource waste, encourages prompt interventions, and reduces manual labor by providing farmers with actionable insights through an intuitive interface. The system is a feasible option for contemporary precision agriculture, as field testing shows increased water efficiency and early detection accuracy.

title: Using Clinical Records and Machine Learning to Predict Alzheimer's Disease Through Data-Driven Methods
authors: Prabhjot Kaur, D. Vetrithangam, Amit Kamra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is the dominant reason for the development of dementia in many older people. If doctors can spot AD at an early stage, it can help in slowing down the progression of the disease and give people better care. In this study, we scrutinized how effectively various machine learning models can distinguish between people with Alzheimer's and those who don't have the disease, by using details about their health and daily habits. We examined five different models: Logistic Regression (LR), Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Random Forest (RF), and Gaussian Naive Bayes, all using data from Kaggle. Among these, the Random Forest model-based experiment provided the best results, followed by SVM and Logistic Regression, which also performed well. Research-based results show that machine learning can help doctors diagnose AD more easily and at a lower cost, especially in areas where modern technology-based scans are not available. For this reason, we require the use of information from patients' health records.

title: Message from the General Chair & the Program Chairs QAI 2025
authors: Giovanni Acampora, Autilia Vitiello, Amir Pourabdollah
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: On behalf of the Organizing Committee, it is our great pleasure to welcome you to the 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (IEEE QAI 2025), held from November 2 to 5, 2025, in the beautiful and historic city of Naples, Italy, a place where science, art, culture, and tradition harmoniously converge, offering a truly inspiring environment for creativity and intellectual exchange.

title: Human Autonomy vs AI Autonomy: Society Resists Against Tech Companies' Desires in the Era of Autonomous Agents
authors: Omid Veisi, Anastasia Kuzminykh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Tech agencies and scholars often use the term ‘autonomy' to describe conversational agents such as ChatGPT, Claude, and Llama. However, this term is borrowed from human characteristics—such as self-awareness, intentionality, and independent decision-making—that are not inherently present in AI systems. While, to some extent, these agents can perform tasks without direct human intervention, their actions are governed by predefined algorithms, training data, and probabilistic models rather than genuine self-directed reasoning. While tech companies are striving to develop fully autonomous agents, they often overlook the societal acceptance of different levels of autonomy. In this study, we aim to discuss the differentiation between human autonomy and AI autonomy, as well as the limitations in AI agents' autonomy, and why these AI agents cannot be called autonomous like humans. Our purpose is to raise scholars' awareness of the need to differentiate between human and AI autonomy.

title: Deconvolutional Port-Starboard Discrimination Algorithm Under Dual Linear Array Conditions
authors: Haoran Ji, Lei Wang, Hongzhuang Cao, Wenjie Zhou, Cong Peng, Xiaokun Jia, Shuhan Liao, Lerong Hong, Zhe Chang
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Although beamforming design enables port-starboard discrimination to some extent, it performs poorly under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions and exhibits low port-starboard suppression, leading to potential misclassification. To address the challenge of port-starboard discrimination in underwater acoustic detection using dual linear arrays, this paper proposes a novel discrimination algorithm based on dual linear array processing. The proposed algorithm first utilizes the Linearly Constrained Minimum Variance (LCMV) criterion to construct a beamforming vector and calculate the spatial spectrum of the received data, thereby obtaining a coarse estimation of the target's azimuth. Building on the beamforming process, we construct a dictionary matrix to establish the relationship between the spatial spectrum and the spatial power distribution vector. Furthermore, to mitigate the impact of sidelobes in the spatial spectrum, we design a set of projection operators to process the spatial spectrum and dictionary matrix, thereby obtaining a cleaner spatial relationship. In addition, to enhance numerical stability, we incorporate a regularization term into the objective function using the noise subspace. Simulations and experimental demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves an exceptionally high port-starboard suppression ratio and superior azimuth resolution capability.

title: Establishment of Security Threats in 5G Networks with Blockchain-Integrated Authentication Protocols and Federated Learning
authors: Deepthi KVBL, Ghassan Samara, E. N. Vijaya Kumari, G. Karthikeyan, V. Samuthira Pandi, R. Mancy Mesilla
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Fifth generation of communication networks (5G) optoelectronic devices provide leapfrogging speed, latency and connectivity that are required for a variety of applications, such as smart cities, autonomous vehicles, and massive IoT ecosystems. Nonetheless, this development is also an alleged growing complexity of emerging threats, such as identity spoon, data manipulation, denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, or user privacy violation. Legacy cloud-centric security models are being complemented by localized security processing at the edge and individual cells, in part due to the fact that 5G is a distributed architecture with heavy reliance at the edge and on end user devices. In this study, we combat the emerging security challenges in 5G networks through a blockchain enhanced authentication framework with FL to provide secure access. The decentralized, immutable, and transparent property of blockchain is promising to protect identity verification, session integrity, and transaction logs in distributed 5G scenarios. Authentication requests are handled through smart contracts to maintain verifiability in a decentralized manner so that there are no single-point-of-failure risks. At the same time, federated learning is a privacy-preserving machine learning paradigm for the edge devices and UEs to collaboratively train on threat patterns without leaking raw data. This method enables sensitive feature information to be kept locally and to simultaneously to corporately improve defense capability of the whole system against new attacks. With the combination of FL and blockchain, the proposed model improves inaccurate threat detection, ensures safe authentication, and maintains the privacy of user data. We develop a comprehensive threat taxonomy to classify threats in 5G, where both inter-slice isolation attack, rogue gNodeB registration, and adversarial AI-based intrusion, and signaling storm are part of this taxonomy. The framework is verified on a simulation platform simulating a multi-slice 5G network and yields improved results for authentication latency, data privacy, and anomaly detection. By 35% faster validation time and 28% better anomaly detection than traditional authentication systems, hybrid model surpasses the traditional models. This study presents important progress towards a secure, distributed architecture for next-generation networks. The paper shows that how blockchain and federated learning could work together to resolve the key problems of the 5G security without compromising performance and privacy. This integration based on those methods provides a solution that looks ahead to an even future, from ultra-dense and hyper-dynamic communications that supports various ultra-dense and hyper-dynamic, cyber threat landscapes and future 6G deployment.

title: DRL-KubeScale: A Reinforcement Learning Based Autoscaler for SLA-Aware Pod Optimization in Kubernetes
authors: Anita Padhy
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Cloud Computing platforms, such as Kubernetes, provide elastic resource provisioning in a highly flexible and efficient manner. Its autoscaling capability dynamically deploys or terminates computational units called pods. The process is commonly referred to as horizontal pod autoscaling (HPA), which triggers pod scaling based on monitored performance metrics. While many studies have demonstrated that HPA can adjust resources according to workloads automatically, existing approaches generally omit the consideration of service-level agreements (SLAs) in autoscaling. The purpose of an SLA is to define a certain level of service that is expected from a supplier and serve as an significant factor for users when selecting service providers. This work proposes a DRL-based autoscaler, namely DRL-KubeScale, to optimize resource allocation for Kubernetes deployments with SLA-awareness. It employs continuous deep Q-learning with state space defined on pod-level metrics and CPU allocation and follows a Markov choice process (MDP) model to determine real-time scaling of pods. DRL-KubeScale is implemented on a prototype system and evaluated under a set of benchmark scenarios with widely used metric types. Testing results found that DRL-KubeScale exceed baseline approaches in terms of autoscaling efficiency and SLA satisfaction.

title: Image Forgery Detection Using Deep Learning
authors: Vanya Jain, Krishna Singh, Gouri Sankar Mishra
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: Digital image manipulation is a growing threat to authenticity in journalism, forensics and security. Traditional forgery detection methods can't keep up with advanced image tampering techniques, we need a better solution. This paper explores deep learning-based forgery detection using ResNet50, finetuned on CASIA v2 dataset. The dataset initially had 7,000 images, we augmented it to 13,500 images to make the model more generalize. We used binary classification approach with 70% of the dataset for the training and 30% for the testing. The results show the model's performance, it achieved 82% accuracy with good precision and recall. We used data augmentation, batch normalization and dropout regularization to optimize the performance. The results show the potential of deep learning techniques in image forensics, a scalable and automated way to detect manipulated images. Future work will explore hybrid models and interpretability enhancements to improve the detection.

title: The Simons Observatory: Studies of Phase Drift in RF Transmission Lines From the First Large-Scale Deployment of Microwave Frequency Multiplexing for Cosmology
authors: Thomas P. Satterthwaite, Zeeshan Ahmed, Cody J. Duell, Shawn W. Henderson, Tristan Pinsonneault-Marotte, Max Silva-Feaver, Yuhan Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: Fulfilling the science goals of the Simons Observatory, a state-of-the-art cosmic microwave background (CMB) experiment, has required deploying tens of thousands of superconducting bolometers. Reading out data from the observatory's more than 67,000 transition-edge sensor (TES) detectors while maintaining cryogenic conditions requires an effective multiplexing scheme. The SLAC microresonator radio frequency (SMuRF) electronics have been developed to provide the warm electronics for a high-density microwave frequency multiplexing readout system, and this system has been shown to achieve multiplexing factors on the order of 1,000. SMuRF has recently been deployed to the Simons Observatory, which is located at 5,200 m on Cerro Toco in Chile's Atacama Desert. As the SMuRF system is exposed to the desert's diurnal temperature swings, resulting phase drift in RF transmission lines may introduce a systematic signal contamination. We present studies of phase drift in the room-temperature RF lines of the Simons Observatory's 6 m large-aperture telescope, which hosts the largest deployment to date of TES microwave frequency multiplexing to a single telescope. We show that these phase drifts occur on time scales which are significantly longer than sky scanning, and that their contribution to on-sky in-transition detector noise is within the readout noise budget.

title: Analysing User Perceptions of Trust in Financial Systems Using Explainable AI
authors: Ramya Mandava, Koya Haritha, Sai Srinivas Vellela, Nagamalleswara Rao Purimetla, BH Krishna Mohan, T Harinadh
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: This research explores user trust perceptions of financial systems with the combination of machine learning and explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) approaches. Utilizing a Random Forest classifier and SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) to facilitate model interpretability, the study identifies a number of significant factors contributing to trust, including perception of security, history of fraud experience, system reliability, transparency of transactions, and satisfaction with the user interface. The findings show that security perception is the most powerful factor, with SHAP values providing clear explanations of trust predictions. The research shows the value of marrying predictive power with explainability to provide greater understanding and control of trust in financial systems.

title: HVPPF: A Hierarchical Visual Privacy Protection Framework for Cloud Services Customized to Balance Privacy and Usability
authors: Jun Mou, Zheyi Zhang, Yinghong Cao, Santo Banerjee, Yushu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: With the growing demand for cloud services, traditional image privacy encryption methods applied in cloud scenarios reveal two major issues. First, security is often achieved at the expense of visibility, which is incompatible with cloud service scenarios such as information preview and search. Second, there is a lack of design for hierarchical visual privacy for users with different security levels. For the above problems, a multi-level key mechanism is designed and integrated with the YoloV5 network, providing not only multi-level privacy protection for sensitive regions but also achieving a balance between visibility and security in these regions. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed framework can decrypt images with multi-level visual effects. Performance analysis shows that the framework achieves an adjustable balance between visibility and security, which users can modify by adjusting parameters. Compared to other visibility-security trade-off schemes, this approach offers advantages including strong reversibility, high image size compatibility, adjustable visual effects, and computational efficiency.

title: MPPT of PMSG Coupled Wind Power Conversion System with a Switched-Capacitor Based Non-Isolated High Step-Up DC-DC Converter
authors: Kurakula Durga Rao, P. V. Rama Krishna, Narayana Rao Kolagani, Manam Ravindra, Gulshan Dhasmana, N. Kalyana Sundaram, Md. Asif, Siva Ganesh Malla
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Wind energy based electric power conversion models are popular in many places to produce electricity for various customers. Among many models, Permanent Magnet Synchronous Generator (PMSG) coupled wind energy conversion systems are attracting and utilized for many applications, especially under medium power ranges. In order to harvest maximum energy from wind turbine under every operating condition, a Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) device must be used. An efficient MPPT approach, controller and a power converter will be parts in MPPT device. Usually many converters especially DC to DC converters are used as a MPPT converter. But unfortunately they are suffering from lack of high gain which is unable to produce sufficient output especially under low wind speeds. Hence, a switched-capacitor based high gain non-isolated DC to DC step up converter is implemented in this paper to utilized as a MPPT converter. Further, two end control methodology is developed to regulate both voltage and current to achieve a fast response during the harvesting maximum power. The Perturb and Observe (P&O) algorithm is incorporated to the proposed control methodology. The proposed model can work effectively during lower wind speeds also due to its ability of high step-up gain. Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) is executed through the utilization of two OPAL-RT modules to demonstrate multiple responses of the suggested model across different operating scenarios.

title:
Impacts of EOT Scaling of ZrOₓ/HfOₓ Dielectric on Monolayer WSe
