authors: Yu-Wei Hsu, Yu-Tung Lin, Nien-En Chiang, Shao-Heng Chen, Ying-Zhan Chiu, Chen-Hsun Hsu, Ting-Hua Wei, Sin-Yue Lee, Zi-Quan Su, Hung-Li Chiang, I-Chih Ni, Tsung-En Lee, Chih-I Wu
publish: IEEE Electron Device Letters
abstract: This work demonstrates the two-step elevated-temperature atomic layer deposit (ALD) process of bilayer ZrOₓ/HfOₓ relatively higher-κ dielectrics reported on chemical vapor deposit (CVD) monolayer (1L) WSe<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> for top-gate dielectric. Top-gated 1L-WSe<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> pFETs with a low subthreshold swing (S.S. ~60 mV/dec) are achieved at a low equivalent oxide thickness (EOT) of 0.8 nm. By scaling the physical thickness of this two-step bilayer ZrOₓ/HfOₓ dielectric with the pinhole-free AlOₓ nucleation layer down to 2 nm, the proposed gate stack exhibits a high effective dielectric constant (ε<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">eff</sub> ~14) and strong reliability (breakdown field E<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">BD</sub> ~21 MV/cm) at the scaled EOT. This breakthrough in gate dielectric integration on p-type 1L-WSe<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> enables balanced n/p performance for 2D-channel devices and enhances the feasibility of future low-power consumption CMOS applications.

title: E2net: Enhanced Ensemble Networks for Dynamic Long-Term Time Series Forecasting
authors: Agung Mustika Rizki, Ary Mazharuddin Shiddiqi, Ahmad Saikhu, Choiru Za'in, Muhammad Ismail, Anggito Anju Hartawan Manalu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Time series analysis is a critical area of data analytics with applications across diverse domains such as economics, healthcare, technology, and environmental monitoring. Despite its importance, forecasting models face considerable challenges when dealing with dynamic and nonstationary data, particularly in long-term prediction tasks. To address these challenges, this paper introduces the Enhanced Ensemble Network (E2Net)-an innovative architecture specifically d esigned f or d ynamic, longterm time series forecasting. E2Net extends the dual-network framework by integrating multiple fast learners and a single slow learner to improve predictive accuracy and generalization. The fast learners employ a negative correlation learning strategy to promote diversity and capture different aspects of the data distribution. In parallel, the slow learner utilizes a self-supervised learning mechanism to extract robust feature representations. To further enhance performance, E2Net incorporates reinforcement learning to derive optimal policies for combining the outputs of the fast learners. This architecture enables E2Net to dynamically adapt to multivariate data patterns while maintaining computational efficiency. E xtensive e xperiments o n m ultiple benchmark datasets, including comparisons with state-of-the-art models such as MANTRA and iTransformer, demonstrate that E2Net consistently outperforms existing approaches, achieving notable improvements across various sequence lengths.

title: Practical Analysis of WPA2 and WPA3 Resistance to Dictionary-Based Brute-Force Attacks Using Weak Passwords
authors: Elvis Eduardo España Ponce, Walter Santiago Sosa Mejia, Christian David Tamayo Obando, Wilson Gustavo Chango Sailema
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Wireless network security is fundamentally based on encryption and authentication mechanisms that prevent unauthorized access to data and network resources. Among these, the Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA) family of protocols, specifically WPA2 and its successor WPA3, are widely adopted standards designed to secure wireless communications through robust encryption and key-exchange methods. This study presents a practical evaluation of WPA2 and WPA3 against dictionary-based brute-force attacks using weak or common passwords. The experimental phase involved configuring two wireless networks under WPA2-Personal and WPA3-Personal security standards. For WPA2, Aircrack-ng and Hashcat were used to capture the four-way handshake and perform offline dictionary attacks. For WPA3, due to its resistance to offline attacks through the SAE protocol (Simultaneous Authentication of Equals), real-time attacks were conducted using Wacker. All experiments were carried out in a controlled Rocky Linux environment, recording key metrics such as cracking time and attack success rate. The results show that while WPA3 provides greater resistance to offline attacks, it remains vulnerable when weak passwords are used. These findings highlight the importance of proper credential management, even when modern security protocols are in place.

title: Deep Learning and Explainable Artificial Intelligence for Comprehensive Disease Diagnosis from Medical Imaging
authors: Ali Nawaz, Amir Ahmad, Abdulla Almarzooqi, Ahmed Alnaqbi, Majed Alblooshi, Saeed Almansoori, Salem Altaher
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: This paper presents an end-to-end framework for pediatric pneumonia recognition on chest radiographs that couples a high-capacity convolutional network with post-hoc explainability. We fine-tune InceptionV3 to discriminate Normal versus Pneumonia on a public pediatric CXR corpus <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5, 8 6 3}$</tex> images while employing Gradient-weighted Class Activation Mapping and Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations to expose salient image regions underlying model decisions. The proposed pipeline attains strong predictive performance and, critically, surfaces clinically meaningful visual rationales, supporting safer deployment of AI tools in diagnostic workflows. Our results indicate that accuracy-oriented modeling and transparent reasoning are jointly achievable on routine radiography, which can facilitate trust, auditability, and human-AI collaboration in practice.

title: A Hybrid Model Based on BASSA-CEEMDAN-BiLSTM-Self-Attention for Real-Time Electric Load Forecasting
authors: Jingwen Wang, Fantao Zhu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: Currently, mainstream power load forecasting algorithms still face challenges in accuracy and training efficiency in handling nonlinear and time-varying complex electricity consumption patterns. This paper suggests a hybrid model to address these limitations in load forecasting. First, the Complete Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition with Adaptive Noise (CEEMDAN) technique decomposes complex power load data into sub-series at diverse frequencies, mitigating mode mixing. Subsequently, the Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) model is leveraged to capture the long-term dependencies dynamic changes in power load. To overcome the limitations of BiLSTM in capturing complex coupling relationships, the Self-Attention mechanism strengthens the model's capacity to capture intricate temporal dependencies. Furthermore, a two-stage hyperparameter optimization algorithm, combining the Sparrow Search Algorithm (SSA) and Bayesian optimization, fine-tunes the hybrid model's hyperparameters. The proposed BASSA- CEEMDAN-BiLSTM-Self-Attention model is applied to a power load dataset from a southern power plant for validation. Experimental results demonstrate that the model achieves high accuracy on the training data, exhibits minimal prediction errors, and explains 98.3% of the data variability, demonstrating its strong predictive capabilities. Compared to other models, it improves R2 by 6.9%-33.4%, reduces RMSE by 33.7%-58.4%, and decreases MAE by 29.2%-62.4%, highlighting its advantages in accuracy and error reduction.

title: Data Augmentation with RNN-Driven CGANs for RF Jamming Intrusion Detection
authors: Brandon Fernandez Ling, Glaucio H.S. Carvalho
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Vehicular networks are a foundational element of intelligent transportation systems, enabling real-time communication between vehicles and infrastructure. These networks are increasingly targeted by physical-layer attacks, particularly radio frequency (RF) jamming, which can disrupt safety-critical transmissions. However, the development of effective intrusion detection systems (IDS) is hindered by the limited availability of high-quality RF jamming data. Data collection is constrained by hardware complexity, legal restrictions, and environmental variability. To address this challenge, we propose a Conditional Generative Adversarial Network (CGAN) model for synthetic RF signal generation at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> speeds. Our architecture integrates four RNN-based combinations of GRU and LSTM units to model the temporal characteristics of RF jamming patterns of. We rigorously evaluate the generated data using Fréchet Inception Distance (FID), Kernel Density Estimation (KDE), and detailed statistical comparisons including mean, standard deviation, and percentile analysis. Results demonstrate that the CGAN-generated signals from our GRU-based generator closely replicate real jamming data, significantly improving IDS performance, especially when leveraging an LSTM-based discriminator. This work underscores the viability of RNNCGAN architectures in mitigating data scarcity and enhancing the robustness of RF jamming detection in wireless vehicular environments.

title: JETROS: A Scalable Robotic Testbed for Experimental Evaluation of Algorithms for Cooperative Vehicle Platooning
authors: Francisca Donoso, Nelson Salvador, Gonzalo Carvajal, Akramul Azim
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: This paper introduces JETROS, a modular and scalable robotic testbed for experimental evaluation of platooning strategies in autonomous vehicles. Each robot combines an NVIDIA Jetson Orin Nano board with a comprehensive sensor suite for implementing vision-based perception, and includes wireless interfaces for inter-vehicle communication. The integrated architecture provides a robust infrastructure for deploying and testing software-based strategies for addressing open challenges in coordinated platooning. Experiments using a leader-follower pair provide preliminary validation of core platooning functionalities, including lane detection, lane keeping, and control of intervehicle distance using layered PID controllers. Furthermore, the tested scenario leverages inter-vehicle communication for reference velocity sharing, as a way to improve safety in scenarios where sensor reliability is degraded, like when the cars move along curved paths. Availability of a high-performance embedded computing unit in each robot facilitates deployment and testing of sophisticated software stacks for perception, control, and communication. We expect that the flexibility and accessibility of the platform will promote experimental validation and critical examination of reported solutions for advanced platooning strategies, ultimately supporting the transition from simulation to real-world deployment.

title: Omnichannel Retail Analytics: A Scalable Big Data Architecture Using Data Vault 2.0 and Apache Spark for Retail Intelligence
authors: Uttam Kumar, Durga Krishnamoorthy, Ram Ghadiyaram
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: Retailers often struggle to integrate data from disparate sources such as their eCommerce platforms, physical stores, and inventory systems. This fragmentation hampers timely decision-making, creates inconsistent customer experiences, and complicates regulatory compliance. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a scalable, intelligent data warehousing architecture for retail applications utilizing Data Vault 2.0 in conjunction with Apache Spark. This innovative framework facilitates the aggregation, management, and analysis of omnichannel data, ensuring flexibility, traceability, and scalability. A synthetic simulation, based on representative retail data, validates the architecture's performance and adaptability. The integration of Data Vault 2.0 and Apache Spark provides a powerful solution for managing and analyzing retail data, empowering retailers to derive rapid insights and respond swiftly to market dynamics.

title: Enhanced Deep Learning for Multi-Class Osteoporosis Detection via Feature Fusion of Diverse Pre-Trained Models from Knee X-Ray Images
authors: Sai Linkan Mohanty, Ashis Kumar Pati, Subhajit Saha, Sudipta Gayen, Abhilash Pati, Amrutanshu Panigrahi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: This study presents a state-of-the-art deep learning method for accurately identifying and classifying bone health states (normal, osteopenia, and osteoporosis) using knee X-ray images. Modern Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models (e.g., EfficientNetV2B3, ResNet152V2, and VGG19) are evaluated in detail in this study by means of transfer learning applied to the ImageNet dataset. An innovative feature fusion method is developed based on this research. It involves merging the features of the two top-performing pre-trained convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and feeding them into a custom-built, fully-connected classification network. This fusion aims to increase significantly overall diagnostic accuracy and resilience by utilizing the complementary strengths of various architectures. The robust workflow includes careful image preprocessing, efficient class balancing, powerful regularization techniques (batch normalization, dropout, and advanced data augmentation), and an ideal learning rate schedule. Most importantly, by locating clinically significant areas in the X-ray images, Explainable AI (XAI) techniques—particularly Grad-CAM—are incorporated to visualize and explain the models' decision-making processes. According to experimental results, the suggested feature fusion model performs better than single models, providing a more precise and understandable multi-class osteoporosis diagnostic tool for knee X-ray images. In the treatment of osteoporosis, this tool can greatly enhance early diagnosis and patient outcomes.

title: Human Intuition Versus Machine Intelligence: A Comparative Analysis of Sentiment Interpretation
authors: Aanjney Bhatnagar, Kushagra Bhatnagar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This study explores the comparative effectiveness of AI-based and human-based sentiment analysis in interpreting literary texts, using Leslie Norris's poem “A Tiger in the Zoo” as a case study. The poem, which juxtaposes the caged existence of a tiger with its natural, untamed habitat, evokes a range of emotional undertones such as confinement, helplessness, and suppressed power. Through this comparison, we aim to evaluate how accurately AI algorithms can detect and interpret these nuanced emotional cues relative to human interpretation. The analysis highlights differences in contextual understanding, emotional depth, and thematic sensitivity, revealing both the strengths and limitations of artificial intelligence in literary sentiment analysis. Ultimately, the study provides insights into the potential for AI tools to assist, rather than replace, human literary analysis. We develop a mathematical framework to compare both the analysis. Further, we use weighted sentiments also in order to get a more deeper insight. We show the comparison by plotting the confusion matrix and accuracy.

title: Efficient Fixed-Step Capacitor Placement Using Random Search Theory
authors: Oscar Danilo Montoya, Juan Diego Pulgarín Rivera, César Augusto Orozco-Henao
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This paper presents a simplified optimization framework that uses a random search (RS) strategy for the optimal placement and sizing of fixed-step capacitor banks in distribution systems. The problem is formulated as a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) model, combining discrete capacitor allocation decisions with nonlinear and non-convex power flow equations. Despite the model's complexity, the proposed RS algorithm efficiently explores the feasible solution space without the need for complex metaheuristic operators or parameter tuning. The optimization objective involves minimizing the total net present value of energy losses and investment-related costs over a multi-year planning horizon. Numerical validations conducted on the IEEE 33-bus distribution network—in both its radial and meshed configurations—demonstrate that the RS approach yields competitive cost reductions (up to 13.85%) when compared to more advanced metaheuristics. The results validate the potential of structured random sampling for practical, lowcomplexity applications in planning reactive power compensation.

title: Computer Simulation Research on Human-Computer Interaction in Pilot Situational Awareness
authors: Tao Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This study proposes a situational awareness computer simulation system based on human-computer interaction, which combines the Kalman filter algorithm to optimize the accuracy and timeliness of information transmission. The system uses the Kalman filter to analyze and dynamically update flight data in real time, providing pilots with high-precision situational awareness information. An intuitive human-computer interaction interface is designed to enable pilots to quickly and accurately obtain key flight parameters in complex dynamic environments. In order to verify the effectiveness of the system, this paper selects typical flight scenarios, uses the Kalman filter to perform real-time filtering processing on flight parameters such as flight speed, position, and altitude, collects accurate simulation data, and evaluates the performance of the system in different environments. The simulation results show that under a variety of complex flight conditions, the system can effectively reduce information delays and improve the accuracy of the situation information provided by more than 15%. Especially in the emergency simulation test, the system significantly improves the pilot's perception of the flight status and the speed of decision-making response, achieving the expected optimization goals.

title: Feasibility and Acceptability of P300-Based Brain-Computer Interface Neurofeedback Training for Cognitive Enhancement
authors: Jin Ni, Joshua Giles, Mahnaz Arvaneh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: This study investigates the feasibility and accept-ability of a P300-based brain-computer interface (BCI) neuro-feedback training protocol in both short-term and long-term settings. Twelve healthy adults were recruited to complete either a single-session trial or a five-session trial. Each session involved a neurofeedback protocol based on the P300 event-related potential (ERP), with cognitive performance assessed using a Random Dot Motion (RDM) task before and after training. The single-session trial demonstrated high feasibility and acceptability, with a full recruitment rate and an 8 % drop-out rate. Significant improvements in reaction time were observed post-training, and over 72 % of participants showed enhanced ERPs separability, particularly in P300 amplitude and reduced non-target responses during feedback. The five-session trial showed a 25 % drop-out rate but faced low recruitment (33 %), highlighting the challenge of sustaining participant engagement over time. Although positive trends in performance were observed, ERP changes across sessions were inconsistent, likely due to the small sample size for the long-term trial <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{n}=3)$</tex>. Overall, the findings support the feasibility and potential cognitive benefits of the short-term P300-BCI neurofeedback training. Further research with larger samples and control conditions is needed to confirm the long-term efficacy and neural impact of extended training protocols.

title: Research on the Evaluation Model of Teaching Effect of New Energy Vehicles Based on Data Fusion
authors: Xiaoyi Wang, Wenxin Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes an evaluation model based on data fusion, which adopts deep learning technology and multi-source data fusion method to comprehensively evaluate the learning effect in the field of new energy vehicles. The model integrates data from multiple aspects such as student scores, interaction records, external environment data, etc., and conducts comprehensive analysis through data fusion technology to improve the comprehensiveness and accuracy of the evaluation. The innovation lies in combining adaptive optimization strategy, which can dynamically adjust the evaluation model according to different situations, optimize weight distribution, and improve the accuracy of the model. Experimental results show that the proposed evaluation model based on data fusion is 15% more accurate than the traditional method, and performs better in robustness and efficiency. This study provides an innovative solution for the effect evaluation in the field of new energy vehicles, especially for data processing and evaluation tasks in large-scale and complex environments, and can provide important data support and methodological guidance for the optimization of related fields.

title: Semantic Fusion Agent for Multimodal TCM Diagnosis and Cross-Domain RAG Integration
authors: Adili Abudukeranmu, Chunyu Tu, Zeyang Cui, Shijian Li, Runhe Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: Recent studies, such as TongueNet and OpenTCM, have explored the application of multi-modal information, including images and text, in traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) diagnostics. However, two major challenges remain: (1) the cross-domain acquisition of diverse Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system structures to bridge users' colloquial descriptions with formal medical terminology, and (2) the semantic fusion of these acquired structures to enable precise alignment of multimodal semantics, which is essential in high-stakes domains such as healthcare. To address these challenges, we propose a “Semantic Fusion Agent,” a versatile intermediate component that bridges users' multimodal inputs (e.g., speech, tongue images, and pulse signals) with downstream RAG retrieval systems. This agent understands the structural requirements of target RAG systems across domains and transforms user inputs into structured semantic representations compatible with diverse knowledge base formats. In this way, the agent enhances the transparency of medical terminology by automatically generating accessible explanations, thereby improving user comprehension and trust. It also supports cross-domain semantic translation (e.g., from TCM to Western medicine or psychological diagnostics). The primary contribution of this work is the introduction of a structured semantic fusion mechanism that significantly improves the retrieval precision and structured-generation quality of RAG systems in diagnostic scenarios; we do not claim clinical diagnostic accuracy.

title: Virtual Reality and Biosignals for Labor Pain Relief: A Pilot Study
authors: Vittorio Santoriello, Alfonso Maria Ponsiglione, Carmine Giugliano, Carmen Buonaguro, Luigi Gallo, Giuseppe Caggianese, Marco Cascella, Giuseppe De Pietro, Andrea Chirico, Antonio Giordano, Francesco Amato, Maria Romano, Maurizio Guida
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Labor pain is intense and multifaceted, requiring effective management to ensure both maternal and neonatal well-being. This study explores the use of virtual reality (VR) as a distraction tool, combined with biosignal monitoring. Electro-dermal activity and heart rate variability (HRV) were recorded using wearable devices on four pregnant women. The acquisition protocol was divided into three phases: before, during, and after VR exposure. To complement the physiological data, the Visual Analog Scale was administered before and after each session. Participants were also asked to evaluate how effective they found the experimental treatment in helping them relax during labor, using a 1 to 10 scale. Results showed reduced sympathetic activity during VR, indicated by lower skin conductance and HRV features (heart rate and low-frequency/high-frequency ratio), suggesting a calming effect. In addition, participants manifested a 55.72% reduction in perceived anxiety and expressed positive appreciation for the VR treatment. Ongoing data collection will allow for deeper investigation of these trends, enabling more detailed analyses during individual contractions and facilitating correlation with subjective questionnaire responses. These findings highlight the potential of VR as a non-invasive, personalized approach to managing labor pain.

title: FloatChat – AI- Powered Conversational Interface for Ocean Data Discovery and Visualization
authors: S. Raja, D. Deepak, A.P Janani, R. Nithish
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The rapid expansion of oceanographic data, driven by global observation programs such as Argo, has created unprecedented opportunities for marine research-yet poses significant challenges in accessibility, integration, and interpretation. Traditional data retrieval and visualization methods often struggle to manage the scale, heterogeneity, and complexity of multi-source datasets such as temperature, salinity, and biogeochemical parameters stored in NetCDF formats. This study introduces FloatChat, an AI-powered conversational interface designed to simplify Argo data discovery and visualization through natural language interaction. By combining Large Language Models (LLMs) with semantic search and geospatial analytics, the system enables scientists and policymakers to query, analyze, and visualize ocean data intuitively. The framework supports realtime data interpretation and adaptive visualization, promoting inclusive access for both experts and non-specialists. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed system improves data retrieval accuracy and reduces exploration time compared to conventional interfaces. Findings indicate that integrating AI-driven conversation with ocean data systems enhances user engagement, fosters better scientific understanding, and accelerates data-driven decision-making in ocean monitoring and climate research.

title: Integration of Quantum Computing and Machine Learning: Promoting Optimization, Pattern Detection, and Computational Efficiency
authors: R.C. Thivyarathi, V.Samuthira Pandi, Abdelhalim Mohammad Jubran, Nitin Bhardwaj, D Jayalakshmi, M Dinesh
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Quantum computing and machine learning (QML) have emerged as a revolutionary per approach to solve complex computational problems that classical systems are unable to. The use of superposition, entanglement, and quantum parallelism helps analyze data up to ten times faster than in a non-quantum manner, enhancing optimization, pattern identification, and computational efficiency. This paper studies the potential of quantum algorithms and machine learning in areas of categorization, grouping, and regression in banking, healthcare, cybersecurity, and scientific simulations. QML shines when it comes to generalizing low cost over high-dimensional data spaces. State-of-theart quantum-enhanced algorithms (QSVMs, VQCs, QBMs) yield better solutions to complex pattern recognition problems. Quantum-inspired neural networks accelerate deep learning architectures by optimizing gradient descent and decreasing training periods. The following research explores how QML enables a potentially computationally efficient solution to combinatorial optimization problems in the realms of logistics, cryptography, and artificial intelligence through quantum annealing and hybrid quantumclassical models. QML is still not able to deploy for the hardware limitations, noise sensitive nature, and quantum decoherence, despite promising results. The study underscores the importance of error correction procedures, as well as noise-resilient quantum circuits, and ultimately their scaling to full computers to reconcile theoretical promise with real-world application. It explores the ability of hybrid quantum-classical models to provide near-term developed applications as a bridge to realizable quantum computation. In this article, researchers present a thorough overview of quantum algorithms, reduced computational complexity, and practical applications, furthering the field of quantumenhanced machine learning. Industries might be revolutionized with quantum computers and AI-based decision-making systems working together with unprecedented computational power. In particular, quantum algorithms, hardware, and quantum cloud computing platforms must be a research focus area to ensure that quantum will deliver the most significant advances in AI.

title: Image Representation Based Malware Detection Using Transfer Learning
authors: Iik Muhamad Malik Matin, Indra Hermawan, Susana Dwi Yulianti, Ihsan Alamal Ahmad, Naurah, Zahra Azizah
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: The rapid evolution of malware presents substantial challenges to traditional signature-based detection methods. This study proposes an image-based malware detection approach utilizing deep learning models to overcome these limitations. Four convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures MobileNetV3, ResNet, EfficientNet, and DenseNet are evaluated and compared in terms of classification accuracy and processing efficiency. Binary files, including. exe, OLE, and PE formats, are converted into 224x224-pixel grayscale images and used to train the models on the DikeDataset. External validation is conducted using malware samples from MalwareBazaar to assess model generalization. Experimental results show that EfficientNet achieves the highest training accuracy at 98.65%, while MobileNetV3 yields the lowest at 95.20%. The average processing time per file is approximately 800 milliseconds on a CPU. The findings suggest that image-based deep learning techniques offer a viable and efficient alternative for malware detection, especially in low-resource environments.

title: Characterizing Short-duration Rainfall Events on the Tibetan Plateau Based on Ground Observation, Satellite Remote Sensing, and Reanalysis Data
authors: Xiaoyan Ling, Yingying Chen, Kun Yang, Run Han, Lazhu, Xu Zhou, Xin Li, Changhui Zhan, Yaozhi Jiang, Jiaxin Tian, Yan Wang, Ming Chen
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Given the vast expanses of bare soil and sparse grassland in the Central and Western Tibetan Plateau (CWTP), the duration of precipitation serves as a critical control on key hydrological and geomorphological responses, such as runoff generation, soil erosion, and sediment transport. This study analyzes the spatial distribution of precipitation events with different durations (short-duration, medium-duration, and long-duration) across the Tibetan Plateau (TP). To explore the differences in precipitation duration between the central-western and eastern TP, we utilize hourly precipitation data from a newly established cross-sectional rainfall observation network (53 gauges) on the CWTP and the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) observation (145 gauges) on the eastern TP for comparison. The main conclusions are as follows: (1) Short-duration (1-3 hours) precipitation events contribute more than 50% of the total rainfall in the CWTP. In contrast, short-duration events contribute less than 30% in the eastern TP, where medium- and long-duration precipitation events dominate. (2) The reanalysis data ERA5 and the high-resolution atmospheric simulation data HAR2 tend to systematically underestimate (overestimate) the contribution of short-duration (long-duration) precipitation events. Specifically, they exhibit mean biases of 23% and 19% for short-duration precipitation, and 34% and 20% for long-duration precipitation, respectively. (3) The satellite remote sensing precipitation data IMERG perform well in estimating the contribution of precipitation events, with biases mostly within 30%. By comparing the original and gauge-calibrated satellite datasets, the results show that calibration with coarse temporal resolutions (daily or monthly) does not necessarily improve the identification of short-duration precipitation events. Our results not only enhance the understanding of precipitation characteristics and processes over the Tibetan Plateau, but also provide valuable guidance for hydrological modeling and the evaluation and improvement of satellite-based precipitation data.

title: Operationalizing ISO/IEC 42001: Requirements and Conformance Evidence for AI Management Systems
authors: Kassem Saleh, Hanady Abdulsalam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: The increasing development and deployment of artificial intelligence (AI) applications across critical sectors has amplified the need for robust AI governance and effective risk management frameworks. ISO/IEC 42001:2023 is the first international standard specifically designed to establish, implement, maintain, and continuously improve an AI Management System (AIMS). This paper explores the requirements outlined in ISO/IEC 42001 standard and provides a structured and systematic mapping of these requirements to specific types of supporting evidence necessary for operationalization and audit readiness. Through a clause-by-clause semantic and textual analysis of the standard, we identify the necessary documentation, controls, and operational records that can serve as verifiable evidence of conformance to the standard. The proposed mapping aims to assist organizations in implementing, operationalizing the standard and maintaining conformance to it. The mapping is used to enhance transparency, and to facilitate compliance with ethical, legal and regulatory obligations. The paper concludes with practical insights for implementers and auditors, providing the basic foundation toward auditable and trustworthy AI governance.

title: Noise Injection Framework for Development of Noise-Robust Predictive Maintenance Solutions
authors: Urszula Jachymczyk, Paweł Knap, Adam Szulecki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: In predictive maintenance (PdM) applications, sensor signals are often affected by various forms of noise that can degrade model accuracy and reliability. While many studies use Gaussian noise to simulate environmental disturbances, real-world sensor data is typically impacted by a broader range of noise types, including impulsive, frequency-dependent, and drift-based distortions. This paper presents a modular noise injection framework designed to augment PdM datasets with diverse synthetic and measured noise signals. The framework simulates realistic sensor and system-level disturbances and is evaluated on vibration data from an online shaft monitoring test stand. We assess the impact of noise-based augmentation on both limited and comprehensive datasets using six machine learning models. Results demonstrate that properly designed noise injection can substantially enhance model robustness and performance, particularly in data-constrained settings. Notably, we observed that models trained on raw time-domain data, while offering greater potential for learning rich signal characteristics, also exhibit higher sensitivity to aggressive augmentation. Our findings highlight the importance of carefully tuning noise augmentation strategies to match the measurement context and model architecture.

title: Study on Worst-Case Gradient Forces on Untethered Magnetic Devices Using Two Synchronized Rotating Magnetic Dipoles
authors: Zhengya Zhang, Bohuan Lin, Anke Klingner, Guang Feng, Yanfei Liao, Jian Guo, Wei Xue, Fengping Li, Wujun Geng, Sarthak Misra, Islam S.M. Khalil
publish: IEEE Magnetics Letters
abstract: Untethered magnetic devices (UMDs) hold significant clinical potential for removing blood clots. However, in the complex intravascular environment, their locomotion may be disturbed. Such disturbances can lead to variations in the magnetic gradient force exerted on the UMD, increasing the risk of vascular damage. Therefore, evaluating the magnetic gradient force acting on the UMD under worst-case conditions is essential for risk mitigation. In this paper, we propose a novel method to estimate the upper and lower bounds of the worst-case magnetic gradient force acting on the UMD, with actuation provided by two synchronized rotating magnetic dipoles. To assess the robustness of the algorithm, we conducted a Monte Carlo simulation in which the dipole directions of the two synchronized rotating magnetic dipoles and the dipole direction of the UMD were randomly varied 1000,000 times in the three-dimensional (3D) space to simulate all possible scenarios that may be encountered by the UMD in intravascular environments. The simulation results indicate that the worst-case magnetic gradient force remains below the upper bound predicted by the proposed algorithm, thereby validating its effectiveness.

title: Transforming Lives and Building Africa’s Future: The Inspiring Journey of the 2025 Pan-African Robotics Competition [Diversity, Outreach, and Development Activities]
authors: Karl H. Johansson

abstract: Provides society information that may include news, reviews or technical notes that should be of interest to practitioners and researchers.

title: Pulse Aid: A Mobile Application for Crash Detection and Emergency Response
authors: Manjeet Kaur Ratan, Nidhi Agarwal
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Car accidents continue to be one of the leading causes of serious injuries and deaths around the world. In these situations, getting timely medical help can make a life-saving difference. This paper introduces PulseAid, a mobile app designed to automatically detect car crashes using the sensors already built into most smartphones, such as accelerometers, gyroscopes, and microphones. PulseAid uses a clever, step-by-step approach to detect when a crash may have occurred: monitoring for abrupt jolts, abrupt turns, and unusual movements. If it detects something serious, it acts immediately. The app immediately contacts emergency contacts via multiple communication methods, ensuring someone knows you may need assistance and can act quickly. At the same time, it pulls up real-time information about nearby hospitals-showing their exact location, the kind of care they offer, whether they're equipped for trauma cases, and how crowded their emergency rooms are-so you can get the right help as quickly as possible. The app is powered by an intelligent hospital database with geospatial indexing, which helps it quickly find the most suitable hospital based on various factors. In real-world tests, PulseAid successfully identified crash events with 92<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup> sensitivity and 94% specificity. Even with its continuous monitoring, the app remains efficient, using only about 2.8% of battery per hour thanks to adaptive sensor management. This work adds to the growing field of mobile health technology by turning everyday smartphones into powerful tools for emergency response-making critical help faster, smarter, and more accessible when every second counts.

title: Real-Time AI-Enabled Anomaly Detection System for Preventing Financial Fraud
authors: Sai Kiran Arcot Ramesh, Feruzbek Jumaniyozov, Sindor Sapaev, Sahil K. Gupta, Samariddin Makhmudov, Irina Kosorukova
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: The problem of financial fraud remains a major threat to economic systems of any country, affecting billions of dollars every year in losses, with traditional guarding tools based on rules falling short of the complex attack vectors pursued by hackers. The major research goal is to come up with and test a real-time AI-powered anomaly detection system that will accurately detect and block potential financial fraud without incurring a high rate of false positive detections. Our approach comprises the integration of ensemble machine learning, such as Isolation Forest, LSTM neural networks, as well as gradient boosting algorithms along with real time streaming, Apache Kafka and distributed computing systems. A large transaction dataset with more than 2.5 million entries, including simulated fraud trends and actual transactions was used to test the system. Experimental results shown assert that the proposed system obtained 97.3% accuracy, 94.2% recall, and 93.8% precision in fraud detection with an average of 1.2 seconds in detecting fraud per transaction. The system shows much better results than investing in the known rule based systems or separate machine learning models, resulting in the decease of false positive rates by 40% in comparison with the currently available interventions. This study would not only help move financial security systems one step further but allow it to create the framework of real-time fraud prevention that could be applied in different financial institutions and with different types of transactions.

title: A Ten Year Bibliometric Analysis of Green Manufacturing from 2011 to 2020
authors: Satendra Kumar Yadav
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: This study is intended to examine the prevalent research trends in the field of Green Manufacturing (GM) by investigating a dataset of 352 scholarly articles indexed in the Scopus database over a duration of ten years, from 2011 to 2020. The study uses bibliometric approaches to discover the distribution and progress of literature in this field. The analysis is categorized into different dimensions, including publication trends by year, journal, country, author, institution, document type, and subject area. The results highlight a steady growth in academic interest and contributions towards Green Manufacturing. Additionally, the results provide critical understandings into the growth, research dynamics, and contemporary developments within the GM field, thus serving as a valuable orientation for researchers and policymakers aiming to recognize and contribute to sustainable manufacturing practices.

title: A Large Language Model-Driven Architecture for Intuitive Interaction in Virtual Reality Environments
authors: Valerio Colonnese, Gilda Manfredi, Nicola Capece, Ugo Erra, Salvatore Ungaro, Michele Rinaldi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: This paper introduces an advanced architectural framework integrating Virtual Reality, Artificial Intelligence, and sophisticated 3D reconstruction techniques. The architecture employs photogrammetry and terrestrial laser scanning to generate highly detailed and realistic virtual environments, providing seamless interaction through natural language commands. Central to the system is a conversational AI assistant powered by a locally hosted Large Language Model (LLM), enhanced by a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) architecture, which ensures precise and contextually coherent responses. As a practical demonstration, the architecture is applied to digitally explore three historically significant rock churches in Matera, Italy. These churches feature intricate architectural and morphological characteristics such as steep terrain, narrow entrances, and uneven surfaces, which are meticulously reconstructed using Unreal Engine to create immersive, high-fidelity virtual representations. The system infrastructure is local, ensuring minimal latency and robust data privacy. The conversational AI component was rigorously evaluated through heritage-specific queries using RAG Assessment (RAGAS) metrics, including Context Precision, Entity Recall, and Faithfulness. The results confirm the system's robust performance and effectiveness, highlighting its capability to accurately convey detailed architectural and cultural knowledge. This approach demonstrates the considerable potential of integrating conversational AI and eXtended Reality technologies in detailed virtual explorations of complex heritage sites.

title: Genetic Algorithm-Based Portfolio Analysis and Optimization Using Customized Genetic Evolution
authors: Bali Devi, Ansh Jain, Yash Dhruv, Venkatesh Gauri Shankar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Portfolio optimization remains a critical challenge in modern investment management, particularly as traditional methods like Modern Portfolio Theory (MPT) and Value at Risk (VaR) show limitations in addressing complex, multi-dimensional investment objectives. This paper presents a novel approach to portfolio optimization using genetic algorithms (GAs), designed to overcome the constraints of conventional optimization methods while accommodating diverse investor preferences and market conditions. Our methodology implements a flexible, multi-factor optimization framework that processes multiple input parameters, including but not limited to asset prices, volatility, correlations, sustainability ratings, and regional preferences. The system employs a fitness score calculation mechanism that aggregates weighted factors across three primary categories: risk/return metrics, portfolio constraints, and asset characteristics. Through extensive validation testing across 8,000 different test cases, our GA-based approach demonstrated an average 30% improvement in portfolio fitness scores compared to initial portfolios. Notable results include successful optimization of sustainability-focused portfolios, with targeted allocations achieving 60.4% median weighting for sustainable assets when specified. The framework's ability to handle multiple objectives while maintaining computational efficiency (8–10 second response time) represents a significant advancement in personalized portfolio management. Our findings (accuracy of 91%, AUC score of 92%, and Log loss of 0.27) suggest that genetic algorithms offer a more robust and adaptable approach to portfolio optimization compared to traditional methods, particularly in addressing the growing demand for personalized investment solutions and specialized investment criteria such as ESG considerations.

title: Trade-Off Evaluation Between Privacy and Data Utility Through the Application of Fully Homomorphic Encryption During ML Models Training for Classifying Misogyny Content
authors: Vita Santa Barletta, Paolo Buono, Danilo Caivano, Domenico Desiato, Roberto La Scala
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: In the context of machine learning (ML), the training of models on sensitive data can produce significant privacy concerns. Specifically, these concerns derive from the inherent nature of datasets, which often hold confidential information. Even with stringent safeguards in place, the formidable processing capabilities of ML algorithms can inadvertently lead to the identification of individuals or, in the most severe scenarios, catas-trophic data breaches. In this work, we delve into the capabilities of the cryptography library ConcreteML, a groundbreaking tool designed to uphold privacy throughout the ML training by harnessing the power of Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE). Moreover, through a series of rigorous experiments, we explore the delicate balance between privacy preservation and data utility using real-world datasets. Our findings reveal that ConcreteML not only maintains robust privacy protections but also delivers encouraging results in terms of data utility, striking an impressive balance that showcases its potential in safeguarding sensitive information while maximizing analytical insights.

title: Research on the Intelligent System of Industrial Control Network Security Protection Based on Artificial Intelligence
authors: Hongliang Liu, Si'nan Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes an intelligent system for industrial control network security protection based on artificial intelligence, which combines DNN and RL and is committed to improving the security protection capabilities of industrial control networks in complex attack environments. The system first analyzes network traffic data through a deep learning model to identify various potential security threats in real time, including but not limited to intrusion detection, malware, data leakage, etc. At the same time, reinforcement learning optimizes the protection strategy based on real-time feedback to improve the decision-making efficiency and response speed of the protection system. The experimental results show that the proposed protection system is significantly superior to traditional methods in terms of accuracy, response speed and anti-attack capability. Specifically, the attack detection accuracy rate is increased by 20%, the response time is reduced by 15%, and the anti-attack capability is improved by 18%. These results show that the protection system based on deep learning and reinforcement learning can not only effectively improve the accuracy of attack detection, but also provide more timely and flexible protection when facing complex and unknown network threats.

title: A 3-to-6-GHzFractional- N Charge-Pump PLL Featuring Bimodal-Like MASH-SR and Charge-Pump-Bleed Calibration Achieving Worst Case In-Band Fractional Spur of −73 dBc
authors: Yao Yang, Haoming Li, Jiahao Chen, Tengjia Wang, Jiarui Liu, Faxin Yu, Yong Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article proposes a bimodal-like multistage noise shaping successive requantizer (MASH-SR) divider controller for the fractional-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$N$</tex-math> </inline-formula> charge-pump phase-locked loop (CP-PLL). Based on the periodic nonlinear noise (PNN) method, fractional spurs caused by the loop nonlinearity can be predicted if the nonlinearity model and the probability mass function (PMF) of the divider controller are confirmed. We demonstrate that the divider controller with an ideal bimodal PMF distribution inherently suppresses fractional spurs induced by the piecewise linear (PWL) nonlinearity. The proposed divider controller exhibits great improvement in suppression capability under PWL nonlinearity compared to the conventional MASH-SR scheme. To achieve this, the PMF of the MASH-SR is analytically derived to characterize spurs, and the state transition matrices are systematically optimized to approximate the bimodal distribution. Simulations demonstrate a 17-dB improvement in fractional spurs. To further reduce the fractional spurs, charge-pump(CP) bleed calibration and multimodulus divider (MMD) step reduction are employed herein. The proposed fractional-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$N$</tex-math> </inline-formula> CP-PLL realized in 65-nm CMOS scores worst case fractional spurs of −73 dBc at an output frequency of 4300.001 MHz.

title: Hybrid Quantum-Classical Walks for Graph Representation Learning in Community Detection
authors: Adrián Marín, Mauricio Soto-Gomez, Giorgio Valentini, Elena Casiraghi, Carlos Cano, Daniel Manzano
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: Graph Representation Learning (GRL) has emerged as a cornerstone technique for analysing complex, networked data across diverse domains, including biological systems, social networks, and data analysis. Traditional GRL methods often struggle to capture intricate relationships within complex graphs, particularly those exhibiting non-trivial structural properties such as power-law distributions or hierarchical structures. This paper introduces a novel quantum-inspired algorithm for GRL, utilizing hybrid Quantum-Classical Walks to overcome these limitations. Our approach combines the benefits of both quantum and classical dynamics, allowing the walker to simultaneously explore both highly local and far-reaching connections within the graph. Preliminary results for a case study in network community detection shows that this hybrid dynamic enables the algorithm to adapt effectively to complex graph topologies, offering a robust and versatile solution for GRL tasks.

title: Adaptive Fine-Tuning for Multiclass Classification Over Software Requirement Data
authors: Savas Yildirim, Mucahit Cevik, Ayse Basar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: The analysis of software requirement specifications (SRS) using Natural Language Processing (NLP) methods has been an important study area in the software engineering field in recent years. Especially thanks to the advances brought by deep learning and transfer learning approaches in NLP, SRS data can be utilized for various learning tasks more easily. In this study, we employ a three-stage domain-adaptive fine-tuning approach for three prediction tasks regarding software requirements, which improve the model robustness on a real distribution shift. The multi-class classification tasks involve predicting the type, priority and severity of the requirement texts specified by the users. We compare our results with strong classification baselines such as word embedding pooling and Sentence BERT, and show that the adaptive fine-tuning leads to performance improvements across the tasks. We find that an adaptively fine-tuned model can be specialized to a particular data distribution, which is able to generate accurate results and learns from abundantly available textual data in software engineering task management systems.

title: Two FOPID Controllers Based SVPWM-DTC of Induction Motor Drive
authors: A. Nandhakumar, Aneerudh A, Mohan Keshava K K, P. Lakshmi Supriya, Pramod Mehra, R. Venkatasubramanian, Rajendar Sandiri, Kandi Bhanu Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Induction motor drives are grabbing attention from many researchers due to its features and applications. Among many available control methods of the induction motor drives, Direct Torque Control (DTC) is a powerful technique and it is having a wide range of applications in industries. In the conventional DTC method, only one controller is utilized to obtain reference torque where reference flux becomes constant. Hence, speed control of induction motor under DTC having its limitation on flux region. Consequently, a second controller is included in this paper to manage the flux by generating a reference flux derived from the discrepancy between the motor speed and its reference. However, conventional PI or PID controllers are unable to deliver its output effectively under rapid variations in the system. Hence, Fractional Order Proportional-Integral-Derivative (FOPID) controllers are incorporated in the proposed DTC method where utilized two FOPID controllers to regulate both torque and flux simultaneously. Further, Space Vector Pulse Width Modulation (SVPWM) is also included in the proposed control method to produce accurate and instant pulses for achieving accurate responses. In this study, the inverter is utilized with two FOPID controllers alongside the SVPWM technique. The proposed control method can effectively minimize ripples in both flux and torque. OPAL-RT modules based Hardware - in the - Loop (HIL) system is developed for presenting various outcomes to enhance the presented control.

title: XAI for Credit Card Fraud: An Ensemble Learning Approach to Detection and Interpretation with SHAP & LIME
authors: Vivin Chandrra Paasam, Aniketh Gandhari, Dhiren Rao B, Topalle Siddha Sankalp, Syeda Sayeeda Farhath, Y. Vijayalata
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Detection of credit card fraud remains challenging due to its rarity and attackers' evolving methods. We propose a machine-learning pipeline that integrates ensemble models with post-hoc explainability. After addressing class imbalance with SMOTE, the model is trained and compared using Random Forest, Logistic Regression, AdaBoost, Gradient Boosting, and XGBoost, with evaluation metrics including F1-score, ROC-AUC, AUPRC, and LogLoss. XGBoost achieves the best overall balance. To ensure transparency, we employ SHAP for global and local insights and LIME for instance-level analysis. The results demonstrate that combining ensemble learning with explainable AI achieves both high accuracy and interpretability, thereby meeting the requirements of the financial industry.

title: Intelligent X-Ray Inspection of Crimping Defects in Transmission Line Clamps Based on YOLOv10
authors: Wu Jian, Wei Yunyao, Zhu Guangze, He Longrong, Zhou Lihui, Yang Yibo, Wu Zhanfeng, Zhang Hanwen, Zhang Minglei, Chang Tengfei
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the continuous improvement of the power grid system on the safety requirements of transmission lines, the crimping state detection of tensioning clamps has become particularly important. The traditional manual detection method is inefficient and easily affected by human factors, which requires a large amount of workload and labor cost to complete the detection task. In this paper, an intelligent inspection method based on the YOLOv10 algorithm for X-ray images of transmission line clamps is proposed and applied to the UAV platform to improve the inspection efficiency. The method focuses on the typical crimping defect characteristics of tension-resistant wire clips, has good detection accuracy, and significantly reduces the manual intervention and workload. The experimental results show that the proposed method achieves 94.0% mAP@0.5 and a processing frame rate of 51 frames/sec in the defect detection task, which is able to meet the demand for real-time detection at the engineering site while ensuring high accuracy.

title: Use-Case-Oriented Hybrid Encoding Pipelines for Robust Image Steganography Under AI-Based Steganalysis
authors: Aayushi Jeeban Tripathy, Siddhant Ashwani, Kavitha C. R.
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Following the increase in the requests of secure and intelligent data concealment, this paper presents a new layered encoding-based image steganography system that combines the framework with robust embedding, dynamically chosen, based on the requirements of the use case. The scheme hinges on a modular 3 stage pipeline using contemporary encoding tricks, ancient cipher permutations and columnar transposition with superimposing of 2 bits Least Significant Bit (LSB). This architecture as opposed to conventional ones designs the encoding stacks to deploy based on the priorities of various domains; military communications, medical data protection, digital watermarking, secure journalism, forensic storage, and covert social messaging included. Evaluation of the framework is done on three types of lossless images, TIFF, BMP, and PNG with 14 technical measures of visual fidelity, capacity, and robustness points. The stego images are evaluated regarding its adaptability to detection by the classical models of machine learning as well as lightweight deep learning models. The results show a high level of imperceptibility, zero bit error after compression and resistant against automated steganalysis. This paper builds a malleable and robust design of safe imagery-based correspondence in a risky context.

title: High-Precision Temperature Estimation Based on Magnetic Nanoparticles Dominated by Brownian Relaxation under Combined AC and DC Magnetic Fields
authors: Zhongzhou Du, Wenze Zhang, Yi Sun, Na Ye, Yong Gan, Pengchao Wang, Xinwei Zhang, Yuanhao Zhang, Shijie Han, Haochen Zhang, Haozhe Wang, Wenzhong Liu, Takashi Yoshida
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Brownian relaxation is one of the primary mechanisms that allows magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) to convert magnetic energy into thermal energy under an excitation magnetic field. Accurately characterizing the MNP’s magnetization dynamics dominated by Brownian relaxation is crucial for achieving high-precision temperature estimation. However, the lack of a readily applicable analytical expression remains a major obstacle to the advancement of magnetic nanoparticle hyperthermia (MNPH). In this paper, the perturbation method was applied to derive analytical expressions from the Fokker-Planck equation, which characterized MNP’s magnetization behaviors under the AC and DC magnetic fields. Numerical simulations were conducted to validate the accuracy of the analytical expressions and to explore the correlation between temperature and the magnetization. Then, a temperature analysis model based on magnetization harmonics was constructed. The first to second harmonic ratios and first harmonic phases were used to calculate MNP’s temperature, respectively. The experimental results demonstrate that within 310 K to 320 K, the estimation error of the temperature using the amplitude ratio of the first to second harmonics is below 0.02 K, while the error using the first harmonic phase is below 0.03 K. The derived analytical expressions are expected to enhance the accuracy of MNP temperature measurements and facilitate their broader applications in MNPH and MNP imaging.

title: A Deep Learning Approach for Nystagmus Recognition in RGB Videos
authors: Giacomo Nunziati, Andrea Porri, Paolo Andreini, Simone Bonechi, Monica Bianchini, Rudi Pecci, Mattia Ronchetti, Franco Scarselli, Simone Vanni
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Nystagmus is a condition characterized by involuntary, rapid and repetitive movement of the eyes, mainly caused by a dysfunction of the peripheral vestibular system located in the inner ear. It may also arise from the dysfunction of brain areas dedicated to the control of equilibrium and of the visual system. Precisely recognizing nystagmus may help in rapidly differentiating benign from potentially life-threatening diseases. In this paper, we propose a method, based on eye tracking, to easily process RGB videos captured with widely used devices (like smartphones and tablets) to recognize horizontal nystagmus and its direction. The proposed pipeline is designed to work in flexible conditions, without requiring specific recording configurations. We train and evaluate the system on real videos and report an AUROC of 88.7% for nystagmus detection and 76.5% for direction classification. These results support the feasibility of using consumer-grade video data for accurate and automatic screening of nystagmus.

title: Evaluating the Influence of Human and Non-Human Web Traffic on Academic Repository Analytics
authors: Jhean Aguilar-Bueno, Robert A. Alvarado-Lugo, Jean P. Lujan-Leon
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Institutional Repositories (IRs) play a critical role in the dissemination of open-access knowledge, yet their performance evaluation is often hindered by non-human web traffic, such as bots and crawlers, which distort key performance indicators (KPIs). In this study, we present a lightweight data analysis methodology designed to identify and filter non-human activity in IRs. Using nearly one year of real data, we combined serverside statistics from DSpace and Solr with anomaly detection techniques, including Tukey's rule and time-interval analysis, to distinguish human-driven downloads from automated traffic. Our results reveal that approximately 89% of the recorded traffic is non-human, significantly inflating raw KPIs such as downloads and views. In addition, we found massive non-human web traffic originating from only 0.01 % of IP addresses, while 99 % of human users performed up to 8 downloads per day. The proposed approach reduces these distortions and provides an accurate assessment of IRs.
