title: Research on Automated Analysis of Classical Literature Interpretation Based on Big Language Modeling
authors: Junzhu Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper focuses on the application of large-scale language modeling in the interpretation of classical Marxist literature. Firstly, it describes the technical foundation of large-scale language models, including the mainstream architectures such as Transformer architecture and multi-head attention mechanism, as well as the training process based on large-scale text corpus with common algorithms and parameter tuning. Then, we describe in detail the process of automated interpretation of classical Marxist literature, covering the pre-processing of literature, such as text cleaning and annotation, as well as the steps of understanding and interpretation generation after inputting into the model, and take the chapter of Capital as an example to show the actual effect. Subsequently, it is critically analyzed, pointing out that there are problems of understanding bias and misinterpretation when dealing with technical terms and complex concepts, and the lack of historical background understanding, one-sidedness due to the influence of data statistics, and the risk of over-reliance and misinformation dissemination. In order to address these problems, we propose to introduce domain knowledge fine-tuning model and combine historical and cultural databases as improvement strategies. The study shows that although there are limitations at present, with the development of technology, large-scale language models are expected to bring new opportunities and breakthroughs for Marxist theory research and promote its innovative development.

title: An Explainable AI Framework for Energy-Efficient Building Control with Human-in-the-Loop Adaptation
authors: Tao Yang, Shuo Fan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: The inability to interpret decisions made by ‘blackbox’ AI models remains a primary obstacle to their deployment in building automation, where safety and trust are paramount. To bridge this gap, our work introduces a transparent framework that integrates a low-cost IoT-sensing platform with an interpretable, rule-based decision engine. Our core contributions are an adaptive comfort model using survival analysis and a hierarchical control strategy (Health > Comfort > Energy). The system was deployed over three seasons and the comfort index was increased by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15-18 {\%}$</tex>, with only a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.1-8.0 {\%}$</tex> increase in energy consumption. High ECTI value shows good efficiency, delivering over twice the comfort gain per unit of additional energy consumed. This work establishes a new paradigm for trustworthy, humancentric building automation.

title: Hypoglycemia Prediction from Pre-Exercise Continuous Glucose Monitoring Time Series: Deep-Learning Versus Feature-Based Machine-Learning Approaches
authors: Agnese Piersanti, Libera Lucia Del Giudice, Greta Beltramba, Christian Göbl, Laura Burattini, Andrea Tura, Micaela Morettini
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Exercise-induced hypoglycemia poses significant risks to individuals with type 1 diabetes (T1D), discouraging their involvement in physical activity and preventing them from exploiting its known benefits. Although continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) systems may alert the patient of impending high or low glucose levels, they still lack efficient and specific algorithms enabling a safe hypoglycemia prediction prior exercise. Deep learning (DL) and machine learning (ML) approaches now represent potential solutions for the development of clinical decision support systems in the field of diabetes. Thus, this study examined CGM time series preceding the exercise and evaluated the use of DL and feature-based ML approaches to predict hypoglycemia occurring from the start of exercise until the following morning. We analyzed 47 CGM recordings pertaining to T1D young patients that performed a controlled exercise on a treadmill. Recordings were labelled as HYPO or NO-HYPO, based on the occurrence or absence of hypoglycemic episodes, respectively. A Bidirectional-Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) model was trained using raw CGM time series and validated through leave-one-out cross validation. Data augmentation techniques were applied to enhance the small and unbalanced dataset. Results were compared to those previously obtained with ML approaches based on clinically relevant CGM features extracted from the same data. The comparison showed that while the Bi-LSTM DL model exhibited very high specificity (SP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">DL</inf>=84.6%vs SP<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ML</inf>=76.1%), feature-based ML was superior in terms of sensitivity (SE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ML</inf>=87.2% vs SE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">DL</inf>=67.7%), especially important in clinical decision making. In conclusion, DL and ML-based approaches both revealed their potential for exercise-induced hypoglycemia prediction.

title: Investigation Into Degradation and Failure Mechanism of Schottky-Type p-GaN Gate HEMT Under Power Cycling Tests
authors: Zijun Luo, Zhiyuan He, Liang He, Ke Zhang, Yijun Shi, Xinghuan Chen, Hao Niu, Xianzhong Zhou, Yuan Chen, Guoguang Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: This study investigated degradation behaviors and failure mechanisms of Schottky-type p-GaN gate high electron mobility transistor (SP-HEMT) under long-term power cycling tests (PCTs). The device exhibited degradation at both the chip level and the package level with electrical parameters deteriorating. After 320k cycles, increases in gate leakage current and subthreshold swing (SS), as well as a positive shift in threshold voltage of the device were characterized. It was speculated that the electrothermal stress during power cycling may have caused the gate degradation. Low-frequency noise (LFN) measurements identified an increase in trap density of gate during PCT. Obviously, a sharp increase in drain leakage current of the device was observed after 520k cycles. Cracks in the GaN layer below the source, detected by scanning electron microscope (SEM), revealed that new leakage paths had formed in the chip due to thermomechanical stress under long-term PCT. Furthermore, the results based on X-ray and scanning acoustic microscope (SAM) showed that solder fatigue after PCT, which led to an increase in device thermal resistance. It finally triggered thermal runaway and resulted in device burnout.

title: Voxel-Based Implicit Modeling and Simulation for Efficient Computation of Microwave Heating With Moving Components
authors: Fengming Yang, Ruxu Li, Yuanyuan Wu, Yang Yang, Xiangwei Tang, Daming Fan, Huacheng Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: Motion units are often introduced to improve microwave heating uniformity, but accurately modeling heating processes with moving samples remains challenging. Implicit-function-based approaches model object motion as dielectric variations but require fine discretization of the motion domain, increasing computational cost. This study proposes a voxel-based implicit modeling method that constructs a voxel domain conforming to the sample shape and assigns electromagnetic and thermal properties through inside–outside boundary identification, enabling mesh refinement only within the sample region while keeping the voxel domain fixed and representing motion through equivalent cavity deformation. The simulations of a small sample, validated at discrete positions and compared with experiments, show that the proposed method reduces computation time to 16.4% of that of the ray-casting method (RCM) while maintaining high accuracy; additionally, the effects of rotation and lifting speeds on heating performance are analyzed.

title: Enhancing Credit Risk Prediction Through Co-Trained Hybrid Quantum Transfer Learning Model
authors: Parvathy Gopakumar, Rubell Marion Lincy G, Salvatore Sinno, Shruthi Thuravakkath
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: In this work, we explore the potential of a co-trained hybrid quantum-classical transfer learning model in enhancing credit risk classification performance. The proposed Quantum Transfer Learning (QTL) framework integrates a classical neural network with a parameterized quantum circuit, training both components end-to-end to enable synergistic learning. For baseline comparison, we evaluated a standalone Quantum Neural Network (QNN) trained directly on raw credit risk data and a conventional classical neural network. Although the standalone QNN demonstrates theoretical feasibility, it suffers from poor recall and unstable convergence due to the lack of feature preprocessing and high computational demands. Experimental evaluations on a real-world normalized credit risk dataset show that the proposed co-trained QTL model significantly outperforms the baselines. In particular, it achieves a higher area under the ROC curve (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{AUC}=0.9134$</tex>) and improved recall (0.73) for the minority class (defaults), underscoring its effectiveness in addressing class imbalance while remaining feasible under current quantum hardware constraints.

title: Real-Time Threat Detection in Critical Infrastructure with Machine Learning and Industrial Control System Data
authors: Saurabh Pratap Singh Rathore, Surendarkumar S, T. Kiran Kumar, Anshu, Avinash Kumar Namdeo, Shailendra Singh Sikarwar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: The present study introduces a framework for the detection of threats in critical infrastructure in real-time. This framework leverages the capabilities of machine learning and utilizes data from Industrial Control Systems (ICS). In order to evaluate the accuracy of threat identification, we conducted a comparative analysis of three well-known machine learning models: Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and K-nearest Neighbors. Our study specifically emphasized the importance of precision as a key parameter in this assessment. The results of our study indicate that Logistic Regression has higher performance compared to the other models, emerging as the most effective method for effectively identifying possible hazards in real-time ICS data. This study highlights the effectiveness of Logistic Regression in strengthening security protocols within vital infrastructure, presenting a hopeful resolution to protect against rising risks and weaknesses.

title: Evaluation of Image Preprocessing Algorithms for Foggy Scene Enhancement
authors: Diego Alberto Guevara Amaya, Jairo Enrique Serrano Castañeda, Juan Carlos Martinez Santos, Edwin Alexander Puertas del Castillo
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Fog significantly degrades image quality by reducing contrast, detail, and color fidelity. This degradation negatively impacts computer vision tasks. This work presents a comparative evaluation of four preprocessing techniques for foggy image enhancement: Dark Channel Prior (DCP), CLAHE, Multi-Scale Retinex (MSR), and AOD-Net. The methods were tested on 61 images from the DAWN dataset. Three no-reference visual quality metrics (NIQE, BRISQUE, PIQE) and average processing time were used as evaluation criteria. Results show that CLAHE offers the best trade-off between quality and efficiency, making it suitable for real-time applications. AOD-Net demonstrates greater robustness and stability, but at a higher computational cost. In contrast, DCP and MSR exhibit limitations in either stability or execution time. The findings highlight that no single technique is universally optimal. The selection should depend on specific system requirements, balancing visual quality, robustness, and efficiency.

title: Brain Network Dynamics Across Resting-State and the BioVRSea Task using EEG Microstate Analysis
authors: Carmine Gelormini, Federica Pescaglia, Lorena Guerrini, Hannes Petersen, Halldór Jónsson, Riccardo Brun, Giorgio Di Lorenzo, Paolo Gargiulo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Postural control (PC) represents a complex sensorimotor process that integrates multiple sensory inputs to maintain balance. The neural correlates of PC remain incompletely understood, especially in dynamic environments. EEG microstate analysis provides a powerful framework for investigating the temporal dynamics of large-scale neural activity at rest and has been increasingly used in task-based experiments. In this study, we applied EEG microstate analysis to the BioVRSea paradigm. This PC task integrates a moving platform and a virtual reality (VR) system to deliver both motor and visual stimuli. Sensory stimulation was modulated across distinct phases in both congruent and incongruent ways, allowing us to examine neural dynamics under varying PC conditions. EEG data were collected from 12 healthy male sailors immediately after a 3-week maritime deployment. Participants underwent a resting-state recording followed by the BioVRSea task. EEG signals were then segmented into five microstates using a K-means clustering algorithm, and microstate temporal dynamics (Duration, Occurrence, and Coverage) were extracted by backfitting the grand mean maps onto the EEG signal. A linear mixed-effect model was employed to assess differences in microstate temporal parameters between resting-state and task conditions. Our findings reveal significant modulations in microstate properties, suggesting that neural dynamics during PC differ substantially from those observed at rest.

title:
FEV
                    <sub>1</sub>
                    Trajectory Classification in COPD Patients
authors: Francesco Bossi, Alberto Greco, Gianluca Rho, Carlotta Marinai, Pasquale Bufano, Michele Zanoletti, Eleonora Melissa, Marco Laurino, Francesco Di Rienzo, Carlo Vallati, Nicola Carbonaro, Henrik Watz, Mustafa Abdo, Alessandro Tognetti
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, with progressive lung function decline severely affecting patients' quality of life. Spirometric assessment, particularly Forced Expiratory Volume in one second as a percentage of predicted (FEV<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>% predicted), is central to monitoring disease progression but is often impractical for regular use due to its invasive and burdensome nature. This study explores an alternative approach for predicting longitudinal changes in FEV<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>% predicted using passive data collected via wearable sensors and demographic variables. Utilizing data from 423 patients in the COSYCONET cohort, physical activity metrics - such as accelerometer readings, step counts, and energy expenditure - were processed from one-week recordings. After constructing paired observations to reflect FEV<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf> changes between clinical visits, the problem was reformulated as a binary classification task (improvement vs. worsening). Principal Component Analysis was used for dimensionality reduction, followed by training six classification models. Naive Bayes and Quadratic Discriminant Analysis (QDA) achieved the highest overall accuracy, with k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN) offering the best sensitivity. Results suggest that non-linear and non-parametric models are more suitable for capturing the complexity of COPD progression. However, performance remains modest, likely due to the simplistic binary threshold applied to FEV<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf> changes. Future research should focus on refining thresholds to better reflect clinically meaningful variations and improve model precision.

title: Deep Integration and Application of AI Technology in 6G Network
authors: Cai He, Lang Qianqian
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the rapid development of AI technology, various kinds of AI applications have been fully and deeply blossomed in many fields, and the in-depth integration of 6G network and AI in the future is an inevitable trend. The 6G network and AI technology empower and promote each other at different technical levels, which can promote the mutual benefit and win-win progress of 6G and AI bilateral ecological industries. This paper described the industrial analysis and technical research of 6G network and AI integration and introduced the concept of Native-AI 6G Network. Hope this paper can provide reference and guidance for the future of Native-AI 6G network planning and construction solutions.

title: Enhanced Pedestrian Detection for Autonomous Driving Using Multimodal Spatio-Contextual Deep Networks
authors: Pulipati Srilatha, Pallati Narsimhulu, Kurikyala Premchand, Somula Ramasubbareddy, Gaddam A Sanjeeva Reddy
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Pedestrian detection has become a significant research focus in autonomous driving. Many investigation mechanisms have developed detection techniques using simple camera devices, which can affect the performance of detection as they produce low-quality images, such as RGB, especially in cases of imbalanced illumination and a lack of texture. The images produced by a thermal camera can retain quality for better detection in complex scenes. Popular works attained maximum accuracy in the detection of pedestrians in a few scenarios. However, there is scope to improve the efficiency of detection in critical scenarios, such as daytime and nighttime, as well as densely populated regions. To address this issue, this article presented Enhanced Pedestrian Detection for Autonomous Driving Using Multimodal Spatio-Contextual Deep Networks to enhance detection accuracy in broad scenarios. This approach is developed in the combination of multimodal data and deep networks. The useful features can be extracted during the pipeline process, which can improve detection accuracy. All input images are normalized into a standard $640 \times 640$ resolution. The contrast of the image is enhanced with the help of CLAHE. Further, the objects are detected using a pretrained R-CNN framework, and the latter model is adjusted with user-defined threshold values for improving the confidence of detection. This investigation was implemented in a user-friendly web application built using the Flask web framework. The web page allows researchers to upload and investigate the detection summary. The proposed approach can be further investigated in real-world applications.

title: Speech Analysis Technology and the Dual Phonetic Transcription Method: A Combined Approach to Enhancing EFL Pronunciation
authors: Donghong Li, Min Yang, Tongtong Lyu, Yitong Wang, Samuel Akwasi Agyemang, Bo Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: Learners of English as a Foreign Language, particularly those with Chinese as their native language, encounter substantial difficulties in pronunciation and listening comprehension owing to interference from their first language. Such interference often results in systematic errors, including the substitution of the mid-close back unrounded vowel [ɤ] for the schwa [ә], alongside challenges in mastering consonant variations such as linking and assimilation. This study introduces a theoretical framework that integrates the Dual Phonetic Transcription Teaching Method, using the PRAAT speech analysis software to enhance EFL instruction. DPTTM concurrently presents standard pronunciations (e.g., “want to” as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$[{}^{\prime}\text{want tu}:])$</tex> alongside their natural, colloquial variants (e.g., “wanna” as [‘wanә]), thereby targeting enhancements in vowel accuracy and the handling of consonant modifications. Furthermore, spectrograms generated via the PRAAT software (e.g., contrasting the [x0264] in the Chinese morpheme “歌” with the [x0259] in the English word “about”; the [e]-like vowel in “月” versus the [e] in “bed”; and the palatalization from /t j/ to /ʧ/ in phrases such as “nice to meet you”) deliver visual feedback crucial for correcting negative first language transfer and optimizing articulatory refinement. The framework also supports interactive exercises, leveraging cognitive psychology principles and offers scalable solutions for diverse learners, with future work exploring empirical validation and applications.

title: Medical CT Image Generation Based on Latent Space Compression
authors: Jinxing Zhu, Jiayu Wu, Tao Wang, Bingding Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: In recent years, with deep learning development, research based on medical image data has received widespread attention. However, deep learning algorithms require model training on a large number of annotated datasets. Access to medical image data is strictly regulated due to the high cost of acquiring and legal, ethical, and privacy considerations. All these reasons lead to the fact that it is often difficult to obtain large-scale medical image datasets. How to expand the existing data by generating simulated medical images through deep learning methods has become an urgent issue. Here, we propose a generation model for 3D medical CT images based on VQGAN and DDPM. Our algorithm employs DDPM to fit the distribution of latent space data of VQGAN, which realizes the generation of CT images at the 3D level and effectively preserves the consistent coherence among CT slices. We conducted experimental validation using the MICCAI FLARE 2022 dataset and comparative experiments for the parameters used in the VQGAN training process. Our proposed model's 3D average slice FID coefficient reaches 20.79, and the FVD coefficient reaches 252.97 in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$128\times 128\times 64$</tex> dimensions. These results demonstrated that our model can effectively generate medical CT images with sound generation quality and stable performance.

title: IoT-Based System for Monitoring Photovoltaic Batteries in Hard-to-Reach Areas: The Wasakentsa Case Study
authors: Karla Vázquez, Andres Calderon, Mónica Huerta, Juan Inga-Ortega, Esteban Ordoñez, Osmani Ordoñez-Ordoñez, Roger Clotet
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: The Wasakentsa health center is of significant importance in the area, as it is the only place that has the necessary equipment to provide adequate care. However, the photovoltaic plant that supplies power to the center lacks an real-time monitoring system for its batteries, which represents a critical challenge that can compromise the efficiency and sustainability of the power supply. For this reason, this project proposes the creation of an IoT system for monitoring the status of batteries in a solar power system, applied to the Wasakentsa health center. Various technologies were analyzed and a Heltec WiFi LoRa 32 V2 microcontroller was chosen, along with voltage, temperature and humidity sensors, in addition to the ThingsBoard platform for visualization of the data collected in real time. The methodology included laboratory tests followed by verification in situ, ensuring that the findings accurately reflect actual system conditions. The system enabled real-time monitoring of parameters of both the batteries and the environment in which they are installed, optimizing energy management and extending system life. The visualization of the data on the ThingsBoard platform facilitated the early detection of possible failures, reducing downtime and improving operational efficiency. Initial experiments, conducted at the Salesian Polytechnic University, demonstrated the functionality of the system, the effectiveness of which was subsequently validated at Wasakentsa. This system is a replicable solution for other isolated communities around the world.

title: It's-A-Me, Quantum Mario: Scalable Quantum Reinforcement Learning with Multi-Chip Ensembles
authors: Junghoon Justin Park, Huan-Hsin Tseng, Shinjae Yoo, Samuel Yen-Chi Chen, Jiook Cha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: Quantum reinforcement learning (QRL) promises compact function approximators with access to vast Hilbert spaces, but its practical progress is slowed by NISQ-era constraints such as limited qubits and noise accumulation. We introduce a multi-chip ensemble framework using multiple small Quantum Convolutional Neural Networks (QCNNs) to overcome these constraints. Our approach partitions complex, high-dimensional observations from the Super Mario Bros environment across independent quantum circuits, then classically aggregates their outputs within a Double Deep Q-Network (DDQN) framework. This modular architecture enables QRL in complex environments previously inaccessible to quantum agents, achieving superior performance and learning stability compared to classical baselines and single-chip quantum models. The multichip ensemble demonstrates enhanced scalability by reducing information loss from dimensionality reduction while remaining implementable on near-term quantum hardware, providing a practical pathway for applying QRL to real-world problems.

title: A Deep Learning Framework for Real-Time Video Captioning and Multilingual Translation
authors: Yash Dev, Sushma Uddanti, Lowkya Mathuraju, Venkata Rami Reddy Chirra
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: This work presents a novel approach to writing textual descriptions of video footage and translating them into different languages in order to increase accessibility. The recommended <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1, 4 5 0}$</tex> YouTube videos from the Microsoft Video Description (MSVD) dataset were used to train a sequence-tosequence model with Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) networks. To create accurate captions, visual characteristics are extracted using a pre-trained VGG16 model. A unique feature of the proposed system is a web application that not only produces captions but also translates them into Hindi, Telugu, French, and Marathi in real-time, allowing users to copy and share the translated text. This work addresses the growing need for automated, multilingual video accessibility, making content inclusive for diverse linguistic communities.

title: From Classical to Quantum Optimization: Enhancing Cultural Heritage Visits Through Adaptive Path Planning
authors: Angela Chiatto, Francesco Colace, Alfredo Massa, Giovanni Trezza, Alfredo Troiano, Carmine Valentino, Nadia Caterina Lasala Zullo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: The enhancement of cultural heritage through personalized itineraries represents a crucial challenge in the tourism and museum fields. Therefore, this work addresses the problem of maximizing the number of historical-cultural points of interest that can be visited within an archaeological site while respecting constraints on the maximum distance that the visitor can cover. In particular, this study begins with a classical treatment of the problem, highlighting the issues that emerged from a preliminary experimental campaign. Subsequently, the problem is modeled as a combinatorial optimization instance, solvable through a classical-quantum approach based on the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA). Thanks to its hybrid structure, QAOA enables the simultaneous exploration of a vast solution space and, through a classical optimizer, updates the parameters of the quantum circuit to converge toward high-performing solutions. The experimental phase utilizes a simulated and simplified environment to evaluate the reliability of the proposed solution and assess its applicability to a real-world case study.

title: Intelligent Intrusion Detection for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles to Enhance Defense Security System: An Improved Ensemble Learning Approach
authors: Shampa Priyadarshini, Janmenjoy Nayak, Pandit Byomakesha Dash, Ramesh Tanty, Sradhanjali Pattanaik
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: The Internet of Drones (IoD) is crucial in modern defense systems but remains vulnerable to sophisticated cyberattacks. This research proposes an improved intrusion detection model based on Histogram-based Gradient Boosting (Hist-GBoost) to heighten UAV attack detection in IoD networks. The model's effectiveness has evaluated with established Machine Learning (ML) models such as Logistic Regression (LR), Support Vector Machines (SVM), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Decision Trees (DT) and ensemble techniques such as Random Forests (RF), Bagging, Adaptive Boosting (AdaBoost), Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) and Histogram based Gradient Boosting (Hist-GBoost). The proposed HistGBoost achieved superior performance, with an accuracy of 99.42%, F1-score of 0.9942 and a near-perfect ROC- AUC score of 0.9999. Detailed attack-wise analysis highlighted exceptional detection accuracy across multiple attack types, including benign traffic (99.20%), DoS attacks (99.22%) and replay attacks (99.95%). The model's robustness ensures high reliability and precision in identifying UAV-based security threats. Its integration into IoD defense systems offers scalable, efficient and accurate intrusion detection contributing to better cybersecurity for dynamic and resource-constrained IoD environments.

title: TopoGCL: Multi-Scale Topological Contrast for Graph Representation Learning
authors: Rui Xie, Bing Li, Wenming Cao, Weikai Li, Xiaofeng Chen, Jin Hu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: Graph representation learning aims to produce effective node embeddings by fully exploiting the graph's inherent structural information and node features. However, traditional methods often struggle to utilize high-order topology effectively due to the over-smoothing issue, particularly in noisy or sparsely labeled graphs. To circumvent this obstacle, we propose a novel multi-scale topological structure-based graph contrastive learning framework (TopoGCL) that explicitly integrates complementary path-based and neighborhood-based structural information. We introduce a symmetric InfoNCE contrastive loss function enhanced by dual temperature coefficients, enabling the model to adaptively balance the discrimination between inter-view and intra-view negative samples. The experiments conducted on benchmark citation networks show that our TopoGCL model achieves competitive or superior performance compared to several state-of-the-art baselines in node classification tasks. Temperature coefficients analysis and ablation studies further validate the critical role of the dual temperature contrastive strategy and multi-view structural augmentation, highlighting their distinct advantages in improving embedding quality and model robustness.

title: AS-Rank: Automatic and Self-Adaptive Fault Root Cause Localization for Microservice Architecture
authors: Yixuan Wu, Yazhuo Gao, Jian Song, Lin Yang, Laisen Nie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: The microservice architecture is increasingly popular across various fields due to its flexibility and logical clarity. However, the highly dynamic operational environment, along with potential configuration and software errors, makes identifying the root causes of failures challenging. To address this issue, this paper proposes an adaptive and automated method called AS-Rank, which consists of three components: anomaly quantification, root cause service localization, and root cause indicator localization. Initially, anomaly quantification evaluates the current state data of the microservices system to generate anomaly scores. Subsequently, a weighted service dependency graph is constructed using these scores and service dependencies. Root cause services are then identified by considering both node and edge weights. Finally, key indicators are selected based on the identified service and analyzed using causal inference techniques. Experimental results demonstrate that AS-Rank accurately identifies root causes in both single and multiple root-cause scenarios.

title: Improving Relay Distance Measurement: Tor Relay Clustering Algorithm Based on K-Mediods
authors: Shangyu Chen, Hongchao Hu, Shuai Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: With the development and application of machine learning, attackers can eavesdrop on the traffic of users browsing websites through malicious relays on Tor user links, and conduct traffic analysis on them, thus carrying out de-anonymization attacks on Tor users. Therefore, identifying malicious relays is critical to ensuring the anonymity of the Tor network. Previous studies have shown that malicious relays usually have similar relay configuration information and go online and offline at the same time, so the nearest neighbor ranking algorithm is designed to measure the similarity of relays. Then according to the seed relays, the malicious relays are screened out. However, this algorithm regards the relay configuration information as a unified string information and adopts a unified distance calculation method, which leads to inaccurate similarity analysis of relays. In order to solve this problem, this paper considers the difference of the configuration information of relays, improves the distance calculation method, and uses the improved distance calculation method to cluster relays based on the K-Mediods algorithm, so that the relays with similar configurations can be clustered together. The experimental results show that the improved distance calculation method has better clustering effect on relays, which is conducive to further identification of malicious relays.

title: Traub-Based Numerical Solution of Power Flow Equations in DC Monopolar Systems
authors: Oscar Danilo Montoya, Rubén Iván Bolaños, Luis Fernando Grisales-Noreña
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This paper presents an efficient numerical approach for solving nonlinear DC power flow problems in radial distribution networks using the multivariate Traub method. Two distinct mathematical formulations of the DC power flow equations are analyzed, both derived from the nodal conductance matrix and incorporating constant-power loads. The Traub method, which exhibits cubic convergence and requires only one Jacobian evaluation per iteration, is applied to each formulation and benchmarked against the classical Newton-Raphson method. Numerical experiments on standard 33-bus and 69-bus test systems demonstrate that the Traub-based solver achieves faster convergence, reduced computational time, and improved numerical stability. These findings highlight the potential of the Traub method as a scalable and accurate alternative for power flow analysis in modern DC distribution systems.

title: Enhanced EEG Complexity and Spectral Alterations in Migraine: A PSD and Higuchi's Fractal Dimension Analysis by ICA and PCA Spatial Filters
authors: Camillo Porcaro, Sadaf Moaveninejad, Romain Aubonnet, Sara Gilli, Gianluca Coppola, Giorgio Di Lorenzo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Migraine is a complex neurological disorder associated with abnormal functional connectivity and altered neural dynamics. This study investigates cortical complexity and spectral properties in episodic migraine using EEG-derived resting-state networks (RSNs) analysed with power spectral density (PSD) and Higuchi's fractal dimension (HFD). EEG data from 22 migraineurs and 25 healthy controls were processed using Independent Component Analysis (ICA) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) spatial filters to extract functionally relevant brain networks. PSD analysis revealed increased low frequency (delta, theta) and decreased high frequency (beta, gamma) power in migraineurs, suggesting disturbed oscillatory activity. HFD analysis showed significantly higher complexity in several RSNs, indicating irregular neural dynamics. Notably, HFD scores correlated with the age of migraine onset and duration, highlighting potential effects on disease progression. These findings suggest widespread dysregulation of brain network dynamics in migraine and support EEG complexity measures as potential biomarkers for diagnosis and treatment monitoring.

title: A Blockchain-Based Framework for Municipal Waste Management in Smart Cities
authors: Anuja Jirapure, Khushboo Khurana, Anand Shakya
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: An essential component of urban governance is municipal waste management, requiring efficient, transparent, and sustainable solutions. Blockchain technology offers transformative potential in addressing challenges such as inefficiency, lack of transparency, and data integrity in waste management systems. The paper presents a blockchain-based decentralized solution to overcome these challenges. A blockchain-based framework for solid waste management in smart cities, integrating smart contracts and authenticated data structures (ADS) to ensure transparency, automation, and data integrity is proposed in this paper. A decentralized blockchain network is integrated to record waste collection, processing, and disposal activities in an immutable ledger. Smart contracts automate key processes such as servicelevel agreements, incentive distribution, and compliance verification, reducing manual intervention and enhancing operational efficiency. An algorithm for authentic verification is used. This verification process will be used by both, user at time of waste pickup service and by waste collector at time of waste disposal, to promote a proper disposal process. This makes the system more secure due to its dual verification process. Track of waste from generation to disposal, ensures that there is no illegal dumping. A mathematical formalization is done for route optimization which will help to reduce the time taken to provide waste pick-up service and minimize the cost. A key solution for effective waste disposal is presented, where the waste is pre-segregation (the user), into different categories such as organic, inorganic, and plastic. The users then fill the details of their segregated waste, schedule the waste pickup service. This is a simple yet powerful system that can greatly benefit waste collection and disposal process. An integrated incentive model is also utilized to reward and maintain the sustainable disposal practices.

title: Research on System Identification Method of Electro Hydraulic Servo Valve for High-Lift System
authors: Lei Pei, Yonggang Xu, Liping Meng, Lvyuan Wu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: This paper conducts a MATLAB-based system identification study to address the problem of accurate modeling of electro-hydraulic servo valves in high-lift systems. By separately collecting time-domain dynamic response data and frequencydomain sweep data, and utilizing the system identification toolbox, a second-order transfer function model of the electro-hydraulic servo valve is identified based on the least squares criterion and the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm. Experimental verification shows that the obtained models exhibit a high degree of consistency in terms of time-domain response, frequency-domain characteristics, and step response, with the goodness of fit exceeding 88%. This study verifies the effectiveness of the adopted identification method and provides a reliable model foundation for subsequent controller design.

title: Assessing the Consistency of EEG Connectome Topology Across Different Parcellation Approaches
authors: Marianna Chianese, Federica Pescaglia, Lorena Guerrini, Carmine Gelormini, Ida Maruotto, Gylfi Örn Pormar, Fabrizio Esposito, Leandro Donisi, Paolo Gargiulo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Network graph theory (NGT) provides a powerful framework for characterizing the topological organization of brain networks and understanding functional integration and segregation within the brain. However, the estimation of NGT metrics is inherently dependent on the definition of network nodes, which is also determined by the choice of brain parcellation atlas. This dependency raises critical concerns about the comparability, reliability, and interpretability of graph-derived metrics across studies, particularly in clinical populations such as patients with Parkinson's Disease (PD). The present study aimed to systematically evaluate the influence of parcellation scheme on NGT metrics computed from EEG-based functional connectivity (FC) data in a cohort of PD patients. Specifically, the objective was to identify which metrics are robust to parcellation choice and thus potentially more reliable for use as biomarkers in clinical neuroscience. EEG recordings were acquired from 18 PD patients using a 64-channel wearable EEG cap during resting-state conditions. Source reconstruction was performed using a Boundary Element Model and cortical time series were extracted using two parcellation atlases: the anatomically defined Desikan-Killiany 56-region atlas obtained from Desikan Killiany 68 and the functionally defined Schaefer 100-region atlas. FC matrices were computed using the Phase Locking Value, and seven key NGT metrics were extracted from each matrix: clustering coefficient, participation coefficient, characteristic path length, global efficiency, strength, transitivity, and assortativity. The agreement between metrics derived from the two parcellations was assessed first using the Wilcoxon signed-rank test, followed by Bland-Altman analysis to evaluate systematic bias and/or other types of errors. Statistical analysis revealed significant differences across most metrics between the two atlases, indicating that parcellation choice can meaningfully affect the topological characterization of functional brain networks. However, two metrics characteristic path length (CPL) and participation coefficient (P) exhibited strong agreement between parcellations, with non-significant Wilcoxon test results (p = 0.913 for CPL; p = 0.055 for P) and Bland-Altman plots showing no trends and 95 % confidence intervals of the bias including the zero line. These findings suggest that CPL and P are robust to parcellation scheme and may serve as stable indicators of global network integration and inter-modular connectivity, respectively underscoring the methodological sensitivity of NGT metrics to the choice of brain atlas. Nevertheless, the observed robustness of CPL and P suggests that certain global integration metrics may provide reliable markers for assessing brain network organization in PD, regardless of parcellation strategy. These findings have important implications for the standardization of brain network analyses and the development of reproducible, generalizable biomarkers. Future studies with larger cohorts and matched healthy control groups are warranted to validate these observations and extend them to broader clinical applications.

title: Retinal Fundus Image Segmentation Using Transfer Learning with MobileNetV2 and U-Net Architectures
authors: Kankanala Srinivas, Aswini Mitikiri, Geetha Pallavi Mandadi, Balaram Murthy Chintakindi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: Accurate analysis of retinal blood vessels is crucial for clinical diagnosis and personalized treatment planning. However, manually segmenting vessels from fundus images is timeconsuming and requires specialized expertise. This work proposes the MobileNet-Unet model for fast and precise retinal vessel segmentation. MobileNet, as the encoder, employs depthwise separable convolutions to lower computational demands, making it ideal for mobile and embedded applications. The Unet decoder progressively upsamples features, using skip connections to retain spatial information. Together, they deliver high segmentation accuracy with reduced resource usage. Experiments on benchmark retinal datasets show that MobileNet-Unet surpasses existing methods in performance. Its balance of efficiency and precision supports real-time clinical deployment, while its flexible design allows extension to other segmentation tasks, such as medical imaging and autonomous navigation.

title: Building Image Caption Based on InceptionV3 Using Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Ashwani Kumar, Premnanda Sahu, Pronaya Bhattacharya, Avinash Kumar Sharma, Mohit Kumar
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Image captioning is the generation of contextually relevant textual data from the visual content of an image. Advancements in computer vision and natural language processing in the field of deep learning have made great improvements. This work demonstrates a deep learningbased approach that effectively integrates Long Short-term Memory (LSTM) with Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to generate meaningful captions. The CNN component of the model utilizes InceptionV3 architecture which is used to extract complex-level features from the images. These features are then passed to the LSTM network, a type of Recurrent Neural Network (RNN), which excels at predicting and learning long-term dependencies-making it suitable for generating contextually accurate captions from images. Flickr8k dataset is used for both training and testing, which consists of 8000 images, each annotated with five different captions. One of the most important part of the process is data preprocessing, which includes cleaning the text, tokenizing, and converting images into suitable feature vectors. The model is trained over multiple epochs and performance is calculated using standard evaluation measures like METEOR. The findings indicate that the model generates accurate and context-aware captions. The evaluation scores improve significantly with additional training, which indicates effective learning over time. This study shows the potential of combining CNNs and LSTMs for solving the image captioning problem and contributes in the ongoing research in multi-model deep learning.

title: Modeling Radio Wave Propagation in Cassava Crops Using ML Algorithms for Planning WSN's
authors: Alexis Barrios-Ulloa, Javier E. Sierra, Boris Medina-Salgado
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Efficient planning of Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) is essential in agricultural applications. In this context, accurately modeling radio wave propagation is key to avoiding errors or increased costs in the design and deployment of IoT infrastructure. This work presents an experimental study in cassava crops aimed at evaluating Machine Learning (ML) algorithms to predict path loss in agricultural environments with dense vegetation. RSSI data were collected under different crop conditions and antenna configurations. The evaluated models included Support Vector Regression (SVR), Decision Trees (DT), Random Forests (RF), and Artificial Neural Networks (ANN), using cross-validation to ensure the robustness of the results. The DT and RF models achieved the best performance, with RMSE errors below 2 dB and coefficients of determination above 97%, while the ANN model showed limitations in its accuracy. These results highlight the value of ML in supporting the design of more accurate and efficient WSNs in agriculture.

title: Selection of Power Grids Using the Single-Valued Ambiguous Fuzzy Entropy and Distance Measures
authors: Shweta Goyal, Shweta Sachdeva, Sangeeta Pant, Anuj Kumar, B.P. Joshi, Birendra Kumar Saraswat
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: The Single-Valued Ambiguous Fuzzy Set (SVAFS) Theory (SVAFST) was introduced recently to handle uncertain systems with more details and it is one of the generalizations of fuzzy set (FS) theory. This type of theory has the ability to employ four different degrees of membership: true, false, ambiguous-true, and ambiguous-false categories in one compact form and proved as an effective way to model uncertainty. Keeping in view the advantages of FS and thus of SVAFS, we are studying the SVAFS in more details and to see the applicability of it to address different kind of problems. In this paper, we are addressing the entropy measure of SVAFS. Thus, the entropy based on distance measures of SVAFS is proposed. Then, this proposed entropy measure is applied to the Power Grids (PGs) classification. Validation of results are carried out with considering some of the existing studies in the domain of SVAFS. Different structures of entropy and distance of SVAFS will comprise in future study with application in different fields.

title: Traffic Flow Prediction Analysis Based on Spatio-Temporal Map Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Jingzhe Kang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: In this paper, a traffic flow prediction method based on spatio-temporal graph convolutional neural network is proposed, aiming to solve the link between highway traffic flow prediction and differential toll pricing. Firstly, the study is conducted by obtaining and preprocessing road toll information, road attribute information and traffic flow data of the freeway. Then, the graph self-learning module is used to encode this information into the graph adjacency matrix, and then the optimal graph adjacency matrix is constructed. Secondly, through the spatio-temporal graph convolutional neural network model based on temporal attention mechanism, this paper effectively improves the accuracy of traffic flow prediction. The proposed model outperforms traditional methods in traffic flow prediction considering price factors and can more accurately reflect the spatio-temporal change law of road traffic flow, providing new theoretical support and practical methods for data-driven differentiated toll pricing.

title: LLM-Driven Event Log Generation from Forensic Cases: A Comparative Study of ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini
authors: Mirai Gendi, Periklis Andritsos
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Event logs underpin both process mining and digital forensic analysis. Yet turning unstructured case narratives into wellformed logs remains a non-trivial task. Much of the work to date has relied on bespoke Natural Language Processing (NLP) pipelines or transformer-based stacks, which are solutions that can be effective but are also engineering-intensive. This study asks a straightforward question: can large language models (LLMs) (ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini, produce structured, XES-compatible event logs directly from forensic narratives? We examine eight case files and assess the outputs along four dimensions that matter in practice: temporal consistency, redundancy, schema compliance, and classification performance. The results are instructive. ChatGPT generated timelines that were fully consistent and adhered to the schema in all cases. Claude performed well overall but showed slightly lower consistency and compliance. Gemini achieved near-perfect temporal alignment, though its outputs varied more across cases. Pairwise comparisons indicate small but meaningful gaps in consistency. Taken together, these findings suggest that LLMs are a potential alternative to custom pipelines for event log generation. Even so, the forensic context warrants caution: outputs should be validated carefully before use, with attention to case details and downstream impact.

title: Artificial Neural Network Approach for Unit Commitment with Renewable Energy Integration
authors: M. Khaled Hussein Omar, Madihah Md. Rasid, Siti Maherah Hussin, Norazliani Md Sapari, Dalila Mat Said, Rozana Zakaria
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources (RES) into power generation systems presents both opportunities and challenges. Traditional methods of power generation scheduling, such as Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP), often struggle to accommodate the variability and uncertainty associated with RES. This study addresses these challenges by developing an Artificial Neural Network (ANN)-based unit commitment optimization model to enhance the efficiency and reliability of power generation scheduling while incorporating solar and wind energy. A comprehensive dataset covering one year of wind power, solar power, and load profiles was collected to train the ANN model. This dataset was further supplemented with detailed operational attributes, cost coefficients, and generator constraints to improve model accuracy and performance. The proposed model is tested on a modified IEEE-14 bus system across various planning intervals: one-day, one-week, and one-month. For further evaluation, the ANN-based approach is compared with the traditional MILP method. The results demonstrate that the ANN-based unit commitment model can effectively schedule generator outputs across different timeframes in the presence of renewable intermittency and achieves a cost saving of approximately $ 51 compared to the MILP approach. These findings underscore the potential of AI-based models for efficient and flexible scheduling in renewable-integrated power systems.

title: Monitoring and Analysis of Energy Variables Through IoT Platforms
authors: Romero-Solana Santiago, Cohen-Manrique Carlos, Porto-Mass Eberto, Quiroz-Herazo Luis, Vergara-Rodriguez Cesar
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This article presents a comprehensive analysis of electrical parameter monitoring conducted in Blocks A and F of the Corporación Universitaria del Caribe (CECAR) during 2025. The study showcases the implementation of an advanced IoT-based energy monitoring platform developed at the Vatio Laboratory, which leverages a hybrid communication infrastructure combining wired and wireless technologies for realtime data acquisition. The system continuously records electrical variables—voltage, current, active and reactive power, and power factor—enabling the identification of consumption patterns and opportunities for energy optimization. To enhance the reliability of the collected data, which exhibited high variability and significant noise, the study evaluates the performance of three smoothing algorithms: Kalman, Savitzky–Golay, and Whittaker. Among them, the Savitzky–Golay and Whittaker methods achieved superior results, with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> values of 0.9857, Signal-to-Noise Ratios exceeding 18 dB, and Mean Squared Errors reduced to nearly 0.0283, substantially outperforming the Kalman filter. These findings validate the effectiveness of advanced smoothing techniques in improving data quality for real-time energy monitoring systems.

title: Explainable U-Net Based Autoencoder Model for Radiation Dose Optimization in Computed Tomography Imaging
authors: Shaoni Banerjee, Apurba Nandi, Arijeet Ghosh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Responsible, Generative and Explainable AI (ResGenXAI)
abstract: Computed Tomography (CT) imaging is essential in diagnostics but presents a radiation risk, particularly for sensitive populations. To address this, we propose a deep learning-based framework for ultra-low-dose CT (ULDCT) reconstruction using a modified U-Net convolutional autoencoder. The architecture preserves fine anatomical structures through symmetric skip connections and is trained end-to-end to restore full-dose quality images without handcrafted filtering. The model is evaluated on a diverse, publicly available CT dataset that includes variable slice thicknesses and reconstruction kernels, ensuring robustness and real-world applicability. Furthermore, Explainable AI (XAI) is integrated to provide transparency and interpretability in model decisions-enhancing clinical trust. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves superior structural similarity (SSIM) and peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) compared to state-of-the-art approaches, while significantly reducing noise and maintaining diagnostic quality. The proposed solution highlights a scalable, interpretable, and clinically relevant pathway for reducing radiation exposure in CT imaging without compromising image fidelity.

title: Personalized Multi-Agent Recommendation System for Monitoring and Coaching through Wearable and Non-Invasive Sensors
authors: Nicola Davolio, Fiorenzo Colarusso, Selay Yuksel, Sara Casaccia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The aging population and the growing prevalence of chronic diseases are placing increasing demands on global healthcare systems. In this context, the remote acquisition of physiological and behavioural data through wearable and non-invasive devices plays a crucial role in supporting Active and Assisted Living (AAL) solutions. However, transforming sensor data into actionable and personalized health guidance remains a key challenge. This paper presents a novel multi-agent system (MAS) designed to support ageing individuals, healthcare professionals, and personal coaches. The system leverages real-time physiological and personal signals to deliver tailored health recommendations, support engagement, facilitate socialization, and enable proactive interventions. Each agent in the system is specialized in interpreting specific data types-such as heart rate, movement, and sleep patterns-and collaborates with others to provide a holistic understanding of the user's health status. Importantly, the behavior and decision-making of each agent are dynamically personalized based on the unique data, preferences, and evolving health conditions of each user. The system also facilitates communication between seniors, coaches, and healthcare professionals, promoting shared decision-making and continuous support. Preliminary results show the system's potential in enhancing user engagement, improving care coordination, and enabling scalable, personalized coaching in AAL settings.

title: Enhancing Brain-Computer Interfaces: Machine Learning Analysis of Alpha-Beta ERD and Fractal Dimension in Motor Imagery EEG
authors: Sadaf Moaveninejad, Franca Tecchio, Francesco Ferracuti, Sabrina Iarlori, Andrea Monteriù, Camillo Porcaro
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) assist people with motor impairments by translating brain activity into control signals. Accurate classification of motor-related neural patterns is crucial for effective diagnosis and treatment. Event-Related Desynchronization (ERD) in the alpha and beta bands (ERD-<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha\beta)$</tex> has been widely used, while Fractal Dimension (FD), a non-linear measure of signal complexity, provides an alternative discriminative feature. This study evaluates ERD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-\alpha\beta$</tex> and FD using Gradient Boosting (GB), Random Forest (RF), k-Nearest Neighbours (KNN), and Support Vector Machines (SVM) on EEG data from 20 selected subjects. FD consistently outperformed ERD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-\alpha\beta$</tex>, with SVM achieving the highest accuracy: 86% for imagined hand movements (IHM) and 81% for imagined fist or foot movements (IFM). RF and GB also performed well with FD, while KNN showed lower accuracy. The method follows a cross-subject evaluation scheme, where models are trained and tested on data from different individuals with no data leakage. The current analysis focused on subjects with stronger EEG activation to ensure robust feature evaluation. The results suggest that FD improves classification accuracy in EEG-based BCls compared to ERD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-\alpha\beta$</tex>, supporting its integration into future BCI systems for improved reliability and usability.

title: Cybersecurity Problems in SAP Digital Supply Chains: Prevent Intrusions, Stopping Data Breaches, and Protecting Logistics Operations that Use Blockchain Technology
authors: Chandra Doddapalli Ramachandra Reddy, Sumanth Aswath Narayana, Niveditha
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Enterprise resource planning (ERP) solutions, such as SAP, have emerged as essential digital backbones for commerce and logistics operations as a result of the rapid transition to digital supply chains that has taken place all over the world. This change has resulted in the introduction of ERP solutions. On the other hand, this modification has also resulted in an increase in the susceptibility of cybersecurity, particularly in areas of SAP digital supply chains that are integrated with one another. This can be seen in the fact that the vulnerability has increased. Because these systems deal with sensitive information in networks for procurement, logistics, and inventory, they are becoming increasingly enticing targets for cyber attacks, ransomware, and threats that originate from within the business. This is because these systems deal with information that should be kept confidential. The purpose of this research is to investigate the developing concerns regarding cybersecurity that are observed within the context of SAP digital supply chains. For the objective of ensuring that data is exchanged in a secure manner and that processes are transparent, special attention is devoted to the prevention of invasions, the reduction of data breaches, and utilization of blockchain technology. The purpose of this research is to provide an advanced architecture that makes use of the decentralized trust model that blockchain technology will enable. This architecture was developed to ensure that data cannot be manipulated, to improve traceability, and to tighten access control among stakeholders in distant supply chains. The strategy that has been offered is designed to establish a multi-layered defense system that will be built of SAP system logs, smart contracts, and blockchain records. These components will work together to improve trust, accountability, and resilience. This framework not only protects the operations of firms that deal with logistics, but it also provides financial assistance to these companies so that they can take precautionary steps against new cyber hazards.

title: Wearable Ultrasound Sensing with Dual Arrays and Machine Learning for Real-Time Tremor Characterization and Antagonist Muscle Monitoring_supp1-3654713.pdf
authors: Xiaoning Jiang
publish: N/A
abstract: Precise and time-efficient sensing of tremor dynamics is essential for developing personalized, adaptive stimulation strategies for movement disorders such as Parkinson’s Disease (PD) and Essential Tremor (ET). Existing modalities—such as inertial measurement units (IMUs) and surface electromyography (EMG)—lack muscle specificity and are prone to stimulation artifacts. To address these limitations, we fabricated and applied a Wearable Ultrasound Sensing (WUS) system, featuring dual flexible 64- element transducer arrays with center frequency of 6 MHz conformed over the flexor carpi radialis (FCR) and extensor carpi radialis (ECR) muscles for simultaneous antagonist muscle monitoring. A machine learning (ML) pipeline was introduced to estimate tissue displacement (TD) from raw ultrasound signals. Across three participants and multiple trials, the WUS system achieved tremor frequency detection within 10 %variation relative to commercial B-mode and IMU sensors, and met statistical equivalence thresholds based on two one-sided test (TOST) analysis. The TD estimation models demonstrated high predictive accuracy, with overall Pearson correlation coefficients between predicted and actual values ranging from 0.88 to 0.97, normalized RMSE values below 10 %, and offline model building times under 800 seconds. Compared to classical B-mode speckle tracking, the proposed WUS-ML pipeline reduced offline model building time by 75 % (from 3095 sec to 792 sec). In real-time performance tests, it reduced frame-level latency from 3700 ms to 17 ms and achieved effective processing rates exceeding 50 Hz, well above the Nyquist threshold for tremor analysis. These results demonstrate the feasibility of dual-array wearable ultrasound for accurate, low-latency tremor tracking and lay the groundwork for future closed-loop afferent stimulation systems in both clinical and at-home environments.

title: QRPL: Q-learning-based Routing Protocol for Low-power and Lossy IoT Networks
authors: Badis Djamaa, Mustapha Reda Senouci, Issam Eddine Lakhlaf, Abbas Bradai, Walid Moussaoui, Yacine Moussaoui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) refers to the interconnection of numerous computationally, memory, communication, and energy-constrained objects over the Internet and local communication technologies by leveraging unicast and multicast routing solutions. These device and network limitations have resulted in several challenges for IoT routing protocols, leading to the standardization of RPL; the Routing Protocol for Low-power and Lossy Networks (LLNs). Nonetheless, while RPL addresses some hardware and software limitations, its decisions still rely on basic hand-crafted algorithms. The recent success of machine learning in several domains has motivated us to consider intelligent algorithms based on Reinforcement Learning (RL) as a solution to this problem. Therefore, we contribute in this paper three Q-learning-based algorithms for intelligent information dissemination and routing in IoT networks, named SMART, TRAP, and TRAST. SMART focuses on the intelligent suppression of unnecessary messages, TRAP dynamically adapts communication intervals to the network's needs, and TRAST combines the two. These proposals have been integrated into RPL, evaluated through extensive simulations on dedicated IoT platforms, and validated via real experiments on the publicly available large-scale IoT-Lab testbed. The obtained results demonstrate the performance of our solutions compared to the state of the art in terms of energy consumption, load balancing, and end-to-end delay.

title: The Next Generation of Internet of Robotic Things (IoRT): Leveraging 6G for Intelligence, Connectivity, and Scalability
authors: Djallel Eddine Boubiche, Sabrina Boubiche, Abdellah Chehri, Gwanggil Jeon
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Magazine
abstract: The Internet of Robotic Things (IoRT) envisions a network of intelligent, autonomous robots collaboratively sensing, analyzing, and interacting with their environments. However, existing wireless infrastructures fall short of supporting the stringent demands for ultra-reliable, low-latency, and high-density connectivity required by these systems. This paper explores how sixth-generation networks can overcome these limitations and transform the IoRT landscape. It presents a comprehensive analysis of 6G’s core enabling technologies and examines how they enhance robotic coordination, scalability, and real-time decision-making. A conceptual 6G-enabled IoRT architecture is proposed to illustrate this convergence, supported by simulation results demonstrating latency, reliability, and energy-efficiency gains. The paper also discusses major research challenges, including interoperability, distributed intelligence, and cybersecurity, and outlines future directions toward developing scalable, resilient, and context-aware robotic ecosystems powered by 6G connectivity.

title: Integrating DWT and Bayesian Neural Networks for Effective Bearing Fault Detection with Uncertainty Evaluation in Induction Machines
authors: Johnny Rengifo, Reynaldo A. García A., Jose M. Aller
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Proper maintenance of Induction Machines (IM) is essential to ensure suitable performance, extend their service lifespan, and minimize the risk of catastrophic failures. Bearing failures are the most common failure mode in induction machines reported in industrial applications, and vibration signal monitoring has become an effective technique for their detection. However, accurate interpretation of these signals requires high expertise to differentiate between normal and faulty operating conditions. In this context, supervised artificial intelligence algorithms have emerged as promising tools for pattern classification in vibration signals. This study presents an innovative approach that integrates the energy levels of Discrete Wavelet Transform coefficients as inputs to train two classification models, a Fully Connected Neural Network (FCNN) and a Bayesian Neural Network (BNN), together with the uncertainty assessment of the inferences. The BNN, in particular, allows for the quantification of epistemic uncertainty, providing a measure of confidence in the predictions. The FCNN architectures were optimized using a random search algorithm in Python, while the BNN parameters were tuned through variational inference with normal distributions for the weights. Results demonstrated high accuracy performance, but the BNN model shows the lowest epistemic and aleatory uncertainty compared to the FCNN method. The results prove the ability to use BNNm models with high confidence in diagnostic and condition monitoring for IM applications.
