title: Efficient Meta-Heuristic Approach for the Multi-Objective Green p-Hub Centre Routing Problem_supp1-3410517.pdf
authors: Tarik Aouam
publish: N/A
abstract: The design of responsive and green networks necessarily entails the optimisation of multiple conflicting objectives with strategic, tactical, or operational decisions. This paper addresses a bi-objective green p-hub centre routing problem with hub location-allocation decisions and vehicle routing decisions. In their respective routes, vehicles may only travel using one selected speed between each node pair. The objectives are the minimisation of the worst service time and the environmental costs incurred during the transportation of all necessary demand flows, respectively. Since the studied problem is NP-hard, a meta-heuristic approach based on the non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm-II meta-heuristic is proposed. Additionally, min-max location and sequential allocation-routing method is developed to generate initial solutions. Furthermore, problemspecific crossover and mutation operators are implemented to efficiently explore the search space. Whereas, a novel rankbased speed selection procedure is devised to determine the appropriate travel speeds for generated off-springs based on their relative ranks in current population. Computational experiments are performed on the Australian Post (AP) dataset, and results indicate that our proposed heuristic approach provides good solutions in competitive CPU times. Finally, a discussion on the obtained Pareto frontier approximations is offered, and analysis is conducted on the effects of key decision parameters such as the number of located hub nodes, and the number of vehicles available at open hubs.

title: Management of Agri-Product Supply Chain Cycle Using Blockchain Technology
authors: Dipti Khobragade, Urmila Shrawankar, Anand Shakya
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: Product safety and traceability have become increasingly important issues worldwide. To tackle challenges in the agri-product sector from a technical standpoint, it is essential to have a reliable traceability system. Such a System should be capable of tracking and monitoring the whole lifecycle of product production, with raw cultivation or breeding, processing, transportation, warehousing, and retail distribution. We propose a trusted, selfmanazing, open, and ecological product traceability system built by blockchain technology. Blockchain, kind a form of distributed ledger technology (DLT), shows data immutable and enhances asset traceability. It is characteristics can greatly improve conventional agri-product supply chains by increasing transparency and building consumer trust in the products they purchase and their origins. Unlike processed goods, agricultural raw products typically do not come with expiry dates. To estimate their edible lifespan, we leverage blockchain technology. The current literature lacks a comparative analysis of both the benefits and limitations of blockchain applications in the agriproduct sector. Therefore, this study introduces a combination of big data and blockchain technologies, incorporating Geographic Information System (GIS) tools for precise location tracking. To boost system efficiency, we integrate Internet of Things (IoT) devices such as RFID tags, which automate data collection and verification, minimizing human involvement. The study may aims to address existing gaps by examining the current state of blockchain applications in agriculture, particularly in the context of product traceability. We review key contributions from existing research and explore how blockchain technology can help solve traceability challenges. Consumer demand for higher quality agricultural products has grown considerably. The proposed system combines blockchain technology with IoT and big data approaches. Overall, blockchain offers a highly promising path for enhancing product traceability, though further effort is needed to support its full adoption and development.

title: Message from Registrar: ICNSoC 2025
authors: P M V Rao
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: It is with great honour and a profound sense of responsibility that I extend a warm welcome to all participants of the Second International Conference on Networks & Soft Computing (ICNSoC 2025). This conference is a proud reflection of our institution's steadfast commitment to academic excellence, interdisciplinary research, and global engagement.

title: A novel trivariate joint model approach considering recurrent events for remaining useful life prediction of hydraulic systems
authors: Jingyi Zhang, Xinbo Qian, Xinyuan Chen, Wentao Li, Yanjun Sun, Jiajie Zhang, Yan Lu, Baojia Chen
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Hydraulic systems are repairable systems widely used in industry. Accurately predicting their remaining useful life (RUL) is critical to ensuring efficient and safe production. Most existing RUL prediction methods for repairable systems rarely consider degradation variability and failure heterogeneity among components of the same type across systems simultaneously. To address this problem, a trivariate joint model approach for the RUL prediction is proposed, which fuses system condition monitoring data, recurrent event data, and failure event data. Firstly, the system condition monitoring results are analyzed to identify multi-stage condition monitoring indicators; recurrent events and failure events are identified based on the multi-stage monitoring results and by utilizing maintenance threshold and failure threshold. Secondly, trivariate joint models with different association structures are constructed, considering various characteristic function forms of condition monitoring data. Finally, the trivariate joint model with the optimal association structure is identified, and its prediction performance is evaluated. In order to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method, the solenoid valve full life test platform is established and a case is conducted by using the collected full life dataset. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: AI-Enhanced GDPR Compliance in IoT Using Blockchain-Based Glass Box Security Framework
authors: K. Rajkumar, Samarjith Harihar, Santhosh Periyanayagam
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The sheer growth of Internet of Things (IoT) systems poses monumental challenges in safeguarding personal data and enforcing regulations like the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). The major concern lies in the lack of transparency and explainability in the existing black-box security models, which makes it difficult to prove compliance and secure user rights. To address this issue, the project suggests an Artificial Intelligence-Enhanced Glass Box Security Guard (GBSG) framework that would promote GDPR compliance in IoT settings by employing mechanisms that are transparent, auditable, and accountable. The policy-based access control, automatic check for compliance, logging, and auditing are integrated in this solution for maintaining GDPR ideals while also supporting user rights in terms of access, correction, and deletion of the data. The solution uses MATLAB simulations and is tested using the NSL-KDD dataset and allows real-time monitoring and tracking, anomaly identification, and compliance enforcements. The novelty in this approach is the replacement of the obscure black-box models by a glass-box framework wherein explainability and compliance validation coexist and bridge IoT functionality and legal privacy obligations.

title: Efficient Communication in UAV Swarm Network Using ESP-32 Wi-Fi Mesh
authors: Jaswanth Viswanadhapalli, Praveen Kumar Devulapalli, Md. Muzammil Ansari, O. Reshwanth
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) swarms are increasingly important for establishing adaptive and versatile wireless communications infrastructure, especially in scenarios where traditional infrastructure is not present or damaged. UAV swarms employ autonomous mobility as well as dynamic line-of-sight (LoS) communication link establishment for enhanced coverage, dependability, and versatility. Most existing UAV swarm communication topologies, however, are based on centralized coordination schemes, which place significant constraints like high communication latency, vulnerability to single points of failure, and inefficient energy waste through centralized control overhead. This project suggests a new, fully decentralized communication topology for UAV swarms, based on the ESP32-based microcontroller platform and the capabilities of Wi-Fi mesh networking. Based on the ESP-NOW protocol, the system enables direct, low-latency peer-to-peer communication by UAV nodes without any centralized access point or infrastructure. Our solution includes significant features including dynamic peer discovery for node mobility adaptation, efficient multi-hop routing for optimal communication paths, real-time hop-count monitoring for network diagnosis, and accurate monitoring of latency for on-time data delivery. Under extensive experimental testing, e.g., under different node mobility and failure scenarios, the system is shown to exhibit stable and consistent performance with zero communication delay. These findings confirm the system's feasibility in mission-critical applications with fault-tolerant, infrastructure-less communication-such as search and rescue, environmental monitoring, disaster relief, and remote surveillance-where timely and fault-tolerant data exchange in UAV swarms is essential.

title: Stochastic Kriging-assisted Controlled Random Search for Simulation Optimization and Its Application to Critical Dimension Measurement
authors: Hyungjin Kim, Aerim Hwang, Shing Chih Tsai, Chuljin Park
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: We consider an optimization problem with continuous variables, where the objective function must be evaluated via simulation. Our interests specifically focus on the situation where limited simulation observations (e.g., one or two) at each solution vector can be obtained, even though each observation includes random noise. To solve the problem, one may employ existing surrogate-assisted algorithms that typically update their surrogate models whenever a new observation is obtained. However, this updating process can face challenges such as out-of-memory issues, high computational costs, or imbalanced data due to excessive exploitation. In this study, we introduce a new algorithm called Stochastic Kriging-assisted Controlled Random Search (SKCRS). At each iteration, it employs a controlled random search to sample multiple vectors and uses a stochastic kriging model to select the most promising candidate solution vector from those sampled vectors. If the model fails to provide useful information to identify a suitable solution vector, the algorithm defaults to functioning as the original controlled random search without using the model. We tested our algorithm and compared it with existing algorithms using numerical functions and a case study in semiconductor manufacturing. The results demonstrate that our algorithm empirically outperforms existing algorithms regarding computational efficiency and estimation accuracy.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Based Dataset Optimization to Strengthen Malware Classification Frameworks
authors: Bhagwant Singh, Kuldeep Singh Sidhu, Shivangi Nigam
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Malware detection has become increasingly challenging due to the growing volume, diversity, and complexity of malicious software. While recent studies have focused primarily on developing advanced classification models, the impact of systematic dataset optimization has received comparatively less attention. This study investigates the role of dataset preprocessing in improving malware classification performance across heterogeneous malware domains. A unified preprocessing pipeline is proposed that integrates class balancing, feature normalization, and supervised feature selection. Specifically, Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) is employed to address class imbalance, Min–Max normalization is applied to stabilize feature scales, and a Genetic Algorithm–based feature selection strategy is used to identify discriminative feature subsets. The proposed pipeline is evaluated using multiple benchmark malware datasets covering network traffic, executable files, Android applications, and memory forensics. Experimental results demonstrate that systematic dataset optimization leads to consistent performance improvements while significantly reducing feature dimensionality across different classifiers. Comparative analysis with standard feature selection methods and an automated machine learning baseline further highlights the effectiveness of the proposed approach. The study emphasizes the importance of preprocessing in malware detection pipelines and identifies zero-day detection and real-time deployment as directions for future work.

title: AgriSight-Net: A Deep EfficientNetV2-Driven Framework for Multi-Class Pest Recognition with Error-Level Analysis and Explainable Grad-CAM Insights
authors: Tanupriya Choudhary, Bhupesh Dewangan, Ritu Agarwal, Ashutosh Sharma, Sampurna Roy
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Early and accurate identification of agricultural pests is essential for preventing large-scale crop damage and reducing excessive reliance on chemical pesticides. This paper presents AgriSight-Net, a robust and scalable deep learning framework for multi-class pest image classification using the EfficientNetV2-L architecture. The pipeline suggested also incorporates a holistic collection of modules which consists of automated preprocessing data, massive image enhancement, and reproducible training controls, in order to efficiently cope with image variability within the real-world. We use the Error-Level Analysis (ELA) to identify artefacts and the Grad-CAM to visualize the activations of discriminative regions that the model uses to make predictions (and thereby to ensure dataset integrity and to improve interpretability). AgriSight-Net, which was conditioned on 12-classes and more than 4,000 pest images, attains a test accuracy of 87.90% and high levels of precision, recall, and F1-score in most classes. The intensive mapping of confusion matrices and analytics-based on classes is not only used to show the power of the system, but also shows the edge cases where similar species visually speaking are used. Fusing ELA with explainable AI will enable the enhancement of the transparency and the rise of confidence in the predictions of the model. The results demonstrate the potential of AgriSightNet as a sustainable, intelligent pest monitoring solution capable of supporting modern precision agriculture and minimizing ecological impact.

title: Early Warning System for Engine Failure Detection in Aircraft Engines Using Machine Learning
authors: Albin Biju, Smrity Prasad, S Kalaivani
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Aviation has a problem with engine defects which are a major concern. Unforeseen causes might render them expensive on the ground and hazardous in the air. We present a system that signals when an aircraft engine is about to fail. Our AdvancedModelTrainer checks a collection of models—Random Forest, XGBoost, Gradient Boosting, LightGBM, Ridge, Lasso, ElasticNet, and a simple neural network—through a dataset of 10,000 engine cycles along with 25 engineered features. Hyperparameter tuning and Remaining Useful Life (RUL) metrics help to select the top two (Gradient Boosting and XGBoost, RMSE 39.99, $R^{2}=0.7715$). A complete MLOps structure keeps an eye on the drift, initiates the retraining process, and sets up dashboards that are user-friendly for the mechanics. The system has detected on 1,433 new engines, 1,126 were classified as Safe, 106 as Warning, and 201 as Critical, which is indicating the coverage of 93.44The dataset used was completely anonymized in order to safeguard sensitive operational data and to not conflict with the aviation data privacy regulations.

title: A RIS-Aided OTFS Communication System with Fractional Doppler Shift Suppression for V2X
authors: Ke Mei, Caijuan Chen, Wenhao Yan, Chaofeng Zhang, Jia Hou
publish: 2025 IEEE Conference on Cloud and Big Data Computing (CBDCom)
abstract: In 6G Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) scenarios, the severe Doppler effect is a major challenge, exacerbated by the increasing number and speed of vehicles. Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation, a core technology against this effect, still suffers from Fractional Doppler Shift (FDS), causing an error floor at high Signal-to-Noise Ratios (SNRs). Furthermore, existing Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS) optimization, focused on signal enhancement, fails to suppress the dominant FDS interference in this regime. To address this, we propose an optimization framework that Maximizes the Target Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (MTSINR). Our framework is the first to explicitly incorporate interference leakage into the objective function, shifting the optimization paradigm from “signal enhancement” to “interference suppression”. The RIS is optimized to reshape the channel, coherently combining the target signal while destructively combining adjacent interference. Simulations validate that our scheme suppresses Inter-Doppler Interference, eliminates the error floor, and enhances system reliability without increasing OTFS frame length, proving its suitability for latency-constrained V2X systems.

title: Review on spin-wave RF applications
authors: Khrystyna O. Levchenko, Kristýna Davídková, Jan Mikkelsen, Andrii V. Chumak
publish: IEEE Transactions on Magnetics
abstract: This review explores the development of spin-wave technology, highlighting magnonics as a promising route for radio frequency (RF) communication systems. The rollout of 5G and the upcoming 6G networks intensifies the demand for devices that can operate at higher frequencies while remaining scalable, compact, and energy-efficient—requirements that spin waves are well suited to meet. The first two sections revisit the fundamentals of magnonics, trace major milestones in spin-wave research, and summarize recent advances in materials and device design. The third section reviews RF applications studied over the past 50 years, with emphasis on key passive components, such as filters, limiters, delay lines, phase shifters, and directional couplers. The final section discusses both the advantages and the open challenges of spin-wave devices, including insertion loss, linearity, and power handling, together with the strategies to address them. By linking fundamental insights with technological needs, this review outlines a path toward practical RF platforms. Spin-wave-based devices, with their scalability, versatility, and potential for low-power operation, hold strong promise for future wireless communication, particularly in the 5G and 6G era.

title: Stabilization and Disturbance Rejection of Uncertain Ball & Beam System using Robust LQR-I Controller
authors: Anjali Rai, Bharat Bhushan, Bhavnesh Jaint
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Understanding uncertainties and restrictions in the model parameters is necessary for accurate modeling and performance analysis of control systems. This paper investigates the robust stabilization of a Ball and Beam system subject to uncertainty. Initially, the unstable non-linear system model is stabilized using a Linear Quadratic Regulator controller with a small integral action (LQR-I). Subsequently, uncertainty is introduced in the form of variations in the ball mass to evaluate the controller's robustness. The performance of the LQR-I controller is determined under 10, 20, and 30 percent deviations in mass, focusing on its ability to maintain ball position and minimize its positional deflection. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the LQR-I controller in preserving system performance despite significant parameter variations, highlighting its potential for robust control of uncertain nonlinear systems.

title: The GREEN Way to Net Zero: AI-Enabled Agents for Sustainability and Innovation Management
authors: Magnus Penker, Soo Beng Khoh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Achieving Net Zero by 2050 is one of the most pressing challenges of our time. Many organisations struggle to move beyond environmental, social, and governance (ESG) compliance towards embedding sustainability as the way of doing business in the future. This paper introduces a novel, AI-enabled 5-Step G.R.E.E.N. Framework designed to guide organisations from sustainability intent to measurable impact. It demonstrates how sustainability-oriented innovation projects can naturally evolve into a comprehensive innovation management system that is ISO 56001 compatible. The incorporation of agentic artificial intelligence (AI) for innovation management, sustainability science, and systems thinking was demonstrated using two AI agents, namely Agent360 and GREEN Agent. These AI agents enable continuous guidance, benchmarking, and ideation support, helping organisations accelerate their sustainability transformation and innovation outcomes. Together, they demonstrate how the fusion of structured frameworks and intelligent agents can catalyse purpose-driven innovation and unlock strategic pathways to a decarbonised future.

title: Design of High-Accuracy Angular Velocity Estimation for Autonomous Vehicles Using DOVETAIL
authors: P D Justin Climend Raj, V Ravi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Accurate estimation of angular velocity in threedimensional (3D) space is critical for enhancing the performance of Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) in modern navigation and geospatial applications. This study proposes a novel framework for angular velocity prediction from GPS measurements by integrating machine learning techniques with a 3D computational algorithm. The approach begins by converting latitude, longitude, and altitude into Cartesian coordinates using the DOVETAIL transformation, providing a robust geometric foundation for deriving angular velocity. The initial angular velocity values computed from the DOVETAIL-based coordinate system are subsequently refined using a machine learning model designed to adapt dynamically to varying navigational conditions. By utilizing features such as position, velocity, and temporal information, the model learns system behavior in real time, thereby improving the accuracy, stability, and reliability of angular velocity estimation.

title: A 220-GHz On-Chip Mixer Circuit Using Microstrip Lines and GaAs SBD
authors: Xiaolin Hao, Guodong Gu, Xiangyang Zhao, Caixia Wang, Lisen Zhang, Xubo Song, Peng Xu, Zhongbo Zhu, Ao Zhang, Jianjun Gao, Cui Yu, Yuanjie Lv, Zhihong Feng
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents a 220-GHz subharmonic mixer based on a fully planar, waveguide-free circuit that uses only microstrip lines and a GaAs Schottky barrier diode (SBD) for enhanced integration capability. A key novelty is the adoption of a custom-designed coupled-line structure to replace traditional waveguide-based hybrids, which achieves effective signal combining and isolation between the local oscillator (LO) and radio frequency (RF) ports <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-chip. Measured at room temperature, the mixer exhibits a single-sideband (SSB) conversion loss (CL) of less than 11 dB from 204 to 228 GHz, with a minimum of 8 dB at 220 GHz. The isolation between the RF signal and the second harmonic of the LO signal is greater than 25 dB. This work demonstrates a compact and low-cost solution for terahertz integrated systems.

title: Adaptive Beamforming of Smart Antenna Array for Space-Time Signal Processing with GA-PSO Using Novel Adaptive Equalizer on Rayleighfading Channels
authors: G. Senthil Kumar, Dorsela Venkata Rami Reddy, Raja GV, Thresia Michael, Yadavalli S S Sriramam, A. Ananda Kumar, Ajay Sudhir Bale
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: In the current landscape, the wireless sector is witnessing a substantial surge in demand for enhanced capacity and high-speed data services. The rising number of users primarily fuels this increase and the growing volume of traffic, which is a result of a significant shift in technology aimed at supporting Internet applications. This shift is largely attributed to the escalating importance of Broadband Wireless Access (BWA). The 2.40GHz licensed frequency band supports a diverse array of application, while the 5850 to 5925MHz band is specifically allocated for automotive radar uses. Within the electromagnetic field, smart antenna arrays are becoming increasingly popular due to their ability to assign high capacity by dynamically managing intrusion in real-time scenarios, such as those encountered in automotive movement and aerodynamics. This is achieved through the adjustment of weights, separations, and phase settings. Furthermore, these arrays hold promise for various spatial signal processing applications, including direction of arrival (DOA) estimation, adaptive beam forming, and a range of digital signal processing (DSP) tasks. A cutting-edge hybrid genetic algorithm, referred to as the Hybrid Lamarckian-Baldwinian System is tested and shown to be effective in solution of practical problems. Moreover, a new equalization method designed to reduce multipath effects in Rayleigh fading environments has been investigated, showing benefits over traditional minimum mean square error (MMSE) and zero forcing equalization methods. The ability to modify the radiation patterns-covering aspects such as side lobes, beam width, main beam direction, nulls-will be a focal point of research for many years.

title: Comparative Bioinspired Optimization for Delay-Compensated SMC in Dominant Dead-Time Systems
authors: Marco Herrera, Omar Aguirre, Diego S. Benítez, Noel Pérez-Pérez, Oscar Camacho, Alvaro Prado
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This work aims to develop and evaluate a tuning methodology for a Smith Predictor-based Sliding Mode Controller (SMC) optimized with five bioinspired algorithms to improve robustness and performance in time-delay systems under uncertainty. The central hypothesis is that combining the predictive capabilities of the Smith Predictor with the robustness of SMC and the optimization power of bioinspired algorithms can produce a controller that maintains high performance. Experimental tests on the TCLab platform, which add significant delays, confirm this. The results show that the proposed strategy effectively manages reference changes, outperforming traditional tuning methods. The main contributions include integrating intelligent optimization with robust predictive control and validating the methodology in a real-time delayed process.

title: NeuroSubNet: Graph Attention-Driven fMRI Modelling for Autism Spectrum Disorder Classification and Subtype Discovery
authors: Swadha Joshi, Aniruddha Gondkar, Chaitali Hadkar, Shanvi Jakkan, Swati Shilaskar
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: It has always been challenging to utilize resting-state fMRI for early diagnosis of autism because ASD involves an interlinked set of dimensions, with connectome data offering thousands of dimensions to process. We present NeuroSubNet, a deep learning model based on a graph attention ideas that aims to tackle both, ASD detection at an early stage and its subclassification as well. NeuroSubNet creates a brain graph with each participant’s ABIDE rs-fMRI scan by treating each of the ROIs as nodes, and using their correlation as weighted links. A series of multi-head Graph Attention Network learn images of ROIs as they relate to each other temporally, while also adjacently focusing on ROIs during the application as it outlines the rows that appear meaningful. The resulting latent representations are clustered to see the fitted representations with a Gaussian Mixture Model to see if the ASD subtype are identifiable. Across the 823 ABIDE participants, NeuroSubNet attains an accuracy of 86.25%, which is more than GCN, CNN, and SVM baseline models. These subtypes differ in cognitive, behavioral, severity and age of the person with ASD and then it aligns it with ADOS and SRS measures, offering an interpretable route to ASD profiling..

title: Field Analysis and Treatment of the Problem of Sudden Abnormal Sound of Plasma Rectifier Dry-Type Transformer in a Power Plant
authors: Jiaju Wang, Xiaoxuan Tian, Yanjun Zhang, Weiyu Jing, Zhen Yan, Xinyuan Hu
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: During the no-load hot standby of a plasma rectifier dry-type transformer in a power plant, the noise of the transformer suddenly changed with a heavy “hum” sound as high as 98dB. No obvious “crackling” discharge sound was found with the aid of auscultation monitoring, and no corona or sparks were found when observed in the dark. The transformer was shut down for inspection, and it was found that the fasteners of the transformer were not loose. Measure the transformer winding insulation and DC resistance, and the iron core is insulated from the ground, and the test results are normal. After the insulation professionals arrived at the site, they inspected and comprehensively analyzed various conditions during operation and during shutdown. Finally, it was determined that the rectifier dry-type transformer ferromagnetic resonance occurred in the public I-section system, and the harmonic resonance was the factor that caused the increase of abnormal sound. At the same time, relevant suggestions are given to provide experience for dealing with similar incidents.

title: NeuroStack: A Agentic AI Platform for Enterprise
authors: Kanav Kahol, Navid Kalantari, Mir Ali
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: NeuroStack is a general-purpose agentic AI platform designed to enable enterprise-scale multi-agent systems with advanced reasoning, memory, and orchestration capabilities. It addresses limitations of monolithic large language model (LLM) agents by introducing a modular eight-layer architecture that spans from cloud infrastructure up to operations and governance. Each layer encapsulates a key concern (from networking and communication protocols to tooling, cognitive reasoning, longterm memory, user interaction, and oversight), providing a structured foundation for building autonomous AI “agent societies.” The need for such an architecture is motivated by current LLM wrappers' shortcomings in memory, tool-use, and governance. An illustrative use case in code conversion demonstrates how multiple specialized agents can collaborate using NeuroStack to perform complex tasks (e.g. code translation and verification) that single agents handle poorly.
