title: Preg-Fit: An Essential Fitness Band for Pregnant Women
authors: Giridhar Urkude, Kashyap Rathod, Manjusha Nambiar PV, Shweta Kharya
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: The changing and delicate nature of pregnancy calls for an approach to continuously monitor the health of both the baby and the mother. The current standard practices, which mainly rely on clinic visits, fail to provide timely and essential data for proactive healthcare management. Most existing wearable devices are designed with a fitness focus, neglecting the needs related to physiology and activity during pregnancy. The presented study introduces an IoT-based health monitor that operates on low power and utilizes the ESP32 microcontroller's capabilities. The device includes a high-quality pulse sensor for monitoring heart rate and maternal and fetal well-being gauge. An accelerometer monitors activity levels, offering insights into complications or changes in daily activities. An OLED screen makes Real-time data display possible, giving mothers instant feedback on their health status. This design can incorporate emergency notification features as needed. In certain situations, future versions could integrate communication modules to send health data or alerts to specified contacts, e.g., spouses or healthcare providers. Taking this proactive stance nurtures a healthcare system focused on patients, which allows for identifying dangers, supports prompt actions, and ultimately protects the well-being of both mother and baby. This initiative advances health monitoring tools and sets the stage for tailored and thorough pregnancy care.

title: Surface Electromyography-Based Muscle Fatigue Assessment During Hand Grasping Exercises
authors: Hiba Hellara, Sawsan Njeh, Aseel Afaneh, Olfa Kanoun
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The accurate assessment of muscle fatigue is important for sports, rehabilitation, and ergonomics. In this study we investigate the potential of employ surface electromyography (sEMG) to monitor muscle fatigue during static and dynamic grasping exercises. Based on the signals from eight sEMG sensors and by extracting fatigue-sensitive features, muscle activity patterns were analyzed, and fatigue was classified into three states: Non-fatigue, fatigue, and extreme fatigue. The dimensionality of the data has been reduced by Principal Component Analysis (PCA). By k-means clustering, an unsupervised categorization of the fatigue states has been carried out. The classification has been carried out by a Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifier and an exceptional accuracy could be achieved with 99.84% for the training data set and 99.58% for the validation data set. These results demonstrate the potential of sEMG signals and machine learning techniques to effectively assess muscle fatigue and provide important input to decisions in rehabilitation strategies.

title: Blood Pressure Monitoring and Assisting System to Support Pregnant Women at High-Risk for Preeclampsia
authors: Ahmad Fais Fison, Noor Azurati Ahmad, Yusnaidi Md Yusof, Amira Anisa Rahman Putra, Azizul Azizan, Ansariadi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Preeclampsia is a complex pregnancy condition characterized by high blood pressure, often leading to damage to organs and tissues. Early detection and management of preeclampsia significantly reduce the risk of serious complications including seizures, liver failure and heart disease in both mother and baby. This paper aimed to provide tracking of blood pressure levels in high-risk pregnant women. The solution serves as a valuable tool in supporting pregnant women at high-risk for preeclampsia, enabling early detection and effective management of the condition. Using K-fold cross-validation, the proposed model achieved clinically acceptable prediction accuracy, with systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) values estimated within an average error margin of approximately 0.414 mmHg (MAE) and a validation loss of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{0. 5 4 4}$</tex> (MSE) for ResNet50, compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{0. 4 1 9 ~ m m H g}$</tex> (MAE) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{0. 5 4 2}$</tex> (MSE) for EfficientNetB0. The results indicate that ResNet50 achieved slightly better prediction accuracy in terms of mean absolute error, suggesting that its deeper residual connections capture more discriminative features, whereas EfficientNetB0 achieved a marginally lower overall validation loss, due to its compound scaling and stronger regularization. Both models, however, yielded negative <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> values (-0.291 for ResNet50 and -0.309 for EfficientNetB0), indicating poor variance explanation and performance below a naive baseline. The novelty of this study resides in its end-to-end integration of a CNN-based blood pressure estimation algorithm with a mobile application specifically built for preeclampsia support. Unlike existing remote blood pressure monitoring techniques that rely on wearable equipment or human input, this system offers non-contact, camera-based assessment with typical smartphones while including clinical context.

title: Deepmyco: Large Language Models for Scaling Mycoremediation
authors: Danika Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: The textile industry is a major contributor to global water pollution, with dye effluent comprising up to 20% of water pollution. This research introduces a novel approach that integrates machine learning with mycoremediation to enable scalable, low-cost dye decontamination. We developed the first public dataset of mycoremediation results by extracting data from over 2,900 research papers using large language models. From this, we built algorithmic models to recommend robust fungal strains and forecast remediation efficacy over time. Experimental validation using Trametes versicolor demonstrated successful decolorization under varied real-world conditions and confirmed predictive accuracy (Root Mean Square Error as low as 0.03). A followup hydroponic trial showed healthy plant growth in remediated water, supporting the method's biological safety. This research bridges AI and experimental science, offering an open-source, replicable solution to industrial dye pollution and a foundation for further innovation in bioremediation at scale.

title: A Blockchain Based Architecture for Scalable and Secure Cross-Border Payments
authors: Mohit Singh Bisht, Shreya Das, Danish, Shubhiksha
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This research explores the integration of cryptocurrency- based payment gateways with cross-border financial systems. With increasing global demand for fast, transparent, and low-cost transactions, cryptocurrency offers a viable alternative to traditional remittance and banking solutions. This paper analyzes some of the existing frameworks, determines technical and regulatory hurdles and puts forth an improved gateway system which beacons blockchain technology for bi-Iateral payment in secure and veritable world. This paper provides a rigorous assessment of the state-of-the-art cryptocurrency payment gateway frameworks and their deployment in the context of international business combinations. The former focuses on the underlying technologies - such as public-key cryptography and digital signatures, and distributed ledgers the latter uncovers the regulatory, technical and security roadblocks that prevent their mainstream adoption. Moreover, the research suggests an improved architecture of cryptocurrency payment gateway system based on being scalable, compliance oriented and interoperable with current financial infrastructures. Through the use of novel blockchain protocol stack and authentication mechanisms, the proposed model aims to fill this gap between the digital assets and global payment networks paving the way for more equitable and frictionless fin tech environment.

title: AIGC-Driven Shape Design of Fitness Devices for the Elderly Under Positive Meaningful Experience
authors: Yi Wang, Siru Pan, Xuanming Feng
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Intelligent Design (ICID)
abstract: At present, with the emergence of the concept of healthy aging and related policies, the design of fitness equipment for the elderly needs to strike a balance between functional effectiveness and emotional value. “Positive meaning design” is very crucial for enhancing the user participation of the elderly when using fitness equipment. However, traditional design methods have some problems It is affected by the slow speed of creative iteration and inconsistency with user needs, which hinders the effective realization of positive significance in the design. To address this issue, this paper introduces generative artificial intelligence technology to explore its enabling role in the positive design of fitness equipment for the elderly. Based on the physiological characteristics, psychological needs, and usage scenarios of elderly users, this paper constructs an integrated framework of “demand - technology - design”. Then, use AIGC tools to quickly generate design plans. During this process, focus on the three core dimensions of positive significance, namely emotional interaction, safety adaptation, and value perception improvement. By paying attention to these three dimensions, drive the continuous iteration and improvement of the design plan.

title: Rule-Based Moral Principles for Explaining Uncertainty in Natural Language Generation
authors: Zahra Atf, Peter R. Lewis
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: As large language models (LLMs) are increasingly used in high-stakes applications, the challenge of explaining uncertainty in natural language generation has become both a technical and moral imperative. Traditional approaches rely on probabilistic methods that are often opaque, difficult to interpret, and misaligned with human expectations of transparency and accountability. In response to these limitations, this paper introduces a novel framework based on rule-based moral principles-simple, human-inspired ethical guidelines-for responding to uncertainty in LLM-generated text. Drawing on insights from experimental moral psychology and virtue ethics, we define a set of symbolic behavioral rules such as precaution, deference, and responsibility to guide system responses under conditions of epistemic or aleatoric uncertainty. These rules are implemented declaratively and are designed to generate adaptive, context-sensitive explanations even in the absence of precise confidence metrics. The moral principles are encoded as symbolic rules within a lightweight Prolog-based engine, where each uncertainty tag (low, medium, high) activates an ethically aligned system action along with an automatically generated, plain-language rationale. We evaluate the framework through scenario-based simulations that benchmark rule coverage, assess fairness implications, and analyze trust calibration. An interpretive explanation module is integrated to reveal both the assigned uncertainty level and its underlying justification in a transparent and accessible way. We illustrate the framework through hypothetical yet plausible use cases in clinical and legal domains, demonstrating how rule-based moral reasoning can enhance user trust, promote fairness, and improve the interpretability of AIgenerated language. By offering a lightweight, philosophically grounded alternative to probabilistic uncertainty modeling, our approach paves the way for more ethical, human-aligned, and socially responsible natural language generation.

title: Exploring the Inverted Classroom Strategy Using PCA for Dimensionality Reduction in Educational Data
authors: Doris Chicaiza, Mariana Moposita, René Barragán, Patricio Sailema
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: In the context of secondary education, the search for innovative strategies that promote autonomous learning has become a priority, especially in subjects like Chemistry, where conceptual understanding poses a challenge. However, limitations persist in the implementation of active methodologies that strengthen student autonomy while simultaneously being evaluated using rigorous analytical tools. Faced with this problem, the current research analyzes the flipped classroom strategy as a teaching methodology, applying data mining and dimensionality reduction techniques, specifically Principal Component Analysis (PCA), to identify significant patterns in student perceptions. The study was conducted with a non-probabilistic sample of 108 high school students, using a Likert scale-based questionnaire. The validity and reliability of the instrument were verified using Cronbach's Alpha coefficient, obtaining a value of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha=0.89$</tex>, which indicates high internal consistency. Subsequently, PCA was employed to reduce data complexity, and the Pearson correlation coefficient was applied to analyze the relationship between the methodology, didactic strategies, and student autonomy. The results show a strong positive correlation between the implementation of the flipped classroom and the development of skills such as leadership, self-management, collaborative work, and learning orientation. It is concluded that the combination of the flipped classroom with analytical techniques like PCA not only optimizes the evaluation of pedagogical strategies but also promotes more autonomous and effective learning processes.

title: Text Localization and Script Recognition Across Various Multimedia Formats
authors: Prachi Chhabra, Geeta Singh, Shivam Chauhan, Nitesh Kumar, Manan Rohilla, Vibhuti Kapoor
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: This paper presents an end-to-end pipeline leveraging YOLOv7 for text localization, CNN for script identification, and CRNN for text recognition, tailored specifically for bilingual documents (English and Hindi) in image-based formats. The approach combines preprocessing, multi-script classification, and sequential recognition, optimized for real-world scenarios with varying layouts and noise levels. The system achieves over 85% accuracy on benchmark datasets, demonstrating its reliability in complex multilingual environments. Applications include bilingual document digitization, automated translation, and assistive technologies for the visually impaired.

title: AI-Driven Cryptographic Techniques for Securing IoT Communications
authors: Abhishek Kumar, Varun Tiwari, Shristi Gupta
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has transformed industries by enabling inter-device connectivity. However, IoT systems face major security challenges due to heterogeneous architectures and limited device resources. Traditional cryptographic methods often lack the efficiency required for such constrained environments. This paper presents an AI-driven cryptographic frame-work that leverages machine learning (ML) and deep learning for real-time threat detection, encryption, and key management. These adaptive models improve response capabilities while optimizing performance. Integrating AI into cryptographic functions improves security and reduces energy consumption - crucial for battery-limited IoT devices. The simulation results show that AI-based methods outperform traditional approaches in both robustness and efficiency. The proposed framework provides a scalable solution for future IoT systems and contributes to developing secure AI-enhanced communication protocols.

title: Comparative Analysis of Deep Learning Models for Cyberbullying Detection Across Social Platforms
authors: Stefania Bello, Vincenzo Gattulli, Alessia Monaco
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: This research focuses on the use of deep learning models for the automated identification of harmful and offensive remarks in online environments, with a particular emphasis on cyberbullying. The main objective is to leverage data from various social media platforms to evaluate the effectiveness of different methods in categorizing violent comments. The study will analyze both the linguistic and behavioral features of these remarks to determine which deep learning architecture delivers the best performance for detection. Moreover, the research explores the hypothesis that, despite the unique characteristics of each interaction, cyberbullying may exhibit similar patterns across different social media platforms. By examining the issue in diverse contexts, it is possible to identify recurring patterns in aggressive online behavior, offering a deeper understanding of the nature of cyberbullying in the digital space. With BERT outperforming all other models across the datasets evaluated, the deep learning models exhibited a remarkable ability to detect cyberbullying.

title: Research on the Application of Time Series Prediction Based on LSTM Neural Networks
authors: Yichen Qiao, Xinyu Hou, Tao Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This study investigates the application of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks in time series prediction, aiming to improve prediction accuracy for simulated time series data and explore the effectiveness of LSTM networks in handling stochastic time series. By constructing a synthetic dataset that simulates seasonal variations and random noise, an empirical analysis of the proposed LSTM model was conducted. The results demonstrate that the model achieves low Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) on both the training and testing datasets, indicating excellent prediction accuracy and generalization capability. Furthermore, the paper proposes future research directions, including the integration of multi-source data and the incorporation of attention mechanisms to enhance prediction accuracy and model interpretability. This study provides novel perspectives and methodologies for time series analysis and holds significant value for decision-making support in related fields.

title: Optimising Quantum Calculations Reliability via Machine Learning: The IBM Case Study
authors: Zakaria Abdelmoiz Dahi, Francisco Chicano, Gabriel Luque, Iván Delgado Alba
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: The current quantum technology depends on hardware/time-dependent features that render quantum calculations highly error-prone. Having faulty calculations generally requires redoing them, which induces an economic/computational overhead by using quantum machines/simulators. This can be problematic due to unaffordable fees, machine unavailability, or loss of quantum advantage. An alternative can be performing the calculations when the machines are in their most suitable state. This work presents a pipeline based on Machine Learning (ML), allowing users to choose the appropriate moment to perform a given computation based on the estimation of the JensenShannon divergence between the noisy and ideal distributions of quantum sampling. This includes (I) an extract-transform-load data module, (II) an ML unit for quantum features forecasting and error prediction, and (III) a web-based visualisation unit. The pipeline was built/tested using 3.5 months of calibration data from three real 127-qubit IBM quantum machines. The results confirmed the applicability of the proposal in realistic scenarios.

title: On the Origin of AI Species
authors: Scott Davidson
publish: IEEE Design & Test

title: Simulation-Based Analysis of an IoT-Enabled Dynamic Tolling System for Intelligent Urban Traffic Management
authors: Victor A. Pelchor-Espinoza, Jorge O. Ordonez-Ordonez, Mónica Huerta, Luis F. Guerrero-Vásquez, Paul A. Chasi-Pesantez
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Urban traffic congestion is an increasing global concern with serious socioeconomic and environmental implications. Traditional toll systems, based on static pricing and physical toll booths, are insufficient to manage dynamic traffic conditions and often exacerbate congestion during peak hours. This paper proposes an IoT-enabled dynamic tolling system designed to adjust rates in real time based on vehicle density and traffic flow, aiming to improve road efficiency. The system architecture relies on traffic data collected from virtual sensors integrated within a SUMO (Simulation of Urban Mobility) environment, managed via the TraCI interface. Through a digital twin model, various tolling strategies are simulated under different traffic scenarios, and their impact on vehicle performance, waiting times, and emissions is analyzed. The results demonstrate that dynamic tolling significantly reduces congestion levels compared to static pricing schemes, validating the effectiveness of the proposed system. This study provides a replicable simulation framework for evaluating intelligent transportation policies prior to realworld implementation.

title: A Space-Vector-Modulation Scheme to Reduce Leakage Current in Soft-Switching Three-Phase Transformerless Inverters
authors: Yuying Wu, Zheng Chen, Chunxu Zhang, Yousu Yao, Shun-Peng Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: When the soft-switching three-phase inverter is applied in transformerless photovoltaic (PV) systems, its common-mode (CM) leakage current has to be suppressed to satisfy grid codes. However, conventional zero-voltage-switching space-vector-modulation (ZVS-SVM) adopted for the inverter produces high common-mode voltage during its operation. In this article, a modified ZVS-SVM scheme is proposed to reduce the CM voltage (CMV) generated by the inverter. Circuit working principles under the proposed scheme are illustrated. Besides, CM behavior and performance of the proposed method are compared with the traditional method. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by simulation and experiments.

title: Blood Cancer Detection with Explainable AI Using Deep Learning
authors: M. Arivukarasi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: This study presents an explainable AIbased deep learning model for blood cancer detection that integrates convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for feature extraction, applies knowledge transfer to leverage prior learning, and combines these with Llama to enhance diagnostic transparency and support healthcare professionals.

title: Direct Torque Control of Five Phase Induction Motor Using Batch Normalization Based TSK Fuzzy Controllers
authors: T. Murali Krishna, Ch. Rambabu, Manam Ravindra, P. Ram Kishore Kumar Reddy, Aditya Agnihotri, N. Kalyana Sundaram, G. Indira Rani, Kandi Bhanu Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: The growing interest in Five Phase Induction Motors (FPIMs) can be attributed to their diverse range of applications, which encompass electric vehicles, advanced compressor systems, and marine propulsion, among others. Among many available drive control systems, Direct Torque Control Method (DTCM) is a powerful strategy to regulate speed, torque and flux within permissible limits of induction motors. However, conventional DTCMs are failed to regulate flux and speed in smoothly under drastically changes in the system due to not regulating flux with any controllers. Hence, the reference flux is obtained through a controller in proposed methodology presented in this paper. Moreover, conventional PI/PID controller cannot produce accurate output due to its fixed gains, hence TSK-Fuzzy controllers are used in this paper. Two TSK Fuzzy controllers are employed in the proposed DTCM where one is to produce reference torque and other is for reference flux. Additionally, the space vector pulse width modulation (SVPWM) technique is employed to generate the appropriate pulse sequence for a five leg inverter used in motor drive applications. A detailed design of TSK Fuzzy controller is also incorporated in this paper. In order to make speed sensorless controller, mathematical modeling is included to estimate speed of the motor to avoid physical sensor. Hardware - in the - Loop (HIL) technique is implemented on OPAL-RT platform to present various results similar to real time responses.

title: Research on Deep Reinforcement Learning Based Adaptive Job-Shop Scheduling
authors: Mengying Zhou, Kaifang Wan, Jiahui Fei, Bo Li, Yongling Fan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: This paper addresses the NP-hard nature of the Job Shop Scheduling Problem (JSSP) by proposing a deep reinforcement learning approach based on the Schlably framework. The method integrates Deep Q-Network (DQN) with a normalized processing time mapping rule, employing an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\epsilon$</tex> -greedy strategy to balance exploration and exploitation while incorporating an action masking mechanism to ensure scheduling feasibility. With the objective of minimizing total tardiness, experimental results on LA06-LA10 benchmark instances demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms classical rules like SPT in reducing total tardiness, validating the superiority of deep reinforcement learning in complex scheduling scenarios.

title: Measuring Environmental Sustainability of Industrial Machinery: From Energy Consumption to Avoidable Emissions
authors: Leopoldo Angrisani, Mauro D'Arco, Egidio De Benedetto, Luigi Duraccio, Immacolata Esposito, Annarita Tedesco
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The concept of sustainability is increasingly central as industries strive to quantify and mitigate their environmental impact. This work presents a metrology-based method for measuring the environmental impact of industrial machinery. The proposed approach is structured in three steps. The first involves the creation of a checklist identifying the relevant components of the machinery to be considered for environmental impact evaluation. The second step entails the individual measurement of the environmental impact associated with each identified component. The third step aggregates these measurements to derive an overall assessment of the machinery's environmental impact. A key feature of the method is its ability to decouple the environmental impact attributable to the machine's operational phase from that associated with the idle phase, during which the machine is powered on but not actively used. As a case study, the method was applied to an industrial press. The results demonstrate that the proposed approach enables a reliable estimation of avoidable emissions linked to idle energy consumption, providing valuable insights for sustainability-oriented process optimization.

title: Multi-Sensor Fusion Based on Sequential Minimum Error Entropy RFS Filtering with Non-Gaussian Noise
authors: Huan Chen, Changyu Yi, Minzhe Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a multi-sensor fusion method based on error entropy optimization for target positioning and tracking. Error entropy approximates the unknown noise distribution characteristics caused by random outliers, non-Gaussian noise, etc., thereby improving the accuracy of fusion tracking. During the fusion process, the system calculates the error entropy value of each sensor observation data in real time to measure the uncertainty of measurement and estimation, thereby adaptively adjusting the noise error covariance matrix in the filtering process to avoid interference from outliers or unreliable data on target state estimation. The method proposed in this paper breaks through the a priori assumptions of noise distribution in traditional algorithms, uses error entropy to approximate unknown noise characteristics from the data level, and builds an adaptive fusion mechanism without a clear noise model. Moreover, a sequential random finite set filtering (RFS) fusion method based on error entropy is proposed, and an iterative solution method is given. This method can still maintain high-precision target positioning and tracking in the face of random outliers and non-ideal observation conditions. By combining error entropy with the filtering framework, this method can effectively deal with the dynamic changes of random noise and enhance the tracking performance of the system in complex environments.

title: An Approach for Cross-Project Defect Prediction Using Composite Distribution Alignment and Domain-Adversarial Neural Networks
authors: Dipender Singh, Sandeep Kumar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Reliability
abstract: Cross-project defect prediction (CPDP) is an important task in software engineering, where data from external projects is used to identify defect-prone modules in a target project that lacks sufficient historical information. However, CPDP remains challenging due to substantial distributional disparities between source and target projects. Many existing methods fail to select appropriate source data for a given target project, which hinders knowledge transfer and degrades predictive performance. To address this challenge, we propose CDA-DANN, a novel framework that combines compatible source project selection with domain-adversarial learning. It introduces a composite similarity metric that jointly captures structural relationships, measured by the Frobenius norm of feature correlation matrices, and distributional divergence, quantified using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. This composite similarity metric guides the selection of the source project that is most compatible with the target. The selected data is subsequently used to train a domain-adversarial neural network (DANN) augmented with a gradient reversal layer, which facilitates the learning of domain-invariant features to improve generalization across projects. We conduct comprehensive experiments on 22 widely used software projects. The results show that CDA-DANN consistently outperforms state-of-the-art CPDP methods, achieving improvements in AUC ranging from 5.48% to 11.59%, and in MCC from 20% to 57.89%. These findings highlight the effectiveness of combining source selection with adversarial feature alignment in achieving reliable and transferable cross-project defect prediction.

title: A Study on a Nationality Classification Model Using Korean Name Embedding and Its Applications
authors: Ju Hwan, Seo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: This study presents an artificial intelligencebased nationality classification model using English-transcribed Korean names and explores its applicability to monitoring researcher mobility. Author information was extracted from the SCOPUS database, and Korean names were segmented into syllables to construct a “Korean Name Embedding” using Sentence-BERT (sBERT). A co-occurrence network analysis revealed clusters of Korean names showing more than 5% similarity with names from other Asian countries (e.g., China, Taiwan, Malaysia). The dataset was subsequently used to finetune an sBERT-based baseline model for nationality classification. Evaluation was conducted on 1,005 author names extracted from the Web of Science (WoS) database. The proposed model achieved 89.6% accuracy, substantially outperforming the open-source name2nat package (75.9%) and a tf-idf + logistic regression baseline (77.1%). The findings highlight the feasibility of using name-based embeddings for automated monitoring of researcher inflows and outflows, which are essential for national innovation capacity assessment. Limitations remain due to the globalization of Korean names and potential misclassification risks. Future work will integrate auxiliary features such as institutional affiliation and country of birth into multimodal frameworks.

title: Network Traffic Reduction Through AI-Assisted Local Data Optimization of Synthetic Data
authors: Matthias Rüb, Jens Grüber, Hans D. Schotten
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Information and Communications Technology (ICOIACT)
abstract: In future wireless networks, AI instances are expected to take on autonomous tasks increasingly. In this context, the availability of high-quality synthetic data is becoming more important, as AI-agents in different domains, such as healthcare and natural language processing (NLP) will be expected to run safety and stability tests without the need for real data. Synthetic data is also useful for clinical practitioners to address imbalances in datasets or to augment existing data. However, this increased demand for datasets places an additional burden on the communication infrastructure, adding to the existing traffic. T his n ot o nly impacts t he performance o f t he network but also negatively affects sustainability. In this work addresses these issues by introducing a new paradigm, which shifts away from transmitting entire datasets and focuses on local data generation and optimization instead. While this approach has been desirable for a long time, recent developments in artificial intelligence (AI), particularly in NLP, have made it now feasible by empowering end-users without technical expertise to perform data optimization. As an exemplary use case, this work demonstrates a large language model (LLM) curated data optimization using synthetic smart insole gait data. Several low-weight LLMs are tasked to assist the curation. It is shown that local light-weight models, which can be deployed even with low-cost clinical IT infrastructure, can support non-experts with the local optimization process of otherwise insufficient synthetic data.

title: Deep Learning-Powered Cybersecurity Solutions to Lower Industrial Internet of Things Threats: Risk Prevention Techniques and Agricultural Case Studies
authors: Shanmugam Muthu, Arokia Suresh Kumar Joseph
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Agriculture is just one of several industries that has been profoundly impacted by the IIoT’s ability to facilitate data-driven decision-making, real-time monitoring, and improved operational efficiency. But, systems are vulnerable to a variety of cyber threats, such as illegal access, data breaches, and service interruptions, due to the rapid integration of IIoT devices, which also provides substantial cybersecurity risks. The goal of this project is to improve cybersecurity for industrial internet of things (IIoT) devices in agricultural settings by creating and deploying solutions powered by deep learning. The study aspires to enhance threat detection and response mechanisms, therefore providing a solid defense against growing cyber threats, by utilizing advanced neural network designs. The proposed cybersecurity solutions examine massive volumes of data produced by IIoT devices in agricultural settings using deep learning techniques like CNNs and RNNs. We train these algorithms on attack data from the past and regular operational trends so that we may detect anomalies and forecast security breaches in realtime. The goal of this research is to build a proactive cybersecurity framework that can see attacks and make the system more resilient by combining these deep learning models with current security solutions. With an emphasis on agricultural case studies, this research demonstrates the real-world applications of deep learning in securing essential IIoT components such as smart sensors, drones, and automated machinery. When compared to more conventional security measures, early results show that deep learning solutions considerably improve threat detection accuracy while decreasing false positives. Furthermore, the study reveals critical risk avoidance strategies that agricultural businesses may implement to protect their IIoT systems from cybercriminals. This report offers useful insights into the development of effective risk management strategies by producing a thorough overview of the challenges and opportunities related to IIoT cybersecurity in agriculture. Stakeholders can use the conclusions as a roadmap to build strong cybersecurity safeguards that protect the availability, integrity, and security of IIoT systems in agriculture.

title: Enhancing Sensors Accuracy for Deploying Precision Agriculture in the Field
authors: Francesco Saccani, Danilo Pau, Michele Amoretti, Stefano Caselli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Sensor drift, caused by environmental and operational stresses, is a significant issue that impacts several domains. In agriculture, it is particularly relevant during irrigation, fertilization, and climate monitoring, ultimately affecting crop yield and quality. This paper adopts a deep edge-centric approach, minimizing reliance on cloud and non-deep edge platforms to improve data privacy, reduce latency and power consumption, and support real-time decision-making. This strategy involves designing lightweight, resource-efficient algorithms that operate on energy -constrained and low -cost deep edge devices, such as the sensors which are essential components to serve metrology purposes. The work is focused on devising on-(ultra tiny)device learning techniques, enabling continuous adaptation to changing conditions while meeting strict power consumption requirements such as the sensor's one. A key contribution is the TinyRBF model, a deeply constrained dynamic Radial Basis Function network tailored for edge devices. TinyRBF addresses the limitations of existing on-device learning methods by balancing prediction accuracy with memory and computational efficiency. Experimental results collected in a challenging agricultural testbed demonstrate its low resource usage and robust performance, making it a scalable solution for real-world applications.

title: FDM-3DGS: Frequency-Domain and Mask Guided 3D Gaussian Splatting for Deblurring 3D Reconstruction
authors: Yuan Sun, Wenhua Qian
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: 3D Gaussian Splatting, as a next-generation explicit 3D representation paradigm, has emerged as a significant technical pathway for 3D reconstruction in recent years, owing to its highly efficient parallel rendering capabilities. However, existing research indicates that the performance advantages of 3DGS heavily depend on high-quality input images and precise point cloud initialization. In scenarios with low-quality observation data (e.g., motion blur, noise interference), the discrete nature of explicit representations makes the model prone to overfitting observational noise. In such cases, the rendering quality of 3DGS may degrade to levels even worse than the baseline performance of NeRF, significantly limiting its application potential under complex imaging conditions. To address these challenges, this chapter proposes a deblurring 3D Gaussian Splatting framework that integrates frequency-domain information and a masking mechanism. The framework constructs a Transformer-based frequency-domain attention network to extract and discriminate effective frequency-domain features, focusing on refining blurred regions. Additionally, a masking mechanism is introduced to fuse pixel information from blurred and non-blurred regions, enabling fast and clear deblurring for 3D reconstruction. Experimental results demonstrate that our method not only enhances scene rendering efficiency but also effectively removes scene blur, achieving state-of-the-art performance.

title: CCGT Operational Optimization: Component-Based vs Configuration-Based Modeling Performance in Uncongested Networks
authors: María Paz Ramírez Atencio, Mauro A. Gonzalez-Sierra
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study presents a comparative analysis of two modeling paradigms for Combined Cycle Gas Turbines (CCGT) in power dispatch optimization: configuration-based versus component-based approaches. Motivated by the increasing integration of Variable Energy Resources (VERs) and demanding operational flexibility requirements, accurate CCGT modeling becomes critical for modern power systems seeking optimal economic dispatch. Both models are evaluated regarding operational constraints representation, computational efficiency, and dispatch accuracy under uncongested network scenarios. The methodology encompasses detailed Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP) formulations, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 4}$</tex>-hour dispatch optimization with demand ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$280-650 \text{MW}$</tex>, and empirical validation using operational data from Termocandelaria S.A. E.S.P. Results demonstrate that while configuration-based models offer computational efficiency, component-based models provide superior granular control achieving 2.7% operational cost reduction <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\$ 22,920$</tex> USD daily savings) through enhanced dispatch accuracy. Statistical validation confirms componentbased superiority with improved CCGT efficiency (59.2% vs 56.8%) and 99.8% nodal power balance accuracy, with future research addressing network congestion scenarios. This work provides validated recommendations for Independent System Operators (ISOs) in Colombia and Latin America's evolving energy landscape.

title: Human Centered Design in 3D Character Modeling with Ethical Framework for AI
authors: Ferric Limano
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: This study aims to develop a framework for creating 3D character modeling using AI, while considering ethical principles in digital design practices. The approach centres on a human-centred design process, which is broken down into three key stages: inspiration, ideation, and implementation. This issue has become urgent due to widespread debates on social media, particularly concerning the rise of AI and its potential threat to the creative industry. An ethical framework for AI must emphasise the following principles: utilitarianism—focused on the consideration of pleasure or pain as consequences of actions; rights—the inherent rights of individuals and groups; and virtue—moral actions that shape one's character. These ethical foundations should guide humans before engaging in creative work using AI, to ensure that ethical boundaries in design are not violated. To arrive at the recommended framework, a project-based research method was employed in the creation of 3D character models. The creative process began with original character sketches, followed by style transformation into 3D rendered models using OpenAI ChatGPT. The prototyping phase utilised the AI-based tool Meshy, and the evaluation was conducted through the 3DS Max 3D Editor software. As a result, the study presents a recommendation for a Human-Centred Design approach in 3D Character Modeling.

title: Early and Differential Dengue Diagnosis Using Random Forest: A Case Study in Sucre, Colombia
authors: Jaider Caldera-Nadaff, Wilson Arrubla-Hoyos, Zurisaddai Severiche-Maury, Víctor Bautista-Naranjo, Humberto Marbello-Peña
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: Dengue is a rapidly spreading viral disease that represents a significant public health threat in tropical and subtropical regions. Colombia, and particularly the department of Sucre, has shown a notable increase in dengue cases in recent years. This study proposes a predictive model based on Machine Learning to assist in the early and differential diagnosis of dengue severity using real patient data. By applying the CRISP-DM methodology, the data were preprocessed, combined, and analyzed to train and evaluate various supervised learning models. The Random Forest algorithm achieved the best performance with an accuracy of 97.83%, demonstrating its potential as a support tool for timely diagnosis and management of dengue. The results highlight the relevance of data mining and machine learning techniques in enhancing healthcare strategies for disease control and prevention.

title: RevMine: An LLM-Assisted Tool for Code Review Mining and Analysis Across Git Platforms
authors: Samah Kansab, Francis Bordeleau, Ali Tizghadam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Empirical research on code review processes is increasingly central to understanding software quality and collaboration. However, collecting and analyzing review data remains a time-consuming and technically intensive task. Most researchers follow similar workflows-writing ad hoc scripts to extract, filter, and analyze review data from platforms like GitHub and GitLab. This paper introduces RevMine, a conceptual tool that streamlines the entire code review mining pipeline using large language models (LLMs). RevMine guides users through authentication, endpoint discovery, and natural language-driven data collection, significantly reducing the need for manual scripting. After retrieving review data, it supports both quantitative and qualitative analysis based on user-defined filters or LLM-inferred patterns. This poster outlines the tool's architecture, use cases, and research potential. By lowering the barrier to entry, RevMine aims to democratize code review mining and enable a broader range of empirical software engineering studies.

title: Enhancing Digital Image Processing with Energy-Efficient Posit Multipliers for VLSI based Quantum Computing Applications
authors: Saba Fatima, Kiruba M., P. Nisha, Pavithra G., Shashidhar V., T.C. Manjunath
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: In this research paper, some novel developments in the optimization of digital image processing efficiency by conducting a simulation study on modular posit multiplier architectures, design and improving the energy efficiency to boost computational performance of energy efficient posit multipliers is presented along with the simulation results. Their Posits numbers systems, an emerging alternatives to IEEE's floating points arithmetic, offers notable benefits in deep learning and image processing due to its ability to efficiently handle non-uniform data distributions. Posit arithmetic stands out for its flexibility, especially in situations where the usual floating-point formats just don't cut it. But while Posits are powerful, their different bit-widths can make hardware implementation-particularly for multipliers-a real headache..

title: Exploratory Modeling Strategies for Robust Medical Condition Classification Using Machine Learning
authors: Paromita Sadhu, Arpit Rastogi, Ayush Sinha, Darshini R
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Machine learning has great opportunities in early detection of diseases and better patient health treatment. This paper provides a predictive model of medical conditions based on a Kaggle healthcare dataset of demographic, clinical and lifestyle variables. The most important health indicators are age, glucose level, blood pressure, BMI, oxygen saturation, cholesterol, triglycerides, HbA1c, and behavioral indicators, including smoking, alcohol use, and physical exercises. Logistic Regression, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Decision Tree, and Random Forest were four classification models that were considered to determine the most effective model. Accuracy, F1-Score, and ROCAUC were the model performance metrics. The accuracy of the Logistic Regression was 91.37%, Decision Tree $\mathbf{8 4. 1 6 \%}$, Random Forest $\mathbf{9 1. 6 3 \%}$ and KNN 81.53\%. The results of ROC-AUC showed a great predictive ability in all models and Logistic Regression and KNN had AUC values exceeding 0.95 in most conditions of significance. Random Forest also presented AUC values over 0.95 in all disorders of significance and especially difficult to classify multi-class disorders, like cancer, diabetes and asthma. The results suggest that ensemble-based approaches could be effective in comparison with traditional classifiers, in dealing with non-linear and high-variance healthcare data. All in all, the suggested predictive models have high potential regarding clinical decision support and preventive healthcare use.

title: Real-Time Hand Gesture Recognition System with User Identification for Industrial Applications
authors: Marco Esposito, Sara Raggiunto, Luisiana Sabbatini, Alberto Belli, Sara Bruschi, Lorenzo Palma, Emanuele Storti, Stefano Rossini, Paola Pierleoni
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Human-Machine interaction plays a pivotal role in contemporary industrial and civil environments. Among other sensing technologies, Leap Motion Controller is a non-contact and reliable one to be used for gesture recognition. In this paper, a dataset composed of more than two thousand samples is presented. The data have been collected by 17 subjects performing multiple repetitions of 26 gestures based on the Italian sign language alphabet. The “LEAP-SDGest: Leap Motion static & dynamic gestures” dataset can be adopted for the development of algorithms for both gesture recognition and user identification, for example, in industrial control applications. An architecture leveraging the MQTT protocol is proposed for this purpose, embedding gesture recognition and access control by exploiting classifier models and MQTT topics structure. In order to validate the dataset and proposed methodology, Machine Learning and Deep Learning models for both control tasks were developed. After a preliminary analysis, the Multi-Layer Perceptron proved to be the best solution and was optimized through grid-search. The resulting models reached 91.6% accuracy for user recognition and 97% accuracy on gesture recognition through very lightweight models and reduced pre-processing. Under strong authentication conditions, an end-to-end success rate of 91% was achieved for the entire system that includes access control and user recognition.

title: Design of Heat Supply Network Balance Control System Based on Multi-Level Hierarchical Intelligent Model
authors: Qi Jinsheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: At present, the central heating system mostly adopts the quantity regulation method, but due to the mutual coupling and flow interference between the branches of the secondary pipe network, it is easy to cause the hydraulic imbalance of the pipe network and the large deviation of the heating temperature. This paper focuses on the heat supply network balance system based on the user side temperature control, adopts the multilevel hierarchical intelligent mode to conduct decoupling analysis on the system, deeply analyzes its unique architecture and operation mechanism, takes the user side temperature as the key feedback. It can realize the precise heat supply network balance regulation, provide new ideas for the refined and intelligent development of the heating field, and help to improve the heating quality and energy efficiency.

title: A Hybrid Machine Learning and Large Language Model Framework for Real-Time DDos Detection and Mitigation With Explainability
authors: Aditya Kumar Shukla, Ashish Sharma
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks remain a persistent threat to network infrastructure, particularly in cloud-native, IoT, and SDN environments. While traditional machine learning (ML) models offer fast and lightweight classification of anomalous traffic, they often lack transparency and actionable guidance for mitigation. In this research, we propose a novel hybrid architecture that combines the efficiency of traditional ML models (e.g., Random Forest) for real-time DDoS detection with the interpretability of Large Language Models (LLMs) for attack summarization and automated rule generation. The ML part identifies traffic using flow-level characteristics derived from the NetFlow and NSL-KDD data sets, whereas LLMs provide natural language explanations of detected risks and provide mitigation rules suited for fire-wall or SDN-Controllers. We test our approach on the NSL-KDD and CIC-DDoS2019 data-sets(Standard data-set for training and testing DDoS attacks), attaining 96.2% detection accuracy with Random Forest and showing that LLMs can generate consistent, humanaligned interpretations with over 91 % accuracy in rule development. This design strikes a compromise between detection speed and explanation, making it ideal for use in operational security situations. Our findings show that integrating conceptual ML detection and LLM-driven insights can considerably improve the reliability, interpretability, and reactivity of contemporary DDoS defensive solution.

title: Prototype of a Predictive System for Selecting Therapeutic Pets in Patients with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
authors: Chaira Mileth Zapa Caraballo, Gabriela Isabel Hernández Mejía, Sebastián Alfonso Sierra Torres, Maria Angelica Garcia Medina, Claudia Lengua Cantero, David de Jesus Acosta Meza, Carmen Molinares Brito, Lety Anet Garcia Medina
publish: 2025 IEEE Colombian Caribbean Conference (C3)
abstract: This study explores the therapeutic care of adolescents with Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) through the integration of animal-assisted therapy (AAT) and predictive technological tools. The main psychological and behavioral traits of ADHD are identified, highlighting the potential of AAT to strengthen self-regulation, attention, and motivation in this population. As part of this innovation, PetMatcher was developed, an artificial intelligencebased application aimed at optimizing the matching between patients and therapeutic animals, considering clinical, emotional, and individual preference variables. To train and validate the predictive model, a synthetic dataset of 200 simulated cases was generated. The results obtained demonstrate the positive impact of AAT and the usefulness of the application as a support for personalized interventions. This work proposes an innovative solution that integrates science, technology, and human sensitivity to improve ADHD care.

title: Computer Malware Infections & their Prevention on Computer Users by AI Inspired Algorithm
authors: Anshu, Keerthika J, G. Raghavendra, Gotte Ranjith Kumar, Shailendra Singh Sikarwar, Deep Biswas
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: The goal of the study is to investigate the effects of a computer virus attack and to outline the steps that people may take to safeguard their personal computers (PCs) against such assaults. In an increasingly digital and interconnected world, it is essential to discuss the dangers of computer viruses and the measures that may be taken to protect against them among users of personal computers. We applied various machine learning algorithms to detect malware or dangerous threats. A high detection ratio meant that the most accurate algorithm had been chosen to be used within the system. One benefit of the confusion matrix was that it quantified the quantity of false positives and false negatives, which gave more insight into how effectively the system performed. Specifically, it was shown that the results of malware analysis and detection with machine learning algorithms to compute the difference in correlation symmetry integrals could be used to detect harmful traffic on computer systems, thereby improving the security of computer networks. The findings demonstrated that DT (98%), CNN (92.76%), and SVM (93.41%) performed well in terms of detection accuracy when compared to other classifiers. In a specific dataset, the malware detection performances of the DT, CNN, and SVM algorithms on a modest FPR (DT = 2.01%, CNN = 3.97%, and SVM = 4.63%) were examined. These findings are noteworthy since harmful software is growing more prevalent and sophisticated.

title: Enhancing Adaptive Sports Participation for Students with Disabilities Through Virtual Reality Kayaking Simulations
authors: Mario Covarrubias, Emma Mencaci, Marco Tarabini, Carlalberto Francia, Manuela Galli
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) technologies have shown significant promise in expanding access to sports participation for individuals with disabilities. This paper introduces a comprehensive VR-based kayaking simulation designed to provide students with special needs, particularly those from the ASPOC association (ages 18-24), with an engaging, inclusive, and adaptive sports experience. The primary objective is to address barriers to physical activity—ranging from environmental and social to cognitive and motor limitations—by delivering an accessible virtual environment that supports real-time interaction and feedback. The simulator incorporates hand tracking, haptic feedback, adaptive difficulty levels, and integration with a physical ergometer to simulate realistic paddling dynamics. A novel element of this study is the introduction of a virtual coach powered by the Captury Live markerless motion tracking system, offering real-time, personalized guidance without requiring wearable sensors. Through a structured user study, the system's impact on user engagement, usability, physical exertion, and immersion is assessed. Results suggest the system's potential in promoting motivation, reducing social isolation, and supporting rehabilitation objectives. This paper outlines the design framework, technical implementation, and experimental findings, highlighting the role of immersive Extended Reality (XR) tools in fostering inclusive sporting opportunities.

title: Cutting is All You Need: Execution of Large-Scale Quantum Neural Networks on Limited-Qubit Devices
authors: Alberto Marchisio, Emman Sychiuco, Muhammad Kashif, Muhammad Shafique
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: The rapid advancement in Quantum Computing, particularly through Noisy-Intermediate Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices, has spurred significant interest in Quantum Machine Learning (QML) applications. Despite their potential, fully-quantum algorithms remain impractical due to the limitations of current NISQ devices. Hybrid quantum-classical neural networks (HQNNs) have emerged as a viable alternative, leveraging both quantum and classical computations to enhance machine learning capabilities. However, the constrained resources of NISQ devices, particularly the limited number of qubits, pose significant challenges for executing large-scale quantum circuits. This work addresses these current challenges by proposing a novel and practical methodology for quantum circuit cutting of HQNNs, allowing large quantum circuits to be executed on limited-qubit NISQ devices. Our approach not only preserves the accuracy of the original circuits but also supports the training of quantum parameters across all subcircuits, which is crucial for the learning process in HQNNs. We propose a cutting methodology for HQNNs that employs a greedy algorithm for identifying efficient cutting points, and the implementation of trainable subcircuits, all designed to maximize the utility of NISQ devices in HQNNs. The findings suggest that quantum circuit cutting is a promising technique for advancing QML on current quantum hardware, since the cut circuit achieves comparable accuracy and much lower qubit requirements than the original circuit. The code is available at https://github.com/eBrain4Everyone/QNN-Cutting.

title: A Dual-Band Filtering Antenna With Large Frequency Ratio Based on Mode-Composite Suspended Coplanar Waveguide
authors: Jian-Kang Xiao, Wei Zhao, Xu-Min Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: A mode composite suspended coplanar waveguide (MCSCPW) is proposed, which is composed of a quasi-suspended coplanar waveguide (SCPW) and a suspended substrate integrated waveguide (SSIW). SSIW is formed by punching metallized via holes in the intermediate guide band of the SCPW and the corresponding metal strip. Meanwhile, MCSCPW can simultaneously transmit quasi-TEM mode and TE<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sub> mode at both high and low frequencies. To verify the advantages of the transmission line and the feasibility of its application, a dual-band filtering antenna with a high frequency ratio is proposed based on MCSCPW. The high- and low-frequency filtering antennas are, respectively, realized through the integration method and cascading design method. The proposed dual-band filtering antenna with high frequency ratio works at 5.03/34.4 GHz with a fractional bandwidth of 8.6%/2.9% and a maximum gain of 7.74/2.12 dBi, respectively, while implementing a frequency ratio of 6.84. It achieves favorable radiation and out-of-band suppression at both high and low frequencies.

title: FC-YOLO: Frequency-Coordinate Collaborative Network for Component Inspection in AOI Systems
authors: Zichao Geng, Xianqiang Yang, Hao Sun, Zhengkai Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Automatic Optical Inspection (AOI) systems are crucial for quality control in Surface Mount Technology (SMT). Their detection accuracy directly affects the yield and reliability of high-density Printed Circuit Boards (PCBs).However, existing methods still face typical industrial challenges, such as high false negative rates and inconsistent responses to similar components when detecting miniature elements. This paper addresses the specific requirements for PCB component detection in industrial AOI, particularly in scenarios involving small targets and densely parallel distributions. We propose an adaptive integration and optimization of existing frequency-domain and coordinate-aware methods, introducing a Frequency-Coordinate Collaborative Network (FC-YOLO). The model features a dual-branch detection framework, which processes image information in parallel across two dimensions. The coordinate branch uses the CPIE mechanism for high-frequency coordinate encoding, enhancing the model’s spatial invariance and fine detail perception, thereby improving the consistency of responses for parallel components. The frequency-domain branch introduces frequency-domain features and designs the FPDConv module, employing learnable differential convolution kernels to adaptively suppress frequency-domain noise and amplify key frequency components, thus improving detection performance for small targets. The features from both branches are efficiently fused via the FCFF module, and their synergistic effect enhances the detection accuracy and response consistency of miniature components. Experimental results on the public PCBWACV dataset and the self-constructed EAPCB dataset show that the proposed method achieves a 4.5% improvement in mAP50 and a 4.1% improvement in mAP50–95 compared to YOLO11. After deployment on an EAOI system with an RTX 4060Ti GPU, the system achieves real-time detection at 206 FPS. It outperforms existing methods in both false positive and false negative rates, showcasing its potential for engineering applications.

title: Comparative Analysis of Structure-From-Motion Underwater Point Cloud Processing Techniques for a Steep Mountain Creek
authors: Moritz Roth, Ianina Kopecki, Philipp Thumser, Nils Rüther
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Mapping underwater topography in mountain creeks with unmanned aerial systems (UAS) and SfM photogrammetry is challenging due to steep slopes, rough substrates, and complex refraction effects. This study investigates which bathymetric correction method - Simple or Multi-cam - provides the most reliable results for technical applications at different flight heights and camera angles. Four data sets (nadir, off-nadir, off-nadir-low, and mixed) were captured by manual flights at $30 \,\mathrm{m}\,{\mathrm{to}}\, 45 \,\mathrm{m}$ altitude and with camera angles up to $50 \,\mathrm{^{\circ }}$ and then analyzed for point density and bathymetric correction accuracy. Point densities ranged from 1400–4700 pts/m$^{2}$, with off-nadir-low having the highest densities at shallow apparent depth, although no consistent correlation was observed between apparent depth and point density. Limiting the refraction angle in the Multi-cam method significantly improved the bathymetric correction, with the nadir configuration ($\theta _{r}=30^\circ$) achieving the best performance (RMSE $0.15 \,\mathrm{m}$, MAE $0.12 \,\mathrm{m}$) and relative accuracy and precision ratios of $1 \,:$534 and $1 \,:$373, respectively. However, due to site-specific challenges, these metrics could not reach the previous benchmarks (relative accuracy in submerged areas $>$ $1 \,:$1000). The absence of a logical correlation between corrected depths and extreme off-nadir configurations suggests that Agisoft Metashape does not utilize all available aligned images for dense cloud generation. Future research should focus on identifying which images contribute to dense cloud generation to further improve accuracy. Theoretical analysis confirms that nadir flight configurations provide the most reliable results when the photogrammetry software lacks specific camera angle support.

title: An Experimental RIS-Assisted NOMA Network
authors: Lütfullah Özkan, Saliha Büyükçorak, Sefa Kayraklik, Ibrahim Hokelek, Ali Gorcin
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: Driven by the emerging capabilities of reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS), this paper presents the implementation and experimental evaluation of an RIS-assisted downlink multi-user non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) network. Two RIS configuration strategies are implemented and compared. The first is a partitioning-based approach, primarily adopted in many existing theoretical RIS-NOMA studies but lacking experimental validation, where each user is served by a distinct subset of RIS elements. The second is a proposed weighting-based approach, which leverages power-domain NOMA and successive interference cancellation (SIC) principles to iteratively maximize the weighted sum of the received signal powers, expressed in the dB domain, across all users according to their power allocation coefficients. The performance of both strategies is experimentally evaluated under real-time conditions in terms of bit error rate and further validated through Monte Carlo simulations. The results demonstrate that the proposed weighting-based approach achieves 8-9 dB power improvement and 1-2 dB performance gain over the partitioning-based approach at high signal-to-noise ratios.

title: VQPET: Leveraging Vector-quantized Codebook Prior for PET Image Synthesis
authors: Haowei Chen, Zhiwen Yang, Yang Zhou, Xiaoqian Zhang, Hui Zhang, Dan Zhao, Bingzheng Wei, Gang Zhou, Yan Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging
abstract: Positron emission tomography (PET) image synthesis is a highly ill-posed problem that requires auxiliary priors to 1) alleviate the loss of high-quality (HQ) information in low-quality (LQ) inputs, and 2) impose additional constraints to reduce mapping uncertainty. However, existing auxiliary priors in PET image synthesis often provide inadequate guidance due to inaccurate prior information or limited prior expressiveness. To overcome the aforementioned limitations, the vector-quantized (VQ) codebook prior is employed as a promising solution. By learning discrete latent feature representations of HQ images through deep models, the VQ codebook prior encompasses accurate HQ information and possesses great expressiveness. Building upon this, we propose a novel two-stage framework, VQPET, that introduces the VQ codebook prior for PET image synthesis. In the first stage, it pretrains a VQGAN on an additional large-scale HQ PET dataset, encoding intrinsic HQ features as code items in the VQ codebook. The VQ codebook prior is thus derived from the high-level features obtained from the pretrained VQGAN and serves as an additional constraint for downstream synthesis. In the second stage, it develops a codebook-prior-guided network (CPGNet) that effectively exploits the VQ codebook prior to produce realistic outputs. Specifically, CPGNet progressively incorporates the VQ codebook prior at multiple decoding levels, providing reliable guidance for HQ synthesis. Compared to previous works, VQPET innovatively leverages additional large-scale HQ datasets to transfer pretrained prior knowledge for enhanced synthesis and functions as a general framework applicable to any encoder-decoder network. Extensive experiments demonstrate the substantial effect and robust generalizability of VQPET.

title: On Differential and Boomerang Properties of a Class of Binomials over Finite Fields of Odd Characteristic
authors: Namhun Koo, Soonhak Kwon
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Theory
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the differential and boomerang properties of a class of binomial Fr,u(x) = xr(1 + uχ(x)) over the finite field Fpn, where r = pn+1/4 , pn ≡ 3 (mod 4), and χ(x) = x pn−1/2 is the quadratic character in Fpn. We show that Fr,±1 is locally-PN with boomerang uniformity 0 when pn ≡ 3 (mod 8). To the best of our knowledge, it is the second known non-PN function class with boomerang uniformity 0, and the first such example over odd characteristic fields with p > 3. Moreover, we show that Fr,±1 is locally-APN with boomerang uniformity at most 2 when pn ≡ 7 (mod 8). We also provide complete classifications of the differential and boomerang spectra of Fr,±1. Furthermore, we thoroughly investigate the differential uniformity of Fr,u for u ∈ F∗pn \{±1}.

title: Keeping Balance at Sea and Ashore: Investigating Habituation-Adaptation Dynamics in Postural Control Among Seafarers and Healthy Adults
authors: Federica Pescaglia, Lorena Guerrini, Carmine Gelormini, Ida Maruotto, Marco Recenti, Hannes Petersen, Halldór Jónsson, Paolo Gargiulo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Postural control (PC) is a crucial function influenced by both habituation and adaptation processes. The BioVRSea paradigm, a novel virtual reality-based approach, provides a comprehensive <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{P C}$</tex> assessment by exposing participants to visual and motor perturbations while measuring electromyographic and center of pressure responses. This study aims to compare the PC responses of sailors recently exposed to prolonged maritime conditions with those of a control group of healthy individuals, focusing on differences in adaptation and habituation strategies. Sailors demonstrated increased complexity and variability in postural sway and distinct neuromuscular activation patterns, suggesting functional adaptations to unstable environments. By highlighting these contrasts, the study seeks to understand better the impact of long-term sea exposure on balance regulation mechanisms. This paper demonstrated a significant difference in the habituation and adaptation phases between sailors and controls, with sailors exhibiting greater sway dynamics and complexity, as well as a distinct Soleus activation pattern indicative of efficient, burst-based motor strategies.

title: Model-Free Time-Delay Compensation Architecture for Leader-Follower CACC Systems
authors: Naoya Sato, Yuma Katsuki, Anan Sawabe, Yusuke Shinohara, Ryogo Kubo
publish: 2025 15th France-Japan &amp; 13th Europe-Asia Congress on Mechatronics (MECATRONICS) / 23rd International Conference on Research and Education in Mechatronics (REM)
abstract: Cooperative adaptive cruise control (CACC) is highly sensitive to communication delays. Conventional delay compensation methods presuppose accurate vehicle and delay modeling, resulting in significant performance degradation in environments with modeling errors. This study proposes a novel model-free delay compensation method for leaderfollower CACC systems utilizing rear inter-vehicle distance (IVD) measurements, front IVD measurements, and vehicle position measurements. The proposed approach introduces intentional feedback delays to cancel forward delays without requiring vehicle or delay models, making it robust against modeling errors. Simulations confirm that the proposed method achieves stable acceleration and IVD responses with or without modeling errors in vehicle dynamics, outperforming the Smith predictor in the presence of modeling errors.

title: A Glimpse on HCAI Frameworks: A Scoping Review to Adapt them to Mixed Reality
authors: Andrea Antonio Cantone, Alireza Mortezapour, Otino Pio Santosuosso, Aurelio Sepe, Simone Spera, Giuliana Vitiello
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: The convergence of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Mixed Reality (MR) is redefining the landscape of immersive technologies, enabling more adaptive, interactive, and intelligent user experiences. However, while AI continues to shape MR systems, critical human-centered dimensions such as transparency, user control, and ethical design are often overlooked. This scoping review investigates the current state of research at the inter-section of Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence (HCAI) and MR. Through a structured PRISMA-ScR methodology, several academic studies incorporating human-centered principles into artificial intelligence-driven MR systems have been identified, revealing a fragmented but promising landscape. In addition, non-academic design guidelines developed by major technology companies were also analyzed. The findings highlight a significant gap: existing HCAI frameworks were not conceived with MR in mind and thus fall short of addressing its unique demands, such as immersion, embodiment, and multimodal interaction. Drawing on reusable design patterns and ethical principles from both research and industry, this review lays the groundwork for a dedicated framework, HCAIMR, that can guide the development of immersive systems that are not only intelligent, but also transparent, inclusive, and truly human-centered.

title: Large Language Models Applications in Oil and Gas: Case Studies and Insights
authors: Shamsu Abdullahi, Umama, Kamaluddeen Usman Danyaro, Haruna Chiroma, Abubakar Zakari, Mujaheed Abdullahi, Shamsuddeen Hassan Muhammad, Noor Amila Wan Abdullah Zawawi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Sustainable Innovation (AI-SI)
abstract: Large-scale language models (LLMs) are becoming increasingly common in the oil industry, where they are being applied to tasks such as seismic data interpretation, reservoir analysis, and predictive maintenance. This study examines the current state of LLM applications in the sector and highlights recent advances, practical implementations, and domain-specific adaptations. Despite the promising developments, problems such as limited domain-specific data, hallucination risks, and interpretation problems continue to impede widespread adoption of LLMs in the sector. To address these problems, the study proposes effective research directions tailored to oil and gas, including aligning LLM deployment with operational needs and promoting cross-disciplinary collaboration. This review provides concise but comprehensive resources for researchers and industry professionals to promote LLM-driven oil and gas innovation.

title: Beyond Technical Transparency: Explainability as a Safeguard Against Manipulative AI*
authors: Ermanno Petrocchi, Simona Tiribelli, Berk Buzcu, Elia Pacioni, Davide Calvaresi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Metrology for eXtended Reality, Artificial Intelligence and Neural Engineering (MetroXRAINE)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) now write with a fluency and persuasiveness that can subtly steer users' choices. When their outputs lack clear and comprehensible explanations, this persuasive power risks undermining human decision-making capacity, raising serious ethical concerns. Current explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) techniques focus primarily on technical transparency for epistemic purposes (how a model works); they are rarely intended to reveal to the user the kind of influence they are subject to. Drawing on the Indifference View of manipulation, we advance a preliminary framework that reconceives explainability as both an epistemic and an ethical imperative. The core idea is based on explanatory metadata: layered annotations that accompany model outputs with four complementary types of explanation-informative, justificatory, causal, and precautionary-which give models the ability to detail the reasons underlying the influence they exert. Doing so shifts the XAI goal from mere transparency to responsible influence. It positions explanations as a safeguard against the manipulative behavior of generative AI systems, laying the groundwork for future methods that measure, audit, and actively constrain ethically problematic influence.
