title: SemAlignRec: A Large Language Model-Driven Cross-Modal Collaborative–Semantic Recommendation Framework
authors: Zongyang Wang, Jun Fan, Qian Gao, Zhixue Zhang, Guohui Ding
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Recommender systems are increasingly vital in e-commerce and social media, yet traditional collaborative filtering and deep learning methods still face challenges in fine-grained interest modeling and data sparsity. Large language models (LLMs), with strong semantic understanding and reasoning capabilities, excel in cold-start and long-tail scenarios. However, the modality gap between low-dimensional collaborative signals and LLMs’ contextual embeddings leads to fusion difficulties and semantic distortion. To address this, we propose SemAlignRec, a unified recommendation framework that enhances fusion through a model-agnostic collaborative–semantic alignment mechanism. Specifically: 1) deep semantic encoding and graph structural enhancement: leveraging LLMs to encode user and item textual attributes into high-quality semantic embeddings, which are further refined by a multilayer deep semantic encoder; a graph enhancement module incorporating residual connections, node attention, and graph perturbations strengthens collaborative embeddings and facilitates their fusion with semantic embeddings; and 2) transmodal fusion and self-supervised optimization: integrating multihead attention, gated fusion, and contrastive self-supervision to achieve precise fusion of collaborative and semantic embeddings. Experiments on multiple datasets show that SemAlignRec delivers substantial performance gains, achieving an overall average improvement of about 6.6% over the compared baselines. In particular, compared with the latest baseline DALR, SemAlignRec obtains an average gain of approximately 9.8% on key metrics for the Amazon and Yelp datasets, demonstrating its strong practical potential.

title: Better Naturalness Evaluation of TTS Systems
authors: Sajad Shirali-Shahreza, Gerald Penn
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Signal Processing
abstract: One of the main goals of Text-To-Speech systems is to generate natural speech. Therefore, a major evaluation criterion of TTS outputs is their naturalness, usually measured through a Mean Opinion Score (MOS). Naturalness is not a well-defined property, however. This paper decomposes naturalness into eight specific dimensions, based on how judges define the term. We then evaluate the outputs of the systems submitted to the Blizzard 2025 Challenge based on these new dimensions and compare the results with alternative evaluations of naturalness. This includes recent subjective human evaluations that were performed by the 2025 Blizzard Challenge organizers, as well as various automatic MOS methods. Based on this analysis, we propose to use five dimensions in place of a single, primitive notion of naturalness: Clarity, Fluency, Human-vs-Computer, Pronunciation, and Understandability. We propose that these would serve as the basis of a better evaluation framework for advanced TTS systems.

title: Design of Microstrip Patch Antenna with Various Soft Computing Techniques for 5G Applications
authors: Neerati Ankitha, Mudapalli Pavankumar, Thotakuri Manish, T Jagannadha Swamy
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: Antenna is one of the important and front-end devices to every communication equipment for further processing of the signal. The existing antenna designs are not properly suitable for adaptive techniques. To enhance the antenna operating frequency for wide range of applications, optimal antenna designs are essential. So, the authors of this paper proposed antenna design with novel designs with the help of soft computing techniques and consider the parameter and data sets for the design of antennas. The proposed antenna designs and simulations results are compared with the existing designs and results shows good results in terms of return loss, gain, efficiency, directivity and bandwidth.

title: Developing Quantum-Enhanced Intelligent Systems for Ethical Cybersecurity through Quantum Machine Learning: Making Transparency, Security, and Scalability a Priority
authors: Venugopala Reddy Kasu, Bakkiyaraj Kanthimathi Malamuthu, S. Karthikeyan, Khaled Tawfiq Al-Assaf, Manish Gupta, S P Vijaya Vardan Reddy
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: The fast pace of development in cyber threats and the growing complexity of digital infrastructures require the creation of robust and new solutions. Quantum computing together with machine learning lead to the development of quantum-enhanced intelligent systems, which holds exceptional promise in overcoming the limitations of contemporary cybersecurity paradigms. This research investigates the prospects of Quantum Machine Learning (QML) to improve cybersecurity, exploiting quantum computing’s capability of handling significantly larger datasets at a considerably faster rate than classical systems. Through its examination of quantum computing paradigms, this research aims to inform the future of cybersecurity solutions and advance safeguards against quantum-enabled adversarial entities, with a focus on ethics, transparency, security, and scalability. Quantum Computing is considered as the future of decryption as the accessible state-of-the-art decryption methods can be broken in the quantum world. For example, quantum cryptographic protocols like quantum key distribution techniques (QKD) will enable theoretically unbreakable encryption and thus help in securing sensitive data. In the meantime, quantum-enhanced models for machine learning have the potential to understand complex patterns through cybersecurity data, which will lead to more accurate threat detection and decreased false positives. We also elucidate the ethical implications of quantum cybersecurity systems, addressing fairness, privacy, and transparency in algorithmic decisions. Furthermore, the study emphasizes the need to design scalable quantum algorithms to enable practical applications in large-scale cybersecurity. This study demonstrates the potential of quantum-enhanced intelligent systems in transforming cybersecurity by enabling stronger defenses against dynamic cyber threats while assuring transparency and ethical use of AI methodologies. The research also details challenges, including the current hardware limitations of quantum computers and the need for regulatory frameworks to oversee AI developed using quantum processes. Our world is facing many challenges and quantumenhanced intelligent systems might precisely be the change that can reshape the future of secure, scalable and ethical cybersecurity infrastructures by addressing them.

title: A Novel Multi-Layer Functional Brain Connectivity-Based Motor Imagery Classification Model Using EEG Sensor Data
authors: Sudip Modak, Suman Halder, Soumya Chatterjee
publish: IEEE Sensors Letters
abstract: This letter presents a novel electroencephalography (EEG) rhythm-based motor imagery (MI) classification framework employing multilayer weighted visibility graph (WVG) and deep learning. In this study, multi-channel EEG signals corresponding to different MI classes were acquired from various subjects by placing sensors on the scalp. The acquired EEG signals were initially decomposed into five frequency sub-bands (EEG rhythms), by segmenting into 2-second overlapping windows. For each rhythm, a multi-layer functional brain network (FBN) has been constructed utilizing WVG, and the resulting functional brain connectivity matrices (FBC) were mapped into RGB images, which were further classified through a lightweight custom ConvNeXt model. In this work, subject independent evaluation was performed using a leave-one-subject-out (LOSO) protocol with stratified 10-fold cross-validation. Experimental validation on two datasets- BCI Competition IV-2a and High Gamma Dataset (HGD), yielded accuracies of 90.20% and 96.1%, respectively. The analysis reveals physiological meaningful connectivity patterns such as contralateral β-band connectivity in BCI IV-2a and enhanced inter-hemispheric γ-band integration in HGD. Ablation studies and benchmark comparison confirmed that the proposed framework achieved high classification accuracy, demonstrating the efficiency and potential for robust, real-time subject-independent MI–BCI applications.

title: A Non-Fixed-Duration Turn-Based Orbital Game Algorithm Based on History-Aware and Predictive Result Reward Proximal Policy Optimization
authors: Xuyang Cao, Xin Ning, Xiaobin Lian, Tongshu Zhang, Suyi Li, Gaopeng Zhang, Zhansheng Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Orbital pursuit–evasion games have attracted increasing attention in recent years. Most existing studies focus on extremely close-range continuous maneuvering scenarios, while medium- and long-range impulsive maneuvering problems are often studied under simplified assumptions, such as synchronous decision-making and maneuver execution, or fixed information measurement delays. In practice, however, satellite maneuver execution typically lags behind decision-making due to control delays and decision validation processes, and the measurement of orbital information is also subject to non-fixed delays caused by environmental and operational factors. To account for this characteristic, this paper considers a non-fixed-duration turn-based orbital pursuit–evasion game setting, in which decision-making and maneuver execution do not occur synchronously and the execution delay is determined by the spacecraft itself. Within this setting, a History-aware and Predictive Result Reward Proximal Policy Optimization (HPRR-PPO) method and an alternating reinforcement learning training scheme are developed. By introducing a predictive result reward and a history-aware terminal reward, the proposed method provides more informative learning signals under non-fixed-duration turn-based interactions. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves better task performance and training efficiency than several baseline methods in the considered orbital pursuit–evasion scenarios.

title: Fault Tolerant Aware Optimal Resource Allocation Scheme for Load Balancing in Cloud System Based on Multi-Objective Constraints
authors: Gudivada Lokesh, P Baby Maruthi, K. K. Baseer.
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Cloud computing has developed as an effective computing system for both business organizations and cloud consumers. Cloud Service Providers (CSPs) create the data centers and computing resources with better effectiveness for stratifying the requirements of the cloud consumers. The consumers mainly concentrate on the duration of response, while the CSPs are disturbed during revenue creation. Effective and accurate resource allocation has the capacity to offer better user satisfaction and improve resource usage. Moreover, the most accurate outcome in resource allocation is attained via an active load-balancing model to balance the workload. It can also assist in preventing bottlenecks and reducing resource usage; therefore, identifying optimal scheduling techniques is still hard. To overcome these challenges, an efficient optimal resource allocation for the load balancing method is designed. In the cloud, optimal resource allocation helps to manage workloads successfully, guaranteeing that significant applications obtain the required resources. In this proposed model, the optimization of resources is done with the help of a Ring Toss Game (RTG)--based optimization algorithm. Finally, to increase the load ability, objective functions like makespan, execution time, throughput, delay, success rate, and average resource utilization are considered. The main aim of optimization is to reduce the number of active servers and to improve the scalability of the cloud system. Thus, this developed model reduces the risk of overloading by minimizing the specific resources, leading to increased system stability and reliability. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed network is investigated by employing several performance measures.

title: Smart Campus Guidance Robot
authors: T. Devakumar, A. Araventha Kannan, B J. BlessonPaul, S. Poobalan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: This paper describes an autonomous robot that serves as a guide on campus. It helps visitors explore and provides information about different departments. The robot uses a microcontroller to control DC geared motors, allowing for smooth movement through an L298N motor driver. A keypad enables the user to choose which department to visit. Once a department is selected, the robot follows a specific route to that location. While it moves, an MP3 player module, speaker, and battery deliver a brief audio summary about the chosen department. Interacting with visitors enhances their educational experience and helps them understand the university or college better. This robot design combines motor control and audio output in an affordable way. It can also be used in museums, industrial parks, large institutions, or any place where automated navigation and information delivery can enhance the user experience.

title: Reliable Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach for Resource Scheduling in Cloud Computing
authors: Ramesh Methuku, Leela Arjuna Rao Uppalapati, Subrahmanyeswar Llla
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: Cloud computing has evolved as a major processing and storage platform in current workload applications. With integration of cloud computing to different real time application such as Internet of Things, big data analysis and industry 4.0 workload, cloud computing has got engaged with large computation for data mapping to cloud resources. Optimal methods for scheduling task in reducing delay and proper resource utilization is much needed objectives in cloud computing. In recent, cloud automation has evolved as an optimal solution to resource utilization in large scale cloud computing. Advanced learning approach such as deep reinforcement learning (DRL) is used for automation of scheduling resources in large scale computing. This paper, outline a method for improving deep reinforcement learning for reliable scheduling of resource utilization in cloud computing. Proposed reliable-DRL (R-DRL) method when compared with reinforcement learning (RL) and deep reinforcement learning with long short-term memory (DRLSTM) shown decrease in request overhead, and latency metric, and an increase in processing success rate for cloud computing.

title: Impact of AI-Powered Duolingo Algorithms on Language Learning Efficiency and Engagement with Reinforcement Learning Personalization
authors: S. Vijayalakshmi, M. Prakash, R Subhasree
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: Adaptive algorithms are coming to language learning platforms, which can keep learners motivated and fasttracked. It focuses on the effects of the reinforcement learningbased personalization incorporated into the AI-based recommendation system of Duolingo. The system monitors the response time, the patterns of errors, and retention of each learner to then randomly choose vocabulary, grammar activities, and conversation exercises that are most appropriate to the changing proficiency. Based on a large multilingual interaction dataset and a high-fidelity real-time simulation world, created in Python, Tensorflow, and OpenAI Gym, the proposed framework optimizes reward signals of both accuracy and engagement at the same time. In experimental analysis, the lesson-completion rate has improved by 23%, the number of repetitive errors reduced by 19% and the number of active daily uses increased by 28% relative to static sequencing. These findings indicate that reinforcement learning can be important in boosting efficiency as well as long-term engagement. It finishes with conclusions of scalable applications in a variety of linguistic settings and defines routes of wider educational application.

title: Facial Animation through Delaunay Triangulation and Affine Transformations
authors: Sourik Poddar, Aditya Banerjee, Sagnik Ghosal, Tejas Advik, Amiya Halder
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: This paper presents a geometric approach for facial motion transfer, utilizing Delaunay triangulation and affine transformations to animate a static source image using motion extracted from a driving video. By leveraging MediaPipe’s FaceMesh for real-time detection of 478 facial landmarks, the method partitions the face into triangular regions and applies affine transformations to align these regions with the driving video’s motion. A Savitzky–Golay filter ensures temporal smoothness, mitigating jitter and enhancing visual coherence. Evaluated on the VoxCeleb dataset, the approach demonstrates superior structural fidelity, identity preservation, and temporal consistency compared to deep learning methods like First Order Motion Model (FOMM) and Thin Plate Spline Motion Model (TPSM). The method’s transparency and computational efficiency make it ideal for controlled facial animations in applications such as virtual storytelling, avatar creation, and educational visualizations.

title: Parametric Analysis of the Wavelet Scattering Transform for Water Leakage Classification and Comparison with Manual Feature Extraction Techniques
authors: David Barrientos-Torres, Erick Axel Martinez-Ríos, Rogelio Bustamante-Bello
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Water pipeline leakages create significant environmental challenges worldwide. Machine learning (ML) is widely used for leakage detection, often based on time and frequency features. However, feature selection is time-consuming and challenging for both binary (leak/no leak) and multi-class (leak type) classification. The Wavelet Scattering Transform (WST) provides translation-invariant, deformation-stable features automatically, but the effect of parameter selection on classifier performance remains underexplored. This study investigates how key WST parameters, specifically the number of wavelets per octave and the invariance scale, influence the performance of a Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifier using acceleration, pressure, and hydrophone data from a benchmarking laboratory dataset. Manual features were also extracted, selected with the minimum redundancy maximum relevance algorithm, and evaluated using SVM, Decision Tree (DT), and Random Forest classifiers. Optimizing WST parameters improved accuracy by 9.65% over prior work, reaching 99.16% with acceleration data in branched topology using 2 wavelets per octave and an invariance scale of 0.04. In contrast, manual features peaked at 82.5% with DT and 15 features. Classifier performance also varied with feature quantity, averaging 8.42% across modalities. Overall, WST-based features outperform manual extraction for leakage classification, supporting more robust data-driven leak detection systems.

title: Developing Delay Tolerant Network Protocols using Bio-Inspired Optimization Algorithms
authors: Ammar Hameed, Yedida Prasanna, Sanjay Yadav, Khusainov Ilyos Jamolidding Ugli, Kapesh Subhash Raghatate, Bakhtiyarov Sirojbek Lecturer
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: CDN (Collaborative Delay Tolerant Network) development is the core to communication in environments with complex topologies and periodic connectivity loss, and large time delays. The current research applies the bio-inspired optimization algorithms to enhance the performance of Delay Tolerant Networks. Bio-inspired algorithms of which are represented by three main methodologies such as Genetic Algorithms (GA) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) holds much promise for adaptive searching in large spaces of solution. The biological inspiration enables such algorithms to enhance routing tactics and resource sharing along with message scheduling procedures in DTNs and, therefore, ensures the provision of an increased network throughput with enhanced packet delivery ratios, together with minimized latency. The research develops novel DTN routing algorithms based on bio-inspired optimisation techniques to address issues of mobility, intermittent connection, and reduced power consumption. This research has both simulated trials and real-world DTN deployments for determining the effectiveness of new protocols and comparing their execution against existing ones to show how bio-inspired approaches increase DTN reliability and stability. This work advances towards the design of secure and efficient DTN protocols whose use in disaster recovery efforts coupled with space communications systems and remote area networks will increase its utility.

title: HAPS-enabled Downlink Coverage Enhancement in Islands and Maritime Areas
authors: Hao Lin, Mustafa A. Kishk, Mohamed-Slim Alouini
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) are poised to play a critical role in next-generation mobile communications, offering enhanced flexibility, improved line-of-sight (LoS) conditions, and overcoming the limitations of terrestrial networks (TNs). Among NTN platforms, high altitude platform stations (HAPSs) have emerged as a promising solution to provide Internet connectivity to underserved regions, including rural areas, islands, and maritime zones, where traditional infrastructure deployment is costly and challenging to deploy. In this paper, we investigate the feasibility of large-scale HAPS deployment to connect island and maritime users, considering real-world shadowing effects on part of HAPSs caused by the presence of island building clusters. We first analyze the coverage performance of onshore (island) and offshore (remote sea) users, in which the channels between HAPSs and the user follow the shadowed Rician distributions and Rician distributions, respectively. Next, we introduce an evaluation method for nearshore users in a hybrid channel environment with HAPSs, and propose approximations that can reduce computational complexity. Based on the simulation results, we discuss how the distance from the island boundary (i.e. the relative remoteness of maritime users) affects coverage performance under different HAPS densities. We also emphasize the importance of choosing a balanced HAPS density or an advanced HAPS deployment scheme.

title: A Study on Stabilizer Rényi Entropy Estimation Using Machine Learning
authors: Vincenzo Lipardi, Domenica Dibenedetto, Georgios Stamoulis, Mark H.M. Winands
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: Nonstabilizerness is a fundamental resource for quantum advantage, as it quantifies the extent to which a quantum state diverges from those states that can be efficiently simulated on a classical computer, the stabilizer states. The stabilizer Rényi entropy (SRE) is one of the most investigated measures of nonstabilizerness because of its computational properties and suitability for experimental measurements on quantum processors. Because computing the SRE for arbitrary quantum states is a computationally hard problem, we propose a supervised machine-learning approach to estimate it. In this work, we frame SRE estimation as a regression task and train a Random Forest Regressor and a Support Vector Regressor (SVR) on a comprehensive dataset, including both unstructured random quantum circuits and structured circuits derived from the physics-motivated one-dimensional transverse Ising model (TIM). We compare the machine-learning models using two different quantum circuit representations: one based on classical shadows and the other on circuit-level features. Furthermore, we assess the generalization capabilities of the models on out-of-distribution instances. Experimental results show that an SVR trained on circuit-level features achieves the best overall performance. On the random circuits dataset, our approach converges to accurate SRE estimations, but struggles to generalize out of distribution. In contrast, it generalizes well on the structured TIM dataset, even to deeper and larger circuits. In line with previous work, our experiments suggest that machine learning offers a viable path for efficient nonstabilizerness estimation.

title: Efficient Pointer Analysis via Def-Use Graph Pruning
authors: Jiaqi He, Karim Ali
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Precise pointer information is essential for dataflow analysis. While flow-sensitive pointer analysis yields highly precise results, it introduces more computations. To provide a better trade-off between precision and performance, prior work has developed LEVPA, a pointer analysis that processes pointers according to their pointer level, generally accelerating the analysis. However, LevPA still performs redundant computations for intermediate variables that are generated during Static Single Assignment (SSA) transformation. For real-world programs, we have observed that those variables may constitute up to 87 % of all analyzed variables. These unnecessary computations cause LEVPA to timeout for large programs. To address these limitations, we present Level-based Intermediate variable Skipping Pointer Analysis (LisPA), an enhancement of LevPA that operates on a def-use graph without computing points-to set of intermediate variables introduced during SSA transformation. The key insight behind LISPA is that intermediate variables do not introduce new pointers into the analysis, because they always alias with variables in the original program. Therefore, there is no need to compute their points-to set in a fixed-point computation. Across 27 real-world C/C++ programs, we show that LISPA is on average <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.14 \times$</tex> faster than LevPA, while using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.38 \times$</tex> less memory.

title: An ML and LLM Method for Forecasting Air Quality and Making Preventive Suggestions: An Analysis of a Densely Congested Area
authors: S Naga MallikRaj, Sabuz Ahmed, Surisetty Navya Sri, Silla Navya, Veedhi Navya Tejaswini, Sahu Preethi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: Forecasting air quality is a crucial technique for monitoring pollution levels and safeguarding human health, particularly in densely populated urban areas. This study deals with a sophisticated Air Quality index (AQI) predicting system specifically designed for metropolitan cities like Delhi, Dhaka, Mumbai, Kolkata and Chennai. The proposed model combines heterogeneous data sources such as pollutant levels, meteorological data, and population density through ML algorithms like Random Forest. One of the important innovations of this work is the integration of NLP methods to gather and analyze unstructured data from news sources, online media, and policy briefs, hence augmenting the system's predictive capacity. With the integration of structured environmental information with text-based information, the system not only accurately predicts AQI but also delivers actionable recommendations and preventive solutions to counteract air pollution risks. The model has 93 % accuracy, precision, and F 1 score, higher than conventional forecasting methods. Such outcomes demonstrate the efficacy and effectiveness of the adopted framework in providing data-driven decisions for individuals and policymakers, creating smarter and healthier cities.

title: Trust-Aware Blockchain Reinforcement Learning for Secure Task Offloading in Edge-Assisted IoV
authors: Wenjing Yin, Xiao He, Zhiyuan Zhao, Hengxiao Li, Cong Liu
publish: IEEE Communications Standards Magazine
abstract: The Internet of Vehicles (IoV) is rapidly expanding, and vehicles continuously generate complex and interdependent computation tasks, which contain precedence constraints that complicate their real-time offloading. These tasks must be processed in real time and with strong security guarantees, which introduces significant challenges in both computation efficiency and trust management. To address these challenges, we investigate secure online offloading of large-scale dependent tasks in distributed edge-assisted IoV environments and develops a blockchain-assisted multi-level feedback queue framework that ensures transparent task registration, tamper-proof execution logs, and fairness among vehicular nodes. To optimize the offloading strategy under dynamic and uncertain system states, the problem is formulated as a multi-stage mixed-integer nonlinear program, and a trust-aware blockchain reinforcement learning algorithm (TaBRL) is developed. The blockchain consensus layer provides verifiable feedback to guide adaptive learning and strengthen decision reliability. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed framework achieves superior task throughput, queue stability, and defense robustness, effectively ensuring secure, trustworthy, and efficient coordination in edge-assisted IoV environments.

title: AI-Driven Circuit Debugging: Leveraging Large Language Models for Automated Fault Detection and Diagnosis
authors: Sowmya MN
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: Traditional circuit debugging methods are often inefficient, time-consuming, and prone to human error, making them unsuitable for handling complex electronic systems. This research introduces an AI-driven debugging tool that leverages Large Language Models (LLMs), machine learning, and object detection technologies to enhance circuit analysis, fault detection, and solution recommendations. The proposed system features a web-based interface that enables users to upload circuit images for automated diagnostics and allows interactive troubleshooting through natural language queries. By ensuring data privacy, system reliability, and high-quality responses, this tool aims to improve usability across various circuit complexities. The integration of AI in circuit debugging is expected to reduce downtime, enhance productivity, and support engineers in maintaining intricate electronic systems. Experimental validation shows reliable fault detection and debugging performance.

title: Optimizing Performance on ARM-Based Platforms: A Hybrid Approach using OpenMP and ARM NEON
authors: I Putu Ananta Yogiswara, I Made Astawa, Yoga Prastiya Wibawa, Marlin Ramadhan Baidillah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: Embedded devices such as the Raspberry Pi frequently face constraints regarding their computing capabilities, which poses a challenge for executing compute-intensive applications. This research intends to assess the efficacy of ARM NEON and OpenMP in enhancing computation on embedded devices through case studies on matrix multiplication. The research methodology is structured into multiple phases, including experiment design, algorithm execution, testing, data collection, and analysis. Four variations were evaluated: matrix multiplication without optimization, matrix multiplication utilizing ARM NEON, matrix multiplication using OpenMP, and the combination of ARM NEON with OpenMP. The testing was performed on a Raspberry Pi 4, measuring the average execution time for each variation. The findings reveal that employing ARM NEON achieves a speed increase of $\mathbf{1. 6 3}$ times, OpenMP provides a speed enhancement of 2.2 times, while the synergy of ARM NEON and OpenMP reaches an average speed increase of 5.37 times. These findings suggest that the integration of both optimization methods can substantially boost the computing performance of embedded devices. Consequently, this study adds to the knowledge of more efficient optimization strategies for real-time computing applications on embedded systems, which could facilitate the deployment of more responsive and effective compute-intensive applications.

title: Design and Implementation of Six-Dimensional Force Sensor Signal Acquisition System
authors: Xiliang Chen, Zihan Ding, Yiwen Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: To address the issue of noise suppression after signal amplification in the signal acquisition system of a six-dimensional force sensor, this paper proposes a hardware circuit-based solution. In the circuit design, the bridge amplification circuit and filter circuit are combined based on the output characteristics of the half-bridge circuit. The millivolt-level output voltage of the Wheatstone bridge is amplified to the volt level, and a second-order RC filter is employed to effectively suppress high-frequency noise and ensure signal integrity. In the design of the amplification circuit, different amplification factors are applied to the three-dimensional force channel and the three-dimensional torque channel, and signal enhancement is achieved through a two-stage amplification scheme. In the design of the analog-to-digital conversion module, the MAX11254 chip is selected, which features an 8x gain and a pre-amplification circuit to form a two-stage amplification structure, thereby realizing high-precision analog-to-digital conversion. Finally, the STM32F103 series microprocessor is used as the main control processing module to implement data acquisition and transmission functions. This design not only ensures measurement accuracy but also significantly reduces system costs and power consumption, providing reliable technical support for the practical application of the six-dimensional force sensor.

title: A Spiking Neural Network-Quantum Model for Spatiotemporal Data Analysis: An Experimental Framework
authors: Ravi Kumar Jha, Nikola Kasabov, Saugat Bhattacharyya, Damien Coyle, Girijesh Prasad
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Artificial Intelligence (QAI)
abstract: The study introduces a novel computational framework combining neuro-inspired information through spiking neural networks (SNNs) and quantum information using quantum kernels to develop quantum machine learning models. The framework uses a 3D brain-inspired SNN model to learn spatiotemporal EEG signals through their dynamic interaction. Spike frequency state vectors are extracted from a 3D SNN and a quantum kernel classifier is used to classify them into predefined classes. The study also proposes a new embedding function to enhance the performance of the quantum kernel classifier. The performance of the model is evaluated using statistical metrics and cross-validation techniques, demonstrating its superior efficacy on multiple state-of-the-art embedding functions and classical baseline classifiers. The results indicate a clear advantage of having an integrated framework of an SNN and a quantum kernel, which overcomes the limitations of existing classifiers in dealing with spatiotemporal data and enhances the performance of existing SNNs by improving the classification of their complex internal states.

title: SynRAG: A Large Language Model Framework for Executable Query Generation in Heterogeneous SIEM Systems
authors: Md Hasan Saju, Austin Page, Akramul Azim, Jeff Gardiner, Farzaneh Abazari, Frank Eargle
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Collaborative Advances in Software and COmputiNg (CASCON)
abstract: Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) systems are essential for large enterprises to monitor their IT infrastructure by ingesting and analyzing millions of logs and events daily. Security Operations Center (SOC) analysts are tasked with monitoring and analyzing this vast data to identify potential threats and take preventive actions to protect enterprise assets. However, the diversity among SIEM platforms, such as Palo Alto Networks Qradar, Google SecOps, Splunk, Microsoft Sentinel and the Elastic Stack, poses significant challenges. As these systems differ in attributes, architecture, and query languages, making it difficult for analysts to effectively monitor multiple platforms without undergoing extensive training or forcing enterprises to expand their workforce. To address this issue, we introduce SynRAG, a unified framework that automatically generates threat detection or incident investigation queries for multiple SIEM platforms from a platform-agnostic specification. SynRAG can generate platformspecific queries from a single high-level specification written by analysts. Without SynRAG, analysts would need to manually write separate queries for each SIEM platform, since query languages vary significantly across systems. This framework enables seamless threat detection and incident investigation across heterogeneous SIEM environments, reducing the need for specialized training and manual query translation. We evaluate SynRAG against state-of-the-art language models, including GPT, Llama, DeepSeek, Gemma, and Claude, using Qradar and SecOps as representative SIEM systems. Our results demonstrate that SynRAG generates significantly better queries for crossSIEM threat detection and incident investigation compared to the state-of-the-art base models.

authors: Chunli Yu, Shayan Noei, Haoxiang Zhang, Ying Zou

title: Reconfigurable Octagon-Shaped Microstrip Patch Antenna with Enhanced Gain Using RF MEMS Switches at 5 GHz
authors: Murali Narayanan R, Anitha G, G Ramkumar
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: This study presents design and analysis of compact octagonal microstrip patch antenna utilizing an inset feeding technique for 5G applications. The antenna features an octagon-shaped radiating patch with a radius of 16.54 mm, and the overall antenna dimensions are 35.8 mm x 25.405 mm. The feed line, designed for efficient power delivery, measures 8.29 mm in length and 0.72 mm in width. Through full-wave electromagnetic simulation, the antenna achieves a return loss of -68.44 dB, indicating excellent impedance matching and minimal signal reflection. The gain is recorded at 7.1 dBi, making the design suitable for high-frequency applications requiring directional radiation and consistent performance. The input impedance is calculated as 50.02 ohms, ensuring efficient energy transfer between the feed and the radiating element. Due to its high efficiency, compact structure, and stable radiation characteristics, the proposed antenna is well-suited for various 5G applications including wireless networks, industrial automation systems, radar technologies, point-to-point communication links, and selected medical imaging equipment operating within the 5 GHz frequency band.

title: AI-Powered Diabetes Prediction: A Comprehensive Machine Learning Strategy for Early Diagnosis
authors: Srija Avula, R Renugadevi, Siva Phanindra Kumar Gumma, Lahari Kommuri, Maddula Dhanusri, Shaik Nissar Ahamad
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Millions of individuals worldwide suffer from diabetes, a chronic metabolic disease that presents serious health and financial difficulties. In order to manage diabetes and avoid its consequences, early diagnosis and prediction might be extremely important. This study uses clinical data from a publicly accessible dataset to provide a machine learning-based method for diabetes prediction. To create prediction models, a variety of machine learning (ML) methods are used, such as Logistic Regression (LR), XGBoost classifier, and Gradient Boosting classifier (GBC). Metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and support are used to assess these models’ performance. The suggested approach shows how ML methods may accurately forecast a person’s risk of developing diabetes, giving patients and medical professionals a useful tool to help them make decisions. The results highlight the potential of integrating data-driven approaches in preventive healthcare management.

title: YAP+: Pad-Layout-Aware Yield Modeling and Simulation for Hybrid Bonding
authors: Zhichao Chen, Puneet Gupta
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) integration continues to advance Moore’s Law by facilitating dense interconnects and enabling multi-tier system architectures. Among the various integration approaches, Cu-Cu hybrid bonding has emerged as a leading solution for achieving high interconnect density in chiplet integration. In this work, we present YAP+, a yield modeling framework specifically tailored for wafer-to-wafer (W2W) and die-to- wafer (D2W) hybrid bonding processes. YAP+ incorporates a comprehensive set of yield-impacting failure mechanisms, including overlay misalignment, particle defects, Cu recess variations, surface roughness, and Cu pad density. Furthermore, YAP+ supports pad layout-aware yield analysis, considering critical, redundant, and dummy pads across arbitrary 2D physical layout patterns. To support practical evaluation, we developed an opensource yield simulator, demonstrating that our near-analytical model matches simulation accuracy while achieving over 1,000x speedup in runtime. This performance makes YAP+ a valuable tool for co-optimizing packaging technologies, assembly design rules, and system-level design strategies. Beyond W2W-D2W comparisons, we leverage YAP+ to investigate the impact of pad layout patterns, bonding pitch, and pad ratios across different pad types, and explore the benefits of strategically placing redundant pad replicas.

title: Voice Conversion: Transformation Through Deep Learning
authors: MohanKumar S, Kanitha S A, Vasuki P
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Voice conversion is a technique that converts a speaker's voice into another while retaining the original content. The main goal of this research is to enhance the quality of voice conversion system that well exhibits speaker identity while ensuring naturalness and intelligibility. To accomplish this, we introduce a three-stage pipeline using a deep learning-based approach. The Encoder draws speaker-specific features from the input speech, the Synthesizer produces mel spectrograms that maintain the linguistic and acoustic features of the target speaker, and the Vocoder synthesizes the final waveform to generate natural-sounding speech. The method is trained on varied speech datasets to achieve robustness over various speakers. Experimental outcomes confirm that the system efficiently alters speaker identity without losing speech clarity and prosody, resulting in high-fidelity voice conversions. The results highlight the capabilities of deep learning in progressing voice transformation technology. Future studies will aim at optimizing real-time performance, enhancing prosody conservation, and furthering speaker similarity, paving the way for use in personalized voice assistants, speech synthesis, and assistive technology.

title: Machine Learning-Based Channel Prediction and Optimization in 6G Massive MIMO Systems
authors: U Archana, M. Suresh, M Jayasankar, S. Varalakshmi, M. Subalatha, S. Kumaran
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Accurate and adaptive channel prediction is vital for achieving high reliability and throughput in 6G massive MIMO networks. Traditional pilot-based estimation and static DL models suffers from channel aging, mobility and high pilot overhead, resulting in the degradation of spectral efficiency (SE) as well as temporal generalization. To overcome such limitations, a hybrid CNN-LSTM-Attention model combined with an online pilot and power optimization algorithm is proposed. The proposed system can effectively learn spatial-temporal channel dynamics, and reduce the number of redundant pilots while updating real-time variations by mean of an incremental retraining phase. Experimental result indicates that, compared with the existing baseline system, pilot overhead can be reduced by $40 \%$ without performance degradation under a desired block error rate and up to $\mathbf{1. 5}-\mathbf{2. 0}$ bits/s/Hz gains of spectral efficiency measured are achievable while at least achieving $30 \%$ reduction in normalized mean-square error. The simulation results highlight the robustness of the model under high mobility and different SNR, thus have verified its potential to be used as scalable low-latency 6G base station.

title: Optivize - Reliable and Automated University Timetabling using Hybrid AI
authors: P Mathivanan, S Vikram, Mano Nikila R, S Kasthuri
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Creating an academic schedule in a university is a hard and complicated task, and as the number of courses, ways of teaching those courses, and limitations on resources increases, the process will get harder. This paper presents an automated way to create academic schedules, using a combination of the latest optimization techniques and a scalable web-based design to produce consistent schedules without any conflicts. The method of scheduling used in this work is called “blended” since it involves the use of both binary decision-making methods (odds/evens) represented by a mathematical model and evolutionary search techniques using a Constraint Solving API that allow for the use of a variety of methods to determine the best schedule given specific academic requirements, such as instructor availability, classroom capacity, program arrangement, and student needs. The architecture for this scheduling system includes Angular as a means of allowing for an interactive experience for users, while the Spring Boot technology enables the rapid generation of schedules that support both on-campus and hybrid format instructional delivery. Real data from a university’s departments demonstrated that the system significantly decreases schedule conflicts, provides better use of classroom and staff time, and provides schedules that are more closely aligned with the university’s overall priorities than schedules produced with current scheduling methods. Thus, the results of this project indicate that universities may benefit from using this type of scheduling framework as they seek to modernize their scheduling practices by integrating advanced decision-making support into academic planning processes.

title: MR-CA-AST: A Multi-Resolution ChannelAttention Audio Spectrogram Transformer for Robust Drone Acoustic Detection
authors: G Arjun Kumar, Ashwani Kumar Dubey, Balaji Srinivasan, Angela Amphawan, Gaurav Kumar Bharti
publish: 2025 Eighth International Conference on Image Information Processing (ICIIP)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of unmanned aerial vehicles has created new challenges in surveillance, defence, and air-traffic safety. Conventional radar or vision-based systems fall short under poor lighting, occlusion, or low radar cross-section, hence motivating the need for acoustic detection. Drone rotors generate unique harmonic and broadband signatures that can be captured through microphones, but these signals are easily masked by ambient environmental noise. We propose MR-CA-AST, a Multi-Resolution Channel-Attention Audio Spectrogram Transformer that effectively combines local convolutional denoising and global Transformer-based temporal modelling. The model employs two convolutional branches running on high and low-resolution Melspectrograms, further empowered by a channel-attention mechanism suppressing irrelevant frequency bands. The combined embeddings are then tokenised using patch embedding and processed by a Transformer encoder to learn from long-range temporal correlations. Experimental results on the Drone Audio Detection Samples dataset (DADS) with 180,320 samples show that the proposed architecture attained a test accuracy of 99.57%, F1-score of 0.995, and ROC-AUC of 0.998, outperforming existing CNN, CRNN, and AST baselines. This method exhibits strong robustness under conditions with heterogeneous noise and forms a promising basis for further integration with distributed acoustic sensing systems in covert drone tracking.

title: Design Analysis of a MEMS based Micro-sized Gripper for Micro-Bio-assembly Applications
authors: S Praveen Kumar, J Sakthi Swarrup, G DineshRam, D Lingaraja, S Ramya
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Smart Structures and Systems (ICSSS)
abstract: Micro Electro Mechanical Systems (MEMS) are miniature devices that integrate electrical and mechanical components, typically operating at the micrometer scale. Due to their compact size and lightweight nature, MEMS are particularly advantageous for applications in the medical field, supporting system miniaturization. One significant application is the microgripper, a MEMS device used for manipulating, holding, and transferring microparticles. Specialized microgrippers are designed to address the challenges of handling micro-optical and micro-electrical components at the nano or micrometer level. During the gripping process, reactive forces are generated between the microgripper arms and the object being held. For objects with curved or rounded surfaces, these response forces act perpendicularly. The behavior of the object during the gripping motion is typically influenced by these forces. Various microgripper designs have been developed for micro-assembly applications using polypropylene material and a mechanical actuator. Under an applied pressure of 5000 $\boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{P a}$, the gripper structures exhibit displacements of $\mathbf{1 6 6. 5 6 ~} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{m}$, $130.09 \mu \mathrm{~m}$, and $31.598 \mu \mathrm{~m}$. The design and analysis of the microgrippers were conducted using COMSOL Multiphysics software.

title: Impact of Energy Harvesting on Low-Power MIMO Communication over Rayleigh Fading Channels with Imperfect Channel Estimation
authors: Bhargabjyoti Saikia, Christina Sabir Rahman, Jhelum Kaushik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Radar, Antenna, Microwave, Electronics, and Telecommunications (ICRAMET)
abstract: This paper investigates the performance of low-power Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) communication systems employing Radio Frequency Energy Harvesting (RFEH) over Rayleigh fading channels under Imperfect Channel Estimation (ICE). A closed-form expression for the Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) probability density function (PDF) is derived by incorporating the EH power splitting ratio ($\beta$) and the channel estimation error parameter (B). Using this formulation, average bit error rate (ABER) is analytically evaluated for both coherent and non-coherent modulation schemes. In addition, channel capacity is analyzed as a key performance metric to assess spectral efficiency. The results show that increasing the EH power splitting factor ($\beta$) significantly improves system performance by reducing ABER and enhancing channel capacity, even in the presence of estimation errors. However, the interaction between modulation type and ICE introduces trade-offs that critically impact system performance, particularly in low-power environments such as Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs). The proposed analysis provides valuable insights for optimizing EH-based MIMO systems operating under practical constraints of limited energy and imperfect Channel Side Information(CSI).

title: XGBoost-Driven Demand Forecasting for Electric Vehicles Using Blockchain Network
authors: B.V.V.L.Kala Bharathi, Anil Kumar Muthevi
publish: 2025 Second International Conference on Networks and Soft Computing (ICNSoC)
abstract: The increasing adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) poses significant challenges to energy demand forecasting. To address this, we propose a novel approach that integrates blockchain-based federated learning with XGBoost to enhance predictive power. Our framework enables secure, decentralized collaboration among multiple data sources, while XGBoost improves forecasting accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods like Random Forest, Lasso, and Decision Tree, providing more accurate energy demand forecasts for EVs. This research contributes to the development of more efficient energy management systems, supporting the widespread adoption of EVs.

title: A Machine Learning-Based Algorithm for Assessing Spatial Safety and Fun in Rural Kindergarten Toilet
authors: Lai Bing
publish: 2025 IEEE 3rd International Conference on Control, Electronics and Computer Technology (ICCECT)
abstract: This paper proposes a machine learning-based assessment algorithm for evaluating safety and interest aspects of toilet spaces in rural kindergartens. The algorithm employs a multi-modal feature fusion approach that combines visual features, environmental sensor data, and spatial attributes through an attention-based mechanism. We designed a two-branch neural network architecture incorporating modified ResNet-50 for visual feature extraction and LSTM networks for processing temporal environmental data. The assessment model utilizes an adaptive weighting mechanism to balance different feature types and adjust to varying environmental conditions. To validate our approach, we collected data from 15 rural kindergartens over six months, including 3,000 spatial images and 180,000 environmental sensor readings. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves 94.2% accuracy in space assessment, outperforming traditional approaches by 5.9-10.7%. The system maintains stable performance across different lighting conditions and occupancy levels, with only a 2.3% accuracy drop under challenging conditions. Real-world testing confirms the system's effectiveness in providing consistent and reliable assessments while maintaining real-time processing capabilities.

title: Automating High-Dimensional Musculoskeletal Control: An Anatomical Adaptation Pipeline for Motion Imitation
authors: ChunHui Wen, Xin Sun, Shuai Guo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Cyber-Physical Social Intelligence (CPSI)
abstract: Developing controllers for physiologically accurate musculoskeletal models is a significant challenge due to the morphological mismatch between generic motion data and specific models. This paper proposes a data-driven pipeline to generate high-fidelity reference motions for a target musculoskeletal model. The proposed pipeline optimizes an anatomical skeleton's shape to match the target model, significantly reducing the initial root-aligned Mean Per-Joint Position Error (MPJPE) by 67% (from 45.90 mm to 15.19 mm). This shape-aligned skeleton is then utilized to retarget motion data, generating tailored reference motions via inverse kinematics. Subsequently, this processed data is used to train control policies for a complex lower-body model with 86 muscle actuators. On walking and sit-to-stand tasks, the trained policies achieve low tracking errors, with the best performance reaching a global MPJPE of 28.27 mm and 26.82 mm, respectively. A comparative analysis of Proximal Policy Optimization and Soft Actor-Critic demonstrates that the proposed framework enables stable and accurate motion imitation in this high-dimensional control context.

title: Exploring Emotion Psychology in AI: Common Perspectives and Their Application in Research and Development to Enhance Empathetic Responses in Artificial Intelligence Systems
authors: Abhishek Sharma, Ashish Avasthi, Vijaya Lakshmi Vangipuram, Pavithra G., Shashidhar V., T.C. Manjunath
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Information Systems and Computer Networks (ISCON)
abstract: Human emotion is at the heart of all that makes a person human. It forms our choices, fuels our creativity, and, in the ultimate respect, defines our relationships. Human emotions shape how one would act, judge, or even communicate. With Emotion AI, an alleged subset of artificial intelligence said to make it possible for it to replicate the human ability of detecting, understanding, and then reproducing emotions, machines can truly have a more meaningful and organic form of chat. The paper tackles the implementation of psychological theories of emotion in AI research and development, especially within the main frameworks of the basic emotions of Paul Ekman, Plutchik's wheel of emotions, and dimensional models such as valence-arousal. Such models were the pillars of developing intelligence systems into recognizing emotions from faces, pitch of voice, and analyzing text. What if these machines learned emotions? And we get into it in this paper. This paper reveals how emotion theories in psychology-from Ekman's six basic emotions to Plutchik's colorful wheel-are redoing the future of AI. From the interpretation of delight in a smile to empathizing through conversation, these models are the heart and soul of emotionally intelligent AI systems. Our journey discusses their real-world impact, the challenges we face, and the ethical lines we have to carefully tread.

title: Deployment of Multihead Attention-Based Convolutional ViT for Visual Defect Detection in Industrial Automation
authors: Durgaprasanna Nagireddi, G. Rosline Nesa Kumari
publish: 2025 IEEE 2nd International Conference on Information Technology, Electronics and Intelligent Communication Systems (ICITEICS)
abstract: Detecting and categorizing defects should be addressed as distinct issues within the domain of artificial vision. With the increasing demand for surface quality assurance in industrial automation, automated defect detection using computer vision has gained significant interest. Recent advances in visual inspection techniques for structural surfaces that enabled their use in efficient and adaptable manufacturing environments. Nevertheless, formulating a global inspection framework based on manually extracted features remains a considerable challenge, especially for both uniform and irregularly textured surfaces. To overcome such existing issues, a novel attention-based model is introduced for detecting visual defects in industrial automation. Primarily, the input images are gathered from the benchmark datasets. Consequently, the collected images are fed as input to the Multihead Attention-based Convolutional Vision Transformer (MA-ConvViT) for classifying the visual defects. At last, the performance of the system is examined using different evaluation metrics and compared with other baseline methodologies. Therefore, the better results demonstrate that the proposed work has the potential to effectively classify the visual defects.
